title: The Prado Finds Out What It Has and Where
description: When Alfonso Perez Sanchez joined the Prado Museum in 1960, the young art historian was given the mundane title of head of the storeroom and the testing job of preparing an inventory of the institution's vast collection.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: House Panel Votes to Cut Off Bomber
description: In a blow to the Bush Administration, the House Armed Services Committee voted today to end production of the Stealth bomber and cut nearly $2 billion from the Pentagon's proposal for the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program.

title: The Sound of Two Houses Clapping
description: The crackling roar in Congress this week comes from yet another avalanche as billions more dollars go plunging into the savings and loan crevasse. But this could also be the week in which Congress sends a far more welcome reverberation. The Senate and House are each poised to vote on legislation that would deter such monumental scandals by breaking the connection between special interests and special treatment.

title: Bengal Goes to Jail
description: A Cincinnati Bengals cornerback, Lewis Billups, was sentenced in Cincinnati yesterday to serve 30 days in jail for pointing a gun at two undercover police officers.

title: Media Business;   Editor Leaving Philadelphia Inquirer
description: The executive editor and president of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Eugene L. Roberts Jr., announced unexpectedly yesterday that he would retire on Sept. 1.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't look out the window.

title: Company News;   Motorola to Ship Wristwatch Pager
description: Motorola Inc. began taking orders for a combination wristwatch and beeper and said it would begin shipping the devices in eight to 10 days. The two-ounce black plastic watch, which can be used in all of the nation's metropolitan areas, stores the telephone number and time of the six most recent calls it receives and has a suggested retail price of $300, the Schaumburg, Ill., company said.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Anti-Government Protesters Rally in a Bucharest Square
description: Scores of anti-Government demonstrators rallied tonight in University Square in the capital's center, the site of a 53-day demonstration that was violently broken up by the police in mid-June.

title: George E. Echols, Oldest U.S. Veteran, 105
description: George E. Echols, who fought in France in World War I and was the nation's oldest known war veteran, died last Thursday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center, the Department of Veterans Affairs reported. He was 105 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Golf Club Admits Blacks

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Helps Underwrite Guatemala Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Reorganizing the Yankees;   Yankees Owners Not of One Mind
description: The Yankees' 18 limited partners, an eclectic group that George Steinbrenner culled from business associates, friends and the fan population, appear to be far from united in seeing his 33-year-old son follow as the Yankees' general partner.

title: Earnings Drop 47% At Chrysler <
description: The Chrysler Corporation today reported a 47 percent decline in second-quarter profits, reflecting lower vehicle shipments and the increased cost of offering bigger incentives to car and truck buyers.

title: Abondoned-Car Owners in New York Now Face Heavy Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing Insurance Change Voted
description: Despite the threat of a veto from President Bush, the House overwhelmingly voted today for changes in the troubled Federal Housing Administration insurance program, which has been losing $4 billion a year because of bad loans.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Fannie Mae in Pricing Of Mortgage Securities
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, priced a total of $1.25 billion in new securities yesterday.

title: Bolton Sullivan, Executive, 94
description: Bolton Sullivan, the founder and retired president of the Skil Corporation of Chicago, died Thursday at his home in Lake Forest, Ill. He was 94 years old.

title: Green Is the Sauce For Late Summer
description: A GREEN sauce whets my appetite better than a sauce of a different color. White sauce sounds bland, brown sauce might be heavy, red sauce lacks delicacy and orange sauce is often too sweet.

title: Catholic Schools Turn to Ads to Fill Classrooms
description: Using market research to advertise their brand of ethically oriented education, Roman Catholic elementary and secondary schools have been waging a secular war against shrinking enrollment nationwide.

title: Boxing: Notebook;   Handshake With King Is Binding for Trump
description: Donald Trump has had a hard time lately keeping his financial empire afloat, but he has caught a few breaks in a boxing operation that for a while also appeared to be in trouble.

title: Cuomo Vetoes Bill to Keep Children Out of Foster Care
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today rejected a bill aimed at keeping children out of foster care by providing housing subsidies to families without shelter. It was one of the few major bills that Mr. Cuomo had rejected in a year when he faces re-election.

title: Jill Esmond Dies at 82; Stage and Film Actress
description: Jill Esmond, a film and stage actress who was the first wife of Laurence Olivier, died on Saturday at her home in Wimbledon. She was 82 years old. No cause of death was given. Ms. Esmond, who appeared in Hollywood films including ''The White Cliffs of Dover'' and ''Random Harvest,'' studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London. She made her London stage debut in December 1922 as Nibs in ''Peter Pan.''

title: Echoes of Wars Fade As Beach Is Called Safe
description: Not far from where Andy Chepaitis presided today atop his lifeguard chair, trench mortar shells pounded the beach in World War I and .50-caliber machine guns raked the dunes in later wars where troops trained before going overseas.

title: Eating Well
description: IF you can't get the student to the classes, take the classes to the student. Some such philosophy was in the works when the Institute for Preventive Medicine at Methodist Hospital opened a satellite center on the second floor of the Rice Epicurean Market on San Felipe here in Houston.

title: Man Is Sought in Park Attack
description: The police continued their search last night for a man who attacked a young couple with a baseball bat -seriously injuring both - as they sat on a bench near Conservatory Pond in Central Park Monday night.

title: Grizzled Castro-Fighter Still Man With a Mission
description: The Cuban Government calls him a terrorist. A goodly number of Cuban exiles in Miami call him a patriot. And American officials have veered, at different times, between one view and the other.

title: Donald L. Ranard, 73, U.S. Aide Who Disclosed Seoul's Lobbying
description: Donald L. Ranard, a longtime Foreign Service official who played a key role in uncovering the role of South Korean lobbyists in Washington in the mid-1970's, died on Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Centreville, Va., and Romney, W. Va. Mr. Ranard's family said he died of leukemia.

title: Defendant In Jogger Case Takes Stand
description: Rejecting furious pleas from his fellow defense lawyers, the lawyer for one of the defendants in the Central Park jogger trial called his client to the witness stand yesterday before a jury in a Manhattan courtroom.

title: Colts Trade Chandler
description: Chris Chandler, the Indianapolis Colts' disgruntled quarterback, was traded to Tampa Bay yesterday, a week after suing the Colts for breach of contract.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8

title: Review/Film;   Emilio Estevez in Reprise of Billy the Kid Role
description: ''Kid'' is the operative word in describing the ''Young Guns'' approach to the Billy the Kid legend, since these films regard Billy as more of a gun-toting cut-up than a true desperado. As played again by Emilio Estevez in ''Young Guns II,'' Billy tends to giggle at tense moments and, during important ones, to mumble.

title: Business Technology;   Storing Summer's Solar Heat for the Winter
description: The biggest problem with solar heating systems is that the sun shines most in the summer, when the heat is not needed, and least in the winter, when it is. But a team at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst has found a storage medium that will hold July's heat for February: the ground.

title: White House Crime: Punish or Expose?
description: The U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington has set a nearly impossible standard for prosecuting high-profile cases that demands exposure as well as punishment. A divided three-judge panel has set aside Oliver North's convictions for crimes related to the Iran-contra scandal. Two judges concluded that the prosecutor failed to prove that he made his case without the aid of Mr. North's compelled, self-incriminating, nationally televised Congressional testimony.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet-Albanian Ties Restored
description: The Soviet Union and Albania have agreed to normalize relations, which were severed in 1961 during Moscow's rift with Beijing, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. The Albanians sided with China in the ideological dispute. The agreement was reached during talks in Bulgaria in June and in Tirana Monday, Tass said.

title: How Chefs View Farmed Fish
description: LEAD: WHEREVER seafood comes from, the true test of it occurs in the kitchen and at the table. With farmed fish, the verdict so far is decidedly mixed.

title: The New Dealer's Guns: More Bullets, Going Faster
description: The pistols used in the four recent killings of children are members of a new generation of large-capacity semiautomatic weapons that have become standard among drug dealers and robbers, the police said.

title: Navy Finds an Object That May Be Jet Door
description: Navy searchers using a remote-controlled deep-sea submarine have found what could be the cargo door that was torn off a United Airlines jumbo jet last year, hurling nine people to their death over the Pacific.

title: Michel Guy, Culture Official, 63
description: Michel Guy, a former Minister of Culture and director of the annual Autumn Festival in Paris, died on Monday after a long illness, associates said today. He was 63 years old.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday, headed ''The Favorite Stocks,'' misstated the performance of several stocks. BellSouth closed on Monday at $53.50 a share, up 87.5 cents; Bell Atlantic, $47.625, up $1.25; Nynex, $75, up 87.5 cents; Ameritech, $59.75, up $1.625; Pacific Telesis, $41.75, up 12.5 cents; U S West, $36.125, up 25 cents; General Motors, $47.375, unchanged; Bell Canada, $32.50, unchanged, and Sears, Roebuck, $33.875, up 12.5 cents.

title: Man's Body Found in Rubble From Blast in North Carolina
description: Investigators found a body of a man in the rubble of a gutted downtown block on Monday while looking for clues to the cause of a weekend explosion that destroyed at least eight busineses, a Federal agent said.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge and other intellectual games are excluded from the Olympics, but the organizers of the Goodwill Games in Seattle have proved more flexible. Twenty-five Soviet players are there, and will compete today and tomorrow against players from the Seattle area.

title: Election Finance Change Is Rejected
description: The Senate rejected an amendment late tonight that called for a voluntary system of public financing of Senate campaigns.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Castro Fantasy

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Declines A Stand on Abortion
description: The governing board of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided by voice vote today to remain neutral on the abortion issue but said it resented government intrusion into personal matters.

title: Company News;   New California Park Is Proposed by Disney
description: Intent on creating a second significant attraction in Southern California, home of Disneyland, the Walt Disney Company disclosed plans today for a big park and resort with an ocean theme in Long Beach, Calif., about 20 miles west of Disneyland.

title: Media Business;   Compromise Cable Vote
description: In a move toward moderate cable re-regulation, the Senate Commerce Committee yesterday approved a compromise measure that would allow the phone companies to act as a delivery system for cable programming, but would not permit them to compete in the programming itself.

title: Hiroshima Study Finds No Genetic Damage
description: A 40-year study of thousands of Japanese who survived the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki shows radiation exposure did not cause genetic damage that could lead to human mutations, a researcher said today.

title: Stealing Slang
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball;   Mets' Find Themselves In Continuing Doldrums
description: ''A little valley we're in,'' Manager Bud Harelson calls it. ''A dry spell,'' Darryl Strawberry calls it. And Mackey Sasser says: ''You can't play every month like June.''

title: ALCOHOLISM CITED IN PILOT'S DEFENSE
description: One of three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying while intoxicated had a higher tolerance for alcohol because he is an alcoholic, his lawyer said today.

title: Traditional Rivals
description: The University of Arkansas may be headed to the Southeastern Conference, but Athletic Director Frank Broyles wants to keep a few rivalries from ending.

title: Albert Rose, a Research Scientist Known for TV Tube, Dies at 80
description: Albert Rose, a research scientist whose work in converting optical images to electrical signals led to the development of the modern television picture tube, died on Thursday at the Princeton Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Charles M. Mapes, Engineer, 89
description: Charles M. Mapes, a communications consultant and retired engineer with A. T. & T., died on Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 89 years old and lived in Suffern.

title: U.S. Proposes Steps to Curb Pollution If Plans by Los Angeles Fall Short
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed far-reaching pollution-control measures today for the Los Angeles area, with some to be used if new state and local efforts failed to bring pollution levels within legal limits.

title: Business People;   After 3 Years of Growth, Imo Creates New Posts
description: Imo Industries has grown so much in the three years since it was spun off from the Transamerica Corporation that it has created the posts of president and chief operating officer. It is bringing in Robert W. Womack to fill them.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Oklahoma Issue
description: The Oklahoma Industries Authority is selling $75.96 million in tax-exempt hospital revenue bonds tentatively priced to yield a maximum of about 7.17 percent for an issue due in 2014 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. For shorter maturities, the issuer is offering yields ranging from 6.20 percent in 1993 to 6.40 percent in 1995, 6.75 percent in 2000 and 6.90 percent in 2002. All of the bonds in this issue are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, the underwriters said. And for that reason, the securities are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Proceeds from the sale will be used for the Baptist Medical Center of Oklahoma.

title: Metro Matters;   Enemies List Getting Shorter: Some Hate It
description: Now hatred is by far the longest pleasure; Men love in haste, but they detest at leisure. - Lord Byron

title: C.D. Yields Fall for 9th Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts have fallen for the ninth consecutive week, and some analysts say they expect further declines.

title: Hiring Quotas Exist, but Employers Won't Tell;   Showing Necessity
description: To the Editor:

title: In Wisconsin, Indian Feasts The Way They Used to Be
description: HELEN SAGLIN, a Chippewa, remembers childhood meals of wild rice, game, cornmeal soup and fry bread. Now, as a member of the Tekakwitha Club, a Roman Catholic women's organization on the Lac du Flambeau Reservation in north-central Wisconsin, Ms. Saglin is cooking similar meals for tourist groups interested in American Indian foods.

title: The Talk of Greenwich;   Vandal? Indubitably. But Barbarian? Hardly
description: Rene Anselmo, like many residents here, is a man of wealth and taste. He drives a Bentley. He modeled his mansion on the Petit Trianon in Versailles. He has donated money to plant thousands of daffodils and tulips along local roads. He even replaced the chain-link barricade at a nearby elementary school with a rail fence more in keeping with this town's country flavor. ''It looked like a reform school,'' he said. Lately, though, Mr. Anselmo's beautification efforts have turned ugly. This month he was arrested on charges of spray-painting a realtor's For Sale sign in front of a home on North Street, the tree-shaded thoroughfare where he lives. He has admitted to vandalizing eight or nine other signs. And he has threatened further attacks.

title: Touche Sets $19.75 Million Settlement
description: The accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche has agreed to pay $19.75 million plus expenses to a former audit client, the Inter-Regional Financial Group, to settle a lawsuit that was in its 12th week of trial in state district court in Minneapolis, the two sides said yesterday.

title: Business Technology;   The Race for Anti-Infection Drugs
description: A small biotechnology company based in Seattle has taken the lead in the race to introduce a class of drugs that build up the body's defense against infections. Analysts say the drugs could prove the most important product of genetic engineering yet.

title: SALVADORAN JUDGE SEEKS HELP OF U.S.
description: A judge's request that two United States officials testify in the investigation of the killings of six Jesuit priests last November has prompted a spirited debate between American officials here and in Washington.

title: Jockey's Remains Identified
description: Body parts that washed up in a garbage bag at Seven Presidents Park beach have been identified as the remains of a New York jockey. Crews removing timber and other waste from beaches on Thursday discovered the bag, which contained a head, arms and legs. The Monmouth County authorities used fingerprints to identify the dead man as Pedro Ortega, 26 years old, of the Bronx, an apprentice jockey who rode at New York's Acqueduct and Belmont Park race tracks.

title: Company News;   Power Plant Sale
description: The FPL Group and the Jacksonville Electric Authority signed a letter of intent to buy an 846-megawatt coal-fired electric generating unit from the Georgia Power Company of Atlanta for $810 million. FPL, a utility holding company based in North Palm Beach, Fla., said it would have a 76 percent stake in the plant near Forsyth, Ga., and Jacksonville Electric would own 24 percent.

title: In School of Other Tongues, English to Get a Say, Briefly
description: For the first summer in 75 years, English will be officially spoken today on the Middlebury College campus. But it is for one day only.

title: Chronicle
description: LEAD: BRIGITTE BARDOT'S crusade to save the animals has long been known in France and around the world. Yesterday the actress's campaign caused news of a different kind when she condemned the ritual slaughter practiced by some Islamic immigrants in France, bumping headlong into simmering racial tensions in the country.

title: Rig Count Falls in Week
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by 26, to a total of 996, according to a widely watched index of drilling activity released on Monday by Baker Hughes Inc. The oil industry toolmaker said the total was still well above the 870 of a year ago. The count reflects the number of rotary rigs exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: MY barbecues this summer have featured much more pork than beef. Pork is a tender and mild meat that can be enhanced by all sorts of marinades.

title: Central Figure Is Convicted In '85 Killing of Drug Agent
description: A jury today convicted Ruben Zuno Arce, a brother-in-law of a former Mexican president and the most important defendant in the 1985 torture and killing of an American drug agent in Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Marlboro Music Festival in Marlboro, Vt., misstated the professional affiliation of a musician at the festival. The musician, Donald Weilerstein, was a founding member of the Cleveland Quartet but left the ensemble last year.

title: 40 ARE STILL HELD
description: Gunmen from a militant Muslim group released the wounded Prime Minister of this Caribbean island nation today, but they continue to hold other members of the Government who were taken hostage four days ago.

title: Wine Talk;   A Voice Of the Mets Has a Nose For Wine
description: RUSTY STAUB is chatting with guests, a couple of young executive types, at his restaurant on Fifth Avenue at 47th Street. They are staring at him, wide-eyed. Could he be telling them about his first major-league homer, off Don Drysdale of the Dodgers, when he was 19 years old and playing for the old Houston Colt .45's? Or the fourth game of the 1973 World Series, during his first go-round with the Mets, when he went four for four with a three-run homer and a two-run single against the Oakland A's? We move a little closer to overhear. ''You may be right about the Sterling Reserve,'' he is saying, ''but I think I'd use the Sonoma-Cutrer Les Pierres or maybe even the Mondavi Reserve. They're two chardonnays that are both hard to beat.''

title: We Shouldn't Resent Japan's Achievement
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball;   Ryan Beats the Brewers for Victory No. 300
description: Nearly a week later, Nolan Ryan was still disappointed that the party in Arlington, Tex., last Wednesday night, with friends and relatives from Alvin, Tex., to the West Coast present, had not ended with a 300th major-league victory.

title: Secrecy Tied to Hanford Tanks' Trouble
description: Senior Energy Department officials said today that the department had failed to deal appropriately with radioactive waste tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State despite more than a year of strenuous efforts by the Energy Secretary, James D. Watkins, to replace a culture of secrecy that had allowed safety problems to fester.

title: GENE TREATMENTS FOR HUMAN ILLNESS MAY BE TRIED SOON
description: The revolution in human gene therapy, so long ballyhooed and debated, began today in earnest as a Government panel approved experiments with two therapies designed to treat human disease by inserting new genes into cells.

title: Review/Television;   He Wouldn't Cooperate, And He Finally Won
description: Bill Moyers and Studs Terkel come not to bury John Henry Faulk but to praise him. They were friends of the Texas performer, who died in April and who is best known for his victory over blacklisters in 1962. ''The Man Who Beat the Blacklist: John Henry Faulk'' may be seen at 9 tonight on Channel 13 and at 10 P.M. on Channels 21 and 49.

title: Corrections
description: A television review yesterday about ''Police Chiefs'' incompletely identified the role of Alan and Susan Raymond in an earlier program, ''An American Family.'' They did the photography; the program was produced and directed by Craig Gilbert.

title: Horse Racing;   Draw for Hambletonian
description: Carl Allen and his son, Rod, could easily race against each other in the 65th Hambletonian at the Meadowlands on Saturday. And their horse, Royal Troubador, could just as easily follow in his father's footsteps, too. The sire, Super Bowl, was the last horse to win the Triple Crown, taking the Yonkers Trot, the Hambletonian and the Kentuck Futurity in 1972.

title: Swinging Briefcases by Day, Rock Guitars by Night
description: ERIC ONORE is a typical young American lawyer. He wears wing-tip shoes and pin-stripe suits. He specializes in civil law and divorce. Most days are as exciting as watching Wite-Out dry. ''I've evicted a family,'' he said, when asked about recent accomplishments.

title: A Plan Aimed at Improving Schools
description: The nation's governors today approved plans intended to give backbone to their national education policies, but the package was greeted with skepticism by some education groups.

title: COMMUNISTS WIN MONGOLIA BALLOT
description: The Communist Party won a majority in this country's first free legislative elections but will invite opposition groups to join the Government, the party chairman said today. The election was held Sunday.

title: Court Orders Blue Cross to Pay For Transplant in an AIDS Case
description: A New York City man suffering from an AIDS infection won a court order yesterday requiring Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield to pay for a bone-marrow transplant from his identical twin.

title: Gain for Hepatitis Drug
description: An advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration recommended the marketing of interferon alpha, the first drug shown to work against a form of viral hepatitis. Page B7.

title: Chung Hyun Ri Journal;   Korean Spat: It's a Wall! No It Isn't! Is Too! Is Not!
description: Amid the layers on layers of defenses leading up to the edge of the demilitarized zone, it is easy to miss one more, added almost as an afterthought 12 years ago: a steep grassy slope, topped with barbed wire, that falls off into a 20-mile cliff of cement facing North Korea.

title: Market Place;   Less Optimism On Japan Stocks
description: THE Tokyo stock market, once again, is tumbling. And as in the 30 percent plunge from January to April, the villians are high interest rates, a weak yen and higher oil prices.

title: Dow Off 12.13; Transport Average Drops
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, but the Dow Jones transportation average fell sharply amid continuing reports that UAL Inc. was having trouble arranging financing for a proposed union buyout.

title: Minority Role in Broadcasting Yields Far Bigger Effect on Radio Than TV
description: After Federal and local law-enforcement officials arrested Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington on drug charges in January, Cathy Hughes devoted a week of her morning radio talk show on WOL-AM to issues raised by the arrest.

title: Fighting Reported Near Embassies and President's House in Liberia
description: Liberian rebel forces seeking to oust President Samuel K. Doe today seized a key section of Monrovia that includes the American Embassy and other diplomatic missions, the State Department said today. But later press reports said Government forces had recaptured part of the area in a fierce counterattack.

title: U.S. Panel Urges Sale of Drug To Fight a Form of Hepatitis
description: By GINA KOLATA

title: At Age 104, Coke Congratulates Itself
description: LEAD: If it weren't for the omnipresent name in red and white script, a visitor to Coca-Cola's new pavilion here celebrating the soft drink's 104-year history might well mistake it for a United Nations building.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   People
description: * Steve Hayden, the chief creative officer of BBDO's Los Angeles and San Francisco offices, has taken on the additional role of chairman of the company's West Coast operations.

title: Casey Steinbrenner
description: The outlook wasn't brilliant for the Yankee nine that day: They were anchored in last place, with less than half the season to play. As their errors, losses, throwaways grew far too numerous to name, A menacing silence fell upon the veteran patrons of the game.

title:
Real Estate;

Canada Pact Aids Upstate New York
description: LEAD: AS a way to diversify their economies, communities throughout the northern tier of New York State are hoping to take advantage of their closeness to Canada and of the free-trade agreement set up two years ago between the United States and its neighbor.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Vietnamese in Bulgaria: Bitter Times
description: Through the barred ground-floor windows of shabby workers' dormitories in a quarter of Bulgaria's capital known as Little Saigon, Vietnamese men sell scarce convenience store staples like Coca-Cola, instant coffee and cigarettes along with Canadian whisky and other hard liquor.

title: Ad Executive Slain in Village While Speaking on Pay Phone
description: An advertising executive was shot and killed Monday night while talking on a public telephone near his Greenwich Village apartment building, the police said. The executive, John Reisenbach, was using the pay phone because his home phone was disabled.

title: Jamaica and Barbados Offer Force to End Trinidad Unrest
description: Jamaica and Barbados have offered assistance to the Government of Trinidad to help it restore public order after the widespread looting and violence produced by an attempted coup.

title: Pretoria Announces an End To Unit Accused in Slayings
description: The South African military announced tonight that it had disbanded a clandestine unit held responsible by its adversaries for the assassination of political dissidents.

title: The Media Business;   House Passes Airwaves Bill
description: The House of Representatives approved a bill late Monday night that would help ease overcrowding of the airwaves by transferring many radio frequencies from the Federal Government to private users and state and local governments. The House passed the bill on a voice vote without dissent.

title: Steinbrenner Whine Fails 'Smell Test'
description: George Steinbrenner's reign of tyranny as the Yankees' principal owner was also a reign of propaganda. Whatever the problem, he shouted loud enough and long enough that it was always somebody else's fault. When the team stumbled, it had to be the fault of the dismissed manager, the dismissed pitching coach or the dismissed players. When a trade backfired, it had to be the fault of his ''baseball people'' in the front office.

title: Steinbrenner Places Son at Helm As Vincent Plots Yanks' Course
description: One day after George Steinbrenner was permanently banned from running the Yankees by Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, he officially designated his son Hank Steinbrenner yesterday as his successor.

title: Books of The Times;   The Bomb as Horror and Warning
description: The Bomb

title: Consolidated Freight Shifts Top Executives
description: Consolidated Freightways Inc., a big transportation company badly hurt by losses at an air freight operation it acquired, has accepted the resignation of its president and chief executive, Lary R. Scott.

title: Baseball;   Rijo Helps Reds Snap 8-Game Losing Streak
description: Jose Rijo pitched, hit and ran well, and Hal Morris had two hits and scored twice as the Cincinnati Reds reawakened to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-2, tonight to snap an eight-game losing streak.

title: BLAME IS PLACED FOR VALDEZ SPILL
description: Drinking by the ship's captain, a fatigued and overworked crew and inadequate traffic control by the Coast Guard all contributed to the enormous oil spill by the Exxon Valdez off the Alaskan coast last year, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled today.

title: Arab Leaders to Meet In Egypt in November
description: Arab leaders will meet in Cairo in November in the first Arab summit talks to be held in Egypt in more than 13 years, Chedli Klibi, secretery general of the Arab League, said today.

title: Company News;   Pic 'N' Save Corp. In Buyback Plan
description: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation, which has been under pressure from an investment group that has sought control of its board, announced a plan to repurchase as much as $150 million of its stock and scale back operations.

title: Reorganizing the Yankees;   Other Owners Either Silent Or Still Quietly Surprised
description: A day after George Steinbrenner was stripped of control of the Yankees, his fellow owners generally maintained their sedate postures.

title: Brett Out With Injury
description: George Brett of the Kansas City Royals, who was knocked down while covering first base during a play on Monday night in Cleveland, is expected to be out of action for several days, according to the Royals' trainer, Mickey Cobb. The 37-year-old infielder was bounced to the ground by Mitch Webster of the Indians, who was attempting to beat out an infield roller, and suffered a sprain and a bruise near his right collarbone. X-rays were negative, but Brett said, ''My collarbone is sore, and it kind of hurts to breathe.'' His batting average dropped to .300 after Brett failed to get a hit in five trips to the plate. (AP)

title: Norman Pleshette, Obstetrician, 87
description: Dr. Norman Pleshette, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Manhattan for almost 60 years, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: Review/Music;   The Rorem Reverse: Singsong for Voice As Instruments Sing
description: Ned Rorem's ''Auden Poems,'' a song cycle that was given its world premiere on Sunday evening at the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, is a study in esthetic schizophrenia. Mr. Rorem proves again and again in his setting of seven W. H. Auden texts of great musical potential that he is quite capable of writing richly expressive, eminently singable music. But in this piece, for some reason, he restricts that aspect of his talent to the instrumental lines. The voice, in this instance that of the tenor Jeffrey Thomas, is mostly allowed only a toneless, earthbound singsong of the sort that has been de rigeuer in contemporary music throughout much of this century, almost regardless of idiom.

title: Cheaper to Phone Germany Than Jersey?
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices on Treasury Bonds Ease
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds eased yesterday in lackluster trading, causing rates to edge up. Dealers described the market's mood as indecisive. Some dealers said a pause was normal after two sessions of sharp advances, but others described the market as confused and contended that the recent price gains had left the market vulnerable to any determined selling.

title: About Education
description: In a contest between child care in France and the United States, American children are the losers.

title: Xerox Profit Declines 27%
description: The Xerox Corporation today reported a 27 percent drop in second-quarter earnings and cited declines in its insurance business.

title: Chronicle
description: LEAD: Maybe he won't officially declare the cold war over. (It might look funny for the Central Intelligence Agency to say such a thing.) But WILLIAM H. WEBSTER, the Director of Central Intelligence, is set to talk about intelligence gathering in the current world climate in an interview with TED KOPPEL next Tuesday live from his office in Langley,

title: Economic Scene;   East Germany's Morning After
description: IF one tottering socialist economy can manage the transition to capitalism, goes the conventional wisdom, that economy is East Germany's. But getting there, suggests Steve H. Hanke, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, is unlikely to be half the fun. For paradoxically, East Germany's great asset - instant access to the markets and wealth of West Germany - could prove a great liability for its least productive workers and enterprises.

title: Book Notes
description: A Big Sayles Advance

title: Reorganizing the Yankees: Horse Breeder at the Ball Park;   Racing Has Been a Focus for Steinbrenner's Son
description: What's the difference, he was once asked, between owning race horses and owning a baseball team?

title: Georges Conchon, 65, Prize-Winning Writer
description: Georges Conchon, a prize-winning novelist and screenwriter, died on Sunday in a Paris-area hospital after a sudden illness, his family said Monday. He was 65 years old.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Unchanged in July
description: The prices farmers get for raw products were unchanged from June to July, but the overall commodity price index was still 2.7 percent above a year before, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Savings Crime Bill Advances
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would strengthen criminal penalties for crimes involving savings and loan institutions and create a special national commission to study the causes of the savings and loan debacle.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., said it reached an intellectual-property-rights agreement with Outbound Systems Inc. that will allow Outbound to continue to offer its products. Details were not disclosed.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Rates Decline In Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates declined modestly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. It also marked the third consecutive week that the average rates have declined.

title: Evolution in Europe;   East Germans Tell How Bonn Paid for Prisoners
description: East Germany's Interior Minister said today that the former Communist Government had released 33,000 political prisoners to West Germany from 1964 to 1989, against indirect payments from Bonn that started at the equivalent of $10,000 a head and ended up at about $60,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoco Oil Co., Chicago, a subsidiary of Amoco Corp., named W. Douglas Ford vice president of operations planning and transportation. He replaces Rodger W. Murtaugh, who is on assignment for Amoco Production Co., another subsidiary.

title: Frohnmayer Shifts Stand On Meetings
description: Faced with a lawsuit filed by four major newspapers, John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and its advisory body, the National Council on the Arts, today decided to open to the public the entire four-day meeting, beginning tomorrow, at which the council will review grant applications.

title: USX Reports Drop in Net Of 15.2% for the 2d Quarter
description: The USX Corporation, which operates the nation's largest steel business and has major energy holdings, yesterday reported a 15.2 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. The company's results were hurt by lower earnings in steel and a $99 million charge for a loss from the expected sale of the exploration and production properties of its Texas Oil and Gas subsidiary.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Monday about a decaying swimming pool in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn was published in error. It showed a small pool from the complex, not the main pool.

title: MOYNIHAN REVISES PLAN FOR TAX CUT
description: In an effort to make his proposal for a Social Security tax cut more attractive to his fellow Democrats, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan today offered a modified version that would stretch out the tax cut over five years instead of two.

title: Priscilla L. Loomis, 99; Active in Charity Work
description: Priscilla Lockwood Loomis, who received an award from Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1981 for 75 years of volunteer charity work, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Huntington, L.I. She was 99 years old and formerly lived in Manhattan.

title: Gull Disease Closes 4 Islands
description: Four privately-owned islands in Lake Champlain will be quarantined because of a mysterious disease that killed 4,000 to 5,000 ring-bellied sea gulls, a state official said today. The birds, almost all fledglings, died of a disease that seems to have subsided, said Bob Inslerman, a wildlife manager for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Many of the birds were among the gull rookeries of Four Brothers, a group of islands off Willsboro.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Endowment Restriction Is Called Unwise
description: Six constitutional law experts today told a commission reviewing the policies of the National Endowment for the Arts that it was unwise to demand that recipients of grants certify under oath that they would not use Federal money to create obscene works.

title: Company News;   Triton Is Planning To Sell Some Assets
description: The Triton Energy Corporation announced plans to sell some assets to raise money to pay long-term debt and undertake new exploration. Triton said it expected to raise $150 million, most of which will go toward paying down $250 million in long-term debt.

title: Golf;   Shoal Creek Club Agrees To Begin Admitting Blacks
description: Bowing to pressure from civil-rights leaders and an increasing number of corporate sponsors who have withdrawn television advertising from next week's P.G.A. Championship there, Shoal Creek Country Club agreed today to accept black members into its previously all-white membership. In return, the civil rights leaders agreed to call off picketing of the championship.

title: What About Souter's Human Resume?
description: It's not hard to sympathize with Justice Thurgood Marshall who, in a television interview, left the impression that he faulted President Bush's nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court.

title: Slide of the Yankees
description: George Steinbrenner has always been a quotable man, nearly always at someone else's expense. But his most revealing remark may have been an unintended commentary on himself. It was 1981. He had just fired Gene Michael as the manager of the New York Yankees and offered him a front-office job. ''Why would you want to stay manager and be second-guessed by me,'' he said, ''when you can be one of the second-guessers?''

title: Food Notes
description: A City Harvest Fair

title: Baseball;   Amid Turmoil, Yanks Continue Their Surge
description: By the end of the week, Mark Leiter could be back in Columbus. There are no assurances, no guarantees that he will remain until the end of the season, when the Yankees finally play their last game in October and then go home.

title: Blinder Files for Bankruptcy
description: Blinder, Robinson & Company, once the largest penny-stock brokerage in the world, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: I.R.A. Says It Killed Tory M.P. in Britain
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that it killed Ian Gow, a Conservative member of Parliament, because he was a close friend of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's and helped to develop British policy in Northern Ireland.

title: Working Less in Japan
description: More Japanese companies have switched to a five-day workweek as the country moves to erase its workaholic image, a Labor Ministry survey showed today. The nationwide survey of 5,000 companies with more than 3,000 employees showed 58.4 percent had gone over to the five-day week, an increase of more than five percentage points from a year ago.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Cost of Paying East's Debt Growing Problem for Bonn
description: When the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl sent West Germany on the fast track toward unification with East Germany, one of its calculations was that the merger would translate into millions of votes. But as the bills for reunification come in and West Germans nervously contemplate a tax increase to pay for it all, the issue is becoming more politically risky.

title: Roseanne Barr's High Art
description: LEAD: Periodically, something happens that is a stark and frightening indication of how small-minded and intolerant the American public can be. The outcry over Roseanne Barr's rendition of the National Anthem is one of those instances. It also demonstrated something perhaps more frightening: Americans have completely lost their sense of humor.

title: Hiring Quotas Exist, but Employers Won't Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Arrested in Killing of Infant in Bronx
description: The police arrested three men yesterday in the killing of a 9-month-old on Monday. The infant was shot through the door of his grandmother's apartment on the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx.

title: Football;   Rookie Latecomer No. 1 for Now
description: In their first week of training camp, the Giants were starved for defensive linemen. Today, they got help when Mike Fox, their second-round draft choice, signed and immediately became the starting left defensive end.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Accounts
description: * Harrows Stores, Hygrade Furniture Transport and the Marriott Financial Center Hotel to Goldberg Fossa Seid Advertising, New York.

title: Shootings Jolt Children to New Views of Guns
description: The closest Leonardo Laziza has come to a real gun was when he saw one, at eye level, on a police officer's hip, tucked inside a holster. But Leonardo, a 6-year-old from Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, said he could identify two kinds of firearms, ''a pistol and a bazooka,'' both from movies and cartoons.

title: Ford and Fiat Announce Joint Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Fiat Group of Italy today announced a joint venture combining their $5 billion worldwide tractor, farm and industrial equipment operations.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE Broadway Barber Shop, between 103d and 104th Streets, and Kay Demetriou, its owner, have been Upper West Side fixtures for four decades. Three generations of families have had their hair cut by Mr. Kay, as he is called, and six days a week for more than 40 years passers-by have been rapping on the shop's window and waving to its proprietor.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Sears Lifts Offer To $300 Million
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, is offering $300 million in notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The size of the issue was increased from a planned $250 million.

title: Judas Priest's Lead Singer Testifies
description: The lead singer for the rock band Judas Priest testified today that he once recorded a phrase backwards, but he denied planting hidden messages in his music to promote suicide.

title: Horse Racing;   Royalty at Saratoga: The Horses, Not People
description: The illusion of high society and the reality of superior horses will return to New York racing Wednesday when Saratoga Race Track opens for the 122d time.

title: U.S. Is Suspending Hearings On New Disability Payments
description: With money for administrative expenses running short at the end of the fiscal year, the Social Security Administration has suspended hearings in September for people seeking disability benefits.

title: Reorganizing the Yankees;   Vincent Directive and Steinbrenner Response
description: Following are excerpts from the documents released by Commissioner Fay Vincent yesterday and the four-paragraph statement issued by George Steinbrenner.

title: A Girl Trout Needs a Boy Trout The Way a Fish Needs a Bicycle
description: THEY call this stark, spectacular crevice of Idaho the Magic Valley after a trick of nature that sends more than a million gallons of water a minute down its vast canyon walls.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Power Of Account Planning
description: NEW YORK has always been a tough market for small agencies. To succeed, most rely on their creative reputations for producing the innovative work not usually found at many larger agencies.

title: Finance/New Issues;   American Express Notes Yield 8.73%
description: The American Express Credit Corporation, a unit of the American Express Company, yesterday entered the bond market with a $200 million offering of notes due 1994 through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

title: Ex-Aide to Bush Saw U.S. Data In S.& L. Deals
description: August 2, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

title: Prisoners in France Protest Freeing of Pro-Iran Terrorist
description: President Francois Mitterrand's decision to pardon a pro-Iranian terrorist who was serving a life sentence on murder charges has touched off a wave of protests in French jails, with prisoners complaining that they were not given similar treatment.

title: No Indictment in Teaneck Killing, But New State Inquiry Is Ordered
description: The New Jersey Attorney General said last night that a state grand jury had not indicted a white Teaneck police officer in the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager in April, but that the case had been ''contaminated'' by errors by the Bergen County Medical Examiner and would be submitted to a second grand jury.

title: F.D.I.C.'S CHAIRMAN EXPECTS 1990 LOSS ON BANK INSURANCE
description: Giving one of his bleakest forecasts to date, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that ever-weakening real estate markets and a near-record number of bank failures were likely to produce the third consecutive annual loss for the fund that insures deposits at commercial banks.

title: Company News;   Freeport-McMoran In Stock Swap Deal
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc. agreed to acquire the publicly held shares of its Freeport-McMoran Oil and Gas Company affiliate in a stock swap worth about $241 million. Holders of the stock will get about three shares of stock in the parent company for every 10 shares held, the company said. Freeport-McMoran valued the oil and gas unit at $10.50 a share.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: SALADS are not the first thing that springs to mind when you're considering the capabilities of the microwave oven, but for the robust salads of summer, it can be an efficient, cool helper. For variety, vegetables can be cooked in one dish, rather than separately timed in a plethora of little pots of boiling water. Chicken, fish and seafood can be cooked quickly.

title: UAL's Stock Plummets By $16.875
description: UAL's stock plunged $16.875 yesterday after sliding $6.125 on Monday, amid rumors that financial support for the $4.4 billion union-led buyout of the airline may be evaporating. The stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $140.

title: 7 Are Indicted in 'Narcotics Terrorism'
description: Seven members of a drug gang that authorities say committed at least three murders to protect its Elizabeth-based operations have been charged with racketeering and conspiracy in a 32-count Federal indictment released today.

title: The Perpetual Crime Wave Crests, and a City Shudders
description: The killing of four children in nine days by gunfire intended for others has pierced New Yorkers' instinctive imperviousness to the violence that increasingly surrounds them in a city where 2,000 people are likely to be murdered this year.

title: Baseball;   Faced With Suspension, Steinbrenner Sought an Alternative
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent wanted to suspend George Steinbrenner for two years, but Steinbrenner opted for life instead.

title: Company News;   A.T.&T. to Cut Computer Jobs
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would shrink its computer equipment operations by up to 650 people through job transfers and possible layoffs.

title: Currency Markets;   Tumbling U.S. Dollar Could Hit New Lows
description: Weakened by a sluggish economy and the expectation of lower interest rates, the American dollar is tumbling, and many economists expect it to reach or come close to all-time lows against several leading currencies.

title: Ashton, After Delay, Ships New Program
description: After more than a year's delay, the Ashton-Tate Company today began shipping an updated version of its flagship product, a program that is considered a key to the company's return to profitability. Dubbed dBase IV Version 1.1, the new program seeks to correct flaws in the original dBase IV announced in October 1988.

title: Heath Is Suspended
description: Mke Heath, the Detroit Tiger catcher, was suspended for two games by the American League yesterday for bumping Umpire John Hirschbeck.

title: Company News;   Shares in Cetus Plunge by 26.6%
description: Shares of the Cetus Corporation, a genetic engineering concern, fell 26.6 percent in response to a regulatory delay in approving a drug the company has developed to treat kidney cancer.

title: Interco Debt Pact Includes Conversion of Bonds to Stock
description: Interco Inc., a St. Louis-based shoe and furniture maker that has been burdened with debts incurred to avoid a hostile takeover in 1988, announced plans yesterday to reorganize its finances and avoid bankruptcy.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday, about the events leading to Commissioner Fay Vincent's disciplinary action against George Steinbrenner, the New York Yankees' principal owner, incorrectly reported Mr. Vincent's initial decision. A baseball official has since said that Mr. Vincent intended to suspend Mr. Steinbrenner from baseball for two years but that he changed his mind on Monday at the request of Mr. Steinbrenner, who accepted a permanent ban from operating the Yankees.

title: Sales of New Houses Up 3>8%; Some Predict a Turnaround
description: Sales of new homes surged 8 percent in June, the sharpest increase since November, the Government said today.

title: Souter Nomination Stirs Abortion Rights Groups
description: Abortion rights groups are building major direct mail campaigns around the nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court, both to raise money and to encourage senators to press the abortion issue in confirmation hearings in September.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a bombing in Israel misidentified the hometown of a Canadian tourist killed in the explosion. It is Willowdale, a suburb of Toronto.

title: Baseball;   His Role on Olympics Becomes Uncertain, Too
description: The actions taken against George Steinbrenner by major league baseball on Monday have raised questions about his ability to remain as a vice president of the United States Olympic Committee, a position he cherishes and one in which he has worked hard.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Besieged Amazon Unionists Say Phoned Death Threats Are Collect
description: Osmarino Amancio Rodrigues, secretary of the National Council of Rubber Tappers, said here today that he and his associates were getting phoned death threats collect.

title: Melba This Peach Isn't
description: Roseanne Barr, purveyor of vulgar entertainment for the TV audience, ran afoul of President Bush last week. The President said he was offended by Miss Barr's singing of ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' at a professional baseball game in San Diego.

title: F.A.O. Schwarz Toy Stores Bought by Dutch Company
description: F.A.O. Schwarz, the 128-year-old toy store that has delighted generations of children, has been acquired by the Netherlands' leading department store chain for an undisclosed amount.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Artist as Art, or, Sui Too Can Be Generis
description: The rejection of Karen Finley and three other experimentalists for grants from the National Endowment for the Arts has made the term ''performance artist'' the subject of considerable debate and wide attention. People who have no conception of the range or purpose of the form now use the words with alacrity, as a synonym for anything outrageous. The fact is that performance art is one of the most inclusive - and misunderstood - of theatrical arts.

title: Review/Music;   Philip Glass Ensemble Plays for a Silent Film
description: The hazards and delights of cultural interchange were on abundant display on Friday at Alice Tully Hall, where the Philip Glass Ensemble performed his score for a showing of the otherwise silent film ''Powaqqatsi.'' The title, a Hopi word, means ''an entity, a way of life, that consumes the life forces of other beings in order to further its own life.'' The 1988 film, directed by Godfrey Reggio, is as beautiful as it is pretentious, and Mr. Glass's score brings it a convincing grandeur.

title: Ed Emshwiller, 65; Made Experimental Movies and Videos
description: Ed Emshwiller, who created avant-garde films and videotapes, died on July 26 at the Henry Mayo Newhall Memorial Hospital in Valencia, Calif. He was 65 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgaria to Share Arms Export Data
description: The new director of a Bulgarian arms-export concern long presumed in the West to have supplied weapons to terrorist organizations said today that his company was willing to share with Western governments information on arms that might have ended up in terrorist hands.

title: Tigers Pound Hawkins
description: The summer is still not over for Andy Hawkins. There are two months remaining, perhaps a dozen or so starts left for him to remove the memory of his strange season. He should want to forget the whole thing right now, but he doesn't.

title: Health;   Personal Health
description: The Incidence of breast cancer is rising among American women. One woman in 10 will eventually get this disease, up from one in 11 just four years ago.

title: Currents;   Images of a Homeland in West Africa
description: THE decorative arts of Africa are usually chronicled in books about masks, bronzes, jewelry, textiles and tools made by men. In ''African Canvas: Art of West African Women'' (Rizzoli, $60), the photographer and journalist Margaret Courtney-Clarke documents a lesser-known form: the art of rural dwellings.

title: Review/Opera;   How Getting Laughs in Mozart Is Serious Business
description: Although the axiom that comedy is more difficult to perform than tragedy is a cliche of criticism, it might even be true. But like many an old saw, this one doesn't always cut deep. The fact is that unless we are talking about the heady level of ''Falstaff'' or ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' opera rarely demands more of singers than low comedy skills. No one complains loudly if a director requires only hearty slapstick in ''Don Pasquale'' or the first act of ''La Boheme.'' One of the mysteries of opera is its ability to make an audience laugh at buffoonery that would not pass as humor in the average senior class play.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Pizza Hut Promotion Features Ninja Turtles
description: Entertainment Marketing and Communications International Ltd. yesterday announced a sponsorship deal linking Pizza Hut Inc., a subsidiary of Pepsico, and the Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles cartoon characters. At the heart of Pizza Hut's agreement is the sponsorship of a 40-city rock-concert tour, with musicians appearing as singing turtles, scheduled to begin in September in New York. Pizza Hut is also devising promotional efforts to coincide with the upcoming release of ''Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' on videocassette and with the planned sequel to that film. Pizza Hut is the second large fast-food chain to use the Ninja Turtles. Burger King, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., features the characters in promotions, including toy giveaways. In addition, the characters have been used to promote hundreds of other products.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a Senate subcommittee hearing on the savings and loan crisis misidentified a lobbyist who used his Washington contacts to help buyers of insolvent savings and loan associations. He is Robert J. Thompson.

title: Daily News Files Suit To Halt Labor Panel
description: The Daily News asked a Federal court yesterday to stop a State Board of Inquiry from examining negotiations between the paper and its unions.

title: Arkansas Goes to S.E.C.
description: Arkansas jumped to the Southeastern Conference today, severing its 76-year ties to the troubled Southwest Conference and possibly starting a restructuring of college football leagues.

title: Treasury Bonds Post More Gains
description: Interest rates resumed their decline yesterday as prices of Treasury securities rallied on new evidence of a weakening economy.

title: Liberian Says He'll Crush Rival, Then Doe
description: A Liberian rebel leader, Charles Taylor, said today that he would let President Samuel K. Doe's army help him crush a rival rebel chief before moving in to oust Mr. Doe himself within 10 days.

title: Zawatson Proves to Be Feisty Newcomer for Jets
description: When Dave Zawatson went to grammar school in Cleveland, he was left-handed, but the teachers at St. Angela's Catholic School insisted that everybody do everything right-handed. That hard-learned lesson seems to be coming in handy for for the Jets' offensive lineman at training camp these days.

title: The Talk of Saratoga;   Horse Season Opens (Oh, and Races Too)
description: In August, people come to Saratoga for more than the horses, or the waters (mineral). They come to soak up the romance of the track: Costume balls, tip sheets, barber shop quartets, racing forms, champagne breakfasts at the morning workout, sunshine and a glimpse of Mellons, Vanderbilts and Whitneys being put through their social paces.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Lays Off 30 In New York
description: CHIAT/DAY/MOJO, the Venice, Calif., agency that seemed to have the golden touch in the last decade, announced yesterday that it had laid off 30 employees in its 150-person New York office, which has lost three major accounts this year.

title: America's Neck and a New Noose
description: Even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, America's energy situation was looking increasingly ominous. Fact one: Imports accounted for a record 50 percent of the oil consumed by the U.S. during the first half of 1990. Fact two: The oil cartel, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, this week raised its target price for oil by 17 percent.

title: Mozambique Will Allow Opposition Parties
description: President Joaquim A. Chissano has announced that for the first time in Mozambique's history, opposition parties will be allowed to compete for power. Mozambican rebels welcomed the move.

title: Books of The Times;   A Sensuist's Ramble in the Realm of the Senses
description: A Natural History of the Senses

title: Health;   Asthma Death Rate Reported Up 30%
description: The nation's death rate from asthma has increased by more than 30 percent in seven years, and nearly 10 million Americans are now affected by the disease, Federal health officials say.

title: Company News;   I.B.M. in Deal to Shed Its Typewriter Unit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation confirmed today that it would spin off its low-technology businesses - typewriters, keyboards and personal printers - into a new subsidiary. Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York leveraged buyout firm, is to become the primary owner of the new unit, the company said.

title: Tilting at Lawn Mowers: Life on a Hill
description: Lawn care is tedious and predictable. Lawns are seeded and fed. They grow. They get mowed. They grow again. But some lawns are more interesting than their owners would like. These homeowners face a bigger challenge than their flatland neighbors; they are the masters and caretakers of steep, almost vertical lawns.

title: Radio Free Europe on the Air From Prague for First Time
description: Radio Free Europe began broadcasting directly from Prague today after 40 years of transmitting news to Czechoslovakia from abroad.

title: Edward F. Landau, 74, Research Chemist, Dies
description: Dr. Edward Frederick Landau, a retired research chemist and holder of six patents, died on Monday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in West Orange.

title: The Media Business;   TV Ratings Spying Case
description: A former employee of the Arbitron Company attempted to give confidential information about the company's television ratings to its principal rival, the A. C. Nielsen Company, the Department of Justice charged yesterday.

title: About New York;   Offering a Hand, With a Stitch And a Smile
description: ''I was always a heavy kid, and there were no clothes for me,'' Saundra Lewis said. ''I would ask my mother for a new dress and she would say, 'We'll have to see about that.' ''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Omnicom Net Rises 16%
description: The Omnicom Group said second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, to $17.4 million, or 67 cents a share, from $15.1 million, or 58 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenues rose 24 percent, to $298.5 million, from $241.7 million in the 1989 period.

title: Close to Home
description: THE bus was going east on 57th Street, and when it reached Madison Avenue, I took my eyes off my paperback and peered out the window. We were passing the building in which I worked at my first job.

title: U.S. and Japan Agree On Telecommunications
description: Japan agreed today to open up its telecommunications market further to foreign companies, meeting an Aug. 1 deadline for possible American retaliation, United States officials said.

title: Civil Rights: The House's Turn
description: Now it's the House's turn to do right by civil rights and reaffirm law weakened by Supreme Court interpretations. The Senate last month passed a civil rights bill. If tradition holds, the House will pass a strong version of the same bill. Then, after the August recess, both chambers can agree on a strong Civil Rights Act of 1990.

title:
Business People;

Burger King Executive Is Named Del Taco Chief
description: LEAD: Kevin K. Moriarty, who started in the restaurant business at Moriarty's Cafe, his family's restaurant in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, has been named president and chief executive of Del Taco Inc., a Mexican fast-food chain based in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: S.I. Ferry: Still a Bargain at Twice the Price
description: Commuters on the Staten Island ferry began paying a quarter more for the ride yesterday, prompting a few to grumble and groan but leaving most still satisfied that the fare, even raised to 50 cents a round trip, remained one of the best bargains in New York.

title: Topics of The Times;   Melons at the MOMA
description: At the entrance to ''Matisse in Morocco,'' on display at the Museum of Modern Art until Sept. 4, is a National Geographic magazine photograph of Tangier in 1906. The city is sun-baked, steamy and tired. Just beyond it is the Tangier painted by Matisse. Fertile, colorful, exuberant, the city is paradise.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Senate Votes to Curb Donations From Outside Campaign Groups
description: The Senate tonight passed the first major campaign finance bill since the Watergate era, a comprehensive package that would bar political action committees from Federal campaigns, infuse public money into Congressional campaigns and offer candidates vouchers for television advertising.

title: Ultimate's Ex-Leader Heads Digital Products
description: Theodore M. Sabarese, an entrepreneur who built a computer company called the Ultimate Corporation into a $200 million business, hopes to do the same with the Digital Products Corporation in his new posts as president and chief executive.

title: Dismissal of Buckey Charges Ends Longest Case in U.S.
description: The longest and most expensive criminal proceeding in American history came to an official end today when a Superior Court judge dismissed all charges against Raymond Buckey, a central figure in the McMartin Pre-School child molestation case.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Accounts
description: * Hoya Museum Crystal to Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre, San Francisco. The account had been with Cadwell Davis Partners, New York.

title: Purchasers Report Fall In Growth
description: A monthly survey released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management indicated a steep decline for the nation's manufacturing economy in July, reversing a three-month growth trend. Economists said the survey gave more credence to assessments that the economy is slowing, perhaps slipping into a recession.

title: Kodak Profits Rise Sharply
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that its earnings had risen nearly fivefold in the second quarter from results that were depressed by a large restructuring charge a year ago.

title: From Honda, an Exotic Challenge
description: The Acura NSX sports car that will be roaring down American roads later in August has swooping lines, a heart-stopping 168-mile-an-hour top speed and a long list of other characteristics that the Honda Motor Company says a competitive ''super car'' should have.

title: Suitor Meets on Bid for Kay
description: Executives of Ratners Group P.L.C., which is trying to acquire Kay Jewelers Inc. for about $410 million, met yesterday to reconsider the terms of its offer to Kay stockholders and bondholders. The company's plans were not disclosed, and no announcement about the offer was made last night.

title: Stocks Plummet in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices fell sharply today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Page D15.

title: Former Associate Sues Rinfret Over Business
description: A former business associate of Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor, has filed a lawsuit charging that Mr. Rinfret went back on a promise to give him a share in his investment businesses.

title: Childbirth: A Guide That Can Enlighten
description: Childbirth, so often touted as a natural occurrence, can also be a daunting one for women who confront an array of modern technological procedures in large medical institutions.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   People
description: * John P. McLaughlin, a senior vice president and director of account management, has been promoted to executive vice president of Gray Kirk & Evans.

title: Bank Stock Prices Decline On Warning by Economist
description: Bank stock prices fell yesterday after a televised allegation by a Stanford University economist that several of the nation's largest banks were ''very close to true insolvency.''

title: Company News;   Fiat Disclosure
description: Fiat S.p.A. has an option to buy the Ford Motor Company's 20 percent stake in their new farm vehicles venture, Fiat's managing director, Cesare Romiti, said in a newspaper interview to be published on Thursday. Fiat and Ford said on Tuesday that they were placing their tractor, farm and industrial equipment businesses into a new company 80 percent owned by Fiat and 20 percent by Ford. Mr. Romiti told Corriere della Sera that Fiat had an option to buy the Ford holding within four years.

title: Company News;   Daisy Systems
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, once a high-flying leader in the electronic automated design business, said the company and its Daisy/Cadnetix Inc. unit had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Daisy Systems, based in Mountainview, Calif., said it had liabilities substantially in excess of its tangible assets. The company also said it would try to sell Daisy/Cadnetix.

title: Ryan Savors His Milestone With a Feeling of Relief
description: The glare from all those bright lights that have followed Nolan Ryan and the Texas Rangers for the last two weeks will shine elsewhere for a while. The questions about his past and his future will not come so often, and from so many strangers.

title: Consumer Rates;   Fund Yields Are Down
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday.

title: New York City Tells All Agencies To Use Same Process for Contracts
description: Striving to make its $6 billion annual spending for goods and services more orderly, New York City issued rules yesterday that will, for the first time, require all agencies to follow the same basic process in letting contracts, for needs from day care to data processing.

title: REBELS IN TRINIDAD FREE ALL HOSTAGES
description: A violent, five-day drama that saw the Prime Minister and half of the Cabinet taken hostage by heavily armed Muslim militants ended peacefully today when 112 gunmen and their religious leader laid down their weapons and freed their remaining 46 hostages.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about new-home sales in June misidentified an economist and, because of an editing error, misidentified the Congressionally chartered corporation for which he works. The economist is Mark Obrinsky; he is on the staff of the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, not the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac.

title: Fort Howard Chief Quits
description: Paul J. Schierl, who has battled illness since arranging a management-led buyout of the Fort Howard Corporation two years ago, resigned today as chief executive after 16 years.

title: Frederick Gloeckner, Horticulturist, 88, Dies
description: Frederick Carl Gloeckner, a New York horticulturist, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: American Legion to Sue U.S. Over Agent Orange
description: The American Legion, the largest veterans' group in the country, said today that it was bringing suit against the Government for failing to complete a study of the health of thousands of Vietnam War veterans exposed to the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: In the Mind of the High-Tech Child
description: THE New Math is ''so simple, so very simple, that only a child can do it,'' the satirist Tom Lehrer sang in the 1960's.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgarian Opposition Leader to Become President
description: After a bewildering series of turnabouts, Bulgaria's Parliament today elected the leader of the main opposition political coalition to the national presidency.

title: The Guns of America
description: Four innocent children killed in nine days in New York City, by bullets fired from semiautomatic weapons but intended for someone else.

title: Chronicle
description: JULIA ROBERTS didn't exactly love Abbeville, S.C., where she worked on a film recently. In an interview in this month's Rolling Stone, the actress, who starred in the film ''Pretty Woman,'' called the town ''horribly racist'' and ''living hell.''

title: A Legal Leg for Designers
description: AFTER years of legal wrangling, the design field in New York state has taken a step toward professional legitimacy with the signing by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of a bill that provides for state certification of interior designers.

title: Briefs
description: * BSN Corp., Dallas, a sporting goods company, said it would solicit offers for the company's assets.

title: Charles (Red) Barrett, Pitcher, 75
description: Charles (Red) Barrett, who holds the major league record for the fewest pitches in a nine-inning game, died at his home Saturday after a long illness. He was 75 years old. While pitching for the Boston Braves in 1944, he faced 27 batters and threw only 58 pitches in a 2-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Home Improvement
description: LINING a closet with cedar paneling helps keep moths and insects away from woolen clothes. Cedar's aroma, which is pleasant to people, is a repellent to insects. Cedar is also safer than chemical repellents, like mothballs, which can be accidentally eaten by children.

title: Augusta and Baltusrol May Admit First Black Members
description: Leaders of two of the most prestigious all-white golf clubs in America said today that the events of Shoal Creek have made the search for black members at their clubs a major priority.

title: Jan Stussy, Artist, 68
description: Jan Stussy, a West Coast artist with works in many museums and private collections, died on Tuesday at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 68 years old.

title: Afghan on a Sudden Trip to Moscow
description: As Afghan rebel leaders and Pakistani officials await the results of talks on Afghanistan between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, attention here and in Kabul is riveted on the sudden and mysterious trip to Moscow by the Afghan leader, Najibullah.

title: Industry Group Approves Incorporation of Accountants
description: In a sharp break with tradition, the directors of the leading oversight body of the accounting profession voted at their July meeting to allow accountants to organize their practices as corporations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Company News page in Business Day yesterday about the Walt Disney Company's plans for a theme park in Long Beach, Calif., misstated the company's business relationship with two attractions on the site in some copies. Disney leases and operates the Queen Mary ocean liner and the Spruce Goose airplane; it does not own them.

title: Talking Deals;   Moscow's Call To De Beers
description: THE historic diamond deal announced last week by the Soviet Union and De Beers Centenary, a Swiss subsidiary of the huge South African mining group, took months of meetings and four sets of shuttle negotiations between London and Moscow.

title: Disputed Art Show Opens Peacefully
description: The widely disputed exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe opened in Boston today without serious protest after a highly unusual broadcast of the show's most sexually explicit pictures on Tuesday night by the local affiliate of the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: IRAQ ARMY INVADES CAPITAL OF KUWAIT IN FIERCE FIGHTING
description: Iraqi troops crossed the Kuwait border today and penetrated deeply into the country and into Kuwait's capital city, senior Administration officials said late Wednesday.

title: Dr. Edward Kline, 81, Retired Official of G.E.
description: Dr. Edward Mahon Kline, an educator, cardiologist and retired medical director of the General Electric Company, died on Monday at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: Final Arguments Begin in Barry Trial
description: Final arguments began today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial, with the prosecution asserting that he was ''a general who joined the enemy'' in the war on drugs and the defense countering that the Government had used ''mustard gas'' tactics to apprehend a man who used drugs only occasionally.

title: Puppy Killing Brings Prison
description: A man convicted of killing a puppy with a butcher knife was sentenced Tuesday to three and a half years in prison under the state's recently toughened law on cruelty to animals. Everston Eugene Webb, 22 years old, was sentenced for aggravated cruelty. Testimony at his Circuit Court trial indicated he killed the dog on May 11 because it was tearing up his yard.

title: P.& G. Sues on Satanism
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, which has previously fought rumors that its 108-year-old moon and stars trademark is a satanic symbol, said this week that it had sued a Kansas couple for claiming the company was associated with satanism. The suit, filed Monday in Federal District Court, contends James and Linda Newton of Parsons made libelous and malicious statements about Procter & Gamble by saying it supports ''the church of Satan.'' The couple are also said to have urged a boycott of the company's products. A Procter & Gamble statement said the Newtons are distributors of household items for Amway Home Products. Mrs. Newton declined to comment.

title: Corrections
