description: An obituary yesterday about Dr. Norman Pleshette, a Manhattan obstetrician, omitted a survivor. She is his wife, Marjorie.

title: Tokyo Stocks and Yen Fall After Iraqi Invasion
description: Japanese stock prices fell sharply in afternoon trading today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait.

title: PROVISION ON AIDS IS IN HOUSING BILL
description: In surprisingly quick action, the House today approved a bill overhauling Federal housing programs for the next fiscal year and approving $27.9 billion to pay for them. The spending would include $150 million to help people with AIDS.

title: Palace Guard Closes In on a Breach of Confidence
description: The most talked-about items in the last two issues of Paris Match magazine were the ones that did not appear in Britain.

title: Who Robbed the S.&L.'s? Congress.
description: The most captivating news story in my home state last year concerned an attempted robbery of tragicomic proportions.

title: Past Creates Wave of TV Nostalgia
description: IRA GALLEN took a gulp of Naya Natural Spring Water from a Lone Ranger cup. ''Hi-yo, Silver,'' he toasted happily before answering his ringing Snoopy telephone.

title: Nationwide Reunion Celebration For Blacks
description: TERI SMITH looks forward to family reunions. They are times for her aunts, uncles, cousins, sisters and brothers to gather to talk of their new babies, travels, childhoods, deceased relatives and dreams. Ms. Smith will also learn more about families from a broader perspective at the six Black Family Reunion Celebrations being held in various cities around the country.

title: De Klerk and Mandela Agree on Talks
description: After a three-hour meeting today, President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela indicated that they had overcome a crisis between them and would resume negotiations on the country's future as planned next Monday.

title: Judge Rejects Los Angeles County's Voting Plan
description: A Federal district judge today rejected the county's redistricting plan for electing county supervisors, calling the proposal ''a nonsensical distortion'' and insensitive to minority members.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE death of a family pet may be a child's first experience with the loss of a person or animal he loves. In some ways it is more emotionally complex than coping with the death of a human being; for instance, the animal may be younger than the child, or may have been with the family since before the child was born. Or the pet may have been seriously ill or destructive and had to be put to death, a decision that many parents and children find frightening and confusing.

title: Revolving-Door Child Care
description: To The Home Section:

title: U.S. Releases Funds for Hearings on Benefits
description: Richard G. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, has agreed to release $5 million to let the Social Security Administration hold hearings next month for people seeking disability benefits, White House officials said today.

title: Two Who Lost Arts Grants Are Up for New Ones
description: Members of the council that advises the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts say they expect fireworks at a meeting here on Friday when they take up recommendations for new grants for two of the four sexually explicit performance artists who were denied grants in June.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Company News;   New Chairman of G.M. Promises Period of Stability
description: Robert C. Stempel, the new chairman of the General Motors Corporation, promised on his first day in office today that the auto maker would not pursue a strategy of reorganization like the one that caused turmoil in the world's biggest auto maker in the 1980's.

title: Group of Blacks Sees Hiring Bias By Morgenthau
description: A group of prominent black legislators, clergy members and leaders of community groups asserted yesterday that District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan was systematically excluding blacks from policy-making roles in his office.

title: Chronicle
description: Seven members of UB40, the British reggae group, were deported from the Seychelles Islands yesterday after being arrested on suspicion of possessing marijuana.

title: Review/City Opera;   A Solid 'Figaro' Opens A Season
description: In its 46-year history, the New York City Opera has had many mandates, sometimes conflicting ones. It has been a home for young American singers, a champion of American opera, a forum for innovative productions, a source of unusual repertory. But one of its humbler jobs has been to present solid, competent performances of standard-repertory operas in conventional productions at moderate prices.

title: Currents;   Making the Children Feel an Urge to Scribble
description: ''SO many people grow up with their parents saying 'Don't draw on the furniture,' '' said the painter Gary Komarin. Mr. Komarin and his wife, Sharon, a former nursery school teacher, aren't that way.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., named Earl F. Wheeler, a general manager of programming systems, as senior vice president. I.B.M. also named Dr. James C. McGroddy, director of its research division, and Mary Lee Turner, director of corporate communications, as vice presidents.

title: Company News;   Cyanamid Buyback Stock
description: The stock of the American Cyanamid Company rose today after the pharmaceuticals company said it planned a stock buyback program that analysts said might total $600 million. Cyanamid's stock rose $1.50, to $56.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said it planned to ask its board to authorize a share repurchase program on Aug. 21. Analysts said a $600 million buyback plan would allow the company to repurchase at least 10 million shares.

title: Chronicle
description: ROGER CRAIG has thrown in the towel after posing in it for Macy's ads. The running back for the San Francisco 49ers, who posed earlier this summer for an ad for Calvin Klein underwear, said that his wife did not like his modeling career.

title: Roll-Call in Senate On Speaking Fees
description: Following is the 77-to-23 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to prohibit its members from accepting speaking fees from special interest groups. A yes vote was a vote to prohibit such fees and a no vote was a vote to permit them. Voting yes were 53 Democrats and 24 Republicans. Voting no were 2 Democrats and 21 Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by xxx.

title: Construction Spending Was Unchanged in June
description: Construction spending, which fell for two straight months, was flat in June, the Government reported today.

title: Trump Shifts Casino Posts
description: A management shake-up was announced on Tuesday at Trump Taj Mahal, the newest and most expensive casino in Donald J. Trump's troubled empire.

title: Phil D. Fine, Lawyer, Dies at 64; Key Force in Boston Development
description: Phil David Fine, a lawyer who played an important role in several major development projects in Massachusetts, died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived in Boston.

title: 10 Die as Rival Palestinians Clash in Lebanon
description: Rival Palestinian guerrillas clashed with rockets and heavy machine guns in their largest district in Lebanon today, and the police said 10 people were killed and 50 wounded.

title: The Media Business;   Chargeurs Buys Pathe
description: A French industrial group, Chargeurs S.A., today bought Pathe-Cinema S.A., the film company that the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti tried to buy earlier this year.

title: Senate Roll-Call on Campaign Financing
description: Following is the 77-to-23 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to prohibit its members from accepting speaking fees from special interest groups. A yes vote was a vote to prohibit such fees and a no vote was a vote to permit them. Voting yes were 53 Democrats and 24 Republicans. Voting no were 2 Democrats and 21 Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by xxx.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on July 25 about changes in leadership at several universities misstated Clark Kerr's tenure as chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley. He was chancellor of the Berkeley campus from 1952 to 1958, and president of the University of California system from 1958 to 1967.

title: Health;   The Quiet Comeback of Electroshock Therapy
description: For Big Nurse in ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' it was a tool of terror, and in the public mind ''shock therapy'' has retained the tarnished image given it by Ken Kesey's novel: dangerous, inhumane and overused.

title: Boot-Camp Jail To Begin in Fall At Rikers Island
description: The New York City Correction Commissioner said yesterday that a ''high impact incarceration plan'' - similar in some ways to the state's boot-camp program for prisoners - would begin at Rikers Island in September.

title: Salary Cap Goes Up
description: The National Basketball Association raised its team salary cap yesterday, and the teams immediately raised their trading intensity.

title: Council and Dinkins Offer Competing Plans on Police
description: Struggling to find a political response to the recent shootings of four children, the New York City Council yesterday proposed adding hundreds of officers to the police force. Hours later, Mayor David N. Dinkins rebuffed that plan as unrealistic and offered his own.

title: INSIDE
description: Disability Hearings Rescued

title: Testimony Shows Both Sides Of Defense Lawyer's Gamble
description: Just after 10:30 yesterday morning, Yusef Salaam swept across the Manhattan courtroom, a tall, lean figure with a young man's face who was there to answer charges that he raped and tried to kill a young woman in Central Park one night.

title: Company News;   Oppenheimer Buyout Is Set
description: The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company said today that it would take part in the acquisition of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation from British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C. for about $150 million.

title: Review/Dance;   Walking on the Wall, Or Maybe It's a Floor
description: Imagine a couple rolling around a bathroom floor for 50 minutes. Then imagine that this ''floor'' is actually an upright wall in a theater, providing an audience with an aerial view as the performers move on the vertical plane by means of toeholds or harnesses.

title: KEY RATES
Ex-Koch Deputy Favored As Head of Port Authority
description: Stanley Brezenoff, the first deputy mayor in the Koch administration, has been designated to be the next executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Market Place;   Bond Investors Gain Overseas
description: WHEN it comes to global bond investing, sometimes all that matters is getting the currency right. In July, the principal determinant of profit was investing in bonds denominated in almost any currency other than the dollar.

title: Fixing and Polishing Broken Metal
description: PAUL KARNER of Restoration and Design Studio said he would restore ''anything in metal,'' from knives and candlesticks to sterling silver hand mirrors. Mr. Karner also repairs many small items with sentimental value. ''But they say it was their grandmother's and they want it,'' he said. So he fixes it.

title: George W. May, Executive, 64
description: George W. May, founder of Firecom Inc. of Woodside, Queens, a manufacturer and installer of alarms, died on Sunday at Glen Cove Community Hospital on Long Island. He was 64 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Currents;   Designs for Humanity: Glasses, Car Seat, Razor
description: THE results of the 1990 ID Magazine Design Review are in.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As far as the Government is concerned, it's unconditional surrender.''

title: Evidence Shows Youth's Hands Up When Teaneck Officer Killed Him
description: New medical evidence that a black teen-ager had his hands up when he was fatally shot in the back by a Teaneck police officer caused the New Jersey Attorney General to order a new investigation, people close to the case said yesterday.

title: George Napack, Engineer, 65
description: George Napack, a chemical engineer and a retired vice president of the Hatco Chemical Corporation, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Westfield, N.J.

title: Calendar: Crafts and Cottage Gardens
description: American Gardens, New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park, the Bronx; (212) 220-8747.

title: Monterey Journal;   Trees and Trademarks: The Disputes Run Deep
description: It's been said that only God can make a tree. But now mere mortals are stepping forward to argue about who owns a tree's image.

title: Currents;   My Style? It's Wonderful. Simply Wonderful!
description: ONE of the most riveting social documents to appear in recent months is ''The AD 100,'' an ''exclusive guide to the world's finest interior designers'' by the editors of Architectural Digest. The guide is being sent this month to all subscribers and is also available on newsstands for $10.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Gorbachev Joins His Main Rival To Shape New Economic Program
description: In a move that could signal a break in their political stalemate, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has joined with his main rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, to create a commission to produce a program of economic change for the Soviet Union by Sept. 1.

title: Outdoors Is Indoors As Garden Decor Moves to the Parlor
description: FROM Manhattan to Berkeley, Calif., and from Atlanta to Newport, R.I., green thumbs and greenhorns are patronizing stores with names like the Potted Plant, the Elegant Earth, Victory Garden and Devonshire. Following in the path of mail-order businesses like Smith & Hawken and Gardener's Eden, which have already spread the word on the well-honed garden, this new breed of shop is bringing the sweet smell of earth (or at least the illusion of it) indoors. Call it garden style.

title: Drug Is Found to Cure Some With a Deadly Liver Disease
description: For the first time, researchers have been able to cure patients with chronic hepatitis B, a devastating and often progressively debilitating liver disease that afflicts more than a million Americans and is the ninth leading cause of death worldwide.

title: Head of United Negro College Fund to Retire Soon
description: LEAD: Christopher F. Edley, under whose leadership the United Negro College Fund became one of the nation's most widely recognized charities, will retire at the end of the year, the organization announced yesterday.

title: Man Who Shot Wife As a Mercy Killing Is Granted Clemency
description: Florida officials today approved clemency for an 81-year-old man convicted of shooting his ailing wife in what he said was a mercy killing, and he is to be freed from prison on Thursday.

title: Don't Let Congress Hobble the Cable Industry;   Telephone and Video
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;   Up Above, A Blimpful Of Colors
description: THAT blimp on the horizon is becoming hard to miss. Over the past few years, the Goodyear Air Ship, also known as the Goodyear Blimp, has been illuminated in designs in red, yellow, blue and green.

title: Stewart Wins by 1-0 On Pinch-Hit in 11th
description: Doug Jennings, a pinch-hitter, broke up a pitching duel with a run-scoring single in the 11th inning and Dave Stewart went the distance as the Oakland A's defeated the Seattle Mariners, 1-0, today.

title: Mets Tie in 9th on Teufel Homer, Win in 12th
description: The Mets turned into August tonight with the kind of desperate action reserved for pennant races. And, in three and a half hours of their ripest melodrama of the season, they survived when Tim Teufel had a pinch-hit home run for a tie with two down in the ninth inning, and then rose up to topple the Montreal Expos, 6-4, with a burst of runs in the 12th.

title: Brother of Man Killed by Police Sues New York
description: The brother of a 24-year-old man shot to death by a police officer outside a party in the Bronx has sued the city, claiming wrongful death.

title: Curionopolis Journal;   Is Gold Worth This? Amazon Is Being Poisoned
description: Slipping a .38 revolver into the waistband of his blue jeans, Norberto Neves de Sousa led fellow environmental agents down a forest path to an Amazon gold-mining camp.

title: Chronicle
description: Last week ''Roseanne'' was the top-rated television show, with a 14.6 rating and a 26-point audience share, according to the Neilsen ratings. Also last week, ROSEANNE BARR, the show's star, sang the national anthem at a baseball game in San Diego, then grabbed her crotch and spat on the field.

title: Miniature Houses, But Grand Visions
description: Eric Lansdown chisels grand visions down to manageable size. He builds fancy miniature houses endowed with architecturally correct details. The houses come complete with painted ivy and trees in front, stains and chipped bricks - in short, ''everything but cracked windows,'' he said.

title: Child Custody in New York
description: To The Home Section:

title: A Skinny Loft Gains Space and Style
description: WHEN Tony Origlio and Kip Vanderbilt first saw their loft in 1985, it looked like a bowling alley with a dazzling view. Although the 70-foot-long loft had a 13th-floor view of the Hudson River and the skyscrapers of midtown Manhattan, it was just 12 feet wide.

title: Sidney Brill, Civil Engineer, 64
description: Sidney Brill, a civil engineer and the owner of a public-works construction company, died on Monday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan. He died of lung cancer, his family said.

title: Huge Financial Stakes for Golf Tours Looming Over Issue of Racial Exclusion
description: The decision by Shoal Creek Country Club to admit black members seems to have stemmed the flight of advertisers from the telecasts of next week's Professional Golfers' Association Championship, and one company, Spalding Sports Worldwide, said yesterday that it might reverse its position and buy commercials on the television broadcast of the tournament.

title: Company News;   Washington Bank
description: Washington Bancorporation filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company listed known liabilities of $61.7 million and assets with undetermined market value. The company said its main banking unit, the National Bank of Washington, would be unable to restore its capital to required levels. But the filing does not include National Bank of Washington or the parent concern's other banking units.

title: New Program on AIDS To Focus on Infections
description: The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is setting up a program to help scientists design new drugs to treat the infections that kill people with AIDS.

title: Pentagon Drafts Strategy for Post-Cold War World
description: The Pentagon has drafted a blueprint for United States military strategy in the 1990's with the assumption that once Soviet forces withdraw from Eastern Europe it would take Moscow up to two years to mobilize for a major invasion.

title: Islanders Sign Two
description: Jari Gronstand, a defenseman, and Bill Berg, a left wing, signed multiyear contracts with the Islanders yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Cracks in a Foundation

title: Met Opera Appoints a General Director
description: Joseph Volpe, who began 26 years ago as an apprentice carpenter backstage at the Metropolitan Opera, was appointed the company's chief administrative officer yesterday, effective immediately. He succeeds Hugh Southern, who was forced to resign in June after only seven months as general manager.

title: Steinbrenner's Son Passes One Hurdle to Power
description: Hank Steinbrenner, designated by George Steinbrenner as the chosen successor to run the Yankees franchise, has cleared one of the three hurdles necessary to make his father's wish a reality and appears assured of clearing the second.

title: Saratoga Opening Day Just About Perfect
description: Meadow Star, Fourstardave and 24,552 horseplayers were the biggest winners this afternoon on a nearly flawless 122d opening day at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Defendant in Rape of Jogger Denies Taking Part in Attack
description: Yusef Salaam repeatedly and emphatically denied yesterday that he had had any part in the rape and near-fatal beating of a jogger in Central Park.

title: Nynex Plans Pedestrian's Mobile Phone
description: The Nynex Corporation plans to spend at least $100 million to build a second cellular telephone network in Manhattan by Christmas of next year, company officials said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: 6 SAILORS DROWN AS FREIGHTER SINKS
description: Six sailors were drowned yesterday after their freighter, her lifeboats and rafts too poorly maintained to use, was pummeled by Hurricane Bertha's 90-mile-an-hour winds and broke up in the Atlantic about 400 miles east of New York.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about Donald Trump and boxing misstated Bill Cayton's managerial relationship with Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion. Although estranged from Tyson, Cayton is still formally his manager.

title: Dukakis Signs His State's Disputed Budget
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today signed the $13.4 billion budget the Legislature sent to him on Saturday, ending seven months of bitter negotiations.

title: House Passes Farm Bill Limiting Subsidies
description: The House approved a 1990 farm bill today that limits commodity subsidies, but not to the low levels sought by members criticizing agriculture spending.

title: Players Wait for Steinbrenner But the Owner Doesn't Show
description: Players waited and reporters waited and photographers waited, but there was no George Steinbrenner yesterday. Not at Yankee Stadium, where he was expected to appear and meet with the players in perhaps his final session with them as the principal owner.

title: Don't Let Congress Hobble the Cable Industry;   Fiber Optic Highway
description: To the Editor:

title: East Europeans Need Private College Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Let Congress Hobble the Cable Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News;   MCI-Telecom Deal
description: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $1.25 billion merger of the MCI Communications Corporation and Telecom USA Inc. MCI said the merger to be completed before the end of the month, pending state regulatory approvals. MCI plans to acquire all of Telecom's outstanding common shares for $42 each, or about $1.25 billion.

title: Health;   Pet Owners Go to the Doctor Less
description: Elderly people who own pets visit their physicians less often than those who do not have pets, and dog owners have the fewest visits of all, a study has found.

title: Leading Indicators Remain Level
description: The Government's main gauge for forecasting the direction of the economy did not budge in June, the Commerce Department said today in a report that analysts said was a sign of a listless economy in the months ahead.

title: Chandler Deal Fails
description: Chris Chandler, the disgruntled Indianapolis quarterback, was back at square one yesterday after the Colts announced the failure of a deal to trade him to Tampa Bay.

title: A Plea for Help
description: This column is an appeal for a special kind of help from Americans who do not live in the big cities - for those of us who do.

title: Fuel Emergency Is Declared For Avianca Jet
description: Air traffic controllers took the unusual step Tuesday night of declaring a fuel emergency on an Avianca Airlines flight headed for Kennedy International Airport because of confusion over how much fuel it had left, one of the controllers and Federal aviation officials said last night.

title: Pentagon Has Earned No Environmental Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Players from the New York metropolitan area were outstandingly successful in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Boston last week, with at least a share in all the major titles.

title: U.S. Tells of Plan to Sell 130 S.& L.'s
description: The Government announced plans today to sell 130 more failed savings institutions and about $50 billion in securities and real estate properties by the end of the year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Miscellany
description: Travel Agent Magazine has been sold by Capital Cities Media Inc. to a partnership headed by Richard Friese, who will serve as the weekly's publisher. Friese's partnership also publishes Unique Homes Magazine.

title: Steinbrenner Not Out of Woods
description: As George Steinbrenner continued to go quietly into the final days of his tenure as the Yankees' boss, his aides continued trying to practice the political art of damage control yesterday.

title: New Europe Alliance In Economics Accord
description: The leaders of Italy, Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary and Yugoslavia, meeting for the first time as a new regional alliance, agreed today to step up political and economic cooperation to promote stability on the changing continent.

title: Evolution in Europe;   2 Germanys Reach Accord on Election Rules
description: The Governments of East and West Germany and their main political parties reached basic agreement today on holding a national election in a unified country on Dec. 2.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Helping Hands Change Tire on Road to Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonald's Waste Study Planned
description: The McDonald's Corporation, which has resisted efforts in some localities to ban its plastic packaging, has agreed to a conduct a joint study with the Environmental Defense Fund on the way it uses and disposes of its packaging and other solid waste.

title: Whereabouts of 500,000 Gallons of Oil Is Baffling in Texas Spill
description: Coast Guard officials said today that they were uncertain what had become of much of the estimated 500,000 gallons of oil that spilled four days ago when a tanker collided with two barges in the Houston Ship Channel.

title: Embattled Futures Chief Resigns
description: Karsten (Cash) Mahlmann resigned today as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest futures exchange, a day after Federal regulators charged an affiliate of his financially troubled commodities firm with misusing customer funds.

title: To Expand Javits Center, Reopen the Coliseum
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News;   Whirlpool Venture
description: The Whirlpool Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company formed a venture to operate Whirlpool's 750-employee vacuum cleaner plant in Danville, Ky. Terms were not disclosed, but Whirlpool will retain a large minority interest in the venture. Whirlpool vacuum cleaners at the plant under the Kenmore name for Sears, Roebuck & Company. The venture will continue that business.

title: Missing Words, and Election Chaos
description: Because of two missing words, and a law that puts a premium on the absurd, an insurgent candidate is working hard to invalidate scores of nominating petitions in the Bronx. The spectacle makes one more eloquent argument for reform of New York State's notoriously niggling Election Law.

title: Ending Feud, India's Leader Dismisses Powerful Deputy
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh dismissed his powerful deputy today for making unsubstantiated charges of corruption against other members of the Cabinet, Indian news agencies said.

title: Sharp Rise in AIDS Infection Is Reported in Third World
description: Eight to ten million people around the world are now infected with the virus that causes AIDS, and the incidence of the infection is rising dramatically in some parts of the world, the World Health Organization reports.

title: Canadian Output Down
description: Canada's economy shrank in May, marking the first back-to-back monthly decline since the 1982 recession, the Government said on Tuesday. Gross domestic product in May fell two-tenths of 1 percent after declining one-tenth of a percent in April, Statistics Canada said. ''It reflects the fact that we're close to the edge of recession,'' said George Saba, an economist at Montreal Trust.

title: Budget Planners Announce Talks
description: President Bush and Congressional negotiators are planning uninterrupted bargaining sessions at Camp David, Md., or a similarly isolated spot outside Washington in early September to work out a final compromise on the 1991 Federal budget, senior lawmakers in both parties said today.

title: The Media Business;   Time Warner's Sports Unit
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it was forming a sports marketing company called Time Warner Sports to expand the corporation's sports ventures and acquire a broad array of sports rights.

title: Topics of The Times;   An Ordinary Immortal
description: Anyone consulting The Complete Baseball Book on Tuesday afternoon would have found only 19 names on the list of pitchers with 300 major league victories, including Denton T. Young and Robert M. Grove. But by midnight E.S.T., one more name had joined Cy and Lefty on that rarified roster - L. Nolan Ryan.

title: Postbabies
description: LEAD: It's apparent that the cultural climate in America during the past decade has shifted radically away from preadolescence backwards into post-babyism. We no longer prefer the merely comic but now the explicitly moronic.

title: Dow Drops 5.94; Bank Stocks Off Sharply
description: Stocks fell slightly yesterday, with bank shares giving ground amid fears that the industry could be facing difficult times.

title: Cardinals Pick Torre To Replace Herzog
description: To the surprise of hardly anyone, Joe Torre was named manager of the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday. The hiring ended a monthlong search for a successor to Whitey Herzog, who, in the middle of his 11th season as skipper, resigned on June 6 with the Cardinals in last place in the National League East.

title: Charles H. Willard, Lawyer, 85
description: Charles H. Willard, a retired partner of Davis Polk & Wardwell, a Manhattan law firm, died on Monday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 85 years old. He died of pneumonia, his wife, Nancy, said. Mr. Willard, who specialized in practice relating to banking, joined the firm in 1930 and became a partner in 1950. He retired in 1973. He was a member of the executive council of the American Law Institute for many years.

title: World Bank Aids Poland
description: The World Bank said on Wednesday that it would lend $300 million to Poland to help that country shift from Communism to a market-oriented economy. The loan will be used to finance imports of basic goods and to provide unemployment compensation, training and employment services to workers who lose their jobs.

title: House Democrats Vow To Stand by Rights Bill
description: As the House of Representatives opened debate today on a major civil rights bill, Democratic leaders vowed to reject revisions that backers say would be the only way to avert a Presidential veto.

title: Theodore Birnbaum, Executive, 73
description: Theodore Birnbaum, a New York business executive, died on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Review/Concert;   Philharmonic Opens Free Park Series
description: New York's fickle weather so far this summer has evidently left outdoor-music lovers feeling not only clammy, but also a bit leery. On Monday, all was well for the opening of the New York Philharmonic's season of free concerts in the parks; a promising afternoon gave way to a gorgeous, cool evening on the Great Lawn in Central Park. Yet despite the added enticement of a fireworks display after the concert, the turnout was modest by the standards of such events: some 50,000 people, in the official police estimate.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Wreckage of Armenian Plane Is Found in Disputed Region
description: The wreckage of a plane carrying 30 people from Armenia was found early today in the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, the Tass press agency reported.

title: AIDS Services To the Homeless To Be Expanded
description: The Dinkins administration plans to provide more testing, treatment and housing for homeless people with AIDS under a broad new program to be announced today.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Telephone Service Is Cut Off Between U.S. and Kuwait
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that all telephone service between the United States and Kuwait was cut off without explanation yesterday at 6:37 P.M. Eastern daylight time.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Accounts
description: * Thompson Medical/Slimfast and General Foods USA, to Lubicom Communications, New York, for the Jewish-market advertising of Slimfast weight-loss products and Post Raisin Bran cereal, respectively.

title: Managua Journal;   What Ended, Battle Begins Over Sandinista Legacy
description: For more than a decade, anyone with doubts about who ran this country could lift his eyes to the Managua skyline, where giant letters on a hillside spelled ''F.S.L.N.,'' the initials in Spanish of the Sandinista National Liberation Front. Recently, however, the famous letters were altered to form a different message: ''Fin'' -or simply, ''The End.''

title: Atlanta Archbishop Had Tie to Woman
description: The recent resignation of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Atlanta came about after he was confronted with evidence of an ''intimate relationship'' with a single 27-year-old Atlanta singer, church officials said today.

title: U.S.-Japan Phone Pact
description: The United States and Japan have resolved a trade dispute over barriers that have blocked foreign companies from the Japanese telecommunications market.

title: Time for U.S. To Cross Magic Line
description: The Goodwill Games may be history as soon as Ted Turner stops performing the wave in public and takes a meeting with his accountant.

title: Hussein Must Be Stopped . . .
description: The seizure of Kuwait sends a further signal that President Saddam Hussein, the megalomaniacal leader of Iraq, must be stopped. If he is not, the consequences will be perilous for the Middle East and for the world.

title: Math Education in New York Must Change for a New Century
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Panel Lets Lilco Drop Evacuation Plan
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the Long Island Lighting Company could scrap its disputed and costly emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant now that most of its nuclear fuel has been removed.

title: Film Fallout: Bright Lights, Cranky City
description: Six times in the last month, the eastbound lanes of the Brooklyn Bridge were closed for a full night, stranding thousands of unwitting commuters in snarled, honking processions along other escape routes from lower Manhattan.

title: Anti-Semitism Hasn't Tainted Solidarity Rift;   One-Sided Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News;   Kansas Gas Board Rejects Takeover
description: The directors of the Kansas Gas and Electric Company unanimously rejected the hostile offer of $27 a share in cash, or $857 million, from the Kansas City Power and Light Company as inadequate. In a letter to shareholders, Wilson K. Cadman, the chairman and president of Kansas Gas, said the acquisition ''could have significantly adverse effect on the company's employees, customers and the communities it serves.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, a holding company for insurance and health-care subsidiaries, named Dennis H. Ferro managing director of its international investment division. The company also named Nicholas Taylor managing director of its international investment advisers unit.

title: Fed's Uncertain Power Over Banking Companies
description: At a time when Federal regulators are scrutinizing the ailing banking industry more closely than ever, a recent Federal court decision has raised the issue of how much control regulators have over the bank holding companies that own the nation's largest banks.

title: Boskin's View on Recession
description: Amid a continuing barrage of weak reports on the economy, Michael J. Boskin, the Presidential adviser, said today that the chance of a recession during the next 12 months, while ''low,'' is ''certainly not zero.''

title: Allies Assess Japan Policy
description: The United States and the European Community renewed pressure today on Japan to import more foreign goods.

title: Campaign Finance Debate Reveals Anxiety in House
description: One day after the Senate ended years of deadlock and approved a major bill to tighten campaign finance laws, the House of Representatives found itself mired today in a dispute among Democrats who feared that the House version could damage their re-election prospects.

title: Review/Pop;   Betty Garrett Remembers When
description: Late in a one-woman show that is rich with salty show business anecdotes, Betty Garrett recalls a meeting with Louis B. Mayer at which the MGM studio boss poked her, knocked her out of her chair and stamped on her toes while pontificating on the do's and don'ts of movie stardom.

title: 16 Months After Valdez Spill, Oil Bill Nears Final Passage
description: The Senate today unanimously approved legislation that is designed to prevent oil spills and to insure that oil companies and carriers pay for damage.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Madison Avenue Street Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed on Sunday from 37th to 50th Streets from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title:
Law;

Working Part Time Without Paying the Penalty
description: LEAD: Trying to recruit and retain the most promising young lawyers, law firms are increasingly accommodating their requests to work part time. Part-time arrangements, which commonly have relegated the lawyers to the ''mommy track'' with no hope of achieving partnership, may now merely delay partnership decisions.

title: Jets' Lyons Enjoying Coslet's New System
description: Bruce Coslet, the Jets' new coach, has declared that under the system he's putting together for the team everybody is regarded as a rookie. There are exceptions, of course, and they are 17th-year place-kicker Pat Leahy and the crafty veteran manning the defensive line, Marty Lyons.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Past Into Present

title: ...And Sanctions Can Do the Trick
description: LEAD: It is often said that economic sanctions ''never work.'' This isn't true. Yet, unless the Bush Administration can overcome the traditional reluctance of the Europeans and Japanese and persuade them to join its sanctions against Iraq, it will only confirm that general skepticism.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   ISRAELIS CONDEMN BAGHDAD'S STRIKE
description: Israeli leaders publicly condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait today and warned that it would contribute to a further destabilization of the Middle East, but they also appeared relieved by the move.

title: Anti-Semitism Hasn't Tainted Solidarity Rift;   Let Us Not Overstate
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene;   On Measuring Living Standards
description: THE revolutions in Eastern Europe have been driven by people's conviction that their standard of living rotted under Communism. You cannot find evidence of this decay in the official data. ''Under the Communist regimes, data have simply been faked in some cases, and collected on a very inadequate conceptual basis in other cases,'' according to David Lipton and Jeffrey Sachs, American economists who have been serving as economic advisers to Solidarity in Poland.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   70's-Style Price Shock Not Likely in This Oil War
description: A new round of economic warfare seemed to be under way yesterday, as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait resurrected both higher oil prices and fears of OPEC domination of the world oil market. But many ground rules have changed, both for nations that export oil and for those that import it.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Tokyo Sees No Threat To Its Reserves of Oil
description: Japan today deplored the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, saying it was watching developments with ''great concern'' but no immediate fear of a serious energy shortage.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   In Two Arab Capitals, Gunfire and Fear, Victory and Cheers
description: Iraqi troops who invaded Kuwait before dawn today swiftly gained the upper hand in the capital despite occasionally fierce resistance by outnumbered Kuwaiti defenders.

title: On Stage
description: Many Hats, but Just One Jacket

title: Renoir Series Is Extended
description: A retrospective of films by Jean Renoir has been extended through Aug. 23 at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place. Admission to each program is $6 ($5 for students and the elderly). Information: 598-7171. Here is a schedule.

title: Herbert O. Fisher, 81, Test Pilot and Official
description: Herbert O. Fisher, a test pilot and a retired aviation executive of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died on Sunday at Chilton Memorial Hospital in Kinnelon, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Kinnelon.

title: German Company to Buy Fireman's Fund
description: Allianz A.G., Europe's largest insurance company, announced yesterday that it would buy the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, the American property and casualty insurer, for $3.3 billion in cash.

title: Company News;   Pilot Effort At Eastern Is Backed
description: Union pilots who joined a strike against Eastern Airlines have the right to replace trainees hired during the carrier's rebuilding, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Savings Inquiry Is Defended
description: In an optimistic assessment of the Government's drive to prosecute criminal fraud in the savings and loan industry, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said at a Senate hearing today that every major accusation of wrongdoing is under investigation by the Justice Department.

title: Uprising Over, but Trinidad Emergency Persists
description: This normally sleepy Caribbean capital was still abuzz today with talk of the electrifying kidnapping of the Prime Minister, half the Cabinet and about 50 other people.

title: Profits Scoreboard
The Iraqi Invasion;   West Europeans Join U.S. in Condemning Invasion
description: West European countries today unanimously condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, with Britain and France joining the United States in freezing billions of dollars in Kuwaiti assets to prevent them from falling into Iraqi hands.

title: Heavy Metal Doesn't Make You a Dropout
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime and the Commissioner: Pressure Mounts for Results
description: Six months after taking office with a mandate from the Mayor to ''take back our streets and our parks, by night as well as by day,'' Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown, while well regarded, has yet to show that he can make a difference.

title: Ousted India Minister Rallies His Followers
description: Calling Prime Minister V. P. Singh ''spineless,'' India's ousted Deputy Prime Minister today called on millions of his followers and farmers to pour into the capital in a show of strength.

title: Diner's Journal
description: New Venture in Miami

title: Anti-Semitism Hasn't Tainted Solidarity Rift;   What Problem?
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Long-Term U.S. Bonds Tumble
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled yesterday, sending interest rates up, after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The invasion raised the specter of a resurgence of oil-fueled inflation, which would undermine the values of bonds and other fixed-income securities.

title: Editorial Notebook;   East Germany's Hero City
description: To understand the swift collapse of East German Communism, see Leipzig. There one can dine in the fine restaurant in the Gewandhaus symphony hall, facing what is still called Karl-Marx-Platz, the epicenter of the upheaval that ended four decades of Marxist rule.

title: Review/Art;   African and Other Portraits, Side by Side
description: Within the art world, there has been a tendency for some time to approach the art of other cultures in one of two ways. One way is based on an assumption that aspects of art are universal and that what one culture values in art is a standard by which the art of other cultures can be measured. Behind the second is a conviction that other cultures are so radically different from our own that no common ground exists and that any attempt to measure the art of those cultures in anything other than its own terms is unjust.

title: Trevino Backs Toyota
description: Lee Trevino will play in the P.G.A. Championship next week in Shoal Creek, Ala., but without wearing shirts bearing the Toyota name after the Toyota Motor Corporation pulled its commercials from the telecast in protest of exclusionary membership practices at the Shoal Creek Country Club, the tournament site.

title: Macy's Gets A Good Price For 1% Stake
description: R. H. Macy & Company, in a move dors about the retailer's financial strength, said yesterday that it had sold a 1 percent stake in the company for a price that values its equity at $1.5 billion - about four times what investors paid when the company was taken private four years ago.

title: Review/Photography;   Ladies and Gentlemen, Welcome to My Life
description: Although art galleries will never replace confessionals, many contemporary artists have taken to using their personal experiences as the primary subject matter of their art. This can be seen as a reflection of what the historian Christopher Lasch has called the culture of narcissism, or else as a reaction to the sardonic emphasis on media experience in the art of the 1980's. But most of this new autobiographical art is not self-indulgent or nostalgic; instead, at its best it is emotionally charged and analytical.

title: Reviews/Music;   Shinehead's Lessons In Morality
description: Shinehead has a dual mission, social and musical. His lyrics promote black self-improvement, saying yes to ambition and unity, no to drugs and broken families. And his music builds a coalition between hip-hop, the music of young American-born blacks, and reggae, the music of a growing community of transplanted Caribbean people; he sings, raps and ''toasts'' in the style of Jamaican dance-hall deejays, his accent shifting with the genre.

title: Dow Slumps 34.66 Points, But Oils Soar
description: Inflation fears touched off by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait pushed most stock prices lower yesterday, including airlines and other users of petroleum products, but sent oil and oil-service stocks sharply higher.

title: Backing Pentagon, Bush Says Military Can Be Cut 25% in 5 Years
description: President Bush said today that the nation's armed forces could be cut by 25 percent over the next five years, as America adapts its military strategy to suit the new era of spreading democracy.

title: Chronicle
description: The National Gallery of Art received nearly $3 million yesterday from funds established by the late LILA ACHESON WALLACE, co-founder of Reader's Digest. The money, $2.9 million, was given by GEORGE V. GRUNE, who is doubly involved with the gift as chairman of the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund and chairman and chief executive of Reader's Digest.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Sketches of the Iraqi and Kuwaiti Leaders
description: Saddam Hussein

title: Business Digest
description: The Iraqi Invasion

title: Latin Plan On Trade
description: Central American economic ministers agreed on Wednesday to a plan to eliminate gradually regional trade barriers and called for the creation of a Central American free-trade zone by 1992.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   U.N. Condemns the Invasion With Threat to Punish Iraq
description: The United Nations Security Council voted overwhelmingly early this morning to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, demanding the immediate, unconditional withdrawal of all of Baghdad's forces from the tiny Persian Gulf nation, and threatening to invoke mandatory sanctions if it does not promptly comply.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: From Africa

title: Anti-Semitism Hasn't Tainted Solidarity Rift
description: To the Editor:

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   ARMS FLOW TO IRAQ HALTED BY SOVIETS
description: The Soviet Union tonight announced that it had suspended the delivery of arms and military hardware to Iraq after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Smokers Vow Strikes As Cigarettes, Too, Disappear
description: It happens like clockwork, all over the city. A truck pulls up to a boarded-up kiosk, unloads its wares, the sale window opens and within minutes smokers appear out of nowhere to take places in line, hopeful that for this day, anyway, their addiction can be fed.

title: Genetic Link Indicated In Lung Cancer Study
description: A study of 337 Louisiana families suggests that there is a genetic component to lung cancer, researchers say.

title: Crackdown in a 'Freer' Korea Puzzles Opposition
description: Two years ago this summer Kim Keun Tae was out of jail for the first time in years, his release hailed as a harbinger that South Korea's new, more democratic Government was willing to tolerate dissent and end a decade of systematic repression.

title: Review/Dance;   A Choreographer and His Themes
description: Eleo Pomare, a provocative choreographer on the New York dance scene for three decades, was honored last Friday evening at the Fiorello Festival of performances at the Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music and the Arts.

title: Homeless Man Is Arrested In Killing of Ad Executive
description: A homeless man was arrested Wednesday night and charged with killing an advertising executive who was making a call at a pay telephone in the West Village, the police said.

title: Review/Art;   The Genius And Panache Of Africa's 'Parisians'
description: DURING the last six years, New York City has been treated to several outstanding, and sometimes provocative, exhibitions of African art, thanks to the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum and especially the Center for African Art. Now the American Museum of Natural History is being heard from, and its ''African Reflections: Art From Northeastern Zaire'' is equal to the best of its predecessors.

title: Miss Leventhal Wed in Glen Head
description: Ilysse Ann Leventhal, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Leventhal of Roslyn, L.I., was married yesterday to Franklin Bruce Rimalovski, a son of Frances Hochman of Great Neck, L.I., and Dr. Alexander B. Rimalovski of Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan officiated at the Glen Head Country Club in Glen Head, L.I.

title: Father Defends His Son At Central Park Trial
description: The father of a defendant in the Central Park jogger trial testified yesterday that his son was forced to sign an incriminating statement without understanding it and without detectives first warning him against self-incrimination.

title: Market Place;   Food Companies Still in Favor
description: A NUMBER of analysts are recommending food stocks to investors, or in stock market parlance ''overweight'' their portfolios with those issues.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Rupert Holmes Onstage
description: No contemporary songwriter, save Stephen Sondheim, is fonder than Rupert Holmes of writing songs that present teasing little puzzles and games. In songs like ''Terminal'' and ''By the Way,'' Mr. Holmes makes a point of finding more than one meaning for the words of his titles. In other songs, like ''Answering Machine,'' his 1979 hit ''Escape (''The Pina Colada Song''), and ''Letters That Cross in the Mail,'' he shows how systems designed to facilitate communication between people can play tricks on them.

title: Girl, 15, Is Shot By a Gunman At a Bronx Park
description: A 15-year-old was shot and critically wounded early yesterday in the Bronx when a gunman opened fire on a group of friends with whom she was standing in a park on the Grand Concourse, the police said.

title: Wheat Prices Up Slightly; Corn and Soybeans Decline
description: Wheat futures prices closed slightly higher today on the Chicago Board of Trade, but the corn and soybean markets fell, extending Wednesday's losses amid forecasts for more good crop weather in the Midwest.

title: Company's Rise is Built on Credit
description: Credit cards are now being tried in fast-food outlets, grocery stores, movie theaters and other places that have historically not accepted them. And that is music to Hatim A. Tyabji's ears.

title: In the House: A Vote to Remember
description: Voters in every Congressional district in America have reason to watch how their representatives vote on the campaign reform bill likely to come up in the House today.

title: Klima Pleads Guilty
description: Petr Klima, a former left wing for the Detroit Red Wings who now plays for the Edmonton Oilers, yesterday pleaded guilty in Pontiac, Mich., to four misdemeanor charges stemming from a 1989 drunken-driving arrest. He is to be sentenced Aug. 23. He faces a maximum of two years in prison. (AP)

title: Sunday Silence Joins Easy Goer In Retirement After Leg Injury
description: Sunday Silence today joined his rival Easy Goer as an early casualty of the racing season when he was retired from racing because of a torn ligament in his left foreleg.

title: Review/Festival Latino;   El Salvador's Violence Hits Home
description: The civil war in El Salvador comes home with predictable violence in ''La Misma Sangre'' (''The Same Blood''), a play by Carlos Velis presented at the Public Theater as part of the Festival Latino.

title: Our Towns;   A Nice Town, But Think Twice Before Parking
description: It's always a hassle when your car is towed. First you have to find out where the car has been taken, then you have to hand over a lot of money to get it out of the lot. In Newburgh, that's if you're lucky.

title: Istomin Pays Mozart
description: Eugene Istomin will be the soloist with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21 in C (K. 467) at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8. The program, to be conducted by Gerard Schwarz, also includes Schubert's Eighth Symphony and his incidental music for ''Rosamunde.'' The program will be repeated evening at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Miscellany
description: * Hill & Knowlton Inc., New York, said the 34 employees of Wexler, Reynolds, Fuller, Harrison & Schule, a Washington public affairs firm, will join the company as a separate unit called the Wexler Group. Craig L. Fuller was named president and chief operating officer of Hill & Knowlton Public Affairs Worldwide, and Anne Wexler was appointed vice chairman.

title: Queens Youth Fatally Shot in Fight Over Moped
description: A 14-year-old from Queens was shot and killed on Wednesday night in an argument over a moped, the police said.

title: Nynex to Establish Office To Address Ethical Issues
description: The Nynex Corporation, which faces criminal and civil lawsuits and regulatory penalties after accusations of impropriety, will create an office of ethics and business conduct, company officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Festival Latino;   'Cronica de una Muerte' In Spanish at the Public
description: As with Gabriel Garcia Marquez's other novels, ''Chronicle of a Death Foretold'' (''Cronica de una Muerte Anunciada'') is suffused with sensuality and mysticism. Despite the absence of suspense, it is a compelling mystery with the author as investigator trying to understand an event that has become an obsession. Shifting between violent reality and visionary dreams, the brief novel is as precise in its prefigurement as any classic prophecy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 26 about Soviet staff members of the United Nations Secretariat misstated the position of Gail Bindley-Taylor, vice president of the United Nations staff union. She said the status of the Soviet staff members was confused; she did not say they were ''secretive.''

title: Reviews/Music;   No Imitation, But Echoes Of a Band
description: Of the 16 musicians in the John Fedchock-Maria Schneider Big Band, which played on Monday evening at Zanzibar and Grill, 550 Third Avenue, at 36th Street, 11 of them, including Mr. Fedchock, are veterans of the orchestra led by Woody Herman. So it is not surprising that echoes of the driving power of Mr. Herman's celebrated Thundering Herd sweep through the Fedchock-Schneider orchestra.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 26 about Coast Guard action against Joseph Hazelwood, the captain of the Exxon Valdez when the oil tanker ran aground in Alaska, misidentified the California port where the tanker was repaired. The ship was in dry dock in San Diego, not Long Beach.

title: The Media Business;   Reed Buys Magazine
description: Reed International P.L.C., a British publishing company, said today that it had acquired the Estates Gazette Ltd., a property magazine, for $:59.4 million, about $110 million. It said it was paying $:50 million for the publishing business and $:9.4 million for the group's property interests. A further $:5 million may be payable depending on advertising revenue over the three years ending on Dec, 31, 1993. Completion of the acquisition is expected on Aug. 31.

title: Margaret Brown, 98, Retired Educator, Dies
description: Dr. Margaret Brown, a former president of the Panzer College of Physical Education and Hygiene in East Orange, N.J., died on Monday at the Hospital Center at Orange. She was 98 years old and lived in Maplewood, N.J.

title: Results Plus
description: GOODWILL GAMES

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   People
description: * Delbert K. Collins and Michael C. Hall, account directors, have been promoted to senior vice presidents of Leo Burnett Co.

title: Race, or Racism, in Social Studies?
description: Does New York State's social studies curriculum fairly reflect the nation's racial and cultural diversity? The question has produced passionate political response. Sensibly, the State Board of Regents has now approved a committee of teachers, administrators and scholars who can offer a scholarly answer.

title: The Media Business;   Meredith Posts a Loss
description: The Meredith Corporation announced today that it lost $49.9 million in its fourth quarter.

title: Reading The Text
description: When hearings get under way next month on the nomination of Judge David Souter to the Supreme Court, it would be a relief if senators and others dropped from their vocabularies the weary slogans applied to judges in recent years. We have had enough of ''activist'' and ''originalist'' and the like.

title: Abused Children vs. the Bill of Rights
description: A hung jury in Raymond Buckey's second trial on charges of molesting children at the McMartin pre-school in California ends that case. But debate over how far states can constitutionally go to combat child abuse has only just begun. This year, a divided Supreme Court rebuffed claims under the First, Fifth and Sixth Amendments and upheld three state efforts to stop child abuse.

title: Saratoga's Proud Place in the Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend;   A Selection Ranging From Grim to Glamorous
description: This weekend brings a pop superstar, a song stylist and ''Beauty and the Beast,'' as well as Northern Ireland, Coney Island and Cambodia.

title: Peru Guerrillas Unmoved by Fujimori
description: In his first week in office, President Alberto Fujimori has appealed to two leftist guerrilla groups to open talks aimed at ending their 10-year-old insurgency, but there appears to be little interest from either group.

title: A Punching Patriot From Cuba
description: He's tall, quick with a jab and quicker with an answer for why he's perfectly satisfied boxing not for money but for himself and his homeland, although not necessarily in that order.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, received orders from Linhas Aereas de Mozambique, a Mozambique airline, for two jet transports valued at $117 million.

title: For Italians, Some Horrors Will Not Die
description: This has always been a country with a cultivated eye for intrigue and conspiracy, where truth is rarely so careless as to lie on the surface and even the rain does not fall by chance.

title: Chronicle
description: MYRNA LOY became 85 years old yesterday and she celebrated among friends in Manhattan at what was billed as a Montana barbecue. The host was JAMES KOTSILIBAS-DAVIS, an old friend who was co-author of her biography.

title: Company News;   Trims at Midland
description: Midland Bank P.L.C. said it was cutting 4,000 jobs from its work force of 33,000 by the end of 1991 through attrition and voluntary departures. Midland also reported a profit of about $:22 million, or about $40.5 million, in the first half of the year. That compared with a net loss of $:383 million in the corresponding period in 1989, when the bank raised its provisions for bad loans to third world countries. The bank is not required to report quarterly results.

title: Invading Iraqis Seize Kuwait and Its Oil; U.S. Condemns Attack, Urges United Action
description: WASHINGTON--Iraqi troops stormed into the desert sheikdom of Kuwait today, seizing control of its capital city and its rich oilfields, driving its ruler into exile, plunging the strategic Persian Gulf region into crisis and sending tremors of anxiety around the world.

title: Met Golf Passive On Clubs' Members
description: The Metropolitan Golf Association will not exert pressure on any of its 314 member clubs to change their membership policies.

title: 4,000 Jobs Being Cut By Pratt & Whitney
description: Pratt & Whitney, the big maker of aircraft engines, said today that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs by 1993 because of expected cutbacks in Defense Department contracts.

title: George J. Fleming, 84; Educator and Author
description: George James Fleming, an author, editor and political science professor who became chairman of the regents at Morgan State University in Baltimore, died Wednesday at the age of 84 at his home in Cockeysville, Md. His wife, Hazel, said the cause of death was liver and heart ailments.

title: New Face;   Crashing A Socialite's Cozy World
description: ''If J. D. Salinger and F. Scott Fitzgerald had mated and had a child, Nick Smith is what I think would have happened,'' Christopher Eigeman surmised the other day.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: Tomorrow

title: Review/Film;   So Small, So Cuddly, And, Oh, So Marketable
description: Huey, Dewey, Louie and their friend Webby (her full name is Webbigail) are more than adorable little ducklings. They have become big-money television stars without the help of their Uncle Donald. Their wildly successful syndicated show, ''Duck Tales,'' is funny enough for children, who warm to the young adventure-prone ducks, and savvy enough for parents, who can appreciate touches like Uncle Scrooge McDuck being interviewed for a television show called ''Life Styles of the Filthy Rich.'' Its bright animation is higher in quality than many cartoon features, not to mention the typical low-rent television cartoon.

title: Heir Apparent Is Seen In Promotion at Grace
description: W. R. Grace & Company, the diversified specialty chemical maker, yesterday named J. P. Bolduc as president and chief operating officer, making him the likely successor to J. Peter Grace.

title: Books of The Times;   Signposts Along the Way to Khrushchev's Fall
description: Khrushchev on Khrushchev

title: STEALTH BOMBER BACKED BY SENATE
description: The Senate today rejected efforts to scrap or even curtail production of the Stealth bomber, choosing instead to provide the $4.6 billion that the Air Force has requested for producing two of the planes in 1991 and for continued research and development.

title: More Companies Choosing to Self-Insure Benefits
description: More than 50 percent of the nation's employees with health insurance provided by their employer now work for companies that design and insure their own health benefits, a sharp increase over the past 15 years, an insurance industry group reports.

title: Wisconsin Dells Journal;   Where Beauty's Place Is Behind the Billboards
description: The signs begin nearly 100 miles out, brightly painted billboards spaced at irregular intervals alongside Interstate 94 as it winds north from Illinois: ''Scenic Boat Tours.'' ''Tommy Barlett Thrill Shows.'' ''Visit Wis. Dells.''

title: Law: At The Bar;   The Highwaymen Come Singing, Singing, and Much To The Chagrin of The Originals.
description: Could country music stars like Willie Nelson or Waylon Jennings possibly be confused with Federal Judge Stephen Trott? Would Johnny Cash or Kris Kristofferson want to palm themselves off as Judge Trott? And will the real ''Highwaymen'' please stand up and sing?

title: Lies? Worse? The View From Queens
description: There was no telling 84-year-old Rebecca Claiborne and 82-year-old Benjamin Lance yesterday that their Congressman, Floyd H. Flake, was capable of stealing money meant to help them.

title: Review/Film;   Spike Lee's Middle-Class Jazz Musician
description: SPIKE LEE is an exhilarating mix of brilliance and bravado, of artist, businessman and preacher. In his stylized visions of our racially tense society - the small-scale sexual comedy ''She's Gotta Have It,'' the inventive musical ''School Daze'' and the astounding political and moral drama ''Do the Right Thing'' - he dares viewers and the Hollywood establishent to keep up with his honesty and humor, his passion and visual flair. A new Spike Lee film might be anything at all except dull and conventional, or at least that seemed true until ''Mo' Better Blues.'' From characters to camera angles, this story of a self-absorbed jazz trumpeter is one long cliche, the kind that might make his most loyal admirers wince and wonder, ''Spike, what happened?''

title: Company News;   Clorox Completes Cyanamid Deal
description: The Clorox Company completed the previously announced purchase of the household products business of the American Cyanamid Company for $465 million. Clorox will finance the acquisition from cash on hand and bank borrowings.

title: Chronicle
description: Later this month a committee of the American Bar Association will meet to assess the qualifications of DAVID H. SOUTER, the Federal appellate judge nominated to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by Justice WILLIAM J. BRENNAN Jr., who retired. One of the committee's 15 members is WILLIAM J. BRENNAN 3d, the retired Justice's son, who is a lawyer in New Jersey. The younger Mr. Brennan was named last year to the panel, the Standing Committee on the Federal Judiciary, headed by RALPH I. LANCASTER Jr., a lawyer from Portland, Me.

title: Viola's Six-Hitter Snaps Mets Out of Doldrums
description: The Mets broke out of their ''little valley'' today and started soaring again, and did it with some frontline performances: Frank Viola muzzled the Montreal Expos, 5-1, pitched six-hit ball and won for the 15th time this season. And Darryl Strawberry brought a ringing end to an 0-for-18 slide with a single and a home run.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Shot As Violence Persists On New York Streets
description: The tide of violence in New York City in the last two weeks - four children killed by stray gunfire, an advertising executive shot dead in the West Village, two cab drivers murdered, a young couple bludgeoned in Central Park - continued yesterday as officials struggled to respond to growing fears.

title: President at CPC Adds Chief Executive's Title
description: CPC International Inc., a big but relatively unfamiliar company behind a host of famous food brands, yesterday named its president, Charles R. Shoemate, to the top post of chief executive, as well.

title: House Votes to Let Airports Tax Airline Tickets
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would let airports levy a new tax on airline tickets of up to $12 on a round trip to help pay for improving and expanding the airports.

title: At the Movies
description: O'Neal as Conscience

title: O'Neill Center Presents Readings of 3 Musicals
description: ''Captains Courageous,'' a musical by Patrick Cook and Frederick Freyer from the novel by Rudyard Kipling, will be given the first of three readings, with music, at 8 P.M. tomorrow in the Rose Barns Theater at the O'Neill Theater Center, 305 Great Neck Road, Waterford, Conn.

title: Invading Iraqis Seize Kuwait and Its Oil; U.S. Condemns Attack, Urges United Action
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 - Iraqi troops stormed into the desert sheikdom of Kuwait today, seizing control of its capital city and its rich oilfields, driving its ruler into exile, plunging the strategic Persian Gulf region into crisis and sending tremors of anxiety around the world.

title: Senate Is Expected to Back New Term for Futures Head
description: After a Senate hearing tonight, Wendy Lee Gramm, the chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, was expected to be reconfirmed for another five-year term.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Black Journalists Look to Last Ceiling
description: Participants in the 15th Annual Convention of the National Association of Black Journalists spoke today of reaching out to break what they described as the profession's final barrier, to reach the top levels of management and media ownership.

title: Manila Rebels Free Aid Workers From the Peace Corps and Japan
description: Communist rebels today released a kidnapped Peace Corps volunteer and a Japanese aid worker but warned the United States and Japan to stay out of the Philippine insurgency.

title: Sweeping 20 Miles of Jersey's Littered Shore
description: Thirty-two-year-old William Crenshaw has served 11 months of his sentence for drug possession and has only four months left before he is eligible for parole, so he figures he will stick with the beach cleanup crew, rather than trying for an easier job on work release.

title: INSIDE
description: Why a Bishop Quit

title: A Very Large Player Has Big Ambitions, Too
description: Ed Cunningham is 6 feet 7 3/4 inches tall and weighs 296 pounds. He says he does not know his jacket size because he has to have his clothes made to order.

title: Congress Moves to Overturn A Military Ban on Abortion
description: In a move that could entangle the White House in the abortion issue, Congress is pressing ahead with proposals to overturn a two-year-old Pentagon policy banning virtually all abortions at United States military hospitals overseas.

title: Company News;   Japonica Accepts Plan on Allegheny
description: Japonica Partners agreed with creditors of Allegheny International Inc. to take control of the bankrupt appliance maker on Aug. 15. The partnership, based in New York and Rhode Island, has been pursuing Allegheny for about a year. Allegheny, which filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in February 1988, owns the Sunbeam Corporation, maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Germanys' Rival Broadcasters Now in Same Boat
description: For nearly 45 years, public television and radio broadcasting in West Berlin and East Germany followed the dictates of the cold war.

title: Frank G. O'Neill, War Prosecutor, 83
description: Frank G. O'Neill, a lawyer who served as chief prosecutor of Japanese war criminals in the Philippines after World War II, died Monday at Milton Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 83 years old and lived in Milton.

title: Review/Opera;   Tale of Judith, Updated
description: As soon as the lights go up on the set of ''Judith'' we know where we are, and it definitely is not Israel in Biblical times. We are in the grim land known as German Expressionism, and any doubt as to where the composer, Siegfried Matthus, and the director, Davis Alden, have brought us is erased at the appearance of a black-faced executioner who busies himself hacking off the heads of prisoners with a meat cleaver. We are not in for a night of fun.

title: INDICTMENT NAMES QUEENS LAWMAKER IN MISUSE OF FUNDS
description: Representative Floyd H. Flake, a powerful Queens minister who rode his popularity into Congress four years ago, has been indicted on charges of diverting tens of thousands of dollars in church funds to his own use.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the Yankees' limited partners misstated a comment by one of them, William Rose Jr., about Hank Steinbrenner's prospects for approval as the team's general partner. Mr. Rose said he had heard that at least one partner, not some partners, wanted ''nothing to do with Hank Steinbrenner.''

title: Pirates Keep Up With Mets
description: Bobby Bonilla drove in three runs with two home runs and a double today, and Andy Van Slyke and Barry Bonds hit two-run homers, leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title:
State Aid on Mortgages;

Companies Help Workers Buy Homes in New Jersey
description: LEAD: For lack of the cash to meet a down payment, Hilda and Wilfredo Serrano, a couple in their 40's living in a rental apartment here, had been shut out of the home-buying market for 12 years. When they finally got some help, they bought a two-bedroom Colonial for $95,000.

title: Panel Named for NASA Review
description: Space program officials announced today that two former Congressmen, a former astronaut and several top industry executives and scientists would serve on an advisory committee that is to examine how to manage the nation's future efforts in space.

title: Crash Injures Unser
description: Al Unser Sr. broke his right collarbone and right thigh and damaged some ribs yesterday in a crash while practicing for Sunday's Marlboro 500 at the Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, Mich. Unser was expected to have surgery later in the day.(AP)

title: Evolution in Europe;   As Merger Nears, German Envoys Study Real Estate
description: The other day, West Germany's deputy chief delegate to the United Nations walked up to the front door of a forbidding gray mansion at 58 Park Avenue, rang the bell and was admitted.

title: Law;   Courts Try Computers and Stash the Paper
description: Presented with tons of documents every year and not enough room to store them, state court administrators are embracing computer technology that they hope will eliminate the need for case files.

title: New Jersey Says Coroner Erred In Teaneck Case
description: New Jersey's Chief Medical Examiner has said that the Bergen County Medical Examiner erred in the case of a black teen-ager shot by a police officer here by misidentifying where the bullet entered the youth's body and failing to match the wound to the bullet hole in the youth's jacket.

title: Company News;   Chrysler Prices To Rise 0.9%
description: Facing slumping sales and tough competition, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it planned only minimal increases in its average 1991 car prices in an effort to regain market share.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the first post-cold-war crisis in the economically dependent world. With the end of the East-West game, small countries can act with impunity to rearrange the neighborhood.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Division Chief For Grand Met
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s food sector has put Peter M. Thompson in charge of its division that oversees Pillsbury International, Haagen-Dazs and Grand Met Foodservice U.S.A.

title: New Arianespace Chief
description: Arianespace this week named its Director General, Charles Bigot, to the post of president, replacing Frederic d'Allest as head of Europe's commercial satellite launching program. Mr. D'Allest announced his retirement last week. Mr. Bigot, who is 58 years old, had served in the consortium's second-highest post since 1982. He and Mr. D'Allest won more than half the world's satellite launching business for Arianespace's unmanned rockets. Mr. D'Allest had led Arianespace since its creation in 1980 as the commercial partner of the European Space Agency.

title: The Barnes Foundation Names New President
description: The Barnes Foundation of Merion, Pa., has named Richard H. Glanton as its new president. The foundation administers a major collection of 19th-and 20th-century Impressionist and post-Impressionist art.

title: Lemon's Triple in 14th Lifts Tigers Past Yanks
description: His arrival in late June was nothing spectacular. Kevin Maas was just another rookie from Columbus, no different from Jim Leyritz or Alan Mills or Oscar Azocar. But 25 games have come and gone in his big-league career, and Maas has had a sudden impact.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   INVADING IRAQIS SEIZE KUWAIT AND ITS OIL; U.S. CONDEMNS ATTACK, URGES UNITED ACTION
description: Iraqi troops stormed into the desert sheikdom of Kuwait today, seizing control of its capital city and its rich oilfields, driving its ruler into exile, plunging the strategic Persian Gulf region into crisis and sending tremors of anxiety around the world.

title: Acknowledging Barry's Drug Use: Lawyers See Risk and Advantage
description: After months of denials from Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. that he had ever used illegal drugs before his arrest in January, his lawyer's acknowledgment to the jury on Wednesday that the Mayor had been an occasional cocaine user may have seemed a startling admission.

title: Company News;   Sears in Talks On Ward Link
description: Rumors swept through Wall Street today that two of the nation's largest general merchants -Sears, Roebuck & Company and Montgomery Ward & Company - had begun merger talks but had terminated them.

title: Auctions
description: Pueblo to Plains

title: Chronicle
description: The Rolling Stones will perform in Prague for the first time because PRESIDENT VACLAV HAVEL of Czechoslovakia wants to meet MICK JAGGER. The concert is scheduled for Aug. 18 as part of festivities marking the country's freedom from Communist rule.

title: An Evening of Piano
description: The pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet will play works by Ravel, Brahms and Liszt in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, on Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., at 5:30 P.M. Sunday. Mr. Thibaudet's program includes Ravel's ''Menuet Antique,'' ''A la Maniere de Borodine,'' ''A la Maniere de Chabrier'' and ''Gaspard de la Nuit''; Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Paganini, Book I (Op. 35), and Klavierstucke (Op. 19), and Liszt's ''Jeux d'Eau a la Villa d'Este'' and Paraphrase on Verdi's ''Rigoletto.'' Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-1252.

title: Why the Bar Exam Is Absolutely Crucial
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: When Bouley was first reviewed in 1987, shortly after it opened in TriBeCa, I noted that the restaurant had ''the potential for greatness.''
