Overstriving and wobbly execution, though, resulted in too many near misses and a two-star rating. Today, though, Bouley displays remarkable poise and self-confidence.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 521 money market mutual funds increased $800.1 million, to $395.42 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 168 institutional funds decreased by $100,000, to $97.97 billion. The assets of the 251 general purpose funds were up by $541.5 million, to $136.44 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased by $258.7 million, to $161.01 billion, the institute said. The institute said it had revised its data for the last four weeks to include additional funds.

title: The Iraqi Invasion: Global Reverberations
description: OIL PRICES Spot market prices surged, with the American benchmark crude rising to $23.11 a barrel, up $1.57. The invasion stirred fears of slower economic growth, higher inflation and OPEC domination of the world oil market. But price increases should be limited by a near-record stockpile worldwide. Page A9.

title: Lawmaker Assails Health Chief
description: Calling Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan ''a disgrace to his race,'' the chairman of a Congressional health committee harshly criticized Dr. Sullivan today for opposing proposals for Federally sponsored national health insurance.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Pop/Jazz;   At Lincoln Center, It's Jazz and It's Classical
description: FOR the last three years, Lincoln Center's Classical Jazz series has done what's nearly impossible: delivered jazz in a concert hall that not only sounds good, but that also generates the sort of excitement found in a club. And the programs have often reflected a critical point of view, too. In the process, the series, which is to begin tonight and run through Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, has become the most important jazz program in America, which is less a tribute to commerce than a tribute to jazz as a social force.

title: Covenant Report Is Said to Find Sex Misconduct
description: An investigation ordered by the Covenant House board of directors concludes that the Rev. Bruce Ritter, the charity's founder and longtime president, engaged in sexual misconduct with young men living at Covenant House shelters for runaway youths, according to people who have read the investigation's report.

title: Judge Picks Japan Routes
description: An administrative law judge recommended today that five United States airlines be awarded direct routes to Japan from six American cities.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Hunt For Clients Intensifies
description: AS the competition for new accounts becomes fierce, a growing number of agencies are being forced to learn how to hustle.

title: Rembrandt Exhibition To Tour Europe in 1991
description: Rembrandt will have his first one-man international show next year, when 130 of his works will tour Berlin, Amsterdam and London.

title: Go For Wand Captures Test Stakes With Ease
description: Go for Wand removed any questions about her fitness, quality or status as the nation's best 3-year-old filly by scoring a smashing two-length victory today in the Grade I Test Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Baroque at Caramoor
description: Paula Robison will be the soloist in a program of Baroque flute and piccolo works in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., tonight at 9. The program includes four Vivaldi concertos, a Concerto in D by C. P. E. Bach, and Jacques Hotteterre's ''Echoes'' for solo flute. Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-1252.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   IRAQ'S ADVANTAGE LIMITS U.S. OPTIONS
description: The Bush Administration faced the sobering reality today that despite a longstanding commitment to defend America's vital interests in the Persian Gulf, there was no easy military means to compel Iraq to withdraw its forces from Kuwait.

title: Iraq's Naked Aggression
description: Without warrant or warning, Iraq has struck brutally at tiny Kuwait, a brazen challenge to world law. Iraq stands condemned by a unanimous U.N. Security Council and major Western oil purchasers. President Bush's taste for bluntness stands him in good stead: ''Naked aggression'' is the correct term for President Saddam Hussein's grab at a vulnerable, oil-rich neighbor.

title: The Iraqi Invasion: A New Gulf Alignment;   Iraqis, Bargaining on Anti-U.S. Sentiment, May Profit by Intimidating the Monarchies
description: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ushers in a new alignment in which Iraqis, Iranians and Palestinian hard-liners appear to share an interest in subduing the oil-rich monarchies of the region and challenging United States influence in the Arab world.

title: Norman Maclean, 87, a Professor Who Wrote About Fly-Fishing
description: Norman Maclean, a professor of English who turned his hand to fiction in retirement and wrote an acclaimed book about fishing, died yesterday at his home in the Hyde Park district of Chicago. He was 87 years old.

title: Company News;   Factory in France For Allied-Signal
description: Allied-Signal Inc. announced it would build a $160 million plant in France to manufacture polyester fiber for passenger car tires, seat belts and other products. The company said the plant would be built in Longwy, a city near the Belgian border, for $160 million. It is expected to begin operating by 1993 and employ about 300 workers.

title: Factory Orders Fell 1.5% in June
description: Orders to factories for manufactured goods declined 1.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today. It was the third time this year that the monthly total of orders declined from the month before.

title: Radja to Roma Team For Two Seasons
description: Under an agreement announced yesterday by the Boston Celtics, Dino Radja of Yugoslavia will play for Il Messaggero Roma rather than the Celtics for the next two seasons, in return for an undisclosed amount of cash. The Italian team had announced earlier that the 6-foot-11-inch forward had signed a five-year agreement, for terms that the team did not disclose.

title: U.S. Case Against Barry Goes to Jury
description: After two months of testimony, argument and legal maneuvering that transfixed this city and captured the attention of much of the country, the Government's drug and perjury case against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. went to the jury today.

title: Lawyers for Noriega Win Right to Review Records of 3 Banks
description: A Federal magistrate ordered three European banks today to provide records of Manuel Noriega's accounts believed to contain millions of dollars to his lawyers. The ousted Panamanian dictator says he needs the money for his legal defense on drug smuggling charges.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Official Talks of Record Grain Crop
description: The Soviet Union, the world's biggest grain importer, could harvest a record 260 million tons this year, but waste and inefficiency may cause food shortages, a top farming official said today.

title: Dinkins to Announce Illegal-Gun Amnesty Plan
description: Still grappling to respond to public concern over recent shooting deaths, Mayor David N. Dinkins plans to announce a campaign today to remind people who turn in illegal guns that they may be granted amnesty and to vow to make minimum one-year jail terms stick for those who do not and get caught.

title: Savings Cure May Kill the Patient
description: When President Bush gathered with Congressional leaders in the Rose Garden last Aug. 9 for the signing of the savings and loan bailout bill, he triumphantly declared, ''This legislation will safeguard and stabilize America's financial system and put in place permanent reforms so these problems will never happen again.''

title: Chronicle
description: When a Spanish photographer tried to snap a photo of MADONNA jogging in Barcelona, her chief bodyguard, MARCUS JOHNSON, got rough. But later he went to the newsroom of El Periodico de Cataluna to apologize in person to the photographer, JUAN VALGANON, the paper reported yesterday. Mr. Valganon was bruised in the encounter.

title: Outdoors;   New Series of Relief Maps Offers Stunning Views
description: Raven Maps & Images of Medford, Ore., is publishing a series of handsome shaded-relief maps of various areas of the United States that will delight devotees of such documents.

title: Debris Explodes, Killing Worker
description: One garbage collector was killed and another critically burned yesterday when a box believed to contain propane exploded, the police said.

title: New York's Carnival, All Grown Up
description: Parades, music, eye-popping costumes, dancing in the streets: carnival celebrations are the unmistakable signature of African culture from Lagos to New Orleans to Rio de Janeiro. New York City's carnivals grew up more recently. In Brooklyn, the West Indian-American Carnival Association puts on an annual festival during Labor Day weekend, and since 1985 the Caribbean Cultural Center has presented a Pan-American carnival in Manhattan.

title: Review/Film;   Whit Stillman's 'Metropolitan,' a Modern Comedy of Manners
description: ''Metropolitan'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 23. The film opens today at the Paris, 4 West 58th Street.

title: Our Prison Profiteers
description: They run the new correctional ''hotels,'' and some of their daily rates would make Leona Helmsley blush.

title: Invasion Shakes Up Markets
description: The dollar rose, gold prices jumped and most of the world's stock markets fell as the news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait spread around the world yesterday.

title: Review/Music;   The Classical Band, With a New Leader
description: The Classical Band, New York's only large-scale period-instruments orchestra, is just a little more than one year old, yet it has already been forced to reinvent itself.

title: Washington Talk;   The Target of Choice For the G.O.P.: Mitchell
description: Move over, Mario Cuomo. George Mitchell, the mild-mannered, sober-minded and rarely quotable Senate majority leader, is emerging as the Democrat the Republicans love to hate.

title: Hank Steinbrenner Facing a Vote on Wednesday
description: Whenever the Yankees' limited partners have met in the last 17 1/2 years, they have spent their time listening to the general partner, George Steinbrenner. Not even suggestions, one limited partner has said, could be made.

title: Review/Film;   A Garden Of Secrets, Sordid Ones
description: Sexy, humorous, possessed of great elan and very much in demand with women, the screenwriter Dan Gillis has a lot of appealing qualities not normally associated with Jeff Goldblum, the actor who plays him. With his intense, buggy gaze and his skittish manner, Mr. Goldblum was an inspired choice for ''The Fly,'' and by some will be forever remembered in that capacity.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Bush, in Freezing Assets, Bars $30 Billion to Hussein
description: In freezing Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the United States, President Bush has fenced off an estimated $30 billion from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Government analysts say.

title: Gubicza's Season Ends
description: Mark Gubicza, the Kansas City Royals pitcher, had arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair a tear in his right rotator cuff. The right-hander is expected to recover in time for spring training, said Steve Joyce, the team physician, who did the surgery.

title: To Americans Abroad, Paris Isn't All Feast
description: Chauffeur-driven cars, drinks by the swimming pool, year-round tans and bottomless expense accounts may not be the happy fate of most American expatriates. But to a good many people back home at least, those are just some of the privileges they think are enjoyed by their fellow Americans abroad.

title: House, 255-155, Approves Restrictions on Financing Campaigns
description: The House of Representatives approved a bill late tonight aimed at slowing the rapidly rising costs of Congressional campaigns after a rancorous debate in which some lawmakers questioned whether the legislation would do any good.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TENNESSEE ERNIE FORD and GEORGE JONES are among the five nominees for the Country Music Hall of Fame. Also nominated Thursday by the Country Music Association were DON GIBSON, THE LOUVIN BROTHERS and WEBB PIERCE. Only one of the performers will be inducted at the association's award show Oct. 8.

title: SENATE UPHOLDS BAN OF ABORTIONS
description: Pushing to complete action on a $289 billion military programs bill, the Senate today rejected an amendment that would have overturned a virtual ban on abortions at American military hospitals overseas.

title: Books of The Times;   Observing Karel Capek's Centenary
description: Toward the Radical Center

title: Bess Goodykoontz, Education Official In 1930's, Was 95
description: Bess Goodykoontz, an educator who served as Assistant United States Commissioner of Education in the 1930's and 40's, died Sunday at her daughter's home in South Newfane, Vt. She was 95 years old.

title: Ex-Civic Leader Is Jailed in Drug Smuggling
description: A Federal district judge has sentenced a former president of the Indianapolis League of Women Voters to nine years in prison for her role in a drug-smuggling ring allegedly operated by her sons.

title: Congress Authorizes $875 Million To Fight AIDS in Hard-Hit Areas
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a bill that would authorize $875 million next year to provide health care to people with AIDS in cities and states hardest hit by the epidemic.

title: Milton Sapinsley, 94, Retired Manufacturer
description: Milton C. Sapinsley, a retired manufacturing executive, died Wednesday at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 94 years old.

title: Carl Ekern, Football Player, 36
description: Carl Ekern, a former linebacker with the Los Angeles Rams, died of head injuries on Wednesday when the Jeep he was driving ran off a highway near the Kern County town of Ridgecrest, the California Highway Patrol said.

title: Critic's Notebook;   The Networks Cover Invasion From Afar
description: How can a television news operation cover a war that is over before it begins and to which cameras are not invited? Well, it rolls out stock newsreel clips, hauls in correspondents and lays on experts. Such were the weapons available to the evening news programs as they addressed the swift Iraqi conquest of Kuwait.

title: CHRONICLE
description: J. RICHARD MUNRO and DR. JOSHUA LEDERBERG are new trustees of the National Museum of Health and Medicine Foundation Inc. Mr. Monro, former chairman and chief executive of Time Inc. and chairman of the executive committee of Time Warner Inc., and Dr. Lederberg, a Nobel laureate and exiting president of the Rockefeller University, joined the board of trustees last week. The foundation was formed last year to raise money for a new, expanded museum. The museum offers educational exhibits pertaining to medicine, public health and disease prevention.

title: CLOSE G.O.P. RACE FOR TENNESSEANS
description: Of more than 100,000 votes cast on Thursday, only 158 separated the top two candidates today in a Republican primary race for the right to challenge Senator Al Gore in November's general election.

title: Ex-Officer and Intruder Die
description: A retired New York City policeman killed a suspected burglar early today before dying of stab wounds, the state police said. The retired officer, Alex Bodnar, 49 years old, died after interrupting what investigators believe was a botched burglary by Ronald Cummings, 29, of Newburgh.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Wednesday about ''The Bomb,'' by Makoto Oda, misidentified another novel about the atomic bombing of Hiroshima. It is Masuji Ibuse's ''Black Rain,'' not ''Hard Rain.''

title: Guida Expects to Win His 3d Hambletonian
description: Lou Guida, harness racing's most successful owner, will seek his third Hambletonian victory in four years today when he sends out Embassy Lobell at the Meadowlands.

title: CANDIOTTI'S KNUCKLER QUIETS YANKS TILL 8TH
description: Tom Candiotti's junk was precious. His knuckleball was doing its contortions on its way to the plate and its dirty dancing in front of and behind it.

title: Fuel Emergency For Avianca Jet Said Premature
description: An Avianca jet that was given emergency clearance to land on Tuesday night was not dangerously low on fuel, an official at the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: Let Islanders Decide Puerto Rico's Fate
description: LEAD: The issue of whether Puerto Rico should become the 51st State of the Union, a sovereign nation, or remain a commonwealth appears to be on the minds of everyone who considers themselves Puerto Rican or has a passing interest in the outcome of the 1991 plebescite. And each political side has gathered support from some unlikely allies.

title: House Approves Civil Rights Bill; Veto Is Weighed
description: As Congress moved closer to a monthlong recess, the House of Representatives today approved a major civil rights bill despite threats by President Bush to veto the measure, which he contends would lead to job quotas.

title: New Jersey Approves Trade of Park Land
description: A swap of park land to let the BASF Corporation build a regional headquarters in the International Trade Center in Mount Olive was approved yesterday by the State House Commission.

title: Rights Group Says Baghdad Has Seized Exiles in Kuwait
description: Amnesty International said today that it had received reports that Iraqi forces in Kuwait had arrested hundreds of Iraqi exiles opposed to the Government of Saddam Hussein.

title: Ship's Survivors Arrive in Maine
description: Soviet rescuers today brought ashore 21 survivors of the wreck of a cargo ship, and the saved sailors said they felt ''very lucky'' to have lived through Hurricane Bertha.

title: As India Opens Its Economy, Some Cling to Socialist Ideals
description: At a time when the whole of Eastern Europe is changing, some political leaders in India continue to hold fast to socialist ideals.

title: Lawmaker Says His Racial Insult of Health Secretary Was Mistake
description: The chairman of a health subcommittee told the House today that he should not have called the Secretary of Health and Human Services ''a disgrace to his race'' when he criticized the Secretary's positions on Thursday.

title: Americans in Kuwait: Some Fear but Confidence About Rescue
description: Americans in the besieged capital of Kuwait spoke yesterday of a modern city transformed overnight into a war zone of rattling gunfire and explosions by Iraqi invaders who seized Government buildings, commandeered police cars and chatted on street corners as residents cowered behind locked doors.

title: Patents;   A Device to Protect Whales From Grounding
description: Thomas J. Ford, a dentist in Brookline, Mass., patented a device this week to protect whales and dolphins from becoming grounded in shallow water.

title: Fruit of Appeasement
description: Saddam Hussein of Iraq has answered with a roar the long, dithering argument over whether it was wiser to indulge him or try to isolate and block him. That is why his blitzkrieg invasion of Kuwait, proving his insatiable ambition, has led so many European commentators to remember Hitler. The same kind of argument went on through the 1930's, until it was too late.

title: PRICE OF OIL RISES; STOCKS IN RETREAT
description: Oil prices rose again yesterday and the stock market fell sharply in unusually volatile trading as investors feared that higher energy prices brought on by the turmoil in the Middle East could push an already weak American economy into recession.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Thursday about a performance by the Philip Glass Ensemble on July 27 at Alice Tully Hall misidentified a children's choir whose recorded music was used in presenting Mr. Glass's score for the film ''Powaqqatsi.'' It is the Hispanic Young People's Chorus from Brooklyn, not a South American group.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a music review in Weekend yesterday about Monday's opening of the New York Philharmonic's season of free concerts in parks gave incorrect information for subsequent concerts.

title: U.S. May Not Support East Europe Aid Bank
description: American support for a new lending organization intended to be the main conduit for assistance to Eastern Europe could be cut off by a dispute between Washington and the organization's management, Bush Administration officials warned today.

title: IRAQIS MASS ON SAUDI FRONTIER; ARABS AGREE TO MEET ON CRISIS; BUSH IS READY TO HELP IF ASKED
description: Powerful Iraqi forces wheeled into position for a possible attack on Saudi Arabia today, while the United States and its allies continued to search, without discernible success, for a way to force Iraq to pull back from its rapid conquest of Kuwait on Thursday.

title: David Goldblatt Weds Ms. Schrag
description: Minna Schrag and David Ira Goldblatt, partners in the New York law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, were married yesterday by Judge Whitman Knapp of Federal District Court in his chambers in Manhattan.

title: Price Plunge Continues For Long-Term Bonds
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds continued to crumble and interest rates continued to rise yesterday, as more investors feared that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait would fuel a resurgence of inflation that would undermine the value of fixed-income debt issues.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The poet JOHN ASHBERY and the Nigerian novelist CHINUA ACHEBE will share Bard College's Charles P. Stevenson Jr. chair in literature. The two writers will teach for the two next semesters at the college in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. The chair was previously held by the American novelist MARY McCARTHY, who died last October.

title: Lucy G. Moses, 103, Benefactor Of Hospitals, Schools and Parks
description: Lucy Goldschmidt Moses, a philanthropist, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 103 years old.

title: Gramm Commodity Nomination Is Backed
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee, in a voice vote, today approved the nomination of Wendy Lee Gramm to a second term as the head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Choctaw Pursuing Justin Industries
description: Choctaw Securities L.P. has engaged the New York branch of Creditanstalt-Bankverein to consider providing financing for a possible effort to gain control of Justin Industries Inc. Choctaw, an investment partnership in Kansas City, Mo., now controls 11.6 percent of Justin's 8.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Late Rally Saves The Mets
description: Joe Torre made his home debut as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and for a while outmaneuvered the Mets in a war of strategy. But just when he needed three outs to win, the Mets mounted a dramatic rally, scored three runs in the ninth inning off Lee Smith and snatched the game from Torre's Cardinals, 5-4.

title: Shrines to Lives Taken in Violence
description: On a street corner in Brooklyn an empty chair stands surrounded by flowers where a young man used to sit and drink beer, before he was killed by a gunman in a passing car.

title: Hawaii Lava Flow Closes Black Sand Beach
description: Lava from Kilauea Volcano has closed the Kalapana Black Sand Beach, one of the island's most popular beaches.

title: Northwest Imposes Fuel Surcharge
description: In an effort to offset rising fuel costs, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would add an $8 fuel surcharge each way on all of its domestic tickets.

title: Protecting Yourself From Losing a Home
description: In the Northeast, economic problems have led to a rash of residenatial mortgage foreclosures by commercial banks and other lenders. But conditions in New York and Boston are not typical of what is happening in some other parts of the nation, even though real-estate markets in most places continue to weaken and bank failures are at a near record.

title: Court Approves Shift at Allegheny
description: Allegheny International Inc. said a Federal bankruptcy court had approved an agreement giving a New York investment group control of the company, which makes Sunbeam and Oster appliances. The court approval will allow the investors, Japonica Partners, to take control of Allegheny on Aug. 15. The deal, announced on Thursday by committees representing the company's creditors and shareholders, is contingent on Japonica's raising enough money.

title: A Police Officer is Still the Focus In Bomb Inquiry
description: No one has been charged yet in the death of a Suffolk County narcotics detective who was killed when his car exploded in February. But Robert Horan, the Nassau County police officer who was originally called the chief suspect, is still the focus of the investigation, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Total Petroleum
description: Total Petroleum (North America) Ltd. said its board has authorized management to examine a possible spinoff to shareholders of its Canadian oil and natural gas operations. It said management had retained Morgan Stanley Group Inc. as a financial adviser on the matter and would report to the board later in the year.

title: Rinfret Releases His Tax Returns For 1989 Only
description: Pierre A. Rinfret today reneged on a campaign promise to release eight years of tax returns, releasing instead only his return for 1989. They showed that he had an adjusted gross income of $438,286 and paid $128,237 in Federal, state and New York City taxes.

title: Texan's Early Strike Makes Democrat Leaders Nervous
description: Riding a hefty lead in fund raising and in the public opinion polls, Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for governor of Texas, has begun a series of pre-emptive strikes against his Democratic rival, Ann Richards.

title: Inner-Ear Origin of Attention Deficit Disorder Lacks Proof;   Dangers of Ritalin
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Aerospace Unit Fetches $715 Million
description: The Loral Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday for the purchase of the Ford Motor Company's aerospace unit for $715 million in cash.

title: Island Feud Slowing Japan-Soviet Thaw
description: Japan and the Soviet Union, in their most intense round of diplomatic activity in recent years, tried and failed this week to narrow their differences on a 45-year territorial dispute that has stood in the way of improved relations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the indictment of Representative Floyd H. Flake incorrectly described Jamaica, Queens. It has a mix of low- and middle-income residents.

title: Jury in Barry Trial Meets for 5 1/2 Hours; Reaches No Verdict
description: The Federal jury weighing the 14 drug and conspiracy charges against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. met for five and a half hours today without reaching a verdict.

title: Bhutto Must Now Confront Foes on Volatile Issue of Religion
description: Faced with an undeclared ethnic war in her home province of Sind and a tense standoff with India over the disputed territory of Kashmir, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto heads next week into a confrontation with her political opponents on Pakistan's most volatile issue: religion.

title: Deeper Economic Uncertainties Confront U.S. Policy Makers
description: For the economic policy makers in the Bush Administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait creates a new storm in an already unsettled atmosphere.

title: PGA Tour to Require Proof of Nonbias at Sites
description: Responding to the recent controversy over membership practices at Shoal Creek Country Club in Alabama, site of the P.G.A. Championship next week, the PGA Tour today announced a new policy intended to insure that none of its 120 yearly tournaments will take place at private clubs that discriminate by race, religion or sex.

title: Has Mayor Forgotten His Promise on Race?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hans Paul Verhoef; Dutch AIDS Patient, 33
description: Hans Paul Verhoef, a Dutch AIDS patient who was imprisoned in Minnesota last year because he did not declare that he had the disease when he entered the country, died in the Netherlands on July 23. He was 33 years old and had been hospitalized since May.

title: Fight Is Intensified on Fake Documents for Aliens
description: Armando Huerta arrived here two months ago from Mexico and, like many of the illegal aliens who continue to come to Southern California, went almost immediately to a seedy part of Alvarado Street near downtown Los Angeles.

title: In News, Public Choice Is a Disaster
description: LEAD: CNN television's experimental use of ''interactive television'' to permit its audience to pick the news it wants to see is misguided. The program encourages viewers to telephone CNN's headquarters in Atlanta and vote on selections from a broadcast ''menu'' of the news stories they could see. Although C

title: Bombs in South Lebanon Kill 11 and Wound 80
description: Bombings in the two largest cities in southern Lebanon killed 11 people and wounded 80 others on Thursday night, the police said today.

title: Giants Plan for Life With and Without Bavaro
description: When Mark Bavaro is healthy, he may be the best tight end in professional football. But he has not been healthy since he tore a knee ligament early last season, a situation that creates major problems for the Giants.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Germanys Agree To Rush Unification

title: OBSERVER Huzzahs for George
description: Humans need to hate a little. It's too bad, but so is their compulsion to uglify everything that's beautiful. We are a superb species, all right, just not quite perfect. Since we must hate, the sensible thing is to hate in moderation. For this reason, I have always hated the New York Yankees.

title: House Roll-Call on Rights Bill
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 272 to 154 by which the House of Representatives today approved a civil rights bill to combat job discrimination. A yes vote was a vote to pass the bill. Voting yes were 240 Democrats and 32 Republicans. Voting no were 12 Democrats and 142 Republicans. X denotes those not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: Lyme Disease Vaccine Available for Dogs
description: A new vaccine to protect dogs against Lyme disease has been granted conditional approval by the Federal Government and is available to dog owners in 43 states.

title: Tatiana Troyanos to Sing At Waterloo Festival
description: The mezzo-soprano Tatiana Troyanos will appear with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra on Aug. 11 at 8:30 P.M for the last concert of the Waterloo Festival, in the tent at Waterloo Village, Waterloo Road, Stanhope, N.J. Miss Troyanos will appear in place of Marilyn Horne, who canceled because of a scheduling problem. Ticket holders who want refunds can obtain them at the place of purchase.

title: Review/Opera;   Corsaro 'Butterfly' Revived
description: It is a pleasure to welcome a season at the New York City Opera that heralds a period of promise if not yet much excitement.

title: Panel Established by Judge To Oversee Drexel Portfolio
description: For the first time since its parent company filed for bankruptcy in February, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. lost its ability to exercise independent control of purchases and sales of securities in its portfolio.

title: Battle for the Saudi Soil
description: With Iraq having overrun Kuwait, the crisis in the Persian Gulf appears to be turning into a struggle between the United States and Iraq for influence over Saudi Arabia and its vast oil reserves.

title: Concern From F.T.C.
description: Some members of the Federal Trade Commission have said that provisions of the five-year contract between the College Football Association and ABC Sports could violate Federal antitrust laws, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday.

title: HUNGARY AFFIRMS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Hungary's first post-Communist Parliament today elected the writer Arpad Goncz, who served a prison term for political activity, as President of the nation.

title: Review/Jazz;   Lots of Improvisation And Just a Hint of Melody
description: Lee Konitz, who has long been one of jazz's more idiosyncratic alto saxophonists, is also one of the least direct. At his first set on Wednesday night at Condon's, where he will be playing through tonight, Mr. Konitz did everything he could to avoid stating a complete melody; instead he hinted, placing tatters of a song against the bluster of the rhythm section. Mr. Konitz's improvisations, shorn of standard jazz ideas, also have a streamlined, modernist austerity that wanders into abstraction.

title: Sri Lanka Says Rebels Killed At Least 93 at Two Mosques
description: Tamil separatists stormed two mosques in eastern Sri Lanka and sprayed Muslim worshipers with machine gunfire, killing at least 93 people and wounding 70, military officials said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: America's English Disease
description: America has just passed a milestone. Unfortunately it's on the way downhill. Last year, for the first time, the United States invested less in plant and equipment than Japan did, even though Japan's economy is half the size. The disparity suggests how grossly America is neglecting its future.

title: Ritter Inquiry Cites Reports From the 70's
description: Complaints about sexual contacts between the Rev. Bruce Ritter and residents at Covenant House were circulating for almost 20 years and were referred at least twice to senior staff members at the charity and the priest's Franciscan superiors, a report released yesterday said.

title: 14 U.S. Oil Workers Missing; Some Believed to Be in Iraqi Hands
description: Fourteen American oil workers are missing in Kuwait, and there are reports that at least some of them may have been taken into custody by invading Iraqi troops and moved across the border into Iraq, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Bridge
description: A majority of declarers, faced with a choice, will prefer a clear-cut line of play to a foggy one. In the diagramed deal from the New York Summer Regional in Manhattan on July 14, South opted for fog and was vindicated.

title: Romania Frees Student Held in 53-Day Protest
description: A student who led a 53-day anti-Government rally has been freed after six weeks' detention, and he denied charges today that he incited protesters to violence.

title: MOSCOW JOINS U.S. IN CRITICIZING IRAQ
description: The Soviet Union and the United States joined tonight in urging a worldwide halt of arms deliveries to Iraq after what they called ''the brutal and illegal invasion of Kuwait.''

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Madison Avenue Street Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 37th to 50th Streets from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Inner-Ear Origin of Attention Deficit Disorder Lacks Proof
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N.L.V. Appeals Ban
description: The University of Nevada-Las Vegas has filed a formal appeal seeking to overturn a National Collegiate Athletic Association ban that would prevent the Runnin' Rebels from defending their national basketball championship.

title: Mental Health Lawsuit Is Settled in Maine
description: A state judge has approved the settlement of a lawsuit filed on behalf of mental patients who said they were denied adequate medical care at the state's largest mental hospital.

title: Audubon Site Is Dropped For Building
description: Using her powers under an obscure state law, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan yesterday placed such tight restrictions on money to be used to build a biomedical laboratory on the site of the old Audubon Ballroom that New York City officials said the project was effectively doomed.

title: Man Stopped By 2 Officers Is Hiding a Submachine Gun
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday after two patrol officers in a squad car saw that he was carrying a large object hidden under his coat, which turned out to be a 9-millimeter machine pistol with a fully loaded 24-shot magazine, the police said.

title: A Defense By Buyer Of S.& L.'s
description: Acquisition Method Studied

title: John Keating Jr., 70, A Retired Cardiologist
description: Dr. John Honan Keating Jr., a retired specialist in internal medicine and cardiology, died on Thursday at the Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J. He was 70 years old and lived in Locust, N.J.

title: Iraq Bolsters Invasion Force, Adding to Worry on Saudis
description: Iraq has deployed armored brigades close to the Saudi Arabian border and poured reinforcements into occupied Kuwait, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Patents;   3-Dimensional Images Of Plaque in Arteries
description: A team of researchers at the University of Virginia Medical School in Charlottesville, Va., obtained a patent this week for a system of producing three-dimensional images that delineate hardening of the arteries.

title: Diet-Pill Death Raises Questions On F.D.A. Role
description: Turn to the back of most supermarket tabloids and some beauty magazines and you will find them - outlandish ads for miracle diet pills and aids that promise quick weight loss without any exercise or hard work.

title: Mideast Anxiety Jolts the Markets
description: Stocks took one of their biggest tumbles of the year yesterday amid widespread anxiety and uncertainty about the Middle East, but the close showed a solid recovery from the far lower levels earlier in the day.

title: Thomas M. Macioce, 71, Is Dead; Former Chairman of Allied Stores
description: Thomas M. Macioce, a lawyer and former chairman and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Brookville, L.I.

title: Violence, Irish and American Style
description: ''The violence in America is completely different: at home it's Catholic and Protestant, but here it's drug related,'' said Peter Evans, one of 450 children from Northern Ireland who ended their summers in New York yesterday.

title: Patents;   Simplifying A Computing Procedure
description: Inspired by origami, the Oriental art of folding paper into ornamental objects, a researcher at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories has patented a method for solving large computational problems.

title: Steinbrenner Letter Raises Tax Question
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent said yesterday it was ''much ado about very little,'' but a letter that George Steinbrenner sent to the Yankees' limited partners earlier this week raised questions about Steinbrenner's intentions.

title: Miss MacDermott Marries M. J. Arena
description: Kristine Parks MacDermott, a geologist, and Michael James Arena, a software engineer, were married yesterday at the Community Church of Mountain Lakes in Mountain Lakes, N.J., by the Rev. William Tolley, a Congregational minister.

title: 'One Who Confronts'
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is known throughout Iraq and the Arab world by his first name, which means ''One Who Confronts.''

title: Sign Vandal Offers New Highway Signs
description: A millionaire who was arrested last month for spray painting For Sale signs he thought cheapened this wealthy suburb now says he's willing to pay to replace metal highway signs with more attractive wooden ones.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE CLIMBS THE MOST IN NEARLY 4 YEARS
description: In a mostly grim report that took many analysts by surprise, the Labor Department said today that the nation's unemployment rate climbed three-tenths of a point in July, to 5.5 percent, in the biggest increase since early 1986.

title: 16 Are Seized in Sales Of Stickers for Autos
description: Sixteen people have been arrested on charges of selling hundreds of counterfeit state automobile inspection stickers to motorists.

title: Americans Went to Nicaragua to Ease U.S.-Inflicted Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Calls on U.N. To Impose Boycott on Iraq
description: The United States asked other members of the Security Council today to endorse its proposal for a worldwide economic boycott of Iraq and occupied Kuwait until Baghdad agrees to withdraw its military forces from Kuwait.

title: The Hall, Rose and Shoeless Joe
description: Jim Palmer and Joe Morgan, two highly deserving and relatively uncontroversial ballplayers, are to be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame tomorrow, but the focus of attention for many remains the moral issues of the candidacy of Pete Rose and Shoeless Joe Jackson.

title: Subic Bay Journal;   Where American Might Is a Bit High and Mighty
description: Contemplating the grand sweep of Subic Bay, recognized for hundreds of years as one of the best-protected natural harbors in Southeast Asia, it is easy to see why the United States Navy wants to keep its access to the huge naval base here.

title: Justice Marshall in Hospital For Observation After a Fall
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall was admitted for observation to the Bethesda Naval Medical Center today after a fall in Chicago on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Jimmy DeSana, a photographer, omitted the name of his companion.

title: Pipeline Ruptures; Dike Contains Spill
description: About 400,000 gallons of jet fuel gushed from a ruptured pipeline as it was being pumped into a storage terminal here early yesterday but workers and a dike kept it from reaching the Arthur Kill, officials said.

title: Iranian Oil-Producing Region Jolted by Strong Earthquake
description: A strong earthquake jolted the Iranian province of Khuzestan today, a little more than a month after an earthquake in the north killed 40,000 people.

title: Review/Dance;   Ideas and Reflections On Time and Memory
description: ''Hey, guys, we made it through Megadance,'' an audience member said as she filed out of Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night after the concluding program in the Serious Fun festival. It was a long night, with eight commissioned dances that together ran for about two and a half hours. The accent was on light entertainment, though, with one charming piece taking the evening's honors.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Frohnmayer Is Asked To End Written Pledge
description: The advisory council to the National Endowment for the Arts voted overwhelmingly today to recommend the elimination of an anti-obscenity pledge that artists and arts institutions have been asked to sign before they can receive grants from the endowment.

title: Oldsmobile Rebate
description: The General Motors Corporation's Oldsmobile division said it set new incentives on 1990 cars in an effort to clear out vehicles from this model year. Beginning immediately, cash rebates will be offered on these Oldsmobile vehicles: Cutlass Calais $750; Cutlass Ciera $1,000; Cutlass Supreme $2,000 at participating dealers; 88 Royale $1,500; Custom Cruiser $1,000; 98 Touring Sedan $1,000; Toronado $2,500 and Silhouette $1,250. It said the program also includes low-rate financing as an alternative.

title: German Leaders in Accord On Speeding Up Unification
description: Leaders of the Governments in Bonn and East Berlin moved today to speed up the formal unification of Germany by seven weeks with national elections on Oct. 14.

title: Iran Sees Time Nearing For New Ties to Britain
description: Reacting to recent comments by Britain's Foreign Minister about Islam and Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' an Iranian ayatollah said today that Britain had ''almost met'' Iran's conditions for restoring diplomatic relations.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: Why Iraq's Aggression May Backfire
description: LEAD: Saddam Hussein's reckless seizure of Kuwait and its oilfields is likely to lead eventually to a strategic realignment in the Middle East that could weaken him. His two prime enemies, Iran and Israel, would be the principal beneficiaries.

title: Atlanta Trades Murphy
description: Dale Murphy, the seven-time All-Star outfielder for the Atlanta Braves, was traded to the Philadelphia Phillies tonight for Jeff Parrett, a relief pitcher, and two players to be selected later.

title: Stotler Move By Creditors
description: Stotler Group Inc., a financially troubled commodity firm based in Chicago, announced last night that an involuntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition had been filed against it by three parties that say they are creditors.

title: About New York;   August. Hmmm. Shirt Weather. It Takes Us Back.
description: Put yourself back there, in that irretrievable New York of 55 summers ago. Kate Smith is on the radio. Lou Gehrig is at first base. Bob Hope plays the Palace. For $1.65 you can catch a movie, a newsreel and five vaudeville acts.

title: KEY RATES
Baseball Was Urged to Delay Inquiry
description: The prosecutor in the Howard Spira extortion case asked baseball to postpone its investigation of George Steinbrenner because he did not want the inquiry to uncover any information ''helpful'' to Spira, the head of the investigation said yesterday.

title: Dip in Mortgage Rates
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.84 percent this week, down from 9.98 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.38 percent, down from 8.41 percent last week.

title: School Custodians Gain, But Not the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Report on Investigation of Father Ritter and Covenant House
description: Following are excerpts from the Statement of the Oversight Committee of Covenant House:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Governments that engage in blatant aggression must know that the international community cannot and will not acquiesce in nor facilitate aggression.'' - An American-Soviet statement. [6:3.]

title: Big Board Seat Down in Price
description: The price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange has fallen to its lowest level in more than five years.

title: Democrat for S.E.C. Seat
description: President Bush today nominated Richard Y. Roberts, a former chief of staff of Senator Richard C. Shelby, Democrat of Alabama, to the vacant seat on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: To Freedom Staggers To Victory at Saratoga
description: To Freedom remained undefeated but failed to live up to his out-of-town notices while barely holding off Fighting Affair to win the $87,900 Saratoga Special by a head today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: ARABS TO CONVENE ON IRAQI INVASION
description: After two days of frantic maneuvering, Arab leaders agreed tonight to hold a summit meeting in Saudi Arabia this weekend to deal with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

title: Workers' Compensation: More to Do
description: Before 1914, workers in New York State who were disabled on the job faced a stark choice: Sue or starve. Then the Legislature devised a no-fault insurance plan that covered medical costs and two-thirds of lost pay. Albany closed its 1990 session by voting a deserved increase in worker benefits. It now needs to restore the compensation system to financial soundness.

title: Jackson Urges U.S. Diplomacy
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson called on the Bush Administration today to move quickly, diplomatically and militarily if necessary, ''to secure an end to the military aggression by Iraq.'' In a telephone interview, Mr. Jackson assailed the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, and said, ''He must know he has pushed us over the line and that his insistence on the occupation of Kuwait and the threat against Saudi Arabia is an extreme act of provocation that would be met with force.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * A&B Hawaii Inc., a subsidiary of Alexander & Baldwin Inc., Honolulu, an ocean transportation company, closed the purchases last week of four commercial properties for a total of almost $55.9 million.

title: 20-Year-Old Charged In Computer Crimes
description: A Ewing Township man who is alleged to have tapped into the state's computer system and tried to infiltrate a Federal computer was arrested yesterday, the state police said.

title: To Village's Disbelief, Farmer Is Indicted in Brother's Death
description: A 59-year-old dairy farmer in the central New York village of Munnsville was indicted today on a charge of suffocating his brother.

title: Making Sense of Senseless Crime
description: New York's summer of pointless violence wears on, prompting frustration, fear and demands for action. Police Commissioner Lee Brown responds with a bold plan to expand the new police strategy known as community patrol. He deserves the chance to make it work.

title: Guidepost;   The World of Plums
description: Summer offers plums in staggering variety. Most are sweet and juicy, but some, notably the Santa Rosa, can be tart and astringent near the pit. Plums are ripe when the skin yields to pressure but is not soft. Clingstone varieties have pits that cling to the flesh; pits in freestone plums do not. title: Farm Policy's Problem Is Subsidies for Few
description: To the Editor:

title: Woolridge to Nuggets
description: The Denver Nuggets yesterday acquired Orlando Woolridge, a forward, from the Los Angeles Lakers for Denver's No. 2 choices in the 1993 and 1995 National Basketball Association drafts, the Nuggets announced yesterday in Denver.

title: Hotel Is Macklowe's Bid for a Shinier Image
description: Harry Macklowe has quietly opened his elegant hotel, which towers 38 stories over Times Square. He hopes his stature will soar with it.

title: Transit Police Dept. Will Let Its Officers Carry 9-mm. Pistols
description: New York City transit police officers will be allowed to carry a more powerful handgun that has long been resisted by officials here because of its possible danger to the public, transit police officials announced yesterday.

title: Review/Opera;   'Boheme' Artists Who Look the Part
description: There was a time, only a few decades ago, when ''La Boheme'' could be successfully staged as a vehicle for great Italianate voices. Dramatic plausibility, if any, was a bonus. Operagoers did not mind, apparently, if the roistering bohemians were overage, overfed and as nimble as arthritic water buffaloes. Now, in an operatic age ruled by the esthetics of television and movies, Puccini's struggling young artists are required to act well and be physically credible. If they sing gloriously, too, that has become the bonus.

title: Drabek Misses No-Hitter by 1 Out
description: Doug Drabek's bid for a no-hitter was broken up by Sil Campusano with two out in the ninth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 11-0.

title: Tough Plea Bargaining Planned in Drug Cases
description: Manhattan prosecutors will impose tougher plea-bargaining procedures on defendants caught in a police drug crackdown in Washington Heights, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Coach Dismissed
description: Coach Jerry Peirson was dismissed by Miami University yesterday for giving one of his basketball players a false grade in a class.

title: Letter: On Refugees;   Expand Asylum to Include Groups
description: To the Editor:

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;

Coping: With Toxic Household Products
description: LEAD: As a test, Philip Dickey polished his kitchen floor with skim milk and concluded that it ''worked pretty well.''

title: Beliefs
description: At 34 years of age, Mark Smith calls himself something of a ''spiritual wanderer.'' Mr. Smith, who drives a delivery truck for New York Newsday, is a trained catechist in the Roman Catholic faith of his upbringing. He has also, he says, ''been in and out of Protestant churches.''

title: 10-Day Car Sales Up 8.4%, Paced by Big Jump at G.M.
description: Cars of domestically produced cars rose 8.4 percent in late July, helped by sharply higher sales for the General Motors Corporation, the industry leader.

title: Florence King Weichsel, Educator, 82
description: Florence King Weichsel, co-founder and former director of the Children's Studio in Rye, N.Y., a private art school for children that closed in 1972, died yesterday at a convalescent home in Albuquerque, N.M. She was 82 years old and had moved to Albuquerque from White Plains five months ago.

title: FIGHTING WORSENS IN LIBERIA CAPITAL
description: Government troops and guerrillas loyal to one of Liberia's two rival rebel leaders fired rockets and shells today in block-by-block fighting for the Liberian capital.

title: A Long, Hot Summer in the Skies
description: It's summertime and the airlines are sweating. The normally prosperous travel season is proving a disappointment for the industry, and as a result the airlines are offering discount fares, although with many restrictions, that are unusual at this time of year.

title: Americans Went to Nicaragua to Ease U.S.-Inflicted Suffering;   Still Witnessing
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money;   Ways to Avoid Emotional Moves
description: Although it is too early to gauge the wisdom of the investors who made sudden market moves - trading for oil shares or dumping stocks - almost as soon as Iraq invaded Kuwait, such moves are generally a mistake for individuals. Patience is more likely to be rewarded, as it has been since the crash of October 1987.

title: Schenectady Fire Kills 5 Tenants
description: Five people were killed last night as fire roared through a rooming house in Schenectady, N.Y.. It was the worst fire in the city in at least 25 years.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Freeing 'After the Fall' From the Ghost of Marilyn
description: When Josette Simon was offered the role of Maggie in Arthur Miller's ''After the Fall,'' she said she had to satisfy herself that playing a part widely identified with Marilyn Monroe would not appear to be a gimmick.

title: Style Makers;   Denise Wallace. Jewelry Designer
description: In her small workshop. Denise Wallace creates jewelry in silver, fossilized walrus ivory and colored stone, capturing Native Alaskan folklore and life. ''I think of myself as a storyteller,'' said Ms. Wallace, a 32-year-old Aleut whose jewelry has been shown at the American Museum of Natural History in New York.

title: Miss Kriegman To Wed in Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Kriegman of Wayne, N.J., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter, Michelle Robin Kriegman, and David Andrew King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. King of Randwick, Australia.

title:
THE SUMMER REPORT;

Joint Ventures
description: LEAD: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: Better Hands for Cars
description: WHEN the Allstate Insurance Company wanted to lower the cost of automobile insurance in Chicago, it knew that a prime obstacle was rapidly escalating pay for body-shop technicians. That, in turn, reflected the dearth of qualified repairmen.

title: Ms. Tucker Wed To Robert Ellin
description: Nancy Jane Tucker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron B. Tucker of Hewlett, L.I., was married last evening to Robert Scott Ellin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Ellin of New York. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg officiated at Jem Caterers at the Sands Atlantic Beach in Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: Top Capitalist
description: In these times, a Bulgarian can take a quick and unconventional route to the top of national politics. Zhelyu Zhelev, a philosophy professor, took over a group called the Club for the Support of Glasnost and Perestroika, became leader of the main opposition coalition and as of last week is Bulgaria's President. The Socialist Party, once the Communist Party, has a majority in Parliament, but Mr. Zhelev nonetheless obtained the required two-thirds vote. Whatever conciliatory gestures the Socialists were making, leaders of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces said they would not enter into a coalition government. Some say opposition politicians want the Socialist Party to take blame for the economic ''shock therapy'' that the Union of Democratic Forces has called for to lead the economy into the 20th Century. But some of them are expected to take Government posts. And Mr. Zhelev, an unapologetic admirer of capitalism, has the power to call elections, which can change everything.

title: I Hear You, I Hear You
description: YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: When Chinon introduced the original Genesis two years ago, it touted its hybrid camera as the ultimate picture-taking machine. It had zoom lens, automatic focusing and exposure settings, built-in flash and high-tech, space-age design.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Kuwait has faith in its Arab brothers. Kuwait has faith in President Hosni Mubarak, King Fahd, custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, and the other leaders. The crisis is an Arab one and Arabs will solve their own problems, God willing.''

title: Comic Relief for Engineers
description: IN AN effort to attract minority children to science and engineering, the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering Inc. has recruited an unlikely hero: the Amazing Spider-Man.

title: House Wares
description: AS THE new school year approaches, computer makers are racing to introduce machines designed specifically for home use. Easier to use, less powerful and less expensive than office PC's, the new machines are expected to appeal especially to students and their parents, and to teachers looking for a home computer.

title: A Stand-Up Genius
description: BOONE

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   A Town With Understated Treasures
description: This hamlet in Orange County, N.Y., squeezes about 60 galleries and shops into one main street less than half a mile long. But there is no big billboard heralding that fact, and the galleries themselves, in 200-year-old houses, look like the long-time residences they are, except for their own tiny hand-painted signs, often camouflaged by overgrown trees.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Should Lawrence Taylor Get A Raise?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Why It Isn't Ungrammatical to Speak the President's English
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnny Mathis on His Mind
description: CROONING

title: Susannah Richards and James Work 3d Are Wed
description: Susannah Richards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Richards of Damariscotta, Me., was married yesterday at her parents' home to James Clark Work 3d, the son of the late Bernice Blackwood of Chicago and the late J. Clark Work of Clermont, Fla. Deborah Potter, a lawyer, performed the ceremony.

title: The Operative Word in America: Deficit
description: CONGRESS is packing itself off for an August vacation, leaving untouched the nasty business of cutting enough spending and raising enough taxes to squeeze $50 billion out of the ever-swelling budget deficit.

title: Show Time
description: This may be the baseball season, but California fans who haven't forgot basketball will get a chance tonight to see some top National Basketball Association stars in action. The event is the fifth annual Magic Johnson all-star game at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif.

title: No, the Louvre Wasn't Broke, But Fixing It Is a Fine Idea
description: It would be difficult to pass through the center of Paris today and not realize that the Louvre is being taken apart, rethought and put together again. Imminent ever since I. M. Pei's designs for the new pyramidal entrance to the museum were revealed some years ago to a chorus of execration, the radical rereading of the Louvre and its collections is going forward in readiness for completion in 1995. It will by then be 14 years since President Mitterrand set the process in motion.

title: Our Animal Rites
description: The bear had the adenoidal breathing of an elderly man with a passion for cigars and a tendency toward emphysema. My first thought, when I saw him contemplating me through tiny eyes from a rise just beyond the back porch, was that he looked remarkably bearlike, like a close-up shot from a public television nature program.

title: At Age 50, The Merritt Faces a Fight For Its Future
description: LEAD: THE Merritt Parkway looks much as it did in September 1940, when workers finished the last links of the rolling, four-lane highway. But as the 50th anniversary of the Merritt's completion nears, the State Department of Transportation is considering an expansion of the roadway to as many as eight lanes.

title: HOW SHOULD PGA TOUR RE-EVALUATE SITE RULES?
description: The PGA Tour should hold more events on public courses. Such courses have no ''membership policies'' other than the fact that some provide greens-fee discounts for local residents.

title: Campus Life: U.C., Irvine;   Leading Students From High Schools Confront Issues
description: On the theory that leaders are born but also must be encouraged, the University of California at Irvine has been asking 50 top high school students from around southern California to wrestle with the social issues of their day - the environment, human rights, drugs and poverty.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are all sorts of aphorisms, maxims, adages, sayings - call them what you will - that are true, but so what?

title: Kathie A. Shutkin To Wed Next Year
description: Dr. and Mrs. Peter M. Shutkin of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathie Alane Shutkin to David Benjamin Mandel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice M. Mandel of Port Washington, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: Junk Mail's Top Dogs
description: Bill Jayme stands on his hilltop patio before his sun-drenched house, his swimming pool, his verdant five acres overlooking the vineyards of Sonoma, Calif. Smiling proudly, if ironically, he says: ''Everything you see was paid for by Dear Reader.''

title: Argentina's Glittering Trove
description: Excited by stories of a mountain of silver, the colonizing Spanish in the early 16th century gave the name Rio de la Plata - River of Silver - to the great South American river system that ends at Buenos Aires. In the Andes, along the continent's western rim, their dreams would be fulfilled. So abundant was the supply of the glittering metal that in the 17th century, in Potosi alone - now part of Bolivia - more than 3,000 mine shafts were opened. Visitors of the time were amazed to find chairs, tables and even the most ordinary of household objects, such as sinks and pitchers, made of sterling silver or silverplate.

title: Restoring the Pride of the Yankees
description: WHEN George Steinbrenner was ordered by Commissioner Fay Vincent to give up operational control of the New York Yankees last week, Americans who treasure baseball as the national pastime and those with a stake in the game as a business both had reason to feel relieved. One of the most demoralizing eras in a fabled franchise's history had ended.

title: CRIME
description: Ed McBain's new Matthew Hope mystery, THREE BLIND MICE (Arcade/Little, Brown, $18.95), takes its ironic nursery rhyme title from the grisly ritual slaying of three Vietnamese kitchen helpers who lived in a Florida coastal town called Calusa. Not long before their deaths, the men had been acquitted of gang-raping the wife of a rich local farmer; so, when hard evidence turns up to implicate the husband of the rape victim, the new assistant state attorney (whose courtroom style is described as ''flamboyant, seductive, aggressive, unrelenting, and unforgiving'') naturally thinks she's got a lock on the case. Indeed, it looks like another no-win situation for Hope, the patron saint defense attorney for such hopeless causes.

title: Regulators Are Seeking to Revise Some Sales of Savings and Loans
description: Federal regulators will seek to make changes in some deals in which the Government sold nearly 100 insolvent savings institutions in 1988, and they may try to cancel some of the sales.

title: Lynn-Ann Ries to Wed Donald Gries
description: The engagement of Lynn-Ann Ries to Donald Selig Gries, a son of Mrs. Barrie M. Damson of New York and Robert D. Gries of Shaker Heights, Ohio, has been announced by her parents, Dr. Edith Dunfee Ries of South Orange, N.J., and William P. Ries of Morristown, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Growing Up Where Violence Wants to Come Play
description: In his short life in the struggling Brownsville section of Brooklyn, 13-year-old Gregory Orr has seen a man shot to death in a crowded courtyard in broad daylight.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Ousted K.G.B. General Running for Parliament
description: In the seven weeks since he went public with allegations of K.G.B. abuses, Oleg D. Kalugin has been officially denounced, stripped of his major general's rank and pension and charged with the crime of disclosing state secrets.

title: Review/Musical;   Love's Labours Gained
description: Everything about the New York City Opera's new production of Stephen Sondheim's musical ''A Little Night Music,'' Friday night at the New York State Theater, conspires to blur the line between opera and Broadway.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KEEPING WATCH: A History of American Time. By Michael O'Malley. (Viking, $19.95.) In tracing the ways timekeeping has evolved in the United States, Michael O'Malley quotes Lewis Mumford's claim that ''the clock, not the steam engine, is the key machine of the modern industrial age.'' There were clocks in the American colonies as early as 1638; by 1700, roughly one white adult in 50 owned a clock and one in 32 a watch. But in a time when news took five days to travel from Philadelphia to New York, and another 10 to reach Boston, every city, town, village and even farm kept its own local time; as late as 1869, when the telegraph transmitted news of the final spike driven in the transcontinental railway, at 12:45 P.M. local time in Promontory, Utah, the time was 12:30 in Virginia City, Nev., 11:46 in San Francisco according to one newspaper and 11:44:37 according to another, and 2:47 in Washington. The railroads and Western Union are largely responsible for moving Americans to a national standard time; this shift, the author argues, drastically changed the way we think about ourselves and our society. Mr. O'Malley, who teaches American history at New York University, has a number of interesting things to say about the growth of clock and watch manufacturing in this country, about the evolution of standard time and the controversies over daylight time and, in his final chapter, he offers a new slant on the Scopes ''monkey trial'' of 1925. But the book too often reads more like a stack of note cards than a unified narrative. Well researched and thorough, ''Keeping Watch'' is a book with many interesting things in it, without at the same time being a very interesting book.

title: Fresh Meals on the Spur of the Moment
description: SUMMER lunches don't have to be complicated affairs. At this time of year, even the most impromptu meals can be made memorable because there is so much good fresh produce around.

title: Erwin Petilos Is Married To Ms. Penfil in California
description: Elizabeth Kimberly Penfil, a daughter of Dr. Richard Lee Penfil of Newport Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to Erwin R. Petilos, a son of Dr. Salvador N. Petilos of Marks, Miss., and Dr. Teresita D. Petilos of Tenafly, N.J. Judge Susanne S. Shaw of municipal court in Orange County, Calif., officiated at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Doreen Ann Penfil.

title: THE NATION: Noonan Q & A;   What She Said At the University
description: PEGGY NOONAN, speechwriter for Presidents Reagan and Bush, answered questions at a forum last week at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Following are excerpts:

title: Campaign Surgery;   Bills in Congress to Tighten Spending May Be an Attempt to Impress Voters
description: After rancorous debate and mostly party-line votes, the House and the Senate have each pased campaign finance bills, the first major effort since Watergate to limit spending and regulate contributions.

title: Sarah J. Beilke and Thomas Michael Begel Wed
description: Sarah Jane Beilke and Thomas Michael Begel were married yesterday in a nondenominational ceremony at the Ventana Inn in Big Sur, Calif., by the Rev. Hugh Rideout, a minister of the Universal Life Church. Mrs. Begel is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Beilke of Green Bay, Wis. She is a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and a saleswoman at the Scully & Scully giftware shop in New York. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Begel of Wyckoff, N.J. He is the president and the principal owner of TMB Industries, a merchant banking group in New York and Princeton, N.J., and a former president of the Pullman Company. He is a graduate of the University of Missouri. His first marriage ended in divorce.

description: CLASSICAL

title: Fashion;   New Textures Are Crisp, Lush and Light
description: If your seersuckers feel sodden and your linens have gone limp, hang on. Men's wear arriving in stores now offers crisp new textures in relatively lightweight fabrics.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Where the View Is Constantly Changing
description: LEAD: A PURE white egret combs the beach on spindly legs. A sturdy tugboat, outlined in amber lights, ushers a barge into the bay at night. A catamaran, lavender and pink sails billowing, skates across the surface of the water. The view changes from minute to minute. Long Island living at its best.

title: At Play on a Working Farm
description: There is something almost mythic about a farm: the sun setting on rolling green pastures, the swoop of barn swallows on their way to the nest, the new life (newborn calves, lambs, kittens, puppies) that seems to crowd the small corners of the cavernous barn. It is the place to view The Farmer - that embodiment of the work ethic - on the job, and to have a glimpse of the livelihood that, as Americans, seems somehow our birthright. There is something about visiting a farm that is like going home, a feeling not based in reality but in America's cultural mythology, and a kind of collective nostalgia.

title: Some Memories Of Life With Father
description: The recent article ''A Man Who Doesn't Know His Son Is Married'' (Opinion page) brought back not too far-off memories of my own life with my father. My father had a close relationship with both of his children when they were young. Plagued by his own insecurities, as his children grew and matured, he felt threatened and left behind. Instead of communicating his feelings to us, he withdrew.

description: The American Circus An Illustrated History

title: Bush Now Supports Inquiry Into Causes Of Savings Scandal
description: The Bush Administration has dropped its opposition to a Senate proposal that would create a bipartisan commission to study the causes of the savings and loan crisis.

title: Denise J. Brown Weds Todd Noel
description: Denise June Brown, the daughter of Mary Alice Brown of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to Todd Joseph Noel, the son of the late Livingston Noel of Grenada, West Indies. The Rev. Dr. Bennett W. Smith performed the ceremony at St. John Baptist Church in Buffalo.

title: 2 Mob Fugitives Hiding In New York, Police Say
description: Two men described as top Mafia leaders, who disappeared in May shortly before their indictment on racketeering charges, are believed to be hiding together in the New York City area, law-enforcement authorities say.

title: A New Taste (Afghani) in Huntington
description: HISTORIC Huntington Village now has an Afghani restaurant. Incongruous as that might seem, it is not a bad fit. Huntingtonians have long demonstrated their love for Greek food by supporting three storefront Greek restaurants within two blocks of each other. There are some similarities between the two cuisines: souvlaki becomes shish kebab and baklava translates to bughluva.

title: Johnson ot Run in January
description: Ben Johnson said today that he would return to competitive racing in January.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The quality of United States stamp production is excellent. Mistakes are seldom made, and when they are, stamps that come off the presses lacking perforations or some colors, or with part of the design upside down, are almost always found by postal inspectors and destroyed. That's almost always. There has been a mini-epidemic of errors in the production of the Lighthouse booklet, the strip of five 25-cent stamps. These handsome stamps have the notation USA 25 in the upper left-hand corner printed in white ink over the colored designs. That is, they almost always have that notation. With some frequency, collectors and non-collectors are reporting that the white ink is missing. Most of the reports are coming from the Northeast, but there have been scattered purchases of such errors elsewhere.

title: Players Sued
description: Two police officers who were on plainclothes duty in Madison, Wis., the night of June 28 say things got pretty rough when they tried to subdue a man who they say was acting obscenely outside a tavern and his two companions intervened. Indeed, according to a series of civil damage suits the officers filed Friday, the three, Chris Chelios of the Chicago Blackhawks, Gary Suter of the Calgary Flames and David Lundeen, a former teammate of the two pros at the University of Wisconsin, ''showed a complete disdain and disregard'' of the officers' ''inherent dignity as human beings.''

title: Stories My Parents Told Me, From the Horror of Hiroshima
description: HIROSHIMA today is a very beautiful city, but 45 years ago it was in ashes. I was born there in 1947, and this is the story my parents often told me when I was a child.

title: Karen Kaufman Weds D. L. Becker
description: Karen Lee Kaufman, a nurse practitioner at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, and Donald Lee Becker, a lawyer in Belmont, Mass., were married yesterday at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Belmont by the Rev. Martha H. Giltinan. Mrs. Becker is a daughter of Mrs. Leonard Kaufman of Rochester and the late Mr. Kaufman. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Becker of Washington.

title: Review/Music;   Blending The Exotic And Familiar
description: One of the discomforts of monitoring new American composition is having to watch young composers steeped in the lore of Third Avenue or the Bronx as they escape into Buddist chant, Tibetan prayers or the everyday musical obeisances of Islam. There is romance in these flights of fancy, but the flight too often is from what one really knows and understands.
