description: LEAD:

title: Ms. McGrath Wed To P. J. O'Rourke
description: Brinn Patricia McGrath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. McGrath of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Peter J. O'Rourke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter O'Rourke of Hillsdale, N.J. The Revs. Gerard Reedy and Dennis P. Keane officiated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: In Seeking Iraqi Motive, Some Turn to 1918 Atlas
description: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is the most iron-fisted of a series of actions that it has taken against the emirate since Kuwait became independent in 1961.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended July 21

title: Works in Progress;   The Lady and the Tiger
description: Siberian Tigers are the largest of all cats, weighing up to 700 pounds, and white Siberian tigers might be the rarest. First bred successfully four years ago by Robert Baudy at the Rare Feline Breeding Center in Florida, there are now six in the world. Five are with Baudy; the sixth, Kita, (above and right), lives in Westfield, Ind. Kita, who at 15 months weighs about 250 pounds, is being raised by Moselle Schaffer, on whose 50-acre farm (called Camel Lot) also reside eight zebras, five llamas (two of them pregnant) and Boris, Kita's 5-year-old, conventionally yellow-hued brother. Schaffer, who is licensed to raise endangered species, has, over the years, sold various critters to zoos but doesn't like to. ''I fall in love with the babies,'' she says, ''though now that I'm up to my ears in zebras. . . .''

title: Veiled Prejudice
description: RACE AND SLAVERY IN THE MIDDLE EAST

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Native Plants for Natural Habitats
description: LEAD: Karen Blumer, a Long Island ecologist, believes that native plants form a link with the past and provide a sense of place. She says that these plants are beautiful and adaptable to a variety of places in a home garden.

title: Murphy Starts Over
description: After spending his entire 13-year career with the Atlanta Braves, Dale Murphy is going to have to learn a new city and familiarize himself with a new team. The 34-year-old slugger was traded to the Philadelphia Philies on Friday night for a relief pitcher, Jeff Parrett, and two players to be named. The Phillies will also get a player to be named.

title: U.S. Says Bush Was Surprised by the Iraqi Strike
description: Despite Iraq's heavy buildup of forces along the Kuwaiti border in late July, the Bush Administration was surprised by the invasion this week and largely unprepared to respond quickly, Administration officials say.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Developers Turning to First-Time Buyers
description: LEAD: Instead of looking for months for a house they could afford, Alice Mur and her fiance, George McKenna, who are first-time buyers, found one right away when they started their search earlier this year.

title: HOW SHOULD PGA TOUR RE-EVALUATE SITE RULES?
description: A country club with an all-white membership is an indictment of racism. A PGA Tour event in an all-white country club is an endorsement of prejudice. Simply stated, the PGA Tour needs to evaluate its position on prejudice and racism.

title: Budget Cuts Leave Libraries Gloomy
description: Carrying a stack of children's books and records, Pamela Englund climbed the steps of the Jefferson Market library in Greenwich Village on a recent Friday afternoon and tugged at the door. It was locked.

title: Ferry Sloop Takes Shape, With Help of Ex-Addicts
description: THE Hudson River ferry sloop family is getting ready to produce another offspring. The 32-foot gaff-rigged sloop, tentatively named the Eleanor - after Eleanor Roosevelt - is being built on the grounds of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Administration Hospital in Montrose, a joint effort of the newly revitalized Riverlovers boat club of Crugers and of drug- and alcohol-abuse patients at the hospital.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has a forced-air furnace that is about 14 years old. A heating contractor the heat exchange unit is badly rusted and he recommends replacing it because the heat exchanger is so bad and because the old unit had insufficient air flow. He says that the new furnace would have 90 percent efficiency and would save about 40 percent in gas costs. Is this logical, and can a gas furnace emit dangerous levels of carbon monoxide?

title: Clyde H. Shaffer, 90, Retired Chief of Breyer
description: Clyde H. Shaffer, retired president of the Breyer Ice Cream Company, died Friday in the Whitehall Nursing Home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 90 years old and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: All About/Phone Cards;   The Latest Front In a Long-Distance Telephone War
description: TELEPHONE calling cards were long the industry's doormats - useful, but taken for granted. Now the largest long-distance companies are giving them mantelpiece display. These thin plastic rectangles for charging calls, with 10-digit numbers and magnetic strips, have become favored weapons in the battle for the nation's $52 billion long-distance market.

title: Christine G. Bona Wed To Robert E. Cabana
description: Christine G. Bona, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Bona of Boonton Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert E. Cabana, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard E. Cabana of Boonton Township. Msgr. John R. Ryan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Magnificat Roman Catholic Church in Kinnelon, N.J.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: BERNARD M. WEINSTEIN;

What's Ahead for the Medical Center?
description: LEAD: WHEN Bernard M. Weinstein took over as Westchester County Commissioner of Hospitals almost 12 years ago, county officials said they were hopeful he could walk on water, so bad were things at the county-owned Westchester County Medical Center.

title: East Meets West In a Dying Steel Town
description: On a humid Saturday in July, police stop traffic from passing along a largely abandoned two-block portion of the main street through Braddock, Pa. (population 4,775 and falling), to allow the Japanese film maker Hiroaki Yoshida to continue shooting his first American movie, ''Iron Maze,'' in some of the town's abandoned buildings.

title: Family Feud
description: TEACHERS are jugglers, balancing competing interests, and, sometimes, competing ideologies, to deliver to their students enough accurate information to help them make reasoned judgments.

title: Data Update
Trinidad Puzzles Over Cause of the Uprising
description: The chief preoccupations in this English-speaking nation of 1.3 million people are calypso, cricket and soccer. So the attempted coup against the Government, and the violence it spawned before its peaceful denouement on Wednesday, struck many Trinidadians as something alien.

title: Beauty;   Lip Reading
description: It's odd, this sensibility we're all plugged into, where colored lips seem normal and naked ones seem, well, naked - and most of us spend a lot of time making sure the latter never happens. Still, the idea of using lipstick treads an uneasy line between the real and the artificial. The fashion writer Kennedy Fraser once declared that ''the woman who replaces her lipstick at the end of a meal often does so with a desperation which suggests that her mouth itself has been obliterated by chewing and by conversation.'' This implies that the routine of constantly applying lipstick is inextricably tied into questions of psyche, of self-image. We are, it seems, what we wear on our lips.

title: 'Steel Magnolias' Returns to a Stage
description: NOW that Hollywood's opened-up, overstuffed, star-strewn ''Steel Magnolias'' is out of the way, it's time to home in on the real thing.

title: House Grows Edgy as Elections Near
description: The House of Representatives is heading into an election season with anxiety growing, as polls show the voters in an angry mood, the savings and loan issue gathers steam and the stalemate over the budget injects a powerful uncertainty into the fall campaign.

title: Photo: Eugene Istomin as guest soloist in the Mostly Mozart series. (Susanne Faulkner Stevens) Review/Concert;   Mostly Schubert Program In Mostly Mozart Series
description: The look seemed somehow right at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening. From an audience that had already thinned out distinctly at intermission, listeners defected after almost every movement. It might have been the New York Philharmonic performing, say, Schoenberg.

title: Tax Plan Sticks New Yorkers With Bailout Tab;   Our Spending Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW SHOULD PGA TOUR RE-EVALUATE SITE RULES?
description: It shouldn't. The key word in this Shoal Creek matter is ''private.'' The club should be allowed to accept and reject whomever it chooses, based on whatever criteria the club establishes. It is private.

title: Patricia Bartley Weds Eric Schwartz
description: Patricia Leahy Bartley and Eric Dane Schwartz were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. Peter in Wilmington, Del., by the Rev. William J. Metzger. Mrs. Schwartz is a daughter of Robert P. Bartley of Wilmington and the late Joan Leahy Bartley. The bridegroom is the son of Helen Dane Schwartz of Princeton, N.J., and the late Kenneth Wood Schwartz.

title: How Art Springs From Disaster
description: LEAD: ALAN FONTAINE, a Westport photographer whose career has frequently taken new directions, has now turned a natural disaster into an original art form.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SCARSDALE;

Moving Toward a New Profile For the Downtown
description: LEAD: FOR more than 20 years this village has considered developing part of its downtown. Now the Board of Trustees has named its preferred developer, the Penn Central Corporation, and is preparing an agreement that could be ready as early as next month. It would pave the way for a new profile in the areas north and south of the Popham Road Railroad

title: Paying the Price For That Lawn
description: Although I was encouraged to learn from ''Perfect Lawns Exact a Price Some Refuse to Pay'' on July 15 that a ''small but growing'' number of Westchester gardeners are trying to cure their chemical dependency on lawn pesticides and fertilizers, I think we still have a long way to go to catch up with western states like California and Colorado, which are legislating lawns out of existence with zoning controls, landscaping covenants and severe water restrictions.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin;   The 'Seniors' at Summer Session Are of the Gray Variety
description: Many students at the University of Wisconsin have been surprised by the age of hundreds of their classmates at this year's summer session. These classmates are retirees, mostly from Florida, whose ages range from the early 60's to the early 80's.

title: More New Magazines, And These Beckon To Black Readers
description: FROM Los Angeles to Boston, black entrepreneurs, swimming against the tide of falling advertising pages and high mortality rates in the magazine industry, are establishing magazines aimed principally at black readers.

title: Jill S. Solodar to Marry Alle J. J. Schilstra in '91
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Solodar of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Suzanne Solodar, to Alle Jetze Jacob Schilstra, a son of Harry Schilstra of Sneek, the Netherlands, and Mrs. Nynke Louwsma-Kramer of Bolsward, the Netherlands. A fall 1991 wedding is planned.

title: Three Finnish Films
description: The Finnish director Aki Kaurismaki's first three feature films will have their New York premieres at the Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, starting Aug. 23. ''Shadows in Paradise'' tells of a relationship between a garbage man and an unemployed supermarket checker; ''Calamari Union'' is about a gang of 17 leather-jacketed young men wandering the streets of Helsinki, and ''Crime and Punishment'' is an updated version of the Dostoyevsky story with the Raskolnikov character a slaughterhouse butcher. Tickets to each showing are $5. Information: 477-2714.

title: Resisting Hitler
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disclaimer To Howls of Success
description: What a coincidence when I found that informative article about New York City chefs on Long Island (July 15).

title: Tax Plan Sticks New Yorkers With Bailout Tab;   Blow to Homeowners
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Players Relive Grandfathers' Glory
description: LEAD: YOUNG athletes like to rave about the playing-field prowess - real or imagined - of their fathers. But two baseball players from Westport, 18-year-old Noel Torpey and Mike Nichols-Marcy, 17, can reach back even further in their lineage - to their grandfathers. And their tales are authentic.

title: Lolly Jewett Wed to Abner Oakes 4th
description: Laura Jewett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Jewett of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Abner Oakes 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oakes 3d of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. John Livingston, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony. The bride, who is 28 years old and is known as Lolly, is keeping her name. She graduated from Dartmouth College and received a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia University, where she is a candidate for a Ph.D. in political science and for a certificate from the Harriman Institute for Advanced Study of the Soviet Union. Her father is the executive vice president of North American Realty Advisory Services, and her mother, Truda Jewett, is the assistant executive director of the Children's Aid Society, both in New York.

title: Trouble on Hemlock Street
description: SEVENTH HEAVEN

title: Belong Now, Pay Later
description: Notice to ambitious lawyers: Want to be a Federal judge someday, or high official in the Justice Department? Now's the time to quit that country club or eating club that refuses to admit minorities or women. Either quit now or at least start compiling a record of agitation for change. That's the message of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which confirms (and sometimes rejects) nominees for judgeships and high Justice posts.

title: Hambletonian to Harmonious
description: Last year, the dead heat in the Hambletonian between Park Avenue Joe, who is owned by Lou Guida, and Probe, who is owned by Frank Antonacci, resulted in a lawsuit to determine just whose horse should have come home with the winner's purse.

title: Put In Next Spring's Bulb Order Now
description: IT IS time to think spring. Although the season is a long way off, the hardy bulb catalogues have arrived in the mail, and gardeners will have to start thinking about what bulbs they will want to plant in the fall.

title: Generations of Poison and Lies
description: Never have so many human beings been exposed to so much radiation over so long a time - while so few knew about it. Now, more than 40 years after it began, we are just beginning to learn what the U.S. government's Hanford nuclear weapons plant in Washington state has done to thousands of citizens who unwittingly drank radioactively contaminated water, breathed radioactively contaminated air, and fed milk laced with radioactive iodine to their children.

title: SENATE APPROVES SHIFT IN STRATEGY FOR MISSILE SHIELD
description: In a direct challenge to President Bush over the plan for an anti-missile system, the Senate today approved a major revision that would require the Pentagon to shift the focus from space interceptors to defenses on the ground.

title: Homeless Quake Victims Face New Burdens in Iran
description: Half a million homeless victims of the Iranian earthquake are threatened by food shortages and the frigid weather about to descend on northern Iran.

title: No Thanks, She Says, I'll Die Elsewhere
description: LEAD: THERE is nothing accidental - or, for that matter, coyly symbolic - about the title of Eleanor Harris Howard's play. She calls the romantic comedy ''I Don't Want to Die on Long Island.'' And, she said, she really means it.

title: Lorraine Linton Wed in New Jersey
description: Lorraine Janis Linton, a daughter of Terese K. Linton Nunziato of Lincoln Park, N.J., and Robert Linton of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Daniel Ross Levinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Levinson of Singer Island, Fla. The Rev. Roger H. Smith, a Unitarian universalist minister, officiated at Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Dance View article in the Arts and Leisure section today, about the Australian Ballet, misidentifies a principal dancer. He is Steven Heathcote.

title: Taxis, by the Book
description: There are many ways to travel from point A to point B in New York City: subways, buses and bicycles. People walk, run or drive. And, of course, there is the yellow cab, about which the Taxi and Limousine Commission now offers convenient and sensible instructions.

title: Dr. Amy C. Heck Married To Dr. Daniel S. Kosches
description: Dr. Amy Caren Heck, a resident in psychiatry at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, was married last evening to Dr. Daniel Scott Kosches, a fellow in gastroenterology at the Albert Einstein-Montefiore Medical Centers in the Bronx. Rabbi Harold D. Halpern performed the ceremony at the Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, L.I.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Creative Kitchen in Port Chester
description: LEAD: THIS restaurant is a find: a creative kitchen is still fine-tuning but quite a few dishes have already been perfected; the solicitous staff clearly cares about the success of this enterprise and wants to please; informal, tropical decor is charming; and the price is so right for this kind of quality that dining here now is something of a bargain.

title: Martin Victor, Mayor, 76
description: Martin Victor, a former Mayor of Lattingtown, L.I., and a former vice president of Babcock & Wilcox, an engineering concern, died on Friday in his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: Final Pits Youth Against Experience
description: After today's semifinals, the final of the Metropolitan Amateur Championship at the Piping Rock Club on Sunday will offer a contrast of experience and youth.

title: Tech Notes;   NASA's New Hydrogen Ramjet
description: RAMJETS don't have turbines, so they can't ''breathe'' and can't carry a plane aloft. But once in flight, these simple jets ''ram'' air into their engine compartments, where it is mixed with fuel and burned. At high speeds, ramjets are lighter and more efficient than conventional jet-turbine engines. Now, engineers at the National Aeronautic and Space Administration's Lewis Research Center in Cleveland are bench-testing a ramjet engine (left) fueled by clean-burning hydrogen for possible use in the hypersonic National Aero-Space Plane, which will fly into orbit in one stage. The engine, which so far has been tested at speeds as high as Mach 3.5, is being put through a variety of weather simulation tests. Scientists can send sharp gusts of air into its inlet ducts to simulate turbulence, then measure the engine's responses so as to design computer control systems.

title: Campus Life: Michigan State;   Tuition Increase Inspires Threat From Governor
description: Gov.

title: Church and State
description: Representative Floyd H. Flake served church and state and abused both, Federal prosecutors said last week. Mr. Flake, pastor of one of the largest black churches in New York City, was indicted on charges of misappropriating $75,200 from a federally subsidized housing complex built by his church and with evading taxes on $66,700 of the church's money that he and his wife put to personal use. The 45-year-old clergyman, whose wife, Margarett, was also indicted on some of the same charges, strongly denied any wrongdoing. There were echoes of support in his Queens district, where the 300-unit housing project he is accused of taking money from is one of the few such successful projects for senior citizens in the nation. But there was also consternation among members of his Allen A.M.E. Church, some of whom contended that the charges were racially motivated.

title: Property Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Currency;   The Dollar Spirals Down
description: THE dollar fell just short of its post-World War II low against the German mark last week. Without Saddam Hussein it might have made it. The Iraqi President's invasion of Kuwait sparked buying of the dollar, a safe haven, on Thursday and there was enough support left on Friday to offset a worrisome economic report. The American unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July, from 5.2 percent, giving another signal that the sluggish economy may be near a recession. But because of the unrest in the Middle East, traders would not dump dollars in anticipation of lower interest rates. The dollar still closed at 1.5875 against the mark, its second-lowest level since the war. With any relaxation of tensions in the Middle East, the low of 1.5700 should not stand much longer. $ Last Previous Year Week Week Ago Japanese Yen 149.42 149.00 139.70 per Dollar W.German Mark 1.5875 1.6115 1.9050 per Dollar Canadian Dollar 1.1507 1.1522 1.1770 per U.S. Dollar British Pound 1.8585 1.8375 1.6075 U.S. Dollar per British Pound Gold $377.25 $367.30 $367.50 Republic National Bank

title: Arab of Vast Ambition: Saddam Hussein
description: With a single, swift military action, Saddam Hussein has dispelled the image he has assiduously tried to cultivate in the West as a man who can be trusted.

title: Men and Women On the Golf Course
description: When Skip Ungar wrote in his recent letter to the New Jersey editor that women golfers could join him on the golf course on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays on an equal basis - assuming they have no objection to eliminating the ladies' tees - he revealed as much about his lack of knowledge of modern-day golf as he did about his patronizing attitude.

title: Manila Troops Said to Kill 19 In a Family to Avenge 2 Dead
description: Soldiers have been accused of killing 19 members of a Muslim family, including six children, to avenge the death of two comrades who were gunned down by a member of the clan, a Government official and witnesses said today.

title: Sitcom Writing: Riches Plus Respectability
description: When the writer-producer Gary David Goldberg dropped out of Brandeis University in 1964, the thought of working within the mainstream was out of the question. Besides, he and many within his generation considered television the enemy. If recruiters from the networks had come to the campus, Mr. Goldberg now says, ''there would have been derision and boycotting, maybe shots fired.'' But times have changed. When he, along with several network executives, spoke at Harvard University a few years ago, Mr. Goldberg says, students were ''just handing out resumes.''

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Minister's Calling: Housing the Homeless
description: LEAD: Alex Cajina surveyed the wreckage of the first-floor apartment below his at 80 Elliott Avenue in Yonkers. The tenants, who had benefited from a sweat-equity homesteading program begun by a Presbyterian minister, were evicted after becoming involved in drugs and destroying the apartment in a two-day rampage.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

A Stopgap Law for the Fragile Coastline
description: LEAD: Over the last few decades, New Jersey's Atlantic coastline has been involved in considerable controversy, focused mainly on how to allow development without damaging the oceanfront's ecology.

title: With Wear and Tear, Habitat Has Become a Home
description: Montreal has several outstanding buildings - new and old - but unlike any other Canadian city, it also contains at least one work that has become known internationally and whose place in the history of architecture is assured. I am referring to Habitat, which was designed by Moshe Safdie and built as part of Expo, the world's fair that the city was host to in 1967. The fame garnered by this unusual housing experiment was based both on the building itself and on the ideas it represented. Almost a quarter century later it is time to examine how both have fared.

title: Dr. Alix Goldman Wed in California
description: Dr. Alix Goldman, a pediatrician, and Christopher Casler, a movie producer and screen writer, were married yesterday in Los Angeles. The Rev. Warner R. Traynham, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony at Salisbury House, an inn. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Goldman of Niantic, Conn. Her husband is a son of Rosemary Casler of Centreville, Md., and the late Harry Casler.

title: MARKET WATCH
description: Is Iraq's Saddam Hussein another Hitler, who will gobble up neighbor after neighbor, until finally stopped?

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Generations Take Their Turns in Mother's Blueberry Patch
description: LEAD: BLUEBERRIES are in season again. Clusters of velvet blue-black fruit ripen on our bushes. And while the sweet berries entice and beckon me to the patch, it is my mother who compels me to them. There is little choice in our family about picking blueberries from the middle of July to the middle of August; the berries are ready to harvest, and we are counted on to help.

title: Why It Isn't Ungrammatical to Speak the President's English;   The Faults of Others
description: To the Editor:

title: PRINCE CHARMING COMES BACK
description: In ''Prince Charming Comes Back'' (Hers, July 15), Daphne Merkin notes that men are bewildered or angry about the movie ''Pretty Woman.'' But she doesn't bother to examine why. We women, she writes, ''still need our myths, our amatory fictions; they help us endure.'' However, I doubt Merkin would be sympathetic to men who ''need'' to fantasize about physically beautiful, intellectually inferior, sexually submissive women to help them endure. I doubt she would trust such men to respect women.

title: Evening Hours;   Celebrating A Theater's 60th Year
description: More than 700 guests from East Hampton and Sag Harbor on Long Island trooped out to Dune Alpin Farm in East Hampton to dance under a large white tent and celebrate the 60th anniversary of Guild Hall in East Hampton and its venerable John Drew Theater.

title: The Language So Far
description: LEAD:

title:
THE SUMMER REPORT;

Costs of Living
description: LEAD: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: Some Memories of Life With Father
description: Bravo for ''A Man Who Doesn't Know His Son Is Married.'' You've done a service to all (especially the boys) who have pangs where their divorced or separated dads should reside in their hearts.

title: Poles Backing Walesa Urge Jaruzelski to Quit
description: The political movement supporting Lech Walesa's bid for the Polish presidency called on Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today to quit the post within weeks.

title: Flashcard
description: HIGH school football and basketball games are the mainstay of sports attendance in the United States, according to a Gallup Mirror of America poll conducted in February. More Americans attended high school football games during the previous year than either college or professional football games. The same held true for high school basketball. The telephone survey of 1,235 people 18 and over found that the reverse is true for baseball; more people went to a professional baseball game in the last year than to high school or college baseball games.

title: Help for Giants
description: With Lawrence Taylor and Leonard Marshall still boycotting the Giants' training camp and five other starters missing while they negotiate new contracts, the team moved to bolster its defense yesterday by picking up a linebacker, Aaron Chubb, on waivers from the Green Bay Packers.

title: Ms. Wagner Wed To Tracy Walker
description: MaryMoss Wagner and John Tracy Walker 4th were married yesterday at the Meeting House-on-the Green in New Marlboro, Mass., by the Rev. Duncan R. McQueen, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Wagner 3d of New York. Her husband, known as Tracy, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker 3d of Charlottesville, Va.

title: About Cars;   From Italy, Luxury Of a Quirky Order
description: It is maybe six years since Alfa Romeo pumped up the red and white balloons and rolled out the tiny hot dogs and other hors d'oeuvres to announce to the motoring press that it intended to become a real presence in this country.

title: Miss Artioli Weds Michael N. Findlay
description: Pauline Ann Artioli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Artioli Jr. of Somers, Conn., and Michael Nielsen Findlay, a son of Mrs. E. Andrew Deeds of Charlotte, Vt., and David B. Findlay Jr. of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Nutting, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Warren (Vt.) United Church.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Travel Advisory column on July 15 about the Chateau de Chambord in France misidentified its builder, Francois I. He was the father-in-law of Catherine de Medici, not of Eleanor of Aquitaine.

title: Caring for Children, Men Find New Assumptions and Rules
description: At a time when there is pressure on men to be more caring and demonstrative to children, more and more men and organizations are worrying that casual physical contact with children may create the impression of sexual misconduct.

title: Deborah Segal Weds Jeffrey A. Gross
description: Deborah Ann Segal, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Segal of Villanova, Pa., was married last evening at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia to Jeffrey Andrew Gross, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul R. Gross of Rydal, Pa. Rabbi Elliot J. Holin performed the ceremony.

title: Data Base Of Ancient Greece
description: HIGH ON the compact-disk charts at universities around the world is the first installment of the Thesaurus Linguae Graecae, a computer compilation of every ancient Greek text in existence.

title: Deaf Girl Finds a Fresh Air Fund Pal
description: From the insistence and intensity of their gestures, it is obvious that Sakina Williams and Brian Cosgrove are locked in a vigorous debate. Absent, however, are the strident voices that usually accompany an exchange between 7-year-olds.

title: Creator vs. Re-creator: Who Wins?
description: Beethoven was, undeniably, the great liberator of Western music. If only symbolically, his insistence on the composer's right to be treated as an equal by the aristocracy and to control his own music made possible the whole Romantic tradition of artistic freedom and independence. We know what riches that movement produced. Perhaps never in history has there been so fruitful a century. It was as if a sleeping volcano had gone off, strewing the landscape with masterpieces in every musical genre.

title: Flashcard
description: AT LEAST a third of the undergraduates surveyed last year said they had been victims of a crime since their college enrollment. The survey, conducted by the Center for the Study and Prevention of Campus Violence, at Towson State University in Baltimore, involved 1,850 students at colleges nationwide. Almost half those student victims reported being intoxicated by drugs or alcohol at the time of the crime.

title: Florio's Tax Changes: Courageous, but More Are Needed
description: IN the face of a huge deficit, a school finance crisis and a tax structure unfair to working families, Gov. Jim Florio's tax increase was an act of courage and leadership.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Fall River, Mass.;

New Condos In an Old Area
description: LEAD: A LOCAL developer's Victorian-style condominiums are designed to attract newcomers to a wealthy historic neighborhood in this mill city.

title: Miss Walsh Wed To J.P. Siebecker
description: Patricia Ann Walsh, a daughter of Drs. Robert J. and Wanda S. Walsh of White Plains, was married yesterday to Joseph Paul Siebecker, a son of Marie Siebecker of Brooklyn and the late Joseph B. Siebecker. The Rev. Robert A. Ferro officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows in White Plains.

title: In Defense of Detectors In the Courthouse
description: While some complain about sensitive metal detectors at the entrance to the Richard J. Daronco Westchester County Courthouse [''The Pros and Cons of Security Often Lie in a Beep,'' July 8] , all who use the courthouse should feel reassured to learn that the magnetometers are effective enough to detect any object containing metal.

title: Grenay Patterson Weds in Brooklyn
description: Grenay J. Patterson, a daughter of Mrs. Grant George Patterson of Brooklyn, and Henry F. C. Robertson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Robertson of Brooklyn, were married there yesterday at Emmanuel Baptist Church. The Rev. Dr. H. Edward Whitaker officiated.

title: Tax Plan Sticks New Yorkers With Bailout Tab
description: To the Editor:

title: Ettore Maserati, 96, Race Car Producer
description: Ettore Maserati, a founder and guiding force of the Maserati racing-car company, died today, the ANSA news agency reported. He was 96 years old.

title:
THE SUMMER REPORT;

Social Security
description: LEAD: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: Playing Himself
description: As a starstruck 17-year-old, David Hampton feared he would never win stage fame on his own, so he latched onto someone else's. It began one night in 1983 when he simply had to get into Studio 54 and hit upon the ruse of posing as Sidney Poitier's son. It worked so well he used it again - for a free meal in a trendy restaurant - and again and again to gain access to the homes of some wealthy and well-known New Yorkers. This eventually cost Mr. Hampton 21 months in prison. ''I didn't know conning people was a crime,'' he said in a recent interview. ''I thought I could do these things and, once I had success, I could look back on it and laugh.'' Inspired by the success of the new play ''Six Degrees of Separation,'' which was in turn inspired by his misadventures, Mr. Hampton returned to New York to try acting again. ''I would rather be known for positive achievements than as a slickster in an Off-Broadway play,'' he said.

description: A question in the Q&A column on June 10 on coping with clogged ears on planes elicited home remedies and professional suggestions from readers. Among them were these:

title: Dallas Police Chief and Aide Put on Leave After an Inquiry
description: The city has placed the Police Chief and his deputy on indefinite leave after an investigative panel found evidence that they may have tampered with witnesses and committed perjury in an internal inquiry that led to the dismissal of a police officer.

title: The Long Arm of the Constitutionz
description: CONSTITUTIONALISM, DEMOCRACY, AND FOREIGN AFFAIRS

title:
ART;

Emotional Skies and Forms
description: LEAD: EXPANSION in the Hamptons art scene in recent years has meant that visitors to galleries can find choices of first-rate nonregional exhibitions along with exhibitions of work by East End artists whose themes deal with the area.

title: The Endangered Civil Service
description: However well-intentioned and enlightened its policies, any government, from the White House to the local motor-vehicle registration office, is only as good as its workers. For the Federal Government, this undeniable truth has recently spelled trouble. It seems to be getting ever harder to staff top-flight political positions, where the turnover rate on average has been about 18 months. Meanwhile, morale, and with it commitment to the job, have been declining among civil servants. Their pay is inadequate. They face an apparent lack of public respect. And not surprisingly, recruiting needed talent is proving more difficult.

title: As Immigration to Israel Soars, Housing Plans Are Grounded by Politics
description: More new immigrants moved to Israel last month than at any time since the first years after the nation's birth 42 years ago.

title: No Headline
description: By midsummer, when Israelis seek relief from the Middle East's sweltering heat, Jerusalem is the only truly comfortable spot in the country. While the days in the city are often very warm, the air is dry, and when the sun goes down visitors and residents don cotton sweaters to ward off the cool winds blowing from the Judean Mountains.

title: Annie R. Davis Weds Lamont R. Bailey
description: Annie R. Davis, a daughter of Rena M. Davis of Brooklyn and the late John M. Davis, was married yesterday to Lamont R. Bailey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. Bailey of Jamaica, Queens. The Rev. Dr. James C. Kelly performed the ceremony at the Bethesda Missionary Baptist Church in Jamaica.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

We Walk in the Tall, Dense Forests of the Young
description: LEAD: WE are the ancients. The young know us by our furrowed brows and our time-obscured contributions to the world they populate. We are the folks who sit on the benches in the parks or on the village green, but we also are the elder statesmen, movers and counselors in the halls of governments.

title: A New Assignment for Artists: Make This Home Unique
description: LEAD: WENDY MacNAUGHTON once spent three weeks on her knees atop a ladder in the Fairfield home of Whitney Vose. She was painting a wandering Clematis vine, its purple bloossoms wrapping their way around a skylight.

title: Rich Zone Shared Since '66
description: Iraqi troops have advanced to within a mile of the Saudi border, entering the Neutral or Partitioned Zone, an oil-rich area divided between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, Kuwaiti officials said today, but Baghdad denied the report.

title: Show Good Will To U.S. Athletes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
Your Own Account;

Avoiding the Poverty of Elder Care
description: LEAD: CONSIDER THIS. A couple scrimps and saves to provide for a major financial goal: a comfortable retirement. When they retire, one develops Alzheimer's disease and is forced to go to a nursing home for round-the-clock care. The nursing home bills then eat up the assets of both.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tulsa, Okla.;

After 5 Years, Apartments
description: LEAD: TULSA'S first apartment complex in five years is being built along Riverside Drive, the Arkansas River parkland corridor that connects downtown and the growing south side.

title: Dix Hills Questions Safety Of Historic Vanderbilt Road
description: LEAD: IN 1906, with the automobile still in its infancy, the millionaire William K. Vanderbilt 2d established a limited access highway to accommodate his annual Vanderbilt Cup motorcar race and to further his dream of making Long Island the automotive racing capital of the United States.

title: A Dedicated Sentry Guards a Watershed
description: IN rural Cornwall Bridge, at the crossing of two winding country roads with the Berkshire Hills as a backdrop, a white farmhouse serves as the home of the Housatonic Valley Association. The organization is a self-appointed sentry, standing guard over the vistas that stretch southward through Connecticut, as it works to protect the environment.

title: Technology;   Lining Up for Potential Gene Therapy Profits
description: LAST week, after years of debate about the scientific and ethical dimensions of inserting new genes directly into humans, the Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee of the National Institutes of Health approved gene therapy techniques to treat certain types of immune disorders and a lethal form of skin cancer.

title: ARIEL SHARON: TALKING TOUGH
description: Sharon's reputation as a soldier rests primarily on his performance in the Six-Day War, which was outstanding. However, a man who spends 25 years in the army must be judged on his cumulative performance. A review of Sharon's military career reveals an uneven record and a persistent tendency to disobey orders, employ excessive force and remain indifferent to civilian casualties.

title: American Graphics, Full of 'Firsts'
description: ALTHOUGH the new and improved Princeton University Art Museum is closed for the summer, there is still art to be seen on the campus, notably in the Firestone Library. On view there is a large exhibition entitled ''American Graphic Arts, A Chronology to 1900 in Books, Prints and Drawings.''

title: Catching Guadeloupe's Beat
description: On a trip to Guadeloupe last June, I stopped at a roadside chicken stand somewhere on the well-paved southern coastal road between Ste.-Anne and St.-Francois. The small outdoor restaurant was empty but as the sun was setting six men came along. One started playing a large drum. Another responded with livelier rhythms on a smaller drum. They began singing in Creole, the African-based first language of Guadeloupe. They sang about their work being done. They sang about working hard.

title: Virtues of A Visual Medium

title: Hostetler: If Mobility Counts
description: When you want to divide five apples equally among seven people, you can do it easily by making applesauce. But how does a professional football team divide playing time when its starting quarterback is experienced but not especially mobile and the backup is inexperienced but mobile?

This means that no American qualified for the elimination matches to pick a challenger for the world championship in 1993. The failure was not for lack of ambition, but things just did not go their way.

description: To the Editor:

title: What Business Stands to Gain - or Lose - With Souter
description: WHAT kind of businesses are likely to be happy if David H. Souter is confirmed by the Senate to succeed William J. Brennan Jr. on the Supreme Court? Probably the ones that are just like the reclusive workaholic jurist: straitlaced, attentive to detail and respectful of both tradition and the restrictions placed on it by Government.

title: Because of Kessel, High Electric Cost
description: What Mr. Kessel didn't say in the article on Lilco (June 24) is that because of the shutdown of Shoreham, Long Island consumers will have the highest cost electricity in the United States. The installation of new gas turbine plants possibly may produce electricity at lower cost than Shoreham but only because the price of oil has fallen from $30 a barrel in the 70's. Were the price of oil (or its gas equivalent) at $70 today as all the energy planners assumed when Shoreham was initiated, the cost of electricity would be even 50 percent higher.

title: Rules Are Disputed On America's Cup
description: Organizers for the 1992 America's Cup regatta in San Diego have set residency limits on sailors and yacht designers to prevent individuals from working for more than one country. But the effort has met with resistance from a key player.

title: M. J. Roach Weds Miss Boddicker
description: Christine Hauser Boddicker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Boddicker of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael James Roach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel T. Roach of Buffalo. Canon Peter T. Elvin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Thompson Memorial Chapel in Williamstown, Mass., assisted by the Rev. Jacob C. Ledwon, a Roman Catholic priest. Mrs. Roach, 24 years old, is a graduate of Williams College. She is to begin teaching seventh grade next month at the Nichols School in Buffalo. Her father retired as a vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust in New York.

title: Brodsky's Role Sets Campaign Agenda
description: AS Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky sees it, the recently concluded legislative session in Albany was a nearly unqualified success. ''We ended spring borrowing, funded the libraries, improved reimbursement rates for hospitals, increased school aid'' and, in general, ''cut spending by state agencies while improving fiscal aid to local governments.''

title: Because of Kessel, High Electric Costs
description: The Long Island Power Authority is the wrong agency, at the wrong time, doing the wrong job in an ineffectual and inefficient manner. The threat of taking over Lilco is no longer credible, and we certainly don't need the Long Island Power Authority to decommission Shoreham.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MONKEY BAY, by Elaine Ford. (Penguin, $7.95.) In a dreary little town on the coast of Maine, Hannah Pratt decides to take revenge for her desolate childhood by seducing her mother's boyfriend. Last year our reviewer, Howard Frank Mosher, said this is ''a realistic, often unexpectedly funny and invariably well-written novel. In its unsparing but sympathetic treatment of its characters and locale, Elaine Ford's book reminds me of Andrew Wyeth's stark paintings, which use the terrain of northern New England to explore a much larger emotional landscape.''

title: Stressing the Role Of a Children's Group
description: ''Providing a Home for Those on the Run'' [July 15] profiled the Emergency Shelter for Runaway and Homeless Youths and its services to county youngsters. In the article, the role of the Westchester Children's Association in establishing, funding, and operating the shelter for three years (toward the end of 1984 through 1987), was omitted.

title: Principals Take To Pulpits
description: ONE Sunday morning James Robinson, 14 years old, watched with surprise from a wooden pew as his Baptist preacher called to the pulpit an unexpected guest: the principal of his old elementary school in Arlington, Va., Marjorie Tuccillo.

title: PRINCE CHARMING COMES BACK
description: ''As far as fairy tales go,'' writes Merkin, ''this one not only has a Prince Charming, but it also has an audacious, instinctive, principled heroine who reforms the Prince . . . the only one who has to do any real self-examination is the man!'' No wonder the film is so pleasing to many women: it perfectly captures the ethos of 1990-style feminism, which evidently holds that no woman need rue any action she has ever taken - least of all, a career in prostitution - as long as she faithfully obeys the dictates of her ''feelings.''

title: Florio's Response To Tax Critics Is Questioned
description: LEAD: THE furor over Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax reform program may have been unavoidable, political experts say, but many contend that a better effort to communicate its benefits could have minimized the public anger and skepticism.

title: Tax Plan Sticks New Yorkers With Bailout Tab;   Ads Are Ephemeral
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE BLACK WOMEN'S HEALTH BOOK: Speaking for Ourselves. Edited by Evelyn C. White. (Seal, Paper, $14.95.) Evelyn C. White has collected more than 40 poems, essays and personal memoirs in ''The Black Women's Health Book.'' Ms. White, a journalist at The San Francisco Chronicle, writes that ''over the past few years, I have observed a growing number of vibrant black women being devastated by a multitude of physical and emotional ailments, ranging from drug addiction to cancer.'' More than 50 percent of black women live in a state of emotional distress; most women with AIDS are black, and a black woman's chance of being murdered is three times higher than that of her white counterpart. Contributors, including the novelist Alice Walker, the social critic Angela Davis and the president of Planned Parenthood, Faye Wattleton, bring these statistics movingly to life. Though many of the topics - including diabetes, lupus, incest, cancer, alcoholism, AIDS, hypertension, sickle cell anemia and grief - are unavoidably depressing, the book also illustrates empowerment, hope and triumph. Some contributions, including a dry, academic piece on the history of black women physicians, do not measure up to the general quality of the writing. However, when the essays hit home, they hit hard. As Ms. White says: ''Painful though it may be, we must look at what ails us and how we can get better. . . . Please take this sisterly medicine and pass it on.''

title: In Europe, Immigrants Are Needed, Not Wanted
description: A BRIEF walk along any street in downtown London, Paris, Frankfurt or Milan immediately shows how immigration from the third world has turned many Western European cities into melting pots. But 30 years after this process began, a surge of racist incidents, smoldering hostility toward immigrants and new moves to keep out poor foreign workers show how Western Europe still has to come to terms with this change.

description: STAR SINGERS

title: Paradise Imposed
description: Imagine a luxury resort in the middle of a lava field. Imagine sod laid on top of the lava and mowed so low you could practically play pool on it. Imagine white sand on the shore, trucked in at hundreds of dollars per load and manicured as carefully as a wealthy woman's hands.

title: Postings: Cattle on the Move;   Slaughterhouse Four
description: They have kept 11th Avenue in their baleful gaze since the early 20th century, but the four giant steer heads on the top of the New York Butchers' Dressed Meat Company slaughterhouses will soon be removed.

title: Sandinistas Accused as Burial Sites Are Unearthed
description: For years, Justina Cardenas Gomez has known what happened to her brothers when they disappeared here in 1983. But she guarded the secret for fear of meeting the same fate.

title: Picture This
description: Whether one can decipher a schedule quickly enough to catch a train or interpret a navigation chart in time to avoid treacherous rocks depends a great deal on how clearly hundreds of pieces of information - facts and statistics - are ordered and presented. In ENVISIONING INFORMATION (Graphics Press, Box 430, Cheshire, Conn. 06410, $48), Edward R. Tufte argues the crucial importance of good information design and gives advice on how to achieve it. Using hundreds of illustrations, from Galileo's 17th-century rendering of sunspots to a contemporary computer-generated illustration of garbage orbiting the earth, Mr. Tufte says that good design incorporates complex data into a simple, universally comprehensible system. For Mr. Tufte, who teaches statistics, graphic design and political economy at Yale University, the essential task of information design is to escape what he calls ''flatland,'' an impoverished two-dimensional region characterized by a limited perspective on insufficient data. He discusses various design techniques - layering, small multiples and use of color - and shows through examples which would be the best way to convey the life cycle of a Japanese beetle or a 24-hour cycle of pollution in Los Angeles. Mr. Tufte writes with a serious purpose: good design is a noble endeavor menaced by ''content-empty colorjunk'' and a ''swamp of perceptual shifts and other ambiguities.'' The book itself provides a model of good design - each beautifully printed page a harmony of space, type and illustration. The language, however, often subverts the author's plea for clarity. Phrases like ''enhancing the dimensionality and density of portrayals of information'' abound, revealing more a taste for density than a craving for lucidity.

title: Judging Shearson's Chairman by His Book Covers
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Sanctions Against Baghdad Imposed by European Community
description: The 12 nations of the European Community imposed an immediate embargo today on oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait and said they would stop selling arms and other military equipment to Baghdad as punishment for having invaded Kuwait.

title: Wall Street;   Utilities Get Some Takeover Action
description: BEFORE the eruptions in the Middle East sent the theorists back to their computer keyboards on Thursday, the Dow Jones utilities had been enjoying a rare market rally, gaining nearly 5 percent over the past two weeks. The reasons were largely defensive, analysts said. With the fearsome gyrations of the Dow industrials and the damage inflicted on the Dow transports by the recent decline in United Airlines shares, the dull world of electricity production - all those reliable dividends, all that recession-proof revenue - seemed especially peaceful.

title: Andrea Whitton Marries on L.I.
description: Andrea Stewart Whitton and Peter Schoellkopf were married yesterday at the Vanderbilt Mansion in Oakdale, L.I., by the Rev. John Fordan, a Unitarian minister. Mrs. Schoellkopf is a daughter of Jayne Simonson Whitton of Macungie, Pa., and Henry G. Whitton of Little Orchid Isle in Vero Beach, Fla. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wolfgang Schoellkopf of Melville, L.I.

title: World Markets;   The Unsettling Iraq Factor
description: SADDAM HUSSEIN, the President of Iraq, bet that Kuwait was vulnerable and it was. So were most of the world's markets, which tumbled dramatically after Iraq's invasion of the emirate last week as the outlook clouded for oil prices, inflation, economic growth and the balance of power in the Middle East. .

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has a forced-air furnace that is about 14 years old. A heating contractor the heat exchange unit is badly rusted and he recommends replacing it because the heat exchanger is so bad and because the old unit had insufficient air flow. He says that the new furnace would have 90 percent efficiency and would save about 40 percent in gas costs. Is this logical, and can a gas furnace emit dangerous levels of carbon monoxide?

title: Wholesale and Retail Prices For Gasoline Climb Swiftly
description: The first message transmitted by major oil companies to Vera Haskins's fax machine came Thursday, less than 24 hours after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait: Gasoline prices would immediately increase by 3.5 cents to 8.5 cents a gallon.
