title: Review/Music;   Soviet Group Amid U.S. High-Tech
description: No one could have dreamed up an odder juxtaposition of artist to physical context than the Shostakovich String Quartet playing at the Winter Garden last Sunday afternoon. Serious, heavy-sounding Soviet musicians attacking serious, heavy-sounding Russian music seemed like space men from another planet set among the palm trees of this glass-domed monument to profit at the World Financial Center.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch;   Dim Sum: Pay-as-you-Chew Dining
description: These Chinese restaurants offer dim sum and other dishes for Sunday brunch. The listing was compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

May I Speak to a Person, Please?
description: LEAD: THE explosion in telecommunication devices has turned the telephone into anything but a user-friendly instrument. As a matter of fact these days, placing a telephone call, once thought of as routine, is more like taking a trip through a mine field.

title: Anti-Communist Radio Endangered by Success
description: In a number of ways, this is a banner year at the American institution known as Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty.

title: Costly Lapse by Gooden
description: The St. Louis Cardinals reached up from last place in the National League East today and did what no team had done in two months: They defeated Dwight Gooden.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Middle Class Is Under Seige And Can't Assist
description: LEAD: IT isn't as though I don't understand what it means to be poor.

title: The Australian Ballet: En Route to a Tradition
description: Surely but not slowly, the Australian Ballet won the hearts of a supposedly jaded audience in New York during one brief and indisputably successful week at the Metropolitan Opera House last month.

title: Sham Tradition For Old-Timers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Horned Owl Is Rare on L.I.
description: The report on the Activities of Volunteers for Wildlife (June 10) was of such good will and so helpful to our cause we hesitate to reply lest we seem ungrateful. We would, however, like to correct a technical inaccuracy, that the great horned owl is a year-round resident on Long Island. This species is common on Long Island. It is ''rare'' that Volunteers for Wildlife receives reports of great horned owls caught in backyard volleyball nets.

title: Food;   Oh Sweet Poison!
description: The first culinary reference to the tomato, as far as I know, is to its use by the Aztecs as an accompaniment, along with squash blossoms and peppers, to their cannibal feasts - a detail observed by one of Cortes's companions and reported by the anthropologist Marvin Harris in his book ''Cannibals and Kings.'' The plant itself originated in the Andes, but the Incas found no use for it and left it for the Aztecs to cultivate and name; they called it tomatl. By 1523, the plant had found its way to Europe, where the Italians took to it enthusiastically. Perhaps for this reason, the English glumly feared the tomato as an aphrodisiac, and declared it poison. ''The whole plant is of a ranke and stinking savour,'' said John Gerard in 1597.

title: Postings: Easier Down Payments;   Sonny Mae Adds a Program
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency announced last month the start of a program that should make it easier for income-eligible, first-time home buyers to enter the housing market. It applies only to buyers who use conventional, rather than below-market-rate, financing.

title: Commercial Property: The Grand Central District;   A Quest for Standards in East Midtown Esthetics
description: Having already taken up the task of patrolling the streets, sweeping up trash, helping the homeless and dispatching cabs, the Grand Central Partnership has embarked on a subtler and more daunting task: shaping taste - at least enough to tame some of the more unbridled shopfronts in mid-Manhattan.

title: Perspectives: House Auctions;   Stirring Up the Buyers in a Slow Market
description: The housing auctioneers put in a good day's work June 23 at the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel. With 800 people in the audience, 68 apartments at a condominium called Executive Plaza, at Seventh Avenue and 51st Street, went on sale.

title: College Grad, 25, Radio News Exec; Career Goal: Miss America
description: LAST year, Bianca Salahshourian, the news director at radio station WWCO in Waterbury, was scanning the newspaper when she spotted an article on the coming Miss America pageant. Another article noted that contestants for the title of Miss Greater Waterbury were rehearsing at a local civic center for their pageant.

title: Increase in Aid for Troubled Youths
description: LEAD: THE designated assessment service division of the program known as PINS - Persons in Need of Supervision - has received an increase in aid as it completes its first full year of operations in the county.

title: Why Rabbit Had to Go
description: ''Rabbit AT Rest'' will be the fourth and last of my so-called Rabbit books. Each of them occurs in the ninth year of a decade and was written, more or less, in the ninth year of the decade.

title: Making Someone Else's House Your Home
description: LAST year, William F. and Ann Powers of Setauket, L.I., and their teen-age daughter spent July in a home in Brittany, while the owners of the French house stayed in the Powers home in Setauket. The families also exchanged autos. Despite some anxiety about the friendliness of their French neighbors, the Powerses were delighted with the experience: a month's lodging in France for the price of operating their own home and car.

title: Iraqis Dig In Around Kuwait, Suggesting No Plan for Early Pullout
description: Iraqi troops fortified some of their positions in Kuwait today, a move that Pentagon officials said indicated that they might be preparing for a long stay.

title: Making A Killer
description: Iraq's capture of Kuwait is, of course, a declaration of war against Western power and economic independence.

title: Champlain's Hideaway Islands
description: Maybe it's myopia, or maybe just the glare off Lake Champlain on a sunny day, but a lot of people turn a blind eye to the tiny archipelago off the lake's northeastern shore. Drivers tend to rush right through, seeing these three islands as little more than a highway from Vermont to Canada. They hurry west across the sand bridge that became the islands' first land link to the mainland in 1850, twist up Grand Isle and North Hero, ignore the turnoff to Isle La Motte and leave the state and country at Rouses Point.

title: The Buddy System
description: MAKING A FRIEND IN YOUTH

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A BOOK OF KELLS

title: Hungry Boaters Order Burgers at Sea
description: THREE days a week, an old Navy lifeboat heads out of the Noank Village Boatyard, bound not to rescue boaters but to feed them.

title: Senegal's Spicy Noonday Feast
description: Flying to Senegal from New York, some visitors get their first glimpse of West Africa even before the coastline comes into view. Still miles from the port of Dakar, Senegal's capital city, the careful observer can spot wooden fishing canoes in bright primary colors bobbing like toys in the Atlantic waves far below. Each day, fishermen of the Lebou ethnic group set out from all along the coast around Dakar in search of ciof (pronounced choff), a meaty white species of grouper prized by Senegalese.

title: The Sounds of Brazil: More Than Lambada
description: It's now clear that outside Brazil, lambada is a new French word for hype. But before the would-be international dance craze fizzled on its way from Paris, American record companies prepared a wave of new releases from Brazil.

title: The Executive Computer;   A Marriage With Video Technology
description: IN the future it may be impossible to tell the difference between a personal computer and a television set. The two technologies are colliding even today, and in a few years we are likely to see conventional business computers giving way to ''smart TV's'' or ''video computers.''

title: Streetscapes: The Central Park Loch;   Taming a Wilderness to Hew to Olmsted's Concept
description: Not too many people take the trouble to visit the Loch, a section of upper Central Park just north of the 102d Street Cross Drive. It has no rowboats, no hot-dog vendors, no swings, no baseball field.

title: Anne McGeown Weds C.J. Rethmeyer
description: Anne Marie McGeown, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John R. McGeown of Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to Craig Joseph Rethmeyer, the son of Madeleine Rethmeyer of Novato, Calif., and Dr. Curtis Rethmeyer of Manhattan Beach, Calif. The Rev. William J. Dowd officiated at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

A FAMILY GONE BAD
description: LEAD:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Fiat's Thrust Into Eastern Europe
description: FRANCESCO GALLO, director of international operations for the Fiat Group, had the proud and worried look of an expectant father as he paced through the half-finished $1.3 billion assembly plant that Fiat is helping build here amid southern Poland's fields of hay and corn.

title: Don't Change the Law for High-Tech Crybabies
description: To the Editor:

title: Landry 6 Others, Enter Hall
description: It was a cloudy, gray morning here at the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and throughout the ceremony on the steps outside the building, a downpour appeared likely. But the rain never fell on the seven inductees and a spirited, elbow-to-elbow crowd of nearly 16,000 spectators. And the celebration turned out to be a sparkling tribute to the diverse array of stars that increased to 155 the number honored inside with bronze busts.

title: A Library Series on Global Affairs
description: LEAD: A SUMMER tradition of exploring international affairs is continuing at the White Plains Library with ''Global Perspectives,'' a three-part lecture series.

title: Style Makers;   Clive Howdle, Furniture Maker
description: Clive Howdle, who calls himself a bespoke furniture maker, built his first pieces six years ago in an old henhouse belonging to his girlfriend's mother in Yorkshire. ''It was fine, except I couldn't make anything terribly tall,'' he said with a little grin. ''I've developed a reputation for being able to shoehorn everything into small spaces.''

title: Iran Reported Ready to Restore British Ties
description: President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said today that his Government was willing to restore diplomatic relations with Britain, which Iran severed in March 1989 as a result of its anger over the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' Iranian news organizations reported.

title: At Blacks' Funeral in South Africa, a Call to Arms and for More Resistance
description: With calls to arms against black adversaries and appeals for increased resistance to the white authorities, anti-apartheid movements today buried 3 of 27 people killed in vicious factional fighting here last month.

title: Study Backs DNA Testing for Investigations
description: Genetic tests used to identify suspects in criminal cases are valid and reliable when properly performed, but strict standards must be set to assure confidence in the method, according to a Congressional study released today.

title: Lifestyle;   Portable Shade Is Big on the Beach
description: The days when the ''Doonesbury'' comic strip lampooned tanning contests with day-to-day coverage of the ''George Hamilton Pro-Am Celebrity Cocoa Butter Open'' seem to be over. So are the days of ''Let the Sunshine In,'' which may or may not be why some beaches now look like variegated mushroom fields of umbrellas.

title: U.S. Is Seeking to Forestall Any Arab Deal for Kuwait
description: Having joined with Moscow and the Western allies in a solid front of opposition to Iraq, Administration officials said today that the United States was now trying to make certain that the Arab states would not undercut efforts to force a total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bald Head Island, N.C.;

For a Resort, Slow 'n' Easy
description: LEAD: UNFAZED by the failure of other projects here in past years, a developer is building a $3 million clubhouse and a marina on this semitropical resort island.

title: For 30 Years, a Manager Travels the Back Roads of Baseball
description: AS he has been doing for more than three decades, Dick Caswell is unloading a bat bag, baseballs, batting helmets and other equipment from the trunk of his car, this time near Cubeta Stadium in Stamford, where the New Rochelle Robins are scheduled to play the Stamford Athletics in a Stamford Twilight League game.

title: Vermont's Classic Villages
description: There is a Vermont we carry around in our imagination, and a Vermont that really exists, and it's in the hill towns of the state's back roads where vision and actuality coexist best. A white church steeple framed by sugarloaf hills of maple and birch; weathered red houses progressing backward into connected red barns; a stream bending around the village in a line of alders; freshly cut meadows rising up from the town's back; a general store selling insulated boots in August, sunflower seeds in March. Picture all these, then add in the idiosyncratic details . . . the ''For Sale'' sign that has been out so long it's taken on the same sandy patina as the abandoned garage that waits behind it; the rusty snowmobile set like a planter in a wildflower-dotted lawn; the school that seems far too large for what few children are about . . . and you have a fairly realistic image of what I'm talking about here, rural Vermont simultaneously at its grittiest and most picturesque.

title: Lunch Companions: Mozart and Goodman
description: ''OUR purpose is simply to provide an oasis in the middle of the workday,'' said Debbie Moran, the series coordinator for the ''Listen 'n' Lunch'' programs at St. Paul's National Historic Site in Mount Vernon. ''We try to offer a wide range of free performances, and the relaxed atmosphere makes each concert an especially enjoyable musical experience.''

title: What's Being Sold Here?
description: LOVE FOR SALE

title: Talking: Roofs;   Making Decisions On Repairs
description: Literally at the top of most maintenance programs for a single-family house should be its roof. A leaky or damaged roof can be the source of a multitude of water problems. A roof that is worn or buckled or has missing tiles can also be an eyesore - and a visual barrier to quick or easy sale.

title: A Cup of Coffee, An Idea on Recycling
description: So William R. Healey burned his hand on a paper coffee cup while trying to transport his beverage, his briefcase and his laptop computer in a crowded elevator to his office in Trenton (''Yes, Plastic Can Be Recycled,'' Opinion page, July 8).

title: Amazon City With a Taste Of Wood Fire
description: Breaking the barbed-wire and cow-pasture monotony of the Belem-Brasilia highway, a large orange sign here proclaims, ''Welcome to Paragominas.'' The sponsor is Stihl, a maker of chain saws.

title: Iraq Makes Its Bid to Run the Show in the Middle East
description: FOR years now President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been the bad boy of Arab politics, a classic bully who lived by the credo that crime pays and absolute crime pays absolutely. The Iraqi strongman was at it again last week, invading his neighbor Kuwait, holding up the whole country for its oil and gold, and then daring the world to do something about it.

title: Correction
description: The Residential Resales column on July 29 listed an incorrect closing price for a home at 3060 Independence Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. It was $412,500, not $129,400.

title: Flash Points
description: TEACHERS are jugglers, balancing competing interests, and, sometimes, competing ideologies, to deliver to their students enough accurate information to help them make reasoned judgments.

title: Quiet Trial Could Lead to Major Abortion Ruling
description: A four-day trial that passed quietly in this small central Pennsylvania town this week may take on enormous importance for millions of American women. It is a likely candidate to become the case the Supreme Court uses to reconsider its decision recognizing the right to abortion.

title: Ms. Osborne Wed To C.C. Grinnell
description: Beth Arlene Osborne and Christopher Chandler Grinnell were married yesterday at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., by the Rev. Horace H. Grinnell, a cousin of the bridegroom. Mrs. Grinnell is the daughter of Mr. and Robert H. Osborne of Shelter Island, L.I. Her husband is a son of the late Katherine Carr Grinnell of Larchmont and the late Mr. Grinnell of Atlanta.

title: Q and A
description: Demolition Next Door

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

How Do You Get There? Practice
description: LEAD: WHEN I lived in California, I used to jot down travel directions on a three-by-five card. Now that I live in Connecticut, that seems remarkable. Here I reach for a notebook.

title: He Bleeds Cardinal Red, So Torre Returned
description: Joe Torre sat in the red baseball uniform of the St. Louis Cardinals and faced the inevitable question: Why would anybody forgo the rewards of the television booth and return to the field at the age of 50 as the manager of a last-place team?

title: ARIEL SHARON: TALKING TOUGH
description: No wonder Ariel Sharon talks tough (''Ariel Sharon: Talking Tough,'' by Joel Brinkley, July 8). Until the Palestinians come to their senses and decide to pursue peace, hawks like Sharon won't let up their vigilance, nor should we, their supporters, want them to. And Ariel Sharon as Prime Minister? Why not? A right-of-center government might be able to achieve the peace that eluded (though not for lack of trying) previous left-of-center

title: Flashcard
description: DURING the last 14 years the number of college degrees awarded to women has increased on all levels. In this same period, the number of degrees earned by men has declined; the exception is associate degrees. In 1989 women earned the majority of associate's, bachelor's and master's degrees as well as more than a third of doctorates and first-professional degrees, such as medical, law, dentistry or theological degrees. The National Center for Education Statistics predicts that for the rest of this century, women will continue to claim most degrees. In addition, women are expected to increase their share of doctorates to more than 50 percent and to earn 40 percent of first-professional degrees by the year 2000.

title: Health Facility Must Oppose Smoking
description: The article on hospitals struggling with a ban on smoking (July 15) cited the state requirements for clearcut smoking policies as a moving force in implementing such an action.

title: Q and A
description: Tours of Mayan Ruins

title: My Teacher, My Self
description: I WAS raised in a Philadelphia ghetto. My parents were divorced; my father, an electrician, was black, my mother Japanese - a stranger in a strange culture who never did learn how to work the system.

title: Barry Trial Jury Deliberates But Fails to Reach a Verdict
description: The jury in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial deliberated for four hours today but did not reach a verdict.

title: South Koreans Apply to Cross North Border
description: Thousands of South Koreans lined up before dawn today for passes to travel to North Korea during a proposed five-day border opening.

title: 8-Term Assemblyman Challenged
description: LEAD: AGAIN and again, beginning in 1974, voters in the 87th Assembly District have sent Peter M. Sullivan to Albany. But Bennett I. Gershman says the time is right this year to send him packing.

title: It's Tough For Movies To Get Real
description: It will surprise no one who has survived the crash-and-burn excesses of this summer movie season to hear that realism right now is at a premium. Indeed, it seems to have gone almost entirely out of fashion.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about accounting standards for nonprofit corporations misidentified an official of the National Charities Information Bureau Inc. He is Ken Albrecht, president of the bureau, not Daniel Borochoff, an analyst.

title: For Baby, All the Residents Are Women
description: LEAD: AT age 44, Sherri Spadone, a mother of four who started college when she was 32 years old, is not typical of doctors beginning the arduous hours of residency.

title: Tina Redwine Is Married
description: Tina Maria Redwine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bob K. Redwine of Atlanta, was married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York to Philip Srini Vasan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Srini T. Vasan of West New York, N.J. The Rev. Thomas F. Powers officiated. Mrs. Vasan, 27 years old and a graduate of Smith College, is a merchandising assistant at the Ellesse sportswear company in New York. Mr. Vasan, 31, is a vice president at Citibank in New York. He is a graduate of Oberlin College with a doctorate in economics from Harvard University.

title:
ART;

50 Artists Reunited At Bronx Museum
description: LEAD: AN art-world tradition that for the most part disappeared some time in the early 1980's has been revived in a different form. It used to be that summer meant ''new talent shows'' in New York City galleries. You would see unusual and novel work in such shows; they were one reason for sticking around during the dog days.

title: Capturing a Taste for 'Adorable Bad Music'
description: ''Don't analyze music; love it,'' said Francis Poulenc. It was a characteristic remark. Celebrated for his wit and elegance (however loud his tweeds), Poulenc was not a graduate of the Paris Conservatory, but of the Sorbonne. Hence his academic foundation was not musical but literary, and his professional outlook was libertarian: ''For Poulenc composing was a game,'' wrote his fellow Frenchman, the composer and conductor Manuel Rosenthal. ''His music is very lively and amusing, running from one melody to the next. There is never any development - no 'grand architecture' as with Ravel.'' According to Rosenthal, Ravel himself admired Poulenc's ''ability to invent popular tunes,'' and the popular element - at least what we now discern retrospectively as a reflection of popular trends of the period - is often implied in much of Poulenc's work.

title: Ms. Del Guercio Planning to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Maria Victoria Del Guercio and Gregory Vander Roest Stanton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Stanton Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Louis R. M. Del Guercio of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: San Francisco Limps In Repair of Damage Months After Quake
description: Bent but not broken, the flagpole atop the Ferry Building was a powerful symbol of San Francisco's durability, its tensile strength, in the days after last October's earthquake.

title: Postings: In Murray Hill;   Future Perfect?
description: What's in store for the Future, a 35-floor condominium, now about halfway completed, at 200 East 32d Street and Third Avenue?

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: As far as any bridge historian can remember, there has never been a tie in the final of a National Knockout Team Championship. Never, that is, until two weeks ago in the Grand National in Boston. The event began at grass-roots level nine months earlier and was down to two teams. At stake was a major title and the right to compete in playoffs to determine the United States representatives in the World Olympiad.

title: Limits Placed on State Rental Help
description: LEAD: IN recent months, the State Department of Human Resources hired extra staff and devoted countless hours to finding apartments for more than 1,300 welfare families who had been living in shelters and motels. All of those families had exceeded the state's 100-day limit for receiving emergency housing benefits and all have now been placed in permanent homes.

title: Portland, Me.
description: To the Editor: In regard to Jane Holtz Kay's portrayal of Portland, Me. (''A Rough-Hewn Maine Seaport,'' Travel, May 13), I found her wording of the following phrase disturbing, if not outright offensive:

title: The Looking Glass, Through
description: When the Berlin wall collapsed last November, the most potent symbol of the cold war went crashing down with it. An even more fearsome one has now fallen with the end of continuous flights of the Looking Glass plane, the airborne strategic command post designed to survive a nuclear attack on the United States and direct retaliation.

title: No Superwomen Need Apply
description: RUNNING MATES

title: Flashcard
description: THERE were 40,407,540 students enrolled in 83,165 public elementary and secondary schools in the United States during the school year 1988-89. California is home to the most public schools, 7,312 of them, while Delaware, with 168, has the fewest.

title: Flashcard
description: MORE than half of all public libraries in the United States do not have any librarians on staff whose primary responsibility is attending to children, who are major users of public library resources and services. Four out of ten public libraries have fewer than two full-time employees, which means librarians must be generalists. Almost two-fifths of public library users in the fall of 1988 were children age 14 and younger, according to a study recently released by the National Center for Education Statistics.

title: Fear Is Quality's Biggest Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Poetry: Mississippi Blues And the Beat
description: There's a point on ''BLues in the Mississippi Night'' (Rykodisc 90155; CD only) when the guitarist Big Bill Broonzy compares notes with his pianist, Memphis Slim, about life in the gulaglike penal camps of the Deep South. ''You know, the way we lived in those tents and things like that,'' Broonzy remembers, ''and the food we had to eat was . . . scrap food from what other people had refused . . . old bags of beans and stuff that they couldn't sell.'' The time is the mid-1940's, and the two musicians, along with the harmonica player Sonny Boy Williamson, have been brought together for this recording by the folklorist Alan Lomax. The men speak candidly about life and the origins of the blues, and they occasionally sing.

title:
BLACKBOARD;

In a Class Beyond the End Zone
description: LEAD: BY 1979, Charles White had nearly everything he could imagine: he was the year's Heisman Trophy winner as the nation's outstanding football player and the Cleveland Browns' first draft pick, with a promising professional career ahead of him. What Mr. White did not have when he left the University of Southern California to follow other

title: Worlds Apart
description: TEACHERS are jugglers, balancing competing interests, and, sometimes, competing ideologies, to deliver to their students enough accurate information to help them make reasoned judgments.

title: When Imitation Isn't the Sincerest Form of Flattery
description: IF America's armchair quarterbacks ever voted for their favorite piece of furniture, chances are they might elect the La-Z-Boy recliner. With huge cushions that gently mold to the supine contours of the heftiest fan and a footrest that stretches obligingly forward to prop up weary feet, the La-Z-Boy has become an icon of middle-class creature comforts.

title: Ms. Moran Wed To M. L. Galeno
description: Carol Linda Moran, a deputy bureau chief in the Brooklyn District Attorney's Office, and Michael Louis Galeno, an Assistant Brooklyn District Attorney, were married yesterday at the Bedford Presbyterian Church in Bedford Village, N.Y., by the Rev. Dr. Thomas A. Hughart.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Home Passes Through a Generation
description: LEAD: THE house a few doors away on the unpaved wagon road looks suddenly transformed. A lovely grandma lives there and now her grandson has taken up residence, too.

title: Iraq Without Hussein Would Be the Same
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Two Jakes' Picks Up The 'Chinatown' Trail
description: ''I don't want to live in the past,'' says the private detective who is the protagonist of Jack Nicholson's new film, ''The Two Jakes.'' ''I just don't want to lose it.''

title:
FOCUS: Boston;

Linkage Fees Subsidize New Housing
description: LEAD: Mixed-income housing is rising in this city's South End neighborhood, encouraged by city planning and financing that uses fees paid by developers of large downtown commercial projects to subsidize construction of low- and moderate-income housing in outlying neighborhoods.

title: Cynthia Franklin Marries
description: Cynthia Leigh Franklin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Franklin of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford to Daniel Kevin Carpenter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Carpenter of Northville, Mich. The Rev. Carl Becker officiated. Mrs. Carpenter, 25 years old, graduated from Cornell University. She received an M.B.A. from Boston University in May. Mr. Carpenter, 26, a University of Michigan graduate, received a law degree from Boston University in May.

title: Fashion;   LEGS!
description: It's not that leggy fashions are exactly new - after all, the short skirt has been around so long that it's almost ancient. But when some of this season's new bodysuits start showing up, watch out! With a skintight fit and wild patterns in bold colors, they are bound to start leg legends anew. The eye-boggling bodysuit, or cat suit as it is sometimes called, is a style trend that has been taken up by designers and comes in every price range. The fabrics vary from wool to silk to cotton, but the stretch fibers woven into all of them give them their super fit and resiliency. Oddly enough, despite their hug-every-curve quality, cat suits are attractive on lots of less-than-perfect bodies. However, ones patterned with such panache as these should be worn only by the best in shape.

title: Cranberry Bogs Cause Wetlands Debate
description: LEAD: STATE cranberry growers are hoping that a new governmental task force will simplify complicated wetlands regulations that have lately kept them from expanding their bogs to meet increased market demand.

title: Show by Fellowship Winners
description: THE thin line separating art from crafts is nearly erased when they are exhibited side by side. In the current exhibition at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts, it is hard to tell the difference, even with a program.

title: Jessica G. Bullard Is Wed in Jersey
description: Jessica Gould Bullard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Bullard of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Paul Lee, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth K. Lee of Seoul, South Korea, and Manassas, Va. The Rev. Gregory W. Schmidt, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills.

title:
TV VIEW;

A Body at Rest Tends to Remain Glued to the Tube
description: LEAD: Most American homes - 57 percent - now have cable television, and nearly all have access to more than 30 channels. One quarter of cable homes can already receive 50 channels, and virtually every cable company in the country has plans to move toward greater channel capability. Within the next two and a half years, Paragon and Manhattan Cable expect to upgrade their systems in New York

title: Campus Life: Tufts;   Judge Upholds Exemption On Building Law
description: A judge has ruled in favor of Tufts University in its case against a city planning law.

title: He Lives to Eat
description: RESERVATIONS RECOMMENDED

title: The Actors Who Follow the Impossible Acts
description: ''It's a tricky task,'' Arthur Laurents said one recent afternoon, discussing the job of bringing a new actor into a working production. Mr. Laurents, who wrote the book for ''Gypsy'' and directed its current Broadway revival, was in the midst of helping Linda Lavin prepare to replace Tyne Daly as Rose. ''I want to use what Linda is offering,'' he added, ''yet it has to adapt to the production as it is.'' Tricky indeed. ''Difficult'' is the word Don Scardino uses to describe the process. As the director of ''A Few Good Men,'' Mr. Scardino has become an expert on bringing in replacements. Since the play opened last November on Broadway, three-quarters of its 20 roles, including all the leads, have been recast. Of course, all productions must accommodate the shifting schedules of actors - especially in the summer, when the Tony awards have been presented and television actors on hiatus are available.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Campus Life: Georgetown;   Neighbors Fight Student Housing Off Campus
description: With their cobblestone streets and 18th-century brick town houses, the neighborhoods surrounding Georgetown University are a source of pride for residents. But many residents contend that the drunken behavior of students living off campus are creating slumlike conditions.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 22 about the Jasna Gora Monastery in Poland misidentified the Roman Catholic holy day celebrated on Aug. 15. It is the Feast of the Assumption, not Ascension Day.

title: Where Fat 'Is Not a Dirty Word'
description: CHERYL AFFINITO, of New Haven, said she could not stand watching her friends isolate themselves because they were too ashamed of their weight to go out in public. She and a friend, Annette Paffen, of Seymour, responded last fall by organizing the Connecticut chapter of the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance.

title: Miss Cotins and Christopher Low Wed
description: Elizabeth Hyde Cotins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Cotins of St. James, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Alfred Maximilian Low, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Low of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Paul B. McInerny officiated at St. Mary of the Isles Roman Catholic Church in Islesboro, Me.

title: Bonn Moves to Buy the East, Before the Bill Arrives
description: AS Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany have been playing it, unification is like one of those ''Lost Our Lease - Everything Must Go'' sales, in which the store never closes but just keeps doing business under another name.

title: He Didn't Ask, but Here's Some Advice for G.M.'s Bob Stempel
description: LEAD: THE General Motors Corporation got a new chairman last week: Robert C. Stempel, 57 years old, who joined G.M. in 1958 and rose through the ranks as an engineer. Gone is Roger B. Smith, 65, who retired after a turbulent decade marked by record profitability as well as a steady decline in market share.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Check rosebushes for water needs and protect them from black spot and mildew with fungicidal spray; these two diseases can defoliate plants unless controlled. Dry herbs for culinary use this winter. Make potpourri. Keep up with vegetable harvests. Mail orders for hardy bulbs for planting in cooler weather.

title: Optical Allusions
description: THE STATE of Texas, long considered a national bellwether in the selection of elementary and secondary school textbooks, is for the first time considering computer software, videodisks and CD-ROM disks as alternatives to conventional printed textbooks in some courses.

title: Low-Income Leap to College
description: AMEENAH A. Long had a crisis of confidence recently as she considered the end of four years at Hartford Public High School and the start of her college career. Four weeks before the graduation ceremonies, she said, ''It hit me -this is it, no more high school,'' only a daunting prospect ahead.

title: On Language;   Acronym Power
description: One way to stand out in a world swimming in mere abbreviations is to assemble the letters into pronounceable words. As several recent examples show, acronyms fall into distinct categories.

title: College Lifeline
description: TEACHERS are jugglers, balancing competing interests, and, sometimes, competing ideologies, to deliver to their students enough accurate information to help them make reasoned judgments.

title: Roll-Call on Spending Limits
description: Following is the vote of 255 to 155 by which the House of Representatives on Friday approved legislation to place a limit of $715,000 on how much House candidates can spend on their election campaigns. Voting ''yes'' were 240 Democrats and 15 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 3 Democrats and 152 Republicans. Y is a ''yes'' vote. N is a ''no'' vote. X denotes those not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: Els Neukermans Wed in Palo Alto
description: Els Maria Neukermans, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Armand P. Neukermans of Palo Alto, Calif., was married there yesterday to Peter Standish Paine 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paine Jr. of New York. The Rev. Russell J. Roide and the Rev. Kamiel de Rooms officiated at St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Immortal Pose
description: LEAD:

title: Ann Burke to Wed Timothy Dansdill
description: Dr. and Mrs. John F. Burke of Belmont, Mass., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Ann Campbell Burke, and Timothy Thomas Dansdill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Dansdill of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Keeping Score
description: To follow developments in the management of the Metropolitan Opera, it might help to have a libretto. Directors of the Met, which has been without a chief administrator since Hugh Southern was forced out as general manager in June, last week named John Volpe to the job. Sort of. Mr. Volpe, who arrived 26 years ago as an assistant carpenter, will be the Met's chief administrator, but he will be called general director instead of general manager and will have less power than his predecessors. For instance, the new executive director for external affairs, Marilyn Shapiro, who like Mr. Volpe was promoted from assistant manager, will report not to the general director but to the president of the Met board, Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey. So, too, will the artistic director and conductor, James Levine. None of which seems to bother Mr. Volpe. He explained: ''I like opera but I can't say that I love it. But I do love running a theater.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

If Stores Close, Should We Mourn?
description: LEAD: THEY stand diagonally across the boulevard from each other,silent shells awaiting the wrecker's ball. Their emptiness is accentuated by rows of vacant parking spaces. No cars. No people. No noise. White lines, asphalt, cracked cement and peeling paint.

title: Miss Brown Wed To Mark Siceloff
description: Suzanne Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Brown Jr. of London, was married yesterday in Basking Ridge, N.J., to Mark Jeffrey Siceloff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. Siceloff of Basking Ridge. Msgr. William J. Capik officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. James.

title: Correction
description: A letter about the second baseman Louy Whitaker (Mailbox, July 29) incorrectly identified the writer. His name is Jim Grondin.

title: HOW SHOULD PGA TOUR RE-EVALUATE SITE RULES?
description: The uproar over the P.G.A. Championship tournament is justified only to the point that most prestige golf clubs are restricted. Perhaps the Shoal Creek affair will lead to quiet work toward more progressive policies at clubs nationwide, which would also ensure that site selection for all tournaments would be completely nonpolitical.

title: Japanese High School Ready to Open
description: LEAD: THE county's newest high school, Keio High School of New York, is to open as scheduled here next month, with about 35 of the 120 entering students transferring from other high schools within the county. All the students in the initial class are the children of Japanese families living abroad.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has a forced-air furnace that is about 14 years old. A heating contractor the heat exchange unit is badly rusted and he recommends replacing it because the heat exchanger is so bad and because the old unit had insufficient air flow. He says that the new furnace would have 90 percent efficiency and would save about 40 percent in gas costs. Is this logical, and can a gas furnace emit dangerous levels of carbon monoxide?

title: M. D. Siegel Weds Sharon Margolies
description: Sharon Melissa Margolies and Michael David Siegel were married last evening at the Union Reform Temple in Freeport, L.I., by Rabbi Lawrence Colton. Mrs. Margolies Siegel is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Margolies of Baldwin, L.I. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Warren Siegel of San Juan Capistrano, Calif.

title:
BLACKBOARD;

Update 1
description: LEAD: IN THE spring issue of Education Life we met a group of intrepid University of Pennsylvania students who had just begun refurbishing a three-bedroom row house in West Philadelphia as part of an unusual class on renovating inner-city housing. It was the third such project that graduate students had undertaken under the direction of William

title: Lillian C. Gustilo Marries
description: Lillian C. Gustilo and Roderick M. Hamar were married yesterday at the Good Shepherd Roman Catholic Church in Golden Valley, Minn., by the Rev. Theodore C. Campbell. The couple, both 26 years old, graduated from Brown University. The bride, who is keeping her name, is a law student at the University of Minnesota. She is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ramon Gustilo of Eden Prairie, Minn. Mr. Hamar, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. Hamar of Wilton, Conn.

title: Brown Tide Back, Puzzling Scientists Seeking Its Source
description: LEAD: TWO years of searching for the cause of explosive algal blooms that turned the bays of eastern Long Island brown and eradicated Peconic Bay scallops between 1985 and 1987 seem to be uncovering some answers, but also some puzzling new questions.

title: New York's Deadly Season
description: SAN FRANCISCO has its earthquakes, the Midwest its tornadoes. But last week, as a crime wave continued to crash over the city, it seemed that one of the most dangerous things a person could do was to live in New York.

title: As the Crow Talks
description: For people who notice such things, there has recently been an unaccustomed hush in nature. The wind sighed and other birds called, but nature's great conversationalist, the crow, was hardly uttering a caw. With young crows not long out of their nests, the parents were keeping quiet, lest predators discover their fledglings.

title: 'As Thousands Cheer'
description: To the Editor:

title: Future Schlock
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: BOOK OF KELLS

title: Karen Petty Wed To David F. Hold
description: Karen Elizabeth Petty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Petty Jr. of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to David F. Hold, a son of Florence G. Hold of New York and Frederick W. Hold of Vancouver, Wash. Dr. Robert M. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md.

title: Steinbrenner Would Qyit U.S.O.C.
description: George Steinbrenner, addressing his Olympic position publicly for the first time, said he would resign as a vice president of the United States Olympic Committee if committee leaders thought it was appropriate because of his banishment from the daily operations of the Yankees.

title: Singing Her Own Song
description: LEAD:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

An Advanced Degree And Retrogressive Behavior
description: LEAD: A COUPLE of months ago, while my wife, Barbara, was attending the Sunday Unitarian Fellowship service, she was asked the whereabouts of her husband. After a moment of reflection, she answered that I was home on that beautiful Sunday suffering from a case of PDS. When queried further, she told her questioner not to worry.

title: Tireless Matchmaker Unites Pets With People
description: LEAD: BETTY LONG was new to Westport in 1926, when a neighbor asked her if she could find a home for a dog that the neighbor could no longer keep. An avowed animal lover, Mrs. Long found not only a home for the pet, but also a vocation that would span more than half a century, as she matched thousands of unwanted animals with new owners.

title: Judge Adopts Plan on Los Angeles Districting
description: The Federal district judge who found two months ago that Los Angeles County had illegally excluded Hispanic people from representation on its governing board has now imposed a plan aimed at remedying that discrimination.

title: Characters From the Heart of Babylon
description: LEAD: ERIC KRAFT is stunned. A friend has called him at his East Hampton home with news about an article in The New Yorker that tells about a local gallery owner who had purchased a collection of ''erotic whirligigs'' from a Tennessee farmer who makes them in his spare time.

title: Bronze Treasures From Indonesia
description: Indonesia's robust bronze tribal artifacts made before the 8th century help to explain the earthiness seen in later objects of the Hindu-Buddhist period, which dominates the exhibition ''The Sculpture of Indonesia,'' at the National Gallery of Art here. At the entrance to the show, organized by the museum to cover artifacts from the fifth to 15th centuries, is a selection of these ancient bronzes: a haunting figure of a man, an elephant-shaped vessel, a flask and a ceremonial ax, works virtually unknown until now in the West.

title:
THE SUMMER REPORT;

Early Birds
description: LEAD: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   For the Back 40 (Or the East 60's)
description: Manhattan has been mistaken for a lot of things over the years, but rarely for a county fair. Not, that is, until this summer, when many of the simple folk of New York City gave their wardrobes an overall overhaul. Bib overalls, of course, can be every bit as useful on Madison Avenue as in the milking barn, what with all those pockets and all that room. They just take a little getting used to.

title: Degrees in Whole Earth
description: MUCH as the creation of a women's studies major reflected a kind of consciousness-raising for students in the 1970's, so environmental studies may be a generational barometer for the 1990's, as colleges and universities increasingly create curriculums on the environment and grant their graduates degrees.

title: Unclogging Ears
description: A question in the Q&A column on June 10 on coping with clogged ears on planes elicited home remedies and professional suggestions from readers. Among them were these:

title: Stop Hussein, With Force if Necessary
description: IN the last three weeks President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has ushered in a frightening era in international commerce and relations. He has used blackmail and force to achieve his commercial and political ambitions. President Hussein, a desperate man facing failed domestic policies, must be stopped now, if necessary by force. Otherwise the world energy market, international commerce and economic progress will be irreparably damaged.

title: Campus Life: Florida A & M;   Rapid Growth Outpaces Space In Dormitories
description: Florida A & M University is discovering that growth can bring pain along with benefits.

title: Litchfield Gets a Stylish, Modern Grill
description: ONE of the smartest-looking modern restaurants to open recently is in Litchfield, a town that prides itself on its 18th-century appearance.

title: Criminal Type Captures Whitney
description: Criminal Type continued to prove himself the country's top race horse by more than default when he scored a thoroughly professional 1 1/2-length victory over Dancing Spree today in the $234,400 Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Update 2
description: MICHAEL Wright, who drew the cover for Education Life's spring issue, left off the number 2. Beth Nelson, 8 years old, of Rochester, Vt., discovered its absence and made her own drawing in a letter to the editor to tell us about it.

title:
Focus: Boston;

Linkage Fees Subsidize New Housing
description: LEAD: Mixed-income housing is rising in this city's South End neighborhood, encouraged by city planning and financing that uses fees paid by developers of large downtown commercial projects to subsidize construction of low- and moderate-income housing in outlying neighborhoods.

title: 'Red Desert' Showing
description: Michelangelo Antonioni's first color film, ''Red Desert'' (1964), is to open a two-week run at the Public Theater on Aug. 31. One of the Italian director's stories of alienation, the film stars Monica Vitti and Richard Harris. The new print, struck from the negative, will be shown nightly except Mondays at 5:30, 7:40 and 9:50, with a Saturday and Sunday matinee at 3:15. Tickets are $6. Information: 598-7171 or (after 1 P.M.) 598-7150.

title: A Ton of Passion and 100 Grams of Patience
description: For a short while, Nicolas de Stael was a name on many lips. Having lived in poverty during the 1940's on the fringes of a Parisian art scene that was itself beginning to seem marginal, de Stael found himself suddenly, in the early 50's, unable to satisfy the demands of his New York dealer for new paintings. Ambitious American collectors clamored for the abstractions, figure studies and landscapes de Stael created by laying slabs of brightly colored paint on canvas, like a mosaicist laying down tiles.

title: Protecting Against Lightning
description: LIGHTNING causes millions of dollars in home and property damage, not to mention hundreds of injuries, in the United States each year. Fortunately, houses in heavily built-up areas where there are many tall buildings generally are at a small risk.

title: HOW SHOULD PGA TOUR RE-EVALUATE SITE RULES?
description: Regardless of the legal issue over clubs declining invitations to blacks, this practice is morally repugnant, and the PGA Tour should respond by conducting its tournaments at nondiscriminating courses.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Strike the Pose: When Music Is Skin Deep POP VIEW;   Video Age Music: Stark Images, Shrill Voices, Skin Deep
description: Probably no record distills the video-game quality of so much contemporary pop more succinctly than M. C. Hammer's hit ''U Can't Touch This.'' Over a funk riff appropriated from Rick James's 1981 ''Super Freak,'' the 27-year-old rap star from Oakland, Calif., proclaims his pop triumph in doggerel that says, in effect, It's great to be top dog in this Darwinian jungle!

title: What's so Funny About Washington?
description: As publishers of slick, adfat magazines go, Bill Regardie is regarded as a very gutsy fellow indeed. Co-founder and editor in chief of the irreverent Washington magazine that bears his name, Regardie has in the past 10 years managed to offend a lot of powerful people. Certainly he seems to have tried to offend them, town house to White House and everything in between. Regardie also managed - inevitably, one might say - to savage Washington's mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., maintaining among other things that his administration was bloated, venal, corrupt, incompetent and just plain stupid. It was a view that alienated many of the city's blacks and triggered a boycott of Regardie's. The publisher, who has been known to roller-skate to lunch at the Palm and wear shorts to board meetings, was unperturbed. Then, two years ago, he hired Pat Oliphant. ''I had wanted for a long time to have an outlet inside the Beltway,'' says Oliphant, the mild-looking cartoonist who has won virtually every award journalism has to offer, including the Pulitzer in 1967, but whose work, oddly, does not appear regularly in a newspaper in Washington, the town where he has lived and worked for the past 15 years. ''I had always done things with national scope and I really wanted to do some strictly Washington things.''

title: Organ Tonation: He Asks Families, in Face of Death, to Consider Gift of Life
description: LEAD: HER tiny chest swelled higher and fuller than it normally would, even with her deepest breath. Then it collapsed, and rose again, with clocklike regularity. Lou Krefski stared at the 2-year-old child, her long auburn hair tossed across the pillow, her eyelids that would not close.

title:
MUSIC;

Hampton to Play a Mix Of Styles at 2 Concerts
description: LEAD: LIONEL HAMPTON and his orchestra, familiar faces and sounds in New Jersey, will perform in the state twice this week, playing a range of jazz and popular styles, including some of Mr. Hampton's own compositions.

title: Boris Yeltsin, Man of the Hour?
description: Vladimir Kvint, Professor of Political Economy of the U.S.S.R. and a former professor at the Communist Higher Party School in Moscow, is a member of the ''Siberian school'' of market-oriented economists. Professor Kvint, who is currently a distinguished lecturer at Fordham University, spoke with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times through an interpreter.

title: Race, Ethnicity and the Privileged
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Thornton, Banker, Is Wed
description: Suzanne Thornton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Thornton of Barrington, N.H., was married yesterday to Thomas Richard DeNunzio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. DeNunzio of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Charlotte H. Sommers officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Tamils Kill 110 Muslims at 2 Sri Lankan Mosques
description: Tamil militants with machine guns and hand grenades raided two mosques in eastern Sri Lanka, killing more than 110 men as they knelt in prayer, witnesses and officials said today.

title: The Home Front
description: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-22

title: It's Summertime And Road Work Slows the Traffic
description: Ben and Dorothy Lin left Bethesda, Md., at 8:15 A.M. yesterday and hoped to be in Tarrytown, N.Y., about five hours later. The Lins established this modest goal before they encountered the George Washington Bridge.

title: 367 on British Jetliner Stranded in Kuwait
description: Among the thousands of foreigners trapped in Kuwait by the Iraqi invasion are 367 passengers of a British Airways jet that was at the international airport when Iraqi troops moved in, the airline announced yesterday.

title: Yanks Explore Role For Seaver
description: Tom Seaver, who had been a Yankee braodcaster on WPIX the last two years, confirmed last night that he and George Steinbrenner had spoken in a ''general conversation'' about the former pitcher's taking a front-office job with the team.

title: Review/Music;   The Cleveland Quartet In Mostly Mozart Bill
description: The Cleveland Quartet offered a Mostly Mozart program with an interesting if subtle thematic thread on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Three of the four works the ensemble and its three musical collaborators played included movements based on quotations from earlier works.

title: Life After Wall Street: Less Stress - Less Money, Too
description: She was an arbitrageur and he was a trader, and before they reached their mid-30's, they had a combined annual income that sometimes exceeded a half million dollars. In the days of 1980's glory - or high-speed greed, depending on the point of view - they were like many of their Wall Street colleagues: always running, and making more money than they ever thought possible.

title: Design;   The Home Team
description: Architects have always had a yen for decorating, and decorators, an itch for architecture. Both often fancy themselves landscape designers as well. Indeed, it is quite common these days to find homes that have been designed, decorated and landscaped by one person.

title: Isolate Iraq
description: Iraq's Arab neighbors have canceled the summit meeting scheduled for today; they can't bring themselves even to try to stop Saddam Hussein's million-man army and undo his conquest of Kuwait. That's now the world's business, and it can be accomplished only with unity and leadership that produce hard-hitting sanctions.

title: Cultural Imperatives
description: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: Freeport Fishermen Fear 'Revitalization'
description: LEAD: FISHERMEN in Freeport fear that the village government wants to force them off the historic ''Nautical Mile'' along the Woodcleft Avenue canal, where fishing has been the trade for 140 years, to clear the way for a revitalized waterfront that would attract more profitable shops and businesses as well as homebuyers looking for a charming place to live.

title: Miss Goldman Is Wed on L.I.
description: Michelle Joanne Goldman and Jeffrey Ford Eisenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Eisenberg of Miami, were married last evening at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Goldman of Sands Point, L.I., by Rabbi Norman Kahan.

title: Surpirses From the Unpredictable Past
description: THE END OF THE LINE

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: The price of rare coins is rising as investors seek unique coins in the highest conditions. The latest to be sold is an ultra-high-relief example of a 1907 $20 gold piece. The MTB Banking Corporation reports that it sold the coin for more than $1.5 million.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;

2 New Hotels Amid a Slide
description: LEAD: With two higher-priced hotels being built and slated for fall openings, questions are being raised about the possibility of an oversupply of luxury rooms in this city.

title: FROM RIVERBANK TO THE BOOKSHELF
description: There is some first-rate writing coming from those whose muse is stimulated by their going afield with rod or gun. John Gierach's ''Sex, Death, and Fly-Fishing'' (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, 238 pages, paperback $8.95, hardcover $17.95) is one such effort.

title: Lillian Goldstein, A Student, Weds
description: Lillian Rachel Goldstein, a daughter of Dr. Elliott J. Goldstein of Pittsburgh and Dr. Marion Zucker Goldstein of Amherst, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Andrew Schapiro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Schapiro of New York. Rabbi Ari Cartun officiated at the Westin William Penn in Pittsburgh.

title: 2 Men Are Shot in the Neck in Mott Haven
description: Two men were shot near the same location in the Bronx within five minutes of each other yesterday, and the police are investigating whether the shootings are related.

title: Campus Life: Hood;   Summer Camp For Scientists Of the Future
description: A year ago Ubaldo (Ozzie) Duran spent his after-school hours roaming the streets of Los Angeles, a member of a tough street gang who carried a knife and picked fights with rival gangs. Today he's thinking about medical school.

title: Who's Afraid of Lytton Strachey?
description: EMINENT VICTORIANS

title: A Hard Look at Waterborne Traffic Control
description: UNLIKE planes in crowded skies, ships in crowded harbors and channels are not required to have guardian controllers sitting at all-seeing radar screens and, via radio, keeping everybody out of each other's way. The Coast Guard does have a control system of sorts, but its weaknesses were underscored last week both by Congressional hearings on the port traffic control needs of Alaska and New York and by a collision in the busy shipping channel between Houston and the Galveston Bay that resulted in an oil spill of perhaps 500,000 gallons.

title: Surgery for Reardon
description: The operation took only a little more than two hours, and the patient will be staying in the hospital only a few days, but by the time Jeff Reardon is able to pitch again the 1990 season will be history.

title: Fine Art Museum Is Not Needed in Roslyn
description: The present unhappy state of affairs of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor will remain unresolved as long as the present management is oblivious to the fact that we simply do not need another fine-art museum located at its present location.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE bird sat high atop a utility pole, a brown-backed bird of prey about the size (and color) of a family-size loaf of sliced bread. To one side of the pole lay a narrow strip of meadows, then woodland. On the other side, a narrower strip of macadam, then a suburban yard. If the bird remained very still, he might pass himself off as just another part of the creosote-stained pole, which for birds of prey is a very good thing.

title: Wall Street;   For Foreign Investors, the Dow's Direction Is Relative
description: THE eruption of a shooting crisis at one of the world's pulse points typically sends nervous international investors scurrying for the safety of the dollar. Sure enough, when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday, the greenback soared - but only for a few hours. Then, the dollar sagged again, as investors pondered the impact costlier oil could have on the fragile United States economy.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Fall River, Mass.;

New Condos In an Old Area
description: LEAD: A local developer's Victorian-style condominiums are designed to attract newcomers to a wealthy historic neighborhood in this mill city.

title: The Quiz
description: AMERICANS have been getting a healthy dose of lessons in civics and government lately, what with proposed constitutional amendments, suggested reforms of the Electoral College (remember the Electoral College?), attempts at taking a census and efforts to establish democracies from scratch.

title: Races to Watch
description: WASHINGTON

title: Flashcards
description: OVER half the public radio stations in the United States - 200 in all - are operated by universities, as are 92 public television stations. The first public radio station began broadcasting from the University of Wisconsin more than 70 years ago. Radio stations were developed by universities, usually by their engineering departments, as a teaching tool. In 1945 the Federal Communications Commission reserved FM channels for noncommercial broadcasting by school boards and universities, after which the university stations grew and prospered.

title: The United Nations Comes of Age, Causing Some Anxiety
description: WITH the end of the cold war, the United States and the Soviet Union are forging a working alliance at the United Nations that offers the organization its first real chance in 45 years to function as it is supposed to.

title: INSIDE
description: Immigrants Pour Into Israel

title: The Fourth R
description: TEACHERS are jugglers, balancing competing interests, and, sometimes, competing ideologies, to deliver to their students enough accurate information to help them make reasoned judgments.

title: Michael Porter Redux: Yes, but . . .
description: In an article on the July 22 Forum page, Michael E. Porter, a professor of business administration at the Harvard Business School, discussed the issue of American competitiveness (''Japan Isn't Playing by Different Rules''). Professor Porter believes that the United States has been moving away from one of its fundamental principles - faith in competition - having been seduced by a mistaken view of the reasons for Japan's success in the world marketplace. He argues that a competitive ''home environment'' is a prerequisite for global success.

title: Center Offers Support on Alzheimer's
description: FEW diseases are as difficult to live with as Alzheimer's, a degenerative brain disorder that is both progressive and irreversible. For the families involved, the personality changes that the afflicted suffer on a day-to-day basis can be devastating.

title: Steinbrenners Outline Chain of Command for Down the Road
description: With the ouster of George Steinbrenner as the Yankees' general partner, Hank Steinbrenner has become the focus of attention as the man most likely to succeed his banished father. Hank, however, is not his father's son who will ultimately rule the Yankees. Barring a coup d'etat from within or forced from without, son Harold will someday assume command of the fabled but fallen franchise.

title: Stone Face on the Sidelines
description: LEAD:

title: In Yonkers, No End Of Strife In Civic Life
description: THE selection of a new police commissioner recently diverted Yonkers from its decade-old struggle over a court-ordered housing desegregation plan. As with almost every public matter in Yonkers, the choice set off controversy.

title: Political Memo;   The Art Of Politics Goes Abstract
description: CONNECTICUT gubernatorial races have generally been pretty straightforward affairs: two parties, two candidates; no muss, no fuss. Each side lined up, snarled a bit and retired to the voting booths, where Democrats usually voted Democratic, and Republicans lost.

title: All the Answers
description: Questions appear on page 20.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Metuchen
description: What is now the tiny Borough of Metuchen grew up as a way station serving coaches carrying passengers from New York City to Perth Amboy, New Brunswick, Newark and Trenton. Today, it is a commuter paradise, straddling Route 27 and within three miles of Route 1, Interstate 287, the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike. It also boasts one of the oldest train stations in New Jersey, bus and rail service to Manhattan and bus service to Newark, Perth Amboy, Plainfield, New Brunswick and the large shopping malls on Route 1.

title: SOUND
description: Like musicians having an off night, sound equipment also suffers spells of being indisposed. But while humans often recover spontaneously, electronic music makers usually need judicious coaxing. Luckily, many problems encountered with stereo equipment are minor ailments, avoidable with a bit of preventive maintenance and easily curable without professional help.

title: Able to Cope On 'Wrong' Side
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Unclogging Ears
description: A question in the Q&A column on June 10 on coping with clogged ears on planes elicited home remedies and professional suggestions from readers. Among them were these:

title: Art Is More Than Just Art
description: ENCOUNTERS & REFLECTIONS

title: Off and Playing at Saratoga
description: This is the Philadelphia Orchestra's 25th anniversary season at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, but the original plan was for something different. In the early 1960's, when a group of upstate New Yorkers started talking about a performance facility on the grounds of the new Saratoga Spa State Park, the idea was to create a summer home for the New York Philharmonic.

title: Hosteling Through Europe
description: Hosteling is a frame of mind, an alternative psychology of travel. As a hosteler you carry your house on your back: your bedroom is a soft white envelope of top sheet, bottom sheet and pillowcase sewn together and called a sheet sleeping sack; your kitchen is a water bottle, a blue enamel cup, a cheap stainless steel spoon and a Swiss army knife; your bathroom is a toiletries bag and a towel; your desk a notebook and several foreign stamps. The traveler makes a new home with these things every few nights and steeps herself in an unfamiliar culture of displacement, the culture of the hostel.

title: Marie P. Keenan To Marry in May
description: Judge and Mrs. John F. Keenan of Riverdale, the Bronx, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marie Patricia Keenan, to William Gregory Mutchler, a son of Thomas F. Mutchler Sr. of Riverdale, Md., and the late Lillian P. Mutchler., A wedding next May is planned.

title: Jets' Lines Coach Is Loud and Clear
description: They have drafted three of college football's most acclaimed offensive threats. They have a pair of million-dollar arms at quarterback.

title: Drunk Driver? Dial CURB-DWI
description: MOTORISTS who suspect they have seen a driver on the road who may be under the influence of alcohol or drugs can now call a toll-free number to alert the nearest police officer, under a new program developed by the state police.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Madison Avenue Street Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed today from 37th to 50th Street from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: THE IRAQI INVASION: Man in the News;   Arab of Vast Ambition Saddam Hussein
description: With a single, swift military action, Saddam Hussein has dispelled the image he has assiduously tried to cultivate in the West as a man who can be trusted.

title: Stephen King Stories Adapted for the Stage
description: A GOOD Stephen King yarn, aficionados of the wildly successful and prolific writer say, can be scary, funny and moving, psychically probing, even meaningful beyond mere menace.

title: Style Makers;   Noel Frankel, Creative Director, Advertising Agency
description: Artists rarely get the freedom to illustrate an advertising campaign without specific requirements. But the new print campaign for MTV, which made its debut in the July 2 issue of Rolling Stone magazine, is different.

title:
Does the Letter Still Rate?;

X Means Protecting Children, That's All
description: LEAD: If 1990 were a movie, it might be called ''The Return of X'' (no one under 17 would be admitted). So far this year nine films have received the Motion Picture Association of America's most restrictive rating: ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover,'' ''Wild Orchid,'' ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,'' ''The Killer,'' ''Frankenhooker,'' ''Life Is Cheap .

description: SUBVERSIVE INTENT

description: Section 4A

title: Martine Balandraux to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Georges Balandraux of Paris have made known the September wedding plans of their daughter, Dr. Martine Balandraux, and Dr. David M. Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Bernstein of Fairfield, Conn. Dr. Balandraux, the chief of the hematology clinic at Beaujon Hospital in Paris, received an M.D. degree from the University of Paris. Dr. Bernstein is the managing director of the Research and Consulting Company in Geneva. He graduated from Yeshiva University and received a doctorate in environmental medicine from New York University.

title: About Men;   The Quick, the Dead
description: The year my family invested in Florida real estate I decided the world was meaningless. I had nothing in particular against Florida, or investments for that matter - I simply happened to be 15. It was a hormonal kind of thing.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: PAULA JEAN SLIER;

Reading Personality by Handwriting
description: LEAD: HANDWRITING analysis, long considered part of a fortuneteller's domain, has found new acceptance in the business world as an employee screening technique that provides a ''quick read'' on personality and performance potential.

title: Susan S. Parrish, Student, Marries
description: Susan Scott Parrish, a daughter of Mrs. Lawrence A. Bianchi of Boston and T. Kirkpatrick Parrish 3d of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Bruce Cordiner Judge, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard D. Judge of Ann Arbor, Mich. The Rev. John J. Perry performed the ceremony, assisted by Canon Arthur W. Dodds, an Episcopal priest, at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in Centerville, Mass.

title: Elegant Lobbies to Lure Office Tenants
description: Not so long ago, the lobbies of even the most architecturally distinctive office buildings were little more than sterile spaces connecting the front door to the elevators. But if the designs of new buildings or of those built or renovated within the last few years are any indication, bland-looking vestibules are a thing of the past.

title: Race, Ethnicity and the Privileged
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW SHOULD PGA TOUR RE-EVALUATE SITE RULES?
description: As an experiment, hold the Masters at a public golf course in Altanta. The corporate jets, the TV hangers-on and the pampered players would find a lot of excuses not to attend that event.

title: Managing;   Inviting the Headhunters Inside
description: THE Baxter Health Care Corporation's Hyland division, a Deerfield, Ill., company that makes protein solutions from blood plasma, is looking for someone to fill a senior position. Several Hyland insiders qualify - but just barely. So Hyland has asked Conex Inc., a New York recruiting firm, to evaluate the insiders, compare them to outsiders and then present Hyland with a slate of candidates from both groups.

title: FLUTIE AND GASTINEAU: HANGING ON IN CANADA
description: The helmet has ''BC'' inscribed on it, and Doug Flutie does not flinch at the coincidence: He was once the darling of an entire nation playing for another B.C.

title: Ms. Edelen Wed To Felix Bizaoui
description: Jeanne Edelen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Edelen of Newtown, Conn., was married yesterday to Felix Bizaoui, the son of Ida Bizaoui of Southfield, Mich., and the late Eli Bizaoui. Eve P. Schare, a justice of the peace in Fairfield, Conn., officiated in the gardens of the home of the bride's parents.

title: Another Power Shortage
description: THE United States will probably be importing 60 percent of its oil by the time today's first-graders get their driver's licenses; debate over whether to build new nuclear reactors seems likely to intensify as those youngsters grow up, and acid rain and the greenhouse effect promise to focus attention on energy use of all kinds for years.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has a forced-air furnace that is about 14 years old. A heating contractor the heat exchange unit is badly rusted and he recommends replacing it because the heat exchanger is so bad and because the old unit had insufficient air flow. He says that the new furnace would have 90 percent efficiency and would save about 40 percent in gas costs. Is this logical, and can a gas furnace emit dangerous levels of carbon monoxide?

title: ARABS' SUMMIT MEETING OFF; IRAQI UNITS IN KUWAIT DIG IN; EUROPE BARS BAGHDAD'S OIL
description: A hastily arranged Arab summit meeting that was to have convened on Sunday in Saudi Arabia to deal with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait fell apart today as Arab leaders sought to mask their divisions and disarray with assertions of brotherhood.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Productivity for the second quarter.

title: Fresh Start
description: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: Mary Howard Weds Stephen Mooney
description: Mary Thomas Howard and Stephen Emerson Mooney, video producers in Boston, were married yesterday at the Union Church of South Bristol, Me., by the Rev. Sidney Maxwell, a minister of the United Church of Christ.

title: Secondhand Emotions in Varied Media
description: THE main event now at Wadsworth Atheneum is ''Robert Longo.'' But first, the superlatives and demi-superlatives: the 12-year retrospective is billed as ''the primary contemporary art exhibition in New England this summer'' and as the vehicle for ''some of the largest works ever mounted'' at the Hartfordmuseum.

title: T.A. Sherif Weds Kerry Goldberg
description: Kerry Meredith Goldberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Goldberg of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Tarek Ahmed Sherif, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ahmed Sherif of Bonn. Judge Nicholas H. Politan of Federal District Court in Newark officiated.

title: The Invasion: Prices and Assessments
description: Gasoline prices have jumped between 4 cents and 14 cents across the country since the invasion. Page 13.

title: A Testament to Sexism at High-Tech Companies
description: To the Editor:

title:
Does the Letter Still Rate?;

Porn Has The X; Let's Use An A
description: LEAD: If 1990 were a movie, it might be called ''The Return of X'' (no one under 17 would be admitted). So far this year nine films have received the Motion Picture Association of America's most restrictive rating: ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover,'' ''Wild Orchid,'' ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,'' ''The Killer,'' ''Frankenhooker,'' ''Life Is Cheap .

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Southwestern Hamburgers:Little Effort for Summerfare
description: When you are looking for a meal that involves little effort, has a summery feel and can be cooked indoors or out, give your hamburgers a southwestern accent.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Mortimer Blumenthal, Psychiatrist, Dies at 68
description: Dr. Mortimer Jacob Blumenthal, a New York City psychiatrist and child psychoanalyst, died yesterday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived and practiced on the Upper East Side.

title: To Make Your Dreams Come True, Try a Little Hockey
description: WISH upon a star. Wish upon a hockey puck. Dreams come true on Long Island no matter what the stimulus. Take the recent feat of Mike Galligan of Floral Park.

title: Anecdotes in Wood, Paint and Cast Iron
description: The clerk in the well-stocked Point-a-Pitre bookstore smiled at me when I asked if he had any books on the island's architecture. ''One does not visit Guadeloupe for the buildings,'' he said. Probably not, in most cases. But even on a tropical island blessed with beaches, Brobdignagian flora and a usually dormant volcano, the houses tell graphic and often delightful stories.

title:
DINING OUT;

Italian Cuisine That's Above Average
description: LEAD: LA FONTANA, a three-year-old Italian restaurant across from the train station in New Brunswick, is reminiscent of a movie depiction of the sort of flamboyant, elaborate turn-of-the-century saloon that Diamond Jim Brady would have frequented.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Talking to Pictures

title: Far Fig Newton
description: The German words that made their way into English once conveyed philosophy and romance, like Zeitgeist for spirit of the era, and Weltschmerz for melancholy over the state of the world.

title: Home Is Where the Dead Are
description: A TRAIL OF HEART'S BLOOD WHEREVER WE GO

title: Golf Strikes Sensitive Nerve
description: The last time Louis J. Willie used his golf clubs, he played on a public course in Birmingham, Ala. Willie's most vivid memory of the day was having to tee the ball up on every shot to avoid breaking his clubs on rocks that dotted the course. That was in 1970. Twenty years later, as the result of a bizarre chain of events that has shaken the golf establishment, Willie is able to play the silklike greens and picture book fairways of the Shoal Creek Country Club in Shoal Creek, Ala.

title: Legal Egos
description: LAWYERS AND THIEVES

title: Coming to a Neighbor's Defense
description: THE tiny dairy-farming town of Munnsville in central New York has never been known as a hotbed of political activism. But this summer many local residents have banded together in a common cause. On store counters throughout Munnsville, population 499, coffee cans have been set to collect donations for the Adelbert Ward Defense Fund.

title: Fashion;   Jackets That Stretch From Summer's End Into Fall
