description: As soon as August arrives, people start thinking about fall. The temperature may be in the 80's or even the 90's, but the specter of September invades the mind and thoughts turn to subdued colors and more serious clothes.

title: Ms. Tolson Wed To Charles Rivkin
description: Susan Melissa Tolson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Tolson of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday to Charles Hammerman Rivkin, a son of Mrs. John S. Long of Chicago and the late Ambassador William R. Rivkin. The Rev. Frederick R. Bloom, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor Arie Eisner officiated at St. Elizabeth Roman Catholic Church in Rockville.

title: 17th Family Folk Festival May Be Finale
description: FOR 16 summers, the Connecticut Family Folk Festival has brought a wide variety of traditional and contemporary music to Elizabeth Park in Hartford, but the announcement of the annual conclave next weekend comes with a disturbing footnote. ''Given the present funding climate,'' says the festival's artistic director, Susan Garber, ''it seems likely that this 17th annual festival will also be the last one. The event is held in high esteem in the area, but it has become increasingly clear that without a complete restructuring, the necessary funds will not be forthcoming.''

title:
The Executive Life;

Disappearing Couches And Other Tarot Cards
description: LEAD: DON'T bother looking for a sofa in William Battalia's office - he refuses to have one in his professional presence. It is a phobia that rises out of an old corporate wound. According to Mr. Battalia, he had always heard that furniture in an executive's office typically disappeared just before that person was dismissed.

title: Mutual Funds;   Adding the Bells and Whistles
description: INVESTORS' seemingly insatiable appetite for index funds should bring more cheer to the mutual fund industry than it does. The problem is that the millions of dollars investors pour into them generate only razor-thin profit margins for the fund companies.

title: Colombia's Advances in the Drug War Are Costly
description: Almost a year into a violent drug war, Colombia claims that it has cut cocaine production, undermined powerful drug organizations and hounded top drug traffickers.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Portentious Pet

title: Painful Decisions
description: The most difficult case i ever had?'' Ruth Macklin pauses, momentarily - and most uncharacteristically - at a loss for words as she thinks back over the hundreds she has considered in a decade as ethicist in residence at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and its affiliated hospitals in New York City.

title: Amy Welles Is Married To Geoffrey L. Kahler
description: Amy Bracken Welles, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Welles Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Lee Kahler, a son of Dr. Richard L. Kahler of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., and Diane D. Kahler of Carlsbad, Calif. The Rev. David S. Hoag officiated at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Currency
description: To the Editor: The rate of exchange of American dollars for Israeli shekels published in the Travel Watch chart (''$1 Equals'') on uly 15 is discouraging.

title: Race, Ethnicity and the Privileged
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberian Rebel Says He'll Arrest Foreigners to Stir World Attention
description: A rebel leader, Prince Johnson, said today that he was ordering the arrest of all foreigners in Monrovia to provoke international intervention in the nation's war.

title: Postings: Directory for $5;   Finding the Watchdogs
description: At a time when not-for-profit housing and development groups have multiplied in New York City, it is hard to keep them straight. Who are the Green Guerrillas and the 52 People for Progress? How does one contact Good Old Lower East Side Inc., or the Neighborhood Action Coalition?

title: Dr. Gayle Milton Marries in Boston
description: Dr. Gayle Pearl Milton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Milton of Newton Center, Mass., was married last evening at the Copley Plaza in Boston to Michael Clifford Zeller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Zeller of Great Neck. L.I. Rabbi Steven Folberg and Cantor Alex Zimmer performed the ceremony.

title: THE THUNDER OF HOOFS, THE RING OF COMMENTARY
description: I was foaled at Saratoga Hospital. Ruined my first sports coat, a red corduroy that ran like a thoroughbred in the rain, selling tip cards at Saratoga Raceway (trots). Got scared of the dark peddling the Pink Sheet, with its nationwide race results, outside Saratoga Lake's gambling hells. Met my first rich people covering Saratoga Race Track (flats) for the daily Saratogian. Then I got out of school - and out of Saratoga - and Saratoga got out of me.

title: Man, 19, Admits Role In Drug-Related Death
description: A 19-year-old Morristown man has pleaded guilty to causing the death of a female friend by supplying her with drugs.

title: P.G.A. MUST GO BEYOND TOKEN CHANGE
description: Once again racism has met its match: money.

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: East Islip $232,000

title: S.A.T.'s Golden Mean
description: ALL the things an adolescent can be,'' laments Thomas S. Anthony, ''is reduced to a three-digit number'' - the Scholastic Aptitude Test score. Mr. Anthony, dean of admissions at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., believes that students give too much weight to this number when gauging their chances of being accepted at a particular school.

title: Profit Centers
description: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

title: Fines for Tanks: Guilty Until Innocent
description: I was impressed with the quote attributed to James Pim (June 24) regarding the Suffolk County Department of Health Services enforcement of the fuel tank regulations: ''Pay the fine - it's small.''

title: Northeast Notebook: Augusta, Me.;   A Deal to Save A Wilderness
description: In the largest single conservation deal in its history, the State of Maine has agreed to pay $13.2 million for 40,000 acres of wilderness.

title: Overflowing Church Hears a Sermon of Defense
description: Thousands of people packed a church in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday morning and through thunderous applause and repeated ovations showed their support for the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, the Democratic Congressman indicted last week on charges of misusing church funds.

title: Senate Approves Measures on Transit and AIDS
description: In the final hours before leaving for its summer recess, the Senate gave final approval late Saturday to legislation to provide more than $4 billion over the next five years to help cities deal with AIDS and to provide money to upgrade airports, mass transit systems and Amtrak.

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge Again As Mideast Tensions Grow
description: Volume was extremely low at 170 million shares for the morning session, about half the level of an active half-day. The trading was so thin that 15 percent of the stocks on the exchange did not open for trading, analysts said.

title: Chronicle
description: Together, they may be Britain's brainiest couple. And together they received honorary degrees from Sussex University recently. LADY ANTONIA FRASER was honored for her contributions to the writing of history. Her husband, HAROLD PINTER, was honored for his contributions to the university.

title: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sales
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, tomorrow's auction of three-year notes, Wednesday's auction of 10-year notes, and Thursday's auction of 30-year bonds and a 36-day cash management bill.

title: Neglect Found in Residences for Disabled
description: Thousands of mentally ill patients and other people unable to care for themselves are being assigned by New York State authorities to live in unsanitary, dilapidated and poorly supervised adult group homes or halfway houses, inspections by a state monitoring agency have found.

title: 9 Held in 2 A.M. Concert Melee in Village
description: Nine police officers were injured and nine people were arrested early yesterday when officers trying to quiet an impromptu street concert in Greenwich Village were pelted with bottles, the police said.

title: The Cost of Confronting Iraq in the Oil Market;   Psychology, More Than Availability, Sways Gas Prices
description: Oil tankers take six weeks to travel from the export terminals of the Persian Gulf to the refineries of the Gulf of Mexico, but oil prices, as events last week have shown, make the trip at something near the speed of light.

title: Chief Honcho Wins A Slow Jim Dandy
description: The Jim Dandy Stakes at Saratoga Race Track is supposed to be a prep for the richer Travers Stakes 13 days later, but none of the four colts who ran today will be back for the main event this year. After this Jim Dandy, no one had any illusions about the quality of the quartet who contested it.

title: New Leader for U.S. Soccer
description: Alan Rothenberg, a Los Angeles trial lawyer who has had no formal ties to soccer for more than six years, was elected today as president of the United States Soccer Federation. Rothenberg only became a candidate 10 days ago after a strong suggestion by the world governing body for soccer that he run.

title: Reacting To Iraq
description: The Bush Administration, which was surprised by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, now faces two daunting tasks - to force an Iraqi withdrawal and a restoration of Kuwaiti sovereignty, and to move the United States substantially toward independence from Middle Eastern oil.

title: People
description: * Chris Amato has been named vice president and senior art director at Cadwell Davis Partners. The agency also named Julie Treacy as vice president and management supervisor.

title: Market Place;   Small Investors Resisting Any Impulse to Sell, So Far
description: The stock market was buffeted by waves of selling and sharply lower prices last week in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But there are signs that most individual investors have not yet begun to sell.

title: Ms. Reich Marries Michael H. Pilson
description: Rebecca Elizabeth Reich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Reich of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Harris Pilson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Neal H. Pilson of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Bernard H. Rosenberg performed the ceremony at Grand Marquis Catering in Old Bridge, N.J.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: American Dream of the 90's: My Child the Tennis Champ
description: Five years ago, Russ and Maggie Miller left their home in southern New Jersey to follow their second-grader, Karin, to the prestigious Nick Bollettieri Tennis Academy in Bradenton, Fla., a tennis think tank that has produced such teen-age luminaries as Andre Agassi, Monica Seles, Aaron Krickstein, Jimmy Arias and Carling Bassett.

title: Study Says U.S. Needs to Attack Infant Mortality
description: A high-level Bush Administration study calls for spending about $500 million a year more to reduce the infant mortality rate in the United States, now higher than in 19 other countries, including Singapore and East Germany.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   U S Sprint In Rebuttal To A.T.& T.
description: A hard-hitting new television campaign by U S Sprint reaches out and thumps American Telephone and Telegraph.

title: Signs in Canada Of a Recession
description: The Canadian Government said last week that its composite leading indicator, a gauge of the economy's upcoming performance, fell four-tenths of a percent in May. It was the fourth consecutive monthly decline.

title: U.N. Expected to Approve Iraq and Kuwait Trade Ban
description: The United Nations Security Council is expected to approve a worldwide ban on oil purchases from Iraq and occupied Kuwait on Monday in retaliation for the Iraqi invasion and to prohibit all other trade and financial dealings with these countries, Council members said tonight.

title: Recycling Lifts Hope and Tests Patience
description: As its landfills grow ever fuller, New York City has begun to turn to recycling. Sharyn Cameron and her neighbors are on the frontier.

title: F.B.I. Report Confirms Sharp Rise in Violent Crime
description: Affirming reports of record levels of violent crimes in many cities, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says the rates for murder, robbery and aggravated assault have risen sharply since 1985.

title: Minor Blessing for Mexico, But Not Really a Windfall
description: The sharp jump in oil prices after Iraq's seizure of Kuwait comes as a minor blessing for Mexico, a nation that enriched itself in the early 1980's by exporting high-priced oil but can no longer raise its production to benefit from a new windfall in prices.

title: U.S. Forces Evacuate 74 After Threats in Liberia
description: A reinforced company of 225 United States Marines flew into Liberia today to evacuate Americans and foreign dependents, after a rebel leader threatened to start taking foreign prisoners.

title: Jill D. Suttenberg Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Jill Dara Suttenberg, a management consultant in Boston, and David Matthew Altshuler, a medical student at Harvard University, were married yesterday at the Dix Hills (L.I.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein.

title: Mark Guffey and Miss Silverman Wed
description: Marjorie Sue Silverman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bennet H. Silverman of Hastings, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lieut. Mark Alan Guffey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Loren Guffey of Conway, Ark. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: A Region Feels the Pinch and Slap In Washington's Talk of Farm Cuts
description: This part of Mississippi's Delta region, in many respects a throwback to the Old South and its vast plantations, will be among the first to be pinched if Washington enacts provisions of farm law just approved by the House of Representatives.

title: Nelva M. Weber, 81, Landscape Architect
description: Nelva M. Weber Sammataro, a landscape architect and columnist in New York and Connecticut, died on Tuesday at the Rose Haven nursing home in Litchfield, Conn. She was 81 years old and lived in Litchfield and Manhattan.

title: Kelly Stars as Yanks Beat Indians, 5-3
description: If there are those among the Yankees who miss Deion Sanders, Roberto Kelly isn't one of them. Not that Kelly disliked Sanders, the flamboyant football player and erstwhile baseball player; it's just that with Sanders gone, Kelly is the Yankees' center fielder again and Kelly likes being the Yankees' center fielder.

title: Accounts
description: * Endless Pools Inc., New York, a maker of pools used for swimming laps, to Da Vinci Einstein Advertising, New York, with an estimated budget of $500,000. The account is the first for the agency, which was formed this summer by two former employees of Chiat/Day/Mojo's New York office.

title: Possible Bid For Greyhound
description: The Blackstone Group, a New York investment firm, is considering trying to buy Greyhound Lines Inc. in a deal to end the six-month drivers' strike, a partner in the firm, Richard Ravitch, said Friday.

title: Correction
description: A headline on Saturday about an unsuccessful attempt in the Senate to overturn a virtual ban on abortions at overseas military hospitals gave an incorrect vote tally in some copies.

title: Iraqi Official Urges Turkey Not to Shut Oil Pipeline
description: Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister reportedly urged Turkey today not to take retaliatory action against Baghdad for the invasion of Kuwait. Officials here said he was told that there were no such plans at this time.

title: Man Accused of Stealing 25 Cabs
description: A Queens man has been charged with stealing 25 medallion taxis during the last month and using them to pick up fares to support his crack habit, the police said.

title: Costly Second Thoughts for Some Books
description: Publishers love to talk about their successful books and the problems of rival houses. They are more reluctant to expound on their own failures and difficulties. And they become positively tight-lipped about their aborted books -manuscripts for which they paid a lot of money but decide not to publish.

title: Highway Bridge Plan Roiling TriBeCa
description: The intersection of Chambers and West Streets is heavy with traffic much of the day and well into the night. To the east is the Borough of Manhattan Community College, a parking lot and a public tennis court. On the west is the rapidly emerging shape of the new Stuyvesant High School building, and between these points lies the latest conflict involving the TriBeCa neighborhood in lower Manhattan and the more recent settlement at Battery Park City.

title: Mark Siegel WedTo Ms. Schiffman
description: Shana Schiffman, a research assistant at the American Enterprise Institute, a policy research organization in Washington, was married yesterday to Mark Eric Siegel, a medical student at Georgetown University. Rabbi Robert Miller officiated at the Glen Island Casino in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Oil Users Pay Price; Japanese Stocks Fall
description: Japan has cut off an eighth of its oil supply as it joins its allies in halting purchases from Iraq and Kuwait. The move raises fears for Japan's economy, and stock prices fell sharply in Tokyo this morning.

title: Differing Views Emerge on Success
description: The degree to which the Goodwill Games, which ended yesterday, succeeded as an international sports event is a judgment that depends largely upon who is measuring.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''There are an awful lot of countries that are in total accord with what I've just said.

title: Maurice Braddell, 89, An Actor and Writer
description: Maurice Braddell, an actor, author and art restorer, died July 28 in England. He was 89 years old.

title: Review/Jazz;   A Festival OPens With the Sounds of New Orleans
description: Traditional New Orleans jazz sounds easy until current musicians try to re-create it. After 60 years of evolution in which most jazz has been conceived as solos with accompaniment, the freewheeling, communal give-and-take of traditional jazz takes a lot of readjustment. Crescent City Summit, which opened the annual Classical Jazz festival on Friday night at Alice Tully Hall, worked to recapture the casual brilliance of the first recorded jazz, with some success.

title: With Care, U.S. Presses Kenyans To Open Their Political Process
description: A senior American official, in Kenya to patch up ruffled relations, has urged the Government to open up the political process but has been careful not to insist on multiparty democracy as the only prescription.

title: In Child Deaths, a Test for Christian Science
description: David and Ginger Twitchell, a Christian Science couple from Massachusetts who relied on prayer rather than on doctors as their young son lay dying from an obstructed bowel, were convicted of involuntary manslaughter last month. It was a stunning verdict, coming as it did in the very shadow of the Mother Church in Boston.

title: Seifert Makes 49ers His Own
description: GEORGE SEIFERT stuck his hands into everything. He coached his players and he coached his coaches. He was not a good listener. His teams won 3 games and lost 15. He was fired. ''It was a learning experience, for sure,'' said Seifert, recalling his stint as Cornell's head coach in 1975 and 1976, a time when he possibly grew the most as a coach but was still nearly run out of town by alumni who were never in favor of his selection. But like most things with Seifert, he found jewels among ruins.

title: Jerusalem Journal;   Getting By in Israel, or, How to Stretch a Shekel
description: If Israelis are hard on the outside and sweet on the inside, as local folk wisdom says, then a good part of their toughness probably comes from the constant struggle against a battered economy, where taxes are all-encompassing, prices are higher than in Manhattan, and meager salaries seldom stretch to the end of the month.

title: Richard S. Rheins Weds Susan Miller
description: Rabbi Susan Lynn Miller, a daughter of Morris J. Miller of Clifton, N.J., and the late Beatrice R. Miller, was married yesterday to Rabbi Richard Steven Rheins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin C. Rheins of Indianapolis. Rabbi Chaim Stern and Cantor Dana S. Troupp officiated at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Mercer Defeats Cooper In 12
description: Ray Mercer, the International Boxing Federation's intercontinental heavyweight champion, pounded out a 12-round unanimous decision over Bert Cooper at Caesars here today.

title: Pro Bono
description: * The Bloom Agency in Dallas has produced a television campaign for the Mothers Against Drunk Driving organization. The campaign promotes both the organization's designated-driver program and its 10th anniversary.

title: Syrian Likens Invasion to Law of the Jungle
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, denouncing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, was quoted today as saying Baghdad was following the law of the jungle.

title: Audit Says Air Force Misspent Nearly $10 Million
description: An internal audit has found that nearly $10 million was spent improperly to refurbish officers' clubs, golf courses and other recreation sites at several Air Force bases.

title: Miscellany
description: * Meredith Corp., Des Moines, a publisher of magazines and books and an owner of radio and television stations, announced the completion of the sale of MMT Sales Inc., New York, a subsidiary that sells advertising time for 29 television stations, to MMT Acquisition Corp., a company owned by the unit's current management.

title: Experts Say Embargo May Work If Nations Maintain Commitment
description: With Japan joining the United States and Europe yesterday by agreeing to halt oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait, the industrialized world has begun an economic campaign against Baghdad that for the moment relies on an embargo but holds out the possible use of a naval blockade.

title: Lawmaker's Role at 3 S.& L.'s Divides the House
description: Three years ago, American Federal Savings and Loan Association was in deep financial trouble, and Federal regulators were threatening to seize it. To minimize the cost to taxpayers, the regulators proposed merging the institution with a more solvent Oregon savings and loan.

title: Coslet Gives Jets a Break
description: Bruce Coslet believes there is life even during football. He took today off along with the Jets' coaching staff and closed the training camp.

title: Trees Imbued With History Get Their Own Honor Roll
description: When James W. Johnson of Waterloo went off to fight in the Civil War, he hung his scythe in the crotch of a Balm of Gilead tree on his farm, asking that it be left there until he returned. He never returned.

title: Triathletes Discover Variety of Rewards
description: THE path to running a triathlon is paved with tales of renewal and reward as recreational athletes discover the value of cross training and pursue peak performance in a wider spectrum of sports.

title: Dinkins to Hire 1,058 More Officers by Spring
description: In the face of stiff pressure to take action against rising crime in New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins is to announce today that he will hire 1,058 new police officers by next spring to increase foot patrols in neighborhoods, a senior mayoral aide said last night.

title: Change on Missile Shield Is Resisted
description: The Pentagon served noticed today that it would fight attempts in Congress to restructure the anti-missile program.

title: Pakistan to Offer Investors Incentives to Expand Tourism
description: Hoping to cash in on growing numbers of tourists visiting Asia, Pakistan is about to announce a comprehensive plan to expand the tourism sector through generous incentives to private investors.

title: Bridge
description: If there were a prize for the best opening lead of the year, the 1990 winner would probably be Peter Weichsel of Encenitas, Calif. In the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the Summer Nationals in Boston last month he and his teammates were involved in a close quarterfinal battle against a group led by Zia Mahmood of Manhattan.

title: Question Box
description: An Old Refrain

title: Editors' Note
description: An article and a chart about food magazines on the Media Business page of Business Day on July 23 unfairly portrayed a 1986 circulation loss at Gourmet. Gourmet's editors point out that the magazine acquired the subscription list of a defunct publication, Cuisine, in 1984 and filled the unexpired Cuisine subscriptions. The subsequent circulation decline of nearly 200,000, they say, was due to the expected attrition of some Cuisine readers and not to a falloff in Gourmet's own subscribers.

title: Baldwin Breaks Through, Winning Met
description: John Baldwin today ended his streak of second-place finishes in major amateur events by capturing the Metropolitan Amateur Championship, a title he also won 23 years ago.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

For a Top-of-the-World Challenge
description: LEAD: IN endurance sports, a few events stand above the rest for their length, duration, difficulty, and epic nature. Cycling has its three-week, 2,122-mile Tour de France. Alaska's Iditarod is the ultimate test in sled-dog racing. Hawaii's Ironman is the ultimate test for triathletes. The Western States 100-mile race is the ultimate test for runners.

title: Identity Crisis for 'Seven Sisters'
description: In magazines as in life, being known as someone's sister can be a badge of pride - or a real drag.

title: Chronicle
description: JEFF JARVIS, former managing editor of Entertainment Weekly, will become Sunday editor of The Daily News, the newspaper announced yesterday.

title: Marla Altman Weds Peter N. Marron
description: Marla Susan Altman, the daughter of Jodee K. Greenberg of Great Neck, L.I. and Dr. Joseph Altman of Springfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Nathan Marron, a son of Sarah Marron of Brooklyn and the late Samuel Marron. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel, performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Times Mirror to Buy Paper
description: The Times Mirror Company said on Thursday that it had agreed to purchase 50 percent of La Opinion, one of the nation's largest Spanish-language daily newspapers.

title: Golfers Hedge Taking Shoal Creek Stance
description: While the aftershocks of the racial controversy at Shoal Creek Country Club continued to reverberate through the golf world, many of the players who are competing there at this week's Professional Golfers' Association Championship have taken what amounted to a free drop on the issue.

title: Why Israel May Show Its Nuclear Hand
description: Soon, as a result of the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, we may know the truth about Israel's chemical, biological and - the ultimate taboo - nuclear weapons capability.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: The Uses of Force
description: President Bush did the right thing on Liberia over the weekend, ordering in the Marines to evacuate threatened Americans and protect the U.S. Embassy. He also sends a useful signal about America's willingness to use appropriate military force in defense of clear national interests.

title: Not Much New Supply In North Sea
description: Oil-consuming nations in need of supplies to replace oil from Iraq and Kuwait will not find much help in the North Sea, which last year accounted for 5.4 percent of world production, oil companies say.

title: Brazil's Costly Trip to a Free Market
description: With elections two months away, Brazil's Government is wrestling with violent strikes, a sharp recession and threats by foreign creditors.

title: Welcome to the Shuttle Please Stow Your Fears
description: Boarding the 9:30 Pan Am shuttle to Boston on Saturday morning was the moment of truth for Buffy Smith. Her hands were clammy, her heart was pounding and she had endured nightmares about being trapped on a plane the size of her bathroom. After months of preparation, Flight 526 was it - her first time off the ground.

title: War-Crime Charges Haunt Scientist
description: Whether Arthur L. Rudolph is a war criminal for persecuting laborers in Adolf Hitler's underground rocket factory or an old man unjustly wronged, there is an inescapable pathos about the situation that confronts him now, as he summons up his failing energies for his daily ordeal in a Toronto immigration court.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: Managers Value Money
description: A new survey indicates that managers, who once listed job security as their top priority, now value money more highly. Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago-based job-placement company, said a survey of 600 managers discharged from Fortune 1,000 companies found job security now ranks second in their hearts to the size of their paycheck. Job satisfaction ranked third and benefits fourth. The survey also found that many dismissed managers, no longer feeling protected in large companies, are turning to entrepreneurial pursuits.

title: Review/Festival Latino;   Miserable in the Promised Land
description: In ''?De Donde?,'' Mary Gallagher has written an intelligent and instructive play about the illegal immigration of refugees to the United States from Central America.

title: South China Floods Kill 108
description: Floods caused by a typhoon have killed 108 people in China's southern coastal provinces of Guangdong and Fujian over the last week, an official report said today. The state flood control headquarters, quoted by the official New China News Agency, said the typhoon flooded 695,000 acres of farmland in the two provinces and destroyed 25,200 houses in Guangdong.

title: Developers in China Hit Hard Times
description: After a five-year development binge that has dotted Beijing's perpetually hazy skyline with dozens of new office and hotel towers, the Chinese are suddenly learning that the flip side of a boom is a bust.

title: Coming to a Doorknob Near You: a Bag of Ads.
description: The prospect of sharp increases in most postal rates next year has breathed new life into the effort to create a nationwide private delivery network that would compete with the United States Postal Service in distributing magazines, catalogues and advertising circulars.

title: Keeping Putts on Track
description: A golf club professional who created a teaching device that controls the direction of a putter as you swing has created a similar apparatus for use at home or on the putting green.

title: Tobacco Free And Up to Snuff
description: A BULGE in the jaw. A gob of brown chaw. Where would baseball be without smokeless tobacco? A lot healthier, says the American Medical Association and the Surgeon General.

title: INSIDE
description: Tangled in the S.& L. Web

title: America Is Still the Lodestar for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Recession and Inflation Fears Rise
description: The credit markets are expected to be whipsawed again this week by the powerful prospects of recession and inflation.

title: Hartford Paper First Up to Bat
description: THE Sporting News is generally acknowledged to have been the first newspaper primarily devoted to baseball since it made its debut March 17, 1886. But now it appears that a paper known as The Bat and Ball, published in Hartford, beat The Sporting News to the newstands by 20 years.

title: Sharon Stern Weds David Levy on L.I.
description: Sharon H. Stern, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Stern of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to David B. Levy, the son of Suzanne Levy of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Daniel Levy. Rabbi Philmore Berger performed the ceremony at Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Moscow Inches Closer to Applying for I.M.F. Membership
description: After years of hostility, the Soviet Union has given the first clear signal that it wants to join the $120 billion International Monetary Fund, and officials both here and in Moscow say it may not be long before the Soviet Union formally asks to join.

title: Shari Birnbaum Weds David Dreier
description: Shari Ellen Birnbaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Birnbaum of Wesley Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Howard Dreier, the son of Judge and Mrs. William A. Dreier of Warren, N.J. Rabbi Gerald A. Goldman officiated at the Pearl River Hilton in Pearl River, N.Y.

title: Khmer Rouge Poised to Gain From U.S. Policy;   Mementos of War
description: To the Editor:

title: NAVY INVESTIGATES REACTORS' SAFETY
description: Investigating allegations of cheating on nuclear reactor safety inspections aboard the aircraft carrier Nimitz, the Navy has restricted four crew members aboard ship.

title: Streets of Sanctuary Now Harbor Criminals
description: Oliver August Jones does not live in the West Village. But he works there - looking for victims.

title: Gulf Premium Added by Lloyd's
description: In reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, marine underwriters in the Lloyd's of London insurance market have added a premium for ships traveling in the Persian Gulf.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1990
description: Iraq and the Oil Market

title: Boris H. Klosson, 69, Expert on Soviet Union
description: Boris Hansen Klosson, a retired foreign service officer specializing in Soviet and Eastern European affairs, died Friday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 71 years old and lived in Chevy Chase.

title: BUSH, HINTING FORCE, DECLARES IRAQI ASSAULT 'WILL NOT STAND'; PROXY IN KUWAIT ISSUES THREAT
description: Committing the United States to roll back Iraq's conquest of Kuwait, President Bush said today that he would not settle for anything less than a total Iraqi withdrawal and would not tolerate the establishment of a puppet regime in Kuwait.

title: Buffalo's Economic Revival Owes Much to Albany Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: In Verification, Trust
description: There are few tasks more urgent than keeping open skies open. Allowing routine inspection of military activities is the surest way to verify compliance with arms treaties. It also has the potential to relax hostility and transform political relations.

title: PROXY IN KUWAIT ISSUES THREAT;   Hostage Warning
description: Iraq's new proxy government in Kuwait threatened to take hostages or nationalize foreign property today in the face of international calls for sanctions in response to President Saddam Hussein's takeover of his oil-rich neighbor.

title: John F. Fanning, Newspaper Executive
description: John F. Fanning, the advertising makeup manager for The New York Times, died yesterday at Centrastate Medical Center in Freehold, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Howell, N.J.

title: 60 Years Ago Tonight, Judge Crater Stepped Into a Taxi
description: On a sticky summer evening 60 years ago tonight, a serious-looking man wearing an old-fashioned choker collar and a brown suit hailed a taxicab on West 45th Street. He said goodbye to two friends on the sidewalk and climbed into the cab, apparently heading for a theater a few blocks away.

title: Review/Art;   For Louise Bourgeois at 79, Honor in Her Homeland at Last
description: At the age of 79, the sculptor Louise Bourgeois is finally being honored by her native France. The site of her triumphal traveling retrospective is not Paris - the Pompidou Center turned it down - but Lyons's Musee d'Art Contemporain, which has given her all three floors of its attractively severe 17th-century building.

title: Business and the Law;   Judicial Struggle In Asbestos Cases
description: Asbestos litigation has turned into a kind of three-dimensional judicial chess game, with plaintiffs, defendants and judges all struggling among themselves.

title: Khmer Rouge Poised to Gain From U.S. Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha's Vineyard Journal;   Vacation Island Is Made Laboratory for a Study
description: The first iridescent posters greet visitors at the ticket office for the ferry to Martha's Vineyard from Cape Cod: ''The designated driver is the life of the party.''

title: Mortimer Blumenthal, Psychiatrist, Dies at 68
description: Dr. Mortimer Jacob Blumenthal, a New York City psychiatrist and child psychoanalyst, died Saturday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived and practiced on the Upper East Side.

title: Miss Fink Weds Joshua Korman
description: Siobhan Oona Fink, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron J. Fink of Los Altos Hills, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Joshua M. Korman, a son of Gerd Korman of Ithaca, N.Y., and the late Dr. Ruth Z. Korman. Rabbis Scott L. Glass and Morris Goldfarb officiated at the Thomas Fogarty Winery in Woodside, Calif.

title: Doubleday Books Receive Editor's Personal Touch
description: With the publication next month of two books bearing her name on the spine, Nan A. Talese will become the latest editor to have a personal imprint within a major publishing house.

title: Transcript of News Conference Remarks by Bush on Iraq Crisis
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription service:

title: President of US West Named to Chief's Post
description: US West Inc., the Colorado-based telecommunications holding company, has named Richard D. McCormick as its chief executive to succeed Jack A. MacAllister.

title: Buffalo's Economic Revival Owes Much to Albany Investment;   Cultural Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: Can you sell a book the length of two magazine articles? Yes, if you are WILLIAM STYRON. First, there was the speech, at Johns Hopkins University. Next, there was the Vanity Fair article, in December. Now, there is the book, ''Darkness Visible,'' to be published on Sept. 4 by Random House.

title: Review/Television;   Aftermath of the Hiroshima Bomb
description: The power of ''Hiroshima: Out of the Ashes,'' tonight's drama at 9 on NBC about the dropping of the first atomic bomb, is generated as much by what the viewer brings to it as by the events on screen. Not only do we anticipate the cataclysm of Aug. 6, 1945, for the people whom we see going about their daily lives on Aug. 5, but after the bomb strikes, we know only too much about the hidden effects on those who survived and on many yet unborn.

title: Jill Frankel Weds Steven L. Elbaum
description: Jill Mimi Frankel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven R. Frankel of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Steven Lawrence Elbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome D. Elbaum of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, assisted by Cantor Stephen Merkel.

title: Reports Conflict on the Fate Of Terrorists Held in Kuwait
description: Diplomats said today that Iraq might have executed 15 pro-Iranian Shiite Muslim terrorists whose freedom was demanded by factions holding Western hostages in Lebanon.

title: Kuwaiti Washington Embassy Embattled Too
description: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has thrown Kuwait's embassy here into turmoil and left Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah in the diplomatically precarious role of representing the exile government of an occupied country.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Company, New York, named Dennis J. Beckingham senior vice president and controller.

title: Khmer Rouge Poised to Gain From U.S. Policy;   Impossible Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Speak to Me of 'Vulnerable'
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Surplus Rises in Japan
description: Japan's trade surplus in the broadest measure rose 12.2 percent in June from the period a year earlier, ending two consecutive months of decline, the Finance Ministry said Friday.

title: R. J. Geller Weds Emiko Kakiuchi
description: Emiko Kakiuchi, a senior researcher for the Japanese Ministry of Education, and Robert James Geller, a professor of geophysics at Tokyo University, were married yesterday in a civil ceremony in Tokyo.

title: Vermont Justices Say Indians May Fish Without Licenses
description: The Vermont Supreme Court has let stand a lower court ruling that the Abenaki Indians of northwestern Vermont have a right to fish in their ancestral homeland without licenses.

title: On Civil Rights: No Steps Back
description: House Republicans went down to defeat on the civil rights bill last week with President Bush's slogans flying. ''Quota bill!'' they declaimed. ''Lawyers' bonanza!'' But 64 percent of the House ignored their watered-down alternative and voted instead for the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990. It was a triumph for reasonableness as well as rights.

title: Puerto Rican Ballet Makes Its Bow With a 15-Year-Old Gold Medalist
description: ''Bueno, senores,'' the ballet mistress calls out. A group of lithe, well-trained young dancers moves to the center of the studio, one of them a solemn, skinny teen-ager with an almost casual look of authority. The Ballet Concierto de Puerto Rico has arrived, with 15-year-old Diana Perez, a gold medalist in the International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Miss., in June, for a performance tomorrow night at the Damrosch Park Band Shell, as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival.

title: Saints Winners at Wembley
description: Britain got another taste of the National Football League today, and for the fifth year in a row, it feasted on the best and worst of the game as the New Orleans Saints opened their preseason with a 17-10 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: Books of The Times;   Synergy Gone Awry: Mazda in Michigan
description: Working for the Japanese

title: 2 Companies, Big and Little, Clash Over Plan on Missiles
description: A proposal to convert aging nuclear missiles into cheap rockets for launching satellites has presented the Government with a difficult choice between conflicting goals: cashing in on the peace dividend and promoting American competitiveness in high-technology industries.

title: Congressman Flake's Indictment: Good Works or Greed?
description: In southeast Queens, where the war against drugs and deterioration is a daily struggle, the white-steepled Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church is surrounded by a complex of tan brick buildings that some call Flakeville, in honor of the minister-turned-politician who built them.

title: White Sox Sweep Brewers
description: Jack McDowell pitched a five-hitter and Lance Johnson drove in three runs today to lead the Chicago White Sox past the Milwaukee Brewers, 6-1, for a sweep of the teams' five-game series.

title: The Price of Confronting Iraq in the Oil Market;   Japanese Joining In Embargo Despite Impact on Economy
description: Japan said last night that it would join its allies in halting all purchases of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, cutting off an eighth of the country's entire supply of oil.

title: RJR Bonds Drop Sharply
description: Prices of some ''junk bonds'' of RJR Nabisco Inc. fell sharply on Friday as rumors swept the market that the company had completed a huge buyback of some of its bonds.

title: German Unity Drive Mired in Politics
description: In their drive to advance the date of German unity elections by seven weeks to mid-October, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his East German partner, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, have plunged this signal event in their nation's history into the cauldron of German politics.

title: Fighting Global Warming Is Good for Business
description: LEAD: There is an air of familiarity to the White House's doomsday warnings against rapid action to combat global warming.

title: Praise for Seaver From Some Yanks
description: Yankee players and coaches reacted positively yesterday to the prospect of Tom Seaver being appointed the team's general manager. There was no word, however, from management of any move to hire Seaver, currently a WPIX television announcer for the Yankees.

title: A President Puts Himself on the Spot
description: Foreign policy, which lifted George Bush so high in the esteem of his fellow Americans, making him seem for months on end like the man with the infallible touch, now threatens to bring him low.

title: Hayes's 2-Run Shot Stops Pirates, 8-6
description: A two-run home run by Von Hayes broke a sixth-inning tie today and sent the Philadelphia Phillies past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8-6.

title: Sari Press Wed To Ira J. Miller
description: Sari Rachael Press, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Press of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Ira Jordan Miller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joshua Miller of Miami Beach. Rabbi Israel Miller, the bridegroom's great uncle, performed the ceremony at Town and Campus Caterers in West Orange, N.J.

title: Environmental Tee Off of Sorts
description: FOR a field in which ''greens'' are generally understood to be putting surfaces rather than bands of aggressive environmentalists, it is surprising how sensitive the golf industry is becoming to the threat the game poses to the surrounding world.

title: Vietnam's Allies Faltering in Cambodia
description: The new American policy on Cambodia has been warmly welcomed here, but it does not alter a domestic situation that, 11 months after the withdrawal of most Vietnamese troops, is slowly deteriorating.

title: Sports of The Times;   Morgan and Palmer in the Rain
description: It was a leaky afternoon yesterday in this hamlet by the lake, just the kind of wet and gray day on which no one here would ever have considered inventing baseball. Umbrellas, yes. But not the national pastime.

title: Two Top Officers Quit At Conquest Exploration
description: The Conquest Exploration Company, which recently tried to sell itself but received no acceptable bids, has announced that its two top officers have resigned and that Randal B. McDonald, former president and chief executive of Pennzoil Inc., had been named president and chief executive on an interim baisis.

title: The Author, On 'Grapes Of Wrath'
description: In 1953, as a student at Columbia, I wrote a paper on the ''Grapes of Wrath'' for a literature course. Although I knew John Steinbeck only through his novels and stories, I mailed the critique to him. To my surprise and delight, I received a letter from him by return post. It was handwritten (so was the 200,000-word ''Grapes of Wrath'' manuscript) on a yellow tablet. It came unedited and contains misspelling and relaxed grammar and punctuation.

title: Dismal Tidings As Mets Fall, 8-3
description: Not necessarily in this order, the Mets lost several things of value today in Busch Stadium: They lost their second straight game to Joe Torre's St. Louis Cardinals, 8-3; they lost a chance to go one-up in first place on the Pittsburgh Pirates, and they lost some confidence in Sid Fernandez, who lost his second straight.

title: Lisa Shapiro Wed To G. T. Grobstein
description: Lisa Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Shapiro of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Gregory T. Grobstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Grobstein of New York. Rabbi Abraham Eckstein performed the ceremony at the Little Neck Jewish Center in Queens.

title: Lynn Lorenzo Weds Michael Pollack
description: Lynn R. Lorenzo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roberto Lorenzo of Penfield, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael D. Pollack, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Pollack of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner officiated at Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle.

title: Washington Talk;   Senate's Carte Blanche Vs. Souter's Blank Slate
description: Early in the century, Supreme Court Justices were confirmed as a matter of course. Felix Frankfurter notes in his reminiscences that even he, once considered an ''execrated character'' by many lawyers because of his radicalism, was approved by the Senate without dissent.

title: Advisory Council Rejects Restriction on Arts Endowment's Grants
description: The advisory council to the National Endowment for the Arts today refused to bar support for any project that ''advocates or promotes a particular political, ideological, religious or partisan point of view.''

title: In Romania, Ceausescu Is Gone but His Crippling Economic Legacy Endures
description: The mammoth August 23 Conglomerate, which produces locomotive and industrial engines, was Nicolae Ceausescu's pet factory, and the factory clings to part of the executed dictator's grim legacy: a near-total obliviousness to market realities.

title: Chronicle
description: When he was 9 years old, DR. HENRY KAUFMAN fled Wenings, Germany, with his parents in advance of World War II. Today he is to become an honorary citizen of the town.

title: Outdoors: Salmon With Finicky Ways
description: PART of the fascination, and frustration, of Atlantic salmon fishing is that everything has to be just right if angler and fish are to be connected.

title: Lenore Elsberg Weds Stephen Asbel
description: Lenore Michele Elsberg, the daughter of Victoria B. Elsberg of Nanuet, N.Y., and the late Julian A. Elsberg, was married yesterday to Stephen Michael Asbel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David S. Asbel of Merion Golf Manor, Pa. Rabbi Alan Katz officiated at Town and Country Caterers in Congers, N.Y., assisted by Cantor Alan Edwards.

title: Ruth M. Shattuck, Town Selectman, 69
description: Ruth M. Shattuck, a former member of the Board of Selectmen for Darien, Conn., died Friday at her home in Darien. She was 69 years old.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Thailand, the Next Tiger
description: Economic development in Thailand is as visible as Bangkok's polluted air or the buildings that seem to spring up overnight. Less obvious but just as important is its political development, a steady consolidation of democratic institutions to match the economic gains. And there is an increasing sophistication and self-confidence in Thailand's foreign policies.

title: Jody Lynn Meier, Student, Is Wed
description: Jody Lynn Meier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Meier of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to James David Reitzes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Reitzes of Kansas City, Mo. Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik performed the ceremony at Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.

title: Limits on Commercials Voted in Italy
description: After an unexpectedly copious amount of political bloodletting, the Italian Parliament today enacted the country's first law regulating television and press ownership and setting guidelines for broadcast commercials.

title: Review/City Opera;   Tito Capobianco Production Of 'Lucia di Lammermoor'
description: With each new season, the New York City Opera presents audiences its familiar if enigmatic face. This is a company difficult to define, perhaps because it has so much difficulty defining itself.

title: 2d Power Failure in a Week Strikes West Side of Chicago
description: An explosion and fire today at an electrical substation caused the second power outage in a week on the city's West Side, cutting off electricity to about 25,000 customers, officials said.

title: Fight Ends in Fire and Knifing
description: An argument ended in a stabbing at 1:45 A.M. today after one youth tried to burn another's house, the Suffolk County police said, and a 15-year-old was charged with arson and assault. After a fight between two youths, the police said, the 15-year-old bought gasoline and ignited a house at 24 Centerwood Street. All seven occupants escaped and extinguished the flames with help from neighbors. The occupant who had been in the fight chased the suspect, who then turned and stabbed him, the police said.

title: Metro Matters;   New York City Is No Dodge City. It's Deadlier.
description: Oakley Ralph couldn't come to the telephone right away to discuss the crime rate in Dodge City, Kan., the other day because he was supervising the installation of an air conditioner in the basement of City Hall. Mr. Ralph is Dodge's Police Chief.

title: Fire Destroys Homes In Oregon Mountains
description: A fire driven by high winds and temperatures close to 100 degrees engulfed about 3,300 acres of parched forest, jumped a 75-foot-wide river canyon and destroyed 28 houses by this afternoon.

title: Ellen Raskin Wed To D. E. Holzberg
description: Ellen Raskin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Raskin of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to David Elliot Holzberg, a son of Ernest Holzberg of Larchmont, N.Y. and the late Rose Holzberg. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman and Cantor Sidney G. Rabinowitz officiated at Temple Beth El in Stamford.

title: Margot Fuchs Weds Marc Schwartz
description: Margot Lynn Fuchs, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Fuchs of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Marc Alan Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Schwartz of Holmdel, N.J. Rabbi Neil Cooper officiated at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: O. B. Hardison Jr. Is Dead at 61; Author and Folger Library Head
description: O. B. Hardison Jr., a professor of English at Georgetown University and former director of the Folger Shakespeare Library, died Sunday at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 61 years old and lived in Washington.

title: For More Drugs, First Test Is Abroad
description: PATIENT trials of new treatments, long a crown jewel of American medical science, are increasingly being conducted overseas, a number of prominent researchers say.

title: Tandy Introduces A New Computer
description: The Tandy Corporation introduced a six-pound notebook computer equipped with hard-disk and floppy-disk drives priced at $1,999. The new machine will compete directly with similar models made by the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Zenith Electronics Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation.

title: Plan to Burn Dioxin Stirs Fear in Arkansas
description: Unless a small, determined band of residents have their way, this city of 29,000 people is about to become the site of the nation's largest incineration of dioxin.

title: Souter's Record, Though Slight, Is Troubling
description: To the Editor:

title: Leader in Georgia Race Driving Hard
description: Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller, whom many see as the heavy favorite in the runoff on Tuesday for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, campaigned Sunday among the clog dancers and fiddlers and more than 25,000 other people at the Georgia Mountain Fair in the rolling hill country where he grew up.

title: Talking Business; with Pfeiffer of Compaq;   The PC Surge In West Europe
description: The European Community's program to turn its 12 nations into a single market is creating a bonanza for makers of personal computers in general and for the Compaq Computer Corporation in particular. Analysts expect the Western European personal computer market to grow by as much as 25 percent this year - twice the pace of the more mature American market - as businesses try to improve their efficiency.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Following his success in Pirandello's ''Henry IV'' in London, RICHARD HARRIS said yesterday that he planned to abandon films and now spend the rest of his career playing major Shakespearean roles. The Irish actor, who is 58 years old, said he would play King Lear, Richard III and Shylock in London's West End in the next few years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Justice THURGOOD MARSHALL of the Supreme Court was released from a hospital yesterday. He had fallen in the lobby of his hotel when he was in Chicago on Thursday to address the annual convention of the American Bar Association.

title: Productivity Rise First in Six Quarters
description: The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in six quarters, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the Labor Department said today.

title: Only a Bruise for Swift
description: The Seattle Mariner pitcher Bill Swift, struck on the forehead by a line drive at the Kingdome while pitching against Minnesota on Sunday night, was released yesterday from a hospital after undergoing tests. Swift, who was sprawled on the mound for four minutes after being hit by a drive off the bat of Gary Gaetti, suffered only a bruise and was expected to make his next start on Saturday. (AP)

title: Commodity Chief Approved
description: The Senate has approved the renomination of Wendy Lee Gramm as the chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Indictment Dropped Against Teacher in Westchester Slaying
description: A Westchester County Court judge today dismissed a murder indictment against Carolyn Warmus, a 26-year-old teacher accused of killing her lover's wife, saying the District Attorney's office had manipulated the grand jury.

title: An Old Area Surges With New Energy
description: This summer, 74-year-old Geraldine Jones has been encouraged by the view from her 12th-floor terrace in the East Tremont neighborhood of the Bronx.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amdura Corporation, Denver, a hardware distributor, said it would sell its Amdura National Distribution Co. unit to Our Own Hardware Co., Minneapolis, a wholesale supplier of hardware, for undisclosed terms.

title: Review/Opera;   Bilingual New Production of 'Ariadne auf Naxos'
description: ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' is an opera about compromise, composed by a man of the theater who believed in the tactics of accommodation and who practiced them in his art and his life. During World War II Richard Strauss let himself be used by the Nazis in the belief that he was using them, with unhappy effects on his reputation. But as ''Ariadne'' and his later ''Capriccio'' show, Strauss's reluctance to stand for long on one leg or the other resulted in some of the most glorious music of the 20th century.

title: Giants' Leach Suspended
description: The San Francisco Giant outfielder Rick Leach was suspended for 60 days by the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, today after a positive drug test.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Ballet Chicago's Addition: Its Own Choreographer
description: It wasn't so long ago that Ballet Chicago was being hailed as an extremely promising new company. And a performance on Saturday night at the Ted Shawn Theater of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here suggested that the company is steadily fulfilling that promise. But the performance also suggested that Ballet Chicago has unearthed that indispensible ingredient for success: a choreographer of its own, with an authoritative young voice and a good deal of imagination and wit.

title: Chevron in Bolivia Pact
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that its Chevron International Ltd. (Bolivia) unit had signed an agreement with the Government of Bolivia to explore for oil and gas in a 2.5-million-acre area in the Andean foothills. Chevron said it would evaluate the feasibility of drilling exploratory wells at the Caipipendi block, 400 miles southwest of La Paz and 200 miles south of Santa Cruz, the country's oil center.

title: U.S. and Vietnam Hold Talks on Cambodia
description: The first formal talks on Cambodia between the United States and Vietnam were held yesterday in New York, and both sides called them useful, although they were evidently inconclusive.

title: Morality Played No Part in Hitler Plot
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Plans Service Cuts to Pay For Adding 1,058 Police Officers
description: Pressured to respond to a recent string of alarming crimes in New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would hire 1,058 new police officers by next spring to increase neighborhood foot patrols and would pay for this by cutting a range of other services.

title: Genentech Agrees To Delay Merger
description: Roche Holding Ltd. and Genentech Inc. agreed to a United States Government request to extend until Aug. 31 the waiting period required under Federal antitrust law for review of their proposed $2.1 billion merger. The Federal Trade Commission had requested more information on the merger on March 23, and the two companies said in a joint statement that they were now in ''substantial compliance'' with that request.

title: Honda Denies Truck Plans
description: An automotive trade journal reported today that the Honda Motor Company plans to enter the truck market and increase its United States sales by 50 percent by 1995, but Honda denied the report.

title: Mauthausen Journal;   At a Death Camp, Gypsies Confront Indifference
description: The delegation of gypsies had come to the site of the Nazi concentration camp at Mauthausen to look for a part of their history, one that has been less examined and less lamented than the fate of other peoples in World War II.

title: Bethlehem Sells Vessels
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said today that it would sell two Great Lakes ore vessels and would recognize a gain from the transaction. The company said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the Lewis Wilson Foy and the Sparrows Point to the Oglebay Norton Company. After the deal is completed, Bethlehem Steel will be left with a fleet of two 1,000-foot vessels used to ship iron ore pellets from Minnesota to the company's Burns Harbour, Ind., plant on Lake Michigan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about religion as a political issue in Pakistan misidentified a human rights lawyer.

title: A Confident Douglas Says He'll Fight On
description: James (Buster) Douglas, the undisputed heavyweight champion, brimmed with confidence yesterday at a news conference in Manhattan promoting his first title defense, which will be against Evander Holyfield on Oct. 25 at the Mirage hotel and casino in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Mortgage Rates Up a Quarter-Point in Just a Few Days
description: Home mortgage interest rates, which last week were hovering just above 10 percent, have increased quickly in recent days, following the yields on Treasury bonds onto higher ground.

title: To Young Milwaukee Drivers, Cruising Ban Is Un-American
description: An effort to stop cruising in Milwaukee and three of its suburbs has led the American Civil Liberties Union to sue on the behalf of teen-agers who say they have a right to free travel.

title: Souter's Record, Though Slight, Is Troubling;   Lawn of Clover
description: To the Editor:

title: Souter's Record, Though Slight, Is Troubling;   Flirting and Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Review/Jazz;   Some Respect for Jackie McLean
description: A tribute to the alto saxophonist Jackie McLean on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall really began two songs in, with the arrival of the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis. Mr. Marsalis and Mr. McLean seared the melody of Mr. McLean's ''Bird Lives,'' tearing through the tune with two impressively assured improvisations so bursting with ideas and momentum that the piece barely held them. The excitement was what the audience at the Classic Jazz festival wanted, and a sense of anticipation spread through the crowd.

title: Grubb & Ellis
description: The Grubb & Ellis Company, a real estate broker, said it would close some offices, cut back some operations, eliminate a number of jobs and reduce travel and advertising spending to save about $7 million during the rest of 1990 and $11.5 million in 1991. The company said it was closing commercial real estate brokerage offices in southeast Denver; Detroit; the Atlanta area; Princeton, N.J., and New York. Four other offices have been reduced in size. The company said the moves would significantly lower its break-even point.

title: Boise Retreats in Northwest
description: Stung by sharply lower earnings this year because of a weak paper market, the Boise Cascade Corporation announced plans today to scale back pulp and paper mill operations in the Northwest while continuing to upgrade its other paper and timber mills.

title: Suspensions For 2 Traders
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has barred two executives of Jefferies & Company from the securities business for six months for their roles in events that led to the criminal conviction of two prominent Wall Street figures last year.

title: David J. Melamed, Lawyer, 60
description: David J. Melamed, a lawyer and former secretary of the Communications Satellite Corporation, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Tax Collecting At I.R.S. Lags
description: The Internal Revenue Service is losing its battle to collect overdue taxes, which are growing faster than tax collections, Government auditors said last week.

title: People
description: * Allen P. Adamson has been appointed senior vice president and group director at Ammirati & Puris.

title: Midwest Banks Plan Merger
description: The Firstar Corporation and Banks of Iowa Inc. said today that they had agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at about $200 million.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Oil Prices Increase Sharply Again; World Financial Markets Tumble
description: Oil prices rose sharply again yesterday and financial markets around the world plummeted as the international embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait appeared to be taking hold.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Maurice A. Pollak, 94; Led Investment Office
description: Maurice A. Pollak, president of the Maurice Pollak Investment Office in West Long Branch, N.J., died on Sunday at his home in West Long Branch, N.J. He was 94 years old.

title: A U.S. Strategy for the Gulf Crisis;   Enlisting the Saudis in Their Own Defense
description: No policy to contain Saddam Hussein, let alone force Iraq to resume the status quo ante in Kuwait, can work without active support from Saudi Arabia. The question for U.S. policy makers and other world leaders is how to persuade King Fahd to take the necessary risks.

title: AIDS Advocates Find Private Funds Declining
description: Advocates for people with AIDS are expressing concern that the public is growing weary of hearing about the disease and that a sense of alarm has given way to a resigned acceptance, making it harder to raise badly needed private funds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOSE RAFAEL MONEO, the Spanish architect and chairman of the architecture department at Harvard's Graduate School of Design, is designing his first building in the United States. It will be a museum and cultural center on the campus of Wellesley College, Wellesley, Mass., and is to house the school's permanent art collection, temporary exhibitions and a theater.

title: Off to Impressive Start at Saratoga
description: Until rains of biblical proportion turned Saratoga Race Track into a mudpit yesterday, the opening week of racing here was as invigorating as the cool Adirondack night air. After extended summer doldrums at Belmont Park, New York State once again is the capital of American racing this month, a place of champions.

title: A Craze May Outsprint Its Creator
description: Rollerblade Inc., a tiny company based near Minneapolis that brought out a roller skate with a single row of wheels, has spawned a sport called blading that in the last three years has become something of a national craze.

title: Dickerson Reports
description: Eric Dickerson reported to the Indianapolis Colts' training camp in Anderson, Ind., yesterday but the star running back did so after failing a physical he took in Indianapolis.

title: Books of The Times;   Van Gogh in Words and His Work
description: Van Gogh

title: A U.S. Strategy for the Gulf Crisis;   Coping with the Economic Consequences
description: President Bush has rallied the U.N. Security Council to vote a trade embargo against Iraq and Kuwait. This is the right response to Baghdad's heinous invasion, but it raises two troubling questions for the U.S.: Will the embargo block Iraqi oil exports? And will it throw the U.S. into a devastating recession?

title: Liberian Rebel Seizes Foreigners, Including American
description: A Liberian rebel leader seized about a dozen foreigners, including an American, as hostages from a hotel outside Monrovia today, the State Department said.

title: Market Place;   Arbitrage Curb's Effect on Volatility
description: The stock market is undergoing a series of stresses with no direct parallels in the recent past. And all this comes as traders are trying to cope with a new rule that many do not fully understand.

title: Bishop Paul Galloway Dead of Cancer at 86
description: Paul V. Galloway, a retired bishop of the United Methodist Church, died Saturday at St. John Medical Center in Tulsa, Okla. He was 86 years old and lived in Tulsa.

title: Patterns
description: Polo for Boys and Trees

title: Air Fares Climbing as Fuel Costs Rise
description: The economic fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has quickly filtered to the airline passenger, with higher oil prices already translating into higher air fares. Two airlines will add surcharges or raise fares on Thursday to offset their higher fuel costs, and several others are considering a similar move.

title: Record 44th Homicide Listed in Bridgeport
description: Bridgeport has listed its 44th homicide this year, matching the record set in all of 1988.

title: Dollar Loses Draw as Safe Haven in Time of Crisis
description: The dollar, a longtime haven for investors in times of military and political crisis, has been all but shunned since Iraq invaded Kuwait.

title: Mets Let Cardinals Take Another
description: The Mets bombed in St. Louis again tonight when they lost to Joe Torre's revived Cardinals for the third time in a row and to Joe Magrane for the second time in a week. And they flew home wondering why the hottest team in the big leagues in June had become a .500 team in August.

title: Banks Are Prodded to Offer Better Service in Poor Areas
description: Responding to pressure from Congress and community groups, Federal regulators have withheld approval for some bank mergers in recent months until the companies agreed to improve service to poor neighborhoods.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Surprises at Summerstage
description: The first dance program of the 1990 Central Park Summerstage festival got off to a varied start on Friday night at the pretty new outdoor performance space just east of the 72d Street Band Shell.

title: Damaged Barge Still Limits Traffic in Houston Channel
description: Salvage crews cleaned the tanks of a damaged oil barge today so it could be cut up and removed and the Houston ship channel fully reopened.

title: Souter's Record, Though Slight, Is Troubling;   Church and State
description: To the Editor:

title: FACING BOYCOTT, IRAQ SLOWS OIL: THE IRAQI INVASION;   BLOCKADE IS HINTED
description: American and British officials said today they would be prepared to organize an international naval blockade of Iraq to insure enforcement of economic sanctions imposed on the country by the United Nations.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Make Major Computer Effort
description: The United States should undertake a major effort to develop superconducting computers that can operate a million times faster than today's fastest machines, a national panel recommends.

title: Trenton Reacts To Possibilities Of Long Protest
description: New Jersey's tax revolt, up to now a citizens' protest with no recourse in this non-election year, is reverberating in both the Legislature and the Governor's office, and Democrats now fear it could carry into next year's legislative elections.

title: Accounts
description: * Crystal Brands Inc., New York, to Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, Philadelphia, for Izod Lacoste golf and tennis attire.

title: Man Fatally Shot in Dispute Over Phone in a Subway Station
description: A 27-year-old man was killed in a Brooklyn subway station, apparently after an argument over the use of a pay telephone, the police said yesterday.

title: African National Congress Suspends Its Guerrilla War
description: After a marathon 15-hour negotiating session with the white authorities, the African National Congress announced early today that it had ordered the immediate suspension of a guerrilla campaign begun 30 years ago in its struggle to end apartheid.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States dropped by 30 last week, to a total of 966, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count stood at 874. The decline was attributed to weak gasoline prices in the last few months.

title: Coast Guard Board Blames New Carelessness in Shipping for Spills
description: A Coast Guard inquiry yesterday blamed a declining standard of care throughout the maritime community for the 12 spills in the Arthur Kill and the Kill van Kull this year.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   U.S. ACTS TO RAISE MIDEAST STRENGTH
description: The United States moved today to increase its naval forces in the Middle East for a possible blockade to enforce the United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq, and other Western officials indicated that they were prepared to join in such an action if it was necessary.

title: John Gronvall, V.A. Official, Is Dead at 59
description: John A. Gronvall, former chief medical director of the Department of Veterans Affairs in Washington, died Aug. 2. He was 59 years old.

title: Prices of 'Junk Bonds' Fall
description: Prices of ''junk bonds'' dropped sharply yesterday as investors worried that many of the low-rated companies that have issued such high-yield securities would have trouble meeting their obligations if higher oil prices caused a recession.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   After Years of Discreet Trade-Offs, U.S. Is Testing the Saudis
description: After three Administrations fought bitter battles in Congress to secure billions of dollars of military aid for Saudi Arabia, insisting that the Saudi Government was crucial to United States interests in the Middle East, the complex relationship between Washington and Riyadh has abruptly reached a crossroads.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEE ATWATER is back in the hospital. The Republican Party chairman became ill in March and the diagnosis was a benign brain tumor. He was visited at George Washington University Hospital yesterday by PRESIDENT BUSH.

title: Are the Children Primed to Test or Read?;   A Better Measure
description: To the Editor:

title: Climate Roller Coaster In Swedish Tree Rings
description: NEW evidence from Sweden reveals that the average summer temperature in far northern Europe has fluctuated almost seven degrees over the last 1,400 years, illustrating how widely the earth's climate varies naturally and suggesting that in the northernmost parts of the world, the effects of any global warming will be hard to feel for a long time.

title: Investor Increases Stake in Henley
description: The Lebanese investor Toufic Aboukhater has raised his stake in the Henley Group Inc. to 9.11 percent from 7.67 percent. He disclosed late last month that he had asked Government regulators for permission to increase his holdings in the Hampton, N.H., manufacturing concern to more than 15 percent.

title: AIDS Research Chief Awaits Key Report On Propriety Questions
description: THROUGHOUT the late spring and summer, Dr. Robert C. Gallo, one of America's most prominent AIDS researchers, has been feeling a withering heat that has nothing to do with the weather.

title: Knudsen Appointment
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation, a construction and engineering company, said on Friday that its chairman and chief executive, William M. Agee, had been named to the additional post of president. Mr. Agee succeeds Frank M. Adams, who died on May 27 in an airplane crash.

title: No Truce in the War on Poverty
description: LEAD: A senior White House official, undoubtedly too embarrassed to be named, was recently quoted describing the Bush Administration's antipoverty strategy as this: ''Keep playing with the same toys. But let's paint them a little shinier.'' The trouble is, America's $180 billion-a-year war on poverty already is gold-plated.

title: Gun Fired at Show Injures 2
description: A man trying to sell an automatic pistol at a gun show accidentally fired it into the crowd, injuring two people, the police said. A 27-year-old man was arrested for investigation of aggravated assault after the shooting on Sunday.

title: F. C. Symonds Jr., 63, A Professor of Surgery
description: Francis C. Symonds Jr., clinical professor of surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, died on Saturday in Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. He was 63 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J., and Southold, L.I.

title: U.S. Rural Assistance Is Criticized in Study
description: After a yearlong study, a nonprofit advocacy group has concluded that many rural Americans suffer needlessly from poverty and pollution because Federal programs to help them are poorly financed and poorly run.

title: Queens Gunman Linked To 6 Felonies in 2 Hours
description: The police say they believe one gunman committed at least six felonies -three robberies, two rapes and a kidnapping - in less than two hours in Queens yesterday.

title: Repairing the Blink
description: Surgeons have devised a procedure in which a tiny gold weight implanted in the eyelid restores the blinking ability to patients with facial paralysis, researchers say. The pull of gravity on the weight mimics nerve function and allows people who have a weakened or damaged facial nerve to close their eyes in an almost natural fashion.

title: Big Man on Campus, Again
description: LEAD: George Allen started this morning, his first in 33 years as a college football coach, by taking an hour's drive to Los Angeles International Airport to drop off his wife, Etty.

title: Gloom Lifts as Maas Hits His 11th Homer
description: The prospect of rain, what with the persistent clouds overhead indistinguishable from the black incinerator smoke that belched across the Bronx sky, was no doubt for more than a couple of Yankee fans as promising as it was threatening.

title: Big Losses at Businessland; Stock Price Plunges
description: Businessland Inc. stunned Wall Street today by posting losses for the fourth quarter and the year far in excess of analysts' estimates. The stock of the personal computer retailer lost more than half its value, plunging $4, to $2.875.

title: Wide Receivers Respond To Challenge by Parcells
description: In the Giants' minicamp in May, Coach Bill Parcells issued a challenge to his veteran wide receivers.

title: New British Sports TV
description: British Aerospace Communications Ltd. said today that it would start a satellite television sports service for British pubs and bars. The sportscast service, which is a unit of British Aerospace P.L.C., will initially concentrate on showing live British rugby league matches on Sundays, with highlight programs on Monday and Tuesday evenings.

title: Long-Term Treasury Yields Soar
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds took their worst battering yesterday since the days just before the 1987 stock market crash, although bargain hunters prevented the interest rate on the benchmark 30-year bond from moving higher than its level of May.

title: Review/Television;   Series in the Summer: What to Watch, or Not
