description: Neither the weather nor television fare has sizzled much this summer. But all the networks have offered a few new series for those inclined to spend the pleasant evenings in front of the tube. John O'Connor and Walter Goodman offer comments on some of the main shows.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Cutting Budget Gap Now Discounted
description: With the American economy seemingly headed for recession and the exploding cost of imported oil about to push it over the edge, analysts widely agree that cutting the budget deficit this year no longer makes sense. But by the same token, they argue, the case for making a credible deal now on future deficit reduction is more compelling than ever.

title: Moore and Zawatson Listed as Starters by Jets
description: Bruce Coslet finally put it in writing today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Eastern Airlines Inc., Miami, named Jack E. Robinson 3d vice president of corporate development and president and chief executive of Eastern Express, its commuter airline.

title: Psychologist's Tapes Can Be Used in Trial In Couple's Murder
description: Conversations between a psychologist and two brothers after their parents were slain can be used as evidence in their murder case, a judge ruled today.

title: U.S. Curtis Cup Coach Dusts Off Clubs
description: The players who captured the Curtis Cup for the United States late last month played the best golf in the first day of the 90th United States Women's Amateur Championship today at Canoe Brook Country Club.

title: Q&A
description: Odor Flashbacks

title: Ill-Equipped for the Crises of the 90's
description: Nothing marked the euphoric and triumphant march of the Reagan Administration into Washington in 1981 more than two policies - a ''free market'' in oil (in lieu of energy independence) and a massive strategic weapons buildup. Last week, nine years and $1 trillion later, we found ourselves threatened by our dependence on Middle East oil and unable to mount a quick and effective military response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

title: John T. Kolody, Hospital President, 70
description: John T. Kolody, retired president of St. Barnabas Hospital, died on Saturday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 70 years old and lived in Whitestone, Queens.

title: CHURCH TO ORDER AUDIT OF FUNDS
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta says it will investigate whether church money went improperly to a woman whose intimate relationships with a priest and an archbishop led to their resignations.

title: NBC Plans Debuts in August for 5 Shows
description: Concerned about television's smaller audience this summer and a looming threat from the Fox Broadcasting Company, NBC announced a prime-time scheduling plan yesterday that will move up the premiere episodes of five new fall series to August. The new television season officially begins Sept. 17.

title: Now or Later?
description: Panicky officials at the U.S. Department of Agriculture are racing around to bank regulators to find Iraqi funds; unless they can seize and use offsetting assets, $2 billion in commodity credit guarantees will come out of taxpayers' pockets to pay for Mr. Bush's past appeasement of Saddam Hussein.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Hundreds of Westerners Rounded Up in Kuwait
description: Iraqi soldiers rounded up hundreds of Westerners, including at least 28 American citizens, from hotels in Kuwait. It was not known what Iraq planned to do with them.

title: Review/Festival Latino;   A Lampoon, With Music, Of Culture And Politics
description: In one of the fastest and funniest sketches in ''Los Rayos Gamma in New York,'' the satirical musical revue that had weekend performances at the Public Theater, a young Puerto Rican minister soberly informs his father that he intends to go into politics.

title: Judge Criticizes Manville's Managers on Bailout of Trust
description: In an attempt to put pressure on the Manville Corporation, a Federal judge said yesterday that the company's senior executives had not been cooperative in helping to bail out the trust they created to assist victims of asbestos.

title: When Rage Explodes, Brain Damage May Be the Cause
description: ''HE was a scientist, but he was acting strangely,'' said Dr. Stuart Yudofsky, a psychiatrist who consulted on the man's case. ''At work, when something didn't go right, he would scream and threaten his co-workers. At home, if his 4-year-old spilled some food at the table, he'd get so mad at her, he'd punch holes in the walls with his fist. It was completely out of character.'' For several years the scientist was treated by a series of psychotherapists, who urged him to examine his childhood for deep-seated conflicts that might explain his rages. Then a psychiatrist prescribed a sedative. Nothing helped.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Text of the Resolution for Sanctions on Iraq
description: Following is the text of the resolution adopted today by the Security Council, calling for sanctions against Iraq:

title: Riverside Picks Union Aide as No. 2 Minister
description: Riverside Church in Manhattan, which has had difficulty in recent years in putting the inspirational message from its pulpit into social action, has hired a former union organizer as its No. 2 minister.

title: Review/Music;   When It's Time to Dance
description: Sam Fan Thomas of Cameroon had an international hit in 1984 with ''African Typic Collection,'' a medley of electrified traditional rhythms bound together by the exhortation ''Dansez, dansez, yeah'' that found fans in French-speaking Africa, Europe and the Caribbean. When he brought his band to Kilimanjaro on Friday night, there was no resisting that imperative; Mr. Thomas's style, makassi, is yet another of Africa's great modern-dance musics.

title: Huge Fire in Oregon May Be Held in Check
description: Residents chased from their homes by a forest fire that continued to burn today after consuming 20 houses returned to find the blaze had roasted meat inside freezers and melted bottles.

title: Amnesty Starts And One Owner Turns In 3 Guns
description: On the first day of a citywide amnesty program for people with illegal guns, only three weapons were turned in - all by the same person.

title: Bodyguard Is Convicted in Case With Links to Drug Agent's Death
description: A Federal jury in Los Angeles has convicted the last of a group of four defendants charged with a number of crimes that included the kidnapping and killing of a United States drug agent in Mexico.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

Today's Fast Track: Bankruptcy
description: LEAD: Two years ago, when I graduated from business school, everyone wanted to be a corporate raider. Why get a first rate M.B.A. if you couldn't acquire an industrial empire and a staggering debt load by your 10th reunion?

title: Slaying of 2 Jews Stirs Violence in Jerusalem
description: Two Jewish teen-agers who disappeared on Saturday while hitchhiking through Arab East Jerusalem were found dead today in a valley between the city and a Palestinian village. They had been bound, gagged and repeatedly stabbed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a short article with a listing headed ''Movies This Week'' in the Television section on Sunday misidentified an actress in ''The Baker's Wife,'' which will be shown at 1 o'clock tonight on Bravo. The runaway young wife is played by Ginette Leclerc; Marlene Dietrich does not appear in the movie.

title: Trader Settles Anti-Fraud Charges With the S.E.C.
description: Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, a former leading Wall Street trader, settled Federal civil anti-fraud charges today that he had manipulated the price of a stock in 1986. Mr. Lewis was also barred from the securities business.

title: Review/Fashion;   Clothes That Can Pack Up and Go
description: Though the approaches to resort collections change dramatically from designer to designer, a strong theme pervades them all: practicality.

title: Hiring Police: What Dinkins Has Said
description: July 19, 1989 - Calling New York ''a city under siege,'' a campaigning David N. Dinkins says that over the next four years he wants to hire 1,300 more police officers for neighborhood foot patrols and for the subways.

title: Defendant's Suit Dismissed In 7-Year Molestation Case
description: A Federal judge dismissed Peggy McMartin Buckey's $1 million civil suit for malicious prosecution today, saying that ''being very, very upset does not state a cause of action,''

title: Midland Journal;   No Champagne Gushers In Texas Over Oil Prices
description: Tripp Wommack, who has been buying and operating oil fields here for 10 years, scanned the buffet room at the Petroleum Club.

title: Rising Costs Forced Taxes Upward in Many States
description: States have increased taxes by $7.6 billion thus far in 1990 to meet rising costs of schools, prisons and health care, a study reported today.

title: Rubbermaid Deal With Eldon Is Set
description: Rubbermaid Inc. signed a definitive agreement to acquire Eldon Industries Inc., which has its headquarters in Inglewood, Calif., in a swap of stock. Rubbermaid, based here, said it had received commitments from Eldon's leading stockholders to vote more than 2.7 million, or 29 percent of the shares outstanding, in favor of the acquisition.

title: Bhutto Is Dismissed in Pakistan After 20 Months
description: The Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was dismissed today by the President of Pakistan, who accused her administration of corruption, nepotism and other acts ''in contravention of the Constitution and the law.''

title: Mitsubishi Assists Venezuela Venture
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation will provide technical assistance for a joint venture to produce its passenger cars in Venezuela beginning in September. A Mitsubishi spokesman, Kyoichi Shimada, said the joint venture, MMC Auto Motriz de Venezuela S.A., would produce 800 passenger cars this year primarily with parts shipped from Japan. Production will increase to 10,000 cars and small trucks by 1995.

title: In Debut, Rookie Pirate Beats the Phillies by 10-1
description: Pittsburgh's Randy Tomlin pitched a five-hitter in his major-league debut tonight, but he didn't have time to enjoy it. While his arm was being wrapped in ice after the game, Tomlin started worrying whether he would go back to Harrisburg of the Class AA Eastern League or remain with the Pirates.

title: Defendant's Mother Ejected For Outburst at Jogger Trial
description: The mother of a defendant in the Central Park jogger trial was ordered removed from the courtroom yesterday after she shouted ''Liar!'' at a prosecution witness.

title: Jury in Barry Trial Deliberates All Day; Reaches No Verdict
description: The Federal jury in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. worked throughout today weighing the evidence compiled in the case, but once again the panel recessed without reaching a verdict.

title: German Move to Speed Up Unity Impelled by East's Economic Slide
description: Among the underlying causes of the East German Prime Minister's surprising call to move up all-German elections is a realization that reunification will cost far more than expected and that monetary union has not slowed East Germany's economic decline.

title: Magellan Nears Venus in Trip to Map Surface
description: AFTER a 15-month voyage from Earth, looping the Sun one and a half times, the Magellan spacecraft is approaching Venus. Scheduled to arrive Friday, it is primed to conduct the first detailed mapping survey of the planet's mysterious surface, which lies beneath a perpetual covering of dense, acrid clouds.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have approached the surge in crime methodically, professionally and creatively.

title: The Iraqi Invasion;   Iraqis Shut Pipeline to Turkey After Ships Sail Away Empty
description: Apparently already feeling the effects of an American-orchestrated boycott, Iraq sharply reduced the flow of oil today through twin pipelines that cross southern Turkey and normally transport more than half its oil exports.

title: Impeached Judge Is Charged With Violation of His Parole
description: A former Federal judge who was impeached by Congress after his perjury conviction was arrested today and charged with breaking parole by carrying a gun, the authorities said.

title: More on Windows 3.0
description: FOR the second stage of testing Windows 3.0, the new Microsoft graphical interface, with a modestly endowed AT-class computer, I loaded a selection of software that had not been written with Windows in mind. That is, each of the programs got its own little icon, or symbol, and could be run by putting the on-screen pointer on the icon and clicking the mouse button twice, even though they had not been designed for a graphical environment.

title: Chess
description: Sparring partners, whether in boxing or chess, do not have an easy time of it. In fact, the boxing partner has the advantage because he gets to wear protective head gear. There is no analogue for the chess training partner who has to put up with one drubbing after another from his principal's slashing combinations.

title: General Dynamics Plans Layoffs
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced today that it would consolidate two California military-related divisions that will result in 1,500 to 2,000 layoffs by the end of 1991.

title: Harold E. Beste, 81, Researcher Who Worked on TV Components
description: Harold E. Beste, an electronics researcher and engineer who helped develop television components and weapons systems, died on Friday at his home in Verona, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: Souter's Record, Though Slight, Is Troubling;   State Court Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: A party of 24 Soviet bridge experts is to arrive in New York City today and tomorrow for a visit that runs through Saturday. The danger that through a ticketing mix-up they would be stranded in Seattle, where they competed last week in the Goodwill Games, was averted by the combined efforts of the bridge community and T.W.A.

title: Fighting Crime, and Fear
description: ''This is where I come for business, 'cause this is where the bread and the jelly are at,'' explains the mugger, with a smirk. ''I see a ripe vic, I tell him, 'You can do it my way or you can do it your way, but do it your way and you'll get hurt.''

title: A.T.&T. Is Adding To Its Stake in Sun
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. agreed to sell about 4.6 million shares of common stock to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for $191.8 million. The sale, when completed, will increase the amount of Sun stock that A.T.& T. has acquired directly from the Mountain View-based computer company to 14.7 percent. A.T.& T., based in New York, had previously bought about 11 percent of Sun's stock directly from the company.

title: British Police Defuse Bomb Linked to I.R.A.
description: The police today defused a bomb they believe was planted by the Irish Republican Army in an attempt to kill a retired British official.

title: Palmer, Morgan Inducted Into Hall
description: The setting was unusual, but Jim Palmer and Joe Morgan finally got to make their speeches today as they were inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Miscellany
description: * Hill & Knowlton Inc., New York, has formed a new unit, Hill & Knowlton International, for its operations outside the U.S. Thomas E. Eidson, president and chief operating officer of U.S. operations for the firm, was appointed president and chief executive of the new division. John D. Bergen, executive vice president of the parent company's Eastern region and general manager of its New York office, replaces Mr. Eidson.

title: INSIDE
description: Mandela's Group Suspends Revolt

title: George Stavrinos, 42, Artist and Illustrator
description: George Stavrinos, a graphic artist and illustrator who helped revive interest in finely drawn representational art, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan. He died of complications of pneumonia, his sister Lydia said. Mr. Stavrinos graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design in 1970, and his drawings and illustrations soon began to appear in The New York Times, Gentleman's Quarterly and Cosmopolitan. He did freelance work for Barney's Clothes, Bergdorf Goodman and Push Pin Studio. In the mid-1980's he created a series of drawings that were used to promote the repertory of the New York City Opera. His work was exhibited in galleries in Manhattan, Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco, Washington, Providence, London, Paris and Tokyo.

title: Careers;   When Going To Executive Search Firms
description: The role of management recruiters, also known as ''headhunters'' and ''search consultants,'' seems to confuse many executives, especially those who have suddenly lost their jobs. In desperation, they deluge recruiting firms with resumes and telephone calls demanding interviews immediately.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Oh, No! They've Created a Monster!
description: There's an early scene in the first of the ''Robocop'' film series that provides a familiar nightmarish shock of technological recognition when a machine, a kind of latter-day Frankenstein's monster, runs amok with tragicomic results.

title: Oppenheimer Fills Post Left Vacant for a Year
description: ''It takes a sense of humor and some talent,'' Edward C. Stanton 3d said yesterday about his new job as managing director of the mergers and acquisitions unit of Oppenheimer & Company.

title: The Iraqi Invasion: Reporter's Notebook;   The Guns of August Make a Dervish Bush Whirl Even Faster
description: Maybe George Bush really believed that the world was becoming kinder and gentler.

title: Iran Deal Disclosed For Fokker Planes
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 6 (AP) -

title: Uncertain Future at the Smithsonian
description: The Smithsonian Institution has been uneasy in recent days about reports of an impending budget squeeze and a major shake-up in its managerial ranks.

title: Naturalists Split by Panther Sightings in East
description: PEOPLE say they are seeing panthers in New England and neighboring areas of Canada. But do the sightings, even if authentic, mean the stealthy big cat is breeding again in the Northeast decades after its presumed extinction there? The question has split naturalists into fervent believers and skeptics demanding foolproof evidence.

title: Dow Plunges by 93.31; Stocks Slide in Tokyo
description: Stock prices plunged again yesterday as continuing tensions in the Middle East pushed up oil prices, leading to investor fears that inflation will heat up.

title: Infant Struck in the Head by a Stray Shot
description: A 5 1/2-month-old boy was shot in the head yesterday in Manhattan when a bullet tore through an apartment wall as he lay sleeping in bed with his grandmother, the police said.

title: Cool Papa's Stolen Moments
description: ''Funny, but I don't have any regrets about not playing in the majors. They say that I was born too soon. I say the doors were opened too late.'' - James (Cool Papa) Bell Perhaps the saddest part about James Bell's baseball career was that he was a major leaguer in every sense but name, but never fully realized it. From 1922, when he began his career with the St. Louis Stars, until his retirement in 1950, Bell, known as Cool Papa, was an outfielder for seven teams in the National Negro Baseball League.

title: Physics and Computers Create a Science of Aquatic Thrills
description: AQUATIC designers are creating giant water slides that are starting to mimic roller coasters and eight-foot-high artificial waves that can propel surfers and swimmers on long, pleasurable rides down the length of a pool.

title: Ship Fire Burns for 6 Hours
description: Firefighters battled a ship blaze at Port Elizabeth from midnight to 6 A.M. today before a carbon-dioxide system smothered the fire, an executive of Maersk Inc., Ken Karahuta, said.

title: Board Offers to Shift Officers From Schools
description: The Board of Education offered yesterday to put back on the street more than 100 police officers now giving instruction in police work and crime-prevention to pupils in New York.

title: Are the Children Primed to Test or Read?;   Doing Their Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Serb Minority Seek Role in a Separate Croatia
description: Within weeks of a declaration of sovereignty by the Yugoslav Republic of Croatia, leaders of the republic's Serbian minority are pressing for cultural and, in all likelihood, territorial autonomy that would further complicate an already intricate political map and could exacerbate already bitter ethnic rivalries.

title: Our Towns;   At Day Care, Ringtoss, Songs And Compassion
description: Each workday morning, Ron Walker, 30 years old, a senior credit analyst for the Bank of Boston, drops off Elvi at day care by 8, then rushes for the 8:36 train to the city. Elvi seems to enjoy day care. Yesterday morning Mr. Walker pulled up to the curb and Elvi dashed from the car, leaving the door open. Didn't even say good-bye. ''She doesn't know who I am,'' Mr. Walker said.

title: Indian Soldiers Seize 12 Leaders Of Kashmir's Militant Separatists
description: Indian troops captured the chief military commander of Kashmir's independence movement and 11 other militant leaders in Srinagar today as the Kashmiris met to discuss strategy, the authorities said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Unit President to Lead National Gypsum
description: LEAD: The National Gypsum Company, a building products manufacturer based in Dallas, said today that its president and chief executive, John P. Hayes, would retire on Oct. 1 and be succeeded by Peter C. Browning, president of the company's Gold Bond Building Products division.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the front page of SportsMonday this week, referring to an article inside about the new head of the national governing body of soccer, misidentified the organization. It is the United States Soccer Federation.

title: By Design;   Baseball Caps Branch Out
description: Baseball caps used to be strictly for men. But this summer women have taken to wearing them with a passion.

title: Bar Group Votes Neutrality on Abortion
description: Lawyers at the American Bar Association's annual meeting called upon the group's policymaking body today to abandon its stance favoring abortion rights and return to neutrality on the issue.

title: Congress Hails Its Bills on Housing As a Reversal of a Decade of Neglect
description: After a decade in which Federal housing programs stagnated or starved, Congress has passed bills that pledge significant amounts of new housing money, both to strengthen current programs and to create new ones.

title: KEY RATES
Lakers Sign Perkins
description: The Los Angeles Lakers yesterday announced they had signed Sam Perkins, an unrestricted free agent, to a multiyear contract reported to be worth as much as $3 million a year. Terms were not announced by the team. After being selected fourth over all in the 1984 draft, out of North Carolina, the 6-9 forward played six seasons for the Dallas Mavericks. Last season, he averaged 15.9 points and 7.5 rebounds. (AP)

title: Are the Children Primed to Test or Read?
description: To the Editor:

title: Election of Rothenberg Is Applauded by FIFA
description: The election of Alan Rothenberg as president of the United States Soccer Federation on Sunday has pleased the world governing body for soccer, which had supported his candidacy over those he defeated: Werner Fricker, the federation president for six years, and Paul Stiehl, the federation treasurer.

title: Governor Facing Test In the Kansas Primary
description: Gov. Mike Hayden has not lost an election since he first won a seat in the Kansas House of Representatives in 1972, but he faces a strong challenge from a political newcomer in Tuesday's Republican primary.

title: Jury Trials Not Needed in Drunken Driving, Court Rules
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that motorists accused of drunken driving are not entitled to jury trials, even though those convicted for the third time can be jailed for six months, fined $1,000, pay thousands of dollars in insurance surcharges and lose their right to drive for 10 years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: More Speed From Muscle Power
description: IN a race of muscle-powered watercraft on Saturday, a light hydrofoil built mostly of aluminum achieved a speed of 17.45 miles an hour, believed by race organizers to be a world record for its class.

title: Souter's Record, Though Slight, Is Troubling;   What's in a Surname?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabbi Jacob J. Hecht, Radio Broadcaster, 66
description: Rabbi Jacob J. Hecht, an educator, writer and radio commentator, died on Sunday while visiting Camp Emunah, a summer camp he founded in Greenfield Park, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. to Challenge P.&G.-Rorer Deal
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said the Justice Department had decided to challenge their agreement to form a strategic alliance. The companies said they disagreed with the Government's stance and were considering their options.

title: Union in Bid For Greyhound
description: The Amalgamated Transit Union, which is on strike against Greyhound Lines Inc., said today that it was working with the the Blackstone Group, an investment house, to buy the nation's largest bus company.

title: Lotus Is Cutting Its Marketing Staff
description: The Lotus Development Corporation has imposed a cost-cutting program that will result in the layoff of about 40 workers, mostly from the company's marketing department. The company, which employs 3,100, said that it was still hiring in some areas and that the net reduction in workers would be about 20 people.

title: Of Magnetism and Monitors
description: CONCERN has been increasing over the possibility of adverse health effects from computer monitors.

title: Savings Deal Questioned By Senators
description: After hearing James M. Fail acknowledge that he made incorrect disclosures to Federal regulators in 1988 when he purchased 15 insolvent savings and loans, members of a Senate panel said today that they were seriously troubled by the deal's inadequate disclosures and questionable finances.

title: Pirates Defeat Expos By 4-3 in 12 Innings
description: Jay Bell's sacrifice fly after Jose Lind's leadoff double in the 12th inning gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory tonight over Montreal, the Expos' sixth consecutive loss, a season high.

title: Ex-Gov. Mecham Raises Hackles Again in Arizona
description: Like the cactuses that dot the desert, Arizonans pride themselves on being able to stand alone, no matter the heat.

title: Tankers Scramble for New Supplies
description: With oil from Iraq and Kuwait under embargo and the threat of war hanging over the Middle East, oil companies are preparing to redeploy their tanker fleets to pick up oil from alternative producers. And they are already paying a price for the region's instability in the form of higher insurance rates for ships and cargo.

title: Union Bars White in Asian Role; Broadway May Lose 'Miss Saigon'
description: Actors' Equity denied permission yesterday for the English actor Jonathan Pryce to appear on Broadway next spring in the role of the Eurasian pimp that he created in the hit London musical ''Miss Saigon.''

title: Market Place;   Is This a Time To Buy or Wait?
description: Wall Street is offering varying, and in some cases contradictory, advice for individual investors seeking a safe harbor after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Some More Bad News For Outdoor
description: The outdoor advertising industry has taken a battering lately from special-interest groups and Federal lawmakers who want to impose tough new restrictions. Now there is more bad news: Advertising revenues for the outdoor industry in the first quarter dropped 15 percent from the period last year, according to the LNA/Arbitron Multi-Media Service.

title: Talks Continue At Western Union
description: Labor-contract negotiations between the Western Union Corporation and the Communications Workers of America continued yesterday after a previous contract between the company and the union expired at midnight Monday. The C.W.A. represents 2,500 of the 3,400 workers at the ailing financial services and telecommunications company.

title: In Jogger Case, Once Viewed Starkly, Some Skeptics Side With Defendants
description: For more than a year, the six black and Hispanic teen-agers charged with the rape and attempted murder of the Central Park jogger appeared to find few supporters as New Yorkers recoiled from what the prosecutors said the youths did during a brutal rampage on an April night.

title: 95-Year-Old Murder Suspect Is Killed by Bus
description: A 95-year-old Manhattan man who was indicted last month in the bludgeoning death of an 88-year-old neighbor was killed yesterday and a companion was injured when they were struck by a Transit Authority bus.

title: Book Notes
description: Children's Books

title: Editor of Financial Times To Resign at End of Year
description: Sir Geoffrey Owen, the editor of The Financial Times for the last decade, will step down at the end of this year, when he will be succeeded by the newspaper's deputy editor, Richard P. Lambert.

title: Lemuel Shepherd Jr., 94, Ex-Chief Of Marines Who Served in 3 Wars
description: Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr., a former Commandant of the Marine Corps and a decorated veteran of both World Wars and the Korean War, died Monday at his home in San Diego. He was 94 years old.

title: Economic Scene
description: While the powerful Japanese economy appears to be in a position to ride out the storm of higher oil prices and disrupted supplies relatively well, the country's weak link in an otherwise solid economic chain may be in the financial markets, economists and analysts say.

title: Georgia Democrats Pick Miller in Runoff for Governor
description: Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller swept the state's gubernatorial primary runoff tonight, outdistancing Andrew Young, the former Atlanta mayor, by a margin of nearly two to one.

title: Corrections
description: Because of incorrect information supplied by a court office, an article on July 13 about the defense lawyers' strategy in the Central Park jogger trial misstated the way the lawyers were retained. One, Michael Joseph, who represents Antron McCray, was appointed by the court; another, Robert Burns, was originally hired by the family of Yusef Salaam and subsequently appointed by the court. Peter Rivera, the lawyer for Raymond Santana, was not appointed by the court.

title: Two Vice Chairmen Appointed for Saks
description: Saks Fifth Avenue, the nation's largest luxury retailer, which was recently bought by a Middle East investment group, named two vice chairmen this week, Arthur C. Martinez and Philip B. Miller.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, the photographic materials and chemicals company, appointed Dennis M. Peck chief executive of Interactive Systems Corp., a computer supplies and services unit.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: August 9, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

title: Mets Continue To Slip
description: Frank Cashen, umbrella in hand and his socks soaking further with every step, walked out onto the field at Shea Stadium last night at 8:30 P.M., splashed around the outfield, deliberated briefly and then declared the scene fit for play.

title: Marines Evacuate 21 More in Liberia
description: United States marines evacuated 21 more foreigners from Liberia today, including several Americans, as a rebel leader who seized more than a dozen hostages on Monday threatened to attack the 237 marines protecting the American Embassy in Monrovia.

title: Oil-Price Climb Slows; New Stability Possible
description: The rise in oil prices on world markets slowed yesterday. And prices could steady or even fall, analysts and traders said, if Saudi Arabia raised its production and other exporting nations followed suit.

title: Higher Recession Risk Seen
description: For corporate America and the domestic economy, the sudden rise in oil prices could not have come at a worse time. With the economy already weak, the added drag of sharply higher energy costs is likely to slash corporate profits and push the economy into a recession, many analysts and economists say.

title: Farm Land Values Up
description: The value of farm land in the Midwest continues its climb in the second quarter of 1990, a new survey indicates. The survey of 420 agricultural bankers in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Wisconsin and Michigan indicates that farmland values rose 1 percent in the April-to-June period. That means farmland values are up 33 percent from their lows more than three years ago, said Peter Heffernan, an analyst for the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. His bank's latest survey showed agricultural land values in the five states were up 6.4 percent from a year earlier.

title: Saudis Make a Stand
description: By allowing American troops to land on its territory and increasing its oil production, Saudi Arabia tonight proclaimed what it has been reluctant to say openly for decades: that its interests lie with the West.

title: Congress: Much Accomplished, Much to be Done
description: Airport Expansion - The House has authorized $17.7 billion in spending over the next two years to upgrade the nation's aviation system that includes letting airports levy a tax on roundtrip airline tickets of up to $12. The tax faces strong opposition in the Senate, which has not yet acted.

title: Supermarket Strike Averted In California as Talks Go On
description: A strike threatened by 80,000 California supermarket workers was put on hold early today so contract talks could continue.

title: Review/Fashion;   Is the Killer Jacket Losing Its Grip?
description: MEN'S fashions were center stage in New York last week as leading designers showed their spring 1991 lines. The dominant message was hang loose. The antidote to the french-cuffed, pin-collared, my-suit-wants-to-eat-you-for-breakfast 1980's seems to be a roomier, slouchier, less uptight Mr. Dude.

title: Virginia Inness-Brown, Arts Advocate, 89
description: Virginia Royall Inness-Brown, a proponent of the arts and former consultant to the State Department, died July 28 at Miles Memorial Hospital in Damariscotta, Me. She was 89 years old.

title: Taylor Belcher Ex-Ambassador to Peru, Dies at 70
description: Taylor Garrison Belcher, former United States Ambassador to Cyprus and Peru, died on Monday at Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Garrison, N.Y.

title: For U.S. Visa, Peruvians Try Lots of Ruses
description: A notebook kept behind the bulletproof glass where American consular officers talk to visa applicants is proof of the desperation created by Peru's deepening guerrilla violence and economic ruin.

title: Blazers Sign Abdelnaby
description: The Portland Trail Blazers announced yesterday that they have signed Alaa Abdelnaby, their first-round draft selection, to a four-year contract. Terms were not announced.

title: Xian Journal;   China in High Heels: A Wobbly School for Models
description: The walls of the sweltering municipal gymnasium were grimy and the uneven light fell in dim pools, but the line of long-legged young women hardly noticed. Waving the latest sunglasses, using mousse to hold their raven black hair just so and with sultry expressions fixed on their painted faces, they swayed happily to the rhythms of a modern Chinese dream, to become fashion models.

title: Five Years Needed to Clean Up Savings Fraud, U.S. Says
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that it would take the Government two to three years to secure indictments against most of the individuals it suspects of savings and loan fraud and five years to clean up most of the cases.

title: About New York;   Picking Up Human Spirits As Well as Trash
description: With an expression somewhere between fascination and compassion, a stylish woman -the sort one expects to see on Fifth Avenue -watched a man in a dirty sweatshirt rummaging through a garbage receptacle.

title: Immigrant Slain At a Restaurant His Family Runs
description: An Afghan immigrant who moved to New York eight years ago was shot and killed at his family-run fast-food restaurant in Brooklyn late Monday night, apparently by a customer who had refused to pay for his meal, the police said yesterday.

title: Sir Peter Hall Quits Festival
description: Sir Peter Hall has announced his resignation as artistic director of the Glyndebourne Festival Opera because, he said, he was not consulted about the director Peter Sellars's decision to delete all the spoken dialogue from his recent production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute.''

title: Hardly a Forgotten Man, McNeil Impresses Coaches
description: Coach Bruce Coslet made a startling admission today, four days before the Jets' opening preseason game: When he took over as head coach, he had virtually given up on Freeman McNeil. But McNeil will start at running back against the Philadelphia Eagles Saturday night.

title: Fannie Mae Prices 2 Debenture Issues
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced two debentures totaling $950 million.

title: Bets Denied By Winfield
description: Allegations that Dave Winfield has bet on nonbaseball sports events, raised in this week's issue of Sports Illustrated, have brought strong denials from the outfielder and his lawyer, Jeffrey Klein, who also questioned the credibility of the magazine's sources.

title: Sri Lankans Kill 42 Rebels Linked to Muslim Massacre
description: Government troops tracked down and killed 42 Tamil rebels held responsible for massacring Muslim villagers, officials said today.

title: Food Notes
description: Tomato Relish With Clout

title: Where Houstonians Go to Fill Their Wide Open Spaces
description: ''WE need to stack that jury as much as we can,'' said the fellow in the shirtsleeves and tie as he took another bite of his barbecued brisket sandwich at Goode Co. ''You heard Wally say he ain't gonna settle.'' Welcome to the land where lawyers eat barbecue for lunch every day and discuss their cases, usually, one assumes, not within earshot of their opponents. Where they mix easily with bubbas in their T-shirts and jeans as well as students in their cut-offs and housewives in their pedal pushers.

title: Crime, Police And Politics;   A Game of Numbers With a Long History
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to hire 1,058 more police officers is the latest in a long string of similar pledges by recent mayors and would-be mayors of New York City, maneuvers in a numbers game that has as much to do with political appearances as with fighting crime.

title: And There's Always Natural Gas
description: Natural gas, long regarded by oil producers as the crab grass of fossil fuels, is getting new consideration because of the crisis in the Middle East.

title: Anti-Abortion Group Urges Boycott of Planned Parenthood Donors
description: In an effort to build on its success in forcing A.T.&T. to end its support of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, an anti-abortion group is calling for a boycott of all corporations that make contributions to Planned Parenthood.

title: FEW CHOICES SEEN FOR IRAQI LEADER
description: Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, unexpectedly faced with a rapid and menacing global response to his invasion of Kuwait, increasingly is being backed into a corner from which his most likely options are to surrender or to lash out militarily, private and Government experts on the Middle East said today.

title: Bridge
description: At this time of tens of thousands of teen-agers around the country are at summer camps, engaged in a wide variety of sporting and cultural activities. To that long list four camps have added bridge this season: Belvoir Terrace in Lenox, Mass.; Camp Emerson in Hinsdale, Mass.; Camp Laurel in Readfield, Me.; and Camp Merrimac, in Contoocook, N.H.

title: For Cable TV, Rerun of a Horror Show
description: LEAD: When the cable industry announced back in the early 1980's that it was in favor of deregulation, many innocent observers were stunned. Why would cable companies cast aside the lucrative monopoly franchises they had won in thousands of hard-fought city hall mud wrestling competitions?

title: Using Cameras to 'See' a Foggy Road
description: Anyone who has driven through a heavy rain or a thick fog can remember squinting and straining to catch a better glimpse of the road. Now engineers at BMW are working on a system using video and infrared cameras to improve drivers' perception of the road under conditions of poor visibility.

title: U.S. and the Soviets as Allies: It's the First Time Since 1945
description: In the five days since Iraq occupied Kuwait, the Soviet Union and the United States have begun testing a new working relationship that is without precedent since the outset of the cold war.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

MCA Names President For Its Records Unit
description: LEAD: Richard D. Palmese, who was once a disk jockey in St. Louis and a philosophy student who studied for the priesthood, has been named president of MCA Records.

title: Chronicle
description: After canceling several appearances in Japan this summer because of exhaustion, LEONARD BERNSTEIN will be back on the podium Tuesday at the Tanglewood Festival.

title: Customs Seizes Iraqi Oil Cargo
description: Customs officials today seized a shipload of Iraqi crude oil at Port Arthur saying it violated the United States trade embargo.

title: Pressure for English-Only Job Rules Stirring a Sharp Debate Across U.S.
description: In what civil rights groups say is a reaction to recent waves of immigrants into the United States, a growing number of businesses, ranging from hospitals to bottling plants, are requiring that their employees speak English on the job.

title: Soviets to Open Exchanges For Free Trading in Rubles
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would open domestic money exchanges next year to allow businesses to trade Soviet rubles freely for foreign currencies.

title: EUROPE AND JAPAN SUPPORT EMBARGO
description: As if anxious to dispel memories of their past support for the Baghdad Government, Western Europe and Japan have moved quickly to carry out European Community and United Nations resolutions ordering trade and arms embargoes against Iraq.

title: Bhutto Blames Army for Her Ouster;   Washington Is Ambivalent
description: Bush Administration officials were strongly divided today in their assessments of the dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: Getting Personal With a Lobster Doesn't Soften a Cook's Heart
description: I'M looking at Louie. Louie is looking back at me. Louie is a two-pound lobster with little black eyes.

title: The Pop Life
description: Speaking Out>

title: A New Mirror Problem for NASA May Stall Vital Weather Satellites
description: A mirror flaw in a new $1 billion series of weather satellites threatens to delay their launching and leave forecasters without vital pictures to track storms and hurricanes, a situation that Federal officials say would constitute a national emergency.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE OIL JOLT

title: Democrats Urge Bush to Pressure Oil Companies on Price Increases
description: Congressional Democrats accused the oil industry today of engaging in price-gouging and exhorted President Bush to stop it.

title: American Magazine Publisher Sells 50% Stake to Japanese
description: In a long-expected move to save his embattled magazine company, Owen J. Lipstein, the publisher of Psychology Today, Mother Earth News and Smart magazines, announced yesterday that he had sold a 50 percent stake in his New American Magazine Company to a Japanese publishing company. The joint venture is one of the few between American and Japanese communications companies.

title: 2 Die When Van Holding 17 Leaves Road, Striking a Tree
description: Two Brooklyn teen-agers were killed and eight were hospitalized when the van in which they were riding left a rain-slicked highway and struck a tree early today, the police said.

title: Chronicle
description: Business and political leaders celebrated the 20th anniversary of Black Enterprise magazine last night at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. And EARL G. GRAVES, the founder, publisher and editor, savored the moment.

title: Born-Again Yankee Fan
description: To the Editor:

title: Maker of Faulty Heart Valve Now Will Try to Reach Users
description: A company that made a faulty mechanical heart valve reversed itself yesterday and said it would try to find all of the 21,000 patients implanted with the device in the United States.

title: Mavericks Eye English
description: Still stunned by the defection of the power forward Sam Perkins, who was signed as a free agent by the Los Angeles Lakers on Monday, the Dallas Mavericks said yesterday they were looking at the possible acquisition of the longtime Denver Nugget forward Alex English.

title: Sweet Snarl of the Chain Saw
description: Scheduling a Maine vacation according to phases of the moon in August is not the easiest thing to do. To maintain proximate sanity, one cannot disclose the scheme; it's really easier to say that you have to check the schedule with the cat sitter or the closet organizer, then sneak a peek at the moon-phase calendar.

title: Communist Ally of Mandela Says Rebel War Could Still Be Revived
description: Joe Slovo, a leading figure in both the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party, said today that the organizations' low-key guerrilla war, suspended in what many here took as a major breakthrough, could still be revived.

title: Don't Pin Housing Drop on Savings and Loans;   Limit Deposit Insurance
description: To the Editor With unerring aim, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady managed to miss the heart of the deposit insurance ''problem'' (''Brady Expects Some New Limits to Be Put on Deposit Insurance,'' front page, July 26).

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 27 about laws requiring businesses to grant leave for workers who need to care for ill family members or newborn babies referred incorrectly to the status of legislation in New Jersey. New Jersey's family-leave law, among the broadest in the nation, went into effect in May, giving employees at businesses with at least 100 workers the right to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave every two years to care for a new baby or an ill family member.

title: Yankees' Deadline Has Flexibility
description: The 20th day of August looms as an important date in the life of George Steinbrenner because it is then that he must step aside as general partner of the New York Yankees. But Aug. 20 is not necessarily a make-or-break date for the Yankees to have found a permanent replacement.

title: Release of 2 Hostages Is Promised in Beirut
description: A previously unknown group calling itself the Palestine Revolutionary Squads said today that it would release two Swiss hostages within 24 hours.

title: Faltering Hopes for Accord on Deficit Are Dimmed Further by Gulf Crisis
description: Democratic and Republican lawmakers said today that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is a serious setback for already troubled budget talks between Congress and the White House and that it will probably scuttle any deficit reduction for the coming year.

title: Democrats Vie for Albany Senate Coup
description: Although seriously underfinanced, New York's Democrats may have their best chance in 20 years to win a majority in the State Senate this November, a victory that would demolish the last base of Republican power in state government.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on Federal housing legislation misstated the difference in spending between the Senate proposal and the Bush Administration plan. According to estimates by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the $27.9 billion Senate version would provide $4.2 billion more than the White House version.

title: Sundstrand Pact With Milton Roy
description: The Sundstrand Corporation reached a confidentiality and standstill agreement with the Milton Roy Company in return for access to the company's confidential financial information. Sunstrand has made an offer of $28 a share, or $160 million, for Milton Roy, a waste-water equipment manufacturer based in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Iraq Jams Voice of America
description: Iraq has been jamming the Arabic-language broadcasts of Voice of America for three days, the radio network said today. The network, run by the United States Government, said it would try to beam its programs to Iraq through satellite television tonight. The jamming has affected much of Voice of America's broadcasting to the Middle East, including the Persian Gulf and Jordan, said the network's deputy director, Robert Coonrood. He said Iraq was also jamming the British Broadcasting Corporation's Arabic-language radio programs.

title: Colombia Swears In President, a Foe of Traffickers
description: Amid tight security, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo was inaugurated today as President of Colombia.

title: Emerson Plans Military Spinoff
description: The Emerson Electric Company said today that it was developing a plan that would spin off to its shareholders all of the equity interest in a new company that would own Emerson's military business.

title: Vying on Hudson
description: Don Johnson, a co-star of the television show ''Miami Vice,'' who in his spare time won the 1988 world championship in the superboat division of powerboat racing, will lead a fleet of more than 40 high-powered motorboats on Aug. 18 when the New York Offshore Grand Prix is contested on the waters of the Hudson River.

title: Trade Schools: Defaults And Broken Promises
description: Bonnie Rodgers says the trade school recruiters knocked on her door, left leaflets in her courtyard and even approached her outside the city welfare office, serenading her with phrases like ''financial aid'' and ''job placement.''

title: Gail Levin Weds John B. Van Sickle
description: Gail Levin, the daughter of Mrs. Shirley Hershberg of Atlanta and the late Barron W. Levin, was married yesterday to John B. Van Sickle, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Van Sickle of Rockford, Ill. Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court performed the ceremony at the Federal Court House in New York.

title: For Congress, One Month Left
description: Finding nothing so urgent that can't wait till September, Congress broke for its summer vacation right on schedule. The budget deficit? Manana. Curbs on campaign contributions? Clean air? Child care? Some other day. New taxes? Horrors.

title: Corrections
description: The main article in Business Day yesterday about the performance of the stock market on Monday incorrectly characterized the drop in the Dow Jones industrial average in some copies. The decline, to 2,716.34, was the biggest one-day drop since Oct. 13, 1989; the close was the lowest since May 4, 1990, when it was 2,710.36.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Chronicle
description: ART BUCHWALD auctioned CARLY SIMON for $8,500. ''She serves you breakfast in bed - she doesn't get in the bed - with a song,'' Mr. Buchwald explained. WALTER CRONKITE went for $5,600. They were among the prizes at an annual celebrity auction, with Mr. Buchwald as auctioneer, Monday night in Edgartown, Mass., on Martha's Vineyard, where they all summer. The event raised about $80,000 for Martha's Vineyard Community Services.

title: Bush's Aim's: Deter Attack, Send a Signal
description: The American troops and planes being sent to Saudi Arabia tonight are intended to be part of a broad international force designed to deter an Iraqi attack on Saudi oilfields and to intimidate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Goetze Pursues a Life Off the Course
description: She is golf's teen-age phenomenon, with numerous championships, including the United States Women's Amateur, to her credit, but Vicki Goetze is not a golf fanatic.

title: Review/Music;   Bolcom Piece Honors William Schuman at 80
description: Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music is performed primarily by the youthful fellows and assorted faculty of the Tanglewood Music Center and takes place in the smaller theaters on the Tanglewood grounds. This year's festival is running from Saturday afternoon through Thursday night.

title: What to Put in the Pot: Cooks Face Challenge Over Animal Rights
description: THE steam from four outdoor lobster pots rose toward the blue sky and danced like happy ghosts in a balsam-scented breeze over Mount Desert Island, Me. It was a perfect Maine day. A lobster kind of day. And a line of station wagons and campers, sports cars and Jeeps pulled into the Bar Harbor Snack Bar.

title: Iraq's Conquest: An Eden in the Sand Ruled in a Tribal Fashion
description: Oil turned Kuwait virtually overnight from a sleepy, mud-walled little fortress that sheltered pearl divers and traders into an air-conditioned Eden where wealth accumulated without work.

title: We Can Keep Oil Cheap . . .
description: How high can oil prices go?

title: Jordan Talks of Balance But Some See Iraqi Tilt
description: As the crisis surrounding Kuwait expands, King Hussein of Jordan is struggling to balance his old friendships with his recent enthusiasm for Iraq and its strongman, Saddam Hussein.

title: Defense Asks, Was Jogger Really Raped?
description: A defense lawyer in the Central Park jogger trial suggested yesterday that the 30-year-old victim was not raped on April 19, 1989, but rather had had sex with someone she knew shortly before she went jogging that night.

title: A Police Comedy That Takes Realism Seriously
description: Michael J. Fox and James Woods were rehearsing a fight scene under the domed rotunda of the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. Their director, John Badham, looked on for a while, then turned to the New York City police lieutenant standing next to him. ''Is that all right?'' he asked.

title: Souter Hearings Won't Be Useful For Predictions, One Justice Says
description: Justice John Paul Stevens said today that it was fruitless and inappropriate to use the coming Senate confirmation hearings of Judge David H. Souter to predict how he would decide cases as a member of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Don't Pin Housing Drop on Savings and Loans;   Oklahoma Bank Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: Tomatoes Connected To Salmonella Cases In 4 Midwest States
description: Raw tomatoes may be the common link in a salmonella outbreak that has sickened more than 100 people in four Midwestern states in the past month, health officials say.

title: Fed Setback In Bank Case
description: A Federal court in New Orleans denied a request yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board for a rehearing of a case testing the validity of the Fed's power to control the financial affairs of bank holding companies.

title: Hicks, Muse Buys 2 Media Services
description: Hicks, Muse & Company, a Dallas-based private investment group specializing in leveraged acquisitions, said it had agreed to purchase two media services companies, Neodata Services and the TMI Corporation, in transactions valued at $104 million.

title: Health-Tx Sued On Plant Closings
description: A Federal judge scheduled a hearing for next week on a lawsuit filed by the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union to keep Health-Tex from closing six plants and laying off workers. The union and 12 workers filed the suit against the children's wear manufacturer on Monday in United States District Court in Birmingham on behalf of 4,000 Health-Tex workers nationwide.

title: Alfred H. Lovell, Book Club Director, 74
description: Alfred H. Lovell, a retired consular official and former executive at the Book-of-the-Month Club, died Aug. 1 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 74 years old.

title: June Level Of Borrowing Rose Slightly
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that consumers repaid car loans much faster than they took out new ones in June, a fresh sign of shrinking economic activity that slowed credit expansion.

title: The Driver Who Stopped Singing
description: His mother wanted him to be a pharmacist: Hang up the old mortar and pestle at 6 P.M., go home to the wife and kids. Steady. Dependable. Safe. The father, on the other hand, did not mind if his son went into the family occupation, which is driving cars at high speed. But Richard Petty often seemed bemused that his son, Kyle, also dabbled in singing, even if it was country music.

title: Books of The Times
description: American Cassandra

title: U.S. Will Allow Norton Merger
description: The White House announced last night that President Bush would not oppose the proposed merger of the Norton Company by Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, a French conglomerate, for $90 a share, or about $1.9 billion in cash. The deal in April ended the $1.64 billion bid made by BTR P.L.C., a British conglomerate.

title: City Hall Asks M.T.A. to Delay 9-mm. Guns
description: The Dinkins administration has asked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to delay arming the transit police with powerful 9-millimeter semiautomatic guns, a decision the Mayor's office called ''profoundly distressing.''

title: Man Shoots 2 at Legal Services Office
description: An apparently deranged man who had been refused help by a Bronx legal aid agency opened fire from the sidewalk into the agency's Grand Concourse offices yesterday, injuring two employees, the police said.

title: Don't Pin Housing Drop on Savings and Loans;   Less Than World War II
description: To the Editor:

title: Baghdad Rages at 'Foreigner' But Middle East Backs Away
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq remained unrepentant in the face of growing pressure today, saying in a speech that ''Iraq will firmly confront any imperialist or Zionist attempt from any side that may stand against Kuwait's uprising or infringe on Arab dignity and land.''

title: Someone Has to Pay
description: My plan was to wax wroth today about gasoline prices being raised at Biff's Exxon before Iraq's Wehrmacht had moved more than 10 yards into money-rich Kuwait. Luckily, while I was searching for the wax my gaze fell on a New York Times story that took the steam out of me.

title: Bogota Party Aide Slain at Queens Home
description: A 49-year-old Colombian immigrant who was a high-ranking official in the New York chapter of his country's Liberal Party was killed Monday night outside his house in Queens, the police said.

title: Bhutto Blames Army for Her Ouster
description: A day after her Government was dismissed by the President of Pakistan on accusations of corruption and mismanagement, Benazir Bhutto described the unexpected action today as a ''quasi-military intervention'' organized by army headquarters.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: WHERE can a couple of top Manhattan chefs go to escape culinary burnout?

title: Iraqi Crisis: Reverberations
description: IRAQI DEFIANCE President Saddam Hussein said Iraq would confront any ''imperialist or Zionist attempt'' to reverse its takeover of Kuwait. Experts said he was being backed into a corner from which his most likely options were to surrender or to lash out militarily. Pages A9 and A11.

title: Chronicle
description: Many of the island's better-known residents bought each other. KATHARINE GRAHAM bought a kayak ride with JUDY BLUME and an autographed copy of her new children's book. Ms. Blume bought an original sketch by SHEL SIVERSTEIN. LOUISE GRUNWALD paid $1,100 for a weekend for two in Washington, with a tour of the Hirshhorn Museum led by OLGA HIRSHHORN.

title: Ford Truck Offer
description: The Ford Motor Company extended its truck-buyer incentive program through Sept. 26, the official introduction date of its 1991 models. The program had been set to expire on Wednesday. The incentive program offers special financing rates and cash allowances of $600 on Ford Aerostar, F-series trucks, Econoline van and Club Wagons, $1,500 on Ford Bronco 2 and Broncos and $1,000 on Ford Ranger.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IT seems wicked, even wrong, these days to revel in the discovery of a fine steakhouse. But there is good news in Minneapolis for those who still share the secret pleasures of red meat, well cut and seriously served.

title: Rioting Follows Funeral of Israeli Teen-Agers
description: Crowds of Jews attacked Arabs here today to avenge the slayings of two Israeli teen-agers who the authorities say are believed to have been killed by Palestinians.

title: Seeks Joint Action
description: Declaring that Iraqi forces massed in Kuwait posed an imminent threat to Saudi Arabia, the United States today ordered thousands of paratroopers, an armored brigade and jet fighters to the Middle Eastern kingdom, officials said.

title: Yanks Win to Start Trip As Maas Hits 12th Homer
description: He had not pitched in two months, not since the June night in Baltimore when his right elbow suddenly gave out in the second inning. But tonight, three months after he was acquired in a controversial trade and 11 months since his last victory, Mike Witt finally won.

title: Chavez and King Are Playing a Cagey Game of Tag
description: Ever since Julio Cesar Chavez stopped Meldrick Taylor in the final seconds of their championship bout in March, his future has been clouded by the question of whether or not he would continue his association with Don King, his longtime promoter.

title: Keep Seeking Sale, Foremost Is Urged
description: Trusts that control about 34 percent of the stock of the Foremost Corporation of America have urged the company not to end its search for a buyer. In a letter dated Friday, Mary Caroline Rottschafer, president of the Frey Foundation, and James E. McKay, trustee for various Frey family trusts, said they would be forced by Internal Revenue Service regulations to sell their 3.5 million Foremost shares within four and a half years. The letter was contained in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Tokyo Stocks Post a Gain; Others Mixed
description: The Japanese stock market made up some of yesterday's losses today, as bargain-hunters pushed the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key Nikkei index up 3.10 percent. The world's other major stock markets rose or declined slightly.

title: Barry Jury Returns With One Verdict, Then Members Decline to Disclose It
description: The jury in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. reached a verdict today on one misdemeanor count of cocaine possession, but in a suprising move it refused to disclose it.

title: Trade Ruling Against Korea
description: Sweaters made of synthetic fibers in South Korea are being sold in the United States at less than fair market value, the Commerce Department said last week.

title: C.D. Yields Off a 10th Week; Savings Units' Rates Mixed
description: Yields on most certificates of deposit and money market accounts have fallen for the 10th straight week. Rates at savings institutions were mixed.

title: Woes for Gastineau
description: Mark Gastineau's return to professional football has not been a resounding success. First, the former Jet All-Pro defensive end signed to play this season with the British Columbia Lions of the Canadian Football League. Then, in his first game, he was ejected for fighting. Now, after having cleared waivers through the league, Gastineau has been placed on the 30-day injured-reserve list.

title: Accounting Rules Approved
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it had voted 3 to 2 to approve a long-awaited consent order that it expects will make the accounting profession more competitive.

title: Ralph M. Holdeman, Church Official, 84
description: The Rev. Dr. Ralph M. Holdeman, a former official with the National Council of Churches who worked in the civil rights movement, died July 31 at Elkhart General Hospital in Elkhart, Ind.. He was 84 years old. Dr. Holdeman, who lived in Elkhart, died of a stroke, said his wife, Mildred.

title: In South Africa: The Nightmare Ebbs
description: The world is too absorbed by the Persian Gulf to be wholly attentive, but there's stunning news from South Africa:

title: Gordon Bunshaft, Architect, Dies at 81
description: Gordon Bunshaft, whose modernist skyscrapers, museums and libraries made him one of the most influential architects of the 20th century, died on Monday evening at his apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Of Dueling Lears and a Fascist Richard III
description: No one here would be so vulgar as to acknowledge anything so crude as a theatrical rivalry, but any visiting theatergoer can see that this is the summer of dueling King Lears on the English stage. The country's two pre-eminent repertory companies, the Royal National Theater in London and the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford-on-Avon, have each just opened major productions of Shakespeare's most epic tragedy. Both stagings feature star actors, and both are the work of ascending-star directors in their 30's: Deborah Warner directs Brian Cox at the National, while Nicholas Hytner directs John Wood at the Royal Shakespeare. As if this were not enough ''King Lear'' to fill the dog days of August, Kenneth Branagh will soon bring his touring Renaissance Theater Company edition of the play, in which he plays Edgar to Richard Briers's King, to the West End.

title: Cobb of Tennessee Signs Buccaneer Pact
description: Reggie Cobb, a former star runner at the University of Tennessee, has signed a three-year contract worth $1.2 million with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Cobb, who was the fifth overall pick in the National Football League draft this spring, missed 17 days of training camp before reaching the agreement on Monday.

title: N.C.A.A. Puts Upsala Basketball on Probation for 5 Years
description: The Upsala College basketball program was placed on five years' probation yesterday, banned from post-season play for three years and ordered to trim its 1990-91 schedule to 22 games from 26.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Apple Bancorp., New York, said the Delaware Chancery Court had denied Stanley Stahl's motion seeking to compel Apple to hold its 1990 annual meeting by Sept. 14.

title: The Catskills Trade In a Little Glitz for Much More Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Companies Find Harlem Wary
description: For years Harlem Week - a celebration of black culture and achievement -has relied on companies like Philip Morris and Heublein Inc. to underwrite its concerts, athletic competitions and receptions.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE scene is the Fruit Palace, a greengrocery in the Midwood section of Brooklyn where Millie Marcus is checking out this, examining that. Another customer enters and heads for the potato bin; the manager greets him with a wave but he passes unnoticed by Mrs. Marcus, who is half-listening to the store radio. Making her salad selections, she hears the newscaster report that President Bush is due in town the next day.

title: U.S. Interference in Liberia Will Backfire
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign for Early German Vote Stalls
description: The campaign by the conservative Government leaders of Bonn and East Berlin to push forward the unification of Germany by seven weeks collapsed today.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade School Problems

title: Plan to Cut Phone Rates
description: The Federal Communications Commission issued details yesterday on its proposed plan to reduce rates by up to 50 percent for international telephone calls from the United States. The F.C.C. said consumers pay an average of $1.20 a minute for international calls and 20 cents a minute for domestic long-distance calls, while it costs telephone companies only a little more to handle international calls. International rates have stayed high because of agreements among national telephone companies that require large, fixed payments to the country receiving the call.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title:
EDUCATION;

School-Choice Program Is Upheld in Wisconsin
description: LEAD: A pilot school-choice program allowing 1,000 low-income students in Milwaukee to use state money to attend private nonsectarian schools has been declared constitutional by a state judge, clearing the way for the program to begin this fall.

title: Don't Pin Housing Drop on Savings and Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Plans Address On Crisis in the Gulf
description: President Bush is to address the nation on the Persian Gulf crisis today at 9 A.M., the White House said late yesterday.

title: Bush's Gamble in Sending Troops: Stakes Are Certain, Outcome Murky
description: By sending combat troops into Saudi Arabia, President Bush moved decisively today to defend fundamental American economic interests, but he also tied the United States and his own fortunes to a potentially explosive crisis with no clear outcome in sight.

title: KEY RATES

Real Estate;

Government Tenants Are Sought After
description: LEAD: Big leases by Federal agencies are coming to the aid of an office market in downtown Washington that is feeling the effects of slow growth by private tenants.

title: Richard Casper Dies; Actor and Director, 41
description: Robert W. (Richard) Casper, an actor, director and choreographer who worked on 30 productions for An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford, N.Y., died Friday at Memorial Hospital in Mount Holly, N.J. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giants' Dorsey Signs 2-Year Pact
description: For two weeks, while six defensive starters have stayed home because of contract disputes, the Giants have struggled through training camp. Today, the problem eased a bit when Eric Dorsey, the starting defensive left end, reported for work.

title: Danger To Movies
description: France's continuing addiction to the movies can be easily measured by the extraordinary variety of feature films broadcast at prime time, free of charge and without commercial breaks, every week on French television.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about problems in raising funds to fight AIDS referred incorrectly to the status of a bill authorizing $875 million for AIDS-related health care. It has been passed by Congress and sent to President Bush.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There have been changes of a sort that cause us to believe there is a growing and continuous threat to Saudi Arabia.''

title: Chronicle
description: CHRISTIAN BRANDO pleaded not guilty yesterday to murdering his pregnant half-sister's boyfriend during an argument at the home of his father, MARLON BRANDO. He also pleaded not guilty to possession of an illegal weapon, a machine pistol.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about Congressional testimony by James M. Fail, an Arizona businessman who bought 15 insolvent savings and loan associations, misidentified Mr. Fail's lawyer. He is Ronald S. Liebman.

title: Review/Jazz;   Ailey Theater To Open Branch In Baltimore
description: The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation will establish a second home, in Baltimore, it announced yesterday. The foundation, which is based in New York City, is the umbrella institution for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, a school and a junior dance company, the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble. Under the program, the Ailey organization is to establish a year-round school, educational and community outreach progams and extended regular seasons for the senior and junior companies, over a three-year period.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE old argument about French wine versus California wine goes on and on, but the wine enthusiasts who gathered here recently had no time for it. They were wine makers, French and American, some of the most highly regarded in their profession, and they were here to learn from each other, not compete.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Steep Market Fall Is Halted; Dow Off 5.70
description: The stock market continued to react nervously to events in the Middle East yesterday but steadied after a steep three-day slide. Fears of higher oil prices and inflation were still very much on investors' minds, as the Dow Jones industrial average fluctuated within a 65-point range.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: AT India Joze, exotic fare is only the beginning. The 17-year-old restaurant, founded by Joseph Schultz, who is the head chef, has its own lively rhythms as well as a menu overflowing with dishes from the Near and Far East.

title: Eating Well
description: SUMMER is the kindest time of all to those who know they shouldn't have their cake, but keep eating it. Succulent melons, blushing nectarines, bright red strawberries, plump plums take the onus off desserts for anyone worrying about what makes most desserts taste so good: fat.

title: ...And Impose a Blockade
description: LEAD: In contemplating a blockade of Iraq and occupied Kuwait in support of the U.N. trade embargo, the Administration and its allies doubtless appreciate just how difficult it is to predict the strategic consequences of such a step. The prospect of a blockade seemed significantly strengthened by reports that President Bush has ordered U.S.

title: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates declined for the fourth straight week at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Impasse on Money Stalls Mississippi School Plan
description: Last fall, Gov. Ray Mabus proposed sweeping changes designed to rescue Mississippi's long-suffering schools. This spring, the Legislature first strengthened and then swiftly approved the package.

title: Quick Action by Turkey On Sanctions a Startler
description: By joining the worldwide sanctions against Iraq today Turkey moved more decisively than many cautious and even nervous people here had wished.

title: Treasury Prices Continue to Fall
description: Prices of Treasury securities continued to drop and interest rates continued to climb yesterday, reversing their morning course, as an uncommonly volatile fixed-income market was buffeted by conflicting reports and rumors about the Mideast crisis.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Nuclear Weapon Plants Face Lawsuits Around the Country
description: In the aftermath of disclosures about nuclear accidents and operations that the Government now acknowledges threatened the safety of thousands of Americans, the nuclear weapons industry is facing a spate of lawsuits brought by workers and neighbors of plants in four states.

title: Paying for New Officers
description: How much is a police officer worth to a taxpayer?

title: Intel Wins Round In Copyright Suit
description: The Intel Corporation won a round in its copyright suit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. over its math coprocessor chip, the 80287. United States District Court Judge William A. Ingram issued a ruling blocking Advanced Micro from using the phrases ''genuine Intel equivalent,'' ''100 percent Intel compatible'' or their equivalents in advertising.

title: Congress Completes Agenda, but Obstacles Remain
description: Before its monthlong recess, Congress moved toward completing an unfinished legislative agenda of the 1980's by passing the first major bills in years on child care, housing, civil rights and the environment. But these ambitious proposals are threatened by legislative, financial and political obstacles.

title: A Stronger Future for Composites
description: A decade ago came predictions aplenty that the growth of composite materials - strong, light combinations of complementary substances - would be so dramatic that all-composite automobiles and airplanes would soon become common. But high production costs and the need for huge capital expenditures have curbed such expectations.

title: U.S. Is Ready to Ask Soviets to Help With Naval Blockade of Iraq
description: Bush Administration officials said today that Washington was prepared to invite the Soviet Union into any international naval force assembled to enforce sanctions against Iraq. They added that they had no doubt that Moscow would want to take part.

title: At Shoal Creek, a Subdued Readiness
description: By all appearances today, Shoal Creek Country Club presented the kind of setting for the P.G.A. Championship that any major golf tournament would envy.

title: The Emergency's Here: Use the Oil
description: American consumers are being ''ripped off on a massive scale,'' Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut said yesterday, voicing anger felt around the country. The anger is directed at gas stations and oil companies that jacked up prices even though the gasoline they were selling was imported long before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

title: Summer Pickings: Tomato and Peach
description: IT is finally tomato and peach time again, and both are finding their way into my summer menus.

title: Jets Will Rely on Former Chargers
description: The reconstituted Jets, so new in so many ways, will be unveiled for the first time in an exhibition game on Saturday night against the Eagles in Philadelphia. No one will remember for long who wins or loses, but there will be a close inspection of the various new parts of the New York team.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A line has been drawn in the sand.''

title: Metro Matters;   Life Goes On: Shrugging Off Crime and Fear
description: Rosemary Baker hummed to herself on the No. 5 train to the Bronx on her way to work at a construction site. She shrugged off fears of crime, even after the rash of violence in recent weeks that has left four children dead.

title: Vincent Plays Down Allegations on Winfield
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent said today that gambling allegations involving Dave Winfield were ''not a serious issue.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Miller Helps Mets Revive
description: Bud Harrelson, who had said he wasn't much of a preacher anyway, opted against holding any revival meeting. Still, as he sat in his office before yesterday's game against the Phillies, the manager of the Mets felt compelled to do some thing inspirational.

title: Ex-Jet Is Barred as Broker
description: William H. Mathis, the captain of the New York Jets football team that won the Super Bowl in 1969, was barred today from the securities business for two years for his role in an insider trading scandal in 1984.

title: The U.S. Stands Up. Who Else?
description: Now it's up to other countries, particularly Arab countries. President Bush has drawn a line in the sand, committing U.S. forces to face down Saddam Hussein. The costs and risks are momentous, going well beyond U.S. military operations in Lebanon, Grenada and Panama.

title: Japan's Oil Safety Net Faces a Test: Will It Hold?
