description: For more than a decade, Room 325 has been a backwater of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry: two cluttered rows of battered gray desks where bureaucrats watched over oil stockpiles while others fought trade wars or built new industries in electronics or aerospace.

title: New York City Signs an Accord On Water Rules
description: Under heavy pressure from state officials, New York City today legally committed itself for the first time to a broad series of water-conservation measures.

title: Marwick's Chairman Leaving Post
description: Larry D. Horner, the head of the world's largest accounting firm, said yesterday that he would step aside as KMPG Peat Marwick's chairman when his six-year term expires in October.

title: Creative Difficulties At Scali
description: SCALI McCABE SLOVES, once one of the most talked-about agencies on Madison Avenue because of its innovative work for Perdue chicken and Volvo, is now getting the kind of critical attention most agency executives abhor.

title: Novelist's Home Is Saved
description: Erskine Caldwell's boyhood home has been saved from destruction and moved to the Moreland town square, where it will become a museum honoring him. Mr. Caldwell, author of ''Tobacco Road,'' ''God's Little Acre'' and at least 50 other books, was born in the house on Dec. 17, 1903, and lived there until he was 14. He died in 1987. The house was the parsonage for the White Oak Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church, where Mr. Caldwell's father, the Rev. Ira Sylvester Caldwell, was once the pastor.

title: Thorn EMI Buys Filmtrax
description: The entertainment and electronics giant Thorn EMI P.L.C. said today that it was buying a British music publishing company with rights to such musical titles as ''Stormy Weather'' and ''Itsa Itsy Bitsy Teeny Weeny Yellow Polka Dot Bikini.''

title: Democrats Hopeful After Miller's Georgia Victory
description: Campaign strategists for Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller said today that their candidate's lopsided victory Tuesday in Georgia's Democratic runoff for governor demonstrated a surprising amount of unity in the party and put Mr. Miller in a strong position for the general election.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From Bush's News Conference on the Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today on the Iraq crisis:

title: Quayle Presses Peru to Take U.S. Military Aid
description: Vice President Dan Quayle said today that the United States does not intend to send American soldiers to Peru to fight drug traffickers.

title: Small Soviet Businesses
description: Citizens of the Soviet Union are now allowed to set up small businesses under regulations approved today by the Government.

title: Around U.S., a Cautious Chorus of Support
description: If President Bush had been listening, he might have been reassured by the talk the last couple of mornings around the tables at Bert & Ernie's Restaurant in Plattsburg, a town of 2,100 people in western Missouri farm country, where patrons begin filtering in at the first daylight.

title: Underpaid in Salary Scheme, 21 Sailors to Get $32 Million
description: In what shipping industry officials call the largest wage award in maritime history, a Federal district judge has ordered that 21 Filipino sailors be given $32 million to make up for a wage system in which some were paid only a fraction of what was reported by ship owners.

title: Rangel and Others Pressing To Salvage Ballroom Project
description: Pressure intensified yesterday to salvage a proposed biomedical center on the site of the Audubon Theater and Ballroom as Representative Charles B. Rangel and a group of New York City legislators urged Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan to withdraw her challenge to the $34 million project.

title: Felony Charges Are Reduced In Dart Case
description: The most serious charges filed against a 33-year-old messenger who the police identified as the so-called Dart Man were reduced to misdemeanors yesterday by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: A 'Home' For Mother And Baby
description: It could be anyone's home. In the living room, a striped sofa and a pine armoire, and down the mauve moire-papered hall is a bedroom with sponged pink walls, white wicker furniture and floral sheets.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about remarks by Justice John Paul Stevens before the American Bar Association misstated his educational background. His undergraduate degree is from the University of Chicago; his law degree is from Northwestern University.

title: Vincent Angered by New Steinbrenner Move
description: Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, said yesterday that any attempt by George Steinbrenner to revise an agreement that limits the control of the Yankees' principal owner over the team could lead to further serious sanctions against him.

title: Farm Credit Bank's $275 Million Issue
description: The Federal Farm Credit Bank is offering $275 million in system bonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   To Baghdad, Poison Gas Is 'Poor Man's A-Bomb'
description: Poison gas, a weapon no United States serviceman has had to confront since 1918, could make the Arabian desert virtually impassable for American ground troops in a no holds-barred war with Iraq.

title: Heady Days Coming for East German Pupils
description: In less than a month, with a new school year, the doors of 7,124 schools will open for East Germany's 2.6 million pupils. And a new and largely unfamiliar world will unfold.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of a technical problem experienced by the Chicago Board of Trade in transmitting data to The Associated Press, the volume and open interest figures for commodity futures and options on futures on that exchange are incomplete in the tables on page D15.

title: Sect Takes Defamation Of Gays for Its Premise
description: To the Editor:

title: Producer Cancels 'Miss Saigon'; 140 Members Challenge Equity
description: The producer of the hit London musical ''Miss Saigon'' announced yesterday that he was canceling the show's Broadway production, which had already sold a record $25 million in advance tickets, because Actors' Equity had denied permission for the English actor Jonathan Pryce to repeat his performance in New York.

title: Arthur Tildesley, 58, A Priest in New Jersey
description: The Rev. Arthur H. Tildesley, an Episcopal priest, died on Saturday at his home in Fair Haven, N.J. He was 58 years old.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Think of the worst pain you ever experienced. Now double it. That is how one sufferer with cluster headaches described the pain that accompanies his attacks, which occur about five times a day for two or three weeks at a time, then mysteriously disappear for six months or more.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Courts Syria and Iran To Join Anti-Iraq Coalition
description: The United States has approached Syria and Iran, Iraq's two most bitter enemies, to see if they would be prepared to take part in the international effort to isolate Baghdad, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today.

title: New Chief at RCA Records
description: The Bertelsmann Music Group said yesterday that the president of its RCA Records label in the United States, Robert Buziak, had been replaced by Joseph Galante, another executive at the label.

title: REBEL CHIEF FREES CAPTIVES IN LIBERIA
description: The leader of a rebel faction today freed foreigners whom his forces had taken hostage in an effort to provoke international intervention in Liberia's tribal war.

title: Iraq Will Be Tough to Dislodge . . .
description: LEAD: Countries can be both weak and strong in different dimensions of warfare, and indeed they usually are. Iraq is no exception. While it has an enormous defensive capacity on the ground, it is highly vulnerable to air attack and is surprisingly lacking in offensive strength.

title: Caretaker Premier Pledges Investigation of Bhutto
description: Pakistan's new caretaker Prime Minister, Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, who took office Monday after the abrupt dismissal of Benazir Bhutto's Government, pledged today to investigate and punish those responsible for what he called ''the worst corruption in Pakistan's history.''

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From News Conference by Cheney and Powell at the Pentagon
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference at the Pentagon today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription agency:

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   ISRAELIS PRAISING DECISION BY BUSH
description: Israeli leaders offered warm praise today for President Bush's decision to send military forces to Saudi Arabia while also reaffirming that Israel has no intention of getting involved in the conflict.

title: Spelling Is Off the Block
description: Spelling Entertainment Inc., which produces movies and television series, said today that it was no longer exploring a sale of the company. Spelling said it had received some interest but not at a level that it believed reflected its value.

title: Thick Rough Looms at P.G.A. Event
description: Golf's best players today sounded off on a topic they could be truly passionate about: the grass at Shoal Creek Country Club.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING

title: Ratners May Alter Kay Jewelers Bid
description: Britain's largest jewelry chain, Ratners Group P.L.C., said it was holding talks to revise its offer to bondholders as part of its $328 million takeover bid for Kay Jewelers Inc. of the United States. Ratners declined to say how much of the debt had been tendered so far.

title: Japanese Education Is More Rigid Than Ours;   The 3-8-0 Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Drops More Than $2 a Barrel
description: The price of oil dropped more than $2 a barrel yesterday, and the price of gasoline fell more than 6 cents a gallon, following reports that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would increase their production to mitigate a feared oil shortage.

title: WPP Group's Earnings Up 92.9% in First Half
description: The WPP Group P.L.C. said on Tuesday that its first-half earnings rose 92.9 percent, to $:27 million ($45.3 million), from $:14 million ($23.2 million) in the comparable period last year. Pretax profits rose 76.9 percent, to $:46 million ($76.9 million), from $:26 million in the first half of last year. Revenues rose 89.1 percent, to $:626 million ($1.05 billion), from $:331 million in the 1989 period. Earnings per share rose to 42 pence, from 33.9 pence in the first six months of 1989. Earnings per American depository share were up to $1.40, from $1.12 last year.

title: Defeat for Democracy in Pakistan
description: Benazir Bhutto's removal as Prime Minister of Pakistan has the smell of a constitutional coup shrewdly timed to take advantage of the world's preoccupation with Iraq. It threatens to enfeeble Pakistan's tenuous democratic traditions unless President Ghulam Ishaq Khan honors his promise to hold elections on Oct. 24.

title: Rose Starts Serving Five-Month Sentence
description: Pete Rose arrived at the Federal work camp here today to begin serving a five-month sentence for cheating on his income-tax returns.

title: A Black Congressional Hope in Connecticut
description: Here in the Naugatuck Valley, long a bastion of the white working class, Gary Franks is an unlikely candidate for a seat in Congress. He is a black Republican.

title: Tagliabue Rejects Request by Allen
description: Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, has rejected a request for reinstatement by Kevin Allen, a former Philadelphia Eagles defensive tackle, who spent 33 months in jail for a sexual assault conviction. Walter Lesnavich, Allen's attorney, said yesterday that he received on Tuesday a copy of Tagliabue's decision, which advised that Allen may reapply next March.

title: For Higher Gas Prices, Many Villains to Blame
description: Paul Evantoff paid 5 cents a gallon more this morning to fill his gas tank at Fred's Chevron than it did last week, a development he attributed to the eagerness of the big oil companies to cash in on the turmoil in the Middle East. ''It's really greed with a capital 'G,' '' Mr. Evantoff said.

title: Iraq: Strategic Opening for Israel
description: LEAD: Iraq's occupation of Kuwait not only menaces Saudi Arabia and the oil producing emirates but also is likely to change the power balance dramatically in the Arab Middle East.

title: Chartwell Buys A Block of Avon
description: Chartwell Associates L.P., an investment partnership, has completed its previously announced purchase of Avon Products Inc. stock from the corporate raider Irwin L. Jacobs, a spokesman for Avon said. Chartwell includes the Mary Kay Corporation, the Dallas-based cosmetics concern; Gordon Getty, an heir to the Getty oil fortune, and the Fisher family of New York The latest purchase involves 1.23 million Avon shares bought for $37.50 a share under an agreement on July 5 between Mr. Jacobs and Chartwell. The investor group now controls 19.8 percent of Avon's voting shares. Shares of Avon rose 87.5 cents today, to $33.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Florio to Talk Directly to Citizens on Tax Increases
description: Confronted with a tax protest that refuses to go away, Gov. Jim Florio announced today that he would go to the voters on television and in fireside chats to explain the record $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through the Legislature six weeks ago.

title: Theory Hints Sunscreens Raise Melanoma Risks
description: The use of common sunscreens may increase the risk of developing melanoma, a deadly skin cancer, two researchers have suggested. But other dermatologists caution that the theory is speculative and remains to be proved.

title: William L. Ellis, 82, Administrative Judge
description: William Leigh Ellis, a retired administrative law judge with the Federal Power Commission, died at the age of 82 on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. The cause of death was cancer, a family spokesman said.

title: Once Again, Tired and Terrified Internal Refugees Wander Over Cambodia
description: Fleeing or forced from their homes by the stepped-up war in the Cambodian countryside, huddling against a torrid sun or stinging rain in crude shelters of thatch and plastic sheeting, they have the semivacant stare of refugees everywhere.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Champion of Arab Poor? Hussein Grasps for Nasser's Revolutionary Mantle
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is trying to claim the mantle of Gamal Abdel Nasser as the revolutionary leader of the Arab world, not only by inveighing against traditional enemies like foreign domination and Israel, but also by setting poor Arabs against the long-ruling, oil-rich royal families of the Persian Gulf.

title: A SWISS HOSTAGE FREED IN LEBANON
description: A Swiss Red Cross worker who had been held hostage in Lebanon for 10 months was freed today and handed over to Swiss authorities, officials and witnesses said.

title: Extra Year Granted
description: The N.C.A.A. has granted the leukemia-stricken University of Arizona linebacker Kevin Singleton a sixth year of eligibility, The Tucson Citizen said yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
Karl Weber, 74, Dies; Actor and Guild Leader
description: Karl A. Weber, an actor and former president of the Screen Actors Guild of New York, died on July 30 at New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 74 years old and had homes in Fort Myers, Fla., and Edgartown, Mass.

title: Books of The Times;   The Artist as Icon, Busybody and Chief Executive
description: Holy Terror

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bank One Texas, a unit of Banc One Corp., said it would buy 400 automated teller machines from Diebold Inc. of Canton, Ohio, for installation in Diamond Shamrock-owned convenience stores in Texas.

title: Kuwait and Panama
description: To the Editor:

title: United Air Group's Bid Extended
description: United Airlines' parent company, UAL Inc., tonight gave an employee buyout group an extra two months to arrange financing for its $4.38 billion bid.

title: Praslin Journal;   Where the Tortoises Play, Tourists Are Limited
description: Mountainous granite islands poking out of turquoise water and slivers of coral atolls that barely peep above the horizon make up this tiny nation that hopes to impress the world with its sensitivity about the environment.

title: Wood, Healy Re-signed
description: The Islanders have re-signed Randy Wood, one of their outstanding wings, and Glenn Healy, one of their regular goaltenders, to multiyear contracts. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Prescott A. Tolman, Executive, 80
description: Prescott A. Tolman, a retired vice president of the E. F. MacDonald Incentive Company and a sport fisherman, died on Friday at St. Luke's Hospital in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 80 years old and lived in Swiftwater, Pa. He died of leukemia, his family said. Mr. Tolman joined MacDonald, the Plaid Stamp company that is now part of the Carlson Marketing Group, in 1952 and was vice president for international relations when he retired in 1982. He had previously been a regional sales manager for Eastern Air Lines.

title: Saddam's Next Target
description: Win or lose in the gamble for control of the world's oil, Saddam Hussein's next major target will be Israel.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   NATO, Bereft of a Military Role, Redefines Itself as the West's Political Galvanizer
description: The United States briefed its NATO allies today on its decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and encouraged them to participate in an international force being formed in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, NATO officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on the Education page yesterday, with a report about defaults on loans to trade-school students, described the article incorrectly in some copies. It was the first of two articles.

title: G.M. Maintains Sales Estimate
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was maintaining its United States auto industry sales projection for 1990 of 14.7 million vehicles despite the potentially ominous consequences of the Middle East crisis.

title: Profit Up 47.5% At SmithKline
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British-American health and household products company, said today that its second-quarter profit jumped 47.5 percent from the period a year ago because of continued sales growth, strong operating profits and large debt reduction.

title: Follower of Winnie Mandela Sentenced to Death
description: Jerry Richardson, coach of a soccer team that formed part of Winnie Mandela's entourage, was sentenced to death today for the murder of a 14-year-old youth last year in circumstances termed ''particularly brutal.''

title: Racketeering Is Still Found at Fulton Fish Market
description: Two years after being appointed to help drive racketeers out of the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, long investigated as a Mafia stronghold, a Federal administrator said yesterday that an ''atmosphere of lawlessness'' and brutality still prevailed there.

title: Illness Is Tied to Way Diet Additive Was Made
description: The recent outbreak of a potentially fatal disease linked to L-tryptophan probably came from an impurity introduced by a change in how the dietary supplement was made, scientists say.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a news analysis article from Washington yesterday about President Bush's decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia appeared without a byline in some copies. The writer was Thomas L. Friedman.

title: Close to Home
description: ALL of us were talking about where we were going to go on holiday. In another month or so, one of the guests was heading for the north of Portugal, where the grapes would be ripe for the picking and men and women with funny flat-sided baskets lashed to their backs would be climbing the steep slopes.

title: Dealers Act To Stabilize Bond Market
description: Treasury securities dealers moved swiftly yesterday to keep interest rates from soaring further by absorbing most of the $10.5 billion in 10-year notes that the Government auctioned as part of its quarterly refunding.

title: New Rate Rules For Truckers
description: To compensate for rapid increases in fuel prices, the Interstate Commerce Commission said yesterday that trucking companies could increase shipping rates with only three days' notice, rather than the seven days normally required.

title: Review/Jazz;   Benny Carter Revisits the Swing Era
description: Better late than never, Lincoln Center commissioned its first jazz composition for the Classical Jazz concert on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall. The composer was Benny Carter, who turned 83 years old yesterday, and the piece was ''Good Vibes,'' a suite for big band with two vibraphone soloists, Milt Jackson and Bobby Hutcherson.

title: Ex-Casino Worker Wins Suit
description: A jury has awarded $235,000 to a former banquet supervisor at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino because she was not promoted to maitre d'hotel. The former supervisor, Adriane Truscello, contended that Trump Plaza had failed to fulfill its promise to promote her to maitre d'hotel of a new restaurant and also interfered with her efforts to get another job. Ms. Truscello said that the casino's former food and beverage director, Stephen Kuypers, had promised her the promotion but that his successor had reneged.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From Iraq's Statement on Kuwait
description: Following are excerpts from a statement today by the ruling Revolutionary Command Council of Iraq announcing Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, as translated by the British Broadcasting Corporation:

title: Occidental Pact On Museum
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that Delaware's Chancery Court had approved the settlement of several shareholder lawsuits claiming the company had wasted assets by supporting an art museum being built by the company's chairman, Armand Hammer.

title: Fed Report Says Economy Slowed Before Mideast Crisis
description: A Federal Reserve survey released today shows the economy was slumping even before the onset of the Middle East crisis that has heightened the possibility the nation will be thrown into a recession for the first time in nearly eight years.

title: Indonesia and Beijing Put End to 23-Year Rift
description: China and bitterly anti-Communist Indonesia restored diplomatic relations today, putting an end to 23 years of discord.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Foreigners in Gulf Fearful
description: While the leaders of the oil-producing countries of the Persian Gulf region welcomed the arrival of American troops in Saudi Arabia and the commitment by President Bush to defend the kingdom, anxiety was evident at airline offices and banks.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Cuomo Says Air Guard Unit Is to Join Forces in the Gulf
description: Governor Mario M. Cuomo said tonight that a unit from the New York Air National Guard will join United States forces in the Persian Gulf.

title: Review/Ballet;   Youthful Talent From Puerto Rico
description: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival offered a tantalizing glimpse of a fine young company when it presented Ballet Concierto de Puerto Rico on Tuesday at the Damrosch Park Band Shell. In its first Manhattan performance, the 12-year-old company presented a tasteful selection of classical and modern ballet pieces, several of them featuring Diana Perez, a 15-year-old who won a gold medal at the 1990 International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Miss. But what stood out most was the elegance and simplicity of the company's style, as well as its quiet eloquence.

title: IRAQ PROCLAIMS KUWAIT'S ANNEXATION;   BUSH DRAWS 'LINE'
description: Thousands of elite United States troops, the vanguard of a force that senior defense officials said may reach 50,000, took up positions in Saudi Arabia today as President Bush vowed to defend the Middle Eastern kingdom and its oil reserves, the richest in the world.

title: Currents;   Highchair For Future Lifeguards
description: CHILDREN can now eat in a highchair that looks like a lifeguard's chair. Its designer, Caleb Kercheval, calls it the Hampton Highchair.

title: TV Reporting Recalls Radio Days
description: Television news organizations, their camera crews and correspondents barred along with other journalists from Iraq and Kuwait, returned this week to what a senior network news executive described as the kind of reporting that radio did during World War II: broad based and, of course, picture-free.

title: Morris Ginsberg, 83; Backed Ships to Israel
description: Morris Ginsberg, a retired steamship company executive who helped buy ships to settle Jews in Palestine in the 40's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Smithsonian Agrees to Share Sculptor's Estate With Town
description: A highly publicized dispute between the town of Rockport, Mass., and the Smithsonian Institution has been resolved in a settlement that declares the town to be the rightful beneficiary of a $1 million bequest from a local millionaire's estate.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Jogger Attack Is Recounted By Prosecutor
description: The prosecutor in the Central Park jogger trial, seeking to rebut what the defense called crucial discrepancies in the state's case, recounted in terrifying detail yesterday the attack on the 30-year-old victim.

title: Bridge
description: When an opponent commits an irregularity and is subject to a penalty, it is perfectly proper to try to take maximum advantage of the situation. But players who do so must calculate carefully, and can sometimes bring an avalanche upon themselves.

title: Insurance Soars on Ships in the Middle East
description: Insurance rates soared in London today for cargoes and ships in the Persian Gulf amid fears that further fighting would break out in the region.

title: Events: Vegetables, Crafts and Antiques
description: City-Grown Harvest, Gateway National Recreation Area, Floyd Bennett Field, near Exit 11S on the Belt Parkway, Brooklyn; (212) 233-2926.

title: Bar Group, in Shift, Adopts Neutral Policy on Abortion
description: In a vote reflecting a deep and painful schism in this traditionally collegial group, the policy-making body of the American Bar Association voted today to abandon its six-month-old stance in favor of abortion rights and to adopt a policy of neutrality instead.

title: Congress, in Switch, Plans to Give Census Workers Jobless Benefits
description: Two months after voting to deny unemployment benefits to thousands of temporary census workers, Congress has decided to reverse itself.

title: A Bank Chairman Is Charged in Queens In a Bribery Scheme
description: A Queens bank chairman was arrested yesterday on charges that he had bribed a Federal tax agent to end an investigation of his finances and then prompted the agent to investigate three of the bank's customers.

title: Supplier of Parts for Shuttle Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
description: A Federal grand jury in Tampa, Fla., indicted a Florida company today on charges of defrauding the Government by falsely certifying the quality of electronic parts it provided for the space shuttle and numerous weapons programs.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From the TV Talk By Mubarak to the Egyptians
description: Following are excerpts from President Hosni Mubarak's nationally televised speech today on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, as translated by The Associated Press:

title: Tokyo Stocks Fall Sharply On Worries About Mideast
description: Japanese stock prices fell sharply today, wiping out all of the Tokyo market's gains from yesterday.

title: 'Star Wars' Makes Even More Sense Now
description: To the Editor:

title: East Germans Fail to Approve Voting Plan
description: The East German Parliament raised new doubts about the timetable for unification today when it failed to ratify an accord outlining procedures for joint elections with West Germany.

title: Accounts
description: * Dutch Dairy Bureau to the New York office of Hal Riney & Partners, for the United States advertising of Dutch cheeses.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   First American Deployment to Gulf Is 'Tip of Wedge,' the Pentagon Says
description: Pentagon officials said today that the initial deployment of United States forces to Saudi Arabia was ''the tip of the wedge'' and that the number of men and arms sent to the Persian Gulf would grow substantially in the next few weeks.

title: W. O. Martin Jr., 79, Ex-Louisiana Official
description: Wade Omer Martin Jr., Louisiana Secretary of State for 32 years, died Monday at his home in Baton Rouge, La. He was 79 years old. The cause of death was not given. Mr. Martin, a lawyer, was elected Secretary of State in 1944 at the age of 33. He quit in 1976 to run for governor. After defeat in that race, he retired to private practice and served as a consultant to the Louisiana Elections Integrity Commission.

title: Navratilova May Play
description: Although Martina Navratilova believes the leg injury she suffered before the Great American tournament in San Diego this week should not prevent her from playing next week, her surgeon thinks otherwise.

title: Son of Former Military Ruler Goes Into Politics in Pakistan
description: A son of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, convinced that the time is right to revive the name of Pakistan's late military ruler, has set aside a career in banking and plunged into politics in anticipation of elections on Oct. 24.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a weekly television ratings chart yesterday misidentified the Middle Eastern leader interviewed on Sunday by Dan Rather on the CBS News program ''60 Minutes.'' It was King Hussein of Jordan.

title: At the Mansion, A Gorgeous Mosaic To Please Any Mayor
description: ''IT'S hard to believe you're in the city,'' Joyce B. Dinkins said as she walked past the perennial borders and towering trees that encircle Gracie Mansion. ''I've always lived in an apartment, and I don't have a green thumb,'' she added, clearly happy to have as her first garden such sylvan surroundings.

title: Review/Jazz;   Saxophonists Spurred By Moment
description: The tenor saxophonists Johnny Griffin and Von Freeman, both playing at the peak of their abilities, stormed through their concert at the Classical Jazz festival at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, offering intense, complicated improvisations.

title: Talking Deals;   Unusual Alliance For McDonald's
description: THE McDonald's Corporation and the Environmental Defense Fund announced a highly unusual deal last week that, if it works, could change the way environmental groups interact with Corporate America. But if it fails, positions could harden on both sides, with executives dismissing environmental advocates as impractical visionaries and environmentalists becoming more determined than ever to use the courts and political process to force change.

title: Yields Down For Week
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell for the week ended yesterday.

title: Tamara Deutscher, Writer, 77
description: Tamara Deutscher, a writer and editor who with her husband, the late Isaac Deutscher, researched the leaders of Soviet Communism, died on Tuesday in London, where she lived. She was 77 years old and, according to family friends, had suffered from emphysema.

title: John Aston, 87, Dies; Pioneer in Cryogenics
description: John G. Aston, emeritus professor of organic chemistry and former director of the Low Temperature Laboratory at Pennsylvania State University, died Monday at Centre Community Hospital in State College, Pa. He was 87 years old and lived in State College.

title: Sterling Drug Explores Ventures
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's Sterling Drug unit, a midsize competitor in a consolidating industry, is in talks about joint ventures with other pharmaceutical groups, Kodak's chairman and chief executive, Kay R. Whitmore, said. ''We''re not prepared to divulge anything specific, but I think you can assume that Sterling Drug is busily talking to other people about what can be done jointly,' Mr. Whitmore said.

title: John Wilson, 76, Dies; Headed U. of Chicago
description: John T. Wilson, a former president of the University of Chicago, died Saturday at Rush Presbyterian St. Luke's Hospital in Chicago. He was 76 years old.

title: Trump Documents Ordered Released
description: Casino regulators in New Jersey ruled today that more than 1,000 J. Trump's financial rescue package must be made public. The documents, however, will remain secret while his lawyers appeal the decision.

title: Futures Chief's Severance Pay
description: The former chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, Karsten Mahlmann, who stepped down amid charges that his trading firm had misused customer's funds, will get $120,000 in severance pay, officials of the futures exchange said on Tuesday.

title: Rumors Haunt Morris, But He Is Resisting Them
description: Joe Morris reads it in the newspapers and hears it on television and radio. He hears people say he is not the runner he was, that his job is in danger, that when the pro football season begins in less than five weeks he may no longer be a Giant.

title: Ex-Nynex Worker Tells Of Purchases
description: The Nynex Corporation made previously unacknowledged purchases from employers of two men who helped organize lewd parties in Florida for the company's purchasing managers, according to testimony filed yesterday with the New York State Public Service Commission by a former Nynex executive.

title: In These Boxes, Junk Mail Just Won't Do
description: LEAD: THOSE architects are at it again.

title: Hear Ye! Hear Ye! Our Baby Is Here!
description: ALTHOUGH most newborn babies seem to look alike - eyes closed and jowly - their birth announcements do not, at least not these days. In recent years, the generation that became parents in their 30's has taken to commissioning professional designers and illustrators to trumpet the event.

title: Washington at Work;   Modern Cassandra With a Message That Angers but Still Wins Support
description: A basic tenet of Washington politics is that bad news doesn't sell. Jimmy Carter found that out in his now-infamous ''malaise'' speech, when he painted a picture of a country entering a moral and economic decline, a speech that many analysts say was the beginning of his political demise.

title: Brady Wants Rate Cut, But Sees No Recession
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that oil price shocks need not topple the economy into a recession, and he called on the Federal Reserve to stimulate growth with lower interest rates.

title: Food Supply Is Vital in Embargo
description: Embargos on trade with Iraq and Kuwait have focused on oil exports, but the effect on Iraq's food imports may also prove critical.

title: Arthur Samuel, 88, Pioneer Researcher In Computer Science
description: Arthur L. Samuel, a computer scientist who did early research on machine learning and artificial intelligence, died July 29 at Stanford University Memorial Hospital in California. He was 88 years old.

title: Review/Television;   Pessimistic Look at Parole System
description: If there is any promising element in America's system for dealing with criminals, parole is not it. That is the message of ''Convicts on the Street: One Year on Parole,'' tonight's streetwise documentary, at 10:45 on the HBO cable network.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Miss Saigon' Canceled

title: Antibiotics After Sex Are Found To Ease Female Urinary Infection
description: Women who suffer frequent urinary tract infections can gain a reprieve from that common and frustrating problem by taking an antibiotic tablet after sexual intercourse, researchers reported today.

title: Eugene F. Black, 87, Ex-Justice in Michigan
description: Eugene F. Black, a former Michigan Supreme Court justice, died Saturday at his home in Port Huron, Mich. He was 87 years old. The cause of death was not announced. Justice Black was a member of the State Supreme Court from 1955 until 1972, when he returned to private practice. He was Attorney General of Michigan from 1946 to 1948. He was a partner in the law firm of Black & Black with his son Douglas and later his grandsons Bryan and David from 1972 until his death.

title: Pet Chief Quits In Dispute
description: The chief executive of Pet Inc., J. Robert Copper, has resigned, citing differences with the food company's parent, the Whitman Corporation of Chicago. A spokesman for Whitman, Chuck Connolly, said Mr. Copper, who is 50 years old, and Whitman's management had agreed on Tuesday that a change was needed at Pet.

title: Expos End Six-Game Slide With Victory Over Pirates
description: Tim Raines broke out of an 0-for-18 slump with two run-scoring doubles to back Dennis Martinez's six-hitter as the Montreal Expos beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-2, tonight.

title: British Airways Net Up
description: British Airways P.L.C. said Tuesday that its first-quarter profits rose 79 percent despite a slower rise in sales. British Airways' profits for the three months that ended June 30 came to $:111 million, or about $194 million, up from $:62 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. The carrier's sales rose 14 percent, to $:1.33 billion, or about $2.3 billion, from $:1.17 billion. The airline said its traffic remained buoyant. Passenger loads on scheduled flights increased to 72.2 percent, from 70.4 percent.

title: Demonstrator Maimed by Navy Train Settles Suit
description: An anti-war demonstrator whose legs were severed by a Navy train carrying munitions has agreed to settle his lawsuit against the Government and train crew for $920,000, his lawyer says.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf; Strategy: Embargo;   U.S. Bets Its Troops Will Deter Iraq While Sanctions Do the Real Fighting
description: By sending American troops to Saudi Arabia, President Bush moved to deter an Iraqi invasion and committed the United States to a long stay in the Middle East kingdom, gambling that a steady tightening of economic pressure will force President Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the New York Jets training camp misidentified the coach shown. He was Bruce Coslet, the head coach.

title: 4 Younger Executives Move Up at Chemical
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation announced a reorganization of its top management yesterday, drawing from its own cadre of executives to name a new president and to create an office of the chairman with four younger executives.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraq Says Israel Plans Attack With U.S. Aid
description: Iraq said today that Israel was preparing to attack it using planes painted with American colors.

title: Poor Training Cited in Steam-Pipe Blast
description: The New York State Public Service Commission said yesterday that poor training of Consolidated Edison workers led to the explosion of an asbestos-lined steam pipe in Gramercy Park last year that killed three people and injured 30 others.

title: Currents;   Permanence for Images Etched on the Berlin Wall
description: SINCE 1984, Hermann Waldenburg, a 50-year-old graphic designer, has been photographing the evanescent images painted on the Berlin wall - the Statue of Liberty, dancing skeletons, heart-shaped faces.

title: Review/Music;   New Orleans In Spirit
description: Walter (Wolfman) Washington's ecstatic second set at Tramps on Saturday night had an easy versality. Mr. Washington, who comes from New Orleans, shows off an urban curiosity, and secular blues, religious gospel, jazz, rock and just about every other form of American music made their appearance. Mr. Washington, a guitarist and singer, is a natural onstage, and once he and his excellent band found their groove, with Mr. Washington singing up in the smash-the-glass falsetto range and unloading strings of notes from his guitar, a party ensued.

title: Currents;   Grinding Time Out of Stainless Steel
description: TWO years ago, Constantin Boym, a Manhattan product designer, began an experiment with a sheet of stainless steel. He sawed, riveted and bolted away, trying to find what processes would leave interesting marks on the metal.

title: Currents;   Music Floating in the Air, And So Are Two Pianos
description: TONIGHT at 8, Paul Panhuysen and Johan Goedhart, Dutch multi-media artists, will turn the Great Hall of the National Building Museum in Washington into a concert hall. The performance is called a Long String Installation.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page listing yesterday headed ''Iraqi Crisis: Reverberations'' misstated Tuesday's price of the benchmark American crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange in some copies. The contract for September delivery closed at $28.31, up 26 cents.

title: Honeywell Plans To Sell Business
description: Honeywell Inc. said it had tentatively agreed to sell Honeywell Federal Systems Inc. to Bull HN Information Systems Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Honeywell said the planned sale continues a transition begun in 1987 to focus the company on its controls businesses.

title: Council Questions Brown on Efforts to Fight Crime
description: The New York City Council aggressively questioned top Dinkins administration officials yesterday about their efforts to fight crime, with one committee chairman saying New Yorkers now know ''how the average Roman felt while Rome burned and Nero fiddled.''

title: Study Finds Housing Costs Keep 32% Poor
description: Nearly one-third of Americans are ''shelter poor,'' spending so much of their income on housing that they cannot afford other necessities, a study released today said.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   PRESS LEFT OUT OF GULF AIRLIFT
description: For the second time in eight months, American troops today headed into a foreign military operation without the special contingent of reporters and photographers that the Pentagon has pledged to summon when United States forces are sent abroad.

title: Japanese Education Is More Rigid Than Ours;   Breaking the Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: Executives Back Action by Military
description: Corporate executives polled by telephone this week strongly support military action in the face of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

title: Raphael Yavneh, 60, Executive and Editor
description: Raphael Yavneh, retired president of the Forbes Investors Advisory Institute, an affiliate of Forbes Inc., the magazine publisher, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Man Wearing the Knickers
description: Anyone who follows golf knows that Payne Stewart wears old-fashioned knickers, his trademark. His golf shoes, though, are less prominent. That's because they are the standard variety, with laces and cleats. They are his shoes, and it is obvious he finds no reason to put himself into anyone else's shoes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avon Products Inc., New York, the cosmetics company, appointed Joseph A. Faranda vice president of marketing research. Edwina D. Woodbury was named vice president of operations analysis.

title: Burmese Forces Said to Fire On Marchers Led by Monks
description: Burmese security forces opened fire today on a peaceful dawn march led by Buddhist monks in Mandalay, killing at least four people, Western diplomats in Rangoon said.

title: Lawsuits Transferred
description: Two lawsuits filed regarding the death of Hank Gathers, the former Loyola Marymount basketball star, were transferred yesterday to the Torrance Superior Court in California.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From Bush's Statement on U.S. Defense of Saudis
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's address from the Oval Office yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: On Tapping Oil Reserve
description: Key members of Congress, as well as many energy economists, are dismayed by the Bush Administration's reluctance to counter the last week's run-up in oil prices by selling stocks from the Government-owned Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Sears Chairman Is Taking Reins of Merchandise Group
description: In a management shake-up announced today, Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Company, will take direct control of the company's troubled merchandise group. Mr. Brennan will assume the additional title of chief executive of that group.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

CIT's Financing Unit Gets a New President
description: LEAD: Lawrence A. Marsiello has been named president of the CIT Group's factoring operations, which provide financing to more than 600 clients in the textile, apparel and furniture businesses.

title: Jamaica Swaps Debt for Equity
description: Jamaica said last week that it had agreed with Mexico on a debt-equity swap program that would reduce the island's Government debt by $30 million. The program means Mexican citizens can buy Jamaican Government debt at 42 cents on the dollar.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraq Confines 38 Americans, But Their Status Is Unclear
description: Iraq released an American child today and permitted United States officials to visit 38 other Americans confined to a Baghdad hotel, but it continued to hold them under armed guard, the State Department announced today.

title: New Drug From an Old Preparation Offers Hope Against Bladder Cancer
description: Last year at the American Urological Association meeting, 1,500 physicians signed a petition to the Food and Drug Administration extolling the virtues of a tiny germ that causes tuberculosis in cows. The germ has emerged as an effective, if unlikely, weapon against certain bladder cancers that might otherwise require surgery to remove the organ.

title: Lost Courage, Lost Play
description: Actors' Equity asserts that a British actor portraying a Eurasian in the musical ''Miss Saigon'' would be ''an affront to the Asian community.'' But refusing to let him repeat his London role on Broadway is an affront to the essence of theater.

title: Albany Alters Cable TV Pact For Manhattan
description: After rewriting a handful of major provisions that New York City negotiators had worked out in round-the-clock bargaining, the state commission that regulates cable television gave final approval today to franchise renewals for the two cable companies serving Manhattan.

title: A New Kind of Crisis
description: For the first time in many years, an American President has discussed a grave international crisis and the serious actions it requires of him without issuing a call to arms against Communism or raising the old, familiar cold war fears.

title: People
description: * Chris Dickens has been appointed worldwide media director at Young & Rubicam.

title: Q&A
description: Pit Marks on Aluminum

title: F.B.I. SETTLES SUIT BY A BLACK AGENT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has settled a lawsuit against it by a black agent who complained he had been a victim of racial discrimination, the bureau said today.

title: Lobby as Urban Living Room
description: FORGET about potted palms and intimate corners in which to rendezvous. There is no clock to meet under.

title: Key Pinch-Hit Homer for Barfield
description: His voice is even, almost unemotional. But behind the words, Jesse Barfield is angry and unhappy and determined to change his course. He still wants the Yankees to trade him.

title: Using a New Stain to Freshen Old Wood
description: LEAD: The great cabinet woods that went into the making of much of the fine antique furniture around today - mahogany, maple, cherry, walnut and rosewood - possessed splendid natural color, and it developed even more after their finishing. But that did not stop furniture makers from helping the process along with colored oils or waxes.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   OIL MARKETS EASE; STOCK PRICES RISE
description: Oil prices fell and the stock markets in the New York and Tokyo steadied yesterday after the United States decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and reports that the oil-rich kingdom would increase its production.

title: Review/Fashion;   Structured Bra Returns to Swimsuits Maybe it's the influence of Madonna.
description: THE string bikini that bares all, the thin film of Lycra that stretches over the body concealing nothing - these glorifications of the natural woman on the beach are now part of the arriere-garde. The bra is back in swimsuits.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JESSICA TANDY and HUME CRONYN were denied a zoning variance for their home in affluent Easton, Conn. Mr. Cronyn and Miss Tandy, who won an Oscar for her role in ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' had hoped to house a chauffeur in an apartment upstairs in their three-car, detached garage.

title: More Babies Are Dying
description: Born in the U.S.A.: it should be a matter of pride. But for too many children, being born here constitutes bad luck. That's the substance of a sidetracked report by the White House Task Force on Infant Mortality.

title: Jury in Barry Trial Reviews Videotape Of Mayor at Hotel
description: The jury weighing the Government's drug and perjury case against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. took another look today at an 84-minute videotape that shows him smoking crack and being arrested in a room at the Vista Hotel here last January. But the Federal panel recessed without announcing any verdict.

title: New York's Financial Disclosure Laws Suffice
description: To the Editor:

title: Plain Cleaning or Fancy? Pick Fancy.
description: HOW do you find a good dry cleaner? One who will not return white linen shirts looking yellow or gray, and who knows how to handle a sequined dress?

title: Currents;   The Instant Art of Capturing History
description: THE Polaroid Corporation in Cambridge, Mass., has introduced a new replica service. Any two-dimensional image, a pastel, watercolor, oil painting, fresco or tapestry, can be reproduced in sizes up to 40 by 80 inches.

title: Applying Lessons of the Civil Rights Struggle
description: When the Rev. Abraham Lincoln Woods speaks to visitors in the quiet of his cramped office at St. Joseph's Baptist Church, it is often with his eyelids nearly closed, his mind drawing on the hard lessons of 35 years on the battlefields of the civil rights movement.

title: Home Improvement
description: CEDAR closet lining, which repels moths without the need for chemicals, is not difficult to install as long as the surfaces are suitable. As noted last week, there are two types of lining; sheets are less expensive and easier to install, but many people find them less attractive than strips. Either kind can be fastened to flat, smooth walls, or to furring strips if the wall has bumps or hollows.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GERARD DEPARDIEU received a two-month suspended prison term and a six-month suspension of his driver's license plus a fine of nearly $2,000 on charges of drunken driving and causing an accident. The actor, who was driving near Vichy in central France following work on his latest film, ''Uranus,'' crashed into a car coming from the opposite direction. Two of its occupants were injured.

title: Burmese Rebel Recalls Days of Violence
description: Every Saturday for the last month, denying himself food or drink, Min Sun Min dons one of his two suits, knots his one red polyester tie and rides the subway to the Upper East Side for an act of revolutionary defiance.

title: Parent & Child
description: A 4-YEAR-OLD boy threw torn pieces of bread at the seagulls that greedily swooped to claim the free meal. One gull was more aggressive than the others and was clearly getting the most food. The boy looked at the bird sternly and sharply admonished him with the words he had apparently been hearing at home: ''You're not sharing!''

title: Japanese Education Is More Rigid Than Ours;   Pattern of Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Train Derailed in Vermont
description: A railroad bed washed away by heavy rain caused the derailment of 11 cars from a northbound freight train on Tuesday. Two crewmen were injured, and 2,000 gallons of diesel fuel spilled into a stream that feeds the White River. Christopher Burger, general manager of the Central Vermont Railway office in St. Albans, said the train was carrying no hazardous cargo.

title: CHRONICLE
description: While Japan commemorates the 45th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, AKIRA KUROSAWA said yesterday that his new film would depict the horror of nuclear war. Shooting has begun in a village outside Tokyo for ''Rhapsody in August.''

title: W. M. Spackman Is Dead at 85; Author of Novels About Romance
description: W. M. Spackman, a writer and classicist who in a burst of creativity late in life became the author of five novels, died on Friday at his home in Princeton, N.J.

title: Market Place;   Mixed Feelings On Bank Stocks
description: FOR contrarian investors in bank stocks, willing to fight the downward trend in prices and steady flow of bad news, the problem in recent months has been to know just which hour is the darkest one that precedes the dawn.

title: What Is Traditional?
description: To The Home Section:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE OIL JOLT

title: Gulf Crisis: Words and Deeds
description: EXPLAINING THE MOVE ''I ask for your support in the decision I've made to stand up for what's right and condemn what's wrong,'' President Bush said in an address. Excerpts, page A15.

title: Dow Rises 24.26 Points as Oil Prices Drop
description: Stocks advanced strongly in active trading yesterday, as oil prices turned downward following President Bush's morning address to the nation explaining the dispatch of United States troops to Saudi Arabia.

title: Bronx Man Is Held in Slaying Of Former Broadway Dancer
description: A 19-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged in the slaying of a teen-ager who had danced on Broadway, the police said.

title: In Kenya, Clergy Too Suffers Reprisals
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art;   A Soviet Movement That Tried To Change All Aspects of Life
description: Death to art, declared the Russian Constructivists in the aftermath of the Russian Revolution, and in its place they envisioned an art devoted, like the revolution, to technology, utilitarianism and social progress.

title: Joaquin E. Meyer, Former Cuban Diplomat, 83
description: Joaquin E. Meyer, a former Cuban diplomat who later served at the Inter-American Development Bank, died on Sunday at the Hospice of Washington. He was 83 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Dean Witter to Appeal
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said this week that it would appeal a court ruling ordering it to pay $23.4 million to Daniel Waite, a former commodities broker who was dismissed in 1982. Mr. Waite contended that Dean Witter, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, had libeled and slandered him in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and in a statement to a potential employer. The statements contended that the broker had violated New York Mercantile Exchange rules while working for Dean Witter. The verdict, returned on Friday in a state court in Houston, includes more than $15 million in punitive damages.

title: Jacques Soustelle, Leader in Fight For a French Algeria, Dies at 78
description: Jacques Soustelle, an anthropologist and former Cabinet minister who was one of the leaders of an underground movement that fought against Algerian independence, died Tuesday in the Paris suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine. He was 78 years old. The cause of death was not reported. Dr. Soustelle, who was named to the Academie Francaise in 1983, was one of Europe's foremost experts on pre-Colombian civilizations in Mexico, on which he wrote several authoritative studies.

title: Japanese Education Is More Rigid Than Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Savings Bond Sales Up
description: Americans bought $629 million worth of United States savings bonds in July, up 4 percent from the period a year earlier and 2 percent from June, the Government reported on Tuesday. The Treasury Department said July's purchases brought total sales for the first 10 months of the 1990 fiscal year to $6.58 billion, up from $6.57 billion in the corresponding period of 1989. It also brought to $122.55 billion the value of savings bonds now held by Americans, 7 percent more than a year ago. The current rate on savings bonds is 7.01 percent, effective through Oct. 31.

title: Indicted Navajo Leader Wins Spot in Tribal Race
description: Despite his suspension as leader of the nation's largest Indian tribe, Peter MacDonald finished only 3,500 votes behind the front runner in Tuesday's tribal presidential primary and will face him in a general election on Nov. 6.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Baseball Notebook;   Brewers Fighting Yankees for Last
description: Until a couple of weeks ago, even the possibility would have been unthinkable. Now, however, the Yankees are within sight of sixth place and have a legitimate chance of escaping a last-place finish. They owe it all to the Milwaukee Brewers. The Yankees, who have been in last place for two and a half months, since late May, were nine and a half games from sixth as recently as July 26. On that date, the five other teams in the American League East that were not in first place were all closer to the top than the Yankees were to sixth.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   The Longest Week: How President Decided to Draw the Line
description: When President Bush and Margaret Thatcher met in Aspen, Colo., last Thursday as the large army of Iraq swarmed into the small kingdom of Kuwait, the British Prime Minister warned Mr. Bush about President Saddam Hussein of Iraq: ''He won't stop.''

title: In an Unaware India, AIDS Threat Is Growing
description: Medical authorities say India is facing a growing threat from AIDS because there is not enough public awareness about the dangers of sexual promiscuity and contaminated blood products. The illness has not been treated as a priority in a nation where millions suffer from other diseases.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Sharper Image
description: The Sharper Image Corporation, a retailer of unusual high-technology products, announced today that it would cut its nationwide workforce by 10 percent. The layoffs of about 110 of the company's 1,100 workers include corporate and store employees. The layoffs come amid a sales slump for most types of retailers. A company spokeswoman said Sharper Image posted its first losses during the second quarter. Sharper Image has 70 stores in about two dozen

title: Quayle Warns Haiti to Hold Fair Election
description: Vice President Dan Quayle warned Haitian leaders today that the United States would cut off economic aid to this Caribbean nation if general elections scheduled for November are not free and fair.

title: Court Suspends Whistleblower In Corruption
description: A lawyer who played a major role in exposing corruption in New York City government by disclosing he had paid kickbacks on a city contract has been suspended from practicing law for five years for his part in the scheme.

title: In a Bruising Outing, the Mets Rally and Win
description: There was blood, both bad and real. There were bruises, to egos as well as to arms and legs.

title: Net Up 24.6% At Wal-Mart
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. reported today that it had a 24.6 percent gain in its second-quarter profit as revenue also increased by the same rate.

title: Big Record Labels Making Big Investments in Rap Music
description: In late 1988, MCA Inc. paid about $1 million to sign on Erik B. and Rakim, a popular rap group whose recordings were previously distributed by the tiny label 4th and Broadway. Earlier this year, Warner Brothers Inc. lured the Jungle Brothers, another rap ensemble, away from Warlock Records, a small New York label, with a $1.25 million contract.

title: Agent Orange Study Was Obstructed, Panel Says
description: After 14 months of investigation, a House committee concluded today that the Reagan Administration had obstructed a $43 million Federal health study of Vietnam veterans exposed to the defoliant Agent Orange, causing the study's cancellation.

title: Don't Tempt Them With Your Cigarettes
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co., New York, appointed Richard S. Bodman senior vice president of strategic planning and corporate development.

title:
Battery Park City;

2 New Projects Test a Sluggish Market
description: LEAD: Two condominium projects under construction at Battery Park City are the latest additions to the 92-acre former landfill in lower Manhattan.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   For Americans, a Dash Across Desert
description: Frank J. Jiral, a Texas oil man, and five other Americans piled into two cars at 4 A.M. Wednesday and headed south out of Baghdad across the scorching desert, bound for the Iraqi-Jordanian border.

title: IRAQ DETAINS FOREIGNERS, UPSETS SUMMIT;   50 SHIPS ASSEMBLE
description: United States and allied naval forces in the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, Mediterranean Sea and Persian Gulf, which will soon constitute an armada of more than 50 major ships, will begin enforcing a blockade on Iraqi commerce within a few days, American officials said today.

title: Sandinista Leadership Rethinking Its Ideology
description: In the past, Sandinista leaders reserved terms like ''coercion,'' ''authoritarianism'' and ''abuse of power'' to describe mortal enemies like the deposed Somoza dictatorship and the Reagan White House. Now, the Sandinistas have turned that language on a new target: themselves.

title: Hurricane Sets Off Floods, Killing at Least 23 in Mexico
description: A hurricane killed at least 23 people this week when raging torrents swept into a river valley in eastern Mexico, devastating homes, roads and farmland, the authorities said today.

title: Jonathan Pryce, 'Miss Saigon' and Equity's Decision
description: Only a few hours after Actors' Equity in New York announced its decision to bar Jonathan Pryce from acting in a Broadway production of ''Miss Saigon,'' Mr. Pryce was back on stage here, doing his job in the theater, giving an electrifying performance in the role of his career.

title: Review/Jazz;   Thoughts On America By Ellington
description: For most of the second half of his career, Duke Ellington, in concert, brought together his hits with longer, more ambitious works. Stung by the mixed critical reception of ''Black, Brown and Beige'' in 1943 and forced by financial necessity, Mr. Ellington walked the line between the traditional function of the big bands, which was to keep a dancing audience happy, and his own aspirations as a serious composer.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Defending Champion Loses in Quarterfinal
description: In a match that will be remembered as one of the most exciting in the history of the United States Women's Amateur Championship, Pat Hurst defeated Vicki Goetze, the 17-year-old defending champion, 1-up, in the quarterfinals today.

title: At the Movies
description: War and Romance

title: Food at the Ball Park: Now It's Cuisine
description: FOR generations, hot dogs and beer have been as much a part of the baseball ritual as chewing tobacco and pudgy managers throwing tantrums at home plate. It was inevitable, though, that the food revolution sweeping across the land would scale the walls of the nation's ballparks, threatening to turn our ingenuous national pastime into a food event.

title: Port Authority Seeking to Buy Aqueduct Track
description: New York State is exploring the sale of Aqueduct Race Track in Queens to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which would close the track and use the land to expand Kennedy International Airport, state officials said today.

title: Frances O'Brien, 86; Did Portraits of Famous
description: Frances O'Brien, a portrait artist, died Tuesday at her home in Tucson, Ariz. She was 86 years old.

title: Reading Saddam's Mind
description: A great leader, a new Saladin, is known for the enemies he makes. I now have the enemies I need.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Vietnam Again, for the First Time
description: Fifteen years after North Vietnamese tanks smashed into Saigon's Presidential Palace, there are still two Vietnams. The Republic of (South) Vietnam, that artificial creation of French colonialism and cold war politics, is no more. But commercial capitalism, the American presence and the Viet Cong-led insurrection pressed a distinctive subculture onto the South. The political ramifications endure.

title: New Incentives On Ford Models
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would offer four-year loans at 4.8 percent on selected car lines and $1,000 cash rebates on others. The low financing and rebates end on Sept. 26, the date of the official introduction of Ford's 1991 models. The 1991 Escort and the Ford Explorer are in showrooms and are exempt.

title: ON STAGE
description: Spider-Man Project

title: Key Witness Slain in Bogota
description: Two gunmen disguised as policemen killed the Government's chief witness in the assassination of the presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan, the police said today.

title: UAL Workers Hopeful on Bid
description: United Airlines workers indicated today that they were encouraged by a decision extending the life of a $4.38 billion employee buyout bid.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Management Is Shuffled
description: After announcing last week that it was laying off 30 of its 150 employees in New York, Chiat/Day/Mojo said yesterday that it has reorganized the top management at the troubled office.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: More Caution by Sponsors After Shoal Creek Furor
description: The scandal over a country club's racially exclusionary membership policy will make corporations more cautious about paying to associate their names with athletic events, a $2 billion industry that until now has been growing explosively.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-11

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption yesterday about Americans' reactions to the Persian Gulf crisis misidentified the man shown. He was Bruce Kennedy of Plattsburg, Mo., not Bruce Wilkinson, who was quoted in the caption.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Dominican Day Parade, Madison Avenue will be closed on Sunday from 37th to 56th Streets from noon to 4 P.M.

title: Apple Faces Challenge To Its Role as Innovator
description: Apple Computer Inc., the Silicon Valley company that defined inventiveness and creativity in the personal computer industry, is engaged in an unfamiliar round of soul searching. Can the computer maker, both employees and supporters wonder, prove that it is still capable of innovation?

title: Rob Moore Stays Close To Home
description: Most football players don't go home for lunch. It's too far, in all senses of the word. But whenever the schedule allows, Rob Moore travels three miles down Hempstead Turnpike to visit his family.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He was taken hostage.''

title: Private Police Patrols Have Reduced Crime
description: Private security patrols working with the police have cut crime in one midtown Manhattan district, new figures show.

title: Article 913590 -- No Title
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, also known as Freddie Mac, is selling $500 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit (Remic) securities through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Private Art Collection Is Stolen in Moscow
description: Thieves made off with the largest private art collection in the Soviet Union Union after breaking into an apartment and tying up the owner, Izvestia reported this week.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Expects Its Force To Be in Place in a Month
description: Reporting that tens of thousands of Iraqi troops were moving south across Iraq toward Kuwait, Pentagon officials said today that it will take about a month to place the first major complement of American ground forces in Saudi Arabia.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   People
description: * Dean Scaros, the president of Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., the United States division of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, has been given the additional title of chief operating officer of the division. The promotion of Mr. Scaros fills the position left vacant since the retirement last year of G. Robert Holmen. The agency also named Kenneth R. Rogers, an executive vice president of the parent company, as managing director of its New York office.

title: 5 in Queens Indicted in Drug Ring
description: A New York State investigation into a major Colombian drug cartel has led to the indictments of five Queens residents on cocaine-trafficking charges and has shed light on what the authorities say is the structure of the cartel's New York operations.

title: Sun Reports Profit in Period
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., helped by strong sales of its low-priced computer work stations, reported sharply improved results for its fourth quarter and 1990 fiscal year.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   No Saudi Request Yet, Pakistani Army Says
description: A spokesman for the Pakistani armed forces said today that there had been no request so far from Saudi Arabia for Pakistani troops to augment an international force facing the Iraqis.

title: What '9-Year-Old Shot in Head' Means;   Hotline for Dealers
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. TO TIGHTEN DIESEL FUEL RULE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would require an 80 percent reduction of sulfur in diesel fuel sold for vehicles driven on the highway starting on Oct. 1, 1993.

title: Georgia Train Crash Kills 3
description: Two freight trains collided near this northwest Georgia town early today, killing two conductors and an engineer and injuring four other railroad employees. The authorities said one train was on the main Norfolk Southern track when it ran head-on into a train that had just moved off a side track shortly before 3:30 A.M.

title: After 32 Years of Democracy, Fears of a Coup in Venezuela
description: In one day, the Defense Minister was replaced and 143 officers retired. Such military changes take place peacefully here, but some Venezuelans wonder how long that will continue.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sun Ra Celebrates

title: Quick Deal For Montana
description: Joe Montana quickly negotiated one of the richest contracts in National Football League history today with Edward J. DeBartolo, the owner of the San Francisco 49ers. The 34-year-old quarterback agreed to a four-year deal reported to be worth $13 million.

title: Review/Film;   If All's for the Worst
description: ''Ariel'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 24, 1989. The film, in Finnish with English subtitles, opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Texaco to Relocate Workers
description: Texaco, which employs 67 Americans in and around Saudi Arabia, has made arrangements to relocate the workers and their families from the area, a company spokesman said today.

title: Prominent Speculator Is Indicted in Japanese Stock Case
description: Prosecutors today indicted one of Japan's best-known and most politically influential stock speculators, Matsuhiro Kotani, today on charges that he manipulated a stock. But the prosecutors left many disappointed when they indicated that the inquiry was now likely to end.

title: Mob-Linked Businessman Slain Outside His Home
description: A construction company owner who illegally demolished four buildings in Times Square in the middle of the night in 1985 was shot to death Wednesday in front of his house in Brooklyn in what the police described as a mob-style slaying.

title: Cantor Zvee Aroni, 65; Held First Pulpit at 18
description: Zvee Aroni, a prominent cantor for Conservative Jewish congregations, died Tuesday at his daughter's home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived in North Miami Beach.

title: In Sex Case, Focus Is on Multiple Personalities
description: In a case that is likely to present some uncomfortable legal issues, an Oshkosh man is to stand trial next month on charges of sexually assaulting a 26-year-old acquaintance suffering from what has been diagnosed as multiple personality disorder.

title: Minor Quake Hits California
description: A minor earthquake rolled through this coastal city early today, jostling nerves but causing no damage or injuries, the authorities said. The 6:15 A.M. temblor had a preliminary reading of 3.0 on the Richter scale, said Heidi Aspaturian, a spokeswoman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. Its epicenter was six miles southeast of Santa Barbara, she said.

title: What '9-Year-Old Shot in Head' Means
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   Profits at Foote, Cone Are Up 9.4% for Quarter
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., the Chicago-based agency, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 9.4 percent, to $7.5 million, or 73 cents a share, from $6.8 million, or 67 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues rose 6.4 percent, to $84.7 million, from $79.6 million a year ago.

title: Howard O. McMahon, 75, Dies; Former Head of Arthur D. Little
description: Howard O. McMahon, a scientist, inventor and former president of Arthur D. Little Inc., the international management and technology consulting concern, died Sunday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: AIDS Programs Are Successfully Enlisted in Drug Addiction Fight
description: A Federal effort to reach drug addicts with programs born out of the AIDS epidemic has recorded success rates as high as 47 percent in getting them to quit, the Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: Panel Finds Error by Manufacturer of Space Telescope
description: The Federal panel investigating the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope has found what appears to be the cause of the instrument's flawed mirror: a spacing error of about one millimeter in an optic device used to guide the making of the telescope's main mirror.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Baghdad Seals Off the Exit Of Foreigners Across Border
description: Iraq informed the United States today that thousands of Americans and other foreigners stranded in Iraq and Kuwait since last week may not leave, the State Department said.

title: Equity Will Reconsider 'Miss Saigon' Decision
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he was ''reaching out to Actors' Equity'' to see if he could help in the dispute that has led to the cancellation of the planned Broadway production of the London hit musical ''Miss Saigon.''

title: Tampa F.B.I. Is Said to Have Helped Steinbrenner
description: Drawing on a 20-year working relationship with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, George Steinbrenner often enlisted past and present agents of the bureau's Tampa office to conduct unofficial background checks of business associates as well as his own employees, former F.B.I. investigators said today.

title: Study Gives Auto Outlook
description: Japanese automobile makers will continue to increase their market share in the United States in the 1990's at the expense of domestic manufacturers, but at a slower rate, according to a study released on Tuesday by the consulting firm Arthur D. Little.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Betty Garrett Looks Back

title: Our Towns;   A Country Club Where Excuses Need Not Apply
description: When Shoal Creek Country Club of Alabama burst into the headlines as a symbol of restricted all-white golf clubs, Robert F. Carroll wasn't too surprised. ''There are Shoal Creeks all over,'' he said. ''There are Shoal Creeks a couple of minutes from here.''

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times on July 31 depicting an apparatus for testing the Hubble Space Telescope's main mirror incorrectly represented the arrangement of the sensor and reference mirror. A diagram today on page A14, with an article on later developments, shows the correct arrangement.

title: As for New York City, the Stronger the Cable TV Bill, the Better
description: To the Editor:

title: How Sonic Youth Came to Make the Sound It Makes
description: Once considered the heroes of New York's underground rock scene, the members of Sonic Youth are fast becoming the antiheroes of the mainstream. After eight years recording for independent labels, the band recently released its major label debut, ''Goo,'' on DGC Records, and it is to perform tonight amid the kitschy grandeur of Roseland Ballroom.

title: Strike at 2 G.M. Plants Closes Ohio Operation
description: A strike by about 3,000 hourly workers of the General Motors Corporation at two parts factories in Flint, Mich., has caused the shutdown of a truck assembly plant in Moraine, Ohio.

title: German Leaders Agree On Elections on Dec. 2
description: In an abrupt shift, the leaders of West and East Germany agreed this evening to hold the first all-German elections since 1933 on Dec. 2.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article yesterday about the dispatch of American troops to Saudi Arabia misidentified a Democratic Representative from Brooklyn. He is Stephen J. Solarz.

title: Ballpark Dining
description: Yankee Stadium

title: He Wants to Play
description: Braxston Banks, a former Notre Dame running back, has sued the National Collegiate Athletic Association in Federal court in South Bend, Ind., in an effort to receive another year of college eligibility.

title: Gabelli-Paramount
description: A group of companies controlled by the New York investor Mario J. Gabelli, the owner of Gabelli & Company, has acquired 5.08 percent of Paramount Communications Inc. for $225.8 million. In a Securites and Exchange Commission filing, the Gabelli group said it now controlled 6.04 million of the entertainment company's 118.9 million shares outstanding.

title: Officer Kills Suspect in a Chain-Snatching
description: A transit police officer chasing a chain-snatcher across several blocks of the Bronx yesterday caught the young man as he hopped into a gypsy cab and shot him to death in the back seat, the police said.

title: Actors' Equity Had to Fight Over 'Miss Saigon'
description: To the Editor:

title: 5,000 More Police Officers Are Needed, Panel Asserts
