description: Saying New York City's crime problems are not hopeless, a business-sponsored anti-crime group offered a formula yesterday that it said could turn back the clock a generation and restore the streets to forgotten levels of safety.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds increased by $6.03 billion, to $401.94 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 169 institutional funds increased by $1.39 billion, to $100.29 billion; 249 general-purpose funds were up by $3.7 billion, to $139.42 billion, and 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $946.9 million, to $162.24 billion, the institute said.

title: Lever to Use More Recycled Plastics
description: In response to growing environmental concerns among consumers, the Lever Brothers Company said it was planning to use more recycled plastics in the bottles of its liquid soaps and other products. The New York-based company pledged to buy at least 10 million pounds of recycled high-density polyethylene a year. It said it hoped the commitment would encourage wider collection of used bottles from municipal trash by providing an assured market for the recycled product.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Five people have been awarded the Charles Frankel Prize by the National Endowment for the Humanities. MORTIMER J. ADLER, the philosopher and author; HENRY HAMPTON, a documentary film producer; BERNARD M. W. KNOX, an author and a former director of Harvard University's Center for Hellenic Studies; DAVID VAN TASSEL, professor of history at Case Western Reserve and founder of National History Day and ETHYLE R. WOLFE, a former provost at Brooklyn College, were recognized for their work in history, literature and other humanitites.

title: Actor's Equity Had to Fight Over 'Miss Saigon';   National Impact
description: To the Editor:

title: English Eyes Mavericks
description: Alex English has agreed to a contract with the Dallas Mavericks, but he won't sign until he has a chance to meet with the team's owner, Donald Carter, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday. (AP)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Canton Industrial Corp., Canton, Ill., a truck company, said it was in talks with Abbott Products Inc., Chicago, an industrial contractor, about consolidating the companies.

title: Books of The Times;   Recalling Suburban Life in the 50's
description: Seventh Heaven

title: As a Political Issue, S. &L.'s Fail Again
description: The nation's governors are calling for a Presidential commission to investigate the savings and loan mess. The head of the Federal bailout agency, L. William Siedman, is asking for an extra $50 billion just to get him through next year. As Congress heads toward its August recess, there is a rush to sponsor bills to create a special prosecutor, extend the statute of limitations, provide more investigators. Most tellingly, politicians are giving back savings industry campaign contributions, retroactively tainted, an almost unheard-of transfer of cash.

title: Police Stop Use of Chemical Spray After a Brooklyn Youth Is Burned
description: The New York City police will no longer use one type of chemical spray to stun people, after a 14-year-old Brooklyn youth was seriously burned when officers used the chemical on him in conjunction with a stun device, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said last night.

title: Oil Rise Helps Soviets, Hurts East Europe
description: The sharp rise in oil prices resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will give a windfall to the Soviet Union, the world's leading oil producer, but create havoc for the fragile economies of Eastern Europe, which depend heavily on imported oil.

title: Reeves Hospitalized
description: Dan Reeves, the Denver Broncos' coach, was hospitalized after he suffered chest pains Wednesday night, his daughter Laura said yesterday. She said Reeves was in good condition at North Colorado Medical Center in Greeley. At a news conference at the Broncos' training camp yesterday, Dr. Randall Marsh said Reeves had suffered chest pains but not a heart attack.

title: Barry Juror In Hospital; Deliberations Held Up
description: Deliberations in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial were suspended today when one of the jurors was hospitalized for what her doctor called stress and depression.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.N. Council Declares Void Iraqi Annexation of Kuwait
description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously today to declare Iraq's formal annexation of Kuwait null and void in international law.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   Grey Profits Up 4.5%
description: Grey Advertising Inc., the New York-based agency, said its second-quarter earnings rose 4.5 percent, to $5.2 million, or $3.96 a share, from $4.9 million, or $3.73 a share, in the comparable period in 1989. Revenues rose 10.1 percent, to $117.6 million, from $106.8 million.

title: Profits Off at Shell and B. P.
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that its profit fell 44.3 percent in the second quarter and the British Petroleum Company reported a drop of 88.9 percent.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Oil-Price Rise Poses a Threat For the Region
description: While the New York region is proportionally less dependent on energy than other parts of the country, the higher oil prices that have prevailed since Iraq invaded Kuwait endanger a local economy that is already among the frailest in the nation.

title: Head-Smashed-In Journal;   In the Bison's Land, Pride Lives On
description: Kenneth Eaglespeaker looked out over the plains that run eastward from the Rocky Mountains to the horizon, past clusters of visitors intent on learning about his ancestors, the Blackfoot Indians who hunted these plains for at least 6,000 years.

title: Review/Film;   Gibson as C.I.A. Pilot
description: There are people who will see Mel Gibson in absolutely anything.

title: P.&G. Profit Surged 66.1% In Quarter
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the world's largest makers of consumer products, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings had surged 66.1 percent, to $284 million, or 78 cents a share.

title: Perrier Sale Backed
description: The Department of Trade and Industry cleared Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.'s $211 million acquisition of Source Perrier S.A.'s non-cola soft-drinks business. The purchase includes two plants in the Paris area and another in Marseilles for various brands of a Perrier unit that includes Oasis and Bali orange squashes, Pschitt sodas and Gini lemonade.

title: Paul V. Callahan, Priest, 68
description: The Rev. Paul V. Callahan, a Jesuit priest and a teacher of classical languages for 33 years, died on Wednesday at St. Ignatius Loyola Residence in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 68 years old.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Says Turkey Plans To Cooperate on Iraq
description: In a crucial strategic development further isolating Iraq, the United States and Turkey laid the basis today for expanded military and intelligence cooperation to counter President Saddam Hussein, a Bush Administration official said.

title: Baby Bells' $2.4 Billion Deal Gains
description: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today removed one of the lingering legal uncertainties in the proposed $2.4 billion acquisition of New Zealand's state-owned telephone company by the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the American Information Technologies Corporation, or Ameritech.

title: Review/Music;   Computing in the Dark
description: Michael Robinson, a composer of electronic music who began his career in New York and moved to Hawaii last year, returned to present 11 of his works at St. Peter's Church on Tuesday evening.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   Accounts
description: * Ritz Carlton Hotel, Chicago, to Zwiren Collins Karo Trusk & Ayer, Ayer's Chicago affiliate, with an estimated budget of $1 million. The account had been with Haddon Advertising Inc., Chicago.

title: Soviet Astronauts Return to Earth
description: Two Soviet astronauts returned to Earth safely today, ending a six-month mission on which they grew crystals for industry and survived a nearly fatal space walk while repairing their damaged capsule.

title: Donaldson To Head Big Board
description: William H. Donaldson, one of the three founding partners of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., was named chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. He will replace John J. Phelan Jr., who will retire in January.

title: Fred L. Heyes, Broker, 70
description: Fred L. Heyes, a former vice president of F. Eberstadt & Company, a Manhattan brokerage firm, died on Wednesday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: My Union, Actors' Inequity
description: LEAD: A few nights ago, I had a bizarre dream. In it, I was watching ''Jeopardy'' and heard my name issue from the television set. The jackpot question was: ''This performers' union, of which Dick Cavett is a member, won the Bonehead Decision of the Year Award in 1990.'' Before any of the contestants could answer, the audience rose as one and shouted, ''What is Actors' Equity?

title: Once More, the U.S. Misreads the Arab World
description: LEAD: President Bush's deployment of U.S. forces was one of the saddest and sorriest events of the gulf crisis. It seems that the parties to the crisis are intent not only on deliberately misunderstanding each other but also making the wrong moves.

title: Birmingham Journal;   Bitter Memories of Bias Accompany City's Gains
description: From the days of Bull Connor's police dogs and fire hoses to the present, perhaps no American city has had to wrestle with the demons of race so conspicuously as Birmingham.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The Grolier Club is the latest of the cushy, homey semiprivate restaurants and nightspots to open in Manhattan - it also has some of the best food. The magnificent Romanesque four-story stone building at 29 East 32d Street has a baronial dining room on the ground floor with mahogany walls, leather and wood booths, scattered palms and soft jazz. The second floor has a bar overlooking the dining room; on the third floor are lounges with fireplaces, couches and upholstered chairs. The fourth floor holds another bar and a dance floor.

title: A 68 Gives Wadkins In P.G.A. First Round
description: While tensile-strength rough and Formica-firm greens made Shoal Creek an often infuriating test of composure today, a player who has been hardened by frustration emerged as the first-round leader of the 72d P.G.A. Championship.

title: A Stroke of Luck in Tumor Research
description: Through a mixture of ferocious drive and almost magical good luck, scientists who just a month ago reported finding the gene responsible for a disfiguring disorder of the nervous system have now discovered how the gene causes it.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iran's Quandary: Yesterday's Foe Today's Friend?
description: Ever since Iraq invaded Kuwait seven days ago, Iran has kept markedly quiet, assailing the Iraqi move but saying little else about the expanding crisis in the Persian Gulf, an area that Teheran has traditionally viewed as its sphere of prime concern and influence.

title: Yanks Win and Enjoy A Streak and a Sweep
description: Hard to believe, but it's been three months since the Yankees enjoyed a stretch like this.

title: Economic Scene;   How Hussein Miscalculated
description: The crisis in the Persian Gulf struck at a time when demand for oil was weakening and prices sagging. In fact, Saddam Hussein's decision to gobble up Kuwait was driven by his need to shore up Iraq's failing economy, undermined by the long war with Iran. So he has put his unemployed, million-man army back to work, both to grab his neighbor's oilfields and refineries and also to panic the world oil market into a steep run-up in price. The rising inflow of foreign money, he calculated, would strengthen his bid for dominance of the Arab world.

title: Critic's Choice
description: Vivaldi's unassuming ''Four Seasons'' has become the very emblem of crass commercialization in classical music. In listener polls, broadcasters report, the concerto cycle ranks second only to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, and since it is handily separable into bite-size units, it constitutes the cornerstone of ever smaller, safer ''play lists.''

title: Steinbrenner Is Growing Unhappy With Deal, Signs Suggest
description: There are signs that George Steinbrenner is becoming increasingly unhappy with the agreement he struck with Fay Vincent and may be heading for an even bigger clash with the commissioner of baseball.

title: Review/Photography;   Focusing on Models Who Embodied Inspiration
description: In a season of mostly humdrum group shows, the James Danziger Gallery has focused on an inspired theme: inspiration itself. Specifically, the exhibition proposes that in the case of photography, inspiration can take corporal form. The seven photographers represented in the show, titled ''Photographers' Muses,'' have each photographed a single model with an obsessive dedication that, in the best of cases, seems akin to love.

title: Emanuel Gets Chance As Giants Fullback
description: When Aaron Emanuel was in high school, he was such a good running back that he seemed ready to skip college and the pros and head right for the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Ready, Set, Trade Those Barrels!
description: Lately, the days in the oil trading room at Conoco Inc. here start with the intensity of a space shuttle launching combined with a horse race. A voice over a loudspeaker counts down the seconds to the opening, and in staccato fashion reels off the buy and sell orders.

title: A Turnaround Manager To Head Jos. A. Bank
description: Timothy F. Finley, a turnaround manager, has been named president and chief executive of Jos. A. Bank Clothiers Inc., which operates 40 retail clothing stores throughout the United States and is known for its American-made men's suits.

title: 17 Con Ed Employees Charged in Briberies
description: Seventeen employees of Con Edison were charged yesterday with extorting payoffs and obtaining bribes from customers and contractors to expedite service, improperly reduce rates and overlook safety hazards.

title: Dorothy Gillam Baker, Educator, 84
description: Dorothy Gillam Baker, a scholar and educator who researched patterns of development in world history, died on Aug. 3 at Albert Einstein Hospital in the Bronx. She was 84 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Lorenzo, Head of Continental Air, Quits Industry in $30 Million Deal
description: Frank Lorenzo, whose bitter fights with unions and appetite for acquisitions did much to reshape the airline industry, is leaving the business. After receiving a surprisingly high offer for his holdings, he said yesterday that he is stepping down as chairman of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., formerly the Texas Air Corporation, and selling his stock to the Scandinavian Airline System.

title: Market Place;   A Good Deal? Yes, for Lorenzo
description: In walking away from the tottering airline empire he created, Frank Lorenzo has arranged a far better deal for himself than is available to other shareholders.

title: Richard Styskal, 53, CUNY Center Deputy
description: Richard A. Styskal, deputy director of the Center for Labor-Management Policy Studies at the City University of New York, died on Sunday. He was 53 years old and lived in Mountainside, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: One Millimeter Off

title: Auctions
description: 3 houses in London to sell rock memorabilia, including Presley's library card and first driver's license and much from the Beatles. Going by the collected wisdom of 1960's rock songs, summer is a time for surfing, romance, street-fighting or just getting gritty on the city streets. Songwriters seem not to have caught on yet, but in the last decade summer has also turned into a hot time for buying and selling rock-and-roll memorabilia. Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips usually hold their largest rock auctions in August or September in London. This year, Sotheby's has scheduled its sale for Aug. 21, and Phillips will hold its auction on Aug. 22. Christie's is devoting a Sept. 21 sale entirely to items related to ''Pink Floyd -The Wall,'' the 1982 Alan Parker film based on Pink Floyd's 1979 rock opera. Some of the celluloids, concept drawings and pastels from the sale can be seen at Christie's East in New York, 219 East 67th Street, from Aug. 28 to Aug. 31, and at Christie's in Beverly Hills, 342 North Rodeo Drive, from Sept. 4 to Sept. 6.

title: Edward F. Buxton, Ad Executive, 73
description: Edward F. Buxton, an author and advertising executive, died on Tuesday at New England Memorial Hospital in Boston. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Film;   A Jake Gittes Who's Older (And Wider)
description: Anybody can begin a movie. It's what happens from the mid-point on that separates the men from the boys.

title: Study Offers Hope for Reducing Assault Injuries
description: Perpetrators of family violence often have records of repeated violence, a new Federal study shows, leading researchers to suggest that people at high risk could be identified. This would allow the development of strategies to prevent the assaults, significantly reducing injury and death, the researchers said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAYNE TORVILL and CHRISTOPHER DEAN, the British Olympic ice-dancing champions, are engaged, but not to each other.

title: Review/Film;   Young Doctors Explore the Boundary Between Life and Death
description: There is no innocence in the world of ''Flatliners'' - not in childhood memories, not in the motives of the medical students who push themselves beyond death and then return to life, not in the film's borrowings from classic horror movies. And all of that is to the good. ''Flatliners'' is a stylish, eerie psychological horror film laced with wit, a movie that thrives on its characters' guilty secrets and succeeds on the strength of the director Joel Schumacher's flair for just this sort of smart, unpretentious entertainment.

title: Dow, Rising For 2d Day, Ends Up 24.01
description: Stocks advanced yesterday for the second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 24.01 points to 2,758.91. Favorable results of the Treasury's 30-year bond auction produced a late rally after stocks had drifted in light trading most of the day.

title: What '9-Year-Old Shot in Head' Means;   They Prefer Handguns
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Shift At Intergroup
description: National Intergroup Inc. said today that Centaur Partners L.P. had won the vote on July 25 to put three directors on its 10-member board.

title: KEY RATES
Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From King Fahd's Speech to Saudis
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia today, broadcast by Saudi television and translated by the British Broadcasting Corporation:

title: Robert Synes, Game Show Producer, 58
description: Robert Synes, a producer and writer of television game shows, died Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 58 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JENNIFER CAPRIATI, the 14-year-old tennis player who turned professional only six months ago, is scheduled to play in the New York area for the first time since she charmed Wimbledon in July. Jennifer lost there to STEFFI GRAF, but is ranked 13th among women players.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   ISRAELIS TEST FIRE A DEFENSE MISSILE
description: Israel conducted its first test of the Arrow air-defense missile today in a clear response to an Iraqi threat on Wednesday to attack Israel with chemical weapons.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Oil Jolt

title: CHRONICLE
description: MEL GIBSON, exhausted from playing the title role in FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI's film of ''Hamlet,'' says he is taking a break after working in four movies back to back.

title: A Voyage to Italy, as Seen in Postwar Cinema
description: A dank, sunless morning. A distracted young woman with the features of a high-fashion model (Monica Vitti) walks along the bank of a ship canal. She holds the hand of her small son, pulling him along as if he were a wooden duck on wheels. She is distracted, but she looks terrific, her dark reddish-blond hair set off by the soft green of her cloth coat, which is, of course, couture.

title: Midway Airlines' St. Louis Routes
description: The Chicago-based Midway Airlines, which offered service between Midway Airport in Chicago and Lambert Field here from 1980 through 1984, will re-enter the St. Louis market starting on Oct. 1. With five round-trip flights a day, Midway could fill a gap created by Trans World Airlines Inc., which is rumored to be planning to pull out of Midway at the end of September.

title: Janet Nevins Young, Executive, 61
description: Janet Nevins Young, the executive director of the Van Hornesville (N.Y.) Community Corporation and a former insurance industry executive, died on Tuesday at her home in Van Hornesville. She was 61 years old. She died of cancer, a nephew said. Mrs. Young was a personnel manager for the Equitable Life Assurance Society and for the Mutual of New York Insurance Company for 20 years. In 1971, she married Richard Young, an international lawyer, and moved to Van Hornesville, near Cooperstown, where she revitalized the nonprofit community corporation. She obtained grants to restore several buildings in the community.

title: Johnson Permitted
description: To Run for Canada Ben Johnson, who lost his Olympic gold medal and 100-meter world record after testing positive for steroids at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, was given Government clearance yesterday to run again for Canada.

title: Polaroid to Build $90 Million Plant
description: The Polaroid Corporation said it planned to build a $90 million plant in New Bedford, Mass., to make advanced films for its new electronic imaging system called Helios. The plant is expected to be operating in late 1992, and it will create more than 100 jobs. Polaroid's president and chief executive, I. MacAllister Booth, said the $90 million would be the company's largest plant investment ever.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   After the Arguments: Jogger Jury Weighs a Jumble of Details
description: After all the witnesses are gone and all the arguments are finished, big court cases often hang on fragments - bits of jumbled facts and incomplete memories - that jurors fix on to test a theory or a witness's account as they try to decide what really happened.

title: U.S. Files Suit Against Georgia, Charging Bias in Election Laws
description: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today challenging Georgia's election system, which requires candidates to participate in a runoff if none receive 50 percent of the vote in primary elections.

title: A Minor Player Gets Major Hit
description: Kelvin Torve, a 10-year minor league veteran, made his first National League hit count - a game-winning, pinch-hit double.

title: Outdoors;   Contestants Set Creations Afloat
description: YOU will have to scramble a bit - the deadline for submitting an entry form is Monday - if you wish to take part in the River Project's annual instant boat contest. This year the contest will be Aug. 25-26, and even if you don't wish to participate, you might enjoy watching the zany event.

title: Curbs Due on Rackets at Fish Market
description: On the heels of a warning by a Federal administrator that racketeers still control the Fulton Fish Market, New York City officials said yesterday that they have a plan for ''comprehensive reform.'' But they said they would withhold details of the plan for about 30 days.

title: Review/Design;   Demure to Demystified, Swimsuits' Hall of Fame
description: It's often said that every picture tells a story, but, in fact, so do many objects, especially when similar ones are grouped in an orderly profusion. ''Splash: A History of Swim Wear,'' a sometimes surrealistic exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology, deploys just such order and profusion in behalf of that essential modern invention, the swimming suit. It does this with a combination of verve, thoughtfulness and visual delight that has become standard fare at the institute in New York City.

title: F.B.I. Settles Black Agent's Suit on Race Bias
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has settled a lawsuit by a black agent who complained that he was a victim of racial discrimination.

title: Military Takes Part in Drug Sweep And Reaps Criticism and a Lawsuit
description: In the first use of active-duty troops to fight marijuana growing in the United States, a contingent of about 200 Army soldiers, National Guardsmen and Federal agents have spent the past two weeks raiding clandestine marijuana gardens in the rugged terrain of the King Range National Conservation Area.

title: 'Roman Holiday' Festival Schedule
description: ''A Roman Holiday: Masterworks of Italian Cinema from Neo-Realism to the Present'' will run through Aug. 26 at Alice Tully Hall. Single tickets to each program are $5.50 ($4.50 each for orders of eight or more tickets). Information: 877-1800, extension 492 or 562. Here is a schedule.

title: Judge Rejects Defense Claim In Central Park Jogger Case
description: The judge in the Central Park jogger trial told the jury yesterday that contrary to defense assertions, the law did not necessarily require parents to be present for the questioning of the three youthful defendants.

title: Ms. Messinger's Obstructionism
description: Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger's veto of a Columbia University plan to build on the site of the old Audubon Ballroom could hasten the decline of a deteriorating community and leave those who want to honor Malcolm X, murdered in the ballroom 25 years ago, with nothing but a building in ruins.

title: Fierce Fighting Erupts Near Monrovia
description: Liberian rebels fought fierce gun battles with the Government army today as they pushed through the suburbs of the capital, Monrovia.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day last Friday misstated the corporate affiliation of Cluett, Peabody & Company. It was acquired by Bidermann Industries from West Point-Pepperell Inc. in March.

title: Restaurants
description: Consistent fare from the north of India, with some scorchers from elsewhere thrown in.

title: Six Accused In $3.7 Million Insider Case
description: Government lawyers in New York and Washington yesterday accused a former associate at a prominent New York law firm, his sister and four others of earning at least $3.75 million from illegal insider trading from 1984 to 1988.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   News Organizations Angry at the Lack of a Press Pool
description: Many of the nation's news organizations expressed frustration and dismay yesterday that a pool of journalists has not been allowed to accompany American troops as they move into position inside Saudi Arabia.

title: Ms. Wiener Weds Richard S. Biegen
description: Deborah Ruth Wiener, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joel H. Wiener of Teaneck, N.J., was married last evening to Richard Scott Biegen, a son of Dr. Elaine Biegen of Whitestone, Queens, and Arnold Biegen of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the Water's Edge at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Bills Sign Holloway
description: Brian Holloway, the former Pro Bowl offensive lineman, has come out of retirement and signed a contract with the Buffalo Bills, the team announced yesterday.

title: Kremlin Softens Its Threat to Armenia
description: The Soviet Government has agreed not to send troops into the republic of Armenia to disarm militant groups that have refused to surrender their weapons, the newly elected nationalist President of the republic said today.

title: Toyota and GKN Pact
description: GKN P.L.C. said this week that it had an exclusive order to supply constant-velocity driveshafts to the Toyota Motor Corporation for Toyota's new passenger car to be built in Britain. The car will be built at Toyota's new plant in Derbyshire in central England. Initial output is expected to be 100,000 vehicles annually, rising to 200,000 at full capacity.

title: Amid the Antiques, a Zinc Woman and Fish Decoys
description: Charles Miller and his 18th-, 19th- and 20th-century European and American furniture travel to some 30 antique shows every year, crossing the country from Maine and Florida to California. This weekend, Mr. Miller, whose firm, Miller Hamilton & Company, is in Chapel Hill, N.C., is in Long Island for the third edition of the Southampton Antiques Show, to be held at the Southampton campus of Long Island University.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Home Section yesterday about the gardens at Gracie Mansion misattributed a quotation. It was Maureen Hackett, the mansion's gardener, who said, ''A lot of guests never leave the porch, so this view across the lawn of flower color seen against the river is important.''

title: Chrysler Delay On Luxury Car
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which has said its financial problems would not hurt new-product development, said today that it would delay the development of its LX luxury car program.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising-ADDENDA;   Miscellany
description: * GGK Holding A.G., the Swiss holding company that is a joint owner of the New York advertising agency Lois/GGK, has formed a partnership with Trimedia Group A.G., a holding company in Zurich. The new company will hold 100 percent of GGK and 65 percent of Trimedia. The sale is not expected to cause any changes at Lois/GGK.

title: Review/Art;   Duality of the Divine, In an Unlikely Setting
description: The centerpiece of the wonderful hodgepodge that is the summer show at the Salander-O'Reilly Galleries is a surprise. This gallery, which specializes in 20th-century art, has put on display ''Christ on the Cross'' by Francisco de Zurbaran, the 17th-century Spanish painter whose finely cut, firmly modeled, sculptural figures, bathed in bright light and black darkness, have appealed to a host of modern artists.

title: The Siege of Iraq
description: President Bush has skillfully orchestrated a two-pronged response to Iraq's occupation of tiny Kuwait. He has dispatched American military forces to prevent the Iraqi divisions from pushing on to occupy Saudi Arabia's oilfields. And he has led the worldwide economic effort to choke off Saddam Hussein's oil exports and force him to withdraw from Kuwait.

title: Soviet Lake Offers Look at Evolution
description: Scientists probing the depths of Lake Baikal in the Soviet Union have discovered heat escaping from cracks in the lake bottom to support rich communities of exotic life, much like those around hydrothermal vents in the midocean ridges. It is the first time such a phenomenon has been found in fresh water.

title: Home-Equity Loans Get Unfair Tax Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Electronics Executive Surrenders on Charges
description: The president of a Tampa electronics company surrendered to the Federal authorities here today on charges that he sold substandard electronic parts to the Government that wound up in missiles and the space shuttle program.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Families of Americans Held in Iraq Wait, Hope and Tie Yellow Ribbons
description: At the Walterscheid home in the tiny town of Jacksboro, Tex., the trees are festooned with yellow ribbons. Family members give directions to the house by telling visitors to turn left at the trees with the big yellow bows.

title: Some Oil Companies Cut Prices
description: Several major oil companies cut or froze their wholesale gasoline prices yesterday. Others said that any price increases would be reasonable. And all the companies that made statements vigorously defended their pricing practices, which have come under strong criticism from consumers, who have faced sharp price rises at gasoline pumps in the last week.

title: Prices Jump in Peru, and the Protest Is Swift
description: The 13-day-old Government of President Alberto Fujimori has announced a 3,000 percent increase in gasoline prices and huge food price increases as part of a drastic austerity plan.

title: Money (But Not The Lawyers', or The Nation's) Dominates Talk at The Bar Convention
description: On the official docket of the American Bar Association's annual meeting here this week, item No. 1 was abortion rights. But amid the tinkling piano bars in the hotel atriums, alongside the canapes and crudites at the receptions, another monomania prevailed: What in the Sam Hill happened to Stan Chauvin's cash? And what was he doing carrying all that loot around?

title: Keating and Five Associates Sued by Savings Regulator
description: Savings and loan regulators announced today that the Government was suing Charles H. Keating Jr. and five business associates, including Keating family members, to recover $40.9 million in depositors' funds from the defunct Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, will redeem on Sept. 10 all of its outstanding 9.25 percent fixed-rate notes due Sept. 10, 1992, which were issued in 1987. The notes will be redeemed at 100 percent of the principal amount, with interest accrued up to Sept. 10 of $46.25 per $1,000 principal amount.

title: Gulf Crisis: Wide Effects
description: IRAQI TROOPS MOVE As an intelligence report said tens of thousands of Iraqi troops were moving toward Kuwait and the Iraqi-Saudi border, American officials said it would take a month to deploy the United States force in Saudi Arabia. Page A8.

title: Results Plus
description: BASKETBALL

title: Washington Talk;   Iraq Puts Election Truisms To Test
description: All the uncertainty in the Persian Gulf has insured at least one thing at home: this fall's elections, which weeks ago seemed but a hodgepodge of races with little national focus, will now revolve heavily around the economy as it sags under the burden of rising oil prices.

title: Bad Hop in 10th Helps Expos Trim Pirates
description: Andres Galarraga scored from second base in the 10th inning on Mike Fitzgerald's bad-hop grounder when Don Slaught did not cover home plate to give the Montreal Expos a 7-6 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Trinidad Rebels to Be Charged
description: Charges of treason and murder will be brought against 114 members of the Muslim group that sought to oust the Trinidad and Tobago Government, the police said today. The Muslims, including a 14-year-old boy, face the death penalty if convicted.

title: Zoning Variances of the Rich and Famous
description: In Hollywood, Alec Baldwin, the blue-eyed star of ''The Hunt for Red October,'' is a major celebrity, the kind of person who attracts gawkers and swooning teen-agers whenever he steps outside. Here in East Hampton, he is just another homeowner who might not be allowed to build an addition to his house.

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday about the arrival of a Middle Eastern ambassador for a White House meeting misidentified him. He was Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah of Kuwait.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   As U.S. Forces Build, a Military Stalemate Shapes Up
description: As American forces pour into Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf, there are signs that a military stalemate between Iraq and the United States is rapidly developing.

title: Long-Term Securities Rebound
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities rebounded strongly yesterday after the Government's successful auction of $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds, the last of its record $32.25 billion quarterly refunding sales this week.

title: More Airlines Raise Fares
description: More airlines raised their fares today, and an industry spokesman attributed the increases to fuel prices that ''have gone through the roof.''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

President Is Replaced In Shake-Up at Thrifty
description: LEAD: Pacific Enterprises, a Los Angeles-based utility, has shaken up the management of its Thrifty Corporation subsidiary, a struggling chain of 1,070 retail stores, naming Daniel A. Seigel to replace Richard G. Eils as president.

title: Perez Has Surgery
description: Pascual Perez, the Yankee pitcher who signed a three-year, $5.7 million contract and then pitched just 14 innings this season, underwent surgery on his right shoulder today in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Court Sets Terms for Whites Adopting Black
description: A referee in Hamilton County Court has ordered that a white family seeking to adopt its black foster child undergo education on black culture as a prelude to legally adopting the girl.

title: Hall of Fame Inducts 7, Led by John Henry
description: With almost every living jockey and trainer enshrined in racing's Hall of Fame looking on, two trainers, a jockey and four horses were inducted into the Hall this morning at the national Museum of Racing on Union Avenue.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   No Oil Emergency Yet, Energy Officials Assert
description: With oil markets still jittery today, the industrial world's senior energy officials sought to reassure the industry and investors that there were sufficient oil supplies worldwide.

title: TV Weekend;   2 Generations of Rusks On Vietnam and Its Toll
description: Tonight's edition of ''20/20'' goes to Athens, Ga., for an account of the reconciliation of Dean Rusk, the former Secretary of State, and his son, Richard, after years of division over the elder Rusk's role in the Vietnam War. The program, at 10 o'clock on ABC, does not go deeply into the reconciliation, which began in 1985; the occasion for dealing with it now seems to be the recent publication of ''As I Saw It,'' which Dean Rusk wrote with his son's assistance.

title: Earl R. Zack, Pyschologist, 77
description: Dr. Earl R. Zack, a psychologist and an educator, died yesterday in Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 77 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Barry Guilty on One Drug Count; Mistral is Declared on Felonies
description: The jury in the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. convicted him today of one misdemeanor count of drug possession and acquitted him of another misdemeanor drug charge. But it failed to reach a verdict on the 12 remaining charges, including the most serious ones.

title: No Vacancy in Eden
description: The Seychelles, 115 islands in the Indian Ocean, has glorious birds, glorious fish, glorious scenery and only one building taller than a coconut palm. Its economy is built on beauty, and the islanders don't want to see it lost to the tramp, tramp, tramp of tourists' feet.

title: U.S. Will Allow Press To Go With Troops
description: The Defense Department said today that it would allow a group of journalists to accompany American troops to Saudi Arabia. The first group of 12 to 15 reporters and photographers is scheduled to leave for Saudi Arabia this weekend.

title: PC Etcetera Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coslet Takes the Offensive in Jets Debut
description: Ready or not, Bruce Coslet will bring a new style to the Jets' sideline Saturday night when they open their exhibition season in Philadelphia.

title: Bando McGlocklin Capital reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pogo Producing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Your Money
description: For people who are afraid of the risk that investing in stocks entails - as are many, given the events of the last week and a half - but who want to share in the market's potential for appreciation, zero-coupon convertible bonds offer an answer.

title: Del Taco Restaurants Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Ultimate Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Figures for 1989 have been reclassified to conform with fiscal 1991 results.

title: Fuel Trading Calmer as Hectic Week Ends
description: The prices dealers are paying for gasoline fluctuated modestly yesterday, according to oil company officials, but the price of crude oil and gasoline edged up in the futures markets on bellicose statements from the Middle East.

title: British Star Talks of Racial Harmony And Disillusionment With Equity
description: Jonathan Pryce seemed remarkably calm for someone at the center of an international theatrical incident. But over breakfast Thursday he discussed his disillusionment about American Equity's decision not to let him recreate his London role of a Eurasian pimp in ''Miss Saigon'' on Broadway.

title: Deliberations Were Earnest and Cordial, Jury Says
description: Jurors in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said tonight that despite their inability to reach a verdict on 12 of 14 charges, their deliberations were cordial, earnest and apparently free of racial strife.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about Soviet-Japanese diplomacy incorrectly characterized a planned visit to Tokyo next month by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. It will not be the first visit since World War II by a Soviet official of that level; Mr. Shevardnadze went to Tokyo in 1986.

title: Chavez on Tyson Card
description: Julio Cesar Chavez, the World Boxing Council-International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champion, will defend his titles against Kyungduk Ahn of South Korea on Sept. 22 in Atlantic City. The bout will be a co-feature on a card headlined by the heavyweight bout between Mike Tyson and Alex Stewart. It will take place at the Convention Center, adjoining Trump Plaza.

title: Hana Biologics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said net income in 1990 included both a gain of $12,756,000 on the sale of the company's cell biology and diagnostic product lines, and an expense of $1,640,000 from reorganization.

title: A Few More Refugees Reach the Saudi Border
description: Braving scorching August heat and other risks of the open desert in rugged all-terrain vehicles, a trickle of Americans and other foreign nationals continued yesterday to reach the relative calm of Saudi Arabia in a series of daring escapes from war-torn Kuwait.

title: Comdata Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results in the latest quarter included a previously announced non- compete obligation arising from an acquisition in 1989 that was prepaid in June. It resulted in a special second- quarter charge of about $23 million. Results in the latest second quarter also included the amortization of the non-compete obligation prior to its prepayment, the write-down of certain equipment, and the write-off of other intangible assets.

title: Kinnard Investments reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books of the Times;   A Rights Crusader On His Home Ground
description: Black in Selma

title: Equity Plans to Meet on Thursday
description: Actors' Equity announced yesterday that it would meet on Thursday to re-evaluate its decision not to let the English actor Jonathan Pryce appear on Broadway in ''Miss Saigon,'' the hit musical in which he is starring in London. In rejecting Mr. Pryce, Equity had said it could not ''appear to condone the casting of a Caucasian in the role of a Eurasian.''

title: Wildfires Force Closing of Yosemite Park; 10,000 Evacuated
description: A siege of hot weather and electrical storms have produced the worst wildfires of the year in the West, leading to the closing of Yosemite National Park and the evacuation of many small communities.

title: Giants Sign Carthon To 3-Year Contract
description: The Giants corraled one of their many missing bodies today. Maurice Carthon, their starting fullback for most of the last five years, signed a three-year contract worth an estimated $1.575 million, including a signing bonus.

title: 2 U.S. Premieres in Merkin Hall Season
description: The American premieres of Sir Harrison Birtwistle's ''Ritual Fragment'' and Handel's opera ''Siroe,'' a concert performance of Rameau's ''Castor et Pollux'' and a four-concert ''American Folk'' series are to be part of the Merkin Concert Hall 1990-91 season.

title: U.A.W. Turns Down 2 Chrysler Proposals
description: The United Automobile Workers union has rejected proposals that would give workers a stake in the financially struggling Chrysler Corporation and would establish a new way to figure profit sharing, a U.A.W. official said today.

title: Homosexuality Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Intercontinental Life reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflected 3-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 15.

title: Colonial Commercial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Columbia Hospital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said figures for the latest quarter included results of Smith Laboratories Inc. and its subsidiary, Sutter Corp., only since May 16, the date they acquired Smith Labs through an exchange offer.

title: Lin Broadcasting Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NuVision Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago 6-month sales figures have been restated.

title: Triton Canada Resources reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $5.5 million from sale of gas-gathering assets to Transwest Gas Systems Ltd. c-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Dakota Town Shaken by 250,000-Biker Rally
description: In a few days, when the thunder fades and the earth stops shaking, the people of this small town in the Black Hills will raise the window shades and peek outside their doors again.

title: Mortgage Rates Jump
description: Fixed-rate mortgages jumped into the double digits for the first time in a month and averaged 10.08 percent this week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The rate was up from 9.84 percent last week and was the highest since mortgage costs averaged 10.11 percent for the week that ended on July 13.

title: Turbo Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included unusual charges of $700,000 for the quarter and $1.5 million for the 6 months, stemming from previously-announced cost-cutting program, including staff reductions. c-Net loss Share earnings for latest 6 months were nil. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Bradley Real Estate Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
British Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. Results are in U.S. dollars; results have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.75 to the pound, the rate prevailing on June 30, 1990, the last date of the reporting period and the year-earlier results at an exchange rate of $1.55 to the pound, the rate prevailing on June 30.

title: Seattle Filmworks reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected after-tax gain of about $264,000, or 14 cents a share, from settlement of lawsuit in the second quarter of fiscal 1989.

title: Mets Take First as Fernandez Regains Form
description: The Mets may not exactly have solved the mystery of Sid Fernandez last night, but they absolutely unraveled part of it when the laid-back left-hander rose from the ruins of two short and brutal losses and pitched a classic three-hitter over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Sico Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Indians in Kashmir Shoot 12 Who Entered From Pakistan
description: Indian border guards shot and killed 12 Muslim separatists today who had crossed over from neighboring Pakistan to campaign for independence of the disputed territory of Kashmir, the police reported.

title: Foundation Health Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Grady Takes One-Shot Lead After 2d Round of P.G.A.
description: The frustration level rose in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship today as the world's best golfers couldn't keep the ensnaring rough of the Shoal Creek Country Club course from getting under their skin.

title: Edberg Defeats Chang to Gain Semifinal and No. 1 Ranking
description: In the summer of 1988, Stefan Edberg of Sweden received a false alarm in the ranking department.

title: William R. Moseley Dies at 75; Led a Major Munitions Supplier
description: William R. Moseley, retired chief executive of Day & Zimmermann Inc., a major Government munitions supplier, died last Sunday at a nursing home in Springfield Township, Pa. He was 75 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Patents;   Getting the Smoke Out Of a Building on Fire
description: A retired engineer who supervised much of the design and construction of San Francisco's subway system during the 1970's has drawn on that experience to invent an emergency ventilation system to remove smoke from burning buildings.

title: St. Joe Paper Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represents net sales and operating revenue. Results for 1989 have been restated to reflect a change in the accounting for certain expenses arising out of the company's transportation and real estate operations. Share earnings for the latest and year-ago 6 months have been adjusted to give effect to a 350-for-1 stock split and change in par value effected March 22, 1990.

title: Sunshine Mining Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Griffin Resorts Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings for the 6 months were not available.

title: Leucadia National reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $17,264,000 for the quarter and $17,050,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,506,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,528,000, or 18 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: First World Cheese Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chase Program To Cut Payroll
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has embarked on its previously announced cost-cutting program by offering employees with more than 10 years' experience a package of benefits for early retirement.

title: Donald R. Heiges, 80, A Lutheran Educator
description: The Rev. Dr. Donald R. Heiges, a former president of two Lutheran seminaries, died yesterday at the Lutheran Retirement Village in Gettysburg, Pa. He was 80 years old. A funeral home spokesman said Dr. Heiges died of cardiomyopathy, a disease of the muscular tissue of the heart.

title: E.G&G. Sets Deal With TI Group
description: E.G.&G. Inc. said it had agreed to sell its fluid components technology group to TI Group P.L.C. for $240 million in cash, subject to regulatory clearances. The business had revenues of $180 million in 1989.

title: G.M. Announces Price Increases
description: The General Motors Corporation said pre-introductory prices of 1991 model-year passenger cars will reflect price increases averaging 1.9 percent over comparably equipped 1990 models. It said the increase will provide for partial recovery of higher costs related to health-care and production costs. Destination charges will remain unchanged from 1990 levels.

title: Finevest Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Madison Gas & Electric reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Brenda Mines Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Electro-Sensors Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNR Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,681,665 and $2,675,235 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $109,619,174 for both periods. The company said net income comparisons between 1990 and 1989 are not meaningful because 1989 results included asbestos insurance recoveries of $45.5 million and a reorganization charge of $109.6 million. The company also said its 1989 results reflected bankruptcy related costs of $2,100,000 in the quarter and $3,200,000 in the 6 months.

title: Argentine Deaths Bring Focus on Health Care
description: The recent deaths of about 30 patients in a state-run women's psychiatric hospital - from malnutrition, the hospital union says - has focused attention on the virtual collapse of Argentina's health-care system.

title: They Had Ice Cream Every Friday
description: Jerry Holtzman - Jerome Holtzman to the readers of his baseball column in The Chicago Tribune - grew up, like many of us, in a house with kids. Unlike the homes of many of us, the house contained 300 kids, about 150 boys and 150 girls. It was on the West Side of Chicago, and called the Marks Nathan Jewish Orphan Home.

title: Witness's Wife Finds Bomb; Bail in Mafia Case Is Altered
description: The wife of a crucial witness in a major Mafia case received a threatening telephone call and found a bomb in her car this week, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday at a court hearing in Brooklyn.

title: Trion Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results for latest periods included an inventory adjustment of $350,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Healthco Holding Raised by Group
description: An investment group that includes members of the Bass family of Fort Worth has raised its stake in Healthco International Inc., a Boston-based distributor of dental equipment, to 7.2 percent from 5.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group did not amend its previous statement that it supports Healthco management's efforts to seek to maximize shareholder value.

title: Rain Delays U.S. Amateur
description: The semifinals of the United States Women's Amateur Championship were washed out today because heavy rains made the Canoe Brook Country Club course unplayable. Pat Hurst of San Leandro, Calif., who on Thursday eliminated the defending champion, Vicki Goetze of Hull, Ga., will oppose Delphine Bourson of France in the first semifinal Saturday beginning at 10 A.M.

title: Milwaukee Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Great American CommunicaFtions reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After income from discontinued operations, which represent earnings from the company's insurance subsidiary which was sold in September 1989, of $2,182,000 and $3,904,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary losses on retirement of debt of $383,000 for the quarter and $805,000 for the 6 months.

title: RESULTS PLUS;
description: TENNIS

title: F.B.I. Clarifies Comment on Files
description: The spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who speculated on Thursday that abuse of the bureau's computerized crime files was quite common clarified his assessment yesterday after checking with officials in charge of the files, known as the National Crime Information Center.

title: 10 Federal Judges Agree on Plan To Consolidate Asbestos Lawsuits
description: Frustrated by the wave of costly and slowly resolved asbestos cases, 10 Federal district judges with the heaviest caseloads agreed today on how to consolidate tens of thousands of cases clogging dockets around the nation.

title: Mexico Doesn't Need Lectures on Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Philippines Uses Foreign Assistance Well
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $410,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: Long-Term Bond Prices Off Sharply
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds were battered yesterday as traders and investment managers sought to hedge their portfolios for the weekend.

title: At Nursing Homes, They're for Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Gitano Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Political Rivals Jockey in Phnom Penh
description: Asked several months ago about the position of Hun Sen, the young and highly visible Cambodian Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, a Cambodian official smiled broadly. ''Don't forget Hun Sen is only No. 3 in the party,'' he said. ''Chea Sim is No. 2.''

title: Patents;   Preventing Facial Rash From Shaves
description: A dermatologist and pharmacist in Houston, Milton D. Moore, has patented a treatment to prevent the painful facial rashes that afflict men who shave coarse or curly hair.

title: Mentor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a one-time after-tax gain of $90,000 for an accounting adjustment. Mentor said that an increase in operating income was partially offset by the financing costs of the April acquisition of Mentor O&O.

title: Copley Properties reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Music;   Five Decades Old but Up to Date
description: It would be foolish to venture grandiose conclusions about the state of new Western classical music from the offerings of any of the annual Tanglewood Festivals of Contemporary Music. This is just one festival, after all, with one set of calculations - esthetic, historical, cultural and political - about how to make up representative programs.

title: Tornado Hits Staten Island, Uprooting Trees
description: A tornado born of a waterspout swirling in lower New York Harbor spun ashore in southeastern Staten Island yesterday afternoon, toppling dozens of trees, popping out windows and dispatching debris through the air and garbage pails down the streets.

title: Gasoline Costs: A Psychological Toll
description: Motorists - which is to say, almost everyone - are howling over the recent increases in gasoline prices. But with shifts in energy use in the time since the last oil shock, the public is focusing on what is most visible, but not most damaging.

title: Review/Pop;   The Unpredictable Aretha Franklin
description: Near the end of her concert Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall, Aretha Franklin sat down at the piano and riffled up and down in surging gospel arpeggios. She eased the style toward the blues and began to sing in a husky voice, toying with phrases and answering her voice with piano filigree, building toward the importunate, lusty climax of ''Dr. Feelgood.''

title: Cambridge Bioscience reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included estimated $1.5 million expense associated with proposed merger with Biotech Research Laboratories Inc. for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Lewis Iselin, 77, Dies; Sculptor of Portraits
description: Lewis Iselin, a sculptor known for his portraits and other figurative works, died Friday at his home in Camden, Me. His wife, the former Sally Cary Curtis, said he died of cancer. Mr. Iselin was 77 years old.

title: The Scorecard: Bumps, Bruises and Hot Heads
description: On the day after their free-for-all with the Philadelphia Phillies in Shea Stadium, the Mets had bumps, bruises, claw marks, one lineup casualty and hostile feelings. But so far they had no fines or suspensions from the National League office, which said no punishment for either team was likely until Monday.

title: Chain-Snatcher Killed by Police Had Jail Record
description: The 24-year-old Bronx man who was killed by a transit police officer on Thursday was a small-time marijuana dealer who had a history of snatching gold chains on the subway and fighting with police officers when they tried to arrest him, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Jazz;   Alto Saxophonist Leads Improvisation
description: It usually takes a jazz group the first few days of a weeklong stand to loosen up, to find the sort of improvisational empathy that defines a good performance. Not so with the alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe's group, which came out fighting at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night, and on Thursday was playing with the excitement and spontaneity that's normally heard only toward the end of an engagement.

title: Dillard Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
One Liberty Properties reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Guidepost;   Plugging In, Paying Out
description: Every time you flip on a light or an appliance, you're buying electricity. Each customer's use varies, of course, but on May 1, the average monthly bill for a Long Island Lighting Company residential customer was $83 for 600 kilowatt hours of electricity. Lilco's and Con Edison's rates are among the highest in the country, so the averages for other areas would have been lower. This is what $83 bought. $ Appliance Monthly Cost 4 hours a day of a 6,500 B.T.U. air-conditioner (8.5 efficiency rating) $12.29 18 cubic foot refrigerator-freezer 15.96 7 hours a day for two television sets 8.13 30 loads of laundry (washing and drying) 12.14 15 uses of a dishwasher 2.06 Lighting a six-room house 10.64 30 oven-cooked meals 6.08 10 hours of microwave oven use 1.93 150 hours of stereo and radio 1.72 8 hours each of blow-drying and ironing 2.53 30 hours each of VCR and computer use 1.52 60 slices of toast and 30 pots of coffee 1.16 4 hours of vacuuming .39 150 hours of ceiling fan use 1.50 2 hours a day of dehumidifier use 4.95 $83.00

France prepared on Friday to bolster its Persian Gulf force to seven ships.

title: Last Stand for the Adirondacks?
description: Any map of the Eastern United States shows it laced with roads -parks and wild lands appear as lonely green islands. Just about the only exception is in northern New York, where the Adirondack Park covers an area the size of Yosemite, Yellowstone, Glacier and Grand Canyon National Parks combined. The Adirondacks are not green by accident. A century ago they were brown, clear-cut for timber. But strong state action has nursed them back to health, turning them into a second-chance wilderness.

title: Bridge

title: Bryan Holme, Author And Publisher, 78
description: Bryan Holme, an author and retired publisher of photographic and art books, died Wednesday at his summer home in Round Pond, Me. He was 78 years old and also lived in Vero Beach, Fla. His son, Christopher, said his father had died of kidney failure. Mr. Holme had been the head of Studio Books, a subsidiary of Viking Press based in Manhattan. For three generations his family had published The Studio, a London art magazine founded by his grandfather.

title: Amid Turmoil, Tankers Are Sent to Iran for Oil

title: Ravenna
description: To the Editor: Joan Gould's otherwise lovely article on the mosaics of Ravenna (Travel, June 10) misstated the Arian heresy. The point at issue between the Arians and the Orthodox in the fourth to sixth centuries was not whether Jesus was fully human or a god who merely appeared to be human. Both sides in the controversy condsidered Him fully human and our fellow sufferer; the idea that he only appeared to be human was a characteristic of several other heretical groups, Gnostics, Apollinarians and Monophysites, each in their own way. The controversy in Arianism was about whether Jesus was fully God: was He the incarnation of the actual Creator of the universe, or was He a demigod created by the original God, and hence inferior to God in divinity? The Orthodox believed in Jesus' full divinity as well as His full humanity, a position Christians are supposed to take to this very day; the Arians saw Him as a divine intermediary, and thus believed in a God and a half. This did have great political implications, but it was not a matter of Arian equality vs. Orthodox hierarchy; absolute rulership and exclusion of the people was just an unfortunate trend of the times, which Theodoric shared in too, as much as he could.

title: Market Forces
description: Very little seafood reaches the table in New York City without passing through hands of criminals, according to Frank H. Wohl. Mr. Wohl, who was appointed by a Federal court in 1988 to oversee the Fulton Fish Market with an eye to curbing the racketeering that has long been rampant there, said in a report last week that an ''atmosphere of lawlessness'' persisted. Mr. Wohl said that a small group of people controlled the unloading of delivery trucks and charged such extortionate rates that it cost as much to move a pound of fish 50 feet at the market as to move it hundreds of miles from New England. Drivers who attempt to do their own unloading are ''subject to physical abuse,'' said the report. Mr. Wohl said he would promulgate new rules to end such goings on but blamed the existing mess at least in part on city government laxity. City Hall returned the aspersions. A spokesman said that the conditions cited in the report reflected Mr. Wohl's ''inability to correct the problem.''

title: In San Francisco, a Good Idea Falls With a Thud
description: When Browning said that a museum's reach must exceed its grasp -all right, I know he didn't quite say that, but it is hard not to wish he had after seeing the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art's major summer exhibition, ''Visionary San Francisco.'' For this is one of the most ambitious, and admirable, efforts to address the realm of architecture and cities that any museum in the country has mounted in the last decade. That it doesn't quite come off - or that the most ambitious aspects of the exhibition come off the least - is no discredit to this museum's impressive reach. At a time when most museums are ignoring architecture, or playing it safe by presenting small retrospectives of the work of individual architects, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has taken on an entire city, trying to show us how San Francisco has traditionally defined itself through its dreams.

title: The Twin Cities
description: Minneapolis and St. Paul rise up on the plain like two glimmering mirages. They are known to outlanders as the Twin Cities, but since there's nothing for hundreds of miles across the farmscape that might invite comparison or confusion, most Minnesotans simply call them the Cities. They perch on tree-lined bluffs at the confluence of the Mississippi and the lesser-known but equally handsome Minnesota River.

title: Making His Point
description: Things were just fine for Hall Thompson and his Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham, Ala., in the weeks leading up to the P.G.A. Championship there last week. Then Mr. Thompson uttered some words that the Rev. Abraham Lincoln Woods thought he should eat. In an interview, Mr. Hall said that Shoal Creek discriminated against blacks and would not be pressured into changing. Mr. Woods, a 61-year-old civil rights activist, said he was ''simply outraged,'' and announced plans to picket the televised championship. As image-sensitive corporate sponsors began to pull out, jeopardizing an expected $30 million bonanza for Birmingham, officials asked him to quiet down and accept Shoal Creek's promise to change soon. He refused. Days before the tournament, Shoal Creek about-faced. ''I'm sure I was underestimated,'' said Mr. Woods.

title: Waiting for Armageddon

They are fundamentalist Christians, men and women who consider themselves ''reborn'' and who read the Bible as inerrant truth. They also, it turns out, read many other books, both fiction and nonfiction - so much so that one of publishing's fastest-growing markets is religious books, from the melodramatic visions of Hal Lindsey to the elegant apologia of C. title: Looking Back
description: Long after the Parking Violations Bureau scandal seemed moribund, it jumped up to bite Michael G. Dowd last week. In 1986, Mr. Dowd helped bring the vast scandal into the open when he informed prosecutors that his Queens company, which collected overdue parking fines for New York City, had for several years paid kickbacks to officials including the Queens Borough President, Donald R. Manes. Mr. Dowd, a lawyer, was not charged and went on to make a reputation for defending battered women in criminal cases. But last week, in an offshoot of the corruption, a state court ruled that Mr. Dowd violated legal ethics by failing to immediately report the unethical behavior of another lawyer, Mr. Manes. He was suspended from practicing law for five years. Amid an outpouring of support in the legal community, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former Federal prosecutor, called the punishment ''excessive and unnecessary.'' Mr. Dowd said he would appeal.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Lawrence Taylor Get A Raise?
description: I was always an offensive groupie until a strong Giant defense, led by Lawrence Taylor, gave me an appreciation for the beauty of the defensive game. It makes my adrenaline flow to chant ''L. T.!'' during a game, to watch him - like an animal of prey ready to attack. What are the Giants waiting for? Give him his raise. He deserves it. He's the best player the Giants have ever had. He adds a dimension of respectability, formidability and excitement to the Giant game, and I, for one, will be very depressed if he's not suited and ready to play on opening day.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Young Americans Are Getting Burned by Easy Credit
description: LEAD: MY grandfather used to say, ''If you can't afford it, save your money until you can.'' But it took a real lesson in the malice of credit-card spending to show me the wisdom of his words.

title: Judge Bars Inquiry in Daily News Labor Talks
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday barred a New York State board of inquiry from looking into a labor dispute between The Daily News and its 10 unions, saying the panel would intrude on collective bargaining, disclose confidential information and irreparably harm the newspaper.

title: More Than Spotted Owls Is Endangered
description: ''Ancient forests: Rage Over Trees,'' a National Audubon Society special, tonight at 8 on the Public Broadcasting Service, was shown on the Turner Broadcasting cable system last September - and therein lies a tale. About three weeks before the original presentation of the hourlong documentary on the controversy over logging in the Pacific Northwest, the Stroh Brewing Company, which had planned to give $600,000 toward the Audubon series, withdrew its support.

Meyer was married last evening to Michael David Jamison, the son of Mrs. Charlotte C. Jamison of Georgetown, Md., and the late William W. Jamison. Rabbi Moshe Edelman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Roseanne Barr Is Insulting
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CRIME
description: Fat, crude, surly Superintendent Andy Dalziel literally plays God in BONES AND SILENCE (Delacorte, $17.95), the 10th entry in Reginald Hill's outstanding procedural series featuring the bluff Yorkshire detective and his sensitive and contemplative associate, Inspector Peter Pascoe. The role of the Deity, which Dalziel assumes for a pageant of medieval mystery plays in his cathedral city, suits the Old Testament personality of the detective, who has achieved local fame as ''a man who walked through brick walls as he headed for the truth.''

title: In Sign of Times, Street Is Named for Beloved Boy
description: Sherif S. Byrd was only 10 years old when he was struck down by a drug dealer's bullet as he played in the spray from a fire hydrant two summers ago on Jesup Place.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table last Sunday listing the performance of world stock markets was out of date. The data, supplied by Goldman, Sachs & Company, were for the week ended July 27. The table for the week ended Aug. 3 appears today on page 26.

title: The Hard Thing About Cutting Infant Mortality Is Educating Mothers
description: A PANEL of Bush Administration officials who investigated infant mortality recommended 18 steps to reduce infant deaths in the United States. Half the recommendations were marked ''high priority'' because they could have a ''direct and immediate effect.''

title: Tech Notes;   M.I.T.'s Video Version of the Hologram
description: The Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is experimenting with holograms using a video image. Holograms, images created on flat surfaces by laser light that appear to be three-dimensional, are now frequently seen as decorative art, on credit cards among other things. Video hologram technology, when perfected, might offer architects the ability to draw a house on a computer screen and then examine its three-dimensional appearance or it could become the basis of three-dimensional television. Doctors might be able to use X-rays or other scanning devices to see organs in three dimensions. The M.I.T. researchers recently took a video image created on a computer screen using a program for a CAD, or computer assisted drawing, and converted it into a hologram. To do this, the computer drawing of a house, say, was first converted into computerized data that described a hologram of the three-dimensional object. This description was converted into electrical signals that altered and varied voltages on a piezo-electric crystal. This caused the crystal to send an ultrasonic wave through a tellurium oxide crystal. Laser light passing through the tellurium oxide crystal was altered so that it contained the holographic information.A system of moving mirrors synchronized with the computer signal were positioned so that the laser beam created a hologram of the image, the three-dimensional house, that appeared to a viewer to hover in front of the lens. One problem: the system gobbles so much computational power that a supercomputer is required to handle the trillions of bits of data involved.

title: America Could Face a Long and Costly Commitment in the Mideast
description: JUST as President Bush was beginning to trust in the stability of the emerging world order, the crisis most feared in the new era has exploded on the Arabian Peninsula. A war over oil is testing his ability to handle sudden adversity and holding out little hope for the kind of benign ending that followed the quiet revolutions of 1989.

title: Women Anchors Are on the Rise As Evening Stars
description: Maria Shriver did not have a baby in order to get into prime time; it only worked out that way.

The rift marks no less than the collapse of the ''social contract'' that for decades bound the networks, advertisers, agencies and, ex officio, the viewers they buy and sell.

description: WESTCHESTER'S mail service received a dubious distinction recently when the Postmaster General of the United States, Anthony M. Frank, called it ''the worst in the nation.''

''I got tired of looking at it all the time and knowing it was just going to be thrown out,'' she recalled. ''I recycle at home, so I wondered why I couldn't do the same thing at work.

The singer goes on to declare mischievously that she finally got her wish. In the current Broadway production of ''Cats,'' she portrays a 200-pound tap-dancing feline named Gumbie.

In this case, at least, a certain poetic justice prevailed, since the pianist, Marc Neikrug, though a composer of some note, has made his fame chiefly as a longtime accompanist of the evening's violinist, Pinchas Zukerman.

title: Ravenna
description: To the Editor: Joan Gould writes of Ravenna: ''Nothing of tourist interest was added from the completion of the mosaics'' (in the sixth century) ''to the opening of Benetton.'' Apparently she is unaware of the Tomb of Dante, a building erected in 1780 to enshrine the older tomb by Pietro Lombardo (1483). This covers the antique sarcophagus in which the poet's remains were originally interred in the old portico of the church of San Francesco. An exile from Florence, Dante found refuge with the Da Polenta family of Ravenna in 1317 and spent his last years with them, finishing ''The Divine Comedy.'' He died in September 1321; an epitaph was engraved over his tomb in 1357, and a bas-relief effigy was carved and a tomb constructed by Pietro Lombardo in 1483.

description: If oil prices stay up, how will the poorer countries - and companies - pay their energy bills?

description: The Pentagon has decided to send a fourth aircraft carrier to the Middle East, military officials said today.

All companies will be affected to some degree by the fallout from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. For some, the impact may range from negligible to potentially catastrophic. For others, the clouds promise to have only silver linings.

title: 17 Are Hurt When Bus Flips on Way to Airport
description: Seventeen people were injured, none seriously, yesterday afternoon in Queens when an airport bus flipped over on the Van Wyck Expressway service road after hitting a large puddle, the police reported.

title: Nudes Expressive of Skill and Power
description: THE David Smith nudes at the Montclair Art Museum come directly from Knoedler & Company, the Manhattan gallery that administers the artist's estate. As art money gets tighter, there will doubtless be more such liaisons, but this one has - or had - a small snag built in.

title: Retracing the Santa Fe Trail
description: The rents that the Santa Fe Trail tore through the earth of Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma and New Mexico serve as one great metaphor for travel. Now they are followed ''in pursuit of an experience that is never quite brought to completion.'' (The words are those of the trail historian Marc Simmons.) Traveling the Santa Fe Trail from Kansas City to Santa Fe is addictive, hallucinogenic, for without the forgotten fears of Indian attack or thirst or childbirth to dispel the boredom, finding the historical remains of the trail in the empty prairies becomes a desperate necessity. In the middle of Kansas the search becomes so intense that one begins to resent the presence of trees, which did not grow there until their seeds were brought by homesteaders or left in the dung of domesticated cattle.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Tired of TV Baseball? Try the Minors
description: Far from the crowds at Shea Stadium and a cellar season in the Bronx, professional baseball is on display in a quieter and perhaps purer form at minor league parks.

title: Corrections

title: Review/Mostly Mozart;   Shaham and Ohlsson Share A Program of Concertos

In an all-Mozart evening that also included the Overture to ''Lucio Silla'' and the ''Paris'' Symphony, Garrick Ohlsson played the piano solos in the G-major Concerto, No. 17, and Gil Shaham was the violinist in another G-major Concerto - the K. 216.
