title: Absolutely Awesome
description: HOW I MADE A HUNDRED MOVIES IN HOLLYWOOD AND NEVER LOST A DIME. By Roger Corman with Jim Jerome. (Random House, $18.95.) The greatest influence on modern American film making is not Ingmar Bergman, not John Ford, not even Alfred Hitchcock, but the man responsible for such efforts as ''She Gods of Shark Reef'' and ''Humanoids From the Deep.'' Roger Corman, the king of the exploitation movie, the Pope of Pop Cinema, has guided the careers of many of the most talented people in Hollywood today - among others, Martin Scorsese, Francis Ford Coppola, Dennis Hopper, Robert Towne, Jonathan Kaplan, John Sayles. Several of them have provided testimonials or reminiscences that are interspersed throughout Mr. Corman's autobiography, ''How I Made a Hundred Movies in Hollywood and Never Lost a Dime,'' written with the journalist Jim Jerome. Jonathan Demme's is typical: ''Roger is arguably the greatest independent filmmaker the American film industry has ever seen and will probably ever see. . . . His contribution to motion pictures has been absolutely awesome.'' As this memoir makes clear, Mr. Corman, as both a director and a producer, taught not only craft and technique but also clarity of thought and, above all, economy of means. Working on incredibly tight budgets, he never had the time to become self-conscious or pretentious. The first ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' probably his most famous film, was shot in two days, and some of the funniest stories in this book concern the ways he went about cutting costs on his more than 200 productions. (When all else failed, he would shoot a scene in the dark so the audience could not see what was actually going on.) The stories do pall after a while. One grows weary of learning about all the films that were milestones for him; there is probably more pace and variation in ''Attack of the Crab Monsters.'' Nonetheless, Mr. Corman comes across as likable, admirable and, in his ability to survive in Hollywood with his integrity intact, even awe-inspiring.

title: Ask It No Questions: The Camera Can Lie
description: Ever since its invention a shade more than 150 years ago, photography has been seen as a medium of truth and unassailable accuracy. Photographs have been used by scientists to map the planets and identify subatomic particles, by police and prosecutors to solve crimes and convince juries, by newspaper and magazine editors to document events around the world - and few think twice about it. Even everyday snapshots serve as litmus tests of social reality to millions of eyes. In the words of Oliver Wendell Holmes, a photograph serves as a ''mirror with a memory.''

title: All About/Deodorants;   The Success of Sweet Smell.
description: The human race may owe its rise to the survival of the foulest. Our hominid forebears, said Louis S. B. Leakey, the anthropologist, smelled so rank that hungry predators recoiled, allowing our unappetizing species to flourish and invent civilization. Brains and an opposable thumb helped, too.

title: Deadline on New York Insurance Bill Is Extended

The most critical talks occurred in the office of France's avuncular United Nations Representative, Pierre-Louis Blanc, at his mission in 1 Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, a five-minute walk away.

The Gershwin is the Piano Concerto in F, with Jon Klibonoff as soloist. The screen gems will be joined to Broadway selections, and the maestro in charge is Peter Sacco.

The Revs. Joseph Napier and Howard O'Shea officiated. Mrs. Apy, 25 years old, graduated from Brown University, as did her husband, and is a management consultant with Andersen Consulting in Boston. Known as the belly department, it is where the innards of the instrument - the metal plate and soundboard - are fitted and set in place. After all, before it gets there, the piano is something less than musical. Furniture, maybe.

Because it uses a lightweight and compact hand scanner, the Caere Typist system is much less expensive and much more convenient to use for everyday tasks than the more expensive desktop scanners used in conventional optical character recognition systems.

New District's Job Is Making Sure the Water Is Fit to Drink

Because the levels were so high, the area was eligible for financial and clean-up help from the Federal Environmental Protection

They are so good at it that Jan Endresen, the son and president of the family-owned company, Aerotech World Trade Corporation of White Plains, recently received a special Presidential citation. title: Error, Stage Left
description: The thought police are busy this year. With all the best intentions in the world - because aren't their intentions always honorable, from preserving the sanctity of the family to promoting racial equality? - they have proferred petitions, organized boycotts, brought lawsuits. Last week they even had the capacity to surprise us. They came out of left field, and they were represented by those people who traditionally have been the quirky, the avant-garde, the antithesis of the thought police type. That is, actors. In Central Park this summer, Morgan Freeman, a gifted actor who is black, has played Petruchio in ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' and Denzel Washington, a gifted actor who is black, is portraying Richard III.

description: INFLATION, and the drug trade, have aided counterfeiters in Connecticut, says Thomas W. Gardner of the United States Secret Service.

title: Grown Children Should Act Grown
description: I am baffled by Barbara S. Cuiffo's article about her children (''College Is Out and the Brood's Back Home,'' Opinion Page, July 22). What was the point of it? Were we supposed to find her grown children cute or charming in their incredible self-absorption? Were we supposed to feel sorry for her because of the extra work they caused her? Find it humorous that they apparently had never heard of environmental concerns and didn't even have the brains to know you don't waste a whole wash-load of water on one item? And at the end, were we supposed to find it heartwarming that after these unattractive people had left, she felt ''a significant slice of warm family life'' was now missing?

title: Formica: When a Household Name Becomes an 'Also-Ran'
description: No company likes to be knocked off the mountaintop by competitors, but the experience is especially galling if that mountain bears the company's name. Consider the case of the Formica Corporation, whose name is to laminated plastic countertops what Xerox is to copiers and Polaroid to instant photography.

title: In Fractious Pakistan, Governments Change, The Military Remains
description: THE army did it.

title: Moscow Is Said to Evacuate Bulk of Nationals From Iraq
description: The Soviet Union has evacuated all but 700 of its 8,000 citizens living in Iraq, Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy said today.

title: Excerpts From Statements By Bush on Strategy in Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday in Kennebunkport, Me., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: Saddam Hussein, Mideast's Noriega, Has to Go
description: The issue underlying President Bush's moves in the Persian Gulf is not Kuwait or Saudi Arabia or even oil. It is Saddam Hussein, the Noriega of the Middle East. Like his Panamanian counterpart, he has to go. He ought to be disposed of now before his power and opportunity for doing greater damage grows.

title: BEST SELLERS: August 12, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 9 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death while defending his wheeler-dealer brother-in-law. 2 2 8 MESSAGE FROM NAM, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A woman journalist's coming of age in the 1960's and 70's. 3 3 6 COYOTE WAITS, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $19.95.) The murder of a Navajo tribal policeman involves an ancient artifact. 4 5 17 SEPTEMBER, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95.) Guests from many parts of the world at a get-together in a small Scottish town. 5 1 THE WOMEN IN HIS LIFE, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Random House, $21.95.) The rise of a billionaire tycoon, from Nazi Berlin to London and New York, and his relationships with five women. 6 4 14 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 7 7 25 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95). The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 8 6 3 STARDUST, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $18.95.) A host of problems besets the private eye Spenser when he's hired to protect a glamorous television star. 9 9 14 AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Manners, morals and murder in Los Angeles's high society. 10 10 14 DRAGON, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) In 1993, Dirk Pitt moves fast to save America from a Japanese extremist. 11 1 GET SHORTY, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $18.95.) A Miami crook goes to Hollywood, where he finds that his life is the stuff of which motion pictures are made. 12 8 22 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) Jason Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade. 13 13 8 SULLIVAN'S STING, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $19.95.) The ordeals of a female cop assigned to track down a Florida con man. 14 14 2 HAMMERHEADS, by Dale Brown. (Donald I. Fine, $19.95.) A Coast Guard unit wages war against the South American drug cartel. 15 11 3 KILLING MISTER WATSON, by Peter Matthiessen. (Random House, $21.95.) How the enigmatic career of a turn-of-the-century Florida plantation owner evolved into an enduring legend. Weeks This Last On Week Weel List Nonfiction 1 1 18 MEN AT WORK, by George F. Will. (Macmillan, $19.95.) The political pundit and baseball buff describes the craft of the game as practiced by three players and a manager. 2 6 2 THE POLITICS OF RICH AND POOR, by Kevin Phillips. (Random House, $19.95.) How the rich got richer during the 1980's and what may lie ahead for American society. 3 2 11 SEVENTH HEAVEN, by Alice Hoffman. (Putnam, $19.95.) Life on Hemlock Street is conventional, orderly and very 1950's in this bustling novel, except that 8-year-old Billy Silk is clairvoyant. LOVE FOR SALE: The Words and Pictures of Barbara Kruger, by Kate Linker. (Abrams, $29.95.) Social and politically conscious photomontages in an unmistakable signature style, thoughtfully clarified and interpreted by Ms. Linker's text. A TRAIL OF HEART'S BLOOD WHEREVER WE GO, by Robert Olmstead. (Random House, $19.95.) The plot of this deft and peculiar novel goes round and round, but at the middle are the citizens - especially the dead ones - of Inverawe, N.H. THE END OF THE LINE: The Failure of Communism in the Soviet Union and China, by Christopher S. Wren. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Anecdote, analysis and lots of life in both countries, delivered by a correspondent of The New York Times. NEMESIS, by Rosamond Smith. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $18.95.) Joyce Carol Oates's third mesmerizing Rosamond Smith mystery concerns a homosexual rape, the murder of a mediocre composer (but much worse man) and its solution by a pianist. THE ANTS, by Bert Holldobler and Edward O. Wilson. (Belknap/Harvard University, $65.) Two distinguished, articulate biologists reveal everything we didn't know we wanted to know about ants.

title: Brennan Wasn't as Eisenhower Expected

title: 'Driving Miss Daisy' In Island Premiere
description: ALFRED UHRY'S multi-award-winning play, ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' has not only just ended its deservedly long Off Broadway run in Manhattan, but the Oscar-winning movie version has recently been released on video with an accompanying television advertising blitz.

title: Not All Drug Lords Are Outlaws
description: The list of drug traffickers in the war on drugs includes a lot of unscrupulous villains: the Colombian drug lords, gangs like the Bloods and the Crips and some U.S. pharmaceutical manufacturers.

title: Two Faces of the Pays Basque
description: Linked by geography, Biarritz and St. Jean-de-Luz lie 10 minutes apart along the southernmost Atlantic coast of France. Yet the two cities are as unlike as tea and cocoa: the former elegant, reserved and with a slight English air; the latter cozy and high-spirited.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

ART;

Pitting Man Against Nature
description: LEAD: IN ''At War With Plants,'' the current installation at the Anthony Giordano Gallery of Dowling College in Oakdale, the artist Barbara Roux invites the viewer to muse on the ways in which we try to limit and confine aspects of the natural world, often to our own detriment.

title: Japanese Discord on Iraq Raises Doubts About Premier's Trip
description: The crisis in the Persian Gulf has stirred unusual discord in Japan over how boldly to assert its leadership in denouncing Iraq and seeking oil supplies from other countries in the region, Government officials say.

title: Fresh Air Fund Seeks More Host Families
description: On the wall of the Fresh Air Fund office in midtown Manhattan hangs a patchwork quilt decorated with names and designs representing some of the 13 states and countless communities that are the destinations of thousands of poor city children for two weeks in the summer.

title: Sanctions on Iraq Appear Effective as Neighbors Block Trade
description: The United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq and Kuwait appears to be throttling shipments of food, military spare parts and other essential goods into the area.

title: Debra Todd Is Married
description: Debra Lee Todd, a daughter of Hazel M. Todd of Atlantic Beach, Fla., and the late Carl N. Todd, was married yesterday to Mark Warner Herlyn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warner B. Herlyn of Mamaroneck, N.Y., by the Rev. William Hester at Marble Collegiate Presbyterian Church in New York. Mrs. Herlyn graduated from the University of Florida and is a flight attendant with American Airlines. The bridegroom graduated from St. Lawrence University and is the national sales manager for resort and travel for Golf Digest and Tennis magazines in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Deborah S. Garb Marries
description: Deborah Shary Garb and Michael Adam Levine were married last evening at the Water Club in New York by Rabbi Richard S. Chapin. Mrs. Levine is a daughter of Muriel Garb of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late Dr. Robert Garb. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Levine of New York. The bride, a graduate of Smith College with a law degree from Emory University, is an associate in the New York law firm of Rosenman & Colin. The bridegroom, a graduate of Swarthmore College, is an investment banker at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.

title: Bulls Sign Grant
description: The Chicago Bulls signed their leading rebounder forward, Horace Grant, to a three-year contract extension yesterday. The agreement, whose terms were not disclosed, ends eight months of talks between Jerry Krause, the Bulls' vice president; Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Bulls, and Grant's representatives, Kyle Rote Jr. and Jimmy Sexton.

title: Technology;   The Service Robot Lumbers Off the Drawing Board
description: The staff at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut has grown accustomed to a strange machine trundling through the corridors. It is a robot called HelpMate that is being tested as a courier by its developer, Transitions Research Corporation of Danbury, to fetch things, like a late meal tray.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ravenna
description: To the Editor: Seldom does the Travel section present such an artistic blending of history, art, theology, psychology, the earthy and the transcendent, the ridiculous and the sublime, as appeared in Joan Gould's beautifully written evocation of Ravenna. It was as though her ''Mosaic Postcards From Paradise'' were accompanied by a long newsy family letter - the family consisting of those happily in love with the city's glorious treasures and intrigued by its paradoxical history and colorful personages.

title: George Whiteley, 81, Expert on the Atlantic
description: George Whiteley, a teacher, author, sailor and marine biologist, died Wednesday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 81 years old and lived in West Chester, Pa.

title: Burmese Military Cracking Down Again <
description: The military Government of Myanmar has increased its forces in major cities after killing four demonstrators last week in Mandalay, Western diplomats in the capital, Yangon, said in telephone interviews Friday and today.

title: Chicago Journal;   Old Names Sparking New Fears In Politics
description: It was only a matter of time.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: For a bridge drama in four acts, the final of the Women's Knockout Teams at the Summer Nationals in Boston two weeks ago would be hard to match. On one side of the battle were the defending champions: Juanita Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., Cheri Bjerkan of Elmhurst, Ill., Pam Wittes of Los Alamitos, Calif., Randi Montin of Woodland Hills, Calif., Kay Schulle and Jill Meyers, both of Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Lawrence Taylor Get A Raise?
description: I think L. T. should get a raise because if you look at the salaries of other football players who are not nearly as good as he is, you see that they earn as much as or more than he does. The Giants wouldn't be nearly as good without him. A lot of people go to the games just to see him sack the quarterback. When I play football with my friends, I pretend I'm him because he's so good. Football players' careers are short, so they should get as much as they can while they are playing.

title: Mirage of Arab Unity
description: The political map of the Arab world has been remade, or perhaps erased, overnight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If that means Saddam Hussein changes his spots, so be it.

title: Barbara M. Taylor Weds M. E. Smith
description: Barbara Mary Taylor, the daughter of Mary D. Raymer of Quincy, Mass., and the late Daniel L. Taylor was married yesterday to Malcolm Edward Smith, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm G. Smith. Rev. Richard Feukes performed the ceremony at the First Parish Unitarian Church in Norwell, Mass.

title: Style Makers;   Julie Bowman, Umbrella Designer
description: How does someone become an umbrella designer? If it's Julie Bowman, born in Cincinnati, she gets a fine arts degree at Indiana University and looks for a job. Hired by Totes for its umbrella division, she finds a career.

title: Mary M. Halladay Is Married to Brian L. Rogers
description: Mary MacIntyre Halladay, the daughter of Comdr. and Mrs. Maurice E. Halladay of Portsmouth, R.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Brian Lewis Rogers, the son of Barbara D. Rogers of Wilmington, N.C., and A. Lewis Rogers of Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Frank W. Carpenter, a Unitarian minister, officiated. Mrs. Rogers and her husband received M.B.A. degrees from the University of North Carolina in May. The bride, 26 years old, is a graduate of Tufts University. The bridegroom, 26 and a graduate of the Groton School and the University of New Hampshire, is an analyst at the Grubb & Ellis real-estate company in San Francisco.

description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

Aycock Is a Crowd Pleaser At Storm King Art Center
description: LEAD: THE selected retrospective of Alice Aycock's sculpture and drawings at the Storm King Art Center here is entitled ''Complex Visions,'' but if the work has built-in difficulties, it is also a definite crowd pleaser.

title: Timely Stories, And They're Documented
description: Slid in among video's new releases this summer are documentaries worth noting. One is ''Common Threads: Stories From the Quilt,'' the 1990 Academy Award winner, to be released next month by HBO. Broadcast by HBO-TV last year, the tape presents five profiles from the AIDS Memorial Quilt, begun in 1987 by the Names Project in San Francisco. Subjects of the biographies include an Olympic athlete, a Navy commander and an 11-year-old hemophiliac. ''Slowly, carefully, powerfully, 'Common Threads' takes the cold statistics and gives them recognizable faces,'' wrote John J. O'Connor in The Times. The price is $25, and profits will be donated to the Names Project Foundation.

title: Rediscovering Brahms: A Distinctive Festival
description: IN New York City, summers mean Mostly Mozart; but 90 miles away at the new Bard Music Festival, the focus will be on Rediscovering Brahms. The 600-acre Bard College campus is in Annandale-on-Hudson, just north of Rhinebeck, in the heart of the Hudson River Valley.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE HOME GIRLS. By Olga Masters. (Norton, $18.95.) The women in Olga Masters' stories do not triumph. They rarely smile and are often mean. Most simply endure. Yet they are powerful, somehow positive characters. Like most of the works of Masters, an Australian who died in 1986, the stories in ''The Home Girls'' tell of poverty, sadness, dreams and lost opportunities, often seen through the eyes of children forced to grow up too soon or women bowed by a relentlessly patriarchal society. In ''The Sea on a Sunday,'' the Went children, too poor to do anything else, spend their Sundays watching the cars heading for the beach, 15 miles away. Their mother pretends she is interested only for their sake and their father pretends no one deserves to go anyway. In ''Passenger to Berrigo,'' Sylvia McMahon, determined to prove she is better than her mother, returns from Sydney, a successful heroine to her siblings but a self-aggrandizing child to her parents. ''Only a maid,'' her mother says to herself, smugly satisfied when she learns her daughter's true occupation. ''A housemaid. No better than me after all.'' Masters' starkly simple writing tastes of the grit of Depression-era Australian farms, where the sun beats down on people instead of gently warming them. ''The Home Girls,'' like Masters' later collection, ''A Long Time Dying'' - in which the same characters appear in circumstance, if not in name - is not light reading, but it is enlightening.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: The Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills.

title: H. G. Mangelsdorf, 83, Former Oil Executive
description: Harold G. Mangelsdorf, a petroleum industry executive who spent much of his 40-year career in senior positions with Standard Oil of New Jersey, now Exxon, died on Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J. His family said he died of heart disease.

title: 'Those Dancing Feet' Keep '42d Street' Alive
description: THE show, a $2 million musical extravaganza, was in trouble. The director-choreographer had fallen ill, the production was falling apart, and the producer was on the warpath. After a five-week tryout at the Kennedy Center in Washington (where the reviews were bad, but business was good), a Broadway premiere was expected.

title: Cambodians Face Loss of Eastern Aid And Trade
description: SOVIET retrenchment and the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, hailed in the West as the opening to a harmonious new post-cold-war world, promises yet another disaster for the people of Cambodia, who have already had their share of ravaging at the hands of external forces.

title: Where Have All His Spies Gone?
description: On Normannenstrasse in East Berlin, in the heart of an ordinary middle-class neighborhood, stands a massive office complex: 41 concrete buildings as grimly functional as the apartment towers that surround them. Nine months ago it was the headquarters of East Germany's Ministry for State Security - the Staatsicherheit - or Stasi, perhaps the most sophisticated and far-reaching espionage organization ever created. But between January and March this year, as East Germany's Communist Government finally collapsed, the Stasi was formally disbanded. Today, the concrete citadel is deserted, its 10,000 rooms sealed, its agents locked out.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: WALTER I. LIPOW;

Pressing a Father's Right to Joint Custody
description: LEAD: THE Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, recently gave unwed fathers expanded rights in cases where the mother might wish to place the baby for adoption. The court threw out laws that said the father had no say in the matter unless he had been living with the mother for six months.

title: A'S CONTINUE DOMINATION OF YANKEES
description: When Willie Randolph sits in the dugout this weekend and looks across the field, the faces he sees are young, unfamiliar and full of uncertainty. The Yankees are no longer the team Randolph spent 13 years playing for; they are not even a facsimile.

title: Less Beer in Philadelphia
description: Less beer and more restrictions on it are on tap for Eagles fans at Veterans Stadium this fall as the main parts of a plan to reduce drunken rowdiness in the stands during football games.

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;

32-Acre Mall For Chinatown
description: LEAD: A 200,000-SQUARE-FOOT mall, the first phase of a major planned expansion of Chinatown, will be built in the 32-acre former Santa Fe yard, minutes south of the Loop.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Lawrence Taylor Get A Raise?
description: Carl Banks and Leonard Marshall have really led the Giant defense for the last three years. Lawrence Taylor's recent injuries, age, and other off-the-field problems call for a trade rather than a raise. This course of action would help both Taylor and the Giants.

title: CAMACHO COASTS IN TITLE DEFENSE
description: Hector Camacho retained his World Boxing Organization junior welterweight title here tonight when he won a unanimous 12-round decision over Tony Baltazar at the outdoor stadium of Caesars Tahoe hotel and casino.

title: Novel Aims to Capture Hamptons Summer Fever
description: LEAD: ''YOU remember the movie 'Moonstruck,' where Cher slaps Nicholas Cage and says, 'Snap out of it!'?'' Gloria Nagy asked. ''What I like to do is give that little slap.''

title: THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
description: I never received a census form, so when The New York Times published a phone number to call to report the omission, I dialed it. A jolly voice told me that a census taker would come to my home to count me. I explained that I would be willing to fill out the census form but that my job required intensive travel and it would be difficult to catch me at home for an interview (not to mention that it seemed silly, since my entire ''household'' consists of me). Weeks later I received written confirmation of this conversation, informing me that I would be interviewed at a future date. I was never contacted again. When your newspaper printed the census form, I filled it out and mailed it in.

title: The Beat Goes On, And On And On
description: Whatever became of the notion that brevity is the soul of wit? The idea occurs, what with all those new CD changers playing for hours without letup.

title: A Star Is Barred and 'Miss Saigon' Cancels
description: WHEN Actors' Equity voted on Tuesday to bar the English actor Jonathan Pryce from re-creating his prize-winning portrayal of a Eurasian pimp in a Broadway production of the London hit musical ''Miss Saigon,'' a lot more was potentially at issue than the future of the $10 million show, or its record $25 million advance sale, or whether the union even had a legal basis for taking such action. One major question was how the ruling would affect the principle of ''nontraditional casting,'' which Equity has pioneered and which it defines as the use of ethnic actors in roles where race or gender is not germane to the character.

title: Man Fatally Shot in Yonkers
description: A man was shot dead and a woman seriously injured early yesterday in a private house in Yonkers, the police said. The man, identified by the police last night as Carmelo Gonzalez, 28 years old, was reported dead at the house, at 711 Scarsdale Road, and the woman was taken to an unspecified hospital in critical condition, they said. The police withheld the identify of the woman victim.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Children Mean You'll Never...
description: LEAD: EVERYONE knows life changes dramatically after having children. It's tough to get enough sleep and tougher to pop out on a whim because you're in the mood for Chinese food. But there are countless other, less obvious changes that come with parenthood.

title: The Split Among Arabs Unleashes a People's Anger
description: FOR Arabs everywhere, it was a momentous week, one in which long-suppressed antagonisms exploded into anger, military action and recriminations. For the Western powers, it was a week whose benefits and costs are only beginning to be counted.

DINING OUT;

Satisfying a Taste for a Sizzling Steak

title: Joan Schwab Is Married
description: Joan Mary Schwab, a daughter of Mrs. George P. Schwab of North Bergen, N.J., and the late Dr. Schwab, was married yesterday at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in North Bergen to Laurence Arthur Nardi, a son of Annette Nardi of Bayside, Queens, and the late Dr. Ralph Nardi. The Rev. Edward M. Matash officiated. The bride, an associate in the Newark law firm of Saiber, Schlesinger Satz & Goldstein, graduated from Fordham University and the Seton Hall University School of Law. The bridegroom, a ship broker with the Intercontinent Chartering Corporation in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., is a graduate of the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I.

title: Harry W. Faeber, Designer, 95
description: Harry W. Faeber, a designer of printing presses and a consultant to printing concerns around the world, died at Brookhaven (L.I.) Hospital on Thursday. He was 95 years old and lived on Shelter Island. His family said he died of pneumonia.

title: Living Cells Enter Commerce; Now, Who Has a Claim to Profits?
description: THE biotechnology industry welcomed the California Supreme Court ruling last month that a man was not entitled to share in the profits from a drug developed from tissues removed from his body. But the case raised questions about the property status of tissues, genes and other biological materials, issues that are not likely to go away.

title: Olivia Lillich Wed To R. B. Hilton
description: Olivia Parsons Lillich, the vice consul for press and cultural affairs at the United States Consulate General in Shanghai, was married yesterday in Wellesley, Mass., to Robert Butler Hilton, a Foreign Service officer who is the assistant public affairs officer at the United States Embasssy in Sana, the Republic of Yemen. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carl P. Ijams, an Episcopal priest, at the chapel at Wellesley College.

title: College Duo in Amateur Final
description: The final of the 90th United States Women's Amateur Championship will be contested by two collegians from California, Stephanie Davis of Stanford and Pat Hurst of San Jose State.

title: Putting Prokofiev and Mozart in the Same Basket
description: About all Prokofiev's ''War and Peace'' and Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte'' have in common, it might be plausibly argued, is that both play in two long acts. Forget for the moment that Mozart sustains lengths more skillfully than anybody, let alone Prokofiev. Such gross differences are easy to point out. However, it is similarity that interests me today, not difference. While they may not jump out, some underlying resemblances can be discerned between the two operas. One close thematic relationship, which may be no news to you, struck me recently when I attended performances of these seemingly unrelated works within a few days of one another: ''War and Peace'' at the Seattle Opera and ''Cosi'' at the Santa Fe Opera.

title: Church Issues Challenge And Kissinger Responds
description: LEAD: A CHALLENGE by one man and a promise from another have been instrumental in an effort to establish a new education fund to aid Westchester youngsters.

title: Outdoors;   Ducks Send a 'Warning '
description: This spring's breeding populations of wild ducks in North America were much the same as in 1989, approximately 22 percent below the 1955-1989 average, according to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Never mind the people who get hysterical over nothing, the disorganized, the dillydalliers and shillyshalliers. It's only to be expected that these types would be prone to panic. But what about the middle-of-the-roaders, the average Jill and Joe? And what about the calm, cool and collected, the logical, the organized, the ''nothing fazes me'' types? Are they indeed calm, cool and unfazed under all or most circumstances? In a word, no.

title: Sri Lanka May Move Tamils From a Region
description: President Ranasinghe Premadasa is weighing a plan to evacuate one million Tamil civilians from the line of fire before the army mounts an assault on the rebel-held Jaffna peninsula in northern Sri Lanka.

title: In Search of the Latino Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: The Paris Season For Gate-Crashers
description: The summer invasion so dreaded by American residents of Paris is in full spate. As the French Parisians flee their city, heading for the sewage-saturated seashore, on come wave upon wave of our fellow Americans, inundating Paris and our apartments: the friends, the friends of friends, the children of friends of friends, the friends of friends of the children of friends, the whole implacable pack of them determined to live it up in Paris for one-eighteenth of what it costs them to live very simply in, say, Fond du Lac, Wis.

title: Using Plastic Pipe for Plumbing
description: BY using plastic plumbing pipe instead of metal, amateurs can perform many home repairs and improvements that otherwise might require hiring a plumber.

title: Reeves Improving
description: He was hospitalized on Wednesday night, but Dan Reeves may be back soon. Following minor surgery for hardening of the arteries, doctors said the 46-year-old coach of the Denver Broncos could be out of the hospital this weekend and back at work in less than two weeks.

title: Correction
description: The TV View article on July 29, about Edward R. Murrow, misstated his age at his death in 1965. He was 57 years old.

title: When Is a Private Building Historic?
description: LEAD: ONE door is missing, and most of the odd-sized windows are broken. The interior, with bare wooden beams and exposed wiring, is as grimy and sad looking as the chipped paint and overgrown yard on the outside of the building.

title: Angela Janklow Planning to Marry Gerald C. Harrington Jr. Next Year
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Janklow of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Angela LeRoy Janklow, to Gerald Christopher Harrington Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrington of Bronxville, N.Y. A spring wedding is planned.

title: RANGERS ELUDE JAMS, BEATING WHITE SOX
description: Charlie Hough won his third straight decision and the Texas Rangers escaped jams in the seventh and eighth innings today to beat Chicago, 7-5, and drop the White Sox four and a half games behind Oakland in the American League West. The White Sox stranded 14 runners and could not overcome an early 6-0 deficit.

title: Sure He's King, But He Comes From Las Vegas
description: On a stage at Pinewood Studios, surrounded by the gilded trappings of British privilege and power, the American actor John Goodman plays a common man - actually a piano player from Las Vegas - who becomes the King of England.

title: Fashion;   For Fall, Stylish Feet (and Knees) Are Covered Up
description: What do you wear with leggings, cat suits, ski pants or micro-miniskirts? Boots. Or at the very least, shoes that look like boots. That's the big news in fall footwear. Even regular shoes are cut high on the vamp for what fashion people call a ''choked up'' look.

title: A Little Weird, but All Right for Starters
description: A woman wary of trees, the father of a creature who seems part baby and part worm, a trashy-chic punk heroine and a deadpan Hungarian woman on the road to Cleveland: some movie heroes are deeply weird, in the best sense of the word. Such socially misfit, funny and appealing characters are most likely to escape from film makers' imaginations at the start of their careers. Without much to lose, directors such as Jane Campion, Susan Seidelman, Jim Jarmusch and David Lynch have created bizarre but wonderfully controlled first features.

title: Couples' Own Embryos Used in Birth Surrogacy
description: In the steamy, oil-rich town of Maracaibo near the northwestern coast of Venezuela, a husband and wife had lived for years with the belief that they would never be able to have children of their own.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The United States Postal Service has stirred the usual summer doldrums by moving up the issuance of a booklet of five stamps featuring Indian headdresses. The stamps, which had been scheduled for the fall, are to be released Friday in Cody, Wyo.

title: Livelier Cuisine for a Cafe in Westport
description: FEW Fairfield County restaurants have the longevity of Cafe de la Plage in Westport. The cozy little place in a sandy cove facing Long Island Sound has survived changes in ownership and chefs, has persevered.Its delightful view almost insures survival. (Our memory of the place dates to 1956, when it featured ''San Francisco cuisine.'') A new chef arrived recently, and the cuisine is a livelier, more contemporary combination of Continental and regional American. This, along with the informal atmosphere of a seaside cafe, makes for delightful summertime dining. Never mind that the service starts out snappily, then loses momentum after the entree is served, ending with a sputter at dessert and coffee time. Sit back and enjoy some of the freshly made creative dishes and revel in the Old Mill Beach view.

title: Artist Creates 'Magical Objects' With Fiber Optics
description: CLYDE LYNDS is an artist who combines the talents of a sculptor, a painter, an engineer and a magician. He casts monumental sculptures in stone; like slow silent fireworks, patterns drawn with points of light seem to move across their surfaces. Although the lights move as subtly as the hands of a clock, their mesmerizing quality compels the viewer to experience the work in time as well as space.

title: Correction
description: A map on April 1 with an article about Glacier National Park included an incorrect highway symbol and misspelled a nearby town. As a reader wrote recently to point out, the highway is U.S. 89, not Interstate 89, and the town is Kalispell.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

The Year of the Red Sox in New York?
description: LEAD: Shortly before he died in March, Ray Goulding, of the great Bob and Ray comedy team, told his wife that if he were to leave her, the Boston Red Sox, a team he loved all his life, would surely win the pennant. When the team was in town last month to play the Yankees, I told that touching story to Joe Morgan, their affable manager.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THAT PLACE IN MINNESOTA: Changing Lives, Saving Lives. By Ed Fitzgerald. (Viking, $18.95.) Take an executive at the pinnacle of his profession in an industry that associates creativity with alcohol. Mix in an exhilarating career full of deals sealed at three-martini lunches. Add forced retirement at the age of 65 and you have created circumstances, at least for Ed Fitzgerald, as explosive as a Molotov cocktail. Mr. Fitzgerald, the former chief executive officer of the Book-of-the-Month Club and author of ''A Nickel an Inch,'' describes in ''That Place in Minnesota'' his month at St. Mary's Rehabilitation Center, a Minneapolis facility for substance abusers. His writing style - wry, engaging, and direct - conveys his intention to disclose intimate experiences and emotions. In many instances, he succeeds. Particularly effective are scenes in group therapy, led by a counselor, Debbie Chapman, who asks the questions her patients most dread. Mr. Fitzgerald vividly portrays two close friends in the group: Denny, a young businessman from Texas who received cocaine in his hometown via Federal Express, and Mac, a Presbyterian minister from Vermont who embraced alcohol after his wife's death. The writer's distaste for the spiritual philosophy of Alcoholics Anonymous provides an interesting counterpoint to the religious undertone of his treatment. What is missing, then, from this heartfelt account? Even though Mr. Fitzgerald reveals severe, alcohol-induced problems with a wife he adores, even though he recalls a few hours spent in jail on a drunken driving charge, he devotes many more pages to others at the center than to his own struggle. His interesting but partial self-portrait leaves the reader wanting more. Was his addiction really broken, for example, in 28 days? ''That Place in Minnesota'' depicts a painful time in the life of an ''intensely private'' man who admits, ''I'd rather be alone with my troubles if I can't choose the people I want to talk to about them.'' Within those limitations, this is a moving and courageous memoir.

title: On Language;   Talking Tall
description: American English is not what it used to be.

title: Tracy Tang to Wed Stephen Limpe
description: Tracy Lynn Tang, an associate director of children's book clubs at the Book-of-the-Month Club in New York, and Stephen Timothy Limpe, an investment banker at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, plan to marry in September. Miss Tang is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar L. Tang of New York and Vail, Colo. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony T. Limpe of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Miss Mather to Wed Raymond Ix Jr.
description: The engagement of Dorothy MacGregor Mather to Raymond Edward Ix Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ix of Lancaster, Pa., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mather 3d of Philadelphia. An October wedding is planned.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE BOSS: J. Edgar Hoover and the Great American Inquisition, by Athan G. Theoharis and John Stuart Cox. (Bantam, $5.95.) By examining recently released files from J. Edgar Hoover's Federal Bureau of Investigation, the authors tell the story of an ideologue who converted an arm of the Justice Department into an empire. ''This strong book proves that, at the top, the bureau was turned into what could be called the H.B.I. (Hoover Bureau of Investigation),'' Herbert Mitgang said in The Times in 1988.

title: Miserable Level of Discourse
description: To the Editor:

title: Melissa Maguire Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Maguire of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Maguire to William James Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy F. Sullivan of Dumont, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Best Time to Stop a Crime Is Before It Happens
description: AS a string of headline-grabbing crimes in recent weeks, including the deaths by stray gunfire of four children, has prompted cries from politicians for action, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown has taken the first steps toward what he describes as ''community policing'' for New York City. Talking of retraining his officers to be peace-keepers who keep order on the streets rather than crime-fighters who merely respond to emergencies and about the need to build a police force that is ''part of, and not apart from, the community,'' Mr. Brown and Mayor David N. Dinkins have announced several moves intended to put more uniformed officers on foot patrols - the cornerstone of community policing. They also unveiled a plan to train all new police cadets in those techniques.

title: Northeast Notebook: Providence, R.I.;   Macy's to Open At a New Mall
description: Macy's has announced it will open a store in downtown Providence, which has no major department store. It will be an anchor of Providence Place, a $300 million mall, office and hotel project to be built not far from the State House lawn.

title: SAUDI ARABIA/At a Glance
description: Vital Statistics

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Poll on Troop Move Shows Support (and Anxiety)
description: Americans rallied around President Bush after he ordered military forces to the Persian Gulf, but the public's support is tempered by an undercurrent of anxiety and skepticism of the sort that has hampered American efforts to project power in the world since Vietnam, according to a poll by The New York Times.

title: How Harley Outfoxed Japan With Exports
description: Gloomy trade figures aside, at least one American product, the Harley-Davidson motorcycle, is outmaneuvering its competitors abroad.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Owens Leads U.S.
description: An inconsistent United States basketball team has had one constant throughout the World Championships in Buenos Aires - Billy Owens.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: Share the Work, Share the Bounty
description: THE way Judy Godino sees it, getting the family food through a cooperative buying club only looks like trouble. Granted, it entails planning weeks in advance, ordering in bulk, making sure someone can take time off from work to unload the delivery truck and separating everyone's order once it all arrives.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Pushy Parent Trap
description: LEAD: WHEN my son was 4 weeks old, we joined a discussion group for mothers and newborns. It had been billed as a cozy outlet for sharing the joys of first-time parenting. In reality it was a feeding frenzy for the already paranoid. Faster than you can say syrup of Ipecac, we were discovering things to worry about that had never occurred to us.

title: Recapturing Maine's Elegance
description: Like wines, antiques of a particular region have a taste of their own. Although many city shops specialize in country antiques, the collector learns more by regular shopping close to the source - an experience enhanced by local scenic and architectural pleasures. On the Maine coast, one area rich in antiques of regional interest is along the roads of the peninsulas extending out from this 200-year-old town on Blue Hill Bay, just across the water from Acadia National Park.

title: Agencies and Colleges Showing Effects Of Budget Cuts
description: IN the state's public colleges, tuition will be higher. At Division of Motor Vehicles offices, lines will be longer. And on state highways, potholes will deepen before they are filled, more litter will accumulate before it is removed, and more time will pass before the deer accidentally killed by a truck or a car disappears from the side of the road.

title: And Now, Doctorates in Development
description: Sarit Rozycki is one of a handful of young New York City developers who have been bidding up prices for prime midtown Manhattan real estate parcels recently. In her case the goal is to put up a 50-story office tower with retail space that she expects to become the first American home of Harrod's, London's swank department store.

title: PAKISTANIS WARY ON NEW ELECTIONS
description: Less than a week after the abrupt dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, Pakistanis seem to be in sorrowful agreement that this Western-educated ''Daughter of the East'' had let her country down at its most hopeful moment.

title: What Fathers Do
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
description: I wish James Gleick had spoken to some real enumerators instead of bedazzling himself with academics. If he had, he would have learned that most of the 350,000 workers on the 1990 census took pride in their work and looked upon it as a patriotic endeavor.

title: Effort to Combat Drunken Driving Gets a New Focus
description: LEAD: PATROLLING Interstate 95 the other night, Trooper Daniel Semosky watched a gold Dodge Charger weave erratically down the road toward Stratford. He headed off in pursuit, switching on his siren, his lights and his video camera.

title: Jeffrey Sharp to Marry Jennifer Antupit in Fall
description: The engagement of Jennifer Carol Antupit to Jeffrey Duncan Sharp, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John T. Sharp of Tifton, Ga., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel N. Antupit of Pound Ridge, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: Pearl Harbor All Over Again
description: FATAL VOYAGE

title: Postings: One-Family Homes;   Buffalo Tops State In Growth
description: Census figures show that the Buffalo area experienced New York State's highest percentage gain in home-building permits for the latest five-year period for which statistics are available.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Collectors of United States proof sets may be in for a nice surprise - cents in some of the sets lack a San Francisco Mint mark and this is making such sets valuable. Within one week of the discovery, proof sets lacking the mint mark on the cent are being bought for $600.

title: Black F.B.I. Agent Looks Back on Years of Harassment
description: In the end, Donald Rochon was still deprived of what had once been his life's dream, to finish out his career as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
description: The insulting stereotype on your cover of a woman mathematician, looking embittered and sexless, may go a long way to explain why so few women enter the field of mathematics.

title: Cooper to Be Waived
description: After 11 seasons, it appears the Los Angeles Lakers and their top defensive guard, Michael Cooper, will part ways. The Lakers will ask waivers on Cooper on Wednesday so that he can pursue plans to sign a three-year, $5 million contract with an Italian team, according to a report in yesterday's editions of The Los Angeles Times.

title: All for Oil, a Fuel That Fouls Air and Water;   Restore Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OSCAR PETERSON: The Will to Swing. By Gene Lees. (Prima, $19.95.) Duke Ellington called him the maharajah of the piano. Artie Shaw told college students that one of his performances was ''the epitome of jazz.'' Oscar Peterson is ''a virtuoso without peer'' whose immense talents have earned him 10 honorary degrees and the Order of Canada. Gene Lees, the former editor of Down Beat magazine and the author of ''Singers and the Song,'' has written an enthusiastic journalistic account of a musician's development as the thinking person's pianist. Mr. Peterson, who was born in Montreal in 1925, credits his father, a Pullman porter, as his greatest musical influence. Mr. Peterson's big break came in 1949 when he played Carnegie Hall, thereby cementing a relationship with the influential jazz impresario Norman Granz. In the 1950's, his trio (with the bassist Ray Brown and the guitarist Herb Ellis) enjoyed great critical and popular success. Mr. Lees consistently defends the pianist, who by his very virtuosity has inspired some sour criticism. ''Oscar Peterson must be considered more than an influence,'' Mr. Lees writes. ''He has become an institution.''

title: All Ye Need To Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Blame Victims, Listen to the Poor
description: I read Barbara Warsaw's ''The Other Side of the Welfare Debate'' (May 27) with resentment. Once again it seems someone is commenting on poverty, morality and indigence from a middle class armchair. I don't have any answers for American poverty. But I get so tired of hearing people suggesting the victims are to blame.

title: Cookie Lavagetto Is Dead at 77; Hit in '47 Series Ruined No-Hitter
description: Harry (Cookie) Lavagetto, the popular Dodger infielder best recalled for his ninth-inning double that spoiled a no-hitter for the Yankee pitcher Bill Bevens in the 1947 World Series, died in his sleep Friday morning at his home in Orinda, Calif.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Is it possible to get too much of a good thing when it comes to color films? It is if you can't figure out which one to use. In recent years film manufacturers have bombarded photographers with so many new and improved emulsions that for many choosing one has become something of a guessing game.

title: Wedding in December For Marci Robin Kislin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kislin of North Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marci Robin Kislin to Mitchell A. Heskel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton M. Heskel of Huntington Valley, Pa. A December wedding is planned.

title: Elections Board Battlers May Lose the War
description: THE county's Board of Elections, which has drawn Albany's attention for the inability of its two commissioners to work together, may have new leadership after this year's elections.

title:
FOCUS;

Buying into a Full-Health-Care Facility
description: LEAD: A growing population of well-to-do elderly people in the San Francisco Bay area is creating a market for retirement communities that offer equity ownership and full-service health care in luxurious surroundings. Two are operating, one is being built and a fourth is being planned.

title: The Niagara of Philosophy
description: THREE RIVAL VERSIONS OF MORAL ENQUIRY

title: Amy Rosen Weds C.L. Connelly
description: Amy Sue Rosen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest B. Rosen of Broomall, Pa., was married yesterday to Christopher Love Connelly, a son of Patricia L. Anderson of San Francisco and John E. Connelly of Fort Salonga, L.I. Judge Edward B. Rosenberg of the Court of Common Pleas officiated at the Radnor Valley Country Club in Villanova, Pa.

description: To the Editor:

title: WITH FUEL PRICES SOARING, MAKE PLANS TO DRIVE FOR ECONOMY
description: A lot of people have been wringing their hands, but it was George F. Will who so deftly put his finger on the problem at the pump.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kara S. Donahue Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Kara Shannon Donahue to Alec Stephen Berman has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Julia Halleran Donahue of Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. Robert M. Donahue of Concord, Mass.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Vietnam's Golden Opportunity
description: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam Vietnam's Communist leaders now have the long-awaited chance to open their country to a brighter economic future. But that will require them to move away from dogmatic foreign policy positions of the past. Thanks to Vietnam's withdrawal of its occupation army from Cambodia and Secretary of State Baker's new diplomatic initiative to prevent a Khmer Rouge victory there, direct talks are now under way. The path toward better relations between the United States and Vietnam is now clearer than at any time since 1975.

title: The Voltaire Project
description: To the Editor:

title:
MUSIC;

Apple Farm Campers Collaborate on Musical
description: LEAD: FOR seven composers and six scriptwriters, all from 11 to 16 years old, collaborating on a musical theater work has been nothing less than exhilarating. For the second year, the Appel Farm Arts & Music Center in Elmer has received a $10,000 grant from the Bergen Foundation to support an original musical written, composed, produced and performed by the campers, with some help from the faculty and staff at the camp.

title: Williamstown's New Look: More Comedy, Less Chekhov
description: In the quiet of Peter Hunt's office at the Williamstown Theater Fes tival, the opening night balloons have sagged to the marble floor, suggesting an air of dogged ebullience. ''Yeah, we were hoping they'd last all summer,'' says the bearded director, giving the rubbery cluster a little kick. ''But I think we're doing well considering we're in the middle of a recession. Right now we're playing to nearly 90 percent capacity.''

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   The Problem of 'Sick-Building Syndrome'
description: SICK-BUILDING SYNDROME, a disorder that medical and environmental professionals say is widespread, but largely unregulated, refers to vague illnesses reported by people who work in large office buildings where the windows are inoperable.

title: Ms. Himsl Weds James R. Arthur
description: Kelton Himsl, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dunstan Himsl of Houston, was married yesterday in Vail, Colo., to James Roberts Arthur, a son of Mrs. Donald Arthur of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and the late Mr. Arthur. The Rev. Julian Rush, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Interfaith Chapel.

title: Vincent Obsessed
description: VAN GOGH

title: Gorbachev: His Trials And His Errors
description: LEAD:

title: In the Movies, Jazz Musicians Are Destined to Die Young
description: Young, gifted and doomed - that's the prognosis for jazz musicians in the movies. On screen, jazz is a siren call, an obsession, an addiction that disrupts the lives it touches and consumes anyone under its sway. The musicians are pure souls, verging on idiot savants, who are so wrapped up in the music that they invariably mess up both business and romance.

title: Sports of The Times;   Power Breakfast With George and Hank
description: It is dawn of Hank Steinbrenner's first day on the job as high potentate of the Yankees. The scene is a scruffy little pied-a-terre used by George Steinbrenner on his visits to New York. This morning the flat seems unusually crowded because Hank has slept on the couch. George: Good morning, son. Hank: I'm not supposed to talk to you, Dad.

title: Who Speaks for Whom in South Africa?
description: SINCE Nelson Mandela walked to freedom in February, South Africa has witnessed a peculiar and often troubled courtship between those who stand for the competing nationalisms that have vied for the nation throughout its modern history. Mr. Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk must now be wondering how long the coziness will last.

title: A Refresher, Not a Race
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

Altitude Adjustment Hour
description: LEAD: WITH his straggly shoulder-length hair and neon-green shorts, Joe Gschwind looks as if he should be getting high on a beach somewhere. And on a recent Sunday morning he was, with his kite.

title: Julia Ann LaFond Wed in Cleveland
description: Julia Ann LaFond, a daughter of Mr. and Thomas J. LaFond of Westlake, Ohio, was married yesterday in Cleveland to Thomas F. X. Powers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Powers Jr. of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Walter P. Krolikowski, a great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church.

title: Joanne S. Lessner To Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Joanne Sydney Lessner to Joshua David Rosenblum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray H. Rosenblum of Pittsburgh, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alford H. Lessner of Newburgh, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: Style Makers;   Joan Raines and Anthony Muto, Dress Company Executive and Designer
description: ''I've never put anything on that looked so great,'' Teresa Shapiro said, pirouetting in a black crepe dress with a white satin peplum. She had come to Bergdorf Goodman to see the clothes Anthony Muto had designed for Joan Raines.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a family living in a violent Brooklyn neighborhood misidentified two family members in some copies. Lynette Orr was in the center and her daughter, Crystal, was at the left.

title: Bystander Deaths Reshape City Lives
description: As the homicide rate soars around the country and the killing of bystanders becomes a fact of life, the routines and rhythms in certain American neighborhoods have been reshaped by fear.

title: ;   The Spirit of Marsalis With the Swing of Sinatra
description: From Yehudi Menuhin to Stevie Wonder, American music has a long tradition of Wunderkinds, though few if any have demonstrated the range of talents commanded by Harry Connick Jr. In the last three years, the 22-year-old entertainer from New Orleans has released no less than five albums. This week three of them - a number matched only by New Kids on the Block - are listed on Billboard's pop album chart. One is his 1989 album of popular standards, ''When Harry Met Sally . . . Music From the Motion Picture'' (Columbia 45319; all three formats), which has sold more than 800,000 copies. It was recently joined on the chart by two new, simultaneously released albums.

title: Corrections
description: Two captions on the Fashion page last Sunday, about jackets for late summer and early fall, were transposed. The model on the lower left was wearing the DKNY jacket and paisley skirt; the seated model was wearing the Adrienne Vittadini jacket.

title: Meg Laidlaw to Wed John M. Nebens
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Laidlaw of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Elizabeth Laidlaw to John M. Nebens, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Nebens of Millwood, N.Y.

description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of the Shorewood community on Shelter Island are worried that the southern side of the island will soon be drastically changed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Audubon's Birds Display Their Plumage at the Barnum
description: ROOSTING at the Barnum Museum are 46 of the 435 birds recorded by John James Audubon (1785-1851) for his double elephant-sized folio ''Birds of America.'' And very handsome they look, hanging on sage-green walls stenciled with the occasional avian silhouette in a lighter tone.

title: Campus Life: Baylor;   A Ban on Dancing Survives Another Test
description: For a short time last spring, it looked as if the Baylor University students of 1990 would be allowed to do something none of their predecessors had been allowed to do in the school's 145-year history - dance on campus.

title: Where Peter Rabbit Romped on Cape Cod
description: The traveler heading north on Water Street in Sandwich, Mass., will encounter a scene that conjures up the archetypal New England village. As the road winds toward the center of Cape Cod's first settled town (1637), it passes several 17th- and 18th-century buildings on the shores of tranquil, wooded Shawme Pond where mute swans, geese and ducks often conduct their stately rounds.

title: National Surveys
description: Want a major league expansion team? If so, you had better be ready to answer questions on everything from parking to population and lighting to luxury boxes.

title: Police Say Man Killed Father For Throwing Out Son's Fan
description: A 22-year-old man was charged in the shotgun slaying of his father in their Islip, L.I., home yesterday after they argued about the father's throwing the son's electric fan into the garbage, the police said.

title: All for Oil, a Fuel That Fouls Air and Water;   More Miles per Gallon
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Trumpet
description: Scholars like Clinton Rossiter describe the American President in terms that make him sound like a hat rack: Chief of State, Commander in Chief, Chief Diplomat, Chief Legislator, Chief Economic Strategist and, at least until the end of the cold war, Leader of the Western World.

title: Two All-Star Right-Handers Wind Up on Opposite Courses
description: Jack Armstrong started for the National League in the All-Star Game and pitched two shutout innings. Ramon Martinez followed him and pitched a third scoreless inning. One month later, Armstrong and Martinez linked up again last Thursday night, and their efforts epitomized the way their fortunes have diverged since the All-Star Game.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Lawrence Taylor Get A Raise?
description: It's great to be great, and when Lawrence Taylor is on his game, he is the greatest. His off-field antics, however, tend to grate. His defiance in opting to play golf instead of living up to his word (contractual agreement) leaves me to ponder how big a fine should be imposed on Lawrence the Great. A raise? Give him a Mulligan.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on page 21 of the Arts and Leisure section today, about the movie ''The Exorcist III: Legion,'' misidentifies the actor shown. He is Jason Miller.

title: Telling the Truth About Abuse of Women
description: What a relief to have Dr. Beverly Birns to tell us the truth about violence against women. In my work researching incest abuse in families I am constantly exposed to the woman blaming in society that asks why mother didn't stop father; that blames mother's alleged rejection of father for father's rape of his children; that blames the Hedda Nussbaums of the world, with their 13 broken ribs and gangrenous legs, for child abuse committed by their partners.

description: Carol E. Samuels, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Samuels, was married in Vancouver, Wash., yesterday to David B. Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo B. Taylor of Portland, Ore. Judge James D. Ladley of Clark County Superior Court in Vancouver officiated at the Marshall House.

title: Anything Else Is Just a Cantaloupe
description: In a field covered with vines, John Hand carefully searched for mature melons the other day, looking for ones with yellow lightening their normally green-tinted skins.

title: Class for Executives: Oriental Orientation
description: THE six executives who file into the conference room at the Darien headquarters of Zotos International, have brought along not the usual accouterments of a business meeting but dog-eared copies of a paperback book, ''Practical Japanese.'' After a minimum of chitchat, these managers at the hair-prouducts company get down to the task at hand: learning the language and culture of Zotos's new parent company, the Shiseido Company Ltd., a Japanese cosmetics conglomerate.

title: Look Before Leaping, but for Goodness' Sake Leap
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab Crisis, as Seen From Carolina
description: As members of the Civitan Club bowed their heads in prayer, a minister reminded them of their good fortune ''in this time of crisis'' to have Representative Howard Coble as their luncheon speaker.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Ocean County Now a Primary Address
description: LEAD: The scarcity of affordable housing in northern New Jersey is increasingly turning home buyers to Ocean County, a resort area with a plethora of new housing developments that continue to spring up within its 637 square miles.

title: Miss Roska Is Married to E. H. Weiner
description: Carolyn Kangleon Roska, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jose C. Roska of Bloomsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Erik Helge Weiner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Erik Weiner of Falkoping, Sweden. The Rev. Joseph H. Fennessy performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Berwick, Pa. Patricia Macy was her sister's matron of honor and Per Arne Weiner, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep up with transplanting perennials, shrubs, especially conifers, but water everything well so the roots become established. Mail orders for hardy bulbs that will be planted in the early fall months. Cut off the stalks of early-blooming hostas and daylilies; carefully remove seed pods from other perennials. Consider reseeding the lawn if the established lawn is full of weeds and bare spots; consider sod to repair bare patches in smaller areas.
