description: An announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William C. Woodhull Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J., of the September wedding plans for their daughter, Linda Barton Woodhull, and Lieut. Todd Christopher Davis of the Navy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Allen Davis of Salem, Ore.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Making Couples Perfect Couples
description: LEAD: MY best friend hates my husband. Her husband hates me and I'm not too crazy about him. Can this foursome survive?

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Rejection? What Happened To Good Manners?
description: LEAD: I AM tired of being rejected. I am tired of being told I'm not good enough by men, magazines and megacorporations, as if their arbitrary set of standards is the last word on the subject. But mostly I'm tired of the lies that accompany rejection. If only people could be honest and admit their reasons for not wanting us, those of us left holding the bag (or manuscript or job application) could make a clean break of it and begin again.

title: Temporary Employment Feels Squeeze
description: LEAD: AS the New Jersey economy slows, many of the state's 220 temporary employment agencies are experiencing a slowdown of their own, with fewer companies calling to hire temporary workers.

title: Katherine Crispell Marries
description: Katherine Gardner Crispell, an executive assistant at the Avatar Investors Associates Corporation, investment advisers in New York, was married yesterday in Sacramento, Calif., to Michael Ross Shumway, a product manager at Timeplex Inc., a telecommunications company in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. The bride, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garrett Crispell of Sacramento. She is a graduate of Choate Rosemary Hall and Scripps College. The bridegroom, 28, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John D. Shumway of Cheshire, Conn., is a graduate of Choate Rosemary Hall and Cornell University.

title: Staten Island Youths Winners of State Title
description: In June, just before the start of the Little League playoffs, which lead to the World Series in Williamsport, Pa., the South Shore team from Staten Island heard words that championship franchises dread: ''Break them up.''

title: Belfast Visitors Build Friendship
description: LEAD: ''I'M sure Ireland will be united someday,'' Marie Therese Hargey said. ''It can't go on like this forever.''

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

When We Took The Dunes For Granted
description: LEAD: SOMEWHERE on the outer edges of my memory, I recall a picnic lunch amid rolling dunes with unobstructed views of the sparkling waters of Little Egg Harbor one way and the crashing Atlantic surf the other. The substance and setting of the event are lodged securely in the recesses of my mind, unexpectedly surfacing when my memory is stimulated by a certain smell or sound or slant of light.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Lincoln Square
description: Lincoln Square, the West Side neighborhood dominated by Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, is not the place for those who feel underdressed when everyone else seems to be in furs and evening dress.

title: Janet S. Weiss Is Married To Dr. Thomas J. Dwork
description: Janet S. Weiss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry R. Weiss of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Thomas J. Dwork, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry J. Dwork, also of Tenafly. Cantor Nathaniel Benjamin assisted Rabbi Bruce Block in performing the ceremony at the Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J. Mrs. Dwork recently graduated cum laude from Harvard University and expects to receive an M.B.A. degree from Rutgers University in July. The bridegroom graduated from the University of South Carolina and the Fairleigh Dickinson University Dental School.

title: Joanna Louise Fowler Weds Eric C. Jonsson
description: Joanna Louise Fowler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howland Auchincloss Fowler of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Eric Carl Jonsson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan R. Jonsson of Honolulu. The Rev. D. Worth Carson performed the ceremony at the National Presbyterian Church in Washington. Mrs. Jonsson, 27 years old, will begin work in September as an investment analyst for the Capital Research Company in San Francisco. She graduated from Princeton University and received an M.B.A. degree from Stanford University. Her father is a physicist at the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Gaithersburg, Md. The bridegroom, 33, is a financial analyst at the Bechtel Group Inc. in San Francisco. He graduated from Stanford University where he received an M.B.A. degree. His father is a vice president of Hawaiian Tug and Barge in Honolulu.

title: Evening Hours;   Under a Tent, In a Museum, At a Factory
description: Ruby and white were the colors for the 40th anniversary celebration of the Saratoga National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame on Monday. Most of the women wore red or white, matching the decor in the tent on the museum lawn. The 550 guests danced and dined under 12 crystal chandeliers.

title: A Life Spent on One Musical Path
description: ''I like attention being given to special birthdays,'' says William Schuman, ''especially when it means performances. I think anything that draws attention to your music and gives a pat on the back is a titillation, but as someone said, 'Flattery is okay if you don't inhale.' ''

title: When 'Nonrefundable' Air Tickets Are Refundable
description: On the face of it, the phrase appears to be self-explanatory and irrevocable: nonrefundable tickets are tickets for which the purchaser cannot obtain a refund.

title: The Threat Facing Cardiac Surgery Unit
description: I was recently an angioplasty patient at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood. I live and work in nearby Wyckoff. The fact that the procedure was performed at Valley Hospital insured that a network of physicians who know me personally were available for consultation.

title: Jubilant Mayor Asks the Capital To 'Forgive Me'
description: The cheers of 500 supporters washing over him, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. asked the people of the nation's capital for forgiveness today and urged citizens and Federal prosecutors to help bind the wounds left by his 10-week drug and perjury trial.

title: Waiting for Better Times at America's Shipyards
description: Worldwide orders for new ships have begun to recover after one of the industry's longest slumps. Yet the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, for one, has recently disbanded a team of managers, designers and engineers capable of building new ships at the company's yard here.

title: Port Authority Plans Outlined
description: The new director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said last week that he would keep the Authority's $6-billion plans to renovate bridges, tunnels, airports, marine terminals and the PATH system moving forward.

title: Corrections
description: A column on page 23 of the Travel section today listing air fares and other information is mislabeled. It is Travel Watch, not Practical Traveler. In addition, under the heading ''Discount Fare,'' the column misstates the lowest round-trip air fare between Rio de Janeiro and Miami for the week of Sept. 9. It is $900, offered by Pan Am and Varig. The Aerolineas Argentinas fare of $829 requires passengers to buy $100 worth of accommodations.

title:
PRO FOOTBALL;

In Rozelle's Retirement Time The Living Is Very Easy
description: LEAD: His most difficult decision? Suspending Paul Hornung. His biggest mistake? Playing games two days after President Kennedy was assassinated. His toughest project? The merger with the American Football League.

title: Campus Life: Ohio State;   Educators Learn To Turn to Others In Student Crises
description: When a 7-year-old student in the Asbury Elementary School here tested positive for the HIV virus, the principal, Sherry Kuehnle, knew just how to handle the situation.

title: The Threat Facing Cardiac Surgery Unit
description: The excellent article about the jeopardy to the Valley Hospital's cardiac surgery-coronary angioplasty program raised many valid points. However, there are a few items that require additional clarification.

title: Iraq Shatters Some Myths About Oil
description: ''We are frankly puzzled by claims that oil imports from OPEC countries constitute a threat . . . . References to OPEC as a ruthless cartel whose aim is to gain a stranglehold on economies of the West are completely false and misleading . . . . We must all endeavor to create a climate of mutual trust and respect . . . .'' - Dr. H. E. Subroto, Secretary General of OPEC, in the October 1989 OPEC Bulletin.

title: Regina Niner Is Married
description: Regina Marsh Niner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Niner Jr., of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Kevin Edward Conley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Conley of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Peter W. Peters performed the Episcopal ceremony at the University of Maryland chapel in College Park, Md. Mrs. Conley, 24, graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and will study for a master's in architecture at Columbia University in September. The bridegroom, 27, graduated from Yale University and is a consultant with Russell Reynolds Associates, Inc., an executive-recruiting consultant firm in New York.

title: Lockerbie Aftermath: Split Among Families
description: ON Dec. 21, 1988, the families of Alexander S. Lowenstein and Warren M. Buser were bonded forever and their lives were changed irrevocably when the two men died in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 high above Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: ''42nd Street'' Brings Joy to Candlewood Theater
description: THE show, a $2 million musical extravaganza, was in trouble. The director-choreographer had fallen ill, the production was falling apart and the producer was on the warpath. After a five-week tryout at the Kennedy Center in Washington (where the reviews were bad, but business was good), a Broadway premiere was expected.

title: What Publishers Will Do for a Place on the Right List
description: WHEN they talk about what it takes to break the sales barrier and get a book onto that self-perpetuating marketing machine called the best-seller list, publishers often sound more like auto executives than purveyors of literature. They discuss a book's ''velocity.'' They talk of ''revving up the sales force.'' They wonder how best to ''put an author on the road.'' And they mumble arcane technical terms like ''the Oprah factor,'' which, they claim, may be the key to sending a book racing off the grid.

title: All for Oil, a Fuel That Fouls Air and Water;   Rip-Off Artists
description: To the Editor:

title: Wooed, Wined and Overworked, Wall St. Lawyers Meet Pink Slips
description: They were the legal profession's gilded generation, an army of lawyers without limits. As law students, they were wined and dined and wooed by the most prestigious law firms in New York. Once hired, they began settling into a frantic but fantastically lucrative life. It was a life of glamour, prestige and, they assumed, stability.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

Great Plains Tragedies
description: LEAD:

title: Scenes From a Nightmare
description: Kampala's Mulago Hospital stirs in the early morning like a great lumbering monster, sloshing and swishing as cleaning women hurl buckets of water onto the floor and rhythmically scrub away the memories of the previous night. On the dusty road outside, streams of people hobble up to the ponderous six-story complex. Inside, barefoot young children scurry through the dark, slippery corridors, carrying blankets and plastic basins to their ailing elders. On October mornings, chilled by the thunderous nocturnal rains, stiletto winds rush through the shattered windows.

title: Julia A. Johnson To Marry in Fall
description: October wedding plans for Julia Anne Johnson and Charles Martin Trautschold 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome F. Trautschold Jr. of Potomac, Md., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Johnson of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: Postings: More Lighting;   Meeting Tenant Fears
description: For 40 years, Louis L. Friedman has cursed the darkness and lit a few candles. As a New York State Senator from Brooklyn in the early 50's, he sponsored a bill requiring landlords to put lights in front of apartment buildings. He believed this would deter muggers and make it less perilous to navigate stairways at night. The bill was opposed by insurance companies, which feared it would give new grounds for injury claims, and died in committee.

title: The Big Screen Pokes Fun at the Little
description: While Bruce Willis is wiping out terrorists on the ground in ''Die Hard 2,'' a plane full of hostages is circling above Dulles Airport, carrying minor but symbolically loaded characters like a slick, creepy television reporter. William Atherton, as the same journalist whose snooping tortured the hero's family in the first ''Die Hard,'' ducks into a bathroom and phones in a live broadcast about the plane's dangerous situation. In a solemn tone he pontificates, ''The truth is not among the hostages, because I, Dick Thornberg, am here to risk my life.''

title: Couple Found Shot Dead in Their L.I. Home
description: The Nassau County police are investigating the deaths of a couple who were found by their son on Thursday night shot in the master bedroom of their split-level ranch house.

title: Hammerin' Hank, Joltin' Joe, mr. Cub And Me
description: As soon as i'd gotten the improbable call inviting me to Chicago to play in the Fifth Annual Equitable Old-Timers All-Star Game, my baseball dream merchant appeared. My vision was pure, uncomplicated: the brick and ivy of Wrigley Field, patriarchal, antediluvian, the baseball acropolis where Babe Ruth called his shot. A standing-room-only crowd, 40 living legends - Joltin' Joe, Hammerin' Hank, Mr. Cub - and me. I'd be sitting on the bench, sandwiched between Bob Gibson and Steve Garvey, discussing hook slides and politics. Up in the stands, my dad would be sharing the moment. Then manager Monte Irvin's words would jump-start my nervous heart. ''Go up there and pinch-hit for Aaron,'' he'd say. I'd been invited to play at Wrigley with these great names in baseball history because, well, it's a weird story. Back in 1968, I was a rookie pitcher with the Philadelphia Phillies. In my major league debut at Crosley Field in Cincinnati, the first batter I faced, Pete Rose, lashed my third pitch, a room-service fastball, for a stand-up double. Really, I'm not making this up. Rose didn't score - Vada Pinson whiffed on a slider, leaving Rose on third - but as fate would have it, a few days later I got the bejabbers beat out of me by two thugs in San Francisco, separating my shoulder. I never pitched in another big-league game. My career stats: 1 game, 2 innings pitched, 3 hits, 1 run, 2 strikeouts.

title: In Connecticut, Landmarking Is Fragile
description: The first stages of rehabilitation have begun on Connecticut's newest national historic landmark, the 209-year-old homestead of Oliver Ellsworth in Windsor, eight miles north of Hartford.

title: Hers;   A Forgiving Land
description: Hands up, American!'' Second Treasure said in Vietnamese. She poked my ribs. ''You're under arrest!''

title: Fighting Words From Ordinary People
description: LEAD:

title: Peru's Poor Feel Hardship of 'Fuji Shock' Austerity
description: As an armed soldier stood guard, Carlos Gomez struggled to keep up with spinning numbers on a gas-pump meter. A gallon of premium had jumped from 41,800 intis to 1,200,000 intis.

title: Grady Takes 2-Shot Lead in P.G.A.
description: Wayne Grady, perhaps golf's most accomplished runner-up, will try to fight off the man who used to hold that dubious distinction in the final round of the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday.

title: Eason Sparks Jets' Offense
description: The most intriguing drama of the Jets' summer of change emerged in the first half of their preseason opener tonight: Although the Jets led by only 3-0 at halftime, their offense had lifted noticeably after Tony Eason replaced his good friend Ken O'Brien at quarterback in the second quarter.

title: Marjorie Williams Marries
description: Marjorie Curtis Williams, a reporter for The Washington Post, and Timothy Robert Noah, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, both in Washington, are planning an October wedding. The couple's parents are Beverly A. Williams of Princeton, N.J., and Alan D. Williams of Jersey City, and Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Noah of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
description: James Gleick's article ''The Census: Why We Can't Count'' (July 15) gets to the heart of our diminished capacity to collect accurate data on a large scale. The Census Bureau has (admirably, I believe) carried out the census it planned. However, the size, diversity and mobility of our society have rendered time-honored cenus methods imprecise, at best. We still employ counting techniques pioneered 200 years ago, when Secretary of State Thomas Jefferson sent out 600 marshals on horseback.

title: Kalen Donaldson Marries
description: Kalen Leigh Donaldson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney Donaldson of San Rafael, Calif., was married yesterday at Incline Village on Lake Tahoe in Nevada, to Stephen Rudd Best, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Best of Weston, Conn. The Rev. James F. Thompson performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Best is an advertising-editorial planning coordinator at People magazine in New York. She is 30 years old and a graduate of California Polytechnic State University. The bridegroom, 36 and a graduate of American University, is the production operations manager at Fortune magazine in New York.

title: NIRVANA IN GRAND CENTRAL
description: THE EXPERIENCE OF PLACE

description: To the Editor:

title: Norah P. Martin Engaged to Marry
description: Judith Draper Martin of Red Bank, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Norah Penhold Martin, to Edward P. H. Burden, a son of Mrs. A. Guilford Tobey of Marblehead, Mass., and the late William A. M. Burden 3d. A September wedding is planned.

title: Hector Barrantes, Duchess of York's Stepfather, 51
description: Hector Barrantes, the stepfather of the Duchess of York in Britain, died on Friday, the family said. He was 51 years old.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Risotto And Spinach, Attractive And Easy
description: The bright green of lightly cooked spinach and the creamy white of rice make an appealing package.

title: U.S. Gulf Policy: Vague 'Vital Interest'
description: In his statement to the nation on Wednesday explaining the decision to send American troops to the Arabian Peninsula, President Bush said that the defense of Saudi Arabia was of ''vital interest'' to the United States. But Mr. Bush and his top aides have not clearly defined just how the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait touches the lives of Americans or affects their future.

title: Lifestyle;   Big Mac With Chopin, Please
description: Danny Deaver adjusted the ornate golden candelabrum on the black Baldwin grand, smiled and glided into his Chopin medley. A polonaise or two later, he peered down from his perch on the restaurant's balcony to acknowledge the applause of the diners below. Their tables were bedecked with fresh flowers, which also blossom in the men's and ladies' rooms.

title: It's Lilco Management That's the Problem
description: The Long Island Power Authority is the wrong agency, at the wrong time, doing the wrong job in an ineffectual and inefficient manner. The threat of taking over Lilco is no longer credible, and we certainly don't need the Long Island Power Authority to decommission Shoreham.

title: Theater School Exchange Program Gives King Lear a Russian Accent
description: In a rehearsal room of the Circle in the Square Theater on West 50th Street the other day, a young man playing Edmund in Shakespeare's ''King Lear'' raised his fist and gazed upward.

title: Why Sing the Anthem Before Games?
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Two Television Formats May Be Better Than One
description: To the fulminant debate on future television standards - which concerns the introduction of high definition television (HDTV) and its impact on existing broadcast technology - some calm but cutting observations have recently been added by James C. Davies, an executive of Barco Inc., a company that makes video projectors in Kennesaw, Ga. In the course of his arguments Mr. Davies takes a few potshots at some sacred cows. Significantly, his remarks were published not in one of the broadcasting journals but in Audio, a magazine uninfluenced by the strife in broadcasting circles.

title: The Town That Pullman Built
description: Preserved first by benign neglect and now by design, the red-brick company town of Pullman, Ill., on the outskirts of Chicago, offers the visitor a revealing course in late-19th-century industrial paternalism. Though this is textbook social history, Pullman today is very much alive, a real place where people live - people proud of their community's past.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth;   Back to Class To Study Japan And Its Language
description: Although a Dartmouth College student might spend years preparing for a Wall Street career, a group of executives is reversing the process, going from the board room to the classroom.

title: Style Makers;   Daniel Levy, Book Editor
description: Daniel Levy never edited a book before last year, and at 32 he is too young to have been involved in the tumult of the 1960's. But today the Los Angeles native is the editor of Citadel Underground and edits books about the counterculture.

title: Campus Life: Vanderbilt;   With 'Jasper,' An Adventure In Teaching Math
description: Linda Abbey, a fifth-grade teacher at the Spalding Drive Elementary School in Atlanta, has heard the same complaints about mathematics for the last five years.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portland, Ore.;

Buyer Gets Store Option
description: LEAD: A LITTLE known local investor has an option to buy a prime downtown block here owned by a financially troubled New Zealand real estate company. Until 1986, half the 40,000-square-foot site was occupied by a branch of the Frederick & Nelson department store, based in Seattle. Three smaller buildings are on the rest of the site.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

The Joys (?) of Summer, Revisited
description: LEAD: YEARS ago, to escape the heat of the city, for $500 four families would rent a six-room bungalow in the country. Having your own space meant that there were only four people using the bathroom simultaneously.

title:
DINING OUT;

A View of the Airfield in White Plains
description: LEAD: ARRIVE early, in the full light of a summery day, in order to take full advantage of this restaurant's attraction - its windows, which look onto the broad expanse of airfield bounded by a low sculptured green hillside behind which the sun sets. Diners are further entertained by the wide-screen, real-life travelogue taking place on this stage - busiest on Friday evening - and can vicariously board and disembark various flying crafts without resting a knife.

title: Elizabeth Marek, Doctoral Candidate, Married to Marc O. Litt, Law Student
description: Elizabeth Anne Marek was married yesterday at her family's home in Hillsdale, N.Y., to Marc O. Litt. Archibald S. Snare, a Town Justice in Hillsdale, officiated.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our bathroom has an imitation marble sink that has developed small black slits. Is there any way to clean or repair these slits?

title:
Northeast Notebook: Boston;

Project Aids Mentally Ill
description: LEAD: A small two-family house in the Jamaica Plain neighborhood has been renovated into two apartments for four mentally disabled adults.

title: Currency;   Looking for Other Havens
description: Last week it was what didn't happen that made the news. Despite the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the sending of American forces to Saudi Arabia, the dollar did not rise sharply. In the past, most traders would have expected the dollar to move much higher because it was considered a safe haven. But at the end of last week, the dollar was only a quarter of a pfennig stronger against the German mark than it had been before the Aug. 2 invasion. It rose a little more against the French franc but weakened against the British pound and the Swiss franc. The dollar's only area of real strength, as in past weeks, was against the yen. The muted performance would seem to indicate that expectations for the dollar are so negative that safe havens are better found elsewhere.

title: Wall Street;   Alex. Brown's Reputation in I.P.O.'s
description: In the haste to find new sources of income in slow times, Alex. Brown & Sons seems to have forgotten that on Wall Street, you are what you take public.

title: Miss Robinson Weds J. C. Brown 4th
description: Louisa Law Robinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Robinson of Pottersville, N.J., was married yesterday to J. Crosby Brown 4th, a son of Mrs. J. Crosby Brown of Blue Hill, Me., and the late Mr. Brown. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John's on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Postings: Coming to White Plains;   14 Modest-Income Condos
description: With state subsidies in place, plans are advancing for a 14-unit condominium in White Plains for buyers with modest incomes. A one-bedroom apartment would cost $95,991 and a two-bedroom $112,181, said Jane Henderson, executive director of the White Plains Housing Information Service, the not-for-profit developer. Income limits would be 78 percent of the Westchester County median, which currently means $28,185 for one person and $40,363 for a family of four. The project, at Fisher Avenue and Bank Street, was designed by Nadler Philopena & Associates of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Steinbrenner Had Early Tie to Spira
description: Throughout the commissioner's investigation of George Steinbrenner's association with Howard Spira, the Yankee owner argued that baseball should also look into the connection between Spira and Dave Winfield. Spira, Steinbrenner contended, became involved on the periphery of baseball through Winfield.

title: Ms. Smyke Wed To D.S. Moskin
description: Camela Irene Smyke and David Scott Moskin were married yesterday at the Meeting House in New Marlborough, Mass., by the Rev. William A. Johnson, an Episcopal priest.

title: How a Meadow Complements a Lawn
description: A MYTH has risen among some gardeners about lawns. They think they would rather substitute a meadow in the belief that it would be much easier to keep. ''All you have to do is plant seed, and voila, a meadow!'' So they say.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Why Should I Settle on L.I.? There Are Reasons, But Then Again...
description: LEAD: OUR friends call it ''Long Guyland'' in deprecating tones. Their letters to us come with sarcastic headings - ''From BEAUTIFUL Long Island.'' They are the Island's unwilling guests, our fellow graduate students. As soon as they can, they'll sever ties to the State University at Stony Brook and settle in Massachusetts or Montana or someplace but not, if they can help it, on Long

title: Present at the Commission
description: Time and the seven-figure auction prices have proven them right, these men and women who first collected and commissioned Impressionist art. Their taste has meant enough to history and the marketplace to warrant several books. IMPRESSIONISM: The First Collectors (Abrams, $75), however, isn't one of them. Anne Distel, a curator at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, has produced a series of sketches so obedient to the first law of biography - tell them what it cost - they read more like appraisers' notes than art history. There are a few delightful details: the novelist Edmond de Goncourt takes a swipe at Charles Ephrussi (one of the models for Marcel Proust's Swann). The textile dealer Ernest Hoschede puts together one of the best collections of his time, then loses his fortune to his creditors and his wife to Claude Monet. The millionaire Louisine Havemeyer, who later donated more than 50 Impressionist paintings to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is arrested and jailed after a suffragist protest, which horrifies her respectable friend Mary Cassatt. If you want more than tidbits, however - if you need a narrative thread to tie things together - you had better look somewhere else. Ms. Distel has not produced a study of the early collectors and dealers of Impressionist art; she has tossed off rough sketches of them. By rights, even these, together with plates of paintings by Manet, Renoir and the other Impressionists, should hold your attention - haven't you wondered, after all, about all those patrons whose faces now stare into yours in museums? But read more than one sketch at a time, and your curiosity will die an untimely death. Ms. Distel appears oblivious to the simplest rules of biography; she ignores questions like: why did they collect art? and lingers, instead, on the vagaries of price. The book's problems are exacerbated by Barbara Perroud-Benson's translation; it's full of French syntax that sounds silly in English.

title: Betty Burnham Hinckley, Executive, 67
description: Betty Burnham Hinckley, president of the real-estate firm of Wood Associates of Greenwich, Conn., died on Thursday at Greenwich Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in the Riverside section of Greenwich. Her family said she died of renal cancer.

title: Reasons Signs 2-Year Contract
description: The Giants added another missing body today when Gary Reasons, a seventh-year inside linebacker, signed a two-year contract for more than a million dollars. Coach Bill Parcells said Reasons might play Monday night against the Bills in Orchard Park, N.Y., in the Giants' first preseason game.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Hamptons Investor Market Moribund
description: LEAD: When Frank Tramontano, a Montauk developer, and E.F.S. Ventures of Sayville decided in 1982 to buy a 28-unit motel overlooking the ocean in Montauk and convert it into a co-op, fortunes were being made in such ventures in the Hamptons.

title: Meet Richard III, A Contemporary In All That's Evil
description: ''Richard III,'' Shakespeare's first enduring drama, is an extraordinary rendition of the price exacted when what is considered appropriate to manly behavior shades first into violence and finally into acts of ultimate brutality.

title: INSIDE
description: A 6-Year-old Wins a Matisse in Court

description: To the Editor:

title: New Haven Welcoming Volvo Tennis Tournament
description: LEAD: WHEN the weeklong Volvo International Tennis Tournament begins tomorrow in New Haven, the stakes will be high for both the players and the city. For the first time in its 19-year history, the event's total prize money will exceed $1 million. And for the first time, the tournament is being held in a city.

title: Miss Cozzarelli Weds M. B. McCann
description: Kathleen Mary Cozzarelli, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James D. Cozzarelli of Chalfont, Pa., was married there yesterday to Michael Brian McCann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. McCann of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. James W. Devlin performed the ceremony at St. Jude Roman Catholic Church.

title: New Deployment in Gulf May Slow Drive for Deep Cuts in Military Budget
description: The commitment of American forces to the Arabian Peninsula is altering the debate over the military budget, promising to slow the momentum for deep spending cuts and to hasten a shift in military planning from superpower standoffs to regional conflicts.

title: THE WORLD: Excerpts;   Fighting The War of Words Over Kuwait
description: ''Since 1980 when we were at war, we faced circumstances which were as difficult as the war itself because they affected our economy and basic resource, namely, oil. There was confusion in the oil market. There was lack of abidance by OPEC decisions. . . . We say that war is fought with soldiers and harm is done by explosions, killing and coup attempts, but it is also done by economic means sometimes. . . . I say that those who do not mean to wage war on Iraq, that this is in fact a kind of war against Iraq.'' - President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, addressing closed session of Arab summit meeting in Baghdad, May 30.

title: Children's Fashion;   Fantasies a la Eloise
description: Thirty-five years ago, a 6-year-old named Eloise first stampeded through the corridors of the Plaza Hotel, and children are still enchanted by her kinetic escapades. So what better way to celebrate the anniversary of Kay Thompson's story, with illustrations by Hilary Knight, than to return to the scene of Eloise's crimes. As fall approaches, velveteens in deep forest green, navy and bright red are in order. And what little girl wouldn't love lace and tulle. For both boys and girls, earthy tweeds - with colorful matching or contrasting jackets and pants - are ''in'' this season.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION: DINING OUT, PRETENTIOUSLY;

Strictly for the Summer Crowds
description: LEAD: NOTHING trendy about this place. Open summers since 1988, Pour Les Hommes d'Ete gives every indication of being with us for several seasons to come.

description: MUSICAL IN THE MAKING

title: Data Update
CORRECTIONS
description: A headline last Sunday on the Business Diary page, with a report about troubles in Chicago commodities trading, referred incorrectly to the market involved. It was the Chicago Board of Trade

title: John Briggs Jr., 74; Critic Who Handled Media for Toscanini
description: John G. Briggs Jr., a music critic who once served as Arturo Toscanini's press agent, died on Friday at the Cooper River Convalescent Center in Pennsauken, N.J.

title: Another Futile Campaign Reform
description: LEAD: The good news is that the House and Senate are finally moving on long overdue campaign finance reform. The bad news is that the bills both houses have passed combine the worst elements of change into a whole that is much less than the sum of its parts.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DAYS AT THE U.N.

title: Historical Violin Styles: Myth and Reality
description: A staple remark in criticism of the string playing that comes out of Juilliard - and criticism is inevitable, since such a high proportion of the best young instrumental talent passes through that venerable school - runs something like this: ''They're taught to play everything in 19th-century Russian style.'' It isn't just because I teach at Juilliard these days that I think this is nonsense; the least exposure to the style in question will dispel the notion at once. They don't even play Tchaikovsky, let alone everything, in 19th-century Russian style.

title:
The Executive Life;

Fleeing the Office, And Its Distractions
description: LEAD: Here is a fascinating figure: A 1989 survey of 521 of the nation's largest companies found that 40 percent of their employees who work from home are men, and that 88 percent of them are managers. This deflates the myth that women on maternity leave make up the overwhelming majority of corporate America's home-bound work force.

title: THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
description: Gleick is not convincing in arguing that a statistical sample would produce an improvement over the actual census count. The imperfect art of sampling, and the inevitably political selection of the ''right'' adjustment formula, would add entirely new sources of distortion to the census results. Gleick seems to forget that we are not talking about stars or fish. We are talking about the American people, who must be located and counted (not sampled) in a constitutionally mandated way. We are a representative democracy, not a sampled one. There is not a member of Congress who hasn't heard of a ''highly detailed survey sample'' which has called an election incorrectly. Will the next proposal be to hold elections by survey sampling because election participation is is too low?

title: Volume Is to Weight as Distance Is to . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, a Bright Side to the S.& L. Bailout
description: By common agreement, the savings and loan bailout is a major financial debacle for everyone except depositors, whose money is safe because of Government guarantees. The cost is borne ultimately by the American taxpayers.

title: Commercial Property: X-Rated Tenants;   The Sun Is Setting on the Times Square Porn Palaces
description: Twilight seems to be near for the gaudy, raunchy, blazingly public pornographic emporiums in and around Times Square, many of which - by a curious circumstance - are now tenants of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Ties Are Sizzling With Individuality
description: Neckties, you may have noticed, are loosening up a little. Gone with the wind are those lockstep power ties that turned gray suits into Wall Street uniforms. In their place are wider, splashier, more individualistic ties that put zip into any suit, regardless of its color. Most of these ties trace their roots to Italy, or more specifically, Florence, and their designs, roughly, to the school of Pop Art. The glow-in-the-dark prints of Pucci, which are making a big comeback in women's fashion, are also showing up on ties. So is a vaguely Warholian influence, evident on the tie in the middle at far right that is splattered with grocery labels. This, clearly, is a tie that can stand up to a soup stain.

title:
Focus;

Buying into a Full-Health-Care Facility
description: LEAD: A growing population of well-to-do elderly people in the San Francisco Bay area is creating a market for retirement communities that offer equity ownership and full-service health care in luxurious surroundings. Two are operating, one is being built and a fourth is being planned.

title: David Lynch Pushes America to the Edge
description: Four films and a hit television series have established David Lynch as the reigning master of locating the bizarre, the surreal and the disturbing in American life, and his new film, ''Wild at Heart,'' which opens Friday, is certain to further that reputation. ''I like people who are in trouble, in darkness and confusion,'' Mr. Lynch said recently during an interview on the set of his much-acclaimed TV series ''Twin Peaks.''

title: Bank Contributors
description: To the Editor:

title: Food;   Creating a Stirrer
description: When my daughters grow up, i want them to be just like Matthew Johnson.

title: Miss Sherman Weds A. M. Shainberg
description: Robin Sherman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall D. Sherman of Short Hills, N.J. was married yesterday evening to Andrew Mead Shainberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond M. Shainberg of Memphis. Rabbis Barry H. Greene and Harry K. Danziger, assisted by Cantor Norman Summers, officiated at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills.

title: Scarves From India and Beyond
description: The filmy, long scarf known as the dopatta, whose function was once limited to preserving the modesty of Muslim and Sikh women on the Indian subcontinent, has burst out of purdah and into the world of fashion. In silk or cotton or weightless organdies, block-printed, woven, tie-dyed, embroidered or ''crinkled,'' the 6-to-8-foot-long scarf, made by fashion houses rather than clothing factories, is a best seller in Indian and Pakistani boutiques.

title: U.S. Group, Including Girl, Allowed to Leave Baghdad
description: After several days of negotiations, 10 Americans attached to the United States Embassy in Baghdad and a 10-year-old California girl who was caught in the invasion of Kuwait crossed the scorching Iraqi desert today into the relative tranquillity of this neighboring Arab country.

title: Open Tickets
description: To the Editor: A wonderful part of air travel used to be the ''open ticket,'' which meant passengers could use their prepunched airline tickets whenever they wished. Open tickets still exist, but they cost an arm and a leg. Most nonbusiness budget travelers are locked into nonrefundable, nonchangeable flights.

title: U.S. Reduces Bonus for Operator of A-Plant
description: Unhappy with the pace of the environmental cleanup at its uranium processing plant in Fernald, Ohio, the Energy Department has decided to deny three-quarters of a $1.67 million semiannual bonus to the company that manages the plant for the nation's nuclear weapons manufacturing complex.

title: Gardens Losing Ground to Development
description: LEAD: BEVERLY AND DANIEL CENTER own a comfortable home with a spacious yard in New Milford. But the past 14 summers they have planted their flowers and vegetables in a community garden at the Eliot Pratt Education Center, because their property has too much shade for a garden to thrive. In New Haven, Serena Spruill and her five children depend on the hundreds of pounds of producethey harvest each year at the Inner City Co-op

title: Carolyn Ross Is Married
description: Carolyn Mary Ross, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Ross of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to John Andrew Stephenson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stephenson of Mt. Kisco, N.Y., by the Rev. Charles A. Ribado at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. Mrs. Stephenson, 26 years old, graduated from Syracuse University and received a master's in school counseling from Long Island University. Her husband, also 26, graduated from the College of Environmental Science and Forestry at Syracuse and is a law student at Pace University.

title: Robert W. Cleveland, Executive, 80
description: Robert W. Cleveland, a road builder and heavy-equipment supplier, died on Thursday at the United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y. His family said he died of lymphoma. The company that bears his name was the contractor for road work at several major projects in the 1930's and 1940's, including the New York World's Fair of 1939-40 and the Pentagon in World War II. Since 1948, Mr. Cleveland has been a dealer for Caterpillar tractors and other equipment, first in Harrisburg, Pa., and later in Armonk, N.Y.

title: Eugenia Sawin Marries Charles Gauvin
description: Eugenia Waterman Sawin, a daughter of Martica R. Sawin of New York and David M. Sawin of Saunderstown, R.I., was married yesterday to Charles Frederic Gauvin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Normand E. Gauvin of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. John Ineson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Episcopal ceremony in the Old Meeting House in Yarmouth, Me.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our bathroom has an imitation marble sink that has developed small black slits. Is there any way to clean or repair these slits?

title: Northeast Notebook: Raymond, Me.;   A King Builds His Castle
description: Sitting on a hill in a modest neighborhood in this town of 4,000 year-round residents is a house the locals call the Castle on Mill Street. It belongs to William King, an architectural draftsman and graphic designer who has been building the 5,000-square-foot dwelling himself, cinderblock by cinderblock, for 18 years.

title: Abby Westervelt, Doctoral Student, Wed to Hayden Pelliccia, Professor
description: Abby Brown Westervelt, a candidate for a doctorate in classics at Harvard University, and Hayden Newhall Pelliccia, a professor of classics at Cornell University, were married yesterday at the summer home of the bride's parents in Warwick, R.I. The Rev. Frank H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Campus Life: Texas;   Treating a Phobia: A Few Minutes In the Dark, Alone
description: Since January, Doron Ilai, a 31-year-old graduate student in clinical psychology at the University of Texas, has helped 60 undergraduate volunteers confront one of their worst fears: claustrophobia.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Teaching the Easy

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Raymond, Me.;   A King Builds His Castle
description: ''I wanted a grand foyer, curved walls, an elliptical stairway, a ballroom and cathedral ceilings,'' he said. ''When you combine all that, this is what it comes together as. Some people say it looks like a French chateau, others a Norseman's hunting cabin.''

title: Rights Abuses by Manila and Rebels Are Reported
description: The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines and the Communist insurgents there have violated the international laws of war governing armed conflict, says a report issued today by Asia Watch, a nonprofit organization that monitors violations of human rights.

title: Exoneration Sought in Mutiny of '44
description: Forty-six years after the Navy convicted 50 black sailors of mutiny for refusing to load ammunition on ships after an explosion killed 320 men, an effort has begun to exonerate them.

title: A Walk Through the Pacific
description: Peter Chermayeff was flying home from Japan two and a half years ago when he looked out at the Pacific and saw the answer to his problem.

title: Q and A
description: By Freighter to Australia

title: Correction
description: An article on July 22 about an increase in the number of women on corporate boards misstated the age of Catalyst, a research and advisory organization for women in the business world. Catalyst is 28 years old; its Corporate Board Resource service, which helps place women on boards, is 13 years old.

title: Kristin L. Powers Weds K.T. Rover
description: Kristin Lynne Powers, a banking executive, and Kevin T. Rover, a lawyer, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Minikahda Club in Minneapolis by the Rev. Dr. Harold G. S. King, a minister of the United Church of Christ.

title: Protesters Say Navy Boats Ran Over Them
description: Two advocates of the protection of dolphins say they were intentionally run over by Navy boats on Friday when they tried to demonstrate against a test involving explosives earlier in the day off Key West.

title: Bad Genes
description: GENOME

title: 'In the Shadow of the Dome'
description: To the Editor:

title: What Price Courage?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Threat Facing Cardiac Surgery Unit
description: If Valley Hospital's cardiac surgery unit is closed, lives will be lost (''Cardiac Surgery Unit Fights for Its Life,'' July 15).

title: This Middle Eastern Play Is in Rice
description: SINCE Iraq invaded Kuwait, some investors have been prowling for ways to benefit from the turmoil in the Middle East. One ''Iraq play'' that has been spotted involves Erly Industries Inc., a Los Angeles-based food processor whose 2.8 million shares are trading at $7.125 over the counter. Like other thinly capitalized stocks, the shares have fallen modestly since the invasion, but speculative investors think they will drop further because of a disclosure in the company's annual report that one short seller described as ''too good to be true.''

title: Taking His Mark
description: The lifetime ban of Ben Johnson has proved to be short-lived. Canadian officials announced last week that Mr. Johnson would once again be allowed to compete for his country. The West Indian born Toronto sprinter was told he could never again run for Canada after he forfeited a gold medal in the 1988 Olympics for using steroids. Marcel Danis, the Canadian Sports Minister, said he lifted the ban on the recommendation of a panel that investigated drug use in athletics after Mr. Johnson's Olympic debacle caused national embarrassment. The panel found that performance-enhancing drugs were widely used. The lifting of the Canadian ban means that the 28-year-old sprinter will be eligible to rejoin the national track team in September, when a two-year international ban ends. ''I am very, very happy that I can run for this country again,'' he said.

title: At the End of the Oregon Trail
description: It's hard to imagine an American beyond the age of 12 who doesn't know a thing or two about the Oregon Trail. Rugged pioneers and their prairie schooners rank up there with the people on the Mayflower as historical archetypes. But even those who can manage a glib discourse on Manifest Destiny or identify the year when the Great Migration began might have trouble pinpointing where the pioneers' journey ended.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Dr. James P. Comer;

'All Children Need More Support'
description: LEAD: THE school-development program popularly known by educators as ''the Comer Method'' operates on the principle that to help troubled children achieve in class, schools must focus on issues like social development, family life, relationships, self-esteem and personal values.

title: Managing;   Keeping the Talented People
description: FACT: A lot of Americans have hit their mid-40's - the age at which, traditionally, bright people step onto the lower rungs of the upper management ladder.

title: A Gallery Celebrated For New Art in 50's
description: LEAD: AFTER spending a year or so sifting through records detailing what happened more than three decades ago at the Signa Gallery, the Hamptons' first commercial art showcase, Alfonso Ossorio was in a self-congratulatory, ''I-told-them-so'' mood.

title: Providence Journal;   World War Long Over, But Not The Battles
description: Behind a tiny American flag on his office desk, Cliff Wilson, the state commander of the American Legion, talks of Pentagon cutbacks, glasnost and the current Middle East crisis with cool detachment.

title: Exxon Is Sued On Price Rises
description: The Attorney General of North Carolina filed a lawsuit Friday against the Exxon Corporation, charging the oil company with deceptive trade practices, and a judge issued an injunction to stop the practices from continuing.

title: Americans Turn the Tables And Buy a British Agency
description: During the last decade, acquisitive British advertising agencies snapped up some of Madison Avenue's most famous names - Ogilvy & Mather; Ted Bates; Compton; Backer & Spielvogel and J. Walter Thompson.

title: Running Long on Consistency
description: CAL RIPKEN JR. hasn't missed a day's work in more than eight years, an impressive enough achievement for a bus driver, a college professor or a stockbroker. It is all the more remarkable in that Ripken is the Baltimore Orioles' shortstop.

title: Bishop Warns That Corruption Could 'Sink' Kenya
description: In an unusually broad attack on corruption, a prominent church leader charged Saturday that misuse of power for economic gain had become the norm among Government officials.

title: Iraqi Invasion Adds To Markets' Problems
description: The world's stock markets have quickly declined since Iraq invaded Kuwait 12 days ago. But the invasion's dramatic impact merely exaggerated the problems already troubling the world markets.

title: Red Sox Open 3-Game Lead
description: Marty Barrett hit a tie-breaking two-run double in the ninth inning today that sent the Boston Red Sox past the Seattle Mariners, 7-2.

title: Jumping Squabble
description: GIVEN the squabble over who would represent the United States Equestrian Team in show jumping at the 1990 World Equestrian Games, which wound up in Stockholm last week, you would have thought it was the riders who did the jumping and the horses who hung on for dear life rather than the other way around.

title: Business Scene;   Airlines in Pull Of Global Magnet
description: THE changes wrought by airline deregulation since 1978 go on and on. Many fares were cut drastically. Routes within the nation were revamped. The industry became concentrated in the hands of nine major carriers. And now globalization is bringing a new upheaval.

title: Skulls Found: Japan Doesn't Want to Know Whose
description: A little more than a year ago, construction workers cleared the site of an old government building to erect the new National Institute of Health and unearthed something that left them a little shaken: 35 human skulls and thighbones that appeared to date to World War II.

title: Reviews/Music;   Hip-Hop With an Accent And a Plea for Community
description: Soul II Soul's concert at the Palladium on Friday night sputtered along amiably, a sort of pleasant variety show. The group, which looked as if it were going to dictate the future of pop and dance music with its ''Keep On Movin' '' album from last year, has a new record plummeting down the charts; the Palladium was nowhere near full, and the future of pop music is now up for grabs.

title: No Loss of Eloquence
description: DURING the 38 seasons that Byrum Saam broadcast baseball in Philadelphia, he was known as much for his non sequiturs as he was for his eloquence. That's partly because the 75-year-old Saam, who was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame last week, never worked for a pennant winner.

title: Helen Drees Ruttencutter, Writer, 63
description: Helen Drees Ruttencutter, a musician and a writer for The New Yorker magazine, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan at the age of 63. Her family said she died of a brain tumor.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf: Man in the News;   Mediator Turned Risk-Taker; Hosni Mubarak
description: For a man long known for his caution, President Hosni Mubarak has put himself in a hot seat, at the center of a storm he himself warned could be ''horrifying.''

title: Review/Television;   Recalling Watts Riots And the Fires' Kindling
description: If earnest intentions could do the job, ''Heat Wave,'' tonight's play at 8 on the TNT cable network about the 1965 rioting in the Watts area of Los Angeles, would make for a more exciting two hours. The writer, Michael Lazarou, is not lacking in sympathy for the young black men who burned and looted through most of that hot August week. He attempts to get across the feelings of hurt, hatred and hopelessness that fueled the explosion. But his message is so framed in the conventions of television drama that at times it seems to be based less on a week that shook the nation than on years of prime-time shows that lull it to sleep.

title: Pakistan's New Government Arrests Supporters of Bhutto
description: Pakistan's new Government began rounding up supporters of the ousted Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, today.

title: Stephen Zimmerman Weds Miss Sloves
description: Judith Leslie Sloves, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Sloves of Yonkers, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Zimmerman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Zimmerman of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Solomon W. Sternstein was assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery in performing the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Curt Warner Is on a Mission
description: CURT WARNER, the Seattle Seahawks' leading career rusher, remembers standing on the sideline at the Kingdome last season while Steve Largent was honored as a Seahawk for all seasons. Largent's No. 80 jersey was retired and Largent received tribute after tribute for his dedication, loyalty and production as one of the finest receivers in pro football history.

title: Americans Focus On Who Will Lead
description: While the United States national soccer team played the consolation match of the Marlboro Cup of New York tournament at Giants Stadium today, some people in the stands were focusing on the question of who will be coaching the team in future competitions, including the 1994 World Cup.

title: Bush's Double Gamble
description: If President Bush loses the gamble he took in pledging that Iraq's conquest of Kuwait ''will not stand,'' he might turn out to be a loser in American politics too.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-11

title: Disabled Veterans Eager to Take Shot at Gold
description: GEORGE KUSTYN, Frank Jones and Haskell Manson, three disabled military veterans, were sitting around a table at a Veterans Affairs medical center in Canandaigua, N.Y. In a place where old war stories are often told and retold, swapped, embellished or simply invented, their conversation was anything but stale.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   An Old Desert Hand Commands U.S. Forces
description: As head of a command once viewed as something of a misfit in the Pentagon's organizational charts, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf finds himself playing a pivotal role in the largest United States military operation since Vietnam.

title: Reviews/Music;   All of Lazar Berman's Power Is on Display at Rutgers
description: In 1976, when the cold war was cold indeed, Lazar Berman appeared virtually unannounced from behind the Iron Curtain and provided the West with an exotic glimpse of a secretive Soviet musical life. On his first United States tour, Mr. Berman made an overwhelming impression as a pianist of great physical power - a performer who did more than just overcome technical problems; he seemed to crush them into insignificance.

title: Linda Fessler Is Marries
description: Linda Beth Fessler and Michael Jeffrey Weinstein were married yesterday at Temple Ohr Torah in North Woodmere, L.I., by Rabbi Theodore Jungreis. Mrs. Weinstein is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Fessler of Merrick, L.I. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Weinstein of Jericho, L.I. The bride, 26 years old, is a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology and is the art director at Quadriga, a publisher of religious greeting cards in New York. The bridegroom, 26, is a student at New York Law School. He is a graduate of Cornell University.

title: A Soviet Film Re-creates History, But It Makes History in Hollywood
description: James Cagney, Pat O'Brien and Humphrey Bogart made ''Angels With Dirty Faces'' on this set, and Warren Beatty used it when filming ''Dick Tracy.'' The so-called Tenement Street lot at the Warner Brothers studio here is hardly the place one would expect to find a Soviet film crew busy at work, but a Soviet actor, Lev Lemke, playing Leon Trotsky, stood patiently in front of an apartment building facade the other morning, waiting for a cue from his director, Leonid Maryagin.

title: Still Raining After 7 1/2 Hours
description: In what may have been the longest rain delay in baseball history, the Texas Rangers and the Chicago White Sox waited . . . and waited . . . and waited.

title: Time Stops for Lawyers Awaiting Jogger Verdict
description: Time seems to have stopped for almost everyone involved in the Central Park jogger trial as the jury deciding the fate of three defendants charged with the rape and attempted murder of a jogger deliberated for a fourth day yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: Miscellany
description: * Chiat/Day/Mojo has sold the assets of a public relations subsidiary, Jessica Dee Communications, New York, to the firm's management. Patrice Tanaka, the general manager and creative director at Jessica Dee, will be the president and chief executive of the new company, to be called Patrice Tanaka & Co. Chiat/Day/Mojo bought the unit in 1987.

title: Freeze on Iraqi Assets Expected to Cost U.S. Banks Little
description: The freeze on Iraqi and Kuwaiti investments and bank deposits announced by President Bush and officials of other Western countries last week is not likely to be costly to American banks, according to Government data and bankers' estimates.

title: Japan Beer Sales Surge
description: The Japanese are reacting to one of the hottest summers in years by consuming beer in record amounts. Beer sales are rising at such a rapid rate that the Kirin Brewery Company, Japan's top brewer, has raised its profit forecast twice since February. Kirin attributed part of its recent profit growth to strong demand for its new Ichiban Shibori beer.

title: India Says Troops Kill 24 in Kashmir Raid
description: Government troops reported killing 24 people in a raid on Friday on two villages in the Kashmir valley in search of Muslim separatists who had ambushed an army convoy.

title: Dump Toxic Wastes Off New York Beaches?
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors: Fishing In a (Bigger) Crowd
description: IT used to be that the only crowd anybody ever noticed on the Missouri River was a tower of tricos, a gray cloud of flies 30 feet high at the water's edge an hour or two after sunrise. A welcome crowd, for when the flies mated and fell to the water in midmorning a frantic hour or two of trout feeding and trout fishing followed.

title: Coutts Journal;   In Canada's Big Sky Country, Eyes Turn South
description: The bearded trucker finishing his pancakes at the Hillview Cafe called himself Big Dog, his call-sign on the citizen's band radio as he takes oil pipes, produce and other loads from Texas, Oklahoma and California into Canada.

title: New Boom In U.S. Oil Is Doubted
description: Executives of American oil companies say they do not expect the sudden jump in crude oil prices to stimulate exploration and drilling because they have not yet been convinced that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will have a long-term effect on prices.

title: Bridge
description: If you are defending with a A-10 holding that surrounds an honor on your right, it might seem obvious to cover if that card is led. But honors should not be covered routinely, and it may be right to play low even if, as in the diagramed deal, everyone knows that the other defender has nothing in the suit.

title: Wendell G. Randolph, Chemical Engineer, 94
description: Wendell G. Randolph, a chemical engineer who played an important role in developing gas masks for the United States Army in World War I and who later headed a family concern that produced industrial paints, died on Monday at his home in Saddle River, N.J. He was 94 years old.

title: Cambodia Seeking Direct Talks With the U.S.
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia has expressed hope that the United States will talk directly to his Government on ending the long war in his country.

title: FEARING RECESSION, AMERICANS SKIMP ON VACATION COSTS
description: Recession looms across America, and wary vacationers are camping out, eating in and heading home early to save a few dollars.

title: In New York's Parks, More Litter and Less Money
description: Newspapers blow across the dusty, threadbare Great Lawn of Central Park. Abandoned cars block a running path in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. Citywide, trees that were once regularly pruned and meadows that were once regularly sodded now receive infrequent care.

title: Western Union Replaces Workers
description: The Western Union Corporation has locked out most of the 2,500 unionized employees who are negotiating a new contract with the communications company.

title: Blaze Destroys Museum's Fire Dept. Display
description: A Fire Department display room in a landmark building was destroyed in a fire here today believed to have been set, fire officials said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it is a good thing that we don't have a field of announced candidates. I think the public can't take three-year Presidential races. They get bored. Candidates get stale.''

title: Reviews/Music;   Simply Ignoring Everyone Else's Rules
description: Sonic Youth tears rock apart from the inside out. All that its listeners can depend on, most of the time, is a basic brute-force drumbeat; above it, Sonic Youth sets free the riotous discord and primal noise that virtually all popular music confines in conventional harmony and ordinary song forms. Sonic Youth doesn't produce chaos - its songs are mapped out as precisely as any pop hit - and its members don't posture as rebels; they sing in unaffected voices, and between songs, they're calm and casual. Sonic Youth simply ignores everyone else's rules.

title: Autocracy and Democracy in the Sand
description: The House of Saud. The Emirate of Kuwait. The United Arab Emirates.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, a front-page article on Saturday about the outcome of the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry of Washington appeared twice in some copies, and a report on the effects of the international embargo of oil from Iraq and Kuwait was omitted from those copies.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 12:

title: Possible Suit by NBC Union
description: A major union at NBC said Friday that it would probably go to court to fight the network's contract proposal that the company plans to impose on Wednesday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allstate Insurance Co., Northbrook, Ill., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co., promoted Rita P. Wilson, a vice president, to senior vice president of corporate relations, effective Sept. 1. She replaces Lawrence H. Williford, who is retiring.

title: McEnroe's Major Priorities: Blend of Family and Tennis
description: ON the tennis court, his terms remain totalitarian. He stalks his stage like a maestro, and before issuing the inimitable strokes that trill forth from his racquet like music, he wants to hear a pin drop.

title: New Yorkers Get to Tell It Like It Is
description: Hoping to leave their marks on history, hundreds of New Yorkers bared their souls to a Sony Camcorder last week for a video time capsule of life in New York in 1990.

title: United Artists Shifting Theater Unit's Officers
description: Peter Warzel has been named president and chief executive of the newly created office of the president at United Artists Theater Circuit Inc., the theater exhibition subsidiary of the United Artists Entertainment Company, the cable and movie theater company that is based in Denver.

title: Only Cypriots Can Settle Cyprus Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Lifeline Systems Inc., Watertown, Mass., a provider of computerized health-care services, to Cabot Advertising, Boston, with a budget of $1.5 million.

title: Review/Dance;   At Jacob's Pillow, Escapes In Dreams and Simplicity
description: The Dayton Contemporary Dance Company is a remarkable troupe. As impressively involved with the past as with the present, the company made both come alive in a rousing performance here on Saturday night in the Ted Shawn Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   A Rightist Israeli Legislator Named Ambassador to U.S.
description: Israel's Cabinet today appointed a member of Parliament, Zalman Shoval, to be Ambassador to the United States.

title: Chronicle
description: In northwest Connecticut, there is a celebrity tennis tournament of a distinctly different sort. The public is not invited, the players are discreet if not sheepish when talking about it and trophies are given for the worst players.

title: Who's to Pay Wins In Saratoga Upset
description: Who's to Pay, who just before the race didn't have a rider, collared Steinlen, who nobody thought could lose, to score a two-length upset victory today in the $88,200 Bernard Baruch Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Amid Mosaic Of Moods, Mayor Runs A Wary Ship
description: David Norman Dinkins is a man of moods, and eight months into his term as Mayor of New York City, his aides have learned to judge them by the satiny warm-up jackets he works in. If he appears in his favorites -gifts from the pop singer Janet Jackson or the Grammy Awards organization - the day is fine.

title: A's Remain Perfect Against the Yanks
description: The games have become so predictable that it isn't so much a question of if the Yankees will lose as it is when. By the time this afternoon was over, they had lost again to the Oakland Athletics, and they seemed to have no explanation for the way things had gone over the weekend.

title: Biker Rally Ends in Violence
description: Gang violence erupted at the end of the Black Hills Motor Classic, a motorcycle rally that attracted more than 300,000 bikers to this town of 6,000 people. A barroom fight Saturday between the Outlaws and the Sons of Silence left three people in serious condition in a hospital, two with stab wounds and one shot. In all, 11 motorcylists died in the week-long event: nine in the 108 traffic accidents, one of carbon monoxide poisoning and one shot by a police officer after he went berserke with a 22-inch knife.

title: Topics of The Times;   The Beach as Ashtray
description: Finding a clean patch of sand has become a real challenge on public beaches and playgrounds. There may be fewer smokers but they seem to leave ever more cigarette butts behind.

title: Ms. Rubin Is Bride Of Paul J. Goldberg
description: Julie K. Rubin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Rubin of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul J. Goldberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Goldberg, also of Merrick, at the Lyman Estate in Waltham, Mass. Rabbi Henry Zoob officiated. The bride graduated from the University of Massachusetts and received a master's degree in audiology from Purdue University. She is on the communications disorders faculty at Emerson College. The bridegroom, a graduate of the University of Rochester, received a master's in social work from the University of Michigan and is the case management supervisor at Somerville-Cambridge Elder Services, a social agency in Somerville.

title: Sports of The Times;   Cookie Lavagetto's Double
description: Cookie Lavagetto, who died at age 77 in his sleep Friday morning at his home in Orinda, Calif., was famous for one thing: He was the Brooklyn Dodger who struck a celebrated pinch-hit in the 1947 World Series. Thoughts of Lavagetto the ballplayer led to the notion here that great moments in sports don't last as long as they used to.

title: Topics of the Times;   Double-Barreled Fashion
description: ''Man is unique among the animals in wearing clothes,'' the fashion historian James Laver wrote once, ''and the question arises as to why he should do so.'' After dismissing modesty and protection against the weather as possible reasons, Mr. Laver came up with what he described as a ''scientific answer . . . so remote from our modern notions that we have to make some effort of the imagination to understand it at all.'' His answer was magic.

title: Japan Stocks Fall Sharply
description: Tokyo stock prices tumbled more than 5 percent today on the widespread selling of long cash-index positions by futures arbitragers before regaining nearly a percentage point. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 1,153.12 points, or 4.22 percent, to close at 26,176.43.

title: Commercials Get a New Star: Television
description: FORGET about product benefits, emotional bonding or any of the other conventions of effective advertising. These days, television commercials are increasingly about television.

title: Soviet Area Seeks Sovereignty
description: The autonomous republic of Karelia on the Finnish border has declared sovereignty, the official press agency Tass reported. Karelia, home to 700,000 people, declared that its constitution and laws took precedence over those of the Soviet Union and of the Russian republic, in which it is located, Tass said.

title: Dr. Weissman Weds Adam Goodfarb
description: Dr. Audrey Michelle Weissman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Weissman of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Adam Davis Goodfarb, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Goodfarb of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Solomon Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Transcript of U.S. Statement About Measures Against Iraq
description: Following is a transcript of the statement on measures to be taken against Iraq made today by President Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: A Youth Tennis Program Is Serving the Underprivileged
description: TENNIS has long been considered an elitist sport in the United States, but recent programs have begun to tap the rich vein of athletic talent in America's poorer big-city neighborhoods.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Off in the Bunkers Of a Golfer's Mind
description: LEAD: IN some quarters in golf, if you are accused of using psychology, your accuser probably means you have done something underhanded, such as asking an opponent if he inhales or exhales before starting his backswing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Myths About Hussein and Iraq
description: LEAD: The defusion of the crisis in the Persian Gulf hinges to a great extent on a realistic and dispassionate analysis both of the personality of Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, and of Baghdad's political objectives and military capabilities. Unfortunately, the prevalent assessment of these two factors is fraught with grave misperceptions and myths.

title: Protection From Sun
description: Athletes who spend long periods outdoors are susceptible to overexposure to the sun. A new product, Sun Spots, has been designed to reduce the problem by signaling when it is time to reapply sun screen to the skin.

title: Miss Graham Wed To C. S. Wachtel
description: Michelle Lynn Graham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Graham of Warren, Ohio, was married yesterday to Clifford Scott Wachtel, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Wachtel of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Matis Blum performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Proposals by Iraqi President: Excerpts From His Address
description: Following are excerpts from the address on the Persian Gulf crisis made by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, carried by Baghdad radio and the official Iraqi News Agency and translated from Arabic by The Associated Press:

title: Tap Dancers and Parade Welcome Sun's Return
description: Just before New Yorkers forgot what that self-luminous, gaseous yellow sphere up in the sky looked like it made a cameo appearance yesterday.

title: Karen Perlmutter Weds Neil Koffler
description: Karen Wendy Perlmutter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Perlmutter of Greensboro, N.C., was married yesterday to Neil Harrison Koffler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Koffler of Newport Beach, Calif. Rabbi Harvey Goldman was assisted by Faith Joy Smith, a rabbinical student, in performing the ceremony at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel in South Orange, N.J.

title: Mets Routed by Surging Cubs
description: The Mets want you to know they are not in a swoon, a slump or even a sinking spell. Not even after losing 6 of their last 10 games and 2 straight to the Chicago Cubs. And don't waste your time fretting over Frank Viola just because he has been kayoed the last two times out and won only twice in his last seven starts.

title: Liberian Loyalists Slow Rebel Drive
description: Government troops mounted a successful counterattack today, dashing rebel hopes of seizing the capital before a West African task force arrives to impose peace.

title: Chronicle
description: CHARLES SAATCHI and KAY HARTENSTEIN wed quietly in London recently. Mr. Saatchi, 47 years old, is a major art collector and co-founder of the advertising conglomerate, Saatchi & Saatchi. Ms. Hartenstein, 37 years old, has been described in the British press as an art dealer and sold ads from 1984 to 1986 for GQ in New York City.

title: Previous Exports to Iraq May Prove Costly for U.S.
description: President Bush's freeze on Iraqi assets and financial dealings may prove costly to the United States Government, which has guaranteed the payment of $1.7 billion that Iraq owes for the purchase of American farm products.

title: Need for Lower Rates Stressed by Analysts
description: How soon will the Federal Reserve move to reduce interest rates and will the cuts be deep enough to ward off a recession that many economists believe is already gripping the nation?

title: Crisis at Top Loan Insurer: A $1.5 Billion 'F'
description: The nation's largest guarantor of student loans is facing a financial crisis because its borrowers defaulted on $1.5 billion in obligations in the last two years. And on Capitol Hill, some legislators are saying that the $2 billion the Treasury spends each year on student loan defaults is a sign that the Government's policies toward such loans are lax.

title: Review/Theater;   Reeve Resurrects Death as a Charming Stranger
description: As the title character in ''Death Takes a Holiday,'' Christopher Reeve has another role commensurate with his larger-than-life presence. Replacing his bright Superman cape with a cloak of spectral darkness, he is a not-so-Grim Reaper. More than anything, it is the actor's drollness that helps invigorate this creaky vehicle, revived at the Williamstown Theater Festival.

title: Cards Complete Sweep of Pirates
description: Bob Tewksbury pitched a six-hitter and Todd Zeile had a homer and double as the St. Louis Cardinals got a season-high 17 hits and beat the slumping Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-0, today for a three-game sweep.

title: Group Says It Has Freed 2d Swiss Hostage
description: A group calling itself the Palestinian Revolutionary Squad said today that it had released a second Swiss hostage in Lebanon, a relief worker for the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Despair, Calm and Disdain Greet Mobilization at Bragg
description: For the second time in eight months, thousands of soldiers here have said swift goodbyes and answered a President's call to action, leaving behind frightened families who study foreign maps and wonder why their fortunes have suddenly been pitted against those of distant dictators.

title: Unearthing of Freed-Slave Cemetery May Put Dallas Road Project on Hold
description: The Freedman's Cemetery, burial place of as many as 2,000 freed slaves and their descendants, has sat just off the North Central Expressway ever since the road was built over some of the graves 50 years ago.

title: Ms. Leahy Weds Adam Weinberg
description: Christine A. Leahy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Leahy of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Adam E. Weinberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Weinberg of Old Westbury, L.I. The Rev. Eliot Daley, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Morton Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Mountain Lakes Preserve.

title: William E. Foley, Judicial Officer, 79
description: William E. Foley, the Federal judiciary's chief administrative officer from 1977 to 1985, died Saturday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 79 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: The S.& L. Cleanup Advances - Slowly
description: The first anniversary of the savings and loan bailout bill has brought forth a predictable one-two punch from Republicans. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady proclaimed that everyone should ''rise above the political blame game.'' And the Republican National Committee ran ads blaming the Democrats.

title: Market Place;   A Wary Response To 'Junk' Auction
description: INSTABILITY in the Middle East has unnerved many investors and led some ''junk bond'' portfolio managers to stay away from an auction of securities last week, the founder of a new trading system says.

title: Reviews/Music;   Britten's 'Albert Herring' Is Given a Sylvan Setting
description: Everything about Glimmerglass Opera's final production of the season, Britten's ''Albert Herring,'' which opened this evening in the Alice Busch Theater, bespoke painstaking preparation. In fact, the staging was not entirely new, but an outgrowth of a production mounted last summer by the company's Young American Artists Program.

title: Heinz Contract For O'Reilly
description: The H. J. Heinz Company has signed its chief executive, Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, to a five-year contract that includes options to buy four million shares of stock, company officials said Friday.

title: Grady Captures P.G.A. Title
