description: In a duel between two players battling their own histories as much as each other, Wayne Grady transcended a career of near misses today while Fred Couples remained a prisoner of his past in the final round of the 72d P.G.A. Championship.

title: Rebels Reported to Kill 119 in Sri Lanka
description: Tamil gunmen rampaged through five fishing villages on Saturday night, killing Muslims in the street with machine-gun fire and machetes, military officials said today. They said at least 119 people were slain.

title: Salzburg Guggenheim Offshoot Exists in Hopes and Blueprints
description: Amid the ceremony of the opening night at the Salzburg Festival last month was another premiere, less noticed perhaps but with names just as big as the festival's Jessye Norman and Seiji Ozawa.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   And Now the 'B Word' (Do Not Say Blockade)
description: The Bush Administration's reluctance to call the blocking of Iraqi commerce on the high seas a naval blockade apparently reflects legal and political concerns about using a word associated with declared wars.

title: G.M. Strike in Michigan Imperils Industry Talks With Union
description: A four-day-old strike at a General Motors Corporation parts plant in Flint, Mich., is affecting other G.M. plants around the country and is influencing bargaining between the Big Three automakers and the United Automobile Workers union.

title: Question Box
description: Hitless More Than Once

title: A Beach in Virginia Is Closed After Explosives Are Found
description: A mile of beach has been closed here after 28 explosive shells, some of which may date to the Civil War, were discovered in sand dredged from the Chesapeake Bay.

title: Camacho, Star of Ring and Ballroom
description: In a ballroom of Caesars Tahoe late Saturday night, Hector Camacho came to party.

title: Gorbachev Denounces Estonia's Declaration
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today denounced the latest separatist declaration by the Baltic republic of Estonia and said it was invalid under Soviet law.

title: Next Life, I'll Be White
description: LEAD: In my next life, I shall certainly aim to come back a white person - make that a white male.

title: They Must Not Die for a Lawyer's Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Zerline Goodman Is Wed at Vassar
description: Zerline L. Goodman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Goodman of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Andrew Rothenberg, a son of Dr. Eleanore Dubin Rothenberg and Stanley Rothenberg, both of New York. Rabbi Charles Feinberg performed the ceremony at the Vassar College Chapel.

title: Modified League
description: GIVEN the rampant popularity of rotisserie league baseball, it is not surprising that a group of bankers, lawyers, politicians, brokers and other businessmen and entrepreneurs who club together in Pennsylvania would start a league of their own.

title: Steinbrenner Decision Leaves Room for Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: They Must Not Die for a Lawyer's Mistakes;   Unjust Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Scotti D'Arcy, Record Producer, 67
description: Scotti D'Arcy, a producer of poetry records and theatrical works, died on July 18 at the Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J., where she lived. Her death, at the age of 67, resulted from pneumonia and respiratory failure, a family spokesman said.

title: Ape Trainer Wins Suit Against Rights Group
description: A Las Vegas showman was awarded $4.2 million on Saturday in his defamation lawsuit against an animal rights group that made public a videotape of his striking his orangutans.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BUSH ORDERS NAVY TO HALT ALL SHIPMENTS OF IRAQ'S OIL AND ALMOST ALL ITS IMPORTS
description: President Bush ordered the United States military today to block exports of Iraqi oil and all imports to Iraq except some food shipments, Administration officials said. The blockade would fulfill the President's threat to halt Iraqi commerce.

title: Indian Powwow Has Religious Origins
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Lawrence Weds Miss Gault
description: Barbara Stewart Gault, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Gault of San Francisco, was married yesterday in Rutherford, Calif., to Robert Prescott Lawrence, a son of James Lawrence of Brookline, Mass., and the late Martina Brandegee Lawrence. The Rev. Victor Ta Wei, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Beaulieu Gardens.

title: Emily Taravella Weds
description: Emily Johannah-Marie Taravella, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Taravella of Queens, was married yesterday to Mark Andrew DiTaranto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent DiTaranto of the Bronx. The Rev. John C. Mulqueen performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Catholic Church in Ozone Park, Queens. Mrs. DiTaranto, 27 years old, graduated from New York University, as did her husband, and received a law degree from St. John's University. She is an associate with the New York law firm of Stockfield & Fixler. The bridegroom, 24, is a third-year law student at Georgetown University.

title: Pennsylvania Job Cuts
description: JLG Industries said Friday that it planned to cut 150 workers at its plant here because of a previously reported softening in its incoming orders. The latest reductions are in addition to the elimination of about 135 positions at some of the company's foreign and domestic plants, JLG said. It said current levels of unfilled orders are at 45 days' sales. The manufacturer and marketer of hydraulic machinery said that after the reductions its work force would total about 1,400.

title: Don't Destroy the C.I.A. - Renovate It
description: LEAD: With the end of the cold war, U.S. intelligence agencies clearly need reforms that may involve substantial reductions in personnel and budgets. As Iraq's bid to control the Persian Gulf has shown, the fortunes of the U.S. will continue to depend in part on political and military intelliegence.

title: People
description: * Beth Rockwood has been named director of media planning at the New York office of Young & Rubicam. The agency also named George Sharpe to the new position of director of media business development. Don Davis, Carla Loffredo and Diane Spencer have been named group media directors.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE OIL JOLT

title: Political Memo;   Few Approach Starting Gates For 1992 Presidential Stakes
description: In the world of presidential politics, nothing much is happening in Panora, Iowa, these days, or Lansing, Mich., for that matter. And that is big news. After more than a decade of complaints that the American process for selecting its presidents had become too long, too grueling and too expensive, it can be announced here today that the 1992 race for President will be shorter.

title: Peekskill Seeks to Stop New Homeless Shelter
description: Frank Wilson was one of the last speakers a few weeks ago when more than 350 people gathered in a library meeting room to protest the construction of a $3 million shelter for the homeless in this small river city.

title: Treasury Will Sell Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late Friday the rate was 7.40 percent on the three-month bill and 7.29 percent for a six-month bill.

title: Sara Seegar, Actress, Dies at 76; Worked in Theater, Films and TV
description: Sara Seegar, an actress who appeared on and off Broadway, in films and on television, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. She was 76 years old and lived at Stone Meadows, Newtown, Pa., with her husband, the actor Ezra Stone, who said she died of a cerebral hemorrhage.

title: Chronicle
description: Los Angeles and New York lie far apart in many ways, but they draw closer for two days next month. About 100 Angelenos are flying east to hear ANDRE PREVIN lead the Los Angeles Philarmonic at the benefit opening on Sept. 26 of Carnegie Hall's centenary season.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   2 of Iraq's Pilots Are Said to Bolt
description: Two Iraqi Air Force pilots have defected by flying their MIG planes to a base in northern Saudi Arabia, diplomats in the Middle East said today.

title: Illegal Guns: Go Get Them
description: In Brooklyn, a young woman leaving early for work hurries back inside her vestibule. In the schoolyard across the street, the kids are shooting again. Now she can see the fire leaping from the muzzles of their semiautomatics. Each year, she reflects, the shooters seem a bit younger. These kids look to be no more than 13 years old.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Many Prominent Americans Support the President's Action in the Gulf . . .Resistance to Blatant Aggression, Defense of Allies and, Above All, Oil
description: Henry Kissinger

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Books of The Times;   An Ill-Tempered Look At the Clock's Tyranny
description: Keeping Watch

title: A Rallying Hurst Wins the Amateur
description: Pat Hurst of San Leandro, Calif., rallied from three holes down to capture the 90th United States Women's Amateur Championship today in 37 holes over Stephanie Davis of Bainbridge Island, Wash.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Oil Crisis Like 1973's? It's Not Necessarily So <
description: The jump in oil prices and drop in supplies stemming from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will do far less damage to the world's economy than did the 1973 and 1979 oil shocks, economists and energy experts say.

title: Leslie MacGregor Wed in Connecticut
description: Dr. Leslie Catherine MacGregor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rob Roy MacGregor of South GLastonbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. David William Levine, the son of Judith F. Levine of New York, and the late Arthur T. Levine. Rabbi Emily F. Korzenik officiated at the Castle Inn in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

American Plastics Chief 'Intrigued' by Its Process
description: LEAD: American Plastics and Chemicals Inc., a start-up company seeking to develop an economical process for manufacturing plastics, has named William Morris its president and chief executive.

title: Rookie Passer Eyes Giant Job
description: When the Giants face the Buffalo Bills in Orchard Park, N.Y., tonight in their first exhibition game, they plan to use four of their five quarterbacks. They will start the season with two or three.

title: Metro Matters;   Youths and City Decay in Schools Of Indifference
description: A few days ago, while reading a newspaper, Martin Cohen saw a face out of the past.

title: Complication On Asbestos
description: The fragile alliance forged last week by 10 Federal judges trying to coordinate and resolve quickly tens of thousands of asbestos personal injury disputes will complicate settlement talks in many large cases, making their immediate resolution much more difficult, lawyers and judges said yesterday.

title: Orion Sees Its Financial Star Fade
description: The summer has been brutally competitive in Hollywood, but perhaps no studio has more at stake than Orion Pictures, one of the last small independent companies.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Aid Helped Hussein's Climb; Now, Critics Say, the Bill Is Due
description: For 10 years, as Iraq developed a vast army, chemical weapons, nuclear ambitions and a long record of brutality, the Reagan and Bush Administrations quietly courted President Saddam Hussein as a counterweight to Iran's revolutionary fervor. Now, critics say, Washington is paying the price for that policy.

title: INSIDE
description: The Mayor's Satiny Moods

title: Months After Pipeline Fireball, Village Scars Remain
description: Along Route 30, the main road that runs past the Schoharie Creek, there is a blackened void in the center of this village. Trees have been burned away, and all that remains of a dozen homes and stores are charred stone foundations.

title: Dr. George Parks, 56, Professor And Pace Business School Dean
description: Dr. George M. Parks, dean of Pace University's Lubin Schools of Business, died on Saturday while scuba diving in Bermuda, the university said yesterday. He was 56 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Barry Says He Will Continue to Serve Community
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today that he intended to remain active in community life in the nation's capital, but he refused to disclose whether he would run again for elective office.

title: Rubella, Not Measles, Causes Birth Defects
description: To the Editor:

title: Zunis' Effort to Regain Idols May Alter Views of Indian Art
description: There is a secret shrine on a sage-covered hill in the heart of the Zuni Reservation where Indians exercise a radically new concept of their property rights every time it rains or snows, every time the sun bears down with the heat of the day.

title: The Changing City; Woodside, Queens;   New Accents and Old Brogue Quietly Reshape Woodside
description: Madge O'Boyle stood in front of the apartment building in Woodside, Queens, where she has lived for three decades, since shortly after the Irish native arrived in the United States, and chatted with neighbors on the sun-baked steps.

title: Like Oil and Taxes, Paperbacks Are Going to Cost More
description: The $5.95 paperback - a mainstay of bookstores and airports - is going the way of the 2-cents plain, the 25-cent candy bar and, in New York, the $6 movie ticket and the $1 subway token.

title: Ilysse A. Feingold Is Wed
description: Ilysse A. Feingold, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin L. Feingold of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven G. Moss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Moss of Old Bethpage, L.I. Rabbis Arnold Turetsky and Alexander Shapiro co-officiated at the Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Mrs. Moss, 24 years old, is a cum laude graduate of Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., where her husband also graduated summa cum laude. She is a doctoral candidate in school psychology at Yeshiva University. The bridegroom, 24, attends the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: O'Brien Starts; Eason Stars
description: Rather than take credit for rousing a moribund Jets team, Tony Eason seemed more intent on explaining why his good buddy Ken O'Brien didn't do as well as he did at quarterback Saturday night.

title: Susan M. Levin Is Wed
description: Susan M. Levin, a daughter of Charlotte S. Levin of Wilmington, Del., and the late Dr. Jules S. Levin, was married yesterday to Dr. David A. Liebergall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon S. Liebergall of Suffern, N.Y. Rabbis David Wolpe and Leonard Gerwirtz co-officiated at Temple Har Zion in Philadelphia. Mrs. Liebergall, 24 years old, and her husband, 26, both graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. She is a second-year student at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, from where the bridegroom received an M.D. He is an intern at the Greenwich Hospital.

title: Europe's Quick Pace May Slow a Bit
description: The higher oil prices that are likely to be the legacy of Iraq's military moves in the Middle East will slow but not stop the buoyant economy of Western Europe, economists say.

title: In Soviet Georgia, Unity On Self-Rule Falls Apart
description: Sitting on a hotel balcony with the soaring peaks of the Caucasus Mountains at his back and two hawk-eyed bodyguards watching him from below, Zviad Gamsa khurdia recently offered his view on the cut-throat world of Georgian politics.

title: Ronit Amir Lowenthal, Pianist, 56
description: Ronit Amir Lowenthal, a pianist and teacher, died on Thursday in Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: S.A.S. Stabilizes Its American Niche
description: Jan Carlzon, the president and chief executive of Scandinavian Airlines System, does not suffer from delusions of grandeur.

title: Velischek Traded
description: The New Jersey Devils yesterday completed payment for the acquisition of Peter Stastny, the 33-year-old center, in a trade with the Quebec Nordiques last March 6. At the time, the Devils sent Craig Wolanin, a defenseman, to Quebec, but promised one more player. Yesterday, they named Randy Velischek, a 28-year-old defenseman, who played in 62 games last season for the Devils, scored no goals, was credited with six assists and logged 72 penalty minutes.

title: Resistant Bacteria a Concern in Poor Nations
description: ANTIBIOTIC-resistant bacteria seem to be more prevalent in certain parts of the world, particularly in developing countries, suggesting that such bacteria could become a serious public health threat, according to a new study.

title: Texas Gas Pipeline Sold
description: KCS Group Inc. said today that it had signed a definitive contract to acquire 90 percent of a 150-mile intrastate natural gas pipeline in Texas from the Morgas Company of Conroe, Tex., for $21.5 million. It said the Moran family, which controls Morgas, would retain a 10 percent interest. KCS said the 12-inch main line runs from north of Houston to 20 miles northeast of Madisonville, and six lateral lines connect to multiple sources of natural gas supply and market outlets.

title: Barry Quits Party to Be an Independent
description: In a move that was both technical and political, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. left the Democratic Party today and declared himself an independent, a position that allows him to seek re-election as Mayor or a seat on the District of Columbia City Council.

title: 'Rogue Computer' Faulted for Bad Parking Tickets
description: A ''rogue computer'' used by New York City's Parking Violations Bureau is responsible for $19 million worth of tickets issued annually to people who do not own cars, people whose cars have been stolen and people who have paid their fines, City Council President Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

The Agency Divested By an S.& L.
description: LEAD: The crisis in the savings and loan industry has forced many ailing institutions to divest themselves of some of their unconventional holdings. The sales have included ''junk bonds,'' artwork and, in one case, an advertising agency.

title: Three Mets Ready to Face Hefty Fines
description: The Mets, still waiting for penalties to fall on three of their star players for participation in the free-for-all with the Philadelphia Phillies last week, said yesterday that they expected hefty fines but would appeal any suspensions.

title: 'Boot Camps' for Rikers Island
description: With some success, prison systems in New York and a few other states have established ''boot camps'' to ease crowding and provide a more constructive routine for young prisoners. Allyn Sielaff, New York City's new corrections commissioner, proposes such a system for the city's jails; he makes a good case.

title: Road Still Rough for Black Candidates
description: Just a year after L. Douglas Wilder made history in Virginia by becoming the first black elected Governor of a state, national attention has been focused on the chances of new breakthroughs by black candidates for governor in Georgia and South Carolina and for the Senate in North Carolina.

title: Dow Up 30.20 in Late Rally; Trading Light
description: The stock market recovered from an opening slump to finish sharply higher yesterday, showing resiliency in the face of uncertainty over Middle East developments.

title: Gold Rises Above $400; 5-Month High
description: Prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday, fueled by the Middle East crisis. Gold jumped to more than $400 an ounce for the first time in five months.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Joe Morgan Couldn't Play At the Club
description: Rusty Staub and Joe Morgan were teammates and friends with the Houston Astros in the mid-1960's and shared an interest not only in doubles and double plays, but in drivers and divots, too. So Staub, a member of a nearby country club, had naturally taken Morgan as his guest to play golf at this club a few times.

title: Sun Microsystems Plans Stock Offer
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said it planned to offer 5.9 million new shares of common stock together with about 1.1 million shares to be offered by individual stockholders. Of the shares to be sold, 5.6 million will be offered in the United States by Goldman, Sachs & Company, Salomon Brothers Inc. and Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Guards, Angered by Assault by Inmates, Block Entrance to Rikers
description: Hundreds of correction officers, protesting the assault and robbery of another officer by inmates last week, blocked the entrance to Rikers Island yesterday.

title: B. Kliban, 55, a Cartoonist Who Drew Zany Cats
description: B. Kliban, an art-school dropout whose cartoons of hordes of round-eyed, striped cats became a multi-million-dollar craze, died Sunday at the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco, two weeks after undergoing heart surgery. He was 55 years old and lived in Corte Madera, Calif.

title: Trump Is Said to Name First Boston as Adviser
description: Donald J. Trump will use the First Boston Corporation rather than Merrill Lynch & Company to reorganize some of his casino debt, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose last week for the first time in three weeks, jumping by 26, to a total of 992, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year earlier, the count was 858. Ike Kerridge, a vice president of Baker Hughes, said the increase might be related to the Iraqi oil embargo.

title: Our Towns;   Parents Work, So Camp Means Catching the 7:37
description: ''Thomas, do you care if your peanut butter sandwiches are squished?'' Nancy Inglis called to her 9-year-old, racing to get him ready for day camp. The humidity was so bad that the white bread had swollen. ''Oh, well,'' she said, smooshing in two sandwiches. The stove said 7:07.

title: Chess
description: On hearing of the Franco-Polish grandmaster Savielly Tartakover's pronouncement, ''Sacrifices only prove that someone has blundered,'' you might be inclined to put it down as just one of the witticisms for which he was always ready to sacrifice the truth. It's not entirely invalid, although it is an exaggeration to claim that beautiful games must take their start in gross errors.

title: U.S. Aide Visits Syria After Talks in Cairo
description: An Assistant Secretary of State arrived here from Cairo today for his second visit to Syria in two days, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: Why This Odd Ethnic Scrutiny of Latins?;   Xuxa, as in Shoeshine
description: To the Editor:

title: Burden of Breathing
description: Q How much carbon dioxide does the average person exhale into the atmosphere each year? Could this make a significant contribution to the burden of greenhouse gases?

title: Hard Questions Dog Carolina Unification
description: To the Editor:

title: Expanding Democracy in Georgia
description: In Georgia, a runoff election is required if no candidate receives 50 percent of the vote in a primary. The Justice Department says that's a form of racial discrimination, not a prudent exercise of democracy. The department's lawsuit is a new and welcome sign of sensitivity to civil rights by the Bush Administration.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD SET IN G.M. STRIKE
description: The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation today reached a tentative agreement that could end a parts plant strike that has forced eight other plants to close or curtail operations, a company spokesman said.

title: Despite Flaw, Hubble Finds New Stars
description: Despite its serious optical flaws, the Hubble Space Telescope has provided scientists with a detailed look into a prolific star-forming area, clearly showing 60 stars in an area once thought to have only 27 stars.

title: Board Ultimatum Denied by Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company categorically denied a report that its chairman, Edward A. Brennan, had been given an ultimatum by its board of directors last week to shape up the company's sagging retail operations or leave. Crain's Chicago Business reported today that Mr. Brennan had been told at a directors meeting last Wednesday that he had six months to achieve marked improvement in retail profits. Crain's attributed the report to unidentified board members.

title: TLC Beatrice Net Up
description: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., a multinational food products company operated by the financier Reginald F. Lewis, reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income doubled, to $17.5 million, from $8.8 million in the corresponding period last year. The company's revenue increased 26 percent for the quarter, to $403.7 million, from $320.5 million in the period last year. The company said its earnings were helped by increased earnings from its ice cream subsidiaries, which benefit from higher sales during warm weather. The company is based in New York and has operations and wholesale and retail food distribution in France and throughout Western Europe. TLC Beatrice consists of 20 operating units in 25 countries.

title: Review/Television;   Maria Shriver Joins Prime-Time Race
description: Tonight, at 10 P.M., NBC brings on the latest entry in the 1990 prime-time network news magazine glamour stakes. ''Cutting Edge With Maria Shriver'' follows close upon NBC's ''Real Life With Jane Pauley'' and CBS's ''Face to Face With Connie Chung,'' which have made fast starts from the post. If ''Cutting Edge'' does as well in the ratings, Ms. Shriver will be back in other specials as the fall season hits its stride.

title: Shutdown at Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would idle its Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar assembly system at its Lorain, Ohio, assembly plant for one week because of a shortage of interior trim materials. The shutdown is effective today. The Thunderbird-Cougar assembly system employs 2,700 hourly employees on two shifts and builds about 5,600 units weekly, Ford said.

title: A New Interest in Taxing Trades
description: Events in the Middle East have revived concern on Wall Street about the prospect of a securities transfer tax - something the financial community is dead set against.

title: Pakistanis Agree to Join Defense of Saudi Arabia
description: Pakistan agreed today to join an international force deployed to defend Saudi Arabia against Iraq.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Dips
description: Japan's trade surplus shrank 10.3 percent in July from the period a year earlier, largely because of increased imports, the Finance Ministry said last week.

title: Con Ed Fire Knocks Out Power, Disrupting Wall St. and Subways
description: A four-alarm fire in an electrical substation knocked out power to the skyscrapers of lower Manhattan yesterday, disrupting financial markets, darkening trading floors, trapping hundreds of people in elevators and forcing thousands of others to walk down endless shadowy flights of stairs lighted by emergency beacons.

title: The Endowment: A Reflective Defense of It and a Show That Tweaks It;   Sending Helms A Message From Home
description: ''The homosexuals are in a battle against American values,'' the speaker says. ''Their ultimate aim is to have the American people accept the proposition that their perverted 'life style' is as worthy of protection as race, creed and religion. I do not buy that. I say to them, 'Bosh and nausea.' ''

title: Backup Computer Is Balky On Craft Exploring Venus
description: One of the Magellan spacecraft's backup computers rejected commands when a memory chip failed, but the problem is not expected to hinder the $744 million exploration of Venus, engineers say.

title: Rare Owl May Face New Peril
description: IN at least two cases, the rare northern spotted owl has bred with the more common barred owl, but scientists say it is too soon to tell whether the crossbreeds are isolated quirks of nature or the progenitors of a new owl species.

title: Labor Pact Is Ratified At U.P.S.
description: A strike against the United Parcel Service of America Inc., the world's largest package shipper, was averted today when drivers and handlers rejected the recommendation of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' leadership and narrowly ratified a new three-year contract.

title: Burning Plants Adding to Nitrogen
description: SCIENTISTS have known for years that nitrogen, the gas that makes up 78 percent of the Earth's atmosphere, is pumped into the air by microbes that convert nitrates in the soil into nitrogen gas. Now scientists in Germany have suggested that there is another way the gas is released into the atmosphere: through the burning of trees, plants and grass by humans.

title: Ex-Judge Named to Study Action Under Asbestos Plan
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn took the first steps yesterday toward carrying out a national plan for resolving asbestos personal injury cases. Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein said that he had appointed Marvin E. Frankel, a former Federal judge, as a special master to conduct hearings on part of the plan.

title: A Profession Divided Is Finding It Hard To Teach Prevention
description: THE ultimate goals of medicine are to prevent illness and to promote public health, and thus many would expect them to be a prime focus of medical education.

title: Workers Take Holiday In Midst of a Calamity
description: Men and women, jackets off and ties askew, streamed out of the emergency exit doors of the World Financial Center by the hundreds, and Marjorie Greenberg, a 22-year-old recruiter for American Express, was leading the pack. She vaulted onto the West Side Highway just after 2:30 and hailed the only visible taxi leaving the downtown maw, looking as elated and thankful as an American serviceman hauling himself onto the last chopper out of the American Embassy compound in Saigon.

title: Gorbachev Restores Rights To Victims of Stalinist Abuse
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today issued a sweeping decree to restore the rights of unrehabilitated victims of Stalinist repression, saying thousands of innocent people still bore a ''stain of injustice.''

title: Why This Odd Ethnic Scrutiny of Latins?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheney Orders Navy to Sharply Cut Submarine and Destroyer Programs
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has sharply scaled back the Navy's Seawolf attack submarine program and has trimmed the service's purchase of new destroyers, the Pentagon said today.

title: Judge Blocks Law on Access To Sex Calls
description: A Federal judge yesterday blocked enforcement of a law that would have prevented telephone customers in New York from reaching ''dial a porn'' numbers without first requesting access to the services.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allen Group., Melville, L.I., an automotive products manufacturer, completed two separate acquisitions: the purchase of a 50 percent interest in a new-partnership joint venture with Metropolitan Air Research Testing Authority, Nashville, and the purchase of 80 percent of the stock outstanding of Grayson Electronics Co., Lynchburg, Va. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 2 Japan Banks' Ratings Cut
description: Moody's Investor Service said today that it had downgraded the long-term debt ratings of Japan's Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and Fuji Bank, two of the world's five largest banking companies.

title: Light Into a Black Box
description: FOR most people, a computer - like a VCR, an automatic teller machine, or perhaps even an automobile - is a ''black box.'' You do something to it, it does something in return, and what happens in between, within the box, is a mystery.

title: Careers;   Executives Cautiously Optimistic
description: A survey on the views of American business leaders was released last week, and the findings indicated a ''guarded optimism'' about the economy. Because of the Middle East crisis, an update was quickly made to get the executives' reaction. They supported President Bush's stand.

title: Environmentalism vs. Jobs Troubles Taos
description: In isolated pockets of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, it is possible to gaze for miles and lose track of the century.

title: Books of The Times;   A Man's Fight for the Rain Forest
description: The World Is Burning

title: Jordan Denounces U.S. For 'Explosive' Tactics
description: King Hussein of Jordan, whose position in the gulf crisis has been equivocal, accused the United States in a speech published today of creating an ''explosive situation'' that threatens the entire Middle East.

title: Market Place;   Some Lessons In Power Outage
description: The fire at a Consolidated Edison plant yesterday showed just how fragile - and resilient -the nation's trading systems are.

title: Chronicle
description: PRINCESS ANNE, the daughter of QUEEN ELIZABETH II of Britain, will be 40 years old tomorrow. The Queen's sister, PRINCESS MARGARET, will turn 60 on Tuesday. There are no official plans to celebrate either birthday, but The Daily Mail has reported that ''a bash at Balmoral'' - Balmoral Castle in the highlands of Scotland - is planned for Princess Margaret's birthday. Another British press report has said that a single royal-family party is planned to celebrate both birthdays - as well as the 90th birthday of the Queen Mother, which was Aug. 4.

title: Besieged Mohawks Face Food Scarcity in Golf Course Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: It often happens that an apparently trivial spot card assumes crucial importance in the late stages of the play. Keep your eye on the heart six on the diagramed deal, played in the final round of the Regional Swiss Team Championship in Cherry Hill, N.J., in mid-June.

title: Piniella's Prediction Proves on the Mark
description: The Cincinnati Reds, making good on Manager Lou Piniella's brash victory prediction, pushed their lead in the National League West back to a comfortable six and a half games tonight by rallying from a four-run deficit to beat the San Francisco Giants, 6-5.

title: Review/Architecture;   Gateway to America Is Once Again Ready To Greet the Masses
description: Ellis Island, the 24-acre pile of landfill in New York Harbor that was the first stop for millions of immigrants hoping to enter the United States between 1892 and 1924, is again poised for the surge of crowds. This time the visitors will be coming to see a $156 million restoration of the island's ornate Beaux-Arts main building, which is to reopen Sept. 8 as the Ellis Island Museum of Immigration.

title: Steinbrenner Son and Yanks: New Doubts Over Succession
description: With George Steinbrenner having to surrender day-to-day control of the Yankees next Monday, there are signs that the succession process is in disarray. The Yankee owner's 18 limited partners are scrambling for solutions even as they prepare to gather in Cleveland tomorrow to select a new general partner.

title: Poland's Public Schools to Offer Classes in Religion
description: Despite objections from the nation's tiny Protestant minority and qualms among senior Government officials, Poland's public schools will begin voluntary classes in religious education this fall.

title: GTE Picks President For Its New Group
description: The GTE Corporation has named Terry S. Parker president of its new Telecommunications Products and Services Group.

title: As Track Creeps South, Slow-Paced Provence Fights Fast Trains
description: France's growing network of high-speed trains may be the envy of many Europeans, but plans to extend it to the country's southern Provence region are stirring more protests than pride.

title: Editorial Notebook;   Children of Privilege, Learning
description: Gillian Williams stands at the front of Room 20 of the San Gabriel Avenue Elementary School. She directs 30 second-graders making their family trees. ''Who goes with you to Disneyland? Who goes with you on picnics?'' That her voice lacks authority is understandable; she is an unusual student teacher who only recently took over the class.

title: U.S. MILITARY FORCE POURS IN;   Americans Escape
description: The international embargo on Iraqi trade tightened noticeably today when an Iraqi tanker sailed away from a Red Sea port without taking on crude oil, and two or three other ships, according to the White House, failed to land Iraqi-bound cargoes in the Middle East.

title: Chronicle
description: The actress ESTHER ROLLE, known for her 1970's role as an iron-willed matriarch in the television series ''Good Times'' and more recently for her portrayal of the housekeeper in the film ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' was injured in a one-car highway accident on Sunday afternoon in Nevada. The driver was killed and two other passengers were injured.

title: KEY RATES
Bush Returning to Washington for Budget Session
description: President Bush is returning to Washington on Tuesday, a day earlier than scheduled, and plans to hold a budget meeting and a news conference where aides said he would prod the Democrats to come to a ''reasonable'' agreement on the budget.

title: Three New Worlds in the Mideast
description: Words: After all the aggression, alarm, councils of state, hostages and troop movements, the controversy of the instant in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis is merely semantic. Should President Bush's orders to U.S. forces to halt shipments of Iraqi oil be termed a blockade, a quarantine, an interdiction or a barricade?

title: Unequal Justice
description: An American jury sent a stern message to the Attorney General the other day: The Government of the United States should never stoop to acting like a pimp.

title: Ethyl Eichelberger, Performer, 45; Creator of a Gallery of Characters
description: Ethyl Eichelberger, a flamboyant presence on the New York theatrical scene for the last 15 years as an actor, performance artist, clown and playwright, died over the weekend at his home on Staten Island. Black-Eyed Susan, an actress who was a frequent leading lady in his plays, said that he had AIDS and had committed suicide by slashing his wrists. He was 45 years old.

title: Curtis Mayfield and 6 Others Injured at Brooklyn Concert
description: Curtis Mayfield, the musician, was seriously injured last night when part of the stage collapsed during a windstorm at a free concert in Brooklyn.

title: 2 Airlines Cut Some Fares
description: Two airlines said yesterday that they had lowered some domestic air fares for a short time. Other airlines have raised most ticket prices to account for higher fuel prices.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of a power failure caused by a fire yesterday at a Consolidated Edison plant in New York, trading was halted around 1:15 P.M. on the American Stock Exchange and the five New York futures exchanges - the New York Mercantile Exchange; the Commodity Exchange; the New York Cotton Exchange; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, and the New York Futures Exchange. Trading did not resume, and activity noted in the tables for each exchange reflects the shortened day.

title: Allied-Signal Product
description: The Environmental Protection Agency gave permission last week for Allied-Signal Inc. to begin marketing a substitute for chlorofluorocarbons, a chemicial that has been found to cause damage to the earth's ozone layer. The new substance, called HCFC 141b, can replace chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, in solvents and foam insulation, said William M. Corcoran, a spokesman for Allied-Signal.

title: Pilot in Mysterious Crash Is Indicted Again
description: A pilot whose plane crashed mysteriously off the Bahamas last year, was among four men charged today in connection with an investments plan prosecutors said was fraudulent.

title: On Horse Racing;   Allies and Foes of Sports Betting
description: Is widespread legal sports betting inevitable or preventable?

title: Cash Beats Wilander
description: Pat Cash, continuing his long journey back after severing an Achilles' tendon 16 months ago, recovered tonight to beat Mats Wilander, 1-6, 7-5, 6-3, in the opening round of the Volvo International tennis tournament.

title: Workers Strike In North Sea
description: Maintenance workers on Britain's North Sea oil platforms went on a 24-hour strike today, the fourth in a series of protests over union recognition, pay and safety.

title: The Killer Drug We Ignore
description: For years, law enforcement, policy-makers and the media have been preoccupied with the menace of cocaine and crack. In the meantime - partly as a result of our single-minded focus on cocaine - heroin has quietly and quickly extended its reach in this country.

title: IVAX Chairman Gets Ferro Stake
description: Dr. Phillip Frost, a physician who is chairman of the IVAX Corporation, a pharmaceutical concern based in Miami, has acquired a 7.7 percent stake in Ferro Corporation. Mr. Frost said he received permission in March 1989 from Government antitrust regulators to raise his stake in Ferro, a Cleveland-based chemical concern, to as high as 15 percent.

title: Black Group Sets Boycotts
description: The predominantly black Progressive National Baptist Convention ended its annual meeting today by calling on its 1.8 million members to boycott Japanese auto makers on the ground that they discriminate against black Americans.

title: Winfield Still Feels Connection to Yankees
description: The feud is over now, but it is still not behind Dave Winfield. Even though he is separated from George Steinbrenner by several months and thousands of miles, Winfield acknowledged today that he remains bound to him, and to the Yankees.

title: 200 Pilots Included In USAir Layoffs
description: USAir Group Inc., the owner of the nation's seventh-largest airline, whose profits have been hurt by industry fare cuts, said it planned to lay off 200 pilots and an unspecified number of other workers. The company, which has hubs at Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and Charlotte, N.C., said it would announce the layoffs to employees on Tuesday.

title: Simon Grolnick; Psychoanalyst, 60
description: Dr. Simon Grolnick, a psychoanalyst and a teacher, died on Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I., and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Blockade of Iraq Raises Oil Prices
description: Oil prices moved up more than $1 a barrel on world markets yesterday as traders reacted to the American blockade of Iraqi oil and the Saudi decision to turn away an Iraqi tanker that had sought to load at a pipeline terminus.

title: Kidnappers in Lebanon Release Swiss Hostage to Syrian Officials
description: Abductors in Lebanon have freed a Swiss hostage, Elio Erriquez, after 10 months of captivity, turning him over to Syrians, who took him to Damascus and released him early today to the Swiss ambassador.

title: Jay Rubin, 86, President Emeritus Of New York Hotel Union Council
description: Jay Rubin, president emeritus of the New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council, A.F.L.-C.I.O., died on Sunday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 86 years old.

title: LARGE DRIFT NETS MOVE TO ATLANTIC
description: Huge, super-efficient drift nets of the kind that ignited a storm of international protest in the Pacific Ocean have been spotted for the first time in the Atlantic near the Caribbean, raising fears that Atlantic marine life could be threatened and that commercial and sport fisheries important to the eastern United States could be devastated.

title: Masaaki Tahara, a Banker, Marries Miss Caspler, a C.P.A., in New Rochelle
description: Denise Grace Caspler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy S. Caspler of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married Sunday at her parents' home to Masaaki Tahara, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Susumu Tahara of Takamatsu, Japan. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated.

title: 2 Giants Battle in Wiring Money
description: The American Express Company, the nation's largest financial-services concern, is aggressively challenging the Western Union Corporation at a business it pioneered and has long dominated: wiring money.

title: Complicated Surgery Through Tiny Incisions
description: THOUSANDS of surgeons are learning a new technique for removing gallbladders that could greatly simplify the operations now performed on some 500,000 Americans each year.

title: Unequal Pay Widespread in U.S.
description: People who work in the same field and are of similar age and education are finding that their wages, once very close, now extend across a much wider range, new studies of Labor Department data show.

title: The Endowment: A Reflective Defense of It and a Show That Tweaks It;   Arts Adviser Says the Problem Isn't Obscenity: It's Mediocrity
description: Practically ever since the debate on the National Endowment for the Arts began to rage last year, the issue that has divided the agency's detractors and supporters has been whether the endowment has financed pornography and blasphemy or whether it has acted to protect the right of American artists to express themselves freely.

title: Treasury Security Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in a session that effectively ended shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday, after a fire in lower Manhattan led to a widespread loss of electrical power.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST, TUESDAY, AUGUST, 14, 1990
description: The Oil Jolt

title: Research Probes What the Mind Senses Unaware
description: THE power of subliminal messages is taken as an article of faith by many people. Critics of advertising often take for granted the power of ''hidden persuaders.'' Many parents stand convinced that messages buried in rock music are poisoning their children's minds. And for vendors of audio tapes, the power of the imperceptible exhortation to strengthen memory or take off pounds is more than an article of faith - it is a profit center.

title: Employer Health Care Gassed by Double Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Navy Cuts Seawolf Plan

title: Liechtenstein Applies to U.N.
description: The tiny principality of Liechtenstein, nestled between Austria and Switzerland, asked to join the United Nations in a letter to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar circulated today. Liechtenstein, with a population of about 30,000 and an area of 61 square miles, would become the 160th member of the United Nations.

title: Jogger Rape Jury Asks for String and Ruler
description: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial, in its fifth day of deliberations, asked for photographs of the victim and the testimony of a police detective who questioned one of the defendants.

title: At Least 500 Americans Manage to Flee Kuwait
description: At least 500 Americans who were trapped in Kuwait by the Iraqi invasion have been able to leave the country and more are expected to depart, the State Department said today.

title: By Design;   Highlights for Tanned Legs
description: Maybe it's just another manifestation of the current casual attitude toward clothing, but bare tanned legs are this summer's in-the-city look. It's a touch of the country come to town.

title: Business and Health;   Unions Joining Discount Plans
description: While labor unions are still actively campaigning for a greater Government role in health insurance, a growing number of them have agreed to participate in discount health-care plans. With no immediate prospects for a national system, union officials say the discount plans can help stretch the limited dollars available for wages and other benefits as health costs keep rising.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * BBS of America, Spring Valley,N.Y., an importer of German road and race wheels, appointed Percy Herrmann vice president of sales and marketing.

title: Mandela's Cause Isn't Limited to South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Concord Journal;   Saving Thoreau's Pond: Rock Stars (Who Else?)
description: The 20th century has chipped away at an idyllic tract of land that surrounds Walden Pond, where Henry David Thoreau used as a retreat to ponder the natural order.

title: Review/Theater;   A Couple Bound In Conflict
description: Near the start of the Soviet writer Sofiya Prokofyeva's two-character drama ''Sin Testigos'' (''Without Witnesses'') the wife in a marriage that came apart nine years earlier declares in a soliloquy that the submergence of her personality in her husband's became a kind of death. Now she feels nothing. The husband, for his part, complains bitterly about his wife's being a noble victim. ''Nobody marries a victim,'' he sneers. Over the course of the one-act, one-hour-and-15-minute play, which has performances through Friday at the Public Theater as part of the Festival Latino, the man and woman who have been separated for nine years circle each other warily while peeling away family secrets. The play, adapted and directed by the Argentine writer Inda Ledesma, suggests a muted chamber version of Ingmar Bergman's epic cinematic portrait of domestic upheaval, ''Scenes From a Marriage.'' Simultaneous translation from the Spanish is available on Thursday and Friday evenings.

title: Soviets Prepare to Evacuate 7,830 Citizens Still in Iraq
description: Baghdad has assured Moscow that Soviet citizens still in Iraq are not directly threatened by the Persian Gulf crisis, but the Kremlin is drawing up plans to evacuate them anyway, the official press agency Tass said today.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;

Accounts
description: LEAD: * Cosmosol Ltd. to Pedone & Partners, New York, for New Idea Hairspray, an alcohol-free aerosol, with an estimated budget of $1 million. The agency said New Idea is the only personal care product that currently meets California's 1996 guidelines for volatile organic compounds emissions, the primary cause of smog.

title: Tucurui Journal;   In an Amazon Lake, Underwater Logging Blooms
description: Perched on the gunwale of a skiff here, Juarez Cristiano Gomes chuckled to himself as he watched a trail of small bubbles rising to the surface of Tucurui Lake.

title: Some Financial Exchanges Are Brought to a Halt
description: The fire in Consolidated Edison's electrical substation yesterday brought some important parts of Wall Street's business to a halt, closing several exchanges and slowing trading.

title: Chronicle
description: B. D. WONG, the actor who was an initiator of the ''Miss Saigon'' dispute, met yesterday at City Hall with Deputy Mayor BARBARA FIFE and DENNIS DELEON, who heads the Mayor's Commission on Human Rights.

title: Pakistan Reports Clash With India in Kashmir
description: Indian soldiers tried to capture a mountain outpost, starting a firefight with Pakistani soldiers along the cease-fire line dividing the disputed region of Kashmir, Pakistan said today.

title: Rinfret Proposes Towns Bid For Waste-Site Exemptions
description: Pierre A Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial nominee, said today that he would solve the perennial problem of finding sites for landfills and garbage incinerators by forcing local governments to bid for the right not to build them.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Bank Earnings listing in Business Day on Thursday misidentified a company that had a loss of $2.9 million in the quarter ended June 30. It was the Homestead Holding Corporation, a Middletown, Pa., savings and loan holding company, not the Homestead Financial Corporation, a savings and loan and real estate development company based in Millbrae, Calif. Homestead Financial reported its second-quarter earnings on Friday and they are in the Bank Earnings listing today on page D6.

title: Don't Celebrate 1492 - Mourn It
description: Throughout the country, groups are organizing counter-celebrations of the quincentennial of the year 1492. They are preparing to counteract the official celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's landing in the Americas. A New York group, tentatively called Columbus In Context, had its first meeting last month. This is our opening statement:

title: Rafsanjani Stresses Iran's Military Role For Security in Gulf 13>
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani has declared the readiness of Iran to restore security to the Persian Gulf area and he called for the army to be put in readiness.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow.

title: Policies Uncertain, Tokyo Leader Abruptly Puts Off a Mideast Visit
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Monday abruptly put off his plans to travel to the Middle East amid indications that his advisers were divided and uncertain about how to promote Japan's interests there.

title: Order for Blockade Largely Isolates U.S. At Security Council
description: The Bush Administration's announcement that American warships are enforcing United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq left the United States largely isolated today at the Security Council, with most of the 15 members saying a new Council decision would be needed before military force could be used.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the National Veterans Golden Age Games, on the On Your Own page of SportsMonday, misidentified the man at left. He was Frank Jones.

title: 4 Die in Boardinghouse Fire
description: A fire early today in a Dallas boardinghouse killed four residents, and a fifth, Margaret Ann Wright, 46 years old, was charged with arson, the authorities said. Nine people, some of them clients of the Dallas County Mental Health-Mental Retardation Center, lived at the house, they said, but they could not confirm whether Ms. Wright or any of the victims were among them. The dead, women ranging in age from 18 to 63, were not identified.

title: Tallying the U.S. Forces in the Mideast
description: With the aircraft carrier Saratoga expected to reach the Mediterranean Sea by today, the United States will have about 10,000 ground troops in Saudi Arabia and about 20,000 sailors and airmen on more than 30 ships in the Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf region.

title: I.M.F. Position On Brazil Debt
description: The International Monetary Fund is likely to urge Brazil to agree to resume debt payments to its creditor banks before striking a new financing deal with the country, the third world's biggest debtor, international monetary officials said.

title: Liberia Rebel Agrees to Cease-Fire Talks
description: In a move that could signal a break in Liberia's military stalemate, a rebel leader agreed today to hold cease-fire talks with a group of West African leaders.

title: Every 10 Minutes, a Landing By U.S. Planes at Saudi Base
description: Every 10 minutes or so, another plane lands in the Saudi desert with American troops and equipment.

title: Bankruptcy and Success Meet in Catskills Hotels
description: Shaeri Reinsilber left her husband at home in Toronto and drove eight hours with a girlfriend to the Catskills resort region here for one thing and one thing only: the food.

title: Mandela's Cause Isn't Limited to South Africa;   Communist Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Justice Chief in U.S. For Talks on Legal Systems
description: Veniamin Yakovlev, the Soviet Minister of Justice, arrived in Washington today for a week of talks on the legal systems in the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: Antarctica Sheds Ice and Scientists Wonder Why
description: SATELLITE monitoring shows that Antarctica has shed more than 11,000 of its 5 million square miles of ice since the 1970's, and scientists say further study is needed to determine whether the findings indicate that global warming is melting polar ice.

title: Players Balk at Plan
description: Several N.B.A. players yesterday challenged the league's new pre-pension benefit plan, saying that a lowering of the salary cap as a result of the plan will hurt free agency.

title: Grant Gets a Raise
description: Horace Grant, a 6-foot-10-inch forward who averaged 13.4 points and 7.9 rebounds as a starter for the Chicago Bulls last season, has signed a $6 million three-year contract extension, The Chicago Tribune reported yesterday. The agreement would make Grant, 25 years old, the second-highest-paid Bull after Michael Jordan, and one of the highest-paid forwards in the National Basketball Association. (AP)

title: Winfield Shows Old Flair As Angels Beat Yanks
description: Dave Winfield faced the Yankees for the first time since he was traded last May and had a good laugh about it.

title: Rabies Vaccine to Be Tested on Virginia Island
description: Eight years after it developed a genetically engineered rabies vaccine, a Philadelphia research institution gained final approval today to conduct the first outdoor field trial of the vaccine in the United States.

title: Safety-Kleen Makes Management Changes
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation has announced the retirement of its chairman of the board and changes in several top management positions.

title: Player Sues N.C.A.A. Over Eligibility Rules
description: College football, already beset by whirlwind changes, is faced this week with a new legal challenge to its authority.

title: A P.G.A. Marked By Larger Matters
description: The 72d P.G.A. Championship was an amalgam of social revolution, overly severe course conditions, unexpected fades by top players and just-as-unexpected contenders.

title: Sanders Joins Falcons And Is Fined $37,000
description: Deion Sanders showed up at the Atlanta Falcons' training camp in Suwanee, Ga., yesterday minus a $37,000 chunk of his $4.4 million salary and bonuses. After going through a physical examination in the morning, Sanders suited up and practiced at cornerback for the Falcons in an afternoon scrimmage.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the Florida Democratic primary for governor misstated the home town of Representative Bill Nelson, one of the contenders. He lives in Melbourne, not Miami.

title: Any Move Toward a Peaceful Settlement Could Precipitate a Military Revolt at Home
description: As President Saddam Hussein of Iraq confronts the United States and its allies on the Saudi border, he must also watch his back against potential military enemies at home, intelligence analysts say.

title: Allied in Move For Southmark
description: Andre Danesh, the president of the Allied Financial Corporation, said today that he was in talks to raise funds to acquire control of the Southmark Corporation, the Dallas-based real estate and financial services concern that emerged on Friday from Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: U.S. Ends Soviet Curb
description: In a bid to bolster United States-Soviet trade, President Bush today raised a longstanding ceiling on the number of Soviet business people permitted to live and work in the United States.

title: Davis Team Selected
description: The team that will represent the United States against Austria in the Davis Cup semifinal round next month in Vienna will be Andre Agassi and Michael Chang in singles, and Rick Leach and Jim Pugh in doubles, the United States Tennis Association said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The foreign power's aim to re-gain control of this Arab land and those who live on it.''

title: A 9-Pound Mac Clone
description: APPLE Computer Inc. has given its blessing to a small Colorado company that makes a nine-pound Macintosh-compatible portable. The rival portable machine, called the Outbound Laptop System, is made by Outbound Systems Inc. of Boulder. It is smaller, lighter and - if you already own a Macintosh Plus or SE - less expensive than Apple's own Mac Portable.

title: 89-Yard Run By Hampton Helps Giants Beat Bills
description: When the Giants chose Rodney Hampton in the first round of the National Football League draft last April, some people wondered what they would do with another running back. They found out tonight when Hampton, on his first carry in a professional game, ran 89 yards for a touchdown.

title: Costs Rising for Chemical Industry
description: Higher crude oil prices are starting to affect prices in the chemical industry, a leading consumer of petroleum products, executives of chemical companies say. And because products derived from crude oil are used to make many of the basic materials that go into a host of other products, notably plastics, consumers will soon feel the pinch.

title: Increased Stake In Alexander's
description: Vornado Inc., the New Jersey real estate developer, said yesterday that it intends to acquire at least $15 million worth of the stock of Alexander's Inc. and perhaps as much as 25 percent of the company's common shares outstanding.

title: Review/Fashion;   Borrowing From a Sunbeam, Resort Wear Glows
description: Designers think clearly about the resort season. Their shows, presented without elaborate fanfare, are concise; the clothes are not obscured by special effects. So it is easy to catch the message.

title: Iraqis Are Reported to Send Home $3 Billion Taken From Kuwaitis
description: Iraq has transferred between $3 billion and $4 billion in gold bullion, foreign currencies and goods seized from Kuwaiti financial and commercial institutions to Baghdad, Arab bankers in London and the Persian Gulf region said today.

title: Patterns
description: Resort Comes Into Its Own

title: U.S. MILITARY FORCE POURS IN;   U.S. Alliances Recast
description: The Persian Gulf crisis is recasting the United States' relations with two of its oldest Middle East allies, Israel and Jordan.

title: Bronx Baby Killed as Father Cleans Gun
description: A 3-week-old Bronx boy was shot to death in his crib Sunday night when a gun his father was cleaning discharged, the police said.

title: Big-Screen Nostalgia With an Outdoor Twist
description: A huge screen in Central Park will mark the setting tonight and tomorrow of ''The Video Drive-In,'' a free event that will hark back, more or less, to the era of drive-in movies, when families and lovers watched the latest Hollywood romance or adventure from the relative privacy of their cars.

title: Mexico Sets Telmex Sale
description: Mexico started the sale today of its giant telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico S.A., whose privatization is a showcase for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's drive to spin off inefficient state-owned industries.

title: Loan Problem At Eurotunnel
description: The English Channel tunnel project suffered a setback today when the British-French consortium building the undersea rail link said it was having difficulty winning support for a new $3.8 billion loan.

title: Public Relations Firm to Present Anti-Abortion Effort to Bishops
description: More than 200 Roman Catholic bishops holding secretive meetings here will get their first glimpse on Tuesday of a new anti-abortion campaign put together by a public relations company.

title: Breeden Sees Industry Glut
description: The United States securities industry has ''substantial overcapacity'' that is similar to the overcapacity in the banking industry, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said here today.

title: Chinese Said to Kill 450 Tibetans in 1989
description: A former Chinese journalist says security forces killed more than 450 Tibetans in the capital of Lhasa in 1989, the Observer newspaper has reported.

title: Bethlehem Steel Plans Sale of Unit
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker. said it planned to sell its railroad freight car division as part of an effort to divest itself of assets unrelated to its basic steelmaking operations.

title: Hedley Donovan Is Dead at 76; Retired Chief Editor of Time Inc.
description: Hedley Donovan, a former editor in chief of Time Inc. who is credited with greatly enhancing the journalistic stature of Time magazine, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sands Point, L.I.

title: Results Plus
description: BASKETBALL

title: Shuttle Parachute
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has begun landing tests of a drag parachute system to be installed in the space shuttles to help slow them down after they touch down.

title: No Accord At Bond Corp.
description: Bondholders in the financially troubled Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. of Australia have failed to agree to the sale of the company's brewing assets, a company director said last week.

title: Arafat's Support of Iraq Creates Rift in P.L.O.
description: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the support given to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, has created a deep rift within the organization's leadership.

title: Pentagon Faces Daunting Challenge In Rushing Sizable Force to Mideast
description: The deployment of American forces to Saudi Arabia, the largest United States military operation since the Vietnam War, has severely strained the ability of the Pentagon to move thousands of troops and tons of weapons and equipment quickly over great distances.

title: Coslet Criticizes Jets
description: Bruce Coslet, the Jets' head coach, called for improvement by his quarterbacks yesterday and reaffirmed that Tony Eason would be the starter when the team plays its second preseason game, against the Chiefs in Kansas City, Mo., on Saturday night.

title: Chip Indicator Continues Slide
description: Chip orders declined in July as the American semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued the downward slide it began in June, a trade group said today.

title: Steinbrenner Drew Up Anti-Vincent Release
description: Lawyers for George Steinbrenner were prepared last week to accuse Commissioner Fay Vincent of severely damaging Steinbrenner's reputation and business by misrepresenting their agreement that will end the owner's management of the Yankees next Monday.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;

Miscellany
description: LEAD: * PPG Industries, Pittsburgh, announced yesterday that it had made a $30 million commitment to the U.S. Olympic Committee and the 1992 U.S. Olympic Team. The company, which makes Pittsburgh Paints, Olympic Stain and Lucite Paints, has been given the right to use the Olympic Committee logotypes and certain sponsorship statements in all its advertising, packaging and promotions for these products.

title: Kuwaiti Oil Concern Seeks Saudi Supply
description: Kuwait's London-based overseas marketing and refining company said today that it was negotiating with Saudi Arabia to supply some of the 400,000 barrels of crude oil and refined products that it had received from Kuwait each day before the Iraqi invasion.

title: Above the Clamor of the City, More Clamor
description: Old MacDonald, presumably, had a rooster to wake up to (45 decibels from across the barnyard). In New York City, he could not hear the crowing for the noise.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;

Cliff Freeman & Partners Wins Three Accounts
description: LEAD: Cliff Freeman & Partners, a New York agency that has about $85 million in billings, has been awarded three new accounts.

title: A Peace Plan for the Gulf
description: LEAD: On Sunday, Saddam Hussein floated his peace plan - and it came down like a lead balloon. His attempt to link the resolution of the Kuwait crisis to all the problems of the Middle East is unacceptable to the West and to his Arab neighbors. But there is an interesting alternative afoot in the region: Yasir Arafat has also come up with a peace plan.

title: A.T.&T.'s New Card Stirs Strong Response
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that the pace at which it distributed its new A.T.&T. Universal card, a combination calling card and general purpose credit card, had accelerated sharply this summer.

title: For South African Squatters, Life Just Gets Harder
description: When the wind blows, as it does in these days of squall and bluster at the Cape of Good Hope, the black plastic roof of Mongezi Sonqwelo's home flaps like a loud and loosened sail so that he has to pause in a winter's tale that has much to do with both the weather and South Africa's future.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a dispute between the Federal Government and New York State over an $80 million Westway grant incorrectly characterized a state application to avoid repaying the grant. The application dealt with potential development between the Hudson River bulkhead and the ends of the river piers, not the area between the bulkhead and the West Side Highway.

Share earnings are after preferred stock dividends of $1,183,000 in 1990 and $5,000 in 1989. R.P. Scherer is a subsidiary of RPS Corp.

title: Loss Posted At Turner Broadcasting
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said today that it lost $44 million on the Goodwill Games, which caused the company to post a second-quarter loss of $8.3 million.

title: Philadelphia Justice System Overwhelmed
description: Violent criminals have so overloaded jails, courts and the police here that city officials say they are routinely setting free thousands of other criminals who repeatedly burglarize houses, snatch purses, steal cars and sell drugs.

title: Use the United United Nations
description: The first sour note has sounded in President Bush's exemplary management of the Persian Gulf crisis. He is faulted for unilaterally ordering naval interdiction of Iraqi ports without waiting for United Nations support. Though Mr. Bush acted legally, the criticism is valid. He can best respond by working with the Security Council to create a joint U.N. command to enforce mandatory economic sanctions against Iraq.

title: Social Security Surplus Won't Spare Taxpayers;   Hearings Scheduled

title: With Shuffled Lineup, Mets, Win and Lose
description: The day's experiment had gone up in smoke. The evening's artless triumph had been followed by the late night's crushing loss. First place in the National League East had been yielded and second place once more occupied.

title: Circuit Research reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Economic Scene;   What Price Cleaner Air?
description: Like purer hearts or thinner thighs, cleaner air is an unalloyed virtue. But like other virtues, cleaner air can only be attained through sacrifice. And according to Paul R. Portney, an environmental economist at Resources for the Future in Washington, Americans may be on the verge of giving up too much for too little: They are not likely to get their money's worth from the sweeping amendments to the Clean Air Act now being cobbled together by Congress.

title: Met Opera Cancels Werner Herzog Staging
description: The Metropolitan Opera and the West German film director Werner Herzog, who was scheduled to make his American opera debut with a new production of Mozart's ''Zauberflote'' on Jan. 10, have agreed to part company - apparently over technical difficulties in realizing Mr. Herzog's artistic intentions.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. COORDINATES FLOTILLA IN GULF
description: The United States Navy is coordinating its actions in the Persian Gulf with the French and British Navies and with the Saudi armed forces, the commander of the Joint Task Force for the Middle East said today.

Latest second-quarter results included a loss of $24.5 million (including a write-off of goodwill of $11.3 million) resulting from the company's divestment of its investment banking group and other operations.

title: Self-Requiem for the Board of Estimate
description: A dying institution of government will conduct its own last rites in a marathon session to start tomorrow. In the process, New York City's Board of Estimate can improve - or obstruct - the life of the city it has managed for 92 years. Dozens of items are on the agenda for its last meeting; four in particular will determine how the board, and its members, are remembered.

description: The American public is ''riveted'' by news of the crisis in the Persian Gulf, according to a survey of public opinion by the Times Mirror Center for the Public and the Press.

title: 2 Nicaragua Currencies
description: Two official currencies were in circulation today in Nicaragua, one on par with the United States dollar and the other devalued almost into oblivion. The central bank announced today that it had devalued the old cordoba 7.2 percent, to 690,000 to the dollar from 640,000. Black market dealers offered 740,000 old cordobas for $1. On Monday the first bills of the new currency, the gold cordoba, began circulating when state workers cashed paychecks in the new money. The Government of President Violeta Chamorro has vowed to maintain the new cordoba on par with the dollar as part of a strategy to cut inflation, which was 62 percent in July.

description: The International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency, issued a report today showing steadily rising inflation in many nations in the first few months of 1990. Britain's inflation rate rose to 9.4 percent from 7.7 percent in the comparable period in 1989.

description: The dollar fell yesterday to its lowest level against the West German mark in that currency's 42-year history, breaking through a significant barrier on a decline that economists said should bring it even lower against the mark and other currencies before the end of the year.

description: LEAD: The University of Chicago will turn 100 in 1992, but will still be a relative youth among this nation's best universities. title: 9 Killed Near Johannesburg
description: Nine people were killed and 35 wounded when squatters attacked a hostel for migrant workers in Thokoza township west of Johannesburg, the police said today. Witnesses said the attack on Monday was apparently to avenge the death of a squatter over the weekend. ''We ran helter-skelter and those in their rooms had to jump through windows,'' a hostel resident, Mpumuzi Tshabalala, told the South African Press Association.

title: New U.S. Operations Chief For Waterford Wedgwood
description: Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C., the British-Irish maker of crystal glassware and china dinnerware, on Wednesday named Christopher J. McGillivary as chief executive for its operations in the United States, where the company has much of its sales.

title: Reports Conflict on a Liberian Rebel Leader's Fate
description: The Liberian rebel group led by Charles Taylor said today that its forces had killed a rival rebel leader, Prince Johnson, in an ambush. But Mr. Johnson was later reported to have appeared at a news conference.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: To Eat a Church Supper Is to Want to Cry 'Amen'
description: Last week, Edna Lewis and her sister Jen Ellis drove the gentle thread of asphalt that weaves through the cornfields and pastures of rural central Virginia toward the grocery. The white-haired women puttered past the brick house where their grandmother had served as a slave, past the meadow where their childhood home once stood and where their brother Lue Stanley Lewis still keeps 18 head of cattle and a pair of pigs. They steered past Bethel Baptist Church, which their grandfather helped found 100 years ago.

title: SIS Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy and filed a joint plan of reorganization with the bankruptcy court on Aug. 1.

title: BANKS' PAYMENTS TO INSURE DEPOSITS MAY JUMP BY 30%
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation moved today to raise the premiums banks pay for deposit insurance by $1.1 billion, or 30 percent, next year. The action reflects increased concerns about the safety of the deposit insurance system and about the effects of depressed real estate prices on commercial banks and the overall economy.

title: Toronto Sun Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for latest 6 months were lowered by 7 cents a share as a result of the company's decision to discontinue accruing interest income on a $50 million (U.S.) subordinated note receivable due from the purchaser of the Houston Post Co. Revenue for the latest and year-ago quarters was not available.

title: Federko Retires
description: Bernie Federko, the 16th-highest scorer in National Hockey League history with 1,130 points over 14 seasons with St. Louis and Detroit, has announced his retirement. The 34-year-old center, who was a free agent, made the announcement yesterday in Detroit, where last season he was the Red Wings' third-leading scorer with 57 points. He played the previous 13 seasons with the St. Louis Blues. (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: CURTIS MAYFIELD, a rhythm-and-blues musician who performed with the Impressions before going out on his own, was listed in critical but stable condition at Kings County hospital in Brooklyn yesterday after being hurt in an accident at an outdoor concert Monday evening.

title: Sonesta International Hotels Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are based on the weighted average number of shares outstanding in each period and allow for preferred dividends. Revenue represents operating revenue.

title: Tele-Communications
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the cable TV and theater company, said yesterday that its loss narrowed in the second quarter to $44 million, compared with a deficit of $64 million a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 22.6 percent, to $890 million, from $726 million a year earlier. The loss was attributed to interest expenses resulting from a variety of deals, including the purchase of the TCI/Cooke Systems, and a 42.5 percent indirect interest in SCI Holdings Inc. as well as the business combination involving United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corporation.

title: Plane Crashes Off Fire Island
description: A plane crashed today in 65 feet of water off Fire Island, the Federal Aviation Administration said. The pilot, Kevin Heffernan of Milltown, N.J., was the only person aboard the Citabria owned by United Aerial Advertising of Nyack, N.Y. A search was halted at nightfall.

title: International Remote Imaging Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Suspicion Keeps a Hospital From Salvadorans
description: When their television screens showed this city engulfed in house-to-house combat that wounded thousands of civilians during a rebel offensive in November, the people of Webster, Mass., decided to donate all the equipment needed for a 50-bed hospital.

title: EATING WELL
description: YOU already know you aren't supposed to exceed more than 30 percent of your daily caloric intake of fat. That's what health professionals keep saying. The only complication is figuring out just what that means in terms of real food.

Cuomo Asserts Federal Courts Shift Obligation
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told the country's leading state court judges today that the Federal courts had increasingly ceded the task of protecting basic liberties to the state courts and in the process had abandoned their obligation to address a number of national problems.
