title: Argentine President Takes Peronist Party's Helm
description: President Carlos Saul Menem has increased his domination of the Argentine political scene by taking over formal leadership of the Peronist party, formerly in the hands of his main rival in the organization, Antonio Cafiero.

title: Pakistan's Caretakers Face Mountain of Tasks
description: Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, who will head a caretaker government until national elections on Oct. 24, has named a Cabinet of experienced administrators, a significant number of whom once belonged to Benazir Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party.

title: 10 Die as Kashmir Militants Fight Indian Security Forces
description: Ten people were killed in separatist attacks on Indian security forces today as major Kashmiri towns marked Pakistan's Independence Day under curfew, police officials said.

title: U.S. Home Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $5,799,000 and $6,369,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the 6 months also included a gain from early extinguishment of debt of $276,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $903,000 and $1,627,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a gain from early extinguishment of debt of $2,587,000, or 6 cents a share, and $3,527,000, or 8 cents a share, for the same periods, respectively. Results for the latest and year-ago 6 months included gross profits from the sale of land and lots of $1.3 million and $2.0 million, respectively; such profits for the latest and year-ago quarters were not significant.

title: John Forsyth Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Trusting a Chef
description: To The Living Section:

title: Augustus D. Clark, 90, A Retired Navy Officer
description: Augustus Dayton Clark, a retired Navy captain who played a significant role in the invasion of Normandy during World War II, died on Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: A Sculptor Whose Imagery Is Encyclopedic
description: Ask the sculptor Alice Aycock where she gets the ideas for her -well, visual fictions, and you're off on a dizzying tour of the cultural universe.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. May Call Up Some Reservists To Ease the Strain on the Military
description: The Bush Administration is considering the partial mobilization of reserve forces to help deter an attack on Saudi Arabia by Iraq, Pentagon officials said today.

title: English Going to Dallas
description: The Dallas Mavericks said yesterday that they would announce today the signing of Alex English, the eighth-leading scorer in National Basketball Association history. English, a forward, is expected to fill the gap left by the loss of Sam Perkins, who signed as a free agent with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A great-grandson of the founder of the Mongolian Republic has made a novel proposal about what to do with a large bronze statue of Joseph Stalin that was toppled earlier this year and is lying on the grounds of the state library in the capital, Ulan Bator.

title: A Bomb Kills 4 in New Delhi On Eve of Independence Day
description: A bomb killed at least four people in New Delhi on the eve of India's independence day celebrations, news agencies reported today.

title: Barbs Don't Faze Commissioner
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent said yesterday that he was not considering further sanctions against George Steinbrenner despite a sudden verbal onslaught from lawyers and associates of the Yankees' principal owner. ''It's a lot of cymbals clanging in the night signifying nothing,'' Vincent said.

title: Margaret B. Mark, 86, Ex-Girl Scout Official
description: Margaret B. Mark, a leader in the Girl Scouts of America and in social work organizations, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86 years old.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Goods Reach Iraq Through Jordanian 'Back Door'
description: A line of battered frighters unloaded and picked up cargo today at this Jordanian port, which serves as an outlet to the sea for Iraq.

title: Suspect Arrested in Rabbi's Slaying
description: A 35-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested on Monday and charged with the slaying of a leader of the Satmar Hasidim in February in the Williamsburg section of the borough, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Smokers spend more money.

title: Sidney Lightstone, Advertising Executive, 94
description: Sidney Lightstone, an advertising executive, died last Wednesday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 94 years old. He died of cancer, his son John said. Mr. Lightstone began in advertising in Detroit with the J. L. Hudson Co. He became sales promotion manager for Gimbel Brothers in Philadelphia and headed his own business in Manhattan and in Chicago.

title: Clinical Data reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Reporters Finding Access Difficult to Foes in Gulf
description: Ted Koppel, the anchor of the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' yesterday became the first American journalist allowed into Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait, but most other news organizations continued to be frustrated in their attempts to enter either Iraq or Saudi Arabia to report on the crisis in the Persian Gulf.

title: Polish Tools Exhibited
description: Looking to the United States market as an opportunity, Polish makers of hand tools are first-time exhibitors this week at the National Hardware Show in Chicago's McCormick Place. The wares of 10 Polish manufacturers, displayed on a card table, ranged from garden rakes and pruning shears to pliers, screwdrivers and clamps. The trade show ends on Wednesday. ''Initial response has been very favorable,'' said Kevin McDonald, a member of the Task Force on Company Assistance, a Warsaw-based agency of the Council of Ministers in Poland that draws support from the United Nations Development Program.

title: One Man's Tangles With the Law
description: June 1, 1989: Juvon Edmunds charged with burglarizing his mother's home in northwest Philadelphia. As in all of the following instances, except where noted, Mr. Edmunds was released without bail, under terms of a court-ordered moratorium on admissions to the city's overcrowded jails.

title: Assistant Pro Finds Time To Play a Bit Between Duties
description: He is in his first year as an assistant pro at the Westchester Country Club, but he is so busy working for perhaps the busiest course in the area that Rudy Virga has played the course only three times.

title: A 'Homeless Co-op Board' As Tough as Park Avenue
description: Ivan Vargas and his wife, Iveliz Ruiz, sat nervously before the six women who would decide if they would get into one of five newly renovated city-owned buildings in the South Bronx. The couple met the first requirement: They were homeless. Now, the committee had some questions.

description: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial deliberated yesterday for the sixth day in State Supreme Court in Manhattan without reaching a verdict. Justice Thomas B. Galligan granted jury requests to review videotaped statements by two of the three youths charged with rape and attempted murder.

title: Freeze Upheld on Manville
description: A Federal appeals panel in New York yesterday affirmed the authority of a Federal judge who has begun to restructure the trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos.

title: Early Return for Reeves
description: Less than a week after he suffered chest pains that required nonsurgical treatment to remove coronary-artery blockages, Dan Reeves, coach of the Denver Broncos, was back at his team's training camp in Greeley, Colo., yesterday after receiving a clean bill of health from doctors at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif. ''It was rough being out, but it could have been a lot worse, that's for sure,'' Reeves said. Doctors at first expected the 46-year-old Reeves to be out three to six weeks. With Wade Phillips, the Broncos' defensive coordinator, substituting for Reeves, the Broncos won their exhibition game with Indianpolis on Saturday, 16-7. (AP)

title: Sales of U.S. Vehicles Down in Early August
description: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell 18.8 percent in early August and analysts attributed the decline to the weakness in the United States economy and unusually strong sales a year earlier.

title: Texaco Signs Pact With Soviet Unit
description: The Texaco Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Soviet Union's Ministry of Geology to study the feasibility of joint oil production in Arctic oilfields south of the Barents Sea. Texaco officials said the Soviets had identified reserves of at least five billion barrels of oil in the region.

title: Whitman Calls Off Sale of Hussmann
description: The Whitman Corporation said it had discontinued negotiations for the sale of its Hussmann Corporation subsidiary and would pull the refrigeration equipment unit off the sale block. Whitman said that, after several weeks of negotiations, it had concluded that the proceeds from the best offer for Hussmann would not justify the sale.

AIDS Therapy Experiment Yields Encouraging Results
description: A new AIDS therapy that involves administering a drug, withdrawing some of the patient's blood, shining ultraviolet light on it and returning it to the body has shown promising preliminary results in a study of five patients, researchers say.

title: Four Mets Receive Fines
description: For the Mets, the final fallout from a fight with the Phillies last Thursday night involved a couple of hurt wallets but no damage to their lineup.

title: Walter J. Lopp 2d, 51, Banker And Corporate Finance Innovator
description: Walter James Lopp 2d, an investment banker and an innovator in corporate financing, died on Friday at his vacation home in Auribeau, France. Mr. Lopp, who also lived in Manhattan, was 51 years old.

Dickerson Is Unlikely For the Colts' Opener
description: Dr. Tom Parr, an orthopedic surgeon treating Eric Dickerson, said yesterday that the star running back of the Indianapolis Colts would probably miss his team's regular-season opener at Buffalo on Sept. 9, but should be ready to play by the end of September. Parr predicted that Dickerson's injured left hamstring would be almost fully recovered when he returns to the Colts and that the star running back would need less than a week to regain his sharpness.

description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference at the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Iran Will Stay on the Sidelines . . .
description: LEAD: So far Iran, a bitter enemy of Iraq, seems to be following its interests and offering minimal support to the international effort to oust Iraqi troops from Kuwait. The U.S. shouldn't hope for much more.

title: Man's Life Support Extended
description: A man who drank a cocaine-laced soft drink from Colombia and collapsed in a coma last month showed signs of life today, and doctors postponed shutting off his life-support systems. The 25-year-old man, Maximo Rene Menendez, was declared brain dead on Monday, and an order was signed by a Dade County judge allowing a hospital to turn off his life-support system. No suspects have been identified in the case.

title: Death Toll Up to 8 in 2 Days Of Dominican General Strike
description: The death toll reached eight in a violent general strike protesting the Government's new austerity program after two people died today, police and radio reports said.

description: There is a water shortage in much of France this summer thanks to a three-year drought, but in Paris it seems that only Badoit is affected. Badoit is a popular mineral water and since the recent spell of record-breaking heat here, there just has not been enough of it to go around.

title: Mr. Rinfret on Garbage
description: Pierre Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, believes that one way to give plausibility to his quixotic campaign against Gov. Mario Cuomo is to offer dramatically unconventional solutions to New York State's problems. He now proposes to resolve the struggle over landfills and incinerator sites by allowing local communities to bid for the right not to have them. That's certainly an original idea. It's also nonsense.

He was thinking of major-suit games, and he would have been intrigued by the diagramed deal, on which North-South played the ''Moysian fit'' in a minor suit, rejecting two plausible seven-card fits in the majors.

title: Emergency Generator Fails at Hospital
description: As lower Manhattan began returning to normal after Monday's blackout, the emergency generator feeding power to New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital shut down yesterday afternoon, plunging the hospital into total darkness and paralyzing its life-support systems for an hour.

title: Once a Hotel Desert, Times Square Blooms
description: Times Square, which has been a near-wasteland for hotels since the Beaux-Arts splendor of the Astor met the wrecker's ball in the 1960's, is now at the center of a virtual tide of new hotels. Coming in the wake of a wave of high-rise construction on the West Side, two brand-new skyscraper hotels, the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza on Broadway at 49th Street and the Hotel Macklowe on West 44th Street just east of Broadway, have opened in the last few months. A third new high-rise hotel, the Embassy Suites at the corner of 47th Street and Seventh Avenue, will open in September.

title: Immigrants Help Others Lost in Maze
description: Sung Soo Kim, a native of South Korea, does not know Esther Cartagena, formerly of Puerto Rico, or Philippe Wilson Desir, formerly of Haiti. But in their adopted city, they each serve a similar role: helping to guide compatriots recently arrived from their homelands through the bureaucratic maze that governs social services, the education of their children and how they do business.

title: Homecare Management Inc.  reports earnings for Year April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Rejecting Claims, Judge Awards Gold Treasure to Its Discoverers
description: A Federal district judge today awarded about three tons of gold, worth perhaps as much as $1 billion, to the salvage group that discovered the sunken treasure off South Carolina three years ago.

title: Dyansen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
First Executive Earnings Drop
description: The First Executive Corporation, a life insurance company that invested heavily in ''junk bonds,'' said today that its earnings fell 40.2 percent, to $30.5 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter that ended June 30. It had earned $51 million, or 45 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avis Inc., Garden City, L.I., named Robert D. Cardillo vice president of sales and marketing.

title: Hadson Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $143,579,000 for the quarter and $144,562,000 for the 6 months; both losses from discontinued operations included a $142,529,000 loss on the pending sale of two subsidiaries. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,777,000 for the quarter and $3,221,000 for the 6 months.

title: Firstcorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results in the latest quarter are due principally to its portfolio of troubled assets. The nonperforming assets costs the company about $6.3 million from interest income foregone, net losses on the sale of real estate, expenses related to selling and managing the troubled assets and some additional reserves.

title: On the Trail of the Tortilla: All Tracks Lead to Tucson
description: THIS beautiful, manageable city, with its crisp, dry, hot climate, desert landscape and pink adobe houses, calls itself the Mexican-food capital of the world - outside of Mexico, one assumes. The most authentic local cuisine is found in South Tucson, a city built in the 18th century, distinct from but surrounded by Tucson.

title: General Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included gain of $100,000, or 6 cents a share, from settlement of disputes with Revco D.S. Inc. c-Net loss d-Included charge of $533,000 due to a change in estimated tax benefits.

title: New Jersey Warns of Ban On Insurer
description: State officials told the ITT Hartford Insurance Group today that if one of its subsidiaries wants to cancel its automobile insurance policies in New Jersey, the giant insurer will be barred from doing any business in the state.

title: Mildred D. Barlow, 67, Foundation President
description: Mildred Devereux Barlow, founder and president of the International University Foundation, died on Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Canadians Clash With Police Near a Mohawk Reservation
description: Canadian police officers firing tear gas and wielding night sticks battled rock-throwing demonstrators late Monday in a second straight day of violent protests against the monthlong blockade of a Montreal bridge by Mohawk Indians.

title: Petrol Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Revenue represents gross revenue.

title: New Fiber-Optic Cable Will Expand Calls Abroad, and Defy Sharks
description: Like Brobdingnagian spools of thread, three giant steel cones in the hold of an unusual ship here are wrapped with up to 3,000 miles of cable no thicker than a garden hose. The cable, composed of six hair-thin strands of glass covered by steel and plastic, can carry 40,000 telephone calls across the ocean floor at a time.

title:
Real Estate;

Sweeteners For Offices In Manhattan
description: LEAD: Having ventured from a primary office location on Fifth Avenue to a secondary location at 300 Park Avenue South last year, Rizzoli, the publishing and bookselling company, is now expanding its operations there. The growth, from one floor to three, is indicative of the leasing activity in that area, despite the general slowdown in the office market.

title: Comcast Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All share and share earnings data have been retroactively adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend effective Oct. 24, 1989. The company said losses in the latest periods are due primarily to financing costs and non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization associated with the company's proportionate share of losses associated with its ownership of 50 percent of Storer Communications Inc. Neither the results of operations or financial condition of the Storer Systems are included in the company's consolidated financial statements.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST, 15, 1990
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Mozambique and Rebels Report Progress in Talks
description: The Mozambican Government and rebel leaders ended a second round of talks here today after what they described as a fruitful exchange on ways to end their 13-year war.

title: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Are Continuing to Decline

title: CHRONICLE
description: TAMMY FAYE BAKKER's church in Orlando, Fla., can hold services at its warehouse ministry on Sunday after winning a zoning dispute. The Orange County Commission on Monday overruled the county zoning board 4 to 1, and said that the site of Mrs. Bakker's New Covenant Ministries would not be unsafe for church services and a radio-television broadcast studio.

description: Darryl Strawberry, who makes $1.8 million a year, said it was a ''stiff'' fine - all of $1,000. He also said he wouldn't do it again, unless, of course, he had to.

description: If you like farce you had to love the outcome of the Government's case against Marion Barry, Washington's most famous film star (a.k.a. ''the Mayor'') and leading contender for the title of Playboy of the Western World.

description: An article on Monday about American policy toward Iraq misstated the year in which the United States removed Iraq from a list of nations that sponsor terrorism. Iraq was taken off the list in 1982, not 1983.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;

Vik Brothers to Buy An Ambase Subsidiary
description: LEAD: The Ambase Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a subsidiary, the Home Insurance Company, to Vik Brothers International, a European-based investment group, in a deal valued at $905 million.

title: Transition at the Top For Goldman, Sachs
description: John L. Weinberg, who has led Goldman, Sachs & Company through one of the greatest and most profitable expansions in the firm's 121-year history, announced yesterday that he would retire in November as senior partner and chairman.

title: Collagen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $241,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Taking Budget Offensive, Bush Accuses Democrats of Imperiling Economy
description: Saying the budget impasse at home deserved the same urgent attention as the crisis in the Persian Gulf, President Bush today dropped his gentleman's agreement with the Democratic leaders in Congress and accused them of endangering the economy by playing politics with the Federal deficit.

title: Former Nemesis Gets Trump Financial Post
description: The Trump Organization announced yesterday that an executive who once masterminded a deal that thwarted a Trump takeover attempt had agreed to join the real estate and casino company as chief financial officer.

title: Spear Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included utilization of net operating loss carryforward of $173,925, or 2 cents a share. c-Net loss d-Included utilization of net operating loss carryforward of $19,037. The company said that its subsidiary James Mitchell & Co. accounted for more than 65 percent of its pretax revenue.

title: Review/Music;   A Concert Opens in the Park, And Then Bows to the Rain
description: Despite thunderstorm warnings, the New York Philharmonic made a valiant attempt to deliver on its promise of a free concert on the Great Lawn of Central Park on Monday evening. In a rising wind and under gray clouds that flickered almost continuously with lightning, the Soviet conductor Valery Gergiev led the Philharmonic in Berlioz's ''Roman Carnival'' Overture (Op. 9) and Debussy's three-movement seascape, ''La Mer.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday on the American forces in the Middle East misidentified the Marine unit involved. It is the First Marine Expeditionary Force, not the First Marine Division.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. Rates had previously declined for four consecutive weeks.

title: P&F Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: A Car Bombing in Peru Damages Fujimori's Presidential Residence
description: A car bomb exploded next to the government palace as Peru's new President, Alberto Fujimori, was meeting with advisers, injuring four passersby, the police said today.

title: Live Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lendl Beaten in Upset, Losing to Washington
description: After beating Patrick McEnroe in the first round of the Volvo International tennis tournament on Monday, Malivai Washington of Glen Cove, L.I. - ranked No. 103 in the world - said he would take the court tonight against Ivan Lendl trying ''to imagine he's just another tennis player.''

title: How to Measure the Rain
description: If the sound of rain falling on a tin roof is the best of all soporifics, then New Yorkers must be the best-rested people anywhere. In the city, the rainfall drums down instead on air-conditioners, garbage cans, the hoods of cars. Never mind. Down it pours and on we sleep.

title: Los Angeles Journal;   In a Smoking Ban, Some See Ashes
description: Just three hours after two City Council committees voted Monday to ban smoking in all restaurants in Los Angeles, Michael Taix was back at Les Freres Taix, his 53-year-old family-run French restaurant on Sunset Boulevard, bemoaning the turn of events.

description: Bond prices rose slightly and long-term interest rates dipped yesterday, as credit market participants reacted favorably to a more stable oil market, rumors of institutional purchases of long-term securities and hopes that the meeting tomorrow between President Bush and King Hussein of Jordan may help to defuse tensions in the Middle East.

description: Retail sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July from the month before, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Asa S. Knowles, 81, Ex-President Of Northeastern University, Dies
description: Asa S. Knowles, president of Northeastern University from 1959 to 1975, died Saturday at his home in Boston at the age of 81.

title: About New York;   For Caring Chefs, Crowning Glory Is the Headgear
description: New York, as a city, wears many hats, but none are in better taste than the toque, the high, white cylinder of headgear to be found in the best, if not the most expensive, kitchens in Manhattan and surrounding arrondissements. Unlike firefighters, police officers, baseball players, postal workers, waiters and bus drivers who work in full view of audiences, chefs are a backstage lot, only recently accustomed to coming out for a bow as the brandy serves as a coda for their caloric symphonies.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because a service that provides The Associated Press with market data remained without power yesterday after a Monday fire at a Consolidated Edison plant in lower Manhattan, the commodity futures tables today contain only settlement prices and net changes, plus volume and open-interest figures where available. The net changes for items traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange are based on the difference between today's settlement price and Friday's close.

Japanese Bankruptcies
description: The number of bankruptcies in Japan fell 12.5 percent in July from a year earlier, the 67th consecutive month of year-on-year declines, the Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today. The number of bankruptcies declined 6.6 percent in July from June. Bankruptcies with debt of less than 10 million yen ($67,000) are not included in the statistics. There were 482 bankruptcies with debts of more than 10 million yen in July. Debts arising from the failures dropped 58.9 percent from a year earlier, and 16.4 percent from June, to 87.22 billion yen ($582 million).

title: Nowhere Vacations: Beyond TV and Fax

You remember what vacations used to be, before advanced technology made it easier to reach out and touch someone, wherever they may be. When the average workweek was 40 hours or less and employers wouldn't dream of interrupting your personal or private time, let alone a vacation, unless it were an emergency.

The team said it had fined the two Pirate players because the team had voted to make the function mandatory. Fans at the auction paid an admission fee plus an additional charge depending on the number of autographs they obtained.

title: Czechoslovak Compensation
description: More than 220,000 Czechoslovaks who suffered during 41 years of Communist rule will probably share around $95 million in compensation, officials said today. Those eligible include people in political trials between the Communist takeover in 1948 and its ousting last year. Many others who emigrated had their citizenship revoked when they left Czechoslovakia. They are now entitled to regain Czechoslovak nationality.

title: Eastern Can Trim Pilots' Pay
description: In a ruling that gives Eastern Airlines some financial relief, a Federal Bankruptcy Court said yesterday that the beleaguered carrier could impose temporary wage and benefits cuts on pilots. At the same time, the airline reported a $35.6 million loss for the second quarter, an improvement from the period a year earlier.

description: Iran has offered to increase its exports of crude oil to Japan to cover the loss of supplies from Iraq and Kuwait, a Government official said today.

title: Bank in Brooklyn Sets Fall Opening
description: The Community Capital Bank, Brooklyn, said yesterday that it had met its goal of raising $6 million of shareholder capital, and it planned to open for business in November. The bank, which attracted about a third of its shareholder funds from 41 religious organizations and another third from institutions like the American Express Company and J. P. Morgan & Company, promised to concentrate on lending to small businesses in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods of New York City.

title: Tax-Exempt Bonds For Dormitories

Itel will buy within 30 days about 4.68 million of the shares at $18 each and another 4.68 million shares before the end of 1990 at $19.50 a share. Itel has an option to buy the remaining 9.35 million shares at either $21 a share by March 31, 1991, or at $22 a share by July 31, 1991.

Khmer Rouge Was Not a U.S. Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: Campbell Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: KEY RATES
Petroleum Development Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Fleeing Kuwait: An American Tells of Four Hours of Terror
description: Iraqi tanks and trucks sat motionless on the sands of southern Kuwait as a four-wheel-drive vehicle carrying two Westerners drove through 120-degree heat toward the Saudi border.

title: McGwire's Slam Lifts Athletics
description: Mark McGwire hit a grand slam in the 10th inning today to become the first major league player to hit 30 or more homers in each his first four seasons to lead the Oakland Athletics to a 6-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Intelligent Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: All share earnings give effect to the company's July 1990 2-for-1 stock split. The company said third quarter financial statements included an accrual of $10.7 million of additional puchase price related to its acquisition of connecting Point of Ameica.

title: MCorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,550,000 for the quarter and $3,038,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after income of $4.5 million, or 10 cents a share, from discontinued operations. d-Net loss and after a loss of $7,255,000 from discontinued operations.

title: New Jerseyan Is Charged as War Criminal
description: The Federal Government today moved to revoke the citizenship of a Somerset man who officials said was a Nazi war criminal known in the concentration camps as the ''black commander.''

title: Gradco Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that net earnings for the latest quarter reflected the previously announced $17.8 million net after-tax gain from the sale of the shares of the company's Japanese subsidiary and operating losses due to the decline in sales of certain copier products to Xerox Corp. and expenses for development, field test and marketing of the new laser printer paper handling products which are currently being released.

title: Faster Approval of AIDS Drugs Is Urged
description: A Presidential advisory panel said today that the Government should speed up approval of experimental AIDS and cancer drugs by requiring less evidence of the drugs' effectiveness before they are put on the market.

title: Eli Lilly Facing Million-Dollar Suits On Its Antidepressant Drug Prozac
description: As reports mount that the nation's most widely prescribed antidepressant drug may spark violent or suicidal behavior in a fraction of patients, lawyers and former users of the medication are banding together to file multimillion-dollar lawsuits against the drug's maker.

title: Critics Say Dinkins Miscalculated Guards' Anger
description: By failing to end this week's correction officers' job action before it mushroomed into a major disturbance at Rikers Island, Mayor David N. Dinkins has fueled further criticism of his cautious, deliberate style.

title: Rebel Leader in Liberia Bars West Africans From Leaving
description: About 50 foreigners joined a West German road convoy out of Liberia's ravaged capital today, but diplomats said the leader of one of the country's two rebel factions refused to let West African expatriates flee the country.

title: Ameriscribe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $694,000 for the quarter and $547,000 for the 6 months; both extraordinary losses included a tax charge of $147,000 and an extraordinary loss of $547,000 on the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $241,000, or 9 cents a share, and $2,036,000, or 73 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago 6 months' income from continuing operations included a charge of $118,000 for the accretion of dividends on preference stock. Latest quarter and 6 months' results were adversely affected by non- recurring charges of $655,000, of which $355,000 represented accrued interest on interest due on the company's defaulted public indebtedness and $300,000 represented termination expense.

title: Margarine, Too, Is Found to Have the Fat That Adds to Heart Risk
description: Margarine, the spread millions use instead of butter in hopes of preventing heart disease, contains fatty acids formed during processing that actually increase coronary risk, according to a study published yesterday.

title: I.C.H.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $5,644,000, or 12 cents a share, reflecting subsidiary's purchases of $21.5 million in principal amount of the company's 11 1/4 percent senior subordinated notes due 1996. c-Net loss

title: Kuwaiti in U.S. Speaks Of an Exile Leadership
description: The Kuwaiti government-in-exile is directing an underground armed resistance and a wide assortment of public services inside its country, from garbage removal to emergency medical care, senior Kuwaiti officials said today.

title: Thomson Unit's New Chief
description: The Thomson Corporation said yesterday that Robert C. Hall would become chief executive of the company's Information/Publishing Group and a director of Thomson effective next Jan. 1.

title: Mavericks Sign English
description: To help fill the gap left by the loss of Sam Perkins, who signed as a free agent with the Los Angeles Lakers earlier this week, the Dallas Mavericks yesterday announced the signing of Alex English, the eighth-leading career scorer in National Basketball Association history. English, who had been a free agent, averaged 17.9 points a game with Denver last season. (AP)

title: Fruit of Loom Stock Is Sold
description: William F. Farley, chairman of Fruit of the Loom Inc., sold 3.75 million Fruit of the Loom class B common shares to a single buyer for $11.50 a share, or more than $43.1 million.

title: Sales Up, Inventories Off in June
description: Business sales rose 1 percent in June for the second consecutive month, while inventories declined four-tenths of a percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: After 7 Days, No Verdict in the Jogger Trial
description: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial was told by the presiding judge last night to get ''a good night's sleep'' and get ready for a ''full day'' today before it retired last night without reaching a verdict.

title: Watch Urged On U.S. Loan Agencies
description: Federal auditors said today that the Government should sharply increase the regulation and supervision of Government-sponsored enterprises that lend money to home buyers and college students or else taxpayers might have to foot the bill in the future.

title: Harry Leahey, Jazz Guitarist, 54
description: Harry Leahey, a jazz guitarist and teacher, died on Sunday at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 54 years old and lived in North Plainfield, N.J., until last year, when he moved to Iselin, N.J.

title: Crown Resources Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said net income for the latest 6-month period included a gain of $5 million from sale of option on an interst in mining property. The company had no revenue in the year-ago quarter because it was in the development stage.

title: Continental To Cut Fares
description: Continental Airlines said today that it would cut fares for flights after Labor Day, matching reductions already announced by other carriers.

title: Florence R. Garfunkel, Social Worker, 83
description: Florence Rubin Garfunkel, a social worker and a trustee of the Educational Alliance for 33 years, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

title: Inc. Magazine Plans A Version for Soviets
description: Bernard A. Goldhirsh, the chairman of the Goldhirsh Publishing Group, said yesterday that a Russian-language version of Inc. magazine would be published in the Soviet Union, beginning in mid-1991.

title: Some Tips for Gluing Broken Furniture
description: LEAD: It's a rare household where a dab of glue isn't needed here and there on furniture. Ideally, broken furniture should be repaired without undue delay. When ignored, even a ''good'' break, with opposing jagged splinters that will come together like a jigsaw puzzle, can become worn and dirty, making a really tight joining difficult.

title: Academy Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $597,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $1,161,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $612,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Oil Prices Stable as Traders Watch OPEC
description: In contrast to their fluctuations in recent days, oil prices were little changed yesterday as the market confronted a lull in news from the Middle East and awaited a decision from OPEC whether it would authorize members to pump more oil.

title: More States Are Laying School Paddle to Rest
description: The threat of lawsuits, an increased concern about child abuse and new evidence that minority and handicapped children are paddled more often than other students have combined to revive the debate about corporal punishment in schools. In the last three years the number of states that have banned paddling has nearly doubled.

title: End to Beginning of CBS
description: CBS Inc. said today that it had ended its operations at WCAU-AM in Philadelphia, the radio station with which William S. Paley began the CBS broadcasting network in the 1920's. The network-owned station switched programming at 1 P.M. without notice to listeners or staff. About 35 employees were laid off. The station's talk show and local news format was replaced with ''golden oldies'' rock-and-roll programming, much of it simulcast from WOGL-FM, another CBS-owned station in the city. A CBS spokesman said WCAU would become WOGL-AM.

title: Staten Island Ousted From Tournament
description: Michael Nebel, a third baseman who bats leadoff for the South Shore team from Staten Island, stepped anxiously to the plate today and waited for Bob Shannon's first pitch.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA
description: * Olympic Airlines, the Government-owned airline of Greece, to Kaufman & Maraffi Inc., New York, with a budget of $1.7 million.

title: On Estimate Board's Agenda, Last Item Is Its Own Demise
description: At 10:30 this morning, in a clean white chamber that looks like a Congregational church, the Board of Estimate, the centerpiece of New York City's government for nearly a century, will come to order to do the business it always does and then do something else. It will die.

title: Facing a Tax Revolt, Florio, on TV, Asks for 'a Little Time'
description: Gov. Jim Florio, in his first statewide television address, pleaded with angry taxpayers tonight to give his tax initiatives time to work, and denied that he had lied to them when he said throughout last year's election campaign and right up to the day he took office that no new taxes would be needed.

title: Treasury Securities Up Slightly
description: Prices of most Treasury securities inched higher in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as traders nervously reacted to sudden shifts in the foreign exchange and petroleum markets as well as a potpourri of rumors.

title: Hancock Fabrics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Maloney Signs Pact
description: Don Maloney signed a one-year contract yesterday to return to the Islanders, but the pact is contingent upon the 12-year National Hockey League veteran making the team at the conclusion of training camp.

title: L.S. Starrett reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Man Indicted In the Slaying Of an Intruder
description: A 19-year-old man who shot a knife-wielding burglar attacking a pregnant woman in an East Harlem apartment has been indicted on charges of second-degree murder and illegal gun possession, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said last night.

title: Chemical to Add To Loan Reserves
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation said in a regular quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that in the second half of the year it expects to add more to its reserves for loan losses than the $151 million it added in the first half. After the disclosure, Chemical's stock fell 62.5 cents a share, to $23.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Speeding Arms to Arab Allies
description: The United States is expediting large-scale arms sales already negotiated with Egypt and Saudi Arabia and is giving higher priority to new weapons requests from other Middle Eastern allies, the Pentagon said today.

title: Scientific-Atlanta Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: Year-ago periods ended June 30.

title: Data Show How Rich Trump Is
description: Donald J. Trump's accountants and bankers have concluded that his empire is worth far less than he contended late last year - and that if he had been forced to sell his assets this spring he might not have realized enough money to get out of debt.

title: Unafraid of Magenta Or Rampant Phloxes
description: MY friend Mary's garden grows very well indeed, and Mary herself is not the least bit contrary. But her large garden a few blocks from my own does go counter to the conventional wisdom about perennial phlox.

title: Charter Medical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said operating income for the latest 9 months ended June 30 reflected second fiscal quarter corrections of previously reported contractual allowances, bad debts and expense accruals. As a result of such corrections, Charter reduced operating income by about $35 million. In addition, results for the latest 9 months reflected the second quarter abandonment of certain development projects and a lawsuit loss resulting in an unusual charge to operating income of $11.2 million.

title: Magadan Lapse Sinks The Mets
description: Dave Magadan broke from first base, snuck a look over his shoulder at the plate and realized he had just stepped into disaster. Magadan's first steal attempt of the season was a play that was not supposed to happen.

title: Federal Agency Moving to Stop Benefits for Dead Veterans
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs is moving to stop payments it made to more than 1,200 deceased veterans, including about 100 who were dead a decade or more.

title: Similarity To N.H.L. Causes Concern
description: Dwight Gooden, Don Baylor said yesterday, has the mentality of a middle linebacker.

title: Burmese Rights Abuses Reported
description: An American human-rights group issued a report today accusing the Burmese Government of ''gross human-rights violations.'' It said atrocities had continued despite the Government's defeat in elections in May.

title: Richfood Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 21
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $494,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Pakistan's decision to join the international force in Saudi Arabia misidentified a Saudi envoy who visited Pakistan. He is Deputy Foreign Minister Abdulaziz Al-Thanyan.

title: INSIDE
description: Dirtier Than Chernobyl

title: Vintage Petroleum Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Biblical Lawn Care
description: To The Home Section:

title: Mostly Mozart to Perform 9 Concerts at Tokyo Center
description: Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival will go to Tokyo next year to perform nine concerts at the Tokyu Bunkamura, a cultural complex that opened last September.

title: Easing of Tensions With Iran Gives Iraq New Flexibility in Shifting Troops
description: As Iraq mends its political fences with Iran, Baghdad expects to free some of its large forces along the Iranian border for possible redeployment to the southern part of the country where they would confront United States forces. But analysts do not believe major Iraqi troop or tank movements are imminent.

title: Centuri Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Business Digest
description: The Oil Jolt

title: Tony Lama Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zycad Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $10,528,000 charge related to restructuring and asset write- down. c-Net income Results for 1989 have been restated.

title: Algebra Bequeathed X
description: To the Editor:

title:
Currents;

A Century of Metropolitan Modernity
description: LEAD: FOR a good 50 years ''modern design'' has automatically been associated with the Museum of Modern Art, the first museum in the United States to devote a department to the subject. But next month a book is to appear that will show the efforts of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in expanding and updating its collection.

title: Border Remains Closed as Seoul Battles Radicals
description: The promise of free travel across the tightly sealed border between North and South Korea faded today as about 10,000 South Korean radicals clashed with riot policemen and the authorities continued to haggle over procedural details.

title: Ellsworth Convertible Growth & Income Fund Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
To Our Readers
description: Because of continuing data-transmission difficulties as a result of the Monday fire at a Consolidated Edison plant in lower Manhattan, The Associated Press was unable to provide data on trading yesterday in several futures and options contracts. They are identified in the tables today on page D17.

title: Market Place;   Will Businessland Face a Takeover?
description: WHEN Businessland Inc. shocked Wall Street with a fourth-quarter loss far in excess of any analyst's estimate, its shares immediately lost 58 percent of their value. Could the big personal computer retailer, which had revenues of $1.35 billion for the fiscal year 1990 but now has a valuation in the $90 million range, be a takeover candidate?

title: Green Tide Rolls In At 'Money Beach'
description: For the second time in two years, money hs washed ashore here, setting off an eager scramble Tuesday afternoon for the bills in denominations of $1, $5, $10 and $20, Police Capt. James Nickles said.

title: Fully Insure Deposits Of Public Pension Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Millicom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Millicom said a change in accounting method, adopted in the fourth quarter 1989, resulted in the capitalization of acquisition fees relating to the addition of new subscribers by the company's U.K. cellular reselling business. This resulted in a decrease to net loss for the latest 6 months and quarter of $5,665,000, or 37 cents a share, and $1,487,000, or 10 cents a share, respectively. Prior to Oct. 1, 1989 it was policy to expense such fees in the current period.

title: Professor Testifies on Ethics of Bush's Son
description: A Government witness in the conflict of interest case against Neil Bush says the President's son lost his ethical moorings but did not try to deceive anyone while a director of a Denver savings and loan.

title: Knowledgeware Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yanks Help Langston Forget His Troubles
description: The solution to Mark Langston's problems? Simple. Give him the Yankees.

title: Sharing the Burden in the Gulf
description: LEAD: The Persian Gulf crisis reveals with new clarity a decades-old fault line in the Western alliance: the difficulties in sharing security burdens beyond the area of the North Atlantic Treaty or, in Japan's case, the Western Pacific. A way has to be found to share the burden more equitably.

title: When Guards Turn Lawless
description: Nearly everyone connected with this week's ugly turmoil at New York City's Rikers Island jail has something to answer for: the guards, who let their legitimate grievances spill over into destructive lawlessness; the Dinkins administration, for letting the lawlessness drag on so long, and Mr. Dinkins's predecessor, who allowed conditions at Rikers Island to reach a flashpoint.

title: Home Improvement
description: SO-CALLED flat roofs, which almost always slope slightly to facilitate drainage, should be inspected about twice a year. Routine maintenance and minor repairs usually can be done easily by amateurs, but widespread or major damage should be handled promptly by a licensed roofer.

title: Inmates Are Prey in 'Ultimate Hunt'
description: A senior Texas prison official and two friends joined in the hunt of a prison inmate as part of an exercise to train dogs to track escapees. Then he ordered jackets embroidered with the slogan ''The Ultimate Hunt'' and sent them to his friends as souvenirs of their adventure.

title: Healthvest reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Fed Blocks Banks' Merger, Citing Concerns on Capital
description: In the clearest signal yet of the importance the Federal Reserve Board places on banks maintaining high levels of capital, the nation's central bank today rejected a proposal by the Bank of New York to acquire a $2.7 billion Connecticut bank-holding company, citing concerns that the resulting institution would not have sufficient capital reserves.

title: Hardware to Make Home More Homey
description: With housing prices way down, the fear at the National Hardware Show, which ended here today, was that retailers and wholesalers would be in no mood to make big purchases. So manufacturers resorted to the obvious: They displayed products that would allow homeowners to improve and beautify their existing properties.

title: Citizens Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Conagra Finishes Deal for Beatrice
description: Conagra Inc. became one of the world's largest food companies when it completed its $1.34 billion acquisition of the Beatrice Company. The deal, completed Tuesday, unites some of the country's best-known food brands: Beatrice makes Peter Pan peanut butter, Hunt's and Wesson condiments and oils, and Conagra makes Banquet, Armour and Chun King foods.

title: A Cat May Look at a Cat
description: Over the past 10 years a New Yorker who is less a pet lover than an easy mark has housed five cats. Not one of them was what the world calls a looker. No oohs and aahs followed when these cats entered the room. One with a little black goatee under her chin even evoked laughter. Another was indistinguishable from every tabby that ever strolled the earth.

title: Castles in the Sand, For Fun and Profit
description: Lucinda Wierenga and Walter McDonald, who live on South Padre Island in Texas, make a living building sand castles. They aren't rich yet, they admit, but they say they are having a lot of fun.

title: Philippine Rebel Leader Orders New Attacks
description: Army rebels trying to oust President Corazon C. Aquino threatened today to start a new offensive against Government targets after four bomb attacks in Manila in two days.

title: Review/Opera;   Richard Strauss's 'Intermezzo,' at Glimmerglass
description: In an interesting juxtaposition with Dorothy Frank Danner's production of Benjamin Britten's ''Albert Herring'' (unveiled Saturday evening in the Alice Busch Theater), Glimmerglass Opera followed this afternoon with a performance of Leon Major's production of Richard Strauss's ''Intermezzo,'' midway through its run. The productions share certain virtues and vices. Most crucially, both inject elements of low humor into subtle, sophisticated comedies of manners.

title: Dorothy Mackaill, Actress, 87
description: Dorothy Mackaill, an actress who starred in silent and sound films in the 1920's and 30's, died on Sunday in her room at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel in Honolulu. She was 87 years old. She died of liver failure, The Associated Press said. Miss Mackaill lived in Hawaii for the last 35 years. She was born in Hull, England, and came to Broadway as a Ziegfeld girl and soon went to Hollywood. In 1927, she starred in the film ''Man Crazy'' and the next year in ''Ladies' Night in a Turkish Bath'' and, with Douglas Fairbanks Jr., in an early sound film, ''The Barker.''

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the calendar on the On Your Own page in SportsMonday this week misstated the site of the Fairfield County Sports Car Club autocross on Aug. 19. It will be held at Southern Connecticut State University, Lot No. 9, in New Haven.

title: Nabors Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results beginning March 1990 included Loffland Brothers Co., acquired in late February 1990.

title: Kill the Fresh Kills Plan
description: New York City's Board of Estimate is likely to reject a Dinkins administration proposal today that would help short-term revenues but hurt long-term garbage disposal capacity. The board is on the right track; the plan is flawed and the city would be unwise to try to revive it later.

title: Free Mail by the Bale
description: Representative Bill Clinger, a Pennsylvania Republican, has taken a stand against the election-year avalanche of free mailings by House incumbents. He's decided not to mail 218,000 newsletters, saving taxpayers $35,000. Similar restraint cannot be expected from his colleagues, most of whom seem oblivious to the House's limits on franking.

title: Odetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
APL Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $5,584,000 for the quarter and $16,335,000 for the 9 months which included $10 million loss on disposal of aluminum doors and windows segment. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $10,275,000 and $20,578,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Momentum Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A Top Macy Executive Plans Early Retirement
description: Herbert Yalof, the 53-year old president and chief operating officer of R. H. Macy & Company's Northeast division, is giving up those posts and taking early retirement.

title: Novo-Nordisk A/S reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chicago's Getaway: Not the Hamptons. No Way.
description: CALL it romantic, bucolic, rustic, nostalgic, but don't call it Harbor Country. ''I despise that name,'' said Ken Schroeder, an architect, echoing many Chicago cognoscenti who drive an hour and a half - 70 miles from the Loop - to second homes along the woodsy stretch of Lake Michigan shoreline that the regional Chamber of Commerce insisted on christening Harbor Country.

title: Moody's Establishes Unit For 'Junk Bond' Companies
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had formed a separate unit within its industrials group to focus on the day-to-day analysis of ''junk bond'' companies.

title: Review/Theater;   An Affectionate Soap-Opera Spoof
description: Early in the second act of ''Quiet on the Set,'' Terrell Anthony's frothy parody of daytime television at the Orpheum Theater, two actresses are discussing that age-old conundrum, ''Do the soaps imitate life, or does life imitate the soaps?'' The answer, they decide, is that ''both imitate commercials.'' Whatever your personal belief, if you ever watched a soap opera, you'll very likely enjoy ''Quiet on the Set.''

title: Household Finance Sells 5-Year Notes
description: The Household Finance Corporation yesterday offered $150 million of five-year notes at competitive bids.

title: Craftmatic-Contour Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest share earnings for the quarter and 9 months are after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Hector of Jets Scheduled For Surgery on Right Knee
description: When Dick Steinberg took over late last year as head of the Jets' football operations, he uttered a prophetic cliche: ''You can never have too many good football players at any position.''

title: Cypress Fund Inc. reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Assets represented net assets.

title: Market Flat, With Dow Up By Only 0.50
description: The stock market ended flat for the second consecutive session, but only after fighting off earlier weaknesses in very choppy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the trading session up 0.50, to 2,748.27.

title: Owens-Illinois Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss from early extinguishment of debt of $40,500,000.

title: After Blackout, a Broker Making Do
description: With the power still out yesterday at the Wall Street brokerage firm of County Natwest USA, 50 of its top men and women grabbed their Rolodexes, packed up their briefcases and piled into taxis for the move to their third makeshift office in three days.

title: Iran Has Condemned the Iraqi Invasion;   Creators of a Monster
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

McDermott Executive Named to 2 New Posts
description: LEAD: McDermott International Inc., an energy services and military contractor in New Orleans, has named John P. Eckert to the new positions of president and chief operating officer.

title: LTV Unit Pleads Guilty Over Air Force Contract
description: A military contractor has pleaded guilty to obtaining Defense Department information illegally to win an Air Force contract worth $5.9 million.

title: Teheran is Pleased
description: Iraq took a dramatic step today to counter its growing international isolation over the invasion of Kuwait, offering to meet almost all of Iran's conditions for settling key issues persisting from their eight-year war.

title: As New England Goes, So May Go the Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: The Latest Accessories Writ Little and Large
description: THIS is the week of the tchochke. At the New York International Gift Fair, 2,200 exhibitors from North and South America, Europe, Australia, Asia and Africa are showing their latest designs, affectionately known by the decorating world as ''accessories.''

title: Colorado Voters Pick Candidates for Senate Race
description: Josie Heath, a former Boulder County Commissioner, won the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in a primary on Tuesday, easily defeating an underfinanced candidate whose campaign had centered on his attacks against the savings and loan industry.

title: Sonora Gold Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Sports Pages yesterday listing the leading home run hitters among rookies this season misidentified Greg Vaughn's team. It is the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Robert C. Kilmartin, Retired Marine General, 93
description: Robert C. Kilmartin, a retired brigadier general in the United States Marine Corps, died on Sunday at his home in McLean, Va., at the age of 93. His family said he died of cardio-pulmonary arrest.

title: The Meaning of Objects
description: To The Home Section:

title: Pilot Alcohol Rule Called Inadequate
description: Federal regulations that prohibit pilots from flying with a blood alcohol level of 0.04 percent or more or within eight hours after drinking an alcoholic beverage are medically inadequate, a new study says. Studies clearly show that that a pilot can conform to the rules and still be feeling the effects of the liquor while flying, according to research published in Thursday's edition of the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: China Seeks New Image as Asian Games Host
description: At a busy intersection here the other day, a young policeman wheeled around and scolded a knot of bicyclists for stopping in the middle of a crosswalk. When one of the bewildered cyclists pointed out that there was no crosswalk painted on the newly repaved boulevard, the officer said: ''You know the rules! What would a foreigner think of such a stupid excuse?''

title: Fines to Begin For Violating Recycling Law
description: Starting today, New Yorkers who violate the city's year-old recycling law face fines that begin at $25 and rise to $10,000.

title: OMI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,028,000 from the sale of a vessel.

title: Formal Dinner Is Victor
description: Formal Dinner may be only the second- or third-best 2-year-old in D. Wayne Lukas's stable, but that was good enough to make him an easy winner over a very weak field today in the $92,100 Sanford Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title:
Currents;

Modern Business Surge At the Flatiron Building
description: LEAD: THE Flatiron Building developed a curious fashion reputation when it was built in 1902. Gawkers would gather at the base to look at women's skirts billowing up from the drafts created around the solitary 21-story tower at Broadway, Fifth Avenue and 23d Street. Times change, but soon skirts and other forms of apparel are expected to lure spectators with purchasing power to that spot.

title: Stephen S. Lai, Physician, 61
description: Stephen S. Lai, a physician and a civic leader in Chinatown in Manhattan, died on Saturday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 61 years old and lived in Watchung, N.J.

title: Ecuador Debt Talks Snagged
description: Disagreements still exist in talks between Ecuador and creditor banks over a refinancing accord for the nation's foreign debt, President Rodrigo Borja said on Tuesday in his midterm ''state of the nation'' address to the national legislature.

title: Oil Price Effect on Japan
description: Higher crude oil prices will damp Japan's economic growth in the fiscal year starting next April 1 but will have little adverse effect in the current year, the Daiwa Institute of Research said in a report today. If crude oil prices remain at about $25 a barrel after October, the growth of the gross national product in Japan in the 1991-92 fiscal year will shrink to 3.5 percent, the report said. It is expected to grow by 4.7 percent this year. The report forecasts that higher oil prices will help to push up consumer prices in 1991-92 by 3 percent after a 2.4 percent rise in the current fiscal year.

title: The Regional Tilt In the S.& L. Bailout
description: LEAD: Are there winners or losers in the nation's multibillion-dollar savings and loan bailout? With so many failed savings institutions concentrated in so few states, isn't the bailout a regional transfer of wealth? Oh no, opines The Washington Post: ''Most of the big S.& L.'s that went bankrupt were competing furiously for brokered deposits .

title: Whitehall Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Critic's Notebook;   Spike Lee's Jews and the Passage From Benign Cliche Into Bigotry
description: In Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' there is a scene he refers to in the published screenplay as ''The Racial Slur Montage.'' One by one, a range of ethnic characters stare into the camera and spit out vicious, stereotypical descriptions of some other ethnic group. The black man played by Mr. Lee says, ''Dago, wop, garlic-breath''; an Italian comes back with, ''Gold-chain-wearing, fried-chicken-and-biscuit-eatin' monkey,'' and a Hispanic man sneers at Koreans as ''slanty-eyed, me-no-speak-American, own every fruit and vegetable stand in New York.'' Forcing viewers to experience this kinetic barrage of ethnic insults is not the most subtle cinematic technique. But it leaves no doubt about Mr. Lee's attitude. The variety of types demonstrates that all bigotry is interchangable, all equally harmful.

title: Talking Deals;   Loral's Fast Move Wins a Ford Unit

One of them, Michael Trant, a former associate deputy attorney general, pleaded guilty to one count of cocaine possession, and the other, Richard Guida, who headed the state attorney general's criminal division until 1986, admitted one count of cocaine distribution. Mr. Guida is a longtime associate of Henry G. Barr, a former top aide to United States Attorney General Dick Thornburgh; Mr. Barr was indicted on drug charges by a Federal grand jury in Harrisburg last week.

title: Cambodian Devaluation
description: Struggling to rebuild its economy amid war and international isolation, Cambodia devalued its currency to 460 riel to the dollar from 360 riel, the official press agency said today. Cambodia's economy, virtually destroyed during the Khmer Rouge rule of 1975-79, has shown signs of improvement under free-market policies introduced by Prime Minister Hun Sen. But inflation is running at 200 percent and the Government faces cuts in aid from Eastern Europe.

title: 2 Audits Criticize Parking Bureau For Misuse of Its Computer System
description: State and city officials released audits yesterday showing that New York City's Parking Violations Bureau has been so poorly run that millions of dollars in tickets have been issued to people who do not own cars, people whose cars have been stolen and people who have already paid their fines.

Malaysia currently produces 595,000 barrels of crude a day. The Asean countries are Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, Singapore, Brunei and Malaysia.

Review/Theater;   Wharton, James and the Morality of Old New York

Together they walked the paths and terraces of this beautiful estate. title: In Cars, Muscle vs. Mileage
description: Experts on automobiles say technologies are readily available to make cars go much farther on a gallon of gasoline, reducing the demand for oil and therefore lessening the impact of events like the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But a renewed taste for cars with muscle is devouring gains in fuel economy.

title: After Uprising at Rikers, Guards Are Said to Have Beaten Inmates
description: New York City officials are investigating allegations that correction officers lined up and beat inmates with nightsticks in a jailhouse corridor on Rikers Island several hours after subduing a disturbance there on Tuesday night.

title: Meat Price Decline Seen
description: Consumers will see some relief from record meat prices as production increases next year, the Agriculture Department said today. Retail pork prices are expected to decline about 1 percent to 3 percent in 1991 from this year's record level, the department's Economic Research Service said. Poultry prices may be down 4 percent to 6 percent. The 1991 forecast was based on indications that farmers will increase livestock production in response to favorable returns this year.

title: Syntrex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 29

The company said the increase in revenue in the latest periods is due primarily to the company's expanded customer base which resulted from the acquisition of the former Lanier Business Systems unit of Harris Corp. in January.

description: The eating disorders anorexia and bulimia are well known as afflictions of adolescent girls and women. But experts now say many more boys and men suffer from these problems than doctors or the public realize.

title: Rentz Leads Met Open By 7 Shots
description: Larry Rentz justified his reputation as one of the longest hitters in the area when he eagled two holes of more than 500 yards today en route to a sizzling seven-under-par 64 in the second round of the 76th Metropolitan Open. Rentz's total of 132 gave him a seven-shot lead. Rentz, in his second year as an assistant to Bob Miller at nearby Knollwood Country Club, eagled the 505-yard ninth and the 535-yard 18th to go with birdies on the 2d, 7th, 10th and 14th and a bogey on the 4th, a par 4.

Nederlander let go of the Tiger's tail and switched his allegiance to the New York Yankees.

description: The chief operating officer of the Yankees will probably file a lawsuit in the next three weeks seeking to block a hearing scheduled before Commissioner Fay Vincent into his involvement in the Howard Spira affair, people close to the executive indicated yesterday.

title: Close to Home
description: TWO nights after it happened, I saw a nicely dressed young couple laying roses at the foot of the telephone booth. There are many such shrines to the suddenly-departed all over New York - a name scrawled on a wall, a heap of flowers, a candle or two - but this was the first that I had seen. The small mound of pink and red blooms was curiously reminiscent of the plaques on Paris buildings that commemorate someone lost to gunfire during the Liberation. ''Mort pour France,'' they read, along with a name and a date, and never fail to send a little shiver down my back. ''Mort pour France,'' I used to say silently, and feel my eyes filling with cheap, easy tears.

title: Marketing Post Filled at Pepsi
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had named David Novak as executive vice president of marketing for its soft drink business.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds increased $2.38 billion, to $404.48 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 169 institutional funds increased by $829.3 million, to $101.11 billion. The assets of the 252 general-purpose funds were up by $469.9 million, to $140.4 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.09 billion, to $163.32 billion, the institute said.

title: The Vatican Needs a Dose of Glasnost
description: LEAD: The Vatican's recent announcement that theologians do not have the right to dissent publicly from the Roman Catholic Church's teachings creates a chill that will reach far beyond Catholic scholars. They now must wonder when a chance remark on a television panel, a statement in a journal article or a paragraph in a book will produce a phone call from some chancery watchman.

description: A small fire of suspicious origin broke out today in the loft of the Rodin Museum, but caused little damage. The museum, a branch of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, houses the world's largest single collection outside Franceof the sculptor's works. A piece of cloth apparently caught fire and set off an alarm, a museum spokeswoman said.

description: A Federal investigation into the possibility of widespread corruption among South Carolina legislators claimed its first political casualty today when a lawmaker who had been identified as a target of the inquiry acknowledged that he was cooperating with Government prosecutors and that his career was over.

title: Review/Theater;   Denzel Washington Portrays Shakespeare's Top Schemer
description: THE tragedy of ''Richard III'' is in the title character's perverted brilliance. In a world of dissemblers, he appears to be the only one with a comprehension of the abuses of politics, as he manipulates his way to the crown and, inevitably, falls to his doom. Any actor attempting this awesome role must be able to convey Richard's demonic sense of purpose and self-worth.

title: Lyme Disease Is Now Linked To Stroke in 20-Year-Old G.I.
description: Two neurologists have reported that a 20-year-old man suffered a stroke as a result of meningitis brought on by Lyme disease. Eleven similar cases have been documented in Europe, they say.

As a result of the inclusion of the Insurance Fund, net other expenses decreased and net income increased $21 million and $38 million from the amounts previously reported for the quarter and 6 months ended June 30, 1989, respectively.

title: Review/Photography;   Amid Train Data, Images Of Danger and Intrigue
description: Placing art in public places is a tricky business. To be successful, the work must be sufficiently provocative to engage an audience that is busy going about its own business. Yet if the art's assault on the senses is too great, it can backfire - witness Richard Serra's much-criticized and now dismantled sculpture ''Tilted Arc.''

title: Tours of Manhattan: The Facts and the Fiction
description: IT is not difficult to come to New York City and go away believing that Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis lives in a town house on ''Beekman Hill'' overlooking the East River, that the rules of baseball were made up in a building called the ''Republican Club'' at 62d Street and Fifth Avenue, that Mount Sinai Hospital is known for the face lifts it performs on movie stars, and that whites abandoned Harlem en masse in 1901 because somebody built factories across the river in New Jersey that year. All you have to do is take a sightseeing tour.

His Enemy Is the World
description: Saddam Hussein is squirming, but there's cruel logic in his harassment of foreigners captive in Kuwait, his bellicose threats to Washington and his startling overture to his archenemy, Iran. He seeks to Americanize the confrontation in the Persian Gulf. By pitting himself against President Bush, he plays shrewdly to Arab hunger for a heroic paladin of Arab grievances. This is not, however, a contest between Saddam Hussein and George Bush. It is between Saddam Hussein and the world.

title: Review/Film;   Having Mother For Dinner
description: Raul Ruiz's 1981 film, ''The Territory,'' takes a theme that has haunted modern literature from ''The Heart of Darkness'' to ''Lord of the Flies'' - the savagery bubbling beneath the veneer of civilization - and gives it a bizarre comic twist. In this variation, two American families on vacation in Europe metamorphose from sophisticated picture-perfect tourists into cannibals without much fuss during a camping trip in the South of France.

description: TRW Inc. said it would close its electronic products plant here and lay off 190 employees. Up to 40 workers could be transferred to TRW plants in Colorado Springs or San Diego within five months. TRW said its avionics and surveillance group, which includes the electronics plant, had consolidated because of declining military spending and increased competition. The move is expected to save TRW about $4 million in 1991.

Review/Music;   Spivakov And Moscow Virtuosi
description: What Vladimir Spivakov and his Moscow Virtuosi do, they do extraordinarily well. Yet listening to the Soviet violinist conducting his chamber ensemble at the Mostly Mozart concert on Sunday night, one could admire and still ask an uncomfortable question: why are they doing it? Enjoying this program of Mozart, Haydn and Vivaldi at Avery Fisher Hall, in other words, depended on how easily the observer could allow breathtaking technical accomplishment to compensate for equally breathtaking misapplications of style.

title: 14 Die in Soweto as Rival Groups Clash
description: Hand-to-hand fighting between rival black groups spread to Soweto today after three days of bloodletting east of Johannesburg while conservative whites tried to break up a meeting that was to be addressed by President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Cellcom reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $374,254 and an extraordinary credit of $370,231.

title: Christie's to Sell Philippine Artworks
description: Christie's has been asked to sell major collections of Old Master paintings and 18th- and early 19th-century English silver owned by the Philippine Government, to benefit the needs of the Philippine people.

title: Quiet, Please! Air Traffic Rerouted From U.S. Open
description: As a result of the intercession of New York City's No. 1 tennis fan, players at this year's United States Open are less likely to be thrown off their games by the incessant roar of departing airplanes. Fans at the National Tennis Center should benefit, too, by hearing the distinct thwock of each serve and volley, not to mention the full range of Monica Seles's grunts and Andre Agassi's groans.

title: Review/Film;   In the Eerie Cosmos Of David Lynch, Reality Is Reeling
description: DAVID LYNCH'S work is all a matter of disorienting scale, of emphases that are out of kilter. The same object can as easily be the surface of the moon, seen in a long shot, or a shriveled, pock-marked basketball photographed in close-up.

title: Stock Plan Backed At Western Union
description: Shareholders of the Western Union Corporation approved the reclassification of the company's preferred stock into common. The vote, at the company's annual meeting, ''put us through the first step of a planned recapitalization,'' the company's president, Robert J. Amman, said. The next step is Western Union's offer to exchange cash, common stock and new notes for the company's outstanding 19.25 percent and 16 percent notes. The offer is scheduled to expire at midnight on Monday.

title: Market Place;   On Phasing Out Stock Certificates
description: WITH support from regulators, and having found what it hopes to be a way around state laws, the securities industry is moving toward doing away with the majority of stock certificates.

title: Sax, Like Yankees, in Summer Slump
description: The numbers aren't what they used to be. Steve Sax's batting average has fallen 61 points from a season ago, and his on-base percentage has tumbled. He isn't even breaking batting helmets with the same frequency: two this year, six in 1989. ''That's because they're making them tougher,'' he said. The summer of Sax's discontent has paralleled the Yankees' dismal and unending slide. The team returned from California early yesterday morning with six straight losses, the latest an 8-1 thumping by the Angels in which the struggling Mark Langston pitched a four-hitter, striking out 11. For the Yankees, a promising start to its trip through the West - a three-game sweep of the Mariners in Seattle - became a distant memory.

title: Adelphia Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Further Decline Posted By Trump's 3 Casinos
description: The performance of Donald J. Trump's Atlantic City casinos deteriorated further in the second quarter, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
