title: More Art Going Back To Germany
description: LEAD: A collection of 362 drawings and watercolors, including works by Rembrandt, Durer and van Gogh that were believed irretrievably lost after World War II, is expected to be returned to a West German museum after 45 years in the Soviet Union.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Another Ollie's

title: Gomez Loses Poise, Tie Breaker, and Contest
description: Andres Gomez lost his composure in a crucial tie breaker against Christo Van Rensburg today, and this may have cost him a berth in the quarterfinals - and perhaps even the final - of the Volvo International tournament.

title: Quixote Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $6,319,000 and $8,714,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and both losses from discontinued operations included a loss provision of $5,400,000 against future losses on the operations and the disposition of Source Scientific. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $500,000 and $975,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-After a loss of $444,000 for the latest 12 months and income of $133,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year-earlier period, both from discontinued operations.

title: Tooter Scooter Favored
description: A field of 10 evenly rated 2-year-old pacers will be in speedy pursuit of a $195,125 first-place purse at the Meadowlands tonight in the $1,043,500 Woodrow Wilson Pace, the richest event on a Million Dollar Babies program that also features the $766,000 Sweetheart for 2-year-old pacing fillies and the $350,000 Mistletoe Shalee for 3-year-old pacing fillies.

title: Gap Earnings Rise to Record
description: Buoyed by strong sales gains in all of its divisions, the Gap Inc. reported record revenues and earnings for its second quarter.

title: Quarex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: The company said it reported combined sales and earnings for the 1990 second quarter prepared on a pro forma combined basis with the sales and earnings reported by PSL Foods Inc. and affiliates with respect to its retail food business. Pro forma combined earnings for the 1990 quarter are $1,088,025, or 22 cents a share, on sales of $65,211,420. Combined earnings for the 6-month period are $1,720,814, or 35 cents a share, on sales of $124,421,103. Quarex has agreed in principle to combine with the retail food business of PSL.

title: Changes in China Offer Lessons for East Europe
description: When China specialists think about how Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union can reorganize their economies, they tend to agree on one point: transforming socialist countries into market competitors will be a far more complex and painful task than is often acknowledged.

title: Landmark Land Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Stocks Fall To 3-Month Low Point
description: The stock market tumbled yesterday to its lowest close in more than three months after being pummeled throughout the day by a worse-than-expected inflation report, falling bond prices, higher oil prices and unsettling news from the Middle East.

title: Orient-Express Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $1,500,000, or 15 cents a share.

title: Economic Scene;   A Hard Transition For the Germanys
description: THE wedding of their economies will create a boom for the two Germanys, but it also means worrisome strains for both of them.

title: Surrealism Meets Politics in Festival Latino Film
description: In ''Gentile Alouette'' (''The Colonel's Star''), one of the most intriguing features to be shown in the 1990 Festival Latino Film series, Geraldine Chaplin portrays a Hispanic movie actress working in Paris who is stalked by a colonel of the secret police of an unnamed Latin American country.

title:
An Experiment in the Catskills;

Elderly Community Linked to Hospital
description: LEAD: An experiment in retirement living next door to a general hospital is getting under way in the Catskill Mountains 90 miles northwest of New York City.

title: Deadline Is Nearing For Jets' Quarterbacks
description: The Jets' quarterback - whoever that will be - has two games remaining to win the starting job.

title: Westbridge Computer reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $63,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pemex Adopts a Corporate Tone
description: Since Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, many industrialized nations have looked nervously to countries like Mexico, one of the largest producers of oil outside the Middle East. But Mexico's state-owned oil company, long past the glory days of the early 1980's when prices were high, will probably not be much help. Short of cash, it is worried about its ability to produce enough oil even to satisfy domestic demand, Indeed, the company, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, is being forced into an important change: The institution that represents a nationalist aspiration to run the economy free of foreign interference is beginning to behave like an international corporation. It is seeking foreign investment and cutting costs, reducing the multimillion-dollar social programs it has subsidized for decades.

title: Vincent Going to Italy
description: Jay Vincent, a nine-year veteran of the National Basketball Association and a member of the Los Angeles Lakers last season, has signed a one-year contract worth $700,000 with Philips Milan of the Italian League, the team announced yesterday. Vincent, 31 years old, played for five teams in his N.B.A. career, averaging 15.2 points. In 41 games for the Lakers last season, the 6-foot-7-inch forward averaged 5.2 points and 11.2 minutes. (AP)

title: Advest Buyback
description: The board of Advest Group Inc. approved a plan to buy back up to two million shares, or about 20 percent of the company's common stock. The intermittent purchases will be conducted in the open market, Advest said. The company is a regional brokerage based in Hartford. Its shares closed today at $3.75, up 50 cents each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: American Real Estate PartFners reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Film;   Sibling Rivalries, Old and New
description: In ''Daddy's Dyin' . . . Who's Got the Will?'' the children of a Texas farmer return to the homestead to relive old enmities and fight over their inheritances.

description: Two part owners of the Yankees did yesterday what George Steinbrenner, the principal owner, cannot do. They sued the baseball commissioner.

title: The Frantic Shuffle in Air Fares
description: The fast and furious ''fare of the day'' game played by airlines in the last two weeks reflects how the industry is caught between the rising cost of fuel and depressed travel caused by a soft economy.

description: An 842-foot tanker crashed into a floating motel for river workers near the mouth of the Mississippi south of here Wednesday night, injuring 50 people.

description: Donald Woods, a former newspaper editor who escaped from South Africa in 1977 after being banned for challenging the police account of the 1977 death of Stephen Biko, returned from exile today.

What to See And When To
description: Movies in the 1990 Festival Latino Film series, sponsored by the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, are to be shown starting today at the Worldwide Cinemas, 50th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Shorts and documentaries are to be shown at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, next Friday to Aug. 30. Screening tickets are $7. Information: 598-7155. Here is a schedule of films this weekend.

description: In a court decision that may strengthen the hand of cooperative apartment owners in financially troubled buildings, a New York State Supreme Court judge yesterday upheld the right of the owners of a Greenwich Village building to auction off 106 apartments owned by a sponsor who is far behind in his maintenance payments.

description: The Commission on Quality Care for the Mentally Disabled recently released a list of the state's 14 worst adult homes. Their residents are mainly former mental patients or poor people unable to care for themselves. Inspectors noted that many homes resembled old back wards of state hospitals.

title: More lawyers are less happy at their work, a survey finds.
description: An American Bar Association survey has corroborated what has become increasingly apparent to lawyers, legal recruiters and psychiatrists: job dissatisfaction among lawyers is widespread, profound and growing worse.

title: Banc One Notes
description: The Banc One Corporation offered $200 million of 20-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers. The 10 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, mature Aug. 15, 2010. They were priced at $99.875, to yield 10.25 percent, 1.40 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's benchmark 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 at the time of pricing. The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Hearns's Manager Is Facing Some Uncertainty
description: One man who is taking seriously the rumors that Thomas Hearns may defect from Emanuel Steward, the only manager and trainer he has had since turning pro in 1977, is Steward himself.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE LAST MONTH BY A SHARP 0.4%
description: In a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy, the Labor Department said today that the Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected increase that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. title: British Wages Up 10%
description: Average earnings of British workers rose 10 percent in the fiscal year ended in June despite Government appeals to employers to hold down wages to fight inflation, official figures showed today. In addition, unemployment increased by a seasonally adjusted 10,900 in July, to 1.63 million, or 5.7 percent of the work force. Both earnings, which were up from 9.75 percent in May.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   At Saudi Base, G.I.'s on Move and Others on Edge
description: Maj. Gen. William G. Pagonis keeps his gas mask and protective clothes in a bag by his feet as he surveys senior officers inside the Saudi Air Force Base at Dhahran, where they are directing the largest American troop deployment since the Vietnam War.

description: b-Net loss The company changed its name and business direction in early 1990 and has acquired seven companies since February 1990. The company was formerly known as Republic Resources.

title: Ex-Farah Head Loses Contest
description: William F. Farah, the former chairman and chief executive of Farah Inc., lost his bid yesterday to unseat a majority of the directors and was himself removed from the board, as a result of voting at a special stockholders meeting last Friday. Farah Inc., based in El Paso, is a leading maker of men's apparel.

title: An Editor Is Appointed At Esquire
description: The Hearst Corporation yesterday announced the appointment of Terry McDonell, the founder and editor in chief of Smart magazine, to be the new editor of Esquire, the venerable men's magazine that helped establish both the ''new journalism'' of the 1960's and the ''new man'' of the 1980's.

description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 1-for-10 reverse stock split on Aug. 3, 1990. Revenue for latest quarter included deferred revenue of $7,647,735 to be recognized in future years.

title: Wofford Kreth Smith, Campus Chaplain, 62
description: The Rev. Wofford Kreth Smith, an Episcopal priest who was chaplain at the University of Mississippi during the turbulent era of integration, died on Aug. 10 at his home in College Park, Md. He was 62 years old.

title: Liberian Rebel Leader Hurt in Crash
description: The leader of one of Liberia's rebel factions, Charles Taylor, was injured in an automobile accident today while traveling to meet a group of West African leaders to discuss a cease-fire in Liberia's civil war, a rebel spokesman said. The talks were postponed.

title: 5 Months Later, Youth Set Afire Returns Home
description: Five months after he was set on fire and almost burned to death, 12-year-old David Opont said yesterday, as he went to his family's new home in Brooklyn for the first time, that he was ''angry but not a lot'' at the older boy who the police say inflicted the agony.

title: Bloodstains Support Claims of Guards' Violence
description: A Rikers Island jailhouse is said to have been found splattered with well over a dozen bloodstains, including palm and finger prints - evidence that strengthens allegations that correction officers retaliated against prisoners in the wake of an uprising on Tuesday night.

title: Strober Organization Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said losses were the result of a continuing decline in construction activity in its marketing area and the closing of the West Haven, Conn. center.

title: American Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $107,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Hewlett In Move To France
description: In a move reflecting the growing importance of the European market, the Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it was moving the headquarters of its personal computer group from Sunnyvale, Calif., to Grenoble, France.

title: New Mission at Energy Dept.: Bomb Makers Turn to Cleanup
description: Less than two years after the Energy Department acknowledged it had caused grave pollution problems at active and inactive nuclear weapons plants in more than 30 states, the department is headed toward becoming the Government's largest environmental agency.

title: Hearing on Eligibility
description: During a 90-minute hearing in Federal court in South Bend, Ind., yesterday, Braxston Banks, a former Notre Dame running back, began his challenge of National Collegiate Athletic Association eligibility rules. Judge Robert Miller Jr. said he would rule on the case this morning.

title: Berry Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Study Says Alzheimer's Medicine Is Useless
description: A study made public today concludes that the only medication approved by the Government for treating Alzheimer's disease is useless and may actually make the disease worse.

description: Results included the operations of wholly owned MacKenzie Investment Management Inc., which reported losses of $766,417, compared with $1,116,710 for year-ago period. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Ames Will Close Office in Syracuse
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it would close its regional accounting office here in a companywide plan to consolidate jobs and cut costs. The closing of the Ames downtown Syracuse office will put nearly 160 people out of work, a company spokesman, Bill Roberts, said.

title: After Long Decline, Teen Births Are Up
description: An 18-year-long decline in teen-age birth rates has reversed itself abruptly, with the sharpest increase among mothers 15 to 17 years old, the Federal Government reports.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: The condition of CURTIS MAYFIELD, the rhythm-and-blues musician who was hurt in a freak accident Monday at an outdoor concert in Brooklyn, remains critical, Phil W. Petrie, the director of public affairs at Kings County Hospital, said yesterday afternoon. The police said earlier that a thunderstorm toppled overhead stage lights.

description: With the New York City Police Department stretched thin by budget cuts and rising crime, many New Yorkers are asking, ''Where are the police?''

description: George Steinbrenner has told his partners that he plans to name a new general manager before he yields control of the Yankees next week, according to partners who attended the ownership meeting in Cleveland on Wednesday.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Tankers Stalled at Gulf As Sanctions Take Hold
description: An unusually large number of commercial ships are anchored outside the Strait of Hormuz entrance to the Persian Gulf, tanker rates for the gulf have fallen and most Iraqi-owned ships are not trying to pick up or unload cargoes in ports around the world, shipping experts said here today.

title: Dataram Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Legion Post Bars a Black Man
description: A Vietnam veteran was denied membership in an all-white American Legion post here last month because he is black, and the incident has led the organization's national headquarters to call for an investigation.

title: Federal Reserve Coping With Power Problems
description: The emergency power systems that kept the banking system in business after Monday's power failure in the financial district in Manhattan are showing signs of wear, causing a new round of problems.

Atwater Condition Worsens, Republican Officials Report
description: The Republican National Chairman, Lee Atwater, has received additional radiation treatment as an inoperable brain tumor has worsened, party officials said today.

title: Rose Is Working In Prison Machine Shop
description: Pete Rose is earning 11 cents an hour working in a prison machine shop and isn't playing for the inmates' softball team yet, the assistant warden said yesterday.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the India Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed on Sunday between 26th and 47th Streets from 1:30 to 4 P.M. For a related street fair, Madison Avenue will be closed between 23d and 26th Streets from noon to 8 P.M.

title: Hugh Gladstone Koehler, Investment Banker, 60
description: Hugo Gladstone Koehler, an investment banker, died on Tuesday at a friend's home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Cos Cob, Conn.

title: An AIDS Martyr the Media Can Love
description: LEAD: Recently a local columnist wrote a sympathetic article about Alison Gertz, a beautiful young woman who contracted the AIDS virus eight years ago in her only sexual encounter with a man. Since going public, Ms. Gertz has been chosen ''Woman of the Year'' by Esquire magazine, appeared on the cover of People and embarked on a national tour to educate others on AIDS.

title: Mall Building Has Slowed
description: Reflecting a cutback in lending by commercial banks, the number of new shopping-center starts in the United States fell sharply in the first half of 1990, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade group based in New York.

title: Drug Suspension For Bax of Bucs
description: Carl Bax of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, sentenced to one year of probation after pleading guilty to two charges of steroid importation, was suspended today from the first three games of the National Football League regular season.

title: Lawrence A. Frost, 83, Podiatrist and Author
description: Dr. Lawrence A. Frost, a podiatrist and a historian who published several books on Gen. George A. Custer, died on Tuesday at Mercy Memorial Hospital in Monroe, Mich. He was 83 years old and lived in Monroe. His family said he died of cardiac arrest.

I.R.S. Seeks $7 Billion From Exxon
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it had received a bill from the Internal Revenue Service for nearly $7 billion for the years 1979 through 1982. It said, however, that the amount in serious dispute was $2 billion, which grew out of an argument over how it priced oil it bought from Saudi Arabia during the oil crisis in that period.

title: Restaurants
description: In recent years, the Ambassador Grill, a cosmopolitan French restaurant next to the United Nations, has been a favorite haunt of people in the diplomatic community. With its commodious setting, agreeable food and remarkably low prices, it has been an underappreciated find in this otherwise barren gastronomic domain.

title: The Judge Not Chosen and Hustler Case;   Souter Etymologized
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korean Riot Police Block Students Seeking to Open Border
description: South Korean students gathered today near the border with North Korea and fought with riot police blocking their way to the North.

title: PCL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $2,408,000 gain on the sale of the furniture and equipment rental businesses. c-Included $609,000 and $721,000 in income for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the businesses sold. Results for 1989 have been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Kentucky Law Officials Are Arrested in Drug Sting
description: The sheriffs of four counties in the eastern Kentucky hills were arrested by Federal agents today on allegations that they took money to protect people they believed were drug traffickers shipping cocaine through the state.

title: Lew DeWitt, 52, Tenor With Statler Brothers
description: Lew DeWitt, the tenor and guitarist of the Statler Brothers country-music group for 20 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Waynesboro, Va. His death resulted from heart and kidney disease, his mother said. He was 52 years old.

title: Xscribe Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
At the Movies
description: ''She's a wild little tidbit.'' That's Laura Dern talking about Lula Pace Fortune, the character she plays in David Lynch's ''Wild at Heart,'' which opens today.

title: Premdor Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $441,000. The company said the increase in revenue was due to the merger of Premdor and Century Wood Door Ltd. in August 1989. Share earnings for latest 6 months were nil. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: INSIDE
description: Teen-Age Birth Rate on Rise

title: Riverside Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Study Finds the U.S. Lags In Communications Goods
description: A study of the nation's telecommunications equipment industry, released yesterday by the Commerce Department, has found that the United States is no longer competitive in markets for consumer products like telephones and facsimile machines and is losing ground in markets for business and telephone company equipment.

title: Pacesetter Business ProperFties reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for 1989 periods included a reserve which increased the loss by $899,000.

title: Young Giants' Defenders Making Good Impressions
description: Mike Fox, Clint James and Greg Mark are growing increasingly important to the Giants. That's because Erik Howard and Leonard Marshall, who represent two-thirds of the Giants' proposed starting defensive line, continue to be absent from training camp.

title: Compudyne Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $29,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $119,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and included a loss of $47,000 for the quarter and income of $4,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. The company said the latest share earnings reflect accrual of dividends on Compudyne preferred stock held by Corcap Inc.

title: Review/Film;   An Adman, His Filofax And a Thief
description: The working title of ''Taking Care of Business'' was ''Filofax,'' a word that reeks of yesterday's yuppies. But being a year or so behind the social curve is the least of this hoary comedy's problems. The screenplay was written by Jill Mazursky, the 25-year-old daughter of the director Paul Mazursky (who is this film's executive producer), and Jeffrey Abrams, who is 24. It might have been invented by two Hollywood hacks who have been churning out scripts for 40 years. This is the old, old trading places gag, and while a good idea can always be reinvented, invention is precisely what ''Taking Care of Business'' lacks.

title: For Children
description: SHOWS, NATURE, MUSEUMS

title: Ralph's Grocery Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 15
description: b-Included charges of $1.3 million in the quarter and $2.6 million in the 6 months for amortization of intangibles previously allocated to goodwill. Net income before taxes, equity appreciation rights, amortization of goodwill, and the above charges was $4.1 million for the quarter and $10.7 million for the 6 months. The company, which is an indirect, wholly-owned unit of Campeau Corp., has not filed for Chapter 11 under the bankruptcy code; the company is, however, owned by units of Campeau that have filed for Chapter 11.

title: Rose's Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Included one-time pretax gain of about $5.4 million resulting from the sale of Rose's Shoe operations to J. Baker Inc.; the company said the impact of this gain was partially offset by an increased LIFO charge. c-Net loss Latest and year-ago quarter sales included sales relating to leased departments. Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect a change in the timing of markdown recording and to conform with 1990 presentation. The change will affect 1989 by quarter but will not impact the annual results.

title: Owner of Disabled Car Finds Market Sluggish
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Brahms Festival, the Man and the Music
description: As most of the summer festivals in the area are winding down for the season and presenting their final weeks of events, Bard College, in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., is about to inaugurate what its president, Leon Botstein, says he hopes will be an annual series at the school.

title: Hewlett-Packard Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago periods reflected just 2 months of results of Apollo Computer Inc., which was acquired in May 1989.

title: Louis Barron, 71, Dies; Barnes & Noble Editor
description: Louis Barron, editor in chief of Barnes & Noble Books, died on Monday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan while undergoing surgery for renal failure, his family said. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan and Downsville, N.Y.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf: Washington at Work;   Military Chief: Man of Action And of Politics
description: At 8 o'clock on the morning after Kuwait fell, Gen. Colin L. Powell strode into the White House crisis meeting. Armed with maps, charts and intelligence reports, people who were there say, he outlined a massive Iraqi onslaught that left the President convinced that military response was inevitable.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: ROBERT THEODORE CURRAN has been named the president and chief executive of the Foreign Policy Association, a national nonprofit organization that seeks to educate the public about foreign policy issues and to provide a forum for debate. Mr. Curran, 58 years old, has been the president of Springfield (Ill.) College since 1987.

title: Gemco National Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $750,000 from settlement of two lawsuits.

title: ON STAGE
description: The Schedule-Making Season

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Navy Begins Blockade Enforcing Iraq Embargo
description: The United States said today that its naval forces in the Persian Gulf, the Gulf of Oman and the Red Sea had begun their blockade of vessels carrying oil, food and other supplies to and from Iraq and Iraqi-controlled Kuwait.

title: Uni-Select Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: New Retail Concepts Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represented net revenue. The company said that the increase in revenues is primarily attributable to the commencement by the company on Nov. 1, 1989 of purchase and taking title to merchandise and then reselling the same ot its customers. As a result the company experienced increased revenues and related cost of sales. Prior to Nov. 1, 1989 the company's revenues were derived principally from commissions and licensing fees.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I suppose one has to have hope. Without hope you can't get anywhere.''

title: TEHERAN TO BACK SANCTIONS; NEW THREAT MADE IN KUWAIT;   PEACE HOPE FADING
description: President Bush and King Hussein of Jordan failed today to make significant progress toward easing the Middle East crisis, and Mr. Bush was apparently unable to win ironclad assurances from the King that he would halt shipments to Baghdad through the Jordanian port of Aqaba.

title: Precision Aerotech reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $209,000 and $5,775,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,209,000 and $2,048,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for 1989 have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Reader's Digest Association Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pool Energy Services Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Franklin Ebaugh, 68, V.A. Medical Official
description: Franklin G. Ebaugh Jr., chief of staff at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif., and a former dean of two medical schools, died on Aug. 7 at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: The monument to WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT in the park named for him behind the main New York Public Library is $265,000 closer to restoration.

title: Baby's Death Renews Move To End Common Law Rule
description: An infant who was shaken into a coma when she was 3 1/2 months old died 18 months later, in February 1989. Because the girl stayed alive that long, murder charges against her father were thrown out this month.

title: Workout for Dorsett
description: Tony Dorsett, 36 years old and six months into retirement, took his first major step toward a comeback by working out Wednesday for the Dallas Cowboys' director of pro personnel, John Wooten.

title: Hawaii Faces Biggest Fish Cookout in History
description: To the Editor:

title: Stateswest Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Marshall Steel reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the history of Yankee ownership misstated the period in which Michael Burke ran the team.

title: Vandal Vessels Invade the Atlantic
description: International outrage has squeezed drift-net fishing fleets out of the South Pacific and forced them to accept supervision in the North Pacific. But there are signs that these vandal vessels are now shifting to Atlantic waters. The fleets' host nations, Taiwan in particular, need to monitor their boats' behavior much more closely.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apple Bank for Savings, New York, a subsidiary of Apple Bancorp Inc., appointed Thomas S. Fiumefreddo, an assistant vice president and mortgage appraiser, as vice president and chief appraiser of its commercial mortgage division.

title: Woman Says Atlanta Archbishop Performed Their Own Wedding
description: In her first public comment since her affair with the Roman Catholic Archbishop here led to his resignation, a Georgia woman said today that their relationship had been formalized in a wedding ceremony he performed.

title: Steinbrenner on the Ban
description: Speaking publicly for the first time on his agreement with Commissioner Fay Vincent to yield control of the Yankees permanently, George Steinbrenner said he had rejected a two-year suspension because he could not have accepted it ''and continue to do the one thing that means most to me right now, and that is the U.S. Olympic Committee.''

title: Critic's Choice
description: Jazz dance was once a distinctly poor relative to ballet and modern dance. But it has got a much better name in recent years, thanks in part to the artistry of the Hubbard Street Dance Company. This weekend, East Coast audiences will have their first chance to see the results of the Tharp Project, a collaboration of Hubbard Street and the noted modern dance choreographer Twyla Tharp, at the Ted Shawn Theater of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass.

title: Onex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included non-operating gains of $2.3 million. Latest and year-ago 6-month share earnings are given after the effect of a stock dividend paid in March. Before the dividend, the earnings per share were 37 cents a share, compared with 80 cents a share, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Aspen Music Festival Appoints New Director
description: Lawrence Foster has been appointed music director of the Aspen Music Festival and School for a three-year term beginning in October. Mr. Foster, who also recently became the music director of the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra, will be responsible for planning the programs of the nine-week Aspen Music Festival. He will also oversee the curriculum at the Aspen Music School, which operates during the festival each summer.

title: Trial By Crucible
description: The last time the King of Jordan bore a message from Saddam Hussein to another chief of state, according to Kuwait's now-deposed Emir, it was this: Do not mobilize your troops lest you provoke Iraq.

title: Solzhenitsyn Cool as Moscow Confirms Offer
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn and 22 other exiled literary, scientific and cultural figures are on a list of people whose citizenship has been restored by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, officials said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc., Oakland, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill Advertising, San Francisco, for its entire line of products, with a budget of $8 million to $10 million. This is the second new account for Goldberg Moser O'Neill, which was formed in June in a buyout of Chiat/ Day/Mojo's San Francisco office by the managers.

title: Westmin Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings are after payment of preferred share dividends. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said the decline in revenue mainly reflected the sale of its oil and gas assets to Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. Westmin said the decline in earnings reflected unscheduled equipment repairs at its H-W Mine, which reduced output, as well as severance costs associated with a reorganization announced in June. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver Stock Exchanges.

title: As New York Crime Rises, Police Officers Contend With Many Other Chores
description: With the New York City Police Department stretched thin by budget cuts and rising crime, New Yorkers from politicians to beleaguered shopkeepers to worried parents are asking the same question: Where are the police?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York's efforts to dispose of low-level radioactive waste described two companies incorrectly. The companies, NDL Organization in Peekskill and Radiac Research in Brooklyn, are the state's two largest brokers of the waste, arranging for its transportation and disposal. They are not the largest producers of radioactive waste.

title: 13 Are Charged In Theft of Data From Computers
description: Thirteen people, including a 14-year-old boy who is a suspect in a computer break-in at the office of the Secretary of the Air Force, were arrested yesterday and charged with breaking into and stealing information from a variety of computers, the New York State Police said.

title: John Adams Life Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Auctions
description: In 1988, Habsburg, Feldman, a little-known Geneva-based auction house with lofty ambitions, opened a New York City office in a grand town house on the Upper East Side.

title: Editorial Notebook;   Hong Kong's Formula for Hope
description: Capitalists have recovered their confidence in Hong Kong. The British colony's stock market, sustained by fresh infusions of foreign capital, has now wiped out the heavy losses that followed last year's Tiananmen Square massacre.

title: Another Prized Theater For Art Films Is Closing
description: The Bleecker Street Cinema, a popular Greenwich Village theater that has shown foreign and avant-garde films since 1962, will shut down on Aug. 30 because of a sharp rent increase, its owner said yesterday.

title: Insituform of North America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Unimed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Galactic Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain of $7,412,000 from the sale of interest in Far South East Gold Resources Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 7 about Rollerblade Inc., a Minneapolis company that makes a roller skate with a single row of wheels, misstated the former jobs held by the two founders of First Team Sports, a Rollerblade competitor. David G. Soderquist previously was an independent salesman of sporting equipment, and John J. Egart worked for a distributor of Adidas products; neither has worked for Rollerblade.

title: Rocky Mountain UndergarFment reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net income and included a tax benefit from tax-loss carryforward of $656,000, or 19 cents a share, and $677,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for year-ago periods included a gain of $1,835,000 from the sale of a division.

title: Bumble Bee to Cut Jobs in Puerto Rico
description: Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc., the nation's third-largest tuna canner, said it would cut 800 jobs at a plant in Puerto Rico as it reduces its production of light-meat tuna. Bumble Bee said its plant in Mayaguez, P.R., would continue operating with more than 1,000 employees although a second shift would be eliminated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: TV Weekend;   Betraying the I.R.A. And Trying to Survive
description: One of the mysteries about ''Act of Betrayal'' is why it should take four hours to tell so simple a tale. The story, which begins tonight at 9 and concludes tomorrow night at the same time on the Arts & Entertainment cable network, has to do with the tracking down of a former officer in the Irish Republican Army named Michael McGurk, whose conscience has compelled him to turn in his ex-comrades because they set off bombs in the vicinity of children.

title: Chrysler Unit Sets $751 Million Offer
description: United States Auto Receivables Trust, a financing vehicle for the Chrysler Corporation, yesterday offered about $751 million of securities backed by car loan payments through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Review/Film;   Adapting to Being Gay Without Sturm und Drang
description: Buddy Fields is full of desperation but too full of good humor to blame others. Though in his 20's, Buddy still lives at home with his parents and younger sister in a small town in central New York State. He feels trapped. He doesn't even have the privacy in which to peruse his copy of Playgirl. When he wants to masturbate without interruption, he has to get into the family's aluminum rowboat and go to the middle of the lake.

title: Oil Prices Resume Rise as Tensions Grow
description: Oil prices resumed their climb yesterday, as a nervous market contemplated the continuing loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude, the heightened tensions in the Middle East and a delay by OPEC members in increasing their oil production.

title: Xytronyx Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Jersey May Scrap Tax on Trucks as Sales Plunge
description: Gov. Jim Florio, who has thus far resisted pressure to change any part of his $2.8 billion tax program, is prepared to rescind the sales tax on heavy trucks if the Legislature can find other sources for the $44 million in revenue that the tax was expected to produce, administration officials and legislative leaders say.

title: Valley Forge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $673,000, or 38 cents a share, and $851,000, or 48 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; both incomes from discontinued operations included a gain of $556,000 from sale of discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $134,000, or 7 cents a share, and $173,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for 1989 have been restated to reflect discontinued operation.

title: Pacesetter Homes Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.N. CHIEF ARGUES BLOCKADE IS HASTY
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations warned the United States today that unilateral action by American warships in the gulf to enforce sanctions against Iraq would breach the United Nations Charter, reports from Lima, Peru, said.

title: G.E. Aircraft Engines Will Cut 1,500 Jobs
description: The General Electric Company's aircraft engines division said today that it planned to eliminate 1,500 jobs in its American operations by 1992 because of cuts in military spending.

title: Equity Reverses 'Saigon' Vote And Welcomes English Star
description: Actors' Equity changed its mind yesterday and voted to permit the English actor Jonathan Pryce to come to Broadway to re-create his prize-winning portrayal of a Eurasian pimp in the hit London musical ''Miss Saigon.''

title: Columbia Expects Loss on 'Junk' Sale
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association said in a filing with regulators that it would lose about $50 million on the proposed sale of its nearly $3 billion portfolio of high-risk ''junk bonds.''

title: Mapplethorpe's Photos Now an F.C.C. Issue
description: Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photographs have drawn the attention of the Federal Communications Commission, which is investigating complaints against a public television station that broadcast some of the pictures.

title: Sports of The Times;   Three Years Too Harsh for Upsala
description: Dr. Robert Karsten has been a Lutheran clergyman much longer than he has been president of Upsala College, so it is no surprise that he quotes the Bible more readily than the rule book of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Ex-Leader of Kashmir Accuses Army of Brutality
description: In a blistering speech that condemned successive Indian Governments for creating ''a crisis of understanding'' in Kashmir, the former elected Chief Minister of the state accused Indian security forces today of repression, brutality and corruption in their efforts to end an uprising there.

title: Amerihealth Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $31,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $77,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $111,000, or 3 cents a share, for both the quarter 6 months, and a loss of $904,000 from a cummulative effect on years prior to 1989 of change in accounting for physician recruitment expenditures for the 6 months.

title: Housing Starts Fell 2.6% in July
description: Construction of new homes fell for the sixth straight month in July, cutting building activity to its weakest pace in nearly eight years, the Government said today.

title: Bubbles and Catcalls for Estimate Board
description: With a champagne toast amid a chorus of catcalls and clicking cameras, the New York City Board of Estimate opened its last meeting yesterday and held hearings on a number of big development projects but, as it usually does, put off most of the big decisions.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Tuesday about a meeting that included discussion of an anti-abortion campaign being financed by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops incorrectly described attendance at the meeting. Those attending the meeting, convened by the conference's Secretariat for Pro-Life Activities, were mainly priests, nuns and members of the laity who are directors of Catholic offices organizing anti-abortion activities; only one bishop, not 200, attended the meeting.

title: Wells American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the decrease in sales was due to continued suspension of production that began in January 1990. Latest quarter loss also included start-up costs and research and development expenses associated with company's new Megamac product line, as well as write-downs of about $473,000 related to discontinued product lines.

title: E-Z-EM Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net income The company said results in the latest fourth quarter and year included a provision, established by the board, of $8,000,000, relating to the anticipated loss of value associated with Lafayette Pharmacal Inc. This provision represents an estimate of the loss associated with the agreement signed June 12 with the Federal Trade Commission requiring divestiture of the Lafayette business. The company's reserve for the sale of Lafayette of $8,000,000 coupled with $1,600,000 of reduced contribution from Sugical Dynamics Inc. (a 51 percent owned subsidiary) accounted for a major portion of the reported loss. Additionally, non-recurring costs related to obtaining reimbursement for the nucleotone procedure and the relocation expense incurred in connection with the move of the company's principal manufacturing plant also affected results for the quarter and year.

title: Pol Pot: Not the Killer We Think He Is
description: LEAD: Blind hatred of Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge is pushing the U.S. toward policy changes that could well contribute to the ultimate destruction of Cambodia as an independent society through conquest by Vietnam.

title: New Orleans In New York As 2 Bands Share a Stage
description: Music defines the cultural life of New Orleans, perhaps more than it does in any other city in the United States. Whether it's a tribe of Mardi Gras Indians leading hundreds of people, singing and dancing, down the city's side streets, or Sunday brass bands that get entire neighborhoods to supply percussion accompaniment with bottles and cans, live music is part of the city's everyday existence.

title: Results Plus
description: LITTLE LEAGUE

title: Prime Financial Partnership reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEY RATES
Wasatch Education Sys reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Micro Healthsystems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
D.O.C. Optics Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Big Cities Lag in Clean Air, U.S. Says
description: More than half of all Americans live in cities that have too much ground-level ozone, the chief factor in the creation of smog, and a third live in areas with dangerously high carbon monoxide, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Wood Gundy Cuts Staff
description: Wood Gundy Inc., a big Canadian brokerage, cut 21 workers today from its investment banking staff, reflecting a slump among investment firms in Canada. Both retail and corporate investors have turned away from stocks in favor of more conservative investments after the stock market crash in October 1987 and decline in October 1989, analysts said. Wood Gundy cut about 100 jobs in July after its integration with Merrill Lynch Canada Inc., which pulled out of the retail investment business.

title: Democracy Betrayed in Myanmar
description: It seemed like a fairy-tale ending to 28 years of ruinous military dictatorship in Myanmar, formerly Burma. In May, in the country's first free election since 1962, an overwhelming majority voted for a party of persecuted opposition democrats, the National League for Democracy.

title: Acton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $2,300,000, or 87 cents a share, for the quarter and $8,086,000, or $3.07 a share, for the 6 months. There were no share earnings after consideration of preferred stock dividend requirements. The company said the year-ago earnings were mainly due to gains of $11,910,226 of its Cable Televsion System, and $11,252,223 realized from the sale of its investment in Land of Lincoln Savings & Loan.

title: Philip Morris Names 2 Leaders at Suchard
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it had selected the new leadership of Jacobs Suchard AG, the Swiss candy and coffee company that it recently acquired.

title: Equity Was Right the First Time
description: When Actors Equity took its stand on ''Miss Saigon'' in favor of fair casting opportunities for its minority members, I stood 100 percent behind my union. Now that it has reversed its decision, I am just as firmly opposed.

title: Bridge
description: One of the rarest plays in the game is the Devil's Coup, in which an apparently certain trump trick for the defense disappears in the endgame. Equally rare, and just as satisfying, is the pseudo-Devil's Coup, in which the trump trick disappears but the defense has missed an effective countermove.

title: Guardians Named for Children in Marrow Suit
description: A judge has appointed guardians for a leukemia-stricken boy and his two young half-siblings, whom the sick boy's father wants tested as potential bone-marrow donors.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: France;   Paris Stressing Independent Role
description: While strongly backing United Nations sanctions against the Baghdad Government, France has quietly distanced itself from the American response to the Iraqi crisis, apparently in the hope of protecting its influence and interests in the rest of the Arab world.

title: American Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Put the Old U.& D. Back on Track
description: Imagine you are seated in a rustic railroad passenger car, near a majestic river. The whistle blows, and you're under way - behind the nostalgic chuffing of steam power. Shortly, the level track gives way to a stiff climb, and the little engine must really work to get you up the grade. You emerge alongside the shore of a pristine reservoir, surrounded by wooded mountains, and skirt its banks for several miles. No roads intrude to mar the timeless beauty of the setting. Then you roll alongside a rushing mountain stream, world-famous for its trout fishing. Deer browse nearby, leaping at your passage.

title: California Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Debra Waxman Weds Andrew Reegen
description: Debra Lynn Waxman and Andrew Edward Reegen were married last evening at the St. Moritz hotel in New York by Walter T. Lawton, the dean of the Council of Leaders of the American Ethical Union.

Etz Lavud Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

CHRONICLE
description: To ease the burdens of office, PRESIDENT BUSH finds solace in country music because ''it is real people singing real stories that we can all understand.'' In a two-page essay in the September issue of Country America magazine titled, ''Why I Love Country Music,'' Mr. Bush wrote that ''I find myself more relaxed with Reba coming over the airwaves,'' referring to the singer Reba McEntire.

title: Community Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Writing Like a Man Just Come in From a Walk
description: Masquerade

title: Patents;   A Crib to Soothe Infants Suffering From Colic
description: A Connecticut physician, seeking relief from the crying of his baby suffering from colic, won patent approval this week for a crib that soothes infants by simulating movements of the womb.

title: St. Petersburg Times Agrees To Buy Out Bass Investors
description: After months of bitter wrangling, The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times has agreed to buy the shares of a group of unwelcome investors including Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier.

title: Visual Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Durham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,944,000 for the quarter and $2,677,000 for the 6 months.

title: PCC Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures for 1989 are unavailable; the company's initial public offering was in October 1989.

title: Amerifax Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is in the development stage.

title: United Security Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $770,000 in gross income recorded for the sale of Pilgrim Life Insurance Co. of America unit.

title: American Pacesetter reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Interpharm Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: West Germany;   In Bonn, a Debate On Limits of Power
description: A dispute has developed between Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher over how far West Germany should go militarily in joining the effort to contain Iraq.

title: How Safe Is Children's Sleepwear?
description: A growing consumer preference for natural fabrics is colliding with longstanding safety requirements that children's sleepwear be made from flame-resistant materials.

title: James Thomas Foley Dies at 80; U.S. Judge in Albany Since 1949
description: James Thomas Foley, a Federal judge for 40 years, died yesterday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 80 years old and lived in North Greenbush, N.Y.

title: Review/Theater;   Puerto Rican Double Bill Mixes Comic and Tragic
description: Repertorio Espanol has constructed an improbable double bill at the Gramercy Arts Theater: a play about a family tragedy among Puerto Ricans in New York City today and a musical about rural Puerto Rico 130 years ago. The fit is, at best, imperfect, but the musical has great charm and one leaves the pair, somewhat miraculously, with little emotional confusion.

title: Canadian Hydropower Poses No Dire Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Cellular Information Sys reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hershey Oil Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Saudi Move For OPEC Meeting

''Our Manhattan friends said we were crazy to come here. I don't think New Yorkers refuse to visit Harlem because of fear,'' Mr. Fridman said meditatively, ''They have a guilty conscience - they realize they have done nothing for the blacks.''

title: Review/Film;   When Heaven Turns Out Not to Be
description: As a New York Mafioso named Vinnie Antonelli, Steve Martin might be some genetic misfire in the Corleone family. Renamed Tod and shipped to a small California town as part of the Federal witness-protection program, Vinnie is a wise guy with a nasal voice, stand-up hair moussed to within an inch of its life and an endless supply of gray silk suits that he wears to mow the lawn. With a swagger that Mr. Martin plays to perfection, Vinnie tries to tip the F.B.I. agent (Rick Moranis) who is assigned to keep track of him, and whiles away time at the local supermarket by repricing steaks at 39 cents each and buying an armload of them. And when he stands in his own backyard and stares at the blue skies and open spaces, Mr. Martin's face expresses profound boredom with such a wholesome life.

title: OBSERVER
description: Julia Child says she is going to continue cooking and eating rich foods. This is outrageous. And what is the Surgeon General doing about it? What is medical science doing about it? They are doing nothing. They are too busy stamping out smokers. Stamping out smokers is good, to be sure. We all feel better every time we come across another filthy smoker who has just been stamped out.

title: Two Stage Triumphs
description: Actors' Equity showed good sense and good grace in admitting that it was wrong to ban the British star of the musical ''Miss Saigon'' from playing his mixed-race role on Broadway. All who love theater can rejoice in a victory for artistic freedom. But protesters who demanded more opportunity for Asian performers can be satisfied, too; their legitimate complaint has now been heard worldwide.

title: Review/Music;   Reconstituted Little Feat Still Rhythm-Prone
description: Try as it might, Little Feat can't escape the ghost of Lowell George, who died in 1979. With Mr. George as its main songwriter and singer, Little Feat brought wordplay and musical gamesmanship to 1970's Southern rock, skewing country with New Orleans polyrhythm and cutting blues with funk. The reconstituted Little Feat, which has made two albums since 1988, still boasts a rhythm section that can swing, strut, boogie and kick in ordinary or odd meters. But its songwriters - Paul Barrere on guitar, Bill Payne on keyboards and the new singer, Craig Fuller - haven't replaced Mr. George's surreal humor or his gift for melody.

Protests Close Refinery
description: Student protesters today forced an important oil refinery in India's northeast state of Assam to close and choked supplies of crude to three others, a state official said. The Assam Chief Secretary, S. R. Sarwan, said in New Delhi that picketing by the All Assam Students Union in six state oilfields had forced the state-owned refinery in the state capital, Guwahati, to close. Assam is the third- largest oil-producing state in India, which imports 40 percent of its oil. The students began the campaign three weeks ago to persuade New Delhi to enforce a 1985 accord callingfor the deportation of illegal Bangladeshi immigrants and the development of industry in Assam.

Taiwan's Indirect Trade

According to official figures, indirect trade routed through Hong Kong reached $1.83 billion in the first six months of 1990, up 4.7 percent over the corresponding period last year. Direct trade between Taiwan and China has been banned ever since Taiwan's Nationalist Government fled to the island after the 1949 Communist victory on the mainland.

description: ''THE party is over,'' said Eugene Albert, a real estate appraiser. ''The binging of the 1980's is finished.'' Mr. Albert was discussing the excesses that characterized the 1980's real estate market and led to a recent law requiring state certification of real estate appraisers.

title: About Men;   The Pennsy And Me
description: The other day, I got an announcement that there will be a 50th anniversary reunion next year of the survivors of Pearl Harbor. As part of it, all the officers who have ever served on the battleship Pennsylvania, which was hit at Pearl, have been invited to a reunion of their own. Ever since men first went down to the sea in ships, they have experienced the tender bond that exists between the seafarer and his vessel. So it was with me; I served on the Pennsy, in the Marine detachment, for two years.

title: A Grim Bush Golfs and Boats as Aides Fret About Image
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 18

title: Iroquois Pipeline Is Part of New Power Lines From Quebec
description: LEAD: THE proposed Iroquois natural-gas pipeline is one of two major projects designed to bring power from Canada to New York and other states in the Northeast.

title:
The Executive Life;

Coping in Industries The Public Hates
description: LEAD: For Susan Nahley, attending a cocktail party can be a nerve-racking experience. Try as she might to avoid confrontation, Ms. Nahley, manager of corporate communications at the Continental Corporation, an insurance company, inevitably winds up in a corner vigorously defending the entire industry - and usually to a perfect stranger.

title: A Lazzeri Vote
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE WORLD: The Gulf;   Iraq, Though Vulnerable, Has Strong Cards to Play
description: SADDAM HUSSEIN, ruthless and wily though he may be, must be an increasingly worried man.

title: If Congress Is Afraid to Declare War . . .
description: LEAD: With regard to issues of war and peace, Congress needs something new. According to civics books, Presidents need declarations of war before engaging in acts of war against nations, like Iraq, that have not attacked America. Thus, during a dispute with Spain about the Florida border, President Jefferson told

title: Bridget Maloney Weds John Bush
description: Bridget Kristine Maloney and John Kenneth Bush, graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married yesterday at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in New Hartford, N.Y. The Rev. Paul J. Drobin performed the ceremony.

title: Roads Sealed as Yugoslav Unrest Mounts
description: Hundreds of Serbs armed with rifles and pistols sealed off towns in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia today, raising fears of ethnic clashes that some Western diplomats say could lead to civil war.

title: All New York Getting Car-Theft Decal Plan
description: For car owners in New York City who have registered their cars in the Combat Auto Theft program, a late night phone call from the police may be reassuring. They may discover that their car has been recovered before they even knew it had been stolen.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the India Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed today between 26th and 47th Streets from 1:30 to 4 P.M.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Amelia Island, Fla.;

Cars on Beach Trouble Ritz
description: LEAD: THE success of a Ritz Carlton Hotel being built in this resort town 22 miles north of Jacksonville could depend on the outcome of a suit aimed at banning the driving of cars on the beach.

title: Greenwich Bookseller Strives to Be Different
description: LEAD: DURING a recent Christmas season, the administrative assistants to 25 corporate executives in Greenwich and Stamford received copies of a book illustrated with Impressionist paintings. ''This book is a bribe!'' proclaimed the enclosed card, followed by a 13-stanza poem extolling the merits of giving books for holiday gifts.

title: Now, a Real Vixen. That's Plausible Casting
description: I'm sure many thoughtful people were upset recently by the Actors' Equity decision to refuse permission for an Englishman to portray a Eurasian pimp in an American production of the musical ''Miss Saigon.'' The issue of artistic freedom, after all, does arouse emotions in the hearts of almost every American, and rightly so. But I suspect I also speak for a sizable minority of theatergoers, and specifically operagoers, in fully supporting the action of the American actors' union. It is about time some action of this sort was taken.

title: Talking: Inspections;   Caveats In Buying A Co-op
description: While a professional engineering inspection has become standard practice among buyers of one-family houses, brokers say that fewer than 10 percent of apartment buyers think it worth the cost to check out the unit - and the building - in which they intend to live.

title: Campus Life: Chicago;   Atlantic Bridge: Boxers Exchange Visits With French
description: Eight boxers from Vitry-sur-Seine, France, are spending eight days at a gymnasium on the South Side to exchange techniques and experiences with Americans.

title: Red Herrings in 'The Veil,' a Thriller
description: WHO did what to whom and why is, of course, the soul of any mystery. The only difference is in how the playwright goes about presenting the facts - and the red herrings - in the case.

title: Playing Favorites
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Brody Weds D. L. Ernsberger
description: Lisa Ruth Brody, a staff psychologist at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, was married yesterday in Brookline, Vt., to Dr. Daniel Livermore Ernsberger, a staff psychologist at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, L.I. The bridegroom's father, the Rev. Dr. David J. Ernsberger, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Massey Farm.

title: Trenton Prison Attack Seen as Inmate Plot
description: An attack on correction officers Aug. 10 at Trenton State Prison was part of a plan by a group of inmates to kill staff members at the maximum-security institution, state officials said.

title: Patricia Stanley Married on L.I.
description: Patricia Mary Stanley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Stanley of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday in Baldwin, L.I., to David Anthony Noblett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Noblett of Simi Valley, Calif. The Rev. Lawrence M. Kupferman performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Safety Hazard In the Making
description: These are so hgih that a disabled vehicle could neither drive up onto nor be pushed onto the emergency shoulder.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Forward To the Past
description: LEAD: ''WHAT's a record player?'' the clerk behind the counter asked, when I had finally decided that my faithful machine of some 20 years needed replacing.

title: Migrant Worker Group Is Subject of Wide Study
description: Feliciana Flores grimaced as the needle slipped into a vein and her blood filled a vacuum tube. But 3-year-old Sergio Flores was unafraid. ''No voy a llorar,'' he said. ''I won't cry.''

title: Dana Wysoczanska Weds
description: Dana Wysoczanska, a teacher of French and a translator of French technical and scientific writings for the Polish Academy of Sciences in Warsaw, was married yesterday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to Peter M. Koloski, an export sales representative for the Evergreen International Corporation, a container shipping company in Jersey City. The Rev. Jan Jacmierski performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a daughter of Wladyslaw Wysoczanski of Krynica, Poland, and the late Dorothy Wysoczanska. Her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Koloski of Poughkeepsie.

title: A Kentucky Home Afloat
description: The dense jungle filling the cove that surrounded our mooring was barely visible in the breaking dawn. An orchestra of birds wrapped their melody around the syncopation of an ancient percolator in the galley as I sat, feet propped on the bow rail, watching the mist lift from the landscape. There was no visible sign of civilization, recalling the shore of some remote Pacific Island until the brightening daybreak revealed the jungle to be tulip trees, sycamores, cedars and maples.

title: British Behaviour
description: The English Tourist Board has just published a code of behavior for foreign visitors to Britain's historic monuments suggesting, among other things, that they prevent ''annoying behaviour'' by their children. Visitors may find the board's imperious ''Twenty Tips for Visitors'' even more annoying than obstreperous kids.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FORGIVENESS: Ireland's Best Contemporary Short Stories. Edited by Augustine Martin. (Four Walls Eight Windows, Cloth, $25.95; Paper, $12.95.) Like the fragrance of peat burning on a damp spring evening or the sound of a horse pulling a rubber-wheeled cart through the streets of Dublin, virtually every one of the 25 stories in this fine new collection conjures up vivid images of Irish life.

title: A TASTE FOR SCRAMBLED ENGLISH
description: Bill Bryson's delightful article ''A Taste for Scrambled English'' (On Language, July 22) brought a friend's anecdote to mind. Her son and his musical group were flown to Japan to make a commercial for a Japanese fast-food emporium. The name of the place was ''D Cup Soup.'' Translation? A large cup of soup.

title: In Search of a Poet's Past
description: A shabby, mice-ridden worker's cottage may seem an unlikely dwelling for a Romantic poet and his family, but such a cottage in the Somerset village of Nether Stowey was, during the final three years of the 18th century, the place where Samuel Taylor Coleridge's imagination took flight. Or, rather, took to sea.

title: THE ANT MAN
description: You don't have to go to the Panamanian rain forest to be fascinated by ants. I was walking past the soccer fields in Inwood Park, at the west end of Dyckman Street, on a Friday afternoon in late August two years ago. I couldn't find a place to sit because there were swarms of black ants in literally every square inch of grass. The air, over the field, was thick with flying gnats. Most were as small as normal gnats. Others, much less numerous, resembled very small wasps, perhaps half an inch in length, with enlarged abdomens.

title: Home Clinic;   Leveling a Sidewalk Slab
description: A CONCRETE sidewalk slab that has tilted because of uneven settling can usually be leveled. Unless the slab is quite large (more than 4 by 4 feet) or thick, the job is fairly easy. But two or more people are required, and at least one must be strong enough to pry up the slab with a lever, as described below. (A concrete slab four inches thick measuring 2 by 2 feet weighs about 200 pounds.) Before beginning, anyalyze the problem that has caused the slab to shift. If the slab has not changed from its tilted position for many years, don't bother fixing it. But if it has shifted within the last year or two, try to trace the cause - usually poor drainage - and remedy it before leveling the slab. If you do not, the slab will probably shift again soon.

title: Review/Theater;   Learning to Love, Too Late
description: During the blackouts between scenes in Ted Whitehead's play ''The Man Who Fell in Love With His Wife,'' excerpts of golden oldies ranging from Nat (King) Cole to the Beatles to David Bowie are played over the Quaigh Theater's sound system. This hit parade from the past is the best part of an otherwise tedious tale of a Liverpool docker's midlife crisis, which he is handling rather badly.

title: In 'The Icicle Thief' Parody Turns Into A Tour de Force
description: An affectionate acknowledgment of 1940's film history informs such recent film noir releases as ''The Two Jakes'' and ''After Dark, My Sweet.'' But ''The Icicle Thief,'' which opens Friday at the Lincoln Plaza, goes further in invoking a postwar cinematic legacy, comically depicting an artist who confronts his own creation.

title: Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;   Trading Space For Upkeep
description: BUSINESS owners who want guaranteed customer traffic twice a day and liberal long-term leases are being sought for commercial space in commuter rail stations outside Philadelhia. The quid pro quo is that the tenants must maintain the stations.

title: Once Again, Ready on the Set For Kim Novak
description: It was the fizzy 50's in Hollywood, the era of Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons, pouty starlets in strapless evening gowns, and industry kingpins in rumpled suits. Harry Cohn ruled the roost at Columbia Pictures, where Rita Hayworth was the resident love goddess. But all was not quiet in the hallowed executive suites. Hayworth's real-life dalliances were putting Columbia's contentious emperor in a royal rage, and he finally decreed that a rival screen siren be found.

title: Saturday Night Is Hardly the Loneliest Night
description: MANY decades ago, between two big projectors and stacks of reels in numbered cans, the projectionist sat staring down from his booth along one projector's beam cutting the vaster dark of the Huntington Theater. He wasn't watching the movie. He had seen it too many times.

title: 'Sweet Equity'
description: To the Editor:

title: Streaking Pirates Beat Reds Again
description: Barry Bonds hit a home run and a double and drove in two runs today, leading Zane Smith and the Pittsburgh Pirates past the Cincinnati Reds, 3-1. It was the fourth straight victory for the Pirates.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE FROG PRINCE

title: New York-Breds Have Defender
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A TASTE FOR SCRAMBLED ENGLISH
description: As a recent, first-time traveller to Egypt, I was amused to find S & M's candies that ''melt in your mouth, not in your hand;'' also, savory, salty crackers called Pitz and a fast-food hamburger chain called Limpy's.

title: A TASTE FOR SCRAMBLED ENGLISH
description: We found illustrations of scrambled English in Barcelona. The popular word there for jogging is el footing. A Barcelona daily, Avui (Catalan for today), printed a feature on a new sport sweeping the United States, one that requires no teamwork, competition, special facilities or complex rules. This new sport, one learns, is el fitness.

title: Katherine Smith Weds Stephen Ware
description: Katherine Ludlow Smith, a daughter of Leonard T. Smith of Rochester and the late Charlotte Smith, was married yesterday to Stephen Jordan Ware, the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Timmis Ware of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dewey F. Fagerburg Jr., the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: Wine;   TREASURED ISLAND
description: It's getting so crowded in Long Island wine country that some of the pioneers have already moved on. It's true; Pat and Peter Lenz, who built one of the first showcase wineries on Long Island in 1978, sold out more than a year ago and moved to Calistoga, in the Napa Valley. Now, is that a sign of a maturing wine region or not? To be honest, it's not. The Lenzes are restless souls and their departure had little to do with the aging of the Long Island wine world. (Lenz Winery, by the way, is moving right along under new owners. Try their gewurztraminer.) There are even signs of the beginning of an East End wine culture. Larry Fuller-Perrine makes the wine at Gristina Vineyards in Cutchogue while his wife, Cynthia, handles marketing at Bedell Cellars down the road a mile or two.

title: Going Commercial
description: Has David Lynch taken his mother's advice and gotten a day job? Mr. Lynch, the director whose luridly skewed visions in the films ''Eraserhead'' and ''Blue Velvet'' attracted a cult following even before the bizarre television show ''Twin Peaks'' made him seriously famous, has just finished making a batch of commercials for Calvin Klein. The ads, for Obsession perfume, play off the popularity of ''Twin Peaks'' by using actors from the series in sort of off-beat mini-love stories loosely based on snippets of Ernest Hemingway, D.H. Lawrence, Gustave Flaubert and F. Scott Fitzgerald. A Klein official said the new ads were supposed to update the Obsession campaign, ''making it softer and more romantic, but keeping the mysterious edge.'' Certainly the little plots seem easier to follow than that of his other new project, ''Wild at Heart,'' a film released last week to very mixed reviews.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 12 about the Lincoln Square neighborhood omitted the largest component of the complex of buildings now being added at the northwest corner of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. It is 3 Lincoln Center, a 45-story, 347-unit condominium, which is being built over a 150-foot base containing other parts of the complex. The condominium developer, Abbott L. Stillman, paid Lincoln Center $48.5 million for air rights, more than a third of the $127 million cost of the other Lincoln Center additions.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 5 about the gubernatorial campaign misstated the position of a Democratic candidate, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, on a state income tax. Mr. Morrison said that as a public official, he had never advocated an income tax for Connecticut.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Some people are still trying to read the lips of various politicians with some accuracy, and good luck to them. Fortunately, there's a much easier way to figure out what's going on in the country, and with most people: read their T-shirts.

title: Trapped in the Mideast: A Cross Section of U.S. By LISA BELKIN
description: In a windowless room of the State Department building in Washington, a carefully guarded list of nearly 2,000 names is said to contain all the information the government has managed to gather on the Americans stranded in Iraq and Kuwait: their names, their purposes for being in the region, their ages, hometowns, relatives' names and phone numbers, when they were heard from last.

title: The Sins of the City
description: LEAD:

title: Don't Measure Souter by the Size of His Town;   More Than Lip Service
description: To the Editor:

title: World Markets;   The Shine's Off Madrid
description: In Spain, one of those small European stock markets that became the darling of investors this spring has taken one of the hardest falls since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The Madrid Stock Exchange Index has fallen 12 percent since Aug. 1. With the index at 258.83, it is not far off its 248.17 low for the year.
