title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Patch seed the thin established lawn; repair smaller bare areas with sections of sod or seed a new lawn promptly. Last call to dig, divide and replant iris rhizomes. Cut out browned stalks and seed pods of hostas and day lilies. Don't delay making plans for next spring's garden, and mail hardy bulb orders for delivery in early fall.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHARITY BEGINS AT HOME: Generosity and Self-Interest Among the Philanthropic Elite. By Teresa Odendahl. (Basic, $22.95.) Who questions the motivations of generous donors to universities, museums, hospitals or any of the 950,000 nonprofit organizations competing for charitable contributions? Certainly not the supplicants, and there have been few scholarly critical analyses of this aspect of philanthropy. Now along comes Teresa Odendahl, an anthropologist, with a provocative book based primarily on 140 interviews with philanthropists, but also on 10 years' experience in the grant-making field. What Ms. Odendahl finds is that the affluent give mainly to preserve elitist institutions that provide pleasure or comfort for the wealthy. She supports her conclusion with copious quotations from the benefactors that reflect the self-interest, the gratification and sometimes the sense of power they achieve as philanthropists. The author's personal convictions are clear. ''Elite American philanthropy serves the interests of the rich to a greater extent than it does the interests of the poor, disadvantaged, or disabled,'' she writes. Perhaps there was too much selectivity in Ms. Odendahl's subjects; maybe the altruistic donors were hiding out on interview days. Some fund-givers and fund-seekers will argue that gifts to support cultural centers, medical research and education help the general public, not just the privileged. Others will take the position that how a donor directs charity is an individual right. Opening up a debate on this murky, little-studied aspect of charitable giving should be beneficial. But there also is a concern that lawmakers intent on trimming budget deficits and increasing tax revenues will seize on the image of the indulgent, self-serving rich to buttress their demand for reducing the charitable deduction.

title: The Battle of the Sexes (To Be Continued)
description: The title, ''Women & Men: Stories of Seduction,'' does a disservice to tonight's unusually grown-up offering at 9 on Home Box Office. Although the seduction process is very much part of two of these mood-capturing adaptations of three well-known short stories, all are considerably more than kiss-and-tell tales.

title: Fashion;   Gambling on the Untried and New
description: A signature is more than a written name; it's an identifying characteristic. And that's the meaning of New Signatures, a shop that opens next Sunday at Macy's Herald Square store as a showcase for new designers with distinctive points of view.

title: Mutual Funds;   Some Picks for the Oil Play
description: Given the sharp rise in world oil prices, what are the prospects for mutual funds that invest heavily in oil and other energy companies?

title: 3 Rebel Organizations in India Link Activities
description: Three well-armed leftist insurgencies in India's strategic and oil-producing northeast have agreed to coordinate their militant activities, the first such move in the troubled region in more than 30 years.

title: Prime Minister Invites Solzhenitsyn to Russia
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, his Soviet citizenship restored by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has been invited by the prime minister of the Russian republic to visit the Soviet Union.

title: An Independent and Erratic Life
description: ETCHINGS IN AN HOURGLASS

title: Teaneck Journal;   After Night of Violence, Storekeepers Are Determined to Stay
description: IF he closes his eyes and allows his mind to wander, John Callas says, he can still hear sheets of glass breaking and crashing to the floor. But more vividly, he remembers the shouts of anger mixed with frustration and fear.

title: Julia Linsley Weds
description: Julia Robertson Linsley and Jeffrey Halpin Carter were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., by the Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund. Mrs. Carter, 27 years old, is the daughter of Susan Cutler Linsley of Wrentham, Mass., and the late James Duncan Linsley. Her husband, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter N. Carter of Montreal. The bride, a graduate of Brown University, is an assistant to Dr. Jeffrey LaCroix, a veterinarian in Fairfield, Conn. The bridegroom, a graduate of Dawson College in Montreal, is a master carpenter in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Oil's Big Chance To Shape the Future
description: For oil companies, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has created a host of uncertainties about prices and supplies. But there is no question that the Mideast crisis, however it is resolved, has the potential to reshape the industry.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Doing Battle For Hungry Birds
description: LEAD: IT seemed like such a great idea: establish a family hobby that my wife, my baby daughter, and I could share together. Given our differences in age and gender, it seemed a daunting task. Then my wife hit upon what seemed the perfect idea for a family activity, bird watching.

title: Style Makers;   Xenobia Bailey, African-Hat Designer
description: ''I've always worn hats, but they never did what I wanted them to,'' Xenobia Bailey said. ''The knit hats become unraveled and the floppy hats just had no style.''

title: Conner Strategy: Playing Catchup
description: Dennis Conner announced last week that he had secured a second major sponsor for his $30 million 1992 America's Cup campaign. But with the money starting to roll in, Conner conceded that he and other United States teams still were in the unsavory position of having to catch up with international challengers.

title: Aleichem Inspires Russian Suite
description: TWENTY years ago in the Soviet Union, it would have been pointless for a composer to write a work based on Jewish stories, and virtually impossible for artists to perform it.

title: Keep Politics Out of Scientific Research
description: Decisions about medical research belong in the realm of cool, unemotional scientific logic. Why then have we allowed politics, activism and social hysteria to turn our nation's health research priorities on end? Giant strides have been made in the treatment of heart disease and cancer, yet funding to continue these programs is being siphoned off to meet the demands of the relatively small but vocal AIDS lobby.

title: Erika Pieger Is Married
description: Erika Pieger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric A. Pieger of Tewksbury, N.J., was married yesterday to Donald Armstrong Odel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Odell of New York. The Rev. Dr. Kenyon J. Wildrick officiated at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J. Mrs. Odel, 27 years old, graduated from Bucknell University. She is a telecommunications analyst and her husband is a data communications analyst at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York. Mr. Odell, 29, graduated from New York University.

title: Brooklyn Man Questioned in Killing of Youth
description: The police were questioning a 49-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday in connection with the shooting of a 14-year-old boy in the Sunset Park neighborhood on Friday night, but had not charged him with attempted murder.

title: Fan Roars
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: When Age Befalls A Ballet Dancer
description: LEAD: ''I was summoned to the director's office and requested to retire,'' says Damara Bennett, recalling the traumatic juncture in her career in 1980 after having performed for 13 years with the San Francisco Ballet.

title: As Mount Vernon Tackles Its Future, There Is Frustration About Its Image
description: LEAD: AS the 21st Century Committee looks at where this city wants to go and how to get there, officials and residents say they are optimistic about the future. But they express frustration about Mount Vernon's negative image, which they say is undeserved.

title: Cooper to Rome
description: The Los Angeles Lakers had no further use for him and neither did any other National Basketball Association team, but Michael Cooper did not need much time to land another job. A day after clearing National Basketball Association waivers after his release by the Lakers, the 34-year-old Cooper, as expected, signed a two-year contract yesterday to play for Il Messaggero Roma.

title: Holdout on Rape Verdict Still Sees Discrepancies
description: One juror at the Central Park jogger trial held out until yesterday against convicting Antron McCray of rape andchanged his mind only after Mr. McCray's videotaped confession was played for the fifth time.

title: Diverse Fare for Fans of Indian Food
description: THE latest Indian restaurant to open in Fairfield County is Ganga in downtown Norwalk, and enthusiasts of Indian cooking should run, not walk, to this modest storefront place.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HORSING AROUND

title: Show Celebrates Group's 40 Years
description: HOW can the work of 28 crafts people be fitted into one compact gallery of the Newark Museum? The solution: think small.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: EXAMINING THE MIDEAST

title: Pearl Bailey, Musical Star and Humorist, Is Dead at 72
description: Pearl Bailey, the entertainer whose distinctive singing style was enhanced by her mischievous witticisms and warm personality, died on Friday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia after collapsing at a hotel where she had been staying. She was 72 years old and lived in Lake Havasu, Ariz.

title: Campus Life: C.S.U., Long Beach;   Roof Collapse Forces Relocation Of Classes
description: Officials of California State University at Long Beach are hurriedly rearranging fall music-school programs after a recital hall roof collapsed and seven other buildings were closed because of concern that they were unsafe.

title: Mary V. Demopoulos Weds A.B. Campbell
description: Mary Vasiliki Demopoulos and Andrew Bolter Campbell, graduates of the Vanderbilt School of Law, were married yesterday at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Bluefield, W.Va. The Rev. Jeffrey Chadwick performed the ceremony.

title: Dana Allen Weds Benjamin Sands
description: Dana Elizabeth Allen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Leonard Allen of Lebanon, N.J., was married yesterday to Benjamin Francis Sands, a son of Sarah Darlington Sands of Merida, Mexico, and William F. Sands of Dallas. The Rev. Gerald J. Gallagher performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE WAY THINGS HAPPEN. By Ingaret Giffard. (Morrow, $21.95.) Ingaret Giffard's memoir, ''The Way Things Happen,'' is structured on a remark by her mentor, Carl Jung, that ''the art of letting things happen became the key . . . with which I was able to open the 'Way' to wholeness.'' It is an admirable method for autobiography: it allows the story to unfold without the deformities that grow from imposed causality or from self-justification.

title: Postings: A Homey Look for Offices;   'Compatible' Condominiums
description: With pitch-roofed, chimney-topped, brick buildings that look more like homes than most homes do, a condominium office park is being planned for the Toms River section of Dover Township, N.J. Its 27 buildings will range from a 1,200-square-foot, one-story unit (for $192,000) to a 2,400-square-foot, two-story unit (for $475,000). The project was designed by the Martin Organization of Philadelphia and is being developed by the Glendenning Corporation of Toms River, headed by Donald Glendenning and his brother, William.

title: Rider's Case Elaborated
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Language;   Medical Edibles
description: Things are easier to remember when they are named after something familiar, and what could be more familiar than food? It comes in every color, shape and size. And everybody eats. The father of modern medicine figured this out 2,400 years ago. Noticing strange noises coming from the chests of some sick people, Hippocrates described the sound to his students as ''bubbling like boiling vinegar.'' A 6-day-old embryo looked like ''a raw egg with no shell.'' And in acute jaundice, the patient's skin was ''very much like the color of a pomegranate peel.''

title: 4 Killed as Oil Tank Explodes
description: Four young people, including two teen-age sisters, were killed Friday night by the explosion of an oil storage tank on which they were climbing. The authorities have not determined the cause of the explosion but say it may have been a spark from a cigarette lighter. ''Places like these are gathering places for teens,'' said Lieut. Robert Davidson of the DeSoto Parish sheriff's office. ''Hopefully, after this, that will end.''

title: Rhonda Marcus Weds
description: Rhonda Beth Marcus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Marcus of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Daniel Sadur, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Sadur. Rabbi Solomon Aidelson officiated at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., assisted by Cantor Charles Ritter. Mrs. Sadur, 39 years old, graduated from Rider College. She heads the Eric Michaels missy division of Takeaway Styles in New York. Mr. Sadur, 37, is the president and owner of the Aldastar Corporation, a crafts and hobby supplier in Brooklyn. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: On Spraying For Gypsy Moths
description: The two ''Other Views'' (Letters to the New Jersey editor, July 15) in response to Pete Dunne's article on gypsy moth spraying raise questions of judgment and fact that call for at least one additional letter.

title: Elizabeth Hiser Weds C.P. Hoban
description: Elizabeth Lawrence Hiser, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Hiser Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Park Hoban, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Hoban of Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. Shirley L. Paxton officiated at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, N.J.

title: Man Is Saved After Plunging From Bridge
description: A man who apparently jumped off the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday was saved by quick teamwork between the crew of a Manhattan sightseeing boat, officers on a police rescue launch and ambulance technicians.

title: Giddy and Romantic, 'Me and My Girl'
description: ''ME AND MY GIRL'' is a most entrancing feel-good model of the bygone English formula musical, and if anyone doubts its ongoing appeal, just look around. A summer package began performances at the Westport Country Playhouse last Monday. The premiere of the Darien Dinner Theater version was set for Friday, nine days after An Evening Dinner Theater displayed its own production in Elmsford, N.Y. And what musical do you think is on tap for next summer at the Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield? For ''Me and my Girl'' watchers everywhere, musical theaters appear to be having another opening of the same show, now that the Broadway production and its various tours have had prosperous runs.

title: Jazz Festival Hails a Seminal Drummer
description: LEAD: ROY HAYNES has been called ''one of the best-kept secrets in jazz.'' Not one to hide behind false modesty, Mr. Haynes accepts this assessment by the publication Jazz Times matter-of-factly.

title: On Soviet Farms: Collective Indifference
description: On a rainy day in late July, the Dawn Collective Farm resembles a hog wallow in which someone has planted discarded tractor parts, rusting sheds and weathered buildings, creating a powerful impression of gloom and neglect.

title: INSIDE
description: Rikers Inmate Dies

title: Part of Crash Survivor's Suit Against Secord Is Dismissed
description: Federal district judge has thrown out major parts of the civil suit brought against Richard V. Secord by the lone survivor of an airplane crash that helped to expose the Iran-contra affair.

title: Suzanne M. Cocco Is Wed To Michael Francis Midlige
description: Suzanne Marie Cocco and Michael Francis Midlige, third-year students at the Seton Hall University School of Law, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Denis in Manasquan, N.J. Msgr. Joseph O'Connor officiated. Mrs. Midlige, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank A. Cocco of Wall Township, N.J., is a graduate of Muhlenberg College. Her father is the chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at the Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J. Mr. Midlige, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Midlige of Parsippany, N.J., graduated magna cum laude from Fairleigh Dickinson University in Rutherford, N.J., where his father is the chairman of the departments of biology and allied health services.

title: For Women Returning to Job Market
description: CONTINUING a 28-year practice of serving nontraditional adult students, Sarah Lawrence College is offering a new one-year program this fall to help those who earned bachelor's degrees 10, 20, even 30 years ago to update job skills for today's marketplace.

title: For Some, a Case of Airplane Angst
description: Edgar Cosman had a choice for his vacation in Panama: a 4-hour-and-45-minute nonstop flight, or a 3-hour flight to Miami, a 2-hour wait in the airport there and a 3-hour flight to Panama City.

title: Gordon Bunshaft: A Man Who Died Before His Time?
description: Gordon Bunshaft was not an easy man: he was brusque, arrogant and impatient with those who could not see the world as he saw it. He believed in making modern buildings, not in talking about them or, indeed, in talking about much of anything else. His personality was as spare as his architecture, and as unbending. But behind that gruff and sullen manner, gray crew cut and ever-present pipe was an architect who, perhaps more than any other, gave the cities of the 1950's and 1960's their tone and their class - and one who, at his death earlier this month at 81, left behind an oeuvre that ranks as one of the major architectural achievements of the century.

title: The Joe Papp of Bali Finds Himself In a Cultural Pickle
description: As the best-known producer-director in Bali, Made Bandem (pronounced MAH-day BAHN-dem) is dealing in a world most of his Western counterparts pray for: an abundance of talented dancers and musicians, audiences sophisticated in the lore of the theater and a society that welcomes great performances.

title: Streetscapes: 19 East 54th Street;   A Fire-Ravaged, 1900 Mansion Now Enmeshed in a Dispute
description: For years, the austere, granite town house at 19 East 54th Street has been a historical question mark for curious New Yorkers.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Call of the Wild

title: Cynthia Romaine Is Married on L.I.
description: Cynthia Scherer Romaine and Thomas Garland Milstead 3d were married yesterday in Bridgehampton, L.I. The Rev. Ronald G. Abrams performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;

Humanizing the Power Of Electronic Technology
description: LEAD: In classical music circles, electronic music has a bad reputation; the average concertgoer probably shudders at the memory of the disjointed bloops and bleeps that characterized the medium in the 1960's. But electronic technology has come a long way since then, and no one has worked harder to humanize its power than Tod Machover.

title: Tracing Turner's Steps In the Yorkshire Dales
description: The Yorkshire dales afford so many pleasures, from Wensleydale cheese to medieval abbeys, that artistic connections seem superfluous. They exist, although for most recent travelers they begin and end with James Herriot, the local veterinarian whose books inspired the television series ''All Creatures Great and Small.'' But a century and a half before Mr. Herriot began celebrating the dales, one of England's greatest landscape painters crisscrossed the region, filling three sketchbooks with his impressions of Yorkshire waterfalls, villages, castles and rivers.

title: Possibilities of Love
description: IT was just one of those one-night stands, Frankie assumed. And Johnny would then get dressed, go back home and leave her alone in her dingy one-room apartment in the Clinton section of Manhattan.

title: Iraqi Remarks On Detention Of Foreigners
description: Following is the text of the statement made Friday by the Speaker of the Iraqi Parliament, Saadi Mahdi Saleh, about the detention of foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, as transmitted by the Iraqi press agency and translated by Reuters:

title: THE WORLD: The Gulf;   Key Points of the Week
description: AS rhetorical salvos intensified in the Middle East last week, the United States sent some of its most sophisticated offensive weapons to the potential battlefront with Iraq. Putting a Vietnam-size troop lift on fast forward, the Pentagon poured in tens of thousands more troops, commandeering commercial airliners to fly them there. President Bush decided to call up doctors, cargo handlers and other non-combat forces from the reserves. A fourth aircraft carrier set sail to the region and radar-evading Stealth fighters were dispatched. Mr. Bush ratcheted up the pressure by ordering the Navy to enforce a blockade of Iraqi shipping. For now, orders were minimal force, like shots across the bows of blockade runners.

title: Ms. Wiechmann, Playwright, Weds
description: Barbara A. K. Wiechmann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack G. Wiechmann of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael John Carley Jr., the son of Constance Worthington of Providence, R.I., and the late Captain Carley, U.S.M.C. The Rev. Nancy Leckerling, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at Olmstead's Overlook in Guilford.

title: Zimbabwe Aide Affirms Plan for One-Party State
description: Bucking the trend in sub-Saharan Africa, the Zimbabwean Foreign Minister reaffirmed on Friday that the Government intended to push ahead with plans to introduce a one-party state.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Griffey Retires
description: He was a significant force on the Cincinnati Reds teams that won the World Series in 1975 and 1976, and now, at the age of 40, Ken Griffey may have provided some crucial help in the team's bid to win in 1990.

title: Taking Fresh Stock of Les Ballets 1933
description: Nostalgia and legend surround Les Ballets 1933, the first company that George Balanchine founded in the West. A more tangible and revealing reminder is the trailblazing exhibition that the four-year-old National Museum of Dance in Saratoga Springs is devoting to Balanchine's short-lived ballet troupe of 57 years ago. The show, ''Les Ballets 1933,'' centers on costumes, props and designs seen for the first time in the United States and will be on view through Oct. 7.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Biarritz and St.-Jean-de-Luz omitted the names of two restaurants in St.-Jean. They are Auberge Kaiku (17 Rue de la Republique; 26.13.20), where a meal for two with wine is about $95, and Chez Pablo (Rue Mlle. Etchero), a family-style restaurant behind the market, where a meal for two with wine is $40.

title: Carolyn E. Jones Weds J. J. Borris
description: At the Highland Presbyterian Church in Lancaster, Pa., Carolyn Elizabeth Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Louis Jones of Lancaster, was married yesterday to Jacques Jean Borris, a son of Andree Borris of Mont-de-Marsan, France, and the late Rene Borris. The Rev. Ross McClintock performed the ceremony. Mrs. Borris, 32 years old, graduated from Syracuse University. She is a freelance photographer. Her father retired as the chairman, president and chief executive of Armstrong World Industries in Lancaster.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

The Good Earth Gone Bad
description: LEAD: AH summer. This is the time for gardeners to revel in nature's wonder. We tilled the soil and planted seeds in our lovely little gardens. Now, luscious produce is appearing in neat, attractive rows. Mother Earth is generous and we are grateful and happy. Or so the myth goes.

title: Latin American Conflict at Home
description: ''WHAT do you think about what's happening in Central America?''

title: Golfers Accused Of Indifference
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Managing;   Under Contract Not to Jump
description: Not long ago, Fred Siegel, a New York executive recruiter, found the ''perfect'' candidate for a senior job at a consulting firm. Lawyers said the courts would certainly overturn the man's contract, which forbade him to work for a competitor, yet Mr. Siegel's client would not hire the candidate. ''We run into this all the time,'' Mr. Siegel said. ''No one wants to go through the costs and hassles of fighting in court.''

title: De-Icing by Hand Cited in Air Crash Inquiry
description: Crew members of a commuter plane that crashed last year, killing all six people aboard, used credit cards to scrape ice from the wings and propellers and declined de-icing equipment at least twice, investigators say.

title: Up and Down
description: He came up for a cup of coffee, and his performance was good to the last drop, but all Mike York has to show for it after one game with the Pittsburgh Pirates is an empty cup and an impressive line in the record book: seven shutout innings and a 7-1 victory over the Reds in Cincinnati.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Initiative And Referendum? Say No.
description: LEAD: WIDESPREAD disagreement with Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package and his sweeping overhaul of the financing of the state's public school systems ha given newlife to a movement ot include initiative and referendum procedures in an amendment, which would have to be initiated by the State Legislature and approved by the voters, must be opposed.

title: Photography's Early Images Keep the Nation's Past Alive
description: PHOTOGRAPHY was officially born with the daguerreotype in the Paris of 1839, but its birth pangs began as early as 1826. In that year, Joseph Niepce (also in France) made an eight-hour exposure of the view from his house on a plate of pewter. Then there was the Englishman William Fox Talbot, who, in 1835, produced the first image on sensitized paper, calling it a calotype and, later on, a talbotype, but not unveiling it until 18 days after the debut of the daguerreotype. So it is fitting that the celebration of the medium's 150th anniversary should still be raging in 1990.

title: Christiane Sweeny to Wed in October
description: The engagement of Christiane Taylor Sweeny to Christopher Ashley Gorycki, the son of Ann Gorycki of New York and the late George Gorycki, has been made known by her parents, Christiane B. Sweeny of Pleasantville, N.Y., and Arthur Sweeny 3d of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: Data Update
Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   The Tastes of Cuba And the Caribbean
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some restaurants that offer Caribbean and Cuban food.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
description: If you're talking about tennis as a lifetime sport with many benefits for physical and mental health, the answer is, it is never too early to begin playing. But if tennis is viewed as a sure path to financial riches, it will be a burden that far too few children will be able to bear and a goal that even fewer will be able to realize.

title: King Takes Record And Lead With a 63
description: Betsy King shattered the record of the Wykagyl Country Club course with a sizzling nine-under-par 63 today for a three-shot lead going into the final round of the JAL Big Apple Classic.

title: A Challenge To Somers On Land Use In Watershed
description: IN its first legal challenge of a municipal planning decision in its watershed region, New York City is suing the Somers Planning Board to prevent a housing subdivision from rising on a peninsula of land jutting into the Amawalk Reservoir.

title: Farm Stand Story Is About One Person
description: The rest of us -- summer and winter residents alike -- feel privileged to overlook one of the last pieces of farmland in the village. Ms. Ecker's charges of traffic congestion are absurd: Dayton Lane is still a place where kids play in the street.

title: Come Home, Papa
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
description: It is a question of whether young tennis players spend too much time at it and are too concernced with playing tournaments, winning and attaining rankings. Excessive focus on these things can cause detrimental effects both physically and emotionally.

title: Hanging Tough Won't Be the Only Test of Leadership
description: THE race is on. President George Bush versus President Saddam Hussein. There is no prize for coming in second.

title: Woman Defending Brother Is Killed by Youth in Bronx
description: A 20-year-old Bronx woman was killed early yesterday when she tried to break up an argument between her brother and a 16-year-old boy who was brandishing a pistol, the police said.

title: Don't Measure Souter by the Size of His Town;   Much Like Brennan
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Car Transforms A Good Samaritan
description: LEAD: SINCE a 6-year-old girl walked alone along a highway in Italy recently, bruised and sobbing and ignored for more than half an hour by hundreds of vacation-bound motorists before one stopped to help her, people have been examining their souls to ask how such an outrage could have occurred.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CROTON POINT PARK;

Model-Plane Pilots' Spirits Soar but Neighbors Cry Mayday
description: LEAD: DR. Ronald Mann took the controls of his Aurora, a sleek red and blue aircraft he says is ''top of the line.''

title: Marla Gusmer to Wed David Jeffrey
description: The engagement of Marla Ann Gusmer to David Arthur Jeffrey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Jeffrey Jr. of Summit, N.J., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William E. Gusmer of Short Hills, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: Campus Life: Michigan;   Gay Rights Group Protests Remarks By an Official
description: Forty student members of a gay rights advocacy organization in Ann Arbor staged their second demonstration of the summer on Thursday to demand the resignation of a university regent they accuse of making anti-gay remarks.

title: Portuguese Bread For a Feast Day
description: THERESA TRUSS eyed the big metal pan of bread dough on her kitchen table. ''I mixed this dough this morning,'' she said. ''I used 25 pounds of flour, 3 dozen eggs, 5 pounds of sugar.''She also noted that she had mixed the dough entirely by hand. ''No spoon,'' she said. ''A spoon would break.'' Mrs. Truss was making dough was for masa sauve, traditional Portuguese sweet bread. Her grandparents came to Connecticut from Portugal, she said, and her parents - especially her father - made the bread regularly when she was growing up.

title: Why Iraq Won't Make Israel Say 'Atom'
description: To the Editor:

title: Together Again
description: In a moment as poignant as when that single teardrop glides slowly over the photogenic cheekbone of Miss Congeniality, Bert Parks and the Miss America Organization made up last week. Mr. Parks, who was fired for being too old in 1980 after 25 years as the pageant's host, agreed last week to appear next month in the 70th anniversary Miss America contest. He will sing the Miss America anthem, ''There She Is,'' and have unspecified other duties, but the contest hosts will continue to be Phyllis George and Gary Collins. Though he was fired at the age of 65, Mr. Parks went on to appear in a wide variety of pageants. He hosted Mrs. America, Miss Asia, Miss Young International, the Mother-Daughter Pageant, U.S. Man of the Year, and even a couple of dog and cat competitions. He smiled gamely last week as his return was announced, but Mr. Parks later admitted that he was still smarting from the dismissal. ''I would not be truthful if I didn't tell you that I carried some residual resentment,'' he said.

title: On Discarding Abstract Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: The Quiet Side of the Delaware Shore
description: A mosaic of marsh, woods and upland fields, Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge on the southwest shore of Delaware Bay is a welcome relief from the crush of the Eastern Seaboard. Its 8,800 acres of rich land draw tens of thousands of migratory birds and relatively few people. Flocks of geese and ducks gather in the fall, shorebirds and warblers in the spring. In summer glossy ibises, black like vanilla beans, forage in the shallow waters, along with great blue herons and other waders. Several species nest in the refuge, among them hawks, terns, ring-necked pheasants, least bitterns, rails and five kinds of dabbling ducks.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Commerce in the Middle Ages was a strange affair. Picture merchants in London adding 12 pence to a shilling and 20 shillings to a pound. And then don't forget farthings, sixpence and guineas. Then, just to complicate the calculations even more, picture them doing all the addition, subtraction, division and multiplication using Roman numerals. Thoroughly confused? So were they. Although the British may be loath to admit it, a French innovation proved to be the way to simplify matters. Called a counting board, the device, painted onto a table or a cloth that covered a table, was the Western equivalent of the abacus. Instead of beads strung onto wires, the counting board was covered with lines so that it resembled a large checkerboard, and tokens were pushed around it to do the calcualtions. The checkered counting board became such a mainstay of accounting that even now the treasury of Great Britain is called the Exchequer.

title: Campus Life: Maryland;   Diggers Unearth Clues to History Of Free Blacks
description: Writers filling history textbooks with accounts of blacks in America's slave days often omit stories about the ones who were never slaves. But the University of Maryland and the Historic Annapolis Foundation plan to piece together part of this forgotten history from broken glass, ceramics and other artifacts unearthed in a parking lot here.

title: Carolin D. Irwin Plans to Marry
description: Mrs. William E. Fenhagen of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Paul Irwin of Gibson Island, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolin Davidson Irwin to Eric A. Angione, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad J. Angione of Norwalk, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: A View Too Close for Comfort
description: My wife and I boarded the day's last bus in Kamikochi, headed down toward the isolated mountain town of Takayama from a mile-high valley in the Japanese Alps. Immediately, we had some questions. Why, we wondered, was a small television mounted on the bus dashboard? And why was a second bus driver standing next to the one behind the wheel? And, strangest of all, why were none of the other passengers, all apparently Japanese, taking the seats at the very front?

title: THE GUIDE
description: SPIRIT WORLD

title:
ART;

Cowboys Ride Into the Sunset as Morning Breaks on Change
description: LEAD: LIFE is getting more nuanced on the lone prairie; it isn't just cowboys and Indians anymore, and art from the region reflects this. ''Artists of the Southwest'' at the Somerstown Gallery here, marked but not riddled with Western cliches and conventions, speaks to this change.

title: Pregnant, Addicted - and Guilty?
description: Traveling West From Detroit about 200 miles along I-96, crack arrived in Muskegon County, Mich., late in September 1988. Or at least that's when the prosecutor Tony Tague first started noticing that a crime rampage was rocking this hard-scrabble, blue-collar county - the kind of siege that supposedly strikes only the nation's largest cities. With only 161,000 people scattered across 7 cities and 16 townships, Muskegon County, a scenic but tired factory area with an unemployment rate nearly double the national average, would appear to be scarcely worth the picking. ''The Detroit drug dealers told us that Muskegon is such a welfare town that it's guaranteed income for them when the checks come in,'' recalls Detective Sgt. Al Van Hemert, a ruddy veteran narcotics cop.

title: Where Will New York Put The State's Nuclear Waste?
description: ON the quiet main streets of a few small towns in upstate New York, it is hard to find lampposts or storefronts without bright orange posters plastered on them. Some say, ''Don't Waste New York,'' others, ''Bump the Dump.'' The residents are afraid their towns will become home to the permanent storage site for low-level radioactive waste that New York must build within the next few years.

title: First for Fresh Air Campers: a Pet Pig, Not a Dog
description: Giggles, a sudden burst of laughter, smiles and nervous shouts of joy. Those were the sounds and expressions of Fresh Air Fund campers on their first visit to the Fund's model farm on the Sharp Reservation, in Fishkill, N.Y.

title: Dorothy Riordan Is Married
description: Dorothy A. Riordan, a daughter of Mrs. Robert Rohe of Katonah, N.Y., and the late Daniel A. Riordan, was married yesterday to Michael G. Hughes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Hughes of Miller Place, L.I. The Rev. John Kauta officiated at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y. Mrs. Hughes graduated from American University and received a law degree from St. John's University, from which her husband graduated; he is a third-year law student at St. John's. Next month, Mrs. Hughes is to become a trial lawyer for the Legal Aid Society, where her husband is a legal assistant.

title: Japan Gives Its Leader A Long Honeymoon
description: WHEN he took office a year ago, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu seemed like the man least likely to succeed. He had no power base, no major record of achievement in government and almost no serious experience at political maneuvering, and he was faced with an electorate irate after more than a year of scandals and unpopular policies.

title: Mets End Their Candlestick Jinx
description: The Mets reached the crisis stage in the pennant race today but survived when David Cone pitched them past the San Francisco Giants, 9-2. He gave up seven hits, struck out 13 batters and kept the Mets from falling three games out of first place in the National League East with 45 games to go in a season that has suddenly become short and dangerous. ''Everybody has a survival mentality on this team,'' Cone said. ''We needed it,'' Manager Bud Harrelson said. ''It's got to start here,'' Darryl Strawberry said. It was the first time the Mets had won in Candlestick Park in five games this year, and only the third time in 17 games over the last three years. And they did it not many hours after they had opened a 10-day trip to California with Frank Viola losing his third game in a row.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Birthdays Remind Me of What I Miss
description: LEAD: ''WHAT will you miss most?'' someone asked.

title: New State Regulations on Cable TV to Begin
description: CABLE television companies in New Jersey will be required to have people available 24 hours a day to answer consumer calls and pay interest on billing mistakes when new state regulations take effect tomorrow.

title: Wall Street;   How the Market Is Treating Energy Stocks
description: A string of recent earnings disappointments in the energy sector just goes to show how forgiving investors have become in light of the gulf crisis and its positive implications for oil prices.

title: Review/Theater;   Landlady as Metaphor For Repressive Regime
description: It's not always easy for an outsider to grasp that he is being presented with a metaphor, but that is not a prime consideration in the case of ''El Palomar'' (''The Pigeon House''), a play being offered by Teatro Encuentro de Costa Rica at the Public Theater as part of the Festival Latino in New York. The new Costa Rican troupe is giving New York a refreshing lesson in stagecraft where language works in tandem with mood and motion.

title: Thornburgh's Son Is Cleared of Drug Accusations
description: The Justice Department says that the F.B.I. looked into an accusation by a former Pennsylvania official that the son of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had used marijuana and cocaine as recently as 1988, but that investigators found the charges to be unsubstantiated.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Commercial Property: The Old J.C. Penney Building;   New Name, New Owners, New Tenants, New Image
description: Take a 26-year-old building that never had any architectural distinction and that was made even more anonymous by its identification for many years with a single, none-too-glamorous tenant, and put it on the Avenue of the Americas, where vacancy rates are among the highest in mid-Manhattan. It would seem to be a recipe for leasing disaster.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: RENSO L. CAPORALI;

Grumman 'Can Stay on L.I., but...'
description: LEAD: WHEN he was a boy growing up in Akron, N. Y., Renso L. Caporali read a ''Ripley's Believe It or Not'' item asserting that throughout history there had nearly always been a war going on somewhere in the world. He believed it then, and still does now as the newly appointed chairman of the Grumman Corporation, Long

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Summer's Assertive Success
description: At least once a season, it seems, a fashion item appears and almost at once asserts itself. This summer that item is a cotton canvas jacket from the designer Isaac Mizrahi that comes in a variety of graphic black-and-white patterns: checks, diamonds, spots, stripes and abstract flowers. Besides the boldness of its racing-pattern prints, what sets this jacket apart is its signature solid-black collar.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Multi-Unit Housing on Rise in Montville
description: LEAD: Over the last two decades, the 19 square miles of Montville Township, in eastern Morris County, have been a magnet for residential growth. A major reason is the township's accessibility to the nearby commercial center of Parsippany and the office buildings that have sprung up in and around it.

title: Fairfield Area May Be Vital In the Race For Governor
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY has long been regarded as the state's political stepchild, a bastion of wealthy Republicans in a largely Democratic, working-class state. It is dominated by news media from New York rather than from Hartford or New Haven. The estrangement is so severe that in 1982, the Republican gubernatorial candidate in New York, Lewis E. Lehrman, raised more money in the county than Connecticut's Republican candidate, Lewis B. Rome, of Bloomfield.

title: A Crucial White Plains Council Seat
description: LEAD: MAYOR Alfred Del Vecchio of White Plains is not up for re-election this year, but to some extent it is his record that is on the line in the race for a seat on the city's Common Council.

title: Talking Back to the Screen
description: SEEING THROUGH MOVIES

title: Residential REsale
description: Closings in the week ended Aug. 4

title: Girl In Baby-Swapping Case Meets Parents and Siblings
description: Kimberly Mays, an 11-year-old at the center of a two-year baby-swap controversy, has finally met the couple who proved she was switched with another infant in a maternity ward, a newspaper report said today.

title: Listen Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
description: Many over-ambitious parents, dazzled by visions of trophies and dollar signs, do push their offspring into tennis almost from infancy. Such parents should be reminded that Stefan Edberg, the Wimbledon champion and the No. 1 player in the world, did not start playing tennis until the age of 7. Throughout a normal childhood spent at home, not at a tennis academy, he continued to pursue many other sports, including soccer, hockey and basketball. This approach fostered the development of the all-around athletic skills so evident in his game today.

title: Can We Put Everyone to Work?
description: FAT YEARS AND LEAN

title: New York's Frisbee Champ Feels Jaws of Defeat in Philly
description: The flying disk slices through the air - whishhh - and Boe takes off after it. His muscles appear in outline as he gains with each bound. Forty, 50, 60 yards: it's within reach. Suddenly he's flying - whooshhh - and he clamps down on the disk. As he settles back to earth the crowd breaks into applause. Boe knows Frisbee. Boe is a 35-pound mutt and New York City's champion Frisbee dog. In the July competition in Central Park, ''he ran away with the title,'' his owner, Jack Mason, said.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: UTRILLO'S MOTHER, by Sarah Baylis. (Fawcett Columbine, $8.95.) Suzanne Valadon, the mother of the artist Maurice Utrillo, worked as a model for the likes of Degas and Renoir; but she was an artist herself, forgotten, in no small part, because she was female. This imagined autobiography often comes off like ''an antimale polemic,'' Richard Goodman said here last year, but the author, who died in 1987, ''was very good indeed at re-creating the ambiance of life in the rural France of 100 years ago. She was a writer of all the senses; smells, sounds and tastes are a fundamental part of her vision, and are rendered with great verve.''

title: Wall Street;   Did the Short-Sellers Stumble?
description: Nothing makes a short-seller more confident of impending disaster than a whiff of disappointment in a high-flying company's sales figures. But the recent experience of Mylan Laboratories Inc., a brash leader of the $2 billion generic drug industry, suggests that the shorts are not infallible.

title: Correction
description: A review of ''Time of Change: An Insider's View of Russia's Transformation'' on Aug. 12 misidentified the reviewer, Abraham Brumberg. He is the editor of ''Chronicle of a Revolution: A Western-Soviet Inquiry Into Perestroika,'' not its author.

title: From Mirage To War
description: A country that emerges from one war without knowing why it came about prepares the way for another war - with the same enemy or his clones.

title: Why They Killed Chico Mendes
description: THE BURNING SEASON

title: Ms. Slusser Weds Matthew Arnold
description: At St. Philip's Roman Catholic Church in Occidental, Calif., Sarah Ann Slusser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser of New York City and Windsor, Calif., was married yesterday to Matthew Baylor Arnold, a son of Dr. Mary B. Arnold of Barrington, R.I., and the late Dr. John Hampton Arnold. Msgr. Robert L. Charlebois performed the ceremony.

title: NEW U.N. WARNING TO BAGHDAD URGED
description: The Security Council voted unanimously tonight to demand the immediate release of all foreigners detained by Iraq and delivered an implicit warning that Baghdad could face international military action unless it complied.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Chinese Newcomer Serving Ossining
description: LEAD: THE most recent in the string of Chinese restaurants occupying this storefront spot in the Arcadian Shopping Center, Panda Garden 1 continues in their tradition. This neighborhood newcomer offers moderately priced dishes (lunch is a particular bargain) that for the most part show care and thought.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: A set of 16 deals played in the Summer Nationals in Boston three weeks ago made a solid imprint on bridge history. The setting was the last act of the 1990 Spingold Knockout Team Championship. The scenario was a mirror image of many comparable occasions.

title: Lee J. Richmond, Poet, 54
description: Lee J. Richmond, a poet and novelist who taught at St. John's University for more than two decades, died on Friday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 54 years old and lived in Hempstead, L.I. The Hempstead Funeral Home said he died of complications from pneumonia.

title: Lisa A. Lien Wed To David Keyko
description: Lisa Ann Lien and David George Keyko were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church at Lafayette Square in Washington by the Rev. Charles A. Cesaretti. Mrs. Keyko is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Lien of Potomac, Md. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Keyko of Westfield, N.J.

title: The Invasion Vacation
description: We didn't want to take this vacation. It was the President's idea. I figured we should just call August on account of invasion, hunker down, and wait for the price of gasoline to reach the foie gras mark. The President would have none of this. ''The American people want to see life go on,'' he said.

title: Composers Gather At New Milford Center
description: ''IT may be possible,'' Charles Ives wrote in his ''Essays,'' ''that a day in a Kansas wheat field will do more good for an American composer than three years in Rome.'' Connecticut may be a little short on wheat fields, but the rolling hills around the Canterbury School, in New Milford, have been deputized well: in its first 10 years, the Charles Ives Center for American Music (not to be confused with the Ives Center for the Arts, in Danbury) has welcomed more than 250 composers from around the country.

title: All About/Meteorological Services;   The Diverse New Industry of Private Weather Forecasting
description: Wertfilms Inc. chose to shoot Nissan commercials in Seattle because it wanted skies that were overcast but not on the verge of a deluge. So the producers called Northwest Weathernet Inc., a private company that could render specific forecasts. ''Five or ten miles can make a difference,'' said Phil Breuser, the vice president of Northwest Weathernet. ''We can go hour-by-hour if they want.''

title: For Civil Rights, It's Back to the Future
description: LEAD: Citing provisions he says will amount to job quotas, President Bush has threatened to veto the Civil Rights Act of 1990.

title: Encountering Elie Wiesel
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Basketball

title: Violent Imaginings Invade Our Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: Jessica Bussgang Marries
description: Jessica Edith Bussgang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian J. Bussgang of Lexington, Mass., was married last evening at the Harvard Club in Boston to Thomas Adam Rosenbloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Rosenbloom of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Cary Yales officiated. Mrs. Rosenbloom is a magna cum laude graduate of Tufts University and will receive an M.B.A. from Harvard University in May. Her husband graduated from the University of Wisconsin at Madison and the Boston University School of Law. He is an associate at O'Connor, Broude, Snyder & Aronson, a Waltham, Mass., law firm.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My husband painted our brick patio with a clear water sealer. This was a mistake because when it rains the water stays on the bricks. Can the sealer be removed?

title: Postings: Carroll Gardens Condos;   Brooklyn Mews
description: Drawing on the architectural tradition of the mews - 19th-century stables or carriage houses grouped around a courtyard - a developer in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn is completing three small houses that are bigger than many apartments but smaller than most single-family homes. The developer, Jonathan Perlstein, has clustered the houses around a private courtyard at 126 Fourth Place. The houses, to be priced from $259,500 to $279,500, will range in size from 950 to 1,100 square feet.

title: NOTE WITH PLEASURE
description: So Much for the Noble Savage

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 5 about housing auctions misidentified the hotel at the base of the Executive Plaza condominium in midtown Manhattan. It is Parc Fifty-One.

title: Don't Measure Souter by the Size of His Town
description: To the Editor:

title: Maria Baldwin Morgan Plans to Wed Christopher Johnson Grill in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Morgan of New York have made known the October wedding plans for their daughter, Maria Baldwin Morgan, and Christopher Johnson Grill, a son of Sandra Johnson of Schoharie, N.Y., and John A. Grill of Woolwich, Me.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-14

title: Phyllis H. Gray To Marry in '91
description: Phyllis Hunt Gray and David George McCormick plan to marry in May. Miss Gray is a daughter of Cynthia Hunt Gray of West Chester, Pa., and John L. Gray 3d of Rye, N.Y. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. McCormick of West Chester.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF    FOREIGNERS IN IRAQ WILL SHARE IN HARDSHIPS, BAGHDAD WARNS; SAUDIS TO INCREASE OIL OUTPUT;   'ACT OF WAR' SEEN
description: Declaring the American-led naval blockade ''an act of war,'' Iraq said tonight that thousands of foreigners, including infants, who have been turned into hostages would suffer the same food shortages as Iraqis.

title: Schools Feel Impact of Children of Drug Abusers
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S elementary schools and preschools are feeling the impact of growing numbers of children whose parents are drug abusers. Many of these children, while not addicts themselves, suffer from emotional and psychological problems related to the use of illegal drugs at home.

title: Joann Knudson Weds Thomas Handler
description: Dr. Joann Marie Knudson, the chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology, and Dr. Thomas Joshua Handler, a resident in radiology, both at the Yale-New Haven Hospital, were married last evening at the New Haven Lawn Club. Rabbi Edward Schlaeger officiated.

title: Chamorro Requests Pardon For Slayers of Her Husband
description: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is asking the legislature to pardon at least five men convicted in the murder of her husband, a popular newspaper publisher whose death helped set off the 1979 revolution.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing in the Travel section last Sunday misstated telephone numbers for eating places and hotels in San Sebastian, Spain, and the immediate area. Here are the correct numbers:

title: Don't Measure Souter by the Size of His Town;   New Hampshire's Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: 15-Story Facelift;   New Windows, Lobby on 33d
description: Most people familiar with the oddly shaped, ''winged'' structure that straddles the Penn Central Railroad tracks on West 33d Street and 10th Avenue know it as the home of Sky Rink, Manhattan's only public indoor ice-skating rink.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin;   Contriving A Shorter Leash For Bucky Badger
description: What do you see when you find a badger wearing boxing gloves and a University of Wisconsin sweater?

title: Susan Wallerstein Weds S. M. Scherr
description: Susan Beth Wallerstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Wallerstein of Smithtown, L.I., was married last evening to Stephen Mark Scherr, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Scherr of Dix Hills, L.I. Rabbi Moshe Edelman and Cantor Tibor Kelen officiated at Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Just How Old is An Old House? Exhibit Offers Clues
description: LEAD: ''THE OLD HOUSE,'' an exhibit at the Fairfield Historical Society, offers clues on demystifying, identifying and determining the dates of a treasure trove of local old houses, ''Half of the requests for information we receive are on how to date an old house,'' said the society's curator, Chris Nevins.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Adams, Mass.;

Making a Mill A 'Centerpiece'
description: LEAD: THE Northern Berkshire Industrial Park and Development Corporation, a regional revitalization agency, is redeveloping a 32-acre site here to preserve a textile mill and sell building lots.

title: Fictional Policewomen Are Good Role Models
description: Both writers have contrasting backgrounds: O'Donnell's work in the theater no doubt helped her to transfer her love of language into writing. Uhnak's portraits are firsthand since she was a New York City transit policewoman who earned the rank of detective. She captured and arrested an armed man without help. Her plots are clever and readers are aware that she was a participant observer in what she writes.

title: Hearings Start on Plan For More Natural Gas
description: LEAD: While events in the Middle East continue to raise deep fears about the future cost and availability of imported oil, a Federal regulatory agency began hearings last week on a proposal to build a 370-mile pipeline that would transport natural gas from the Canadian border to Long Island.

title: In Changing Times, the Amish Move Afield and Set Up Shop
description: LEAD: IN a red barn-style building along a busy stretch of Route 31 in Flemington, the first Pennsylvania Dutch farmers' market in New Jersey is bustling.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Howell $179,900

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: SHORTLY after midnight, after most of those New Jersey residents who enjoyed clear consciences (but no air-conditioning) had finally fallen asleep, the first winds of autumn stirred the night.

title: Hospitals Still Wary on State Aid
description: WHEN Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed a bill last month that will pump much-needed money into hospitals in the state, it was no guarantee that the county's hospitals would receive a ''fair share'' of the funds, a spokesman for a regional hospital association said last week.

title: Women, Too, Deserve a National Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: Cory Aquino's Downhill Slide
description: Corazon Cojuangco Aquino glides into the reception room, smartly dressed in a pastel peach suit. Smiling warmly, she radiates serenity and self-confidence as she chats about her family, her travels, the weather. I have known her for two decades, and she has always appeared to be extraordinarily poised, even under enormous stress - a trait she attributes to her fatalism. Now, however, her composure seems to mask a certain uneasiness. She recoils when I seek to steer the conversation toward the problems facing her presidency - as if an admission of troubles might be construed as a sign of weakness. But she is indeed beleaguered by daunting difficulties.

title: 3 Youths Guilty of Rape And Assault of Jogger
description: Three young men were convicted last night of raping and beating a jogger in Central Park but were acquitted on the most serious charge they faced, attempted murder.

title: Spano Vies for Conservative Spot
description: LEAD: STATE SENATOR Nicholas A. Spano, a Yonkers Republican who has traditionally had strong support from Conservatives, is facing a primary challenge for the Conservative Party nomination because of his decision to support abortion rights.

title: Rachel F. Weber Weds Carlos A. Ortiz
description: Rachel French Weber and Carlos Alejandro Ortiz Cathcart were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church in Woodstock, Vt., by the Rev. William P. Gallagher.

title: May K. Mukuda Is Wed in California
description: May Kyoko Mukuda and Michael Renne Ty Tan were married yesterday at St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church in Palo Alto, Calif., by the Rev. Alexander Larkin.

title: Joanna Feinman Weds
description: Joanna Bess Feinman, a daughter of Carol and Matthew Feinman of New York, was married yesterday to Tom Riordan, a son of Henry and Aileen Riordan of Summit, N.J. Walter Lawton, an Ethical Culture Society leader, performed the ceremony at the bride's parents' summer home in Arkville, N.Y. The bride, 37 years old, will keep her name. She graduated summa cum laude from the University of Massachusetts, where her husband, also 37, received a master's degree in English. She is a Ph.D. candidate in clinical psychology at New York University, where the bridegroom teaches writing. Mr. Riordan is a Harvard University alumnus. His two previous marriages ended in divorce.

title: Dragging Nancy Through the Mud
description: LEAD: NANCY REAGAN'S love of the lavish has made her an irresistible target for numerous comic routines. Now the former First Lady is the centerpiece of a one-person show that became such an underground hit in its month-long run at P.S. 122 in Manhattan's East Village that it moved this month Off Broadway, to the Actors Playhouse.

title: Anglo-American Music And a World Attuned
description: If the arts are mankind's mirror, then international popular music may be a reflection of international politics and economics. Or so I brooded recently in Hamburg, West Germany, listening to the music on a restaurant sound system. The fare consisted of a nonstop onslaught of English and American pop hits, not a German among them.

title: Protect Passengers Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Senior League Shuffles Lineup
description: The Senior Professional Baseball Association has reduced its Florida membership by half and added one team in California and another in Arizona, Richard A. Remmert, vice president of the year-old league, said Friday.

title: Where There's Smoke There's Flavor
description: THE idea of smoking fish and game to preserve them has been around since the discovery of fire. But recently customers at the new West Street Grill in Litchfield, Conn. (203-567-3885) have been intrigued by the subtle, smoky flavor of unexpected foods such as tomatoes, corn and even lentils.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: Albeniz: 'Iberia' (complete); Granados: 'The Maiden and the Nightingale'

title: Gioia Arnold Whittemore Is Married To John B. Frelinghuysen in Vermont
description: The United Church of Christ in Dorset, Vt., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Gioia Arnold Whittemore of Greenwich, Conn., to John Brewster Frelinghuysen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Frelinghuysen Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title:
Focus: Oakland, Calif.;

Downtown Growth at a Rival's Expense
description: LEAD: The decision by the Crowley Maritime Corporation to move its headquarters out of San Francisco and across the bay has given another lift to this city's steady advance in the regional competition for office jobs.

title: Fashion;   Versatile Metal Makes a Varied Apparel
description: Jewelry and fashion designers are rediscovering anodized aluminum, a metal that lends itself to delicate shaping and subtle coloration in the electrochemical process that gives it its name.

title: Don't Measure Souter by the Size of His Town;   Mr. Dooley Says
description: To the Editor:

title: Practical Traveler;   Air Fare Savings, Real and Apparent
description: A TIMES correspondent who needed to get from Chicago to Minneapolis this summer booked a seat at the last minute for the 334-mile trip. The United coach ticket cost $246.30, not counting tax, for the flight of an hour and 10 minutes. He asked for an open-date return ticket and was booked in first class. He said he did not want to pay for first class, and the agent replied it was cheaper than coach - $240.74, not counting tax. The reporter said this was proof that air fares were crazy.

title: Ellen A. Bauerle Weds David S. Potter
description: Ellen Ann Bauerle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Bauerle of Delaware, Ohio, was married yesterday to David Stone Potter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. David Potter of New York. The Rev. Kristen Leslie, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Michigan League in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Postings: Matching Grants;   Religious Repairs
description: Flushing Friends Meeting House, built in 1674 in Queens, had to repair its exterior, including its soffits and cornices, and to put in a new security system. St. Alban's Episcopal Church, built in 1865 in the Eltingville section of Staten Island, wanted to restore the exterior to its original colors and replace rotting boards. The 1918 Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, on West 88th Street, wanted to repair its stained-glass windows.

title: PRISONS CRITICIZED ON AIDS PROGRAMS
description: America's jails and prisons are not coping with the rapid increase of AIDS among inmates, causing needless suffering, say health and legal experts from around the country.

title: Unions Are Expanding Their Role to Survive in the 90's
description: Organized labor, battered by union-busting, concessions contracts and shrinking membership during the 1980's has begun to expand its services to attract new members and remain relevant for the ones they already have.

title: The Best of Steinbrenner Combines Standard Golden Oldies
description: For anyone who missed the first 17 seasons, this has been the ''best,'' or the top hits, of George Steinbrenner.

title: Courting the Muse at Playwrights Horizons
description: ''I sometimes produce shows that I know are less than great,'' says Andre Bishop, the 41-year-old artistic director of Playwrights Horizons. ''Of course, sometimes Mr. and Mrs. Audience don't care that I'm producing a show for what I feel is a valid purpose.''

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Neither Could Sell, So They Swapped
description: LEAD: Richard L. Ruebin, a real estate developer, and his wife, Antoinette, bought a five-bedroom contemporary colonial house on five acres in Pound Ridge in 1987.

title: Downturn In Economy Brings More Foreclosures
description: LEAD: WITH the state's economy faltering, more and more debt-laden Connecticut homeowners find themselves facing foreclosure. While the number of properties being taken over by banks in Connecticut remains relatively small, the number of foreclosures has increased markedly.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Replacing Some Trash With Flowers
description: LEAD: THIS was a good summer for gardens. The wet spring and well-spaced, timely cloudbursts in July kept lawns green and glowing, and flower plantings flourished. In the Baldwin-Oceanside area there is scarcely a block without a noteworthy display. Two nurseries, Atlantic and Dee's, had standing room only on weekends, and the variety of annuals and perennials for sale increases each year.

title: Walking in New York And Staying Alive At the Same Time
description: IT is not sheer coincidence that the imperial city of New York is also the most pedestrian city in the country. In contrast to other communities where people move mainly by car, New York is an infantry operation, dependent on auxiliaries in the shape of mass transit.

title: Norris Holds On to Win Offshore Prix
description: It was a rivalry made in Hollywood that determined the winner today of the Ultra Slim-Fast New York Offshore Grand Prix, the first major powerboat race on the Hudson River in nearly a decade.

title: 'A Howling Tempest in the Brain'
description: DARKNESS VISIBLE

title: Debra Wright Is Married
description: Debra Lynn Wright, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Wright of Ilion, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Joseph Ryan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Ryan of Ozone Park, Queens. The Rev. George B. Greene performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Ryan, 24 and a graduate of the State University of New York College at Potsdam, is the marketing coordinator and public relations director at the Boston architectural firm of Huygens, DeMella, Schaffer & Associates. The bridegroom, 27, is a law student at Harvard University, where he is a senior editor of the Journal of Law and Public Policy. He is a summa cum laude graduate of SUNY's College at Albany.

title: Jane Alexanian Wed to L. D. Sperling
description: Jane Abbott Alexanian, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Alexanian of Houston, was married there yesterday to Lawrence David Sperling, the son of Phyllis C. Sperling of Glenview, L.I., and Dr. Herbert L. Sperling of New York. The Rev. John Stelling, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Ted Sanders officiated at the Doctors' Club.

title: Weill's Odyssey: Part 1, Europe, Is Getting Its Due
description: In his 90th birthday year, Kurt Weill remains an increasingly emblematic 20th-century composer. Before most anyone else, he abandoned modernist dissonance and abstraction in favor of a style that delicately balanced formal integrity with popular appeal.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: To ask or not to ask? That is the question many novices have on their minds when venturing out to photograph strangers.

title: A Gift to America From Trumbull, Conn.
description: The date was Aug. 26, 1989 and Trumbull, Conn., had just won the Little League World Championship against the unbeatable foe. At least that's what almost everybody believed.

title: Moscow Letting Long Lost Masters Leave
description: COUNTRIES and people are not all that the new Soviet Union is ready to turn loose. Now comes word that hundreds of priceless drawings and watercolors that were thought to have disappeared forever from Germany during World War II have actually been kept safe in Moscow and will soon go back to the museum whence they came.

title: Q and A
description: Down Payment in Escrow

title: Colleen F. Gibbs, A Designer, Weds
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Millbrook, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Colleen Frances Gibbs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John David Gibbs of Arlington Heights, Ill., to Cornelius DeForest Howland 3d, a son of Mrs. Cornelius D. Howland and the late Mr. Howland. The Rev. Joseph Reynolds performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Jazz;   A Young Blues Guitarist Intent on Modernization
description: About halfway through his set at Manny's Car Wash on Tuesday night, the young blues guitarist and singer Kenny Neal played ''The Things That I Used to Do.'' The song, which was written by Guitar Slim in the mid-1950's, has become a standard because of its originality, derived from a distinct guitar figure and the unusual rise and fall of its melody. ong, Mr. Neal had been playing his own tunes, blues pieces slightly modernized with funk rhythms borrowed from the 1970's. There had not been a moment of distinction, and the constrast between Mr. Neal's own anonymous material and ''The Things That I Used to Do'' was telling.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Columbus, Ohio;

A Catalyst For Renewal
description: LEAD: A $93.9 MILLION convention center for which ground was broken at the end of June on the north side of downtown is stirring hopes for revitalization and a growth in tourism in surrounding older neighborhoods.

title: Blacks March in an Afrikaner Suburb
description: Andre Erasmus peered down the broad, straight road outside his tin-roofed home in a whites-only suburb here and gazed with a baleful eye on the advance of 15,000 black protest marchers, chanting through the dust clouds raised by many stamping feet.

title: 'A Hard Life for the Non-poor'
