title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Flowers With Perfume to Lighten a Gardener's Chores
description: LEAD: On hot and humid days when the summer breeze blows the scent of fragrant plants through the garden, it's exhilarating. Nothing is more delightful than these heady moments when gardening chores become enjoyable.

title: Works in Progress;   Steps in the Right Direction
description: ''You know how your leg goes to sleep sometimes?'' Sarah East says. ''That's what it feels like.'' Sarah, an 11-year-old from Anadarko, Okla., whose congenitally deformed left leg was amputated when she was an infant, is describing the tingling on her thigh provided by a new device aimed at helping amputees ''feel'' their feet.

title: A Photographer Writes on the Holocaust
description: LEAD: IN 1983, Newsweek assigned Bernard Gotfryd, a staff photographer for 26 years, to cover ceremonies at the White House honoring survivors of the Holocaust. From 6 A.M. until 11 P.M. Mr. Gotfryd took photographs, listened to the conversations and watched the faces of the survivors as President Ronald

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Wife's Road to Adventure Is a Cul de Sac
description: LEAD: NOW that we have arrived in the enlightened 90's, it has become acceptable to reveal all manner of juicy tidbits about oneself without fear of derision or scorn. What used to be called ''abnormal behavior'' is now accepted as just a slight aberration of the norm.

title: Psychological Counseling From the Company Store
description: AFTER two decades of rapid growth, employee assistance programs, which have helped millions of workers suffering from angst and workplace stress, are experiencing an identity crisis of their own.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A Grandmother Always, in the Heart
description: LEAD: ''WHERE is Percy buried?'' asked Zachary, my 7-year-old grandson. ''Mommy said he's buried in the garden. Show me.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My husband painted our brick patio with a clear water sealer. This was a mistake because when it rains the water stays on the bricks. Can the sealer be removed?

title:
ART;

Sculpture That Demands Viewer Involvement
description: LEAD: CONCEPTUAL art has been with us for several decades, and even those who feel nostalgic about the era when visually sensuous art monopolized attention can appreciate the Conceptualists' role in putting content from the external world back into art.

title: Gun-Control Group Heartened by '76 Souter Brief
description: When David H. Souter was Attorney General of New Hampshire, his office once argued that the Constitution does not guarantee individual citizens the right to carry firearms.

title: An Anthropologist With Bite
description: FOX AT THE WOOD'S EDGEA Biography of Loren Eiseley.

title: Hermann Simon, 89, Lawyer in Manhattan
description: Hermann E. Simon, a lawyer who specialized in estates and trusts and who obtained compensation from West Germany for victims of Nazi persecution, died of a heart attack on Tuesday in an elevator on his way to work at his office in lower Manhattan. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Miss Barry Weds Richard Grinalds
description: The chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Maura Roff Barry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Barry Jr. of Green Farms, Conn., to Richard Drummond Grinalds, a son of Maj. Gen. and Mrs. John Southy Grinalds of Belle Haven, Va., and San Diego. The Rev. Joseph Sullivan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
description: Yes, definitely, and for several reasons. First, tennis is a physically demanding sport, and young professionals are, by participating in this sport so competitively, asking for trouble. Their bodies have not yet fully developed, and such a taxing sport can cause serious physical problems later on.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

Why They Sing the Blues
description: LEAD: There is not a lot of of text in GOING TO CHICAGO: A Year on the Chicago Blues Scene (Woodford Publishing, 4043 23d St., San Francisco, Calif. 94114, Paper, $19.95), and there is little need for words in this collection of more than 200 photographs of blues artists. The images of the singer Big Twist and the guitarist Roy Buchanan - both no longer with us - made me realize how valuable this book will become as the years and these legends pass.

title: What IS Youth Coming To?
description: FOR years Americans have been bludgeoned by one report after another documenting what a mess the new generation is supposed to be. Their grade point averages and S.A.T. scores are falling while high school dropout rates are rising. They don't know when the Civil War was or what Lithuania is.

title: Making a Splash in Paris
description: During the dog days in Paris, tourists may find themselves compulsively swallowing a Perrier at every corner cafe and dangling their fingers in city fountains from the Jardin du Luxembourg to the Place des Vosges. They will undoubtedly wonder, too - as I did during the uncharacteristically hot month of June in Paris this year - how in the world they decided to vacation in the sultry city instead of by the breezy seashore.

title: Madison Avenue, Where Humor Can Get Some Respect
description: Humor on Madison Avenue is no longer a laughing matter. It has evolved from whimsical fad into an established marketing tool that is now taken very seriously, something akin to product demonstration, celebrity endorsement, the sexual tease or the adorable child.

title: The Executive Computer;   Can the New dBASE Solve Ashton-Tate's Problems?
description: Nearly two years after it rushed a flawed version of dBASE to market, the Ashton-Tate Corporation of Torrance, Calif., has finally brought out a new, improved update of the leading data base management program for personal computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation and compatible models.

title: Two Cheers for the Soviet Boom
description: To the Editor:

title: Systems for Students on the Move
description: The college years are when music begins to occupy an eminent place in many lives. During this time, nothing more effectively spurs incipient musical interests than a really good-sounding yet easily transportable stereo system. Whether acquired with savings from a summer job or as a munificent back-to-school gift, such a system serves as an exploratory probe into still unknown worlds of music.

title: Barrie Ladenheim, a Teacher, Is Wed
description: Barrie Ladenheim, a teacher at the Roosevelt Island Public School in New York, and Dr. Kenneth S. Austin, an orthopedic surgeon at the New York University Medical Center, were married yesterday at the Dellwood Country Club in New City, N.Y. Rabbi Louis Frishman officiated.

title: Review/Rock;   Cajun Singer Transcends Novelty
description: In the mid-1950's, when the Cajun rockabilly singer Joe Cheramie was 17, he earned a contract with RCA records. The company flew the singer, who called himself Joe Clay, from Harvey, La., to New York City, where he recorded with a group of New York's best black rhythm-and-blues musicians. A rare early example of racial integration in pop music, the records, featuring two drummers who played simultaneously, are astonishingly hard. They didn't sell at all.

title: Sin Tax Justified
description: To the Editor:

title: Recycling Measure: A Pleasant Surprise
description: As chief environmental official for the Town of Babylon, Suffolk County, New York, I was dismayed to read in the article ''Recycling: New Report, New Debate'' that our town had abandoned its newspaper recycling program in order to provide the requisite amount of fuel for our resource recovery plant. It is untrue.

title: An Exciting Country Showplace
description: THE Bellport is made for summer. This white, gingerbread Victorian house with cornflower blue shutters has open doorways, swirling ceiling fans and herb, vegetable and cutting gardens. It is a perfect backdrop for the season.

title: Food;   Summer Improv
description: Let's face it. the stark truth for many of us who spend summer weekends at the beach or in the mountains is that when it comes to groceries, the pickings are often slim. For the cook approaching the weekend with a definite menu in mind (culled, no doubt, from some enticing new cookbook filled with seasonal recipes), this can be a hair-tearing exercise in frustration. My neighborhood grocery store in Connecticut, where I've spent many a summer weekend, is certainly no place for the exotic cook, carrying just the basics: lots of canned food, a meager supply of fresh produce, no seafood other than frozen shrimp and absolutely no fine cuts of meat.

title: Roderick Cook, Actor On Stage, Dead at 58
description: Roderick Cook, the British-born stage and film actor who was perhaps best known for his 1972 Off Broadway revue ''Oh Coward!'' in which he adapted and performed the works of Sir Noel Coward, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 58. Dan V. Fuller, his business manager, said Mr. Cook died of what appeared to be a heart attack.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   A Riverside Retreat With a Notable Arboretum
description: For visitors, the 130-acre Bayard Cutting Arboretum's informal gardens provide a respite along the Connetquot River here in Suffolk County, about 50 miles east of Manhattan. In addition to its conifer collection, some of which is unique to Long Island, the arboretum offers a network of well-maintained nature trails, an architecturally notable mansion and a carriage house where concerts, meetings and art exhibits are held.

title: Daisies Are Coming Into Their Own
description: DAISIES are dandy, and August and September are the months when they come into their own. There are white ones, golden ones, yellow ones, blue ones, even maroon ones.

title: 'An American Looks at Britain'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Traditional Neighborhoods' Make Gains
description: LEAD: Recently, architects such as Andres Duany in Miami and Peter Calthorpe in California have generated considerable interest among designers and land planners on the merits of what is being called traditional neighborhood development.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 5 about Gov. Jim Florio's response to critics of his tax program misidentified the chairman of the Democratic State Committee. He is Philip Keegan.

title: Going Round the World Via Beer Barrel
description: ''Yes, my name really is Michael Jackson,'' says the narrator. ''But I don't sing and I don't drink Pepsi.'' Indeed, this British-born Michael Jackson is the antithesis of his rubber-limbed American counterpart: pudgy, professorial, woolly, contemplative. And while this Michael Jackson doesn't partake of soft drinks, he sure does put down a vat or two of beer every year.

title: FOX IN THE NETWORK HENHOUSE
description: Fox Broadcasting has done more than just create successful, youth-oriented programming (''Fox in the Network Henhouse'' by Cameron Stauth, July 15). It has given us a glimpse at our own future, and it's not pretty. From the urban body counts on shows like ''Cops'' and ''America's Most Wanted'' to the antihero Simpsons, watching Fox television is like peering over the horizon into post-industrial America.

title: Quarrels Over Who Said What and When
description: THE FIREMAN'S WIFE

title: Beachgoers Returning With Renewed Confidence
description: TWO years after the horror stories about medical debris led to widespread panic and many beach closings, Long Island's shores are once again clean and the crowds have returned.

title: Fears That Haunt a Scrubbed America
description: Put yourself, for a moment, inside the mind of Jesse Helms. Imagine a scrubbed, manicured neighborhood, a pocket of decency in the heart of our sinful land. The music is by Wayne Newton, the paintings are by Norman Rockwell, and sex takes place only between married men and women in beds at night.

title: Audience Fickleness Is No Mystery
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion: The Paris Couture;   The Need For New Ideas
description: The end of the line has come for a couple elements of design. After viewing the Paris fall couture collections, it is clear that skirts cannot get any shorter and clothes cannot get any tighter. Anyone interested in fashion could sense that the time has come for shifts of both ambiance and silhouette.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Competing for the Buyer on a Budget
description: LEAD: The 347 Group, a Port Jefferson Station developer, has begun offering a 1,280-square-foot house, with a one-car garage, for $94,990 in the first 57-unit phase of a 366-unit development in Manorville called Manor Run.

title: Computer Age Overtakes Yale's Typewriter Master
description: LEAD: The computer age has finally caught up with the Whtilock Typewriter Shop, in New Haven. Pinched by rising rent and falling demand, Manson H. Whitlock said he has reluctantly decided to close the repair business he has operated since 1934, the oldest business of its kind in the city.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My husband painted our brick patio with a clear water sealer. This was a mistake because when it rains the water stays on the bricks. Can the sealer be removed?

title: Style Makers;   Richard Morgenthal and Robert Warner, Opticians
description: They're opticians, but they're also artists. So Richard Morgenthal and Robert Warner decided to combine their areas of expertise and design a line of eyeglass frames.

title: Photos of Paterson And 1968 Multiples
description: PHOTOGRAPHS of Paterson taken by George Tice between 1967 and 1970 and a portfolio of multiples produced by artists working in 1968: these are the current attractions at the Paterson Museum, and though they have little in common beyond period and smallness of scale, they exist in a kind of symbiosis.

title: Largest Force Since Vietnam Committed in 15-Day Flurry
description: In only 15 days, while Congress was scattered on summer recess and much of official Washington was on vacation, senior Bush Administration officials have committed the United States to its broadest and most hazardous overseas military venture since the Vietnam War.

title: The Irene Adler Story, Continued
description: In the lightsome spirit of the Baker Street Irregulars and their universe, I'd like to add some recently discovered notes concerning Irene Norton, nee Adler (''Jerseyana,'' July 8).

title: There's More to Giacometti Than Met the Eye
description: It is hard to imagine another gallery anywhere capable of mounting a Giacometti exhibition like the one here at the Galerie Beyeler through Sept. 29. Only a gallery with intimate, thick-walled spaces similar to those in which Giacometti grew up in Italian Switzerland could make his work seem so comfortable and, in the process, call into question the understanding of Giacometti based on seeing his knobby, kneaded, bone-thin figures in the big white spaces of museums.

title: Fashion;   LOOKING BACK TOWARD THE FUTURE
description: Paris itself is mighty inspiration for fashion movers. This summer, three exhibits may further fuel the creative process. At the Louvre, there is a fascinating re-creation of a work put together in 1945 to show the world that Paris's couturiers and artisans had not gone down the drain during World War II. Titled the ''Theatre de la Mode,'' it is a series of elegant Parisian settings populated with 228 doll-size wire mannequins in couturier styles of the time (top). Included are photographs of Parisians during and just after the Occupation. The plucky styles, some presaging the ''New Look'' of 1947, seem tantalizingly different. Using 2,000 pairs of gloves from its archives, the Hermes boutique has put together an inventive show titled ''Le Gant Elegant'' (one example, insert). Gloves, many mechanized, read books, make love, go strolling, play musical instruments, march in parades and swim in fish tanks. Highly entertaining, the exhibit also points up the creativity that Paris artisans lavish on every article of feminine attire. For one week, the house of Chanel re-created a suite at the Ritz where Coco Chanel lived during the 1930's (Chanel, below). The purpose was to publicize its new watch collection. To visit these rooms so redolent of Chanel's aura - ''It's as if she just left a cigarette smoldering in a crystal ashtray,'' said one visitor - was to leave with a longing for this luxe era.

title: Technology;   Getting the Kinks Out of the Global Rescue System
description: The global satellite-based rescue system for locating downed airplanes and wrecked ships saves hundreds of lives each year, but it has been plagued by a false-alarm rate of 97 percent. Now a new system is being proposed that could drastically reduce the false alarms that waste precious time and millions of dollars.

title:
DINING OUT;

French and Italian Fare by the Delaware
description: LEAD: THERE are few restaurants where one can eat out of doors during the summer. So the Black Tulip in Washington Crossing, with its outdoor terrace abutting the road that runs alongside the Delaware River, is a welcome addition to the dining-out scene.

title: Come Home, Papa
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvadoran Foes Meet to Seek an End to War
description: Government and rebel negotiators met today to work toward an end to El Salvador's civil war, and the Government's chief delegate said progress was possible despite differences over the future of the army.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

When the Ocean Burns
description: LEAD: AN AMERICAN HERO. The Red Adair Story: An Authorized Biography. By Philip Singerman. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) This is a book about the romance of the oil patch, or rather how romantic it used to be. Paul (Red) Adair, the well-known fighter of oil-well fires, comes from the Texas of cigarettes and whisky and wild, wild women.

title: Art World Head Scratching
description: To the Editor:

title: That's Me Behind The Machine Gun
description: One day in 1988 I found myself strapped into a kind of canvas sling behind the machine gun in the open side of a helicopter gunship, scooting along above the hot, flat jungle known as the Chapare - the principal coca-growing region of Bolivia. We were looking for clandestine landing strips, clandestine laboratories. We were about 500 feet up, well within small-arms range. The wind blew through my hair and the racket was deafening. I watched our shadow moving below, moving fast. The tops of the trees were mauve, like cauliflower. Then for vast stretches the jungle disappeared. It had been scalped. Slash and burn. Long trees lay every which way on their sides, and amid them, beside them, grew the new coca bushes. The trees were like giant straws strewn over the ground out of a box.

title: Basking in the Regional Warmth of Swiss Faience
description: As guardians of the local culture and regional arts, the provincial museums of Europe are an invaluable resource for the study of special products manufactured locally.

title: Radio Contact Restored With Magellan Craft
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration restored steady radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft on Friday night, and today engineers continued the task of returning the craft to normal operation.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

There Are Spooks in This Suburb
description: LEAD: HERE LIES THE WATER. By Meredith Steinbach. (Another Chicago Press/Independent Literary Publishers Association, Box 816, Oak Park, Ill. 60303, Cloth, $17.95; Paper, $9.95.) Meredith Steinbach would probably cringe at the comparison, but her second novel is the spookiest tale of life gone wrong in suburbia since Ira Levin's ''Stepford Wives.

title: Political Art Comes of Age In the U.S.S.R.
description: For years, bits and pieces of what has loosely been termed unofficial Soviet art have appeared in American galleries and museums. The names of Ilya Kabakov, Erik Bulatov, Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid were the only ones to become familiar in the United States, but it was clear from their works that many alternatives to official Socialist Realism existed. The question for outsiders was: What did these alternatives look like?

title: A Polar Bear's Picnic
description: Below the small plane the results of the brief Arctic summer could be seen: inlets of clear water covered with broken patches of melting ice that looked like white lace tossed over the bright blue water. The landscape itself was austere and barren, covered with bare stone scoured out of the earth by ancient glaciers. The rocks heave up out of the landscape, then roll off as far as the eye can see. And what the eye can see is the very definition of earth tones: browns, tans, greens.

title: What's Doing In;   Amsterdam
description: Marlise Simons; Marlise Simons, a native of the Netherlands, is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times.

title: Home Sales Slump: Some Undeterred
description: LEAD: EVEN though the real-estate market in New Jersey does not look too promising right now, there are people who are preparing for the end of this sluggish market.

title: Christopher J. Walton Weds Sandra M. Wall
description: Sandra M. Wall and Christopher J. Walton were married yesterday at 45 Downing Street, a Manhattan caterer. Adele Agin officiated.

title: How the Big Oil Companies Blundered
description: The rush by oil companies to raise gasoline prices after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was a tremendous public relations blunder. By raising prices, these companies unraveled the thin cloak of credibility around their industry.

title: 2 Californians, Agreeing on Many Issues, Turn to S.& L. Crisis
description: Gauged by the broad made-for-television generalities that govern American politics today, not much divides the two candidates for governor of California on the major issues facing the state.

title: Drug Users' Children Need Help At School
description: LEAD: THE crack epidemic is a little more than five years old, which means that the first wave of the so-called ''crack babies,'' physiologically and emotionally scarred by their mothers' drug abuse, will be entering schools this fall. School officials in Connecticut's urban centers are wrestling with the problem of how to serve the needs of these youngsters.

title: Chrysa A. Radice, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Chrysa A. Radice and Dr. Charles A. Lawson were married yesterday at St. Philip's Roman Catholic Church in Clifton, N.J., by the Rev. Christopher DiLella. The couple's parents are Claire Beaven of Clifton and the late Arthur C. Radice and Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Lawson of Wilmette, Ill.

title: A Friendly Suggestion From the Home Office
description: Going all the way back to 1823, the Monroe Doctrine has been invoked at the slightest suggestion of outside interference on the American continent.

title: Ice Cream for La Dolce Vita
description: Sometime during the Roman Empire an anonymous genius poured fruit juice over snow and ate it. The difficulty of obtaining and keeping snow meant that only the privileged could enjoy this proto-sherbet, which disappeared with the decline of the empire.

title: LAWYERS CONDEMN 5-YEAR SUSPENSION
description: Several specialists in legal ethics say that a court acted too harshly in imposing a five-year suspension from legal practice on a lawyer whose disclosure that he had paid kickbacks to New York City officials helped expose major municipal corruption.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My husband painted our brick patio with a clear water sealer. This was a mistake because when it rains the water stays on the bricks. Can the sealer be removed?

title: Reaction to Jogger Verdict Ranges From Support to Disillusionment.
description: In the East Harlem neighborhood where the jogger trial defendants live, just northeast of Central Park, some residents welcomed the verdicts last night, but others insisted it was unjust.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Florida Hotel, Closed, Looking For Operator

title: Julia G. LeStage Is Married
description: Julia Greene LeStage, a funding coordinator at the American Finance Group, and Joseph Anthony McOsker 3d, an associate in the law firm of Jon E. Steffensen & Associates, both in Boston, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass. The Rev. David White officiated. Mrs. McOsker, 26 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald LeStage 3d of Attleboro, Mass. She graduated from Wells College. Mr. McOsker, 31, graduated from Brown University and the Suffolk University Law school. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anthony McOsker Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
description: No. If they and their parents think they are mature enough to cope with the intensity of competition, unscrupulous agents and managers, rakish media, frenzied fans, social and academic underdevelopment, serious injury, give them the opportunity to play.

title: Sing, Sing, Sing
description: JAZZ SINGING

title:
Your Own Account;

Cash Flow for the College-Bound
description: LEAD: They may be on the beach this weekend, but in just a couple of weeks this year's college freshmen will be hitting the books - checkbooks as well as textbooks.

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: LEAD:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article about Soviet art on page 37 of the Arts and Leisure section omits a paragraph. The second full paragraph in the third column should read:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: SHE DROVE WITHOUT STOPPING. By Jaimy Gordon (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $18.95.) Jane Turner, female desperado, is on the lam. She's 21 years old and in flight from the stifling norms of 1960's family and social life. She has yearned, to no avail, for the approval of her rejecting father, whose sexist impulses and rampant infidelities have long disturbed the family peace.

title: Trouble on the Range as Cattlemen Try to Throw Off Forest Boss's Reins
description: In the high sage and scrub forest of southern Idaho, a handful of cattlemen have squared off against a stubborn United States ranger in a battle over land, water and a way of life as old as the mythology of the American West.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Most Dispassionate Defense of the Unmanicured Lawn
description: LEAD: OH, oh! They were doing it again. From all the racket, I could tell that our neighbor's lawn service had arrived, and because they cared for several homes, they would be here for quite a while.

title: Not Sauce for The Gander
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
description: Child prodigies should be permitted to develop their talents and share them with the world from the moment those talents become evident. The children should be encouraged, supported, nourished, nurtured. Certainly any child with minimum talents should not be pushed to try to reach a goal that is impossible or unlikely.

title: Looking Beyond the Mideast Crisis
description: The conventional wisdom in Washington was that President Bush took an immense risk when he shifted his stance on tax increases. But even before the Middle East crisis, the bond market was sending a different message. It signaled that major economic benefits would flow from a White House budget deal. Only if fiscal policy is tightened appropriately can interest rates come down and growth resume.

title: Sticking To Rules
description: Although Japanese corporate interests have been buying golf courses and sponsoring tournaments in the United States in order to increase their visibility on television back in Japan, what happened this weekend at the JAL Big Apple Classic pretty much resembled a drive into a bunker.

title:
BASEBALL;

Evans: Good Enough to Become Great
description: LEAD: It would be easy to follow the Boston Red Sox without ever noticing their designated hitter, Dwight Evans. Consider some of the distractions:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SCIENCE AND BABIES: Private Decisions, Public Dilemmas. By Suzanne Wymelenberg. (National Academy, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.) This book contends that when it comes to the task of reproducing ourselves, our priorities need a vigorous reshuffling. The irony is that the United States, with the financial and technological wherewithal to tackle issues of reproductive health, has such a deplorable record: infant mortality rates here hover somewhere below those of Hong Kong and Singapore, and our rates for unwanted pregnancies and abortions are the highest in the industrialized world.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Aug. 12 about Fastbreak Vacations, in Chicago, misstated its telephone number for information on discount travel. The number is (900) 990-3335.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: A rather vague area of postal history - improvised delivery services - often leads students to view their collections as paradigms of particularly turbulent periods.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: BETTY KOEHLER;

Helping Women Battle Alcoholism
description: LEAD: BETTY KOEHLER is the founder and director of Crawford House, a halfway house that is observing its 10th anniversary this year. Ms. Koehler, who has been honored by several New Jersey organizations for her work helping alcoholic women to recover, has personally worked with more than 700 women in the last decade.

title: Ms. Warner Weds William Simmons
description: Deidre Lin Warner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Mooney of Washington, N.J., was married yesterday to William Richard Simmons, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Simmons of Plandome Manor, L.I. The Rev. E. Wayne Antworth, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, performed the ceremony aboard a yacht in New York Harbor.

title:
MUSIC;

Doing Your Own Thing By Making Your Own Thing
description: LEAD: John Cage's assertion that any sound ''can become musical by taking its place in a piece of music'' was a declaration of musical war. New music demanded new sounds, argued Mr. Cage in a 1937 lecture; for him, the humblest sound sources, from brake drums to flower pots, were equal in value to pianos and saxophones.

title: Putting Lyme Disease Into Perspective
description: DR. MATTHEW L. CARTTER, an epidemiologist with the preventable diseases division of the State Department of Health Services, is in charge of surveillance for Lyme disease. He was the editor of an edition of the Connecticut State Medical Society magazine last year devoted to the disease.Lyme disease was originally believed to cause only the characteristic rash and arthritis, but doctors now know that it can cause cardiological and neurological problems.

title: O'Brien-Eason Race Goes On
description: The Jets' quarterback battle between best friends produced stirring performances tonight by both Ken O'Brien and Tony Eason.

title: Currency;   Down, Down, Down
description: It happened. The dollar fell last week to its lowest level against the German mark since that currency was created 42 years ago. There was no celebration. With the United States facing a possible recession, there is little the Federal Reserve can do to counter the fall, which can add to inflationary pressures by raising the cost of imported goods. Those pressures have already been magnified by the huge increase in oil prices since the Middle East crisis began. By week's end, the dollar fell to 1.5495, just over two pfennigs below the previous low close in New York of 1.5700, reached on Dec. 31, 1987. Now traders are waiting to see how soon the dollar will reach its all-time low against the Swiss franc, which closed Friday at 1.2830. The current low, 1.2690, was also reached on Dec. 31, 1987.

title: Confess, but Get Out of Town
description: LEAD:

title: Q and A
description: Discount Travel Agencies

title: Wood Wears Coats of Many Colors
description: AS Betsy McManus and Jennifer Thurstan see it, a plain surface should not be left alone. It can be painted, glazed, stenciled, stippled or maybe all of the above. Wood can be made to look like marble or semiprecious stone. Ordinary pine can be made to resemble exotic zebra wood.

title: China's Greatest Dissident Writer: Dead but Still Dangerous
description: ''If China is not to perish, then as history tells us, the future holds a tremendous surprise for the murderers. This is not the conclusion of an incident, but a new beginning. Lies written in ink can never disguise facts written in blood. Blood debts must be repaid in kind: the longer the delay, the greater the interest.'' -Lu Xun

title: Gillian Lusins Is Married
description: Gillian Marie Lusins, a daughter of Dr. John and Anna Marie Lusins of Oneonta, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Simon Paul, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Paul of Philadelphia. The Rev. Richard Breuninger, a Methodist minister, officiated at Shineman Chapel at Hartwick College in Oneonta.

title: Stephanie Feinstein Is Wed
description: Stephanie Beth Feinstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Feinstein of Brooklyn, was married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York to Alan Jonathan Marquesano, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Marquesano of New York. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated.

title: Rikers Inmate Dies and Inquiry Begins
description: A Rikers Island inmate died yesterday at Harlem Hospital, but it was unclear whether the death was related to the violent disturbance at the nine-jail complex Tuesday night in which 135 people were injured, 92 of them inmates.

title: Campus Life: Lehigh;   A Condo Project Strikes the Fancy Of Many Parents
description: Harold K. Tish said he knew that his University Square condominium project was going to be a success when he received a letter from a Lehigh University alumnus living on a remote island in the South Pacific. The alumnus, Thomas A. Bayer, was interested in buying a condominium for his daughter, Melissa, an incoming freshman at Lehigh.

title: U.S. Ships Fire in Warning When Iraqis Refuse to Halt By MICHAEL R. GORDON
description: An American warship fired six warning shots near an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman today after it refused to heed warnings to halt, officers said today. [In Washington, Defense Department officials reported that a second set of warning shots was fired by an American warship in the Persian Gulf. [A statement from the Defense Department said that neither Iraqi tanker was stopped but that they were under ''close Navy surveillance.'' Pentagon officials said they did not know where the vessels were headed.] American vessels in the Persian Gulf were ordered to general quarters following the incident, the highest state of alert, Navy officers said.

title: Jeffrey Rose Wed To Katie Behne
description: Kathryn Lindsay Behne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Behne of Riverside, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Dennis Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Rose of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Gilbert D'Souza officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena.

title: Harvest of Surplus Food Eases Plight of the Hungry
description: It all started with potato skins.

title: Lenders Feel New Pressures To Aid Poor Neighborhoods
description: Already squeezed by mounting defaults, lower earnings and a savings and loan debacle that has made them shy away from many development proposals, the nation's real estate lenders are now feeling pressure from another source - new Federal rules that require greater attention to the credit needs of minorities and low-income neighborhoods.

title: Statement by Iraq's Social Ministry
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Iraqi Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs about the treatment of foreigners in Iraq, as transmitted by the Iraqi press agency and translated by Reuters:

title: Tennis Stars Split by Rival Tournaments
description: THE competition began at the Northstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup in Commack long before the first ball is to be served this week.

title: Switzer Speaks
description: In his years as Oklahoma's highly successful head football coach, Barry Switzer may have made his share of mistakes, but three he denied ever making were being in a hotel room in Las Vegas, Nev., where cocaine was used, betting on his team's games and manipulating the Sooner drug-testing program.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT. By Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) In this era of sequels, it's only logical that Sidney Sheldon should give us a follow-up to his extremely popular 1974 novel, ''The Other Side of Midnight.'' The only question is why it took him so long. At the end of that book, you may recall, Catherine Douglas had disappeared into a stormy night, escaping her husband, Larry, and his mistress, Noelle Page, just as they were about to kill her.

title: They Were Not Broken
description: BOUNCING BACK

title: Tech Notes;   Computers Linked by Light
description: In the past, computers were linked together by networks made of wire or fiber-optic cables that were placed under the floors and under the ground. Now, engineers at the Photonics Corporation in Campell, Calif., are linking them with light. The new networking system - Photolink (right) - works very much like the remote control unit of a television set. It transmits data between computers by converting it into modulated pulses of invisible infrared light. Light-emitting diodes send the rapidly pulsing infrared signals through a lens, which bounces them off the room's ceiling. Photo diodes in the units sense incoming signals and convert them into the electrical impulses a computer can use. Processors inside the units compensate for extraneous light. The systems can connect computers in neighboring buildings by sending beams through windows and across streets.

The Agriculture and Markets Law (article 26, section 374) states: ''The use of a decompression chamber or decompression device of any kind is hereby declared to be inhumane when used for destroying an animal and is hereby prohibited.''

title: Friendly Persuasion
description: Sometimes before gods can help people, people have to help the gods. When the Zuni Indians of New Mexico, feeling the strong tug of old beliefs, began in recent years to seek the aid of ancient war gods - whose appeal is not limited to wartime - they had to rescue dozens of the carved wooden statues from museums and private collectors. As a result, among the various Indian tribes that have fought to regain possession of cultural artifacts, the Zunis have become experts on getting the job done. The tribe has recovered 38 of the striking, starkly sculpted cylinders in recent years and is negotiating now for 13 more that are in the hands of the Brooklyn Museum. Barton Martza, head councilman of the Zuni, said that the tribe retrieved most of its war gods by simply explaining that the communally carved statues were tribal property that no individual Zuni could legally sell - they fetch up to $40,000 each - or even give away. Furthermore, ritual requires that the idols be left exposed to the elements until they disintegrate. ''We really don't get into the legal stuff very much,'' he said. ''When we go talk to a museum, we just tell them what we believe.''

Verbally, he's no deep thinker; when he's not singing about sex, his messages tend to be benevolent and banal. His new album, ''Graffiti Bridge'' (Paisley Park/Warner Bros. 27493; all three formats), sloganizes with ''Everybody's lookin' 4 love,'' ''Makin' love and music's the only things worth fighting 4'' and, on the utopian side, ''There will be peace 4 those who love God a lot.''

Holmes Jr. of Monticello, Ga., and St. Simons Island, Ga. The Rev. James K. Yeary performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Athens. Mr. Hussein and Mr. Bush are now engaged in a struggle within a struggle, namely over whether the fate of the Americans and other foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq will weaken the international resolve to squeeze Baghdad hard enough to force a withdrawal from Kuwait.

Brent wasn't injured, physically anyway; he wasn't even playing. Brent Musburger was CBS's lead sportscaster for the game and - as nearly everyone had learned from headlines the day before - CBS had dumped him. The game was to be his last assignment for the network.

Mrs. Stoll, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy Payne Gaylord of Pound Ridge. She is a graduate of the Fox Lane School and Dartmouth College. A former deputy press secretary for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, the bride is an account executive with Kaufman Public Relations in Washington. Her father heads Gaylord Direct Marketing in Armonk, N.Y.

Jews should study Jewish texts, the rabbis declared; anything more was a distraction, anything less a rebellion against God.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: PATRICIA TENERELLA-BRODY;

The Emotional Aspects of Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: WITH Lyme disease in the county on the increase each year, more and more people are feeling the physical pain that a deer tick the size of a pen point can cause. But it isn't only physical pain that sufferers of this disease can feel. There is also the mental anguish, in some cases of not knowing what is wrong, and in other cases of not getting well despite the antibiotic ''cure.

title: As Accord on Afghan Future Nears, Refugees Live in Fear and Hardship
description: On the rocky border with Afghanistan, where millions of exiles might be expected to rejoice in the news that Moscow and Washington are nearing agreement on their political future, there is no joy. Among the Afghans, guerrillas and refugees alike, there is tension, mounting hardship and despair.

title: Giants Plod to a Slim Victory
description: The crowd of 48,773 spectators in the Astrodome watched the Giants make their share of big plays. Dave Meggett's 49-yard punt return set up a field goal. Everson Walls's 31-yard interception run set up another. But another interception by Walls and one by Tracy Gravely were wasted.

title: British Homosexuals Report Rise in Attacks
description: ''We think attacks are increasing for a number of reasons,'' said Chris Woods, a reporter for Capital Gay, a weekly newspaper for homosexuals. ''The AIDS and HIV epidemic has had an impact with the aid of the tabloids, which label it the gay plague. In the last 20 years, lesbian and gay politics have progressed dramatically in this country, but the police attitude reflects a 60's approach to a 90's problem. They still project us as a homosexual underworld, with various vices, who need to be controlled. That is absolute baloney.''

title: Guggenheim Museum Is Designated a Landmark
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously last week to designate the Guggenheim Museum a landmark - perhaps the first time in the distinctive building's history that a group of nine people have agreed upon all its merits.

title: On the Mend
description: Just saying ''no'' nearly cost David Opont his life five months ago, when a neighborhood bully tied him up, beat him and set him afire after David refused to smoke a cigarette he thought contained drugs. As he was released from a New York City hospital last week, the 12-year-old, who had initially been given only a 50 percent chance of survival, called on ''politicians and teachers'' to ''do more to make our children safe.'' Doctors said that David had made remarkable progress during two months of intensive therapy. His plight had attracted national attention and a visit from Ronald and Nancy Reagan. But last week his parents, who emigrated from Haiti two years ago, were anxious to get him out of the limelight and into his new home in Brooklyn, where relatives were visiting for ''a small get-together to make him feel good.'' His 13-year-old assailant, meanwhile, is scheduled to go on trial next month on charges including attempted murder.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Hawthorne
description: To many people, Hawthorne is just the name of a traffic circle, even though that circle disappeared in the late 60's to be replaced by the three-tiered Hawthorne Interchange connecting the Saw Mill River, Taconic and Sprain Brook Parkways.

title: 'Council School' Offers Training to Hopefuls

title: Faces of Death in Liberia

Begun with an invasion by about 150 rebels led by Charles Johnson, a former minister in President Samuel K. Doe's Government, the war is now being waged by three factions: the Government, Mr. Taylor's troops, and a third group led by Prince Johnson, a former rebel commander under Mr. Taylor.

It won't come as a surprise to anyone that I was met with utter amazement every time I told people where I was going, and that I was doing it by choice. ''But why New Jersey? It is so dirty,'' was the general message.

title: Punjab Theater Bomb Kills 2
description: A powerful bomb exploded at a movie theater near Amritsar today, killing 2 people and wounding 45, the police said. They said they suspected Sikh extremists of setting the bomb, which went off at the theater in the town of Patti.

description: Forty-nine years ago, a German soldier stationed in Poland decided to spend his birthday taking pictures in Warsaw. The soldier, Heinz Jost, who had been a small-town innkeeper, had seen bodies piled alongside the wall that enclosed the city's ghetto, the now-infamous 2.4-square-mile area in which the Nazi occupation forces had confined 500,000 Polish Jews.

title: Russian Party Ranks Shrink
description: The head of the Russian republic's Communist Party was quoted today as saying 162,750 members - 90,000 of them factory workers - quit in July, about 1.5 percent of the 11 million members. The announcement by Ivan K. Polozkov, who was elected in June, was reported by the republic newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya.

title: This Tour Blends Cycling and Helping

description: Cloudy skies and intermittent rain put a damper on Harlem Day festivities yesterday, but tens of thousands of people still turned out on 125th and 135th Streets to eat, listen to music, shop and socialize.

title: Personal Business by a Nose
description: The owner Ogden Mills Phipps and the trainer Shug McGaughey, who sent out Rhythm to win the Travers Stakes here Saturday, completed a weekend Grade I double when their Personal Business scored a narrow victory today in the $117,000 John A. Morris Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

title: The Nonproliferation Hoax
description: LEAD: The Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons is now being reviewed in Geneva by many of the 142 nations that have ratified it. Like three previous review conferences held since the treaty came into force in 1970, this one is likely to extol the virtues of nonproliferation - the next best thing to motherhood - and ignore flaws that make the treaty dangerously out of date.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

description: LEAD: In a move that surprised many retail industry analysts, Donald G. Thomson was named president of Michaels Stores Inc. last week.

title: A Long-Awaited Pavilion Makes Its Debut Tonight
description: For many who attend the free performances by the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera every summer in New York City's parks, the blaring sound and harsh timbres produced by the amplification system the two organizations share have been accepted as the cost of hearing music in the open air. But since 1980 the Philharmonic, the Met, and the sound and lighting designer Peter Wexler have been planning an ambitious replacement system.

title:

description: The case against the three defendants convicted in the rape and the beating of the woman who came to be known as the Central Park jogger was won not in a courtroom in lower Manhattan but in three grubby New York City police station houses, where detectives smoothly convinced the three young men to confess.

title: Mack Trucks' Projection

Mack now expects sales to total $1.67 billion, compared with the $1.5 billion predicted earlier. Mack originally predicted a loss of $130 million. The truck maker lost $97 million for the first half of the year and went into default on its large bank loans.

title: Bob Knight Recalls Len Bias
description: THE conversation on a plane flight recently between two strangers seated together, one a sportswriter with some gray in the sideburns of his unruly hair and the other a sophomore in college, got around to drugs on campus. ''It's still a major problem,'' said the young man. ''You wonder,'' said the sportswriter, ''whether the death of Len Bias made any impact at all.'' ''Glen Bias?'' repeated the young man. ''No,'' said the sportswriter, ''Len Bias.'' ''Was he heavy metal?'' asked the student. The sportswriter explained that Bias was a star basketball player for the University of Maryland who had been chosen by the Boston Celtics as the top pick in the National Basketball Association draft in June 1986. He had a brilliant future, with fame and a million-dollar contract just around the corner. Now he'd be able to make his working-class family very comfortable, as well.

description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said tonight that he would free foreigners being held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait in exchange for a complete military and political pullout by the United States from the Persian Gulf region.

description: A Federal appeals court on Thursday directed a Federal judge in Cleveland to limit his effort to consolidate thousands of asbestos cases from elsewhere in the nation.

title: Jane Green Is Married to Lee Bender
description: Jane Beth Green, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Green of Ambler, Pa., was married yesterday to Lee Stewart Bender, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bender of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Richard Fagan, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Roger Barrer Married to Diane Tepper
description: A report yesterday about the wedding of Diane Sabesin-Tepper and Roger Barrer referred incorrectly to the bride's mother and to the bridegroom's parents. Mrs. Barrer's mother, Rose Sabesin, lives in Chicago. Mr. Barrer's parents are deceased.

title: Cadmus Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Behind Rikers Melee: Tensions Wrought by Strain of Change
description: Last week's bloody eruption at Rikers Island highlights dramatically the tensions of the nation's most populated penal complex as it grapples with sweeping changes that have come close to altering its very nature.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Despite the financial predicament that DONALD J. TRUMP finds himself in, Trump is becoming a bigger and bigger name in real estate. That is, brothers EDDIE and JULIUS TRUMP, no relation to Donald.

title: Good Day for Yanks and Merrill
description: With the game against the Seattle Mariners an hour away, Stump Merrill, manager of the Yankees, sat alone in his office yesterday afternoon, poring over the scouting reports and statistical breakdowns. The silence was ultimately broken by the sound that over the years had amused, annoyed and forever haunted the men who had sat in Merrill's chair. The phone rang. George Steinbrenner was on the line, and Merrill understood immediately, he said later, that a lot hung in the balance. Steinbrenner, the departing owner of the Yankees, said hello and asked if anyone else was in the room with Merrill. The manager said there wasn't. ''Good,'' Steinbrenner said. Merrill, his employment status about to be decided, wasn't quite so sure it was.

title: Let's Leave Oil Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters;   Going for the Gold In the Campaign For Surrogate
description: The low-visibility four-way contest for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Surrogate has turned into a race for money: the candidate with the most is likely to be the strongest contender in the Sept. 11 Democratic primary. (The nomination virtually assures election.) The feverish quest for campaign money tends to reinforce the court's already questionable image - that of an institution that oversees billions of dollars in estates while dispensing millions of dollars in fees to favorite lawyers to serve as guardians in estates and trusts. It's an image that all four candidates - like candidates before them - promise to change.

title: Conflict to Consensus
description: Over lunch recently, a Chilean who was a bright young official in the long-ago Government of Salvador Allende looked back on that period with a certain realistic nostalgia:

title: Gooden Falters But Mets Win, 10-9
description: Forget that the Mets won a game they had to win tonight when they outscored the San Francisco Giants, 10-9, and stayed two games out of first place in the National League East. Forget that Kevin McReynolds knocked in six runs with two home runs and a single. And, most of all, forget that Dwight Gooden won his 13th game of the season.

title: 100 in Indiana Are Evacuated As Heavy Rains Threaten Dam
description: About 100 people were evacuated from the area around Lake Manitou today after high water from heavy rains threatened to break a dam, the authorities said.

title: Iraq Crisis Gives Fed New Woes
description: The dominant figure in the credit markets these days does not sit in the Federal Reserve's ornate office at the corner of Constitution Avenue and 20th Street in Washington, but in the Iraqi presidential palace in Baghdad.

title: Ruddock Wins; Odum May Protest
description: Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, a highly ranked heavyweight contender from Toronto, knocked out Kimmuel Odum at 2 minutes 58 seconds of the third round of a scheduled 10-round fight at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino here today. But the result was tainted by a knockdown Ruddock scored after the bell ending the second round, and by the prospect of a protest that was raised by the defeated fighter and his handlers.

How Vulnerable Is Iraq?
description: Short of food and dependent on imports for everything from auto parts to chicken parts, Iraq's economy is widely assumed to be exceptionally vulnerable to a trade embargo. If the United States and its allies are prepared to stand up to Baghdad's threats over the weekend to cut off food to foreigners in Iraq - an indication that the embargo is indeed causing worry - the effects of the sanctions are likely to take hold quickly.

title: Air Fleet's Call-Up Unlikely to Hurt Airlines
description: The Government's activation of the Civilian Reserve Air Fleet last week is not expected to affect scheduled passenger flights by the nation's airlines, industry executives and analysts said over the weekend.

description: Not only have the Giants made two different offers to Lawrence Taylor, as General Manager George Young confirmed Saturday night, but they also appear to be close to signing two other defensive players, Erik Howard and Mark Collins.

title: New York Pakistanis Seek Ballot Power
description: Over the wail of a Pakistani folk song and the cries of children imploring their parents for sweets like gulab jamun or rus malai, all along the two-block stretch of Coney Island Avenue reserved for the first Pakistan Day Festival in Brooklyn yesterday, there was a constant exhortation to register to vote.

title: Concorde Career Colleges reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Barri Gordon Is Married To Daniel R. Waltcher
description: Barri Hope Gordon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gordon of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Daniel Russell Waltcher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Waltcher of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi Ronald Millstein officiated at the Loft in New York.

title: Review/Television;   His Life Was Changed by the Blues
description: John Hammond, the subject of an ''American Master'' biography tonight at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, put his music where his conviction's were. For five decades as a talent scout and producer, he had a double agenda: making the best blues-rooted music available to the widest public, and working toward an ideal of a desegregated America.

title: Trading Business
description: STEVE JONES, a 15-year-old from Natrona Heights, Pa., considers himself an avid baseball fan, and a fairly crafty businessman. So tomorrow, between innings of Little League World Series games in Williamsport, Pa., he will reach for his portfolio and go about the business of trading, buying and selling the most popular collectibles associated with Little League baseball in recent years: team pins.

title: U.S. Consults U.N. on Use of Force As Navy Shadows 2 Iraqi Tankers
description: With American warships shadowing two loaded Iraqi oil tankers in Middle East waters, the Bush Administration began a round of urgent diplomacy today in hopes of winning United Nations approval of its use of military power to enforce the international embargo on trade with Iraq, Administration officials said.

title: Mona Last, Lawyer, Weds Rabbi Howard S. Herman
description: Mona E. Kushner Last, an associate in the law firm of Watstein & Watstein in Bristol, Conn., and Rabbi Howard S. Herman of the Farmington Valley Jewish Congregation in Simsbury, Conn., were married yesterday at the rabbi's congregation. Cantor Susan L. Levine performed the ceremony.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   A Grim Bush Golfs and Boats As Aides Fret About Image
description: The President's vacation has stopped being fun.

title: Digital Systems International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Television;   Adventure With a Cause
description: ''The Last Elephant'' is evidence for the proposition that good causes make bad art. In pursuance of its honorable campaign to arouse indignation over the slaughter of Africa's elephants by ivory poachers, the National Audubon Society has come up with a show that poaches on countless B-movies but produces nothing as precious as ivory. The two-hour result can be seen tonight at 8 on the TNT cable network.

title: Martha Lemer Is Wed
description: Martha Dorothy Lemer, an associate in the law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, and Richard J. Byrne, a vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago. Rabbi Neil Brief officiated. The bride, 28 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Lemer of Skokie, Ill. She graduated from Brandeis University and the Georgetown University Law Center. Mr. Byrne, 29, is a son of Merle Byrne of Oceanside, L.I. He graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton, and received an M.B.A. from Northwestern University.

title: Falconbridge Gold reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Midwest Quake Is Predicted; Talk Is Real
description: Life on the fault line is always interesting, as people in this trembly old Mississippi River town often say, but a prediction by a man named Iben Browning is making life hereabouts downright exciting.

title: City of Past and Future, Berlin Refashions Itself
description: When the two German states are joined, probably only nine weeks from now, this sprawling city of over four million people will once again be the capital of a united Germany and more - a great metropolis of Europe and the world.

title: Move by FundAmerica
description: FundAmerica Inc., a buying club with 100,000 members, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors and asked the court to appoint an independent examiner to investigate various allegations against it. The company, based in Irvine, Calif., is facing scrutiny from regulators in Florida and other states and is the subject of a $150 million class-action suit filed in San Francisco. Its Federal bankruptcy filing in Santa Ana, Calif., listed assets of $17.5 million and liabilities of $14.5 million.

title: Rostagno, No. 79, Wins Volvo Title
description: In a tournament that was rife with upsets to players like Ivan Lendl and Andrei Chesnokov, 79th-ranked Derrick Rostagno defeated No. 135 Todd Woodbridge of Australia today, 6-3, 6-3, in the final of the Volvo International tournament here.

title: Memtek Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Banking Expert Criticized
description: In an unusual move, the chairman of the House Banking Committee has suggested that a financial expert who is studying the health of the commercial banking industry's deposit insurance system for a banking subcommittee should be removed.

title: A Debut of Sorts For a 14-Year-Old
description: LEAD: The waiting is over for Chanda Rubin. Tonight, the 14-year-old will play her first match against a prominent player when she meets Hana Mandlikova, a former United States Open champion, in the Pathmark Tennis Classic, in Mahwah, N.J.

title: Steinbrenner Era Could End Today
description: By 5 P.M. today, barring a court-ordered reprieve, George Steinbrenner is expected to terminate a 17 1/2-year run as the very visible managing owner of the Yankees.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Investor Finds Values In Bankrupt Companies
description: LEAD: Andre Danesh, the president of the Allied Financial Corporation, is an investor with an unusual perspective. The Boston-based investor specializes in bankrupt companies, using the ''intuition and calculation'' that he learned in getting a Ph.D. degree in chemistry.

title: Reviews/Music;   'Tosca' With a More Human Scarpia
description: The New York City Opera's sturdy production of ''Tosca,'' which returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday evening, makes some interesting points by toying with viewers' expectations. We expect the corrupt Baron Scarpia, for instance, to be irredeemably evil, but he is introduced in an understated way that makes him more complex and at times more human.

title: Brazil's Plan on Bank Debt
description: Brazil does not plan to make payments on its foreign bank debt this year, the nation's economy minister said Friday.

title: Clemens Wins 18th With a 4-1 Victory
description: Roger Clemens scattered seven hits in seven innings for his sixth consecutive victory and 18th of the season as the Boston Red Sox ended a three-game losing streak today with a 4-1 decision over the California Angels.

title: Jessica Decker Is Married

The couple's parents are Dr. Jack Decker of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Dr. Ona Robinson of White Plains and Nicole Martin of Erie, Pa., and the late Morton Kramer.

description: Retail prices in Britain rose 9.8 percent in the 12 months that ended in July, the same rate as in June, the Government said Friday. Some economists had forecast that the rate might break through 10 percent because of higher wage settlements and consumer spending. Lower prices for seasonal foods in July left the figure unchanged from June.

The television spot, which will be the first public service announcement featuring the raisins, will have the characters performing a rap song encouraging children to read. The spot was created by Will Vinton Claymation Productions. Mr. Vinton's clay-animated figures have appeared in a variety of commercials.

The recital this evening by the veteran bass Yevgeny Nesterenko in the Nicholas Music Center here offered that promise, but no guarantees. The 52-year-old Russian had not appeared in the United States much of late, and recent reports of his vocal state were mostly discouraging.

title: Flake Pleads Not Guilty to All Charges
description: As hundreds of his supporters packed the courtroom and filled the air with hymns on the sidewalk outside, Floyd H. Flake, the Congressman and minister from Queens, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he had embezzled funds from a federally subsidized housing complex and cheated on his income taxes.

title: Net Up 2.1% At K Mart
description: The K Mart Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent despite lower prices, mainly because of growth in apparel and seasonal hardware sales.

title: Michael Is Named Yanks' General Manager
description: George Steinbrenner, in the last official baseball move of his controversial and unpredictable ownership of the Yankees, yesterday appointed Gene Michael as the team's general manager, replacing Harding (Pete) Peterson.

The latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $961,000 included pretax capital gain of $1 million and pretax charge of $330,000 related to vesting under the company's restricted stock bonus plan and the latest 6-month income from continuing operations of $1,234,000, or 14 cents a share, included pretax charge of $659,000 related to the stock bonus plan and the $1 million pretax capital gain recorded in the second quarter. Year-ago quarter's income from continuing operations of $1,442,000, or 17 cents a share, included pretax capital gain of $2.2 million and a pretax charge of $516,000 related to the stock bonus plan, and year-ago 6-month income from continuing operations of $2,992,000, or 35 cents a share, included pretax charge of $911,000 from the stock bonus plan and the $2.2 million pretax capital gain recorded in the year-ago second quarter.

title: Reviews/Music;   City Opera's 'Figaro' Gets a Mostly New Cast
description: The New York City Opera is taking a more sweeping approach to cast changes this season than it has in the past. Instead of replacing a few singers at a time, the company is presenting first and second casts as independent ensembles. On Sunday afternoon, the second cast of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' was to take over, and for the most part, it did.

description: Gov. Jim Florio won a test of wills with one of the nation's insurance giants last week, but the war over who will ultimately pay the bills for the state's $3 billion auto insurance fiasco is certain to be a long one.

title: New Method of Analyzing Health Data Stirs Debate
description: INCREASING use of a controversial statistical method to evaluate medical therapies and surgical procedures is beginning to affect profoundly the care of pregnant women and patients with cancer, heart disease and many other common conditions.

description: Searchers today found the bodies of two victims of a weekend collision between two light planes over Long Beach Harbor, officials said.

title: Critic's Notebook;   How Network Reporters Cover The Gulf, or at Least Some of It
description: Since the beginning of the confrontation between Iraq and the United States, network correspondents have been trying to break through interdictions on coverage by both sides. All the big guns have been deployed: Dan Rather and Ted Koppel in Baghdad; Tom Brokaw and Sam Donaldson in Saudi Arabia; others in Cairo, Riyadh, Amman, Damascus, Dubai, Ankara, Aqaba, Jerusalem and other points east, moving as close as they can to the action, or at least the activity.

description: A plainclothes police officer was wounded yesterday afternoon in Harlem when a man in a livery cab he had just stopped pulled a gun and shot him, the police said.

description: Israeli political and military leaders are saying that time is not on the side of the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis, and that it should act now.

title: Ex-Wife and Army Deserter Have a Reunion in Nebraska
description: An Army deserter who spent 30 years in East Germany and was arrested when he returned to the United States earlier this year was reunited Sunday with his former wife and their daughters.

title: Liberia Leader, Rejecting Truce Offer, Won't Quit
description: Negotiations for a settlement of the Liberian civil war made little headway today, amid indications that President Samuel K. Doe is unwilling to yield power in order to gain a cease-fire.

title: Oil Prices Ease a Bit After Climb
description: After rising for seven days, the price of oil closed slightly lower yesterday, the first trading session after the announcement by the Saudi oil minister that his country would pump an extra two million barrels a day, with or without OPEC approval. But the price of gasoline continued to rise sharply, and both markets remained nervous.

description: A frustrated and besieged Saddam Hussein now makes a liar of his Foreign Minister and affronts law and Islamic custom by interning ''foreign guests'' in Iraq and Kuwait. In fact, as President Bush said yesterday, thousands of innocent citizens are now hostages. Small wonder that some Americans respond viscerally, urging armed reprisals or even a declaration of war.

title: New Victims of the Realty Slump: Insurers
description: The insurance industry is starting to suffer from the slump in real estate that has already hurt many banks and savings and loan institutions. The delinquency rate on mortgages for office buildings, hotels, shopping malls and other commercial properties held by the nation's insurance companies has increased sharply in recent months, leading to predictions by some in the industry that foreclosures on these types of loans could double over the next three years.

title: Review/Music;   Contrasting Styles in a Heavy-Metal Battle of the Bands
description: Friday night's show at the Beacon Theater shaped up like a heavy-metal battle of the bands, with the headliner, Danzig, facing pressure from Soundgarden, the contender. The audience wore its tribe membership in the form of strict all-black dress with tattoos or band T-shirts proclaiming allegiance to favorites like the Cro-Mags or Slayer. It showed its critical displeasure by walking out during sets; in the end, Danzig won the battle simply because more people stayed to hear it.

title: Gay Men's Chorus Audition
description: The New York City Gay Men's Chorus will hold auditions for its 11th season on Sept. 11 and 12 at 7 P.M. The 150-voice company will present concerts at Carnegie Hall and Alice Tully Hall during the 1990-91 season. A prepared song is required, and applicants will undergo sight-reading and voice-placement tests. Nonsingers who wish to help with the day-to-day operations of the group may also apply. Information: 691-7590.

title: James A. Starr, Hollywood Columnist, 86
description: James A. Starr, who wrote one of the first Hollywood movie columns, died at his home here on Monday. He was 86 years old. His wife said he died in his sleep. Mr. Starr began his newspaper career in 1924, writing reviews, gossip and features for The Los Angeles Daily Record. He later moved to The Los Angeles Express, earning $150 a week, a large salary for the 1920's.

description: Interco Inc., a footwear and furniture maker, will ask its bondholders to exchange their bonds for 95 percent of the company's common stock and other considerations under a complicated plan announced today.

title: Mary S. Shorb, 83; Helped to Discover Vitamin B12 in 40's
description: Mary Shaw Shorb, a microbiologist whose research led to the discovery of vitamin B12 in 1947, died Saturday at Greater Laurel-Beltsville Hospital in Maryland.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Travel Is Discouraged To Jordan and Yemen
description: The State Department advised Americans today to defer nonessential travel to Jordan in view of the Iraqi military invasion of Kuwait and ''continuing unstable conditions in the region.''

title: People

title: Warriors Sign Two
description: The Golden State Warriors announced yesterday that Tom Tolbert, a restricted free agent, and Kevin Pritchard, a second-round draft pick, have signed contracts. Tolbert, a 6-8 forward, agreed to a four-year contract, while Pritchard, a 6-3 guard, reached a three-year agreement with the team. No other terms were released. Tolbert was the last player waived by the Warriors in their 1989 fall training camp. (AP)

title: American Colloid Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Imperial Chemical
description: Imperial Chemical Industries of Britain said it was setting up a wholly owned subsidiary in Poland, its first in Eastern Europe. Peter Schellinck, director of ICI Poland Ltd., said the new company would provide a base for the whole group to explore opportunities in Poland, especially for its agrochemicals and paints businesses.

title: Pirates Rout the Astros For 6th Victory in Row
description: Neal Heaton pitched six shutout innings for his first victory since June 24 and Gary Redus hit a two-run homer tonight as Pittsburgh beat the Houston Astros, 7-1. The victory was the Pirates' sixth in a row.

title: Are We Safe in Our Own Skins?
description: LEAD: When I was a medical student, I participated in the care of a 4-year-old boy with leukemia. His only hope of a cure was a bone marrow transplant. Of his relatives only his father, who was divorced from the boy's mother, was a potential donor. The father refused to be tested to see if he could be a donor.

Mating for Life? It's Not for the Birds of the Bees
description: AH, romance. Can any sight be as sweet as a pair of mallard ducks gliding gracefully across a pond, male by female, seemingly inseparable? Or better yet, two cygnet swans, which, as biologists have always told us, remain coupled for life, their necks and fates lovingly intertwined.

title: Pakistan Said to Have Fired on Indian Troops
description: Pakistani troops fired heavy artillery at Indian Army positions this morning in the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir, the Indian Defense Ministry announced.

description: A maverick former K.G.B. general said today that he had won the first round of an election to the Soviet Parliament.

description: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission surely means to do good on Manhattan's West Side - but so far its good intentions risk paralyzing the welcome development in the large area bounded by Central Park West and Amsterdam Avenue and 62d and 96th Streets.

title: Export Restrictions Fail to Halt Spread Of Supercomputers
description: The growing ease with which it is possible to design and build supercomputers is making it increasingly difficult for the United States and Japan to keep the powerful machines from proliferating. That raises the possibility that more nations may be able to use supercomputers to design advanced weapons systems.

The 38-year-old five- time United States Open champion was sidelined with a wrist injury in Milan on Feb. 6 that made questionable his appearance at this year's Open.

Merrill Officer Stepping Down
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that William W. Moore, the senior vice president in charge of its municipal markets group, would step down from his post at the start of next year.

title: Breast Cancer Drug May Benefit the Heart
description: TAMOXIFEN, a hormonal drug taken by thousands of women to help prevent recurrence of breast cancer, may also protect them against heart disease, according to a study reported in the current issue of the Journal of the National Cancer Institute. The two-year study, conducted among 140 women past menopause, showed that the medication helped reduce their blood levels of cholesterol and especially of harmful LDL cholesterol.

title: Delta Is Firm on New Planes
description: The chairman of Delta Air Lines said today that the carrier would not abandon any of the orders and options it had for new aircraft, despite indications that the airline industry was facing lower profits.

title: Chip Manufacturer May Close Plant
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation may close a computer chip plant and lay off as many as 2,000 employees in cost-cutting measures. The company is considering closing its chip manufacturing plant in Puyallup, Wash., industry sources said. The plant produces memory chips and logic semiconductors for supercomputers. The company declined to comment today.

title: Reviews/Music;   St. Luke's Group vs. the Elements
description: For the sake of valuable musical instruments, if for no other reason, it is high time this meteorologically misbegotten season of outdoor music comes to a close. By the end of the final concert of the Caramoor season in the Venetian Theater this evening, the instruments of the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble must have been thoroughly waterlogged. And just as well, for the players might otherwise have been tempted to use them as kindling against the cold.

title: Steinbrenner Steadfast In U.S. Olympic Role
description: Despite his departure from major league baseball after more than 17 1/2 years as principal owner of the Yankees, George Steinbrenner does not intend to resign as a vice president of the United States Olympic Committee, his spokesman said yesterday. His intention could put the U.S.O.C. executive committee in the uncomfortable position of recommending that he resign, after a meeting tomorrow in Colorado Springs.

title: Puzzle in Infant Mortality
description: For more than a decade researchers have said blacks have the nation's worst infant mortality rate because pregnant black women receive the poorest prenatal care. But a new study of other ethnic groups suggests that other factors may play a larger role than expected.

title: Bush's Warning to Iraq Spurs Gain by Dow
description: President Bush's warning yesterday that he would hold the Iraqi Government responsible for the safety of American hostages being held in Kuwait and Iraq helped give the stock market its first lift since Wednesday.

title: Review/Music;   Bernstein Leads His Annual Tanglewood Concert
description: Leonard Bernstein has long been the most intensely emotional, the most nakedly human of conductors. That means all his concerts are suffused with a power of personality that focuses attention on himself. In his youth, this insertion of personality could detract from the music; now, in his magisterial maturity - he turns 72 this Saturday - it usually augments the impact of his performances.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Citizens Being Moved Just Some of Those at Risk
description: The 47 Americans in Iraq and occupied Kuwait who have been picked up and transferred to unknown locations are among a far larger group of foreigners, numbering in the hundreds, taken from hotels and residences and apparently placed in strategic military and industrial installations.

title: Parochial Politics on Oil
description: America's unhealthy dependence on imported foreign oil stems mainly from President Reagan's belief that the best energy policy was no policy. But local politicians have made their own egregious contributions to the debacle without even the fig leaf of ideology. Just consider the performances of Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and the city fathers of Los Angeles, who among them are forcing the United States to import an extra 120,000 barrels of oil a day.

title: By Design;   Where Is Sir Walter Raleigh?
description: From Southampton to Saratoga Springs, summertime partygoers dressed for outdoor affairs have encountered an unexpected problem: a sea of mud under the tents. With all the wet weather, the grass at outdoor parties, especially near the bar and the buffet, can turn into ooze, transforming all those well-dressed swells into literal muckymucks.

description: A man who drove through a red light and struck another vehicle was convicted of murder today in the death of an 11-year-old girl killed in the crash. The police said Mr. Padula's car was traveling faster than 70 miles an hour when it struck a car in which Eleanor Hosley was riding on July 11, 1989, in Oneonta, about 50 miles east of Albany.

title: Miscellany
