description: * Peter Arnell, executive creative director of Arnell/Bickford Associates Marketing, New York, said the agency has added an estimated $24 million in new business since Aug. 1, raising its total billings to nearly $58 million. The largest of the 10 new accounts, all clothing or accessories business, is the worldwide advertising for the Italian company Byblos, for its men's and women's clothing and perfumes.

title: Dynatronics Laser Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $23,001 from an adjustment to compensate for over-credited tax loss carryforwards in previous quarters for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $21,800 for the year.

title: Ault Inc.  reports earnings for Year to May 27
description: b-Net income

title: Try International Law in Dealing With Iraq;   Bush's Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazilian Capital Blacked Out
description: Most of the capital, Brasilia, was without power today, and the Government said it suspected sabotage by striking electricity workers. Officials said four of the five transmission lines serving the area of 1.8 million people were out of action, trapping people in elevators and disrupting businesses. Brazilian electricity workers have been on strike for two weeks to press for a 200 percent pay increase.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In his new book on the Rolling Stones, A. E. HOTCHNER says that witnesses told him that BRIAN JONES was drowned by construction workers who were renovating his house in Hartfield, England. Mr. Jones, the guitarist and singer who formed the rock group, was pronounced dead after being taken unconscious from his swimming pool on July 2, 1969, at Cotchford Farm, once the home of the author A. A. MILNE.

title: Payola Trial Is Opening Today For Successful Record Promoter
description: In a case that has already generated enormous alarm in the $9-billion-a-year record-and-music industry and forced changes in its business methods, one of the most powerful and successful record promoters of the 1980's is going on trial here Tuesday in Federal court, charged with racketeering and providing payola.

title: Biomagnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a one-time expense of $1,058,000 related to the resolution of a dispute with a university medical center.

title: National Gas & Oil reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: Prior 12-month revenue figures were restated. Share earnings have been adjusted for 7-percent stock dividend paid in December 1989.

title: Vanderbilt Gold Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: To the Noisy And Possible Bitter End
description: A man from New York was talking to a man in the Middle West by telephone yesterday morning, and mentioned that a major news matter here was the status of George Steinbrenner, and whether a judge in Cleveland would issue a restraining order to allow the Yankees' managing partner to continue in that capacity. Otherwise, Steinbrenner, by order of the commissioner of baseball, Fay Vincent, was to relinquish by midnight last night the position he had held for the last 17 1/2 years.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   200,000 Kuwaitis Take Refuge in Other Gulf States
description: More than 100,000 Kuwaitis have taken refuge in Saudi Arabia and perhaps another 100,000 in other gulf nations, representing a third of the native population of the Iraqi-occupied nation, Kuwaiti and Saudi officials say.

title: $300 Million Sale Of Carr-Gottstein
description: An investment firm set up by a former partner in Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a prominent leveraged buyout firm, has acquired Alaska's largest food and drug wholesaler for $300 million. The acquisition is the first by Leonard Green & Partners, a private merchant bank set up to organize management buyouts. Along with members of management, it is purchasing the Anchorage-based Carr-Gottstein Inc. from L. J. Carr and B. J. Gottstein.

title: Europe Plane Deal By AMR Unit Seen
description: AMR Eagle Inc., the largest United States commuter air carrier and a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, will buy $1 billion worth of European-made aircraft in one of its largest purchases ever, sources said. The company refused to confirm or deny the reports by Reuters that AMR Eagle would buy 100 twin-engine turboprop planes from ATR, the French-Italian joint venture.

title: Try International Law in Dealing With Iraq;   Israel's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Chris Silva, Swimmer, 29
description: Chris Silva, a swimmer and a leading force in attracting blacks to American competitive swimming, was killed Sunday when the car he was driving crashed into a tree. He was 29 years old.

title: Cambridge Shopping reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ecologists Turn to Hardy's World View;   Humanity Off the Hook
description: To the Editor:

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From President's Remarks to V.F.W. on the Persian Gulf Crisis
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks today to the convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Jury Misconduct Charged in Case of Agent's Death
description: Lawyers for four men convicted of kidnapping and other crimes linked to the slaying of an American drug agent in Mexico challenged their convictions today, adding another strange chapter to a trial already complicated by unusual events.

title: Partner Limits Duties At Goldman, Sachs
description: Robert N. Downey, who over the last 11 years helped to make Goldman, Sachs & Company the leading municipal bond underwriting firm on Wall Street, will retire as a general partner on Nov. 30, John L. Weinberg, senior partner at Goldman, Sachs, announced yesterday.

title: Richard Strout, 'TRB' Columnist And Capital Reporter, Dies at 92
description: Richard L. Strout, the acerbic nonconformist who wrote the ''TRB From Washington'' political column in The New Republic for 40 years and was Washington correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor for more than 60 years, died Sunday at the Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. He was 92 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Talking Business with Lipsky of Salomon Brothers;   Help for Dollar Called Unlikely
description: The dollar has reached a new low against the German mark and it is close to touching its record low against the Swiss franc.

title: U.S. Bioscience reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Environmental Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Success of a Horse Vaccine in China Raises Hope in Fight Against AIDS
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, a viral epidemic was ravaging China's horse population. Many horses had fevers and lacked energy, and a number died. Other infected horses showed no symptoms, although they could transmit the disease by blood-to-blood contact and through sex.

title: Hall Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge from a reversal of net operating loss carryforward of $310,000.

title: Imprisoned Racist Admits to 2 Killings in '80
description: Ten years ago today, two young black men were gunned down as they jogged near a city park. An avowed racist, Joseph Paul Franklin, was convicted of the murders, and now, in a prison television interview, he had admitted his guilt.

title: We Can Afford to Fight Iraq
description: While the cost of Operation Desert Shield will be high, it's nothing the U.S. can't bear. And we can do this without placing a substantial additional burden on taxpayers and while still paring down the military. But it will require some creative thinking about deployments as well as financial contributions from our allies.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Information Services Corp., New York, a subsidiary of American Express Co., named Gary P. Tobin vice president of communications and public affairs.

title: Israeli Court Delays a Plan For V.O.A. Station in Desert
description: The Supreme Court of Israel issued a temporary injunction today against construction of a Voice of America relay station in a southern desert.

title: Linpro Specified Properties reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Panama Drug Smugglers Prosper As Dictator's Exit Opens the Door
description: When invading American troops deposed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega last December, many Panamanians and Americans hoped for a quick end to the cocaine smuggling that his Government reportedly tolerated and even promoted.

title: Hurco Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Phonetel Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARCO Keeps Price Freeze
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it would maintain its freeze on gasoline prices, but would raise its prices for diesel and jet fuel.

title: Trimedyne reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Our Towns;   For Mentally Ill, An Alternative To Adult Homes
description: President Bush's domestic experts love to say, ''You don't solve social problems by throwing money at them.'' But the social-service workers struggling to hold things together know the huge difference money can make. Care for the mentally ill at adult homes versus group homes is a prime example.

title: Analytical Surveys Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Export Rise Forecast
description: Regardless of the impact of events in the Middle East on the cost of oil, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher believes United States exports will continue to grow and keep the nation's economy out of recession this year.

title: Gooden Is Puzzled by Mound Woes
description: What's wrong with Dwight Gooden?

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Few From Left or Right Protest Bush's Big Stick
description: So far, the critics of American military involvement in Saudi Arabia have been few and relatively soft-spoken, pending further developments in the confrontation with Iraq, notably its duration.

title: Talks Aimed at Ending Salvador's Civil War Fail
description: Three days of talks between the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas here have failed to produce a cease-fire in their civil war.

title: U.S.-Russian Shoemaking Venture Set
description: In a major consumer goods venture with the Soviet Union, a Long Island company has a preliminary agreement to help Russians produce 50 million pairs of shoes over the next decade.

title: Ivanisevic Seeking To Shed Bad-Boy Image
description: Goran Ivanisevic, the tempestuous 18-year-old Yugoslav who most reminded Boris Becker of a young, ruthless Boris Becker just after defeating him in the first round of the French Open, has decided to exchange his temper for a top-10 ranking.

title: Dick Strout's Two Lives
description: In every sense, Richard L. Strout stood out in the innumerable press conferences he attended during his six decades as a Washington reporter. Nobody could miss this six-footer with a bemused expression and guardsman's mustache. Besides that, Mr. Strout, who died Sunday at the age of 92, was a singular figure who led a dual journalistic existence and came to occupy an unusual niche in the nation's capital.

title: Medicare Delays Predicted if Budget Impasse Causes Spending Cuts
description: Bush Administration officials said yesterday that automatic spending cuts that would result from failure to reach a budget agreement with Congress would mean a severe delay in Medicare payments to hospitals, doctors and the program's millions of elderly beneficiaries.

title: New Jersey Backs Plan For Trump
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission unanimously, if somewhat reluctantly, approved a bank loan package yesterday to help rescue Donald J. Trump's real estate and gambling empire.

title: John Fox; Writer, 38
description: John Fox, a novelist and short-story writer, died of AIDS on Aug. 14 at his home in Manhattan, a family spokesman said. He was 38 years old.

title: Civil Suit Against Secord Goes to the Jury
description: A Federal jury began deciding today whether Richard V. Secord, a leading figure in the Iran-contra affair, must pay compensation to the sole survivor of a 1986 airplane crash in Nicaragua and to the family of the plane's co-pilot.

title: Black Agent to Head Team Investigating F.B.I. for Bias
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, has named the agency's highest-ranking black field agent to investigate allegations that evidence of widespread racial discrimination within the bureau was covered up by white supervisors, F.B.I. officials said today.

title: India Sends Soldiers to the Pakistani Border
description: The Indian Army dispatched tanks and troop reinforcements today to the frontier with Pakistan, where soldiers from the two nations have been exchanging artillery fire for two days, officials and witnesses said.

title: Deere Profit Up 16.2%
description: Deere & Company said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 16.2 percent from the period last year as sales rose 7.9 percent. Deere said it earned $114.1 million, or $1.50 a share, in the three months ended July 31, compared with $98.2 million, or $1.30 a share, a year earlier. The company's fiscal year ends on Oct. 31. Revenue in the quarter rose to $2.05 billion, from $1.9 billion a year earlier. Deere fell $3.875, 25, to $52 .625, in trading today on the Big Board.

title: Incumbent Senator And Governor Win In Wyoming Voting
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson, an incumbent Republican, and Gov. Mike Sullivan, an incumbent Democrat, handily won their primary races today.

title: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Mixed
description: After declining for more than three months, yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were reported mixed in the week that ended yesterday.

title: Review/Theater;   Moss Hart's Valentine To the Craft He Adored
description: Moss Hart's love affair with the theater, so movingly chronicled in his memoir, ''Act One,'' did not blind him to the inequities of his profession. In the theater, a private or collaborative act of creativity is subjected to the capriciousness of actors, producers, audiences and, of course, critics.

title: Review/Music;   To the Beaux Arts Trio, Mozart Isn't Everything
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival has found modest ways to reinvent itself over the years. It has increasingly allowed its performers to stray into the early Romantic repertory, and occasionally beyond. It has offered early-instrument concerts, and in recent years it has increasingly brought in outside orchestras to alternate with its resident ensemble.

title: MORE EUROPEANS TO JOIN GULF FORCE
description: Anxious to demonstrate full support for American moves to isolate Iraq, Western European governments decided today to increase and coordinate their naval activities in the Persian Gulf and to reject Baghdad's demands that they close their embassies in Kuwait.

title: The Pop Life
description: Nevilles on the Record

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Oil Jolt

title: West African Force Sent to Liberia
description: Five West African nations began sending troops to Liberia today amid indications that negotiations for a cease-fire in the eight-month-long civil war were deadlocked, African diplomats said.

title: Policy Set on Giving Away Property Seized in Bailout
description: Federal regulators today approved what once might have seemed unthinkable -guidelines for giving away property the Government has seized from the wreckage of the savings industry.

title: Richard Little Purdy; Professor, 86
description: Richard Little Purdy, a retired professor of English at Yale University, died on Aug. 7 in a nursing home in Chatham Township, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Man Is Dead After Drinking Beverage Laced With Cocaine
description: A man who went into a coma after drinking a Colombian soft drink that had been laced with cocaine died Monday after doctors turned off his life support equipment.

title: The Revolt in New Jersey
description: After years of calm under Gov. Thomas Kean, New Jersey suddenly seethes with revolt. It was prompted by his successor, Jim Florio, with a bold but highly complex package of stiff new taxes. Widespread resistance demonstrates that Mr. Florio has so far failed to convince New Jerseyans that the new taxes are necessary.

title: Official Denies Interference in Agent Orange Study
description: A top Federal health officer today denied a Congressional charge that the Reagan White House had interfered with a study of the chemical Agent Orange's effects on soldiers in Vietnam.

title: Douglas Defense: A Financial Outlook
description: Is the title defense of James (Buster) Douglas against Evander Holyfield on Oct. 25 destined to be a financial flop?

title: Pakistan Plans to Try Hijackers Of Soviet Jet, but Moscow Differs
description: Eleven convicts from a Siberian labor camp who hijacked a Soviet jetliner to Pakistan and requested political asylum will go on trial here, Pakistani television said today. But the Soviet press agency Tass reported that the hijackers would be extradited to the Soviet Union. There was no explanation for the differing reports.

title: Boris Shragin, a Writer On Russians, Dies at 63
description: Boris Shragin, a Soviet human-rights advocate and writer, died on Aug. 15 in La Guardia Hospital in Queens. He was 63 years old and lived in Queens. He died of lung cancer, his wife, Natalia Sadomskaya, said.

title: Keep Hanford's Radiation Risk in Perspective;   Dangers Exaggerated
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film;   A Rebellious Teen-Ager Takes to the Airwaves
description: ''Pump Up the Volume'' asks the question: what's a poor younger generation to do when the traditional modes of teen-age rebellion -sex, drugs and radical politics - have already been used up by its elders? A fanciful, romantic solution, proposed by the film's writer and director, Allan Moyle, is that the MTV generation abandon the tube to heed the mysterious call of nighttime radio.

title: Review/Music;   The Philharmonic and Its New High-Tech Shell
description: Given the cold, blustery, intermittently rainy evening, Monday's final free summer parks concert by the New York Philharmonic in Central Park turned out to be more ceremonial and technical than musical. But what music there was sounded nice enough, in two senses of the word ''sound.''

title: Washington Considers a Clear Iraqi Defeat To Be Necessary to Bolster Its Arab Allies
description: Iraq called today for negotiations on ending the Persian Gulf crisis, but did not offer to pull its troops out of Kuwait. The White House quickly responded that no talks were possible until Iraq unconditionally carried out the United Nations demand that it withdraw its forces from Kuwait.

title: T.W.A. Increasing Domestic Fares
description: Trans World Airlines joined other carriers and said that it would increase domestic fares by 5.3 percent to offset higher fuel costs.

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge Over Crisis in Mideast
description: The Tokyo stock market plummeted today in reaction to the continued tensions in the Middle East and the tumbling prices on Wall Street.

title: Woman Dies After She Is Hit By Car Driven by 11-Year-Old
description: A 58-year-old Stamford woman died on Monday after being struck and pinned under a car driven by an 11-year-old girl, the police said.

title: State Dept. Contract Gives Wang a Boost
description: In its most positive news in more than two years, Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that the State Department had awarded the company a five-year, $841.3 million contract to supply and service a range of desk-top and midrange computers.

title: College Football In Transition;   Familiar Sort of Scrutiny For New TV Deal
description: When the five members of the Federal Trade Commission return from recess after Labor Day, they may have on their minds a subject dear to many at this time of year both inside and outside the Washington Beltway: college football on television.

title: U.S. TO CALL 40,000 RESERVES TO SUPPORT SAUDI TROOPLIFT; REJECTS IRAQI OFFER TO TALK
description: To fill gaps in the United States military buildup in the Persian Gulf region, President Bush on Wednesday is expected to order a mobilization of reserves that will initially place about 40,000 Americans on active duty, Administration officials said today.

title: Keep Hanford's Radiation Risk in Perspective;   Cover-Up at Chernobyl
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Junk Bonds' Post Sharp Price Decline
description: Prices of some high-yield ''junk bonds'' fell sharply yesterday as investors reacted to the uncertainty in the Mideast and to concerns about a possible recession. Some mutual fund portfolio managers sold these speculative bonds to meet an increase in redemptions by nervous individual investors, traders said.

title: Oil and Gas Prices Rise Slightly
description: Prices for oil and gasoline rose slightly yesterday after swinging sharply during the day. They surged early in the day but then fell back after a statement by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that traders said was less aggressive than expected.

title: Economic Scene;   Baby Boomers' Free Lunch?
description: EVERYONE knows that America's rapidly aging baby boomers are burning the candle at both ends, consuming when they should be saving for retirement. Everyone also knows the boomers are depending on the rapid accumulation of cash in the Social Security trust fund to save their bacon.

title: Estimate Board Approves Audubon Ballroom Plan
description: As New York City's Board of Estimate continued its fade into oblivion early this morning, it approved the creation of a biomedical research center on the site of the Audubon Ballroom in Washington Heights and, early yesterday, a plan by the developer Peter S. Kalikow to demolish part of a tenement complex designated a landmark.

title: Challenge To Microsoft Advancing
description: The effort to challenge the domination of the Microsoft Corporation's software that allows desktop computers to operate popular programs like word processors and spreadsheets gained momentum yesterday as three companies agreed on a single standard for the rival Unix software.

title: Tillicum Journal;   This Music Is Intended To Make Youths Walk
description: A cluster of noisy teen-agers clad in Bart Simpson T-shirts, the uniform of the moment, gathered in the convenience store parking lot to show off their modified Mohawk haircuts and just hang out on a hot August night.

title: An Appeal From Mubarak
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt made an emotional appeal today to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his occupying troops from Kuwait.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LETTER from our friend, the fearless gourmet:

title: Suspense Over Giants' Holdouts Continues
description: Bill Parcells is either convinced that one of his four defensive holdouts will not play this season or the coach of the Giants is making an attempt to put pressure on someone through the news media.

title: New York Violates Welfare Ban
description: New York City welfare officials continue to place homeless families in unauthorized welfare hotels despite a court order prohibiting their placement in any but three designated welfare hotels, city officials and advocates for the homeless said last night.

title: Market Place;   2 Companies Gain In Mideast Woes
description: IT is an old tradition on Wall Street that even an ill wind can whip up a nice profit for someone.

title: Harry Adelberg; Lawyer, 84
description: Harry Adelberg, founder of the law firm of Adelberg, Rudow, Dorf, Hendler & Sameth in Baltimore, died Sunday at his home in Baltimore. He was 84 years old.

title: Review/Television;   Race Relations and Violence's Aftermath
description: The crimes, conflicts and assorted calamities that populate each evening's local news shows give the same kick as prime-time dramas. The pictures of shaken victims, filled bodybags, grieving relatives, handcuffed suspects, the agitated reporting, the little jolts of excitement and of pathos are plainly aimed at viewers' emotions. The people who put together the 5 and 6 P.M. vaudevilles are not ill-intentioned; edifying tributes to tolerance and plugs for pleasanter aspects of city life are common. But the pro forma pieties of the anchors are no match for the nightly spirit of mayhem.

title: INSIDE
description: Inquiry on F.B.I. Bias

title: A Major Revival in Research on Vaccines
description: New strategies for developing the next generation of vaccines are resurrecting investment in a medical field that has been in the doldrums for years.

title: 41 Charged in Mob Case Based on Informer
description: Forty-one people, including members of six organized-crime families and two of their bosses, were charged with racketeering today on the basis of almost 400 conversations secretly recorded by one informer.

title: Egyptians Tell of Iraqi Rule in Kuwait
description: Every day thousands of Egyptian workers fleeing Kuwait are pouring through this tiny port city tired, dirty, thirsty and broke - but most of all angry.

title: Bush Regains Record Rating in Crisis
description: The Persian Gulf crisis has propelled public approval of President Bush back to its highest level, with support for his stand against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait overwhelming misgivings about his handling of domestic problems, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: European Bank Plan
description: The European Community's executive body today endorsed a blueprint for forming tighter economic and monetary links that would include an American-style central bank in 1993. It would also lead to creation of a single currency to be used throughout the dozen nations of the trading bloc. The plan was offered to guide the nations at a special conference opening in December to make any needed changes in their founding Treaty of Rome to forge an economic and monetary union.

title: Dempsey Suspended
description: Rick Dempsey, the Los Angeles Dodger catcher, was suspended for one game by the National League yesterday and was fined an undisclosed amount for fighting. Dempsey and Len Dykstra of the Philadelphia Phillies were ejected in the seventh inning of Monday's game in Los Angeles.(AP)

title: Dozens Are Injured In Further Outbreak Of Rikers I. Unrest
description: At least 50 prison inmates and 30 guards were injured last night in a melee at the Correctional Institution for Men on Rikers Island after prisoners barricaded themselves inside a dormitory and set fires, a prison spokeswoman said.

title: Extension of Offer For Kansas Gas
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said it had extended its $857 million tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric Company stock until Sept. 14, saying that about 43 percent of Kansas Gas shares had been tendered. Kansas City Power said that about 13.7 million of the 31.7 million outstanding shares of Kansas Gas had been tendered as of the previous deadline of midnight Monday.

title: Astros Stop Pirates' Streak at Six
description: Danny Darwin won his eighth game in a row and Eric Yelding singled to break an eighth-inning tie as the Houston Astros ended the Pittsburgh Pirates' winning streak at six games tonight with a 2-1 victory.

title: Prices of U.S. Securities Lower
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as dealers used movements in oil prices as their major indicator to buy or sell securities.

title: Leo Dana Dies at 94; Aide at Union Carbide
description: Dr. Leo I. Dana, a former Union Carbide research executive who specialized in low-temperature physics, died on Thursday in Canton, Ohio, at the age of 94.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm out of here, dude. They want to listen to that stuff, they can have it.''

title: In Kuwait, Quiet but for Troops
description: Kuwait City was described in a Washington Post article today as quiet, with Iraqi troops advancing toward the border with Saudi Arabia past hundreds of empty houses, ruined royal palaces and smoldering trash fires in vacant lots.

title: Keep Hanford's Radiation Risk in Perspective;   Hazardous Uranium
description: To the Editor:

title: Armenian Parliament Weighs Independence
description: Armenia's parliament debated a declaration of independence today and considered setting up its own army for protection from neighboring Azerbaijan, the Soviet new outlets reported.

title: A Day Short of Death, a Georgia Killer Is Given Life
description: Just a day before a 39-year-old convict was to die in the electric chair, the Supreme Court granted a stay of execution today, and hours later the Georgia Board of Pardons and Paroles granted clemency and commuted the man's sentence to life imprisonment.

title: Real Estate;   Building Plan In Detroit Starts Debate
description: COMERICA INC., one of Detroit's largest banks, has won approval for a controversial plan to tear down a riverfront auditorium that was donated by the Ford family to the city and put a new corporate headquarters on the site.

title: Robert W. Trombino; Parks Official, 39
description: Robert W. Trombino, chief of stadium and marina operations for the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, died on Sunday at his home in East Elmhurst, Queens. He was 39 years old.

title: Bucharest Journal;   In a Dispirited Land, a Dash of Initiative and Verve
description: In the dark, dreary terrain of Romania's impoverished economy, Anda Baldau, a secretary turned shopowner, and Petru Rares, a Western-educated economist turned technocrat, are two bright spots.

title: 52 Rich Hong Kong Investors To Be East German Citizens
description: Fifty-two rich Hong Kong executives will pay $960,000 each and invest nearly $10 billion more in return for East German citizenship, the East German Government said today.

title: Notre Dame Accused
description: Steve Huffman, a former lineman for Notre Dame who quit the team during preseason practice in 1987, has charged there was widespread steroid use on the football team and that Coach Lou Holtz ''had to have known'' about it.

title: For Centuries, Hostages Have Been Used, and Misused, During Wartime
description: United States officials have been dogged politically by the problems of freeing Americans held hostage abroad since even before George Washington took the oath of office as President.

title: A Base With No Name: U.S. Puts It on the Map
description: The following report was filed under the ground rules that govern American correspondents accredited to the Pentagon who are working in Saudi Arabia. The ground rules prohibit the reporting of exact numbers of troops or weapons, their exact locations or the names of enlisted personnel.

title: Cereal Makers Settle Lawsuit
description: The Kellogg Company, the world's largest maker of breakfast cereal, and Nabisco Brands Inc., the large biscuit and cereal maker, said yesterday that they had settled Kellogg's lawsuit over shredded wheat out of court.

title: This Time, Will We Learn Our Lesson on Oil?
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI Plans Digital Shift Next Year
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to deploy an all-digital long-distance network by the end of next year, and might take a charge of $500 million to $550 million against this quarter's earnings to cover the cost of retiring older network equipment.

title: Keep Hanford's Radiation Risk in Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Booby Trap Death Brings Fine
description: In a bargain with prosecutors, a 46-year-old Denver man today pleaded guilty to manslaughter for rigging a shotgun booby trap that killed a young man who had broken into his machine tool shop. He was placed on six years' probation and ordered to pay $9,500 in fines and restitution.

title: THATCHER OPPOSES DEAL ON HOSTAGES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that Britain would not negotiate over the thousands of Western nationals trapped in Iraq and Kuwait and that she was considering sending more forces to the Persian Gulf.

title: Envoys at U.N. Say Soviets Block Endorsement of Force Against Iraq
description: Soviet objections have so far been the main cause of the United States' inability to win Security Council backing for the use of force to uphold the embargo of Iraq, diplomats here say.

title: Target of Paper's Barbs Resigns at Dartmouth
description: A Dartmouth College music professor who frequently clashed with a student newspaper has resigned, putting an end to one of the college's most painful public quarrels.

title: Gerard A. Fulham, 70; Led Holding Company
description: Gerard A. Fulham, former chairman of the Pneumo Corporation, a concern with holdings in the aerospace and military industries and food and drug distribution, died Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 70 years old and lived in Oyster Harbors, Mass.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cluett, Peabody & Co., New York, a manufacturer of men's and women's apparel and a subsidiary of Bidermann Industries Corp., appointed Robert E. Briefel president of its hosiery group. The company also announced the retirement of William Droeger as president of its Gold Toe hosiery division.

title: Brooklyn Girl, 3, Is Struck by a Stray Bullet
description: A 3-year-old girl was shot and critically wounded last night on a street in the East New York section of Brooklyn when she was caught in the cross-fire of two feuding groups of youths, the police said.

title: Japan Trade Group Fills Top Post in New York
description: The Japan External Trade Organization has named Tetsuo Matsufuji president of its New York office. Jetro is one of the leading Japanese Government agencies that promote trade relations between Japan and other countries.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;

Belfast, Me.
description: LEAD: IF you're traveling along the coast of Maine this summer, leave room after the lobster for a scoop of handmade chocolate chip butter crunch ice cream or a tiger paw caramel, pecan and chocolate from Cranberry Tiger, an offbeat little shop up the hill from Belfast Harbor, about five doors down from the only stoplight in Waldo

title: In a Surprise Move, Hess's Chief Retires
description: In a move that surprised the industry, Irwin Greenberg has retired as president and chief executive of Hess's Department Stores. He spent 14 years as president of the chain and also served as chief executive for the last five.

title: Nazis Didn't Figure in Plot to Kill Hitler
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Experts frequently ask themselves this question during the play: ''Why didn't so-and-so do such-and-such?'' The answer can be illuminating, and was on the diagramed deal for Sidney Lazard of New Orleans, who has been one of America's most formidable performers for four decades.

title: Yanks Add To Streak As Cary Triumphs
description: Chuck Cary, who did not win any of his last 10 starts of the George Steinbrenner regime, won last night in the first game the Yankees played without Steinbrenner in command. There was, however, no cause and effect.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Chronicle
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH II dusted off a rare honor and gave it to her baby sister yesterday. The Queen invested PRINCESS MARGARET with the Insignia of the Royal Victorian Chain, as a personal honor on her 60th birthday. ELIZABETH, THE QUEEN MOTHER, is the only other member of the royal family to have received the insignia.

title: Jets Report No Progress With 3 Unsigned Players
description: The Jets announced no progress with their three unsigned players yesterday but they did cut a corner in an effort to get down to next Tuesday's 60-man roster limit.

title: Her Outing Is Brief but Historic
description: The first female starting pitcher in a Little League World Series game lasted just three batters today, but a teammate came to the rescue with six innings of relief and pitched Trail, British Columbia, to an 8-3 victory over Matamoros, Mexico.

title: Irving X. Fabrikant; Diamond Importer, 86
description: Irving X. Fabrikant, the president of M. Fabrikant & Sons, a leading diamond importing and manufacturing concern, from 1930 to 1980, died on Saturday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Slaves to Oil
description: We are all hostages now, and by our own consent. It is our addiction to imported oil that has undone us. ''Just say no,'' Nancy Reagan used to advise the young tempted by drugs. Neither her husband nor anyone else of public consequence dared issue the same good advice to a vast public of all ages that was hopelessly hooked on oil.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a medical, agricultural and consumer products company, said its board had approved the repurchase of 10 million to 12 million shares of its common stock.

title: Little Change In Phone Rates
description: Prices for long-distance telephone service, which have plunged more than 40 percent since the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984, may not decline much more, according to a study by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Soviets Urge Iraq to Aid Trapped Foreigners
description: The Soviet Union urged a senior Iraqi envoy today to provide guarantees for all foreigners remaining in Iraq and Kuwait and ease evacuation of Soviet citizens from the Persian Gulf region.

title: Hartford, Its Boom Over, Sees Downtown Decaying
description: The hundreds of millions of dollars that poured into Hartford in the 1980's changed the skyline and tripled the amount of office space downtown, but the makeover appears now to have only masked a continuing decline in the heart of Connecticut's capital.

title: Boeing Gets Order From the Japanese
description: The All Nippon Airways Company of Japan has ordered 17 more Boeing 747-400's in a deal valued at $3.5 billion, including parts and related equipment, the Boeing Company said on Monday. Delivery of the aircraft, the world's largest passenger jetliners, is scheduled to begin in 1995.

title: Town's Cancer Rate Is Termed Not Unusual
description: State officials say they have definitively ruled out a higher than usual rate of cancer in this town, despite fears that an electric substation has caused illness along one street.

title: Keep Hanford's Radiation Risk in Perspective;   'Still Classified'
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Honored With Fields Medal in Mathematics
description: Fields Medals, the most prestigious international awards in mathematics, were bestowed yesterday upon two mathematicians from the United States and one each from Japan and the Soviet Union.

title: The President and the Hasty Hawks
description: A cynical theory making the rounds in Washington holds that Americans will soon tire of President Bush's intervention in the Persian Gulf. Therefore, the theory goes, Mr. Bush should quickly exploit his high standing at home and abroad by undertaking, in Henry Kissinger's words, the ''surgical and progressive destruction of Iraq's military assets.'' Yet there's no evidence that Americans are as fickle as the Hasty Hawks contend.

title: Franklin and Seiko Distribution Deal
description: Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc. announced that it would sell electronic reference products in Japan under a distribution agreement with Seiko Instruments Inc. The publishing company, based in Mount Holly, will export electronic speaking dictionaries intended for students of English as a foreign language. The products use speech synthesis to pronounce American English words.

title: U.S. and Mexico Take On a Joint Burden: Sewage
description: When the Tijuana River ripples down the hillside from Mexico into the United States, it brings each day millions of gallons of raw sewage, a thick black stream that meanders, bubbling and stinking, past stables and farmland to empty into the ocean off San Diego.

title: Magellan Radio Link To Earth Lost Again
description: Engineers lost radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft tonight for the second time in five days, the national Aeronautics and Space Administration said late tonight.

title: $501 Million Issue From Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, priced $501 million in floating-rate and inverse floating-rate funding note pass-through certificates yesterday in a sale managed by Lehman Brothers.

title: For Gay Travelers, More Places to Go
description: ON a blistering August day the lounge chairs around the swimming pool at the Rainbow Mountain Resort here are overflowing with bare arms and legs. The smell of coconut oil and the sounds of ''I Got You Babe'' fill the air. Everything about this middle-class enclave seems typical of life in a Pocono Mountain resort except for one thing: nearly all the guests are gay.

title: Taking A Loftier View of the Timberland
description: Until recently, forest products companies surveyed timberland by sending workers out in pickup trucks to study the land acre by acre. But now, pinpointing the age, firmness and species of trees is accomplished much more quickly and more precisely from a much higher vantage point. Under technology developed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the International Paper Company surveys its forests using infrared photos taken by satellite.

title: Review/Pop;   Intelligent Rap With a Message
description: ''How many intelligent people are in the house?'' K. R. S.-One, the rapper who leads Boogie Down Productions, asked a packed house on Monday night at S.O.B.'s. When not enough hands went up. he asked it again. K. R. S.-One, otherwise known as Kris Parker, wants to use rap, as he said onstage, to ''defend the side of the light, the side of truth and justice.''

title: Scientists Back Smaller, Simpler Satellites for Monitoring Climate
description: A panel of experts told the White House today that smaller, simpler satellites that can monitor the Earth's climate should soon take priority over the huge Earth Observing System, an elaborate $30 billion array of six large satellites the space agency plans to place in orbit starting in 1997 or 1998.

title: Mets Miss Opportunity to Close In on Pirates
description: On a night when the Pittsburgh Pirates finally lost a game, the Mets lost even more: They lost their poise, they lost their chance and they lost their own game here when they were zapped by Ed Whitson and the San Diego Padres, 7-0.

title: WINE TALK
description: SONOMA-CUTRER, Jordan and Robert Mondavi. Familiar names? If you eat out and if you drink wine when you do, they should be. According to a survey by Wine and Spirits magazine, a trade publication, they are the wines American diners order most: as Wine and Spirits put it, ''the most popular wines in the most popular restaurants.''

title: Little Progress Is Seen In Signing of Coleman
description: The Nets have not made significant progress toward signing Derrick Coleman, the No. 1 pick in this year's National Basketball Association draft. Coleman's attorney, Harry MacDonald, was disappointed with the outcome of a three-hour meeting with the Nets' front office last week. Coleman is seeking a five- or six-year contract that would make him the league's highest-paid rookie. According to MacDonald, the Nets' latest offer was far less than the contract given to Sam Perkins, the former Maverick forward who signed a six-year, $19 million contract with the Los Angeles Lakers last week.

title: Fears of Mideast Conflict Push the Dow Down 52.48 Points
description: Stocks gyrated wildly yesterday in heavy trading amid fears of war in the Middle East, with the New York Stock Exchange intervening three times to keep the price decline from feeding on itself.

title: Circle K Is Closing Unprofitable Units
description: The Circle K Corporation has begun closing 201 unprofitable stores and will complete the job by the end of the month, Ray Cox, a company spokesman, said.

title: How the U.S. Can Vote in Haiti
description: The story seems grimly familiar. A provisional Government in Haiti is stumbling toward elections. Violent incidents blaze up with increasing frequency as the election nears, creating an atmosphere of fear. Washington is betting on the armed forces to insure the security of the voting. But there seems little will to curb the violence either by the Government, the police or the military.

title: Excerpts From Iraqi Chief's Note and Iraqi Official's Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from an ''open letter'' from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to President Bush yesterday, as transmitted by the official Iraqi News Agency and translated from the Arabic by Reuters, and excerpts from a news conference yesterday by the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, in Amman, Jordan, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network:

title: Census May Cut Congress Seats For New Jersey and Connecticut
description: The first rough numbers from the 1990 census are out, and they indicate that even though Connecticut and New Jersey gained population in the last decade, both could lose seats when the House of Representatives is reapportioned.

title: OREGON CONSIDERS TAX CREDITS TO AID PRIVATE SCHOOLING
description: In the most ambitious plan yet to give parents a choice of schools for their children, an Oregon proposal would grant tax credits to cover tuition for private school or expenses for educating a child at home.

title: Change Starts to Sink In For Yanks
description: On the first day of the rest of the Yankees' life without George Steinbrenner, Stump Merrill said that things would be different.

title: East Germans Seek October Unity Date
description: Trying to end a dispute over the timetable for German unity, the East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, said today that a majority of the parties in East Germany's Parliament had agreed on Oct. 14 as the date for formal merger with West Germany.

title: WILD HORSE PLAN IS CALLED COSTLY
description: A Government program offering wild horses for adoption is becoming increasingly costly, with no evidence that Federal rangeland has benefited, a Congressional study has said.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE been amazed by the variety of fresh salmon in markets around the country, each with its own texture and flavor. Once you get to know them, you can bring out their best qualities.

title: Albert Whitaker, 82, Secret Service Official
description: Albert E. Whitaker, a retired special agent of the Secret Service who was in charge of the New York district for many years, died on Monday in Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Wantaugh, L.I.

title: Venezuela Debt Accord
description: Venezuela's public foreign debt will be lowered by more than 20 percent under an agreement reached with creditor banks, Venezuelan officials announced today. The deal covers $20.5 billion of the nation's $26 billion of public-sector debt. The country owes about $35 billion in public- and private-sector debt. Initial agreement on the debt-reduction and reorganization plan was reached between Venezuela and its commercial bankers in March. Since then the final details were worked out and banks with loans to Venezuela chose among the debt-reduction and new-loan options in the proposal. The most popular debt-cuttting options were the exchange of Venezuelan debt for low-interest 30-year United States-guaranteed bonds and the lending of fresh funds to Venezuela.

title: Miscellany
description: * Advertising pages for the magazines monitored by the Publishers Information Bureau were down by 5.8 percent last month, compared with the corresponding period last year. Ad pages for January to July fell by 3.6 percent, compared with the 1989 period. But because of large rate increases, revenues for the first seven months of the year were up by 1.6 percent from the period last year.

title: I Am Not an Anti-Semite
description: LEAD: Because of Moe and Josh Flatbush, the mislabeled ''villainous'' owners of the jazz club in ''Mo' Better Blues'' who occupy less than 10 minutes of screen time in the film, some critics are suggesting that I am engaging in anti-Semitism. One even insinuated that in my relatively small body of work there is some pattern of bigoted representation of Jewish people.

title: Gerald F. Stevens, 52, Connecticut Legislator
description: Gerald F. Stevens, a lawyer, former Connecticut legislator and a 1978 Republican candidate for governor of Connecticut, died on Monday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 52 years old and lived in Milford, Conn.

title: In the Wine Country of Long Island, a Rising Star: Merlot
description: Long Island merlot may not be as familiar as California cabernet, but recent vintages of these lush, smooth, fruity wines are gaining a fine reputation.

title: Philadelphia Mayor Seeks Taxes to Avoid Deficit
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode says Philadelphia is not bankrupt and can avoid a $206.4 million deficit if the state and City Council work with him to raise taxes and cut spending.

title: Chronicle
description: CAROLYN SKELLY was robbed of more than $1 million in jewelry over the weekend, the sixth time she has been robbed. Rings, necklaces and a diamond bracelet were stolen from her jewelry box 15 feet from where she slept early Saturday night in her mansion in Newport, R.I.

title: Studies Dispute View of Dyslexia, Finding Girls as Afflicted as Boys
description: Despite a widespread belief to the contrary, girls are just as likely as boys to have the reading impairment dyslexia, three studies say.

title: Iraq Proposes Peace Talks, Then Lashes Out at the U.S.
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sent his Foreign Minister here to propose peace talks with the United States today, then delivered another slashing attack on President Bush.

title: Tired of Eating Out? Send for Your Chef.
description: LEAD: TWO incompatible types emerged from the 1980's: the couch potato and the insatiable restaurantgoer. But by the dawn of the 90's, a few fortunate people were finding a way to reconcile their interests in staying at home and their desire to enjoy good food: hire a chef.

title: A Kinder, Gentler Stadium?
description: George Steinbrenner has been kicked out of Yankee Stadium, but he does not seem to know it. The question is: does everybody else?

title: Chip Maker Plans Layoff; 2,000 to Go
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, still in search of sustainable profitability, said today that it would reduce its work force by 2,000 people, shut two production operations and take a $140 million charge against earnings in the quarter that ends on Sunday.

title:
EDUCATION;

Experiment Pioneered the School Choice Concept
description: LEAD: Next month three states will join Minnesota in allowing parents to transfer their children freely to other school districts, taking state funds with them, and Wisconsin will begin a program to give low-income Milwaukee students state dollars for attending private, nonsectarian schools.

title: Group Home Offers Mentally Ill Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Moscow Playing Cute on Kuwait?
description: LEAD: Before we in the West canonize the Soviet Union for its condemnation of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, its arms embargo and its willingness to join a United Nations-endorsed naval blockade of Iraq, we might consider a simple fact: The Soviet Union almost certainly knew ahead of time that the Iraqis would invade

title: Jazz Group to Open Miller Theater Season
description: The New York debut of the Richard Tee Committee, a jazz ensemble, will open the season at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater, Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street, on Sept. 22. The group features Mr. Tee, a pianist; Steve Gadd, a drummer; Lenny Pickett, a saxophonist; Will Lee, a bassist; John Tropea, a guitarist, and Ralph MacDonald, a percussionist.

title: Panel Issues Broad Attack On U.S. Response to AIDS
description: In the strongest language it has used so far, the top Federal advisory panel on AIDS issued a three-part report today assailing the Government's drug testing programs, the nation's rural health care system and the ''shocking number'' of medical professionals it said were unwilling to treat people infected with the virus.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Climb 4.1% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest for the month ended Aug. 15 increased by 26.37 million shares, or 4.1 percent, to a record 668.96 million shares.

title: Whom Trump Likes (Himself) and Hates (Many) Floyd Norris
description: Trump

title: Critic's Notebook;   Berlin's Museum Intrigue Goes Public
description: In the international museum world, there is at this moment no hotter seat than the one occupied by Dr. Wolf-Dieter Dube, who has been director general of the West Berlin Museums since 1983. In a matter not of months but of weeks, he and his colleagues in both West and East Berlin have to agree on a master plan for the unification of the Berlin museums. Museologically, the city is to be turned into an epic game board. On that board, ideally, there would be only winners.

title: Producer Demands A Free Hand to Cast 'Miss Saigon' Roles
description: Even though he has finally won approval for the British actor Jonathan Pryce to repeat his role as a Eurasian pimp in ''Miss Saigon,'' Cameron Mackintosh said yesterday that Actors' Equity would have to give him a free hand on other casting decisions before he would bring his hit London musical to Broadway.

title: Souter Approval Urged By Conservative Groups
description: The preliminary jousting over President Bush's nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court continued today, with a conservative coalition calling for quick and unanimous confirmation.

title: EATING WELL
description: IN a recent rerun of ''Thirtysomething,'' Melissa, a main character, suggested that a friend use margarine rather than butter because it was ''less caloric.'' The fact is, margarine and butter have the same number of calories, and a study released since the program was rerun has cast doubt on margarine's role in reducing cholesterol. But in that scene a common nutrition myth was reinforced for millions of television viewers.

title: Pakistanis Race to Save Indus Valley Ruins
description: The Pakistani Government, racing against time to save the Indus Valley ruins of Mohenjo-Daro, the site of one of the world's oldest but most mysterious civilizations, is planning an international appeal for help.

title: Frank Viola, 78, Dies; Was Bronx Postmaster
description: Frank J. Viola, a former Postmaster of Bronx County, died yesterday at his home in New Fairfeld, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: First Images of Venus Are Better Than Hoped
description: Space agency engineers said today that initial images of the ruptured surface of Venus sent by the Magellan space probe were better than expected and that the craft appeared to be functioning normally again after last week's surprising radio blackout.

title: Mitchell R. Cutler; Book Dealer, 39
description: Mitchell R. Cutler, a dealer in rare art books, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Life's Work Stolen: A Professor Tries to Cope
description: It was, after all, just another break-in, like so many others that have made an industry of removable car radios. And it certainly does not rank with the acts of mindless violence that have sent shudders through New York City in recent months.

title: Raiders Not About to Move
description: An official of the Los Angeles Raiders says they will be staying put this year.

title: KEY RATES
With Embargo, Cheaper Tea
description: The price of tea has been hit by the Persian Gulf crisis. The United Nations trade embargo against tea-drinking Iraq has helped push it down to two-year lows.

title: Embargo Turns Aqaba Into Port of Little Import
description: The trim little port here, Jordan's only outlet to the sea and historically an important site for Iraq, was virtually at a standstill today as a result of United Nations sanctions and a United States naval blockade.

title: John Stalnaker, Ex-Administrator Of Merit Scholarships, Dies at 87
description: John M. Stalnaker, a psychologist, educator and former president of the corporation that selects high school students as National Merit Scholars, died Sunday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Twitterpated Lice?
description: No, birds don't do it. Neither do bees. Nor educated fleas. Fall in love, that is. According to this week's Science Times section, falling in lust is more like it. Mammals, all but a few species, are a faithless bunch; and bird behavior is a scandal. Thirty percent of those cute little eggs that Papa Bird is guarding so zealously are really some other fly-by-night's responsibility.

title: Second Thoughts
description: Elden Campbell, a 6-foot-11-inch former Clemson star who was the Los Angeles Lakers' first-round draft choice in June, spent last week in Europe, practicing with an Italian team and spawning rumors that he would spurn the Lakers and join the Italian League. Yesterday, Campbell cashed in on the rumors. He signed a multiyear contract with the Lakers. Terms were not disclosed.(AP)

title: Efficient ARCO Gains From Its Price Freeze
description: At an ARCO station on a busy corner in suburban Torrance, Calif., drivers are lining up this week to buy regular unleaded gasoline for $1.13 a gallon - 8 cents less than at the Exxon station across the street. Throughout the West, people have been flocking to other ARCO stations to buy gasoline at prices 4 to 12 cents below those of competing stations.

title: Viktor Tsoi, Singer And Songwriter, 28; Star of Soviet Rock
description: Viktor Tsoi, the lead singer and songwriter for Kino, one of the Soviet Union's most popular rock bands, died in a car crash outside Leningrad on Aug. 15. He was 28 years old.

title: Chronicle
description: ELIZABETH LEDERER, the lead prosecutor in the Central Park jogger trial that concluded Saturday, is also embroiled in personal court matters.

title: Rinfret, Stalking Governor, Gets Lecture but No Debate
description: For the second time in five days, Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, ambushed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today by making a surprise appearance at one of the Governor's public events.

title: 300th-Ranked Player Knocks Out Wilander
description: Mats Wilander, once ranked No. 1 in the world, was upset by 300th-ranked Todd Martin, 0-6, 6-4, 7-5, last night in the opening round of the W.C.T. Tournament of Champions, an exhibition event at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Yemen Agrees to Block Iraqi Oil; Missile Flow to Kuwait Reported
description: The mounting confrontation between American warships and two loaded Iraqi oil tankers in waters near the Persian Gulf was at least temporarily defused today when Yemen said it would not allow the tankers to unload their cargo in its port of Aden.

title: S.&P. Cuts AMR Rating And Unit's
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it had reduced the rating on about $2.6 billion debt issued by the AMR Corporation and its American Airlines Inc. subsidiary. The rating agency cited pressures on the airline company from rising costs, heavy capital expenditures financed mainly by debt, and leased equipment and property not carried on balance sheets.

title: Jet Skids to Safe Landing
description: A United Airlines Boeing 737 jetliner with 107 people aboard was unable to lock its right landing gear but skidded to a safe emergency landing at Los Angeles International Airport today.

title: In South Africa, Joint Plea to End Black Strife
description: The South African Government and the leaders of two black homelands jointly pleaded for peace today after fighting between black factions that has killed nearly 400 people and wounded more than 1,500 in weeklong battles.

title: Chronicle
description: BILLIE JEAN KING has managed to find a way to be on hand when she is inducted into the National Women's Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls, N.Y., on Sunday. BARBARA JORDAN, DR. FLORENCE B. SEIBERT and the late photographer MARGARET BOURKE-WHITE are also being inducted and Ms. Jordan, a former Congresswoman from Texas, and Dr. Seibert, a biochemist and researcher in cancer and tuberculosis, are unable to attend.

title: About New York;   Where Hizzoner Holds Court Beneath a Tree
description: Some of the most important civic business of the Crotona section of the South Bronx is conducted beneath a tree that rises out of a trash-strewn vacant lot at the corner of 181st Street and Prospect Avenue.

title: Surgery Gives Man 2 Hearts
description: A rare operation has left a man with two functioning human hearts and a clean bill of health, the University of Wisconsin Hospital said today. Surgeons placed a human donor heart in William Rammer, 53 years old, of Kaukauna, on July 21 to supplement his diseased heart, said Dr. Barry Fields, the hospital's chief heart transplant surgeon. Mr. Rammer told reporters he could feel ''a twin heartbeat, and you can feel them overlap once in a while.''

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Land of Ancient Vineyards Takes On the Giants
description: ''THE Rhone,'' said Francois Perrin, ''will be the new Bordeaux.''

title: SUNY to Impose New Fees In Face of Budget Problems
description: The 380,000 students at the State University of New York, who have successfully opposed proposals to raise their tuition in the last few years, will be hit with new and higher fees this fall that could exceed the tuition increases they have fended off.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   At Wendy's, Folksiness Is Effective
description: DAVE THOMAS, the founder of Wendy's International and its folksy spokesman, was not a success when he started appearing in commercials for the fast-food chain. Within the advertising industry, his awkward and stilted performance was widely criticized.

title: Rabies Vaccine Is Tested on Deserted Island
description: In the first field test of a genetically engineered rabies vaccine in the United States, 26 scientists took boats to Parramore Island on Monday and put out 4,000 baited doses of the vaccine.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of books by B. F. Skinner on Monday, with his obituary, misstated the date of ''Walden Two'' in some copies. It was published in 1948.

title: A Bank Expert's Plan for Change
description: When Lowell L. Bryan, head of the banking group at McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, ponders the future of the banking system, he recalls his father's explanation of how the failure of four banks in Oklahoma during the early 1930's carried away the family fortune.

title: Affirmative Action Has India's Students Astir
description: For more than a week, a student protest has been growing steadily on the campuses of this and other Indian cities, spilling onto roads and railway tracks, parks and bazaars.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Nibbling or Partying

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: San Francisco
description: THE emphasis is on the olive in many restaurants here these days, with glass bowls of olive oil replacing crocks of butter on tables. Traditional sauces have been displaced by olive-oil vinaigrettes, and house-made olive breads, laced with olive oil and studded with green and black flecks of kneaded-in olives, are the bread of choice.

title: On the Politics of Green-Bean Cookery
description: OH, the green bean. The sensible, long-suffering legume. Requiring little for itself in terms of glory or kid-glove treatment, Phaseolus vulgaris is the unsung handmaiden of cuisine. The green bean sings to the cook: ''Steam me, boil me, blanch me, do what you want to do; pickle me, stir-fry me. . . .'' We therefore tend to take the bean for granted.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Lee J. Richmond, a poet and teacher at St. John's University, misstated part of his background as an author. He did not write the novel ''High on Gold''; the author was Lee M. Richmond.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;

Evanston, Ill.
description: LEAD: SOME customers dote on the omelets; others prefer the sandwiches. But everyone who's ever been to Cafe Sarkis, a 30-seat short-order grill between a gas station and a parking lot in this northern Chicago suburb, agrees that Sarkis Tashjian, the owner, is one of a kind.

title: Ford Introduces European Line
description: Ford of Europe introduced its new Escort and Orion line of small family cars. The line, in which the Ford Motor Company unit has invested $1.5 billion over the last five years, will go on sale around in Europe next month. The cars are powered by 1.3- to 2-liter engines.

title: Bridgeport Selects A New Police Chief
description: Thomas J. Sweeney, deputy commissioner of the Westchester County Department of Public Safety, was named Bridgeport's new police chief yesterday.

title: Reagan Set Table for Savings and Loan Orgy;   States' Wrongs
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Gulf Crisis Stirs Concern on Asian Games' Fate
description: The crisis in the Persian Gulf is truly a terrible thing, a Chinese writer complained the other day.

title: Nynex to Release Document
description: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it would release today a lengthy deposition by Guy M. Struve, a New York lawyer who led a 1988 investigation into lewd parties in Florida attended by a dozen of the company's purchasing managers and employees of some Nynex suppliers.

title: Mideast Fears Shake Tokyo Stock Market
description: Stock prices plummeted today in unrelenting selling, sending the Japanese market to its second steepest drop ever and raising fears of a more prolonged slide.

title: Coffee Machines Recalled Over Fire Hazard
description: An estimated 800,000 Proctor-Silex automatic drip coffee makers are being recalled because they pose a potential fire hazard.

title: The Appliance Brand-Name Game
description: At Abt Television and Appliance here in this Chicago suburb, no fewer than 15 models of washers and dryers crowd the showroom. So why is Kitchen Aid, a Whirlpool subsidiary best known for its premium dishwashers and heavy-duty mixers, muscling into the market with its own brand of laundry appliances?

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Saudis Plan to Supply U.S. With Fuel for Military Use
description: Saudi Arabian oil officials moved today to suspend their nation's daily export of hundreds of thousands of barrels of jet and diesel fuel, diverting much of it to the American military as a down payment on reimbursement for United States aid in the Persian Gulf crisis, Saudi officials say.

title: Currents;   On Feeding Your Fancy (And Birds)
description: FALL bird migration is about to begin and a twiggy birdhouse or feeder is a splendid way to appeal to birds of passage. It also adds a sculptural note to the garden.

title: Earliest Figures For Census Fall Below Estimate
description: Preliminary 1990 census figures for half the 50 states show that the tally is running more than 2 percent below the Census Bureau's own projections.

title: Heat Gets Williams
description: The Miami Heat signed the forward John (Hot Rod) Williams to an offer sheet yesterday reportedly worth an estimated $18 million over six years.

title: 100 More Die as Rival South African Blacks Fight
description: Factional fighting in black townships around Johannesburg raged into a 10th successive day. The police reported 100 more deaths today and overnight, raising the tally of dead beyond 500 in the 10-day period.

title: Mireet Greenspan Weds in Brooklyn
description: Mireet S. Greenspan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Greenspan of Flushing, Queens, was married last evening in Brooklyn to Joseph E. Wolf, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mitchel L. Wolf of University City, Mo. Rabbi Simcha Krauss performed the ceremony at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD HARRIS is at center stage in a campaign to save the Young Vic Theater in London. Mr. Harris, currently starring in the hit production of Pirandello's ''Henry IV'' at the Wyndams Theater in London, makes an appeal for contributions after each performance.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Kuwaitis Resist Iraqis by Work Boycott and Armed Raids, 'Eyewitness' Articles Say
description: Kuwaitis remain defiant in the wake of the Iraqi occupation of their country, and an underground armed resistance has sprung up, according to an article in the Wednesday issue of The Washington Post. The paper said that the article was ''an eyewitness account of recent events.''

title: SRI LANKAN PLANES HIT TAMIL TARGETS
description: The air force bombed and strafed targets on the Jaffna peninsula today in what military officials called a new offensive against the northern stronghold of the Tamil rebels.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In 1980 people said, 'These are the numbers we are going to have to deal with.' I don't think that it's the case this time. Now there's an acceptance that there are errors in the census.

title: N.L.R.B. Opposes Inquiry on Daily News
description: The National Labor Relations Board has joined the The Daily News in opposing the New York Department of Labor's effort to create a board of inquiry that would look into the paper's negotiations with its unions.

title: Robert Robinson, 76, Pioneer Spinal Surgeon
description: Dr. Robert A. Robinson, a pioneer in spinal surgery and one of the first to employ the use of an electron microscope to study bones, died Aug. 16 at a retirement community in Baltimore. He was 76 years old. Dr. Robinson, who had been professor and chairman of the department of orthopedic surgery at the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions, died after apparently suffering a heart attack, John Hopkins said. He retired from Hopkins in 1979 but continued to see patients.

title: Talks on 'Miss Saigon' Are Continuing
description: Actors' Equity said yesterday that ''cordial discussions'' about ''Miss Saigon'' were held during the day between the union and the show's producer, Cameron Mackintosh. Mr. Mackintosh has demanded a free hand from the union in casting the show before he agrees to bring the hit London musical to Broadway.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CBS Records, New York, a subsidiary of the Sony Corporation of America, named Jon R. Peisinger president of its music video enterprises division.

title: Washington Phone Venture
description: The Washington Post Company and American Personal Communications Inc., a small cellular telephone company in Baltimore, said yesterday that they had agreed to form a limited partnership to develop a new generation of cellular telephone service in Washington.

title: Campgrounds Guide for the Fall
description: As in previous years, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation will keep certain campgrounds open throughout the fall.

title: Rose Status, Year Later
description: Yesterday was Cara Chae Rose's first birthday, and while undoubtedly a joyous occasion it was not quite the harbinger her father once predicted it would be. It was a year ago tomorrow, in fact, that her father, Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, was suspended from baseball after the commissioner, A. Bartlett Giamatti, concluded that Rose had bet on Reds' games.

title: Intergroup to Consider Sale of Foxmeyer Unit
description: National Intergroup Inc. said today that it would ''entertain and evaluate proposals'' for the sale of its Foxmeyer Corporation drug distribution subsidiary. National Intergroup said several potential buyers had indicated they were interested in the unit.

title: High-Tech Tolls, and Less Pollution
description: Can transponders unclog the traffic that backs up for miles at New York City's toll bridges and tunnels? Authorities are about to experiment with systems already installed in places like New Orleans and Dallas. The sooner the better.

title: G.M. Cancels Plan For a Convertible
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had canceled plans for a convertible version of the Chevrolet Beretta because of mounting costs, engineering and quality problems and delays.

title: South African Equality Begins With Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Florio, With His Popularity Sinking, Moves a Top Aide
description: Amid a growing tax revolt and criticism within his own party of his slow response in defusing it, Gov. Jim Florio today removed his chief of staff. Top Democrats saw the move as a shakeup among the Governor's political advisers.

title: Pac-10 Unlikely To Expand Soon
description: Expansion of the Pacific-10 Conference seems to be just about a dead issue, for the time being.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROMAN POLANSKI, who fled the United States to avoid being sentenced for having sexual relations with a 13-year-old girl, is entitled to have a lawyer defend him against a suit filed by the victim. A state appeals court in Los Angeles ruled on Monday that Mr. Polanski, who fled to France in 1977, should have the chance to answer the suit, brought by the victim in 1988. She asked for damages for distress she said was caused by the Polish-born film director, who had pleaded guilty to one count of unlawful sexual intercourse. Her lawyers had asked for a default judgment against him.

title: Harold L. Oram, 83, A Fund-Raiser, Is Dead
description: Harold L. Oram, the founder and president of the Oram Group, fund-raisers for humanitarian and environmental causes, died on Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Yorktown Heights.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   West Hopes U.N. Will Back Use of Force in the Embargo
description: Western diplomats expressed hope today about the prospects of winning Security Council endorsement for military action to enforce the embargo against Iraq.

title: Hospital Police Officer Is Killed
description: An off-duty police officer for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation was fatally stabbed on a subway train in Brooklyn yesterday during a fight with two youths who had robbed two transit workers moments earlier, the police said.

title: A Children's Video Helps With Moving
description: When Marcel and Judith Burnim moved to their new house in Brookline, Mass., a few weeks ago they found that two of their biggest problems were unpacking and acclimating their three children to their new surroundings. They tried to prepare their younger children for the change through discussion, but they also received some help from a new children's videotape about moving.

title: From Tragedy to Absurdity With Finland's Prolific Upstart
description: Seventeen guys in dark glasses are playing electric guitars and keyboards on the stage of a small club in Finland. All of these men are named Frank, and some of them have died earlier in the film, ''Calamari Union,'' which is not about a rock band at all, but about the Franks' meandering attempts to get to the other side of Helsinki. Yet here they are, alive and singing what could be the director Aki Kaurismaki's anthem: ''Bad boys are coming to break all your toys.''

title: In Village, The Past Is Recalled And Resold
description: WITH the opening of U.S.E.D. last Sunday, it feels as if it is 1976 again in Greenwich Village. That was the year Jerry Harmyk opened Johnny Jupiter on West 10th Street, a strange new breed of shop that seemed to combine garage sale, flea market and toy store.

title: Japan Stocks Plunge; Finance Sector Ailing
description: The sharp slide in the Tokyo stock market accelerated today after a heavy selloff yesterday.

title: Electrolux Plans To Lay Off 15,000
description: Electrolux A.B., the Swedish appliance company, said it would cut 15,000 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, over the next two years to bolster falling profits. The company made the announcement as it reported that profits in the first half of the year fell to $175 million from $346 million in the 1989 period.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   G.I.'s Learning to Conquer the Desert
description: The following report was transmitted under rules imposed in Saudi Arabia by the Defense Department for American correspondents accredited to the Pentagon. The rules prohibit reporting of exact numbers of troops or weapons, their exact locations or the names of enlisted personnel.

title: Samaranch On Gulf Crisis
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that he was very worried that the crisis in the Persian Gulf could adversely affect the Asian Games, scheduled to begin next month in Beijing.

title: Who Says a Lobster Outranks Broccoli?
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;   A New Life Is Found For Dairy Byproducts
description: MATHEW RUBIN, a Vermonter who is an engineer by training and an environmentalist by temperament, has found a good use for cheese products' residue. Concerned about landfill space, he persuaded the Vermont Whey Company of Montpelier to dry the 50,000 pounds of whey byproducts left each day to be reused as garden fertilizer.

title: Bridge
description: One of the unobtrusive advantages of the Lightner double, asking for an unusual lead against a slam, is that it inhibits some bad penalty doubles at high levels. West would have been much better off if he had remained silent throughout the auction on the diagramed deal, but he gave South some useful help by repeated doubles.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Hawaiian Electric Chief To Retire at End of Year
description: LEAD: Hawaiian Electric Industries, which operates Hawaii's leading electric company as well as an insurance company and a savings and loan association, said that its president and chief executive, C. Dudley Pratt Jr., will retire at the end of the year. Mr. Pratt will be succeeded by Robert F. Clarke, a group vice president of the company.

title: 'Religious War' in Ukraine, Orthodox Assert
description: Russian Orthodox leaders accused Ukrainian Catholics today of waging a ''religious war'' against them, including attacks on churches and hostage-taking.

title: Joe Lombardo, Graphics Designer, 45
description: Joe Lombardo, an award-winning graphics designer, died on Aug. 15 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: California on Verge of Making Its Presidential Primary 2d in Nation
description: In a move that could have a profound effect on Presidential elections, the leadership of the California Legislature agreed today to move up the state's Presidential primary to second in the nation after New Hampshire.

title: Stocks Fall Again as Oil Surges
