description: Stock prices tumbled late yesterday in the wake of a surprising $2.51-a-barrel rise in crude oil futures.

title: The Panama Pretext
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health
description: Check whichever statements apply. At this point in the summer, your sunglasses:

title: Reagan Set Table for Savings and Loan Orgy;   President and Son
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Ager Arrested in Shooting of Girl, 3
description: A teen-ager who the police say worked as a gunman for a crack-dealing ring was charged yesterday with firing a bullet that critically wounded a 3-year-old girl as she played with her shadow on a Brooklyn sidewalk Tuesday night, the police said.

title: CBS New Division President Is to Announce His Departure
description: After two tumultuous years at CBS, David W. Burke has been forced out as president of the network's news division, an executive of the network said last night. The executive, who would speak only on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Burke would be replaced by Eric Ober, the president of the five television stations owned and operated by CBS.

title: 3 INCUMBENTS WIN IN WYOMING RACES
description: Former Gov. Clifford P. Hansen's daughter won the Republican nomination for his old job in a primary on Tuesday. In November, she will face the Democratic incumbent, Mike Sullivan, who easily defeated his opponent, a motorcycle mechanic.

title: Reagan Set Table for Savings and Loan Orgy;   Pay Off in Shares
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters;   Politics, Pensions And the Shadow Of a Raider
description: Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider and chairman of Trans World Airlines, has focused on a new target, New York State's $47 billion pension fund, which he thinks should be used to influence management to be more efficient and competitive in corporations in which it has holdings.

title: Trump Signs Bailout Pact
description: Donald J. Trump completed the signing of all documents relating to his bailout package yesterday and received the first installment of $65 million in new loans.

title: You Get Eight Miles to the Gallon, and a Microwave Oven, Too
description: If the Statue of Liberty had looked over her shoulder last week, she would have seen the Wally Byam people right at the water's edge here in their round-edged, riveted, shiny aluminum homes on wheels. All 378 of them.

title: A Kuwaiti Newspaper Reopens in London
description: In a whitewashed building in a working-class area of west London, the daily newspaper Al Qabas is waging a war of well-chosen words against the Iraqi invaders of Kuwait.

title: Steinbrenner Inactive in U.S.O.C.
description: After four hours of tedious discussion and debate this afternoon, senior members of the United States Olympic Committee recessed without resolving whether George Steinbrenner would remain as one of the organization's three vice presidents.

title: Pepsico Drink Deal
description: Pepsico Inc. said it had signed an exclusive five-year contract to supply soft drinks to Ponderosa and Bonanza restaurants beginning next month. No financial details were released. The Metromedia Company owns the 1,200 Ponderosa and Bonanza locations.

title: Welch's 21st Victory Ends Athletics' Slump
description: The Oakland Athletics righted themselves after a three-game losing streak tonight and beat the Chicago White Sox, 7-1, as Bob Welch won his 21st game and Willie Randolph had three hits, including a triple.

title: Review/Theater;   Moliere's Invalid Reborn In a Brazilian Carnival
description: Deep into end of ''O Doente Imaginario'' (''The Imaginary Invalid''), the Teatro do Ornitorrinco's rollicking, irreverent version of the classic 17th-century farce, Moliere's archetypal hypochondriac, Argan, has a dream about dying.

title: Calendar: Crafts Show, Frames, Flowers, Tours
description: Autumn Crafts, Lincoln Center, Fordham University Plaza, 62d Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues; (212) 677-4627.

title: U.S. in Plea On Textiles
description: The United States has asked China to cooperate in halting purportedly illegal shipments of textiles intended to avoid quota restrictions, an American trade official said today.

title: Review/Jazz;   A Rousing Welcome For a Cuban Trumpeter
description: A series of musical explosions punctuated Monday night's packed performance at the Village Gate. The concert, a welcome party for the Cuban trumpeter Arturo Sandoval, featured the orchestras of Mario Bauza and Tito Puente, along with the guest singers Celia Cruz and Graciela. Mr. Sandoval, who arrived from Cuba in July, has recently been given political asylum in the United States; he, along with just about everybody else who walked the stage - including Bill Cosby - knew exactly how to get a crowd going.

title: Lebanon Moves To Create Political Equality
description: The Lebanese Parliament has adopted basic changes in the Constitution that Government officials said could establish political equality between Muslims and Christians for the first time since independence 47 years ago.

title: Pathe Makes A Payment
description: The Pathe Communications Corporation has paid another $50 million toward its $1.3 billion purchase of the MGM/UA Communications Company.

title: Stotler Facing Charges By 2 Regulatory Panels
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have filed separate disciplinary charges against Stotler & Company, the collapsed futures trading firm, for hiding its financial difficulties from the two regulatory agencies beginning in December 1989.

title: Books of The Times;   Daimler-Benz and Its Nazi History
description: Mercedes in Peace and War

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE OIL JOLT

title: Ex-Thornburgh Aide Denies Drug Charges
description: A former top aide to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh pleaded not guilty today to four drug-related charges.

title:
Talking Deals;

Chrysler Facing New A.M.C. Cost
description: LEAD: CHRYSLER'S 1987 acquisition of American Motors gave Chrysler the prestigious Jeep line and A.M.C.'s share of the United States vehicle market. But Chrysler bought some headaches as well, among them a potential $100 million liability to Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the French auto maker.

title: Shaken Baby Syndrome, Deadly but Little-Known Condition
description: There were no scars, no burns or cuts and only two bruises on his back to hint of trauma when 2-month-old Kwok-wei Jiang was brought, dead on arrival, to Metropolitan Hospital in Manhattan on July 6, 1988.

title: For F.B.I., Back to Political Sabotage?
description: LEAD: On May 24 a car bomb exploded under my seat as I drove through Oakland, Calif. The attack followed a series of death threats against me and occurred as I was traveling to organize nonviolent protests with Earth First! against overcutting of the redwood forest in northern California. My injuries are painful and severe, and will leave me permanently crippled.

title: Sugary Diet Link to Delinquency Discounted
description: University of Wisconsin researchers have found no support for the common belief that sugary foods or the abnormal metabolism of sugar can provoke aggression or other behavior problems in juvenile delinquents or, for that matter, in nondelinquent boys.

title: PRICE OF OIL JUMPS BY 9% IN ONE DAY
description: The price of oil topped $31 a barrel yesterday, the highest price since November 1985, when the oil markets were still recovering from the Iranian revolution of five years earlier. The current Middle East crisis has raised prices to a level higher than they were when Iran and Iraq were trying to sink each others' tankers.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Doubling Up Inmates Is Upheld in Court
description: A Federal judge yesterday refused to halt Connecticut's preparations to greatly expand the use of housing two inmates to a cell and to add beds at the state's maximum-security prison.

title: Coslet Likes the New Jets' Line Play
description: The Jets' defensive line, last in the National Football League in 1989 with 28 quarterback sacks, has taken quarterbacks down nine times in the first two exhibition games.

title: Mississippi to Pay $4.7 Million to Settle Bias Suit
description: The State of Mississippi has been ordered to pay more than $4.7 million in the final ruling of a 20-year-old discrimination suit against the state's employment agency.

title: Leo Dana Dies at 94; Aide at Union Carbide
description: Dr. Leo I. Dana, a former Union Carbide research executive who specialized in low-temperature physics, died last Thursday in Canton, Ohio, at the age of 94.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Jordan's Ruler: A Peacemaker or Just Indecisive?
description: As the gulf crisis deepens, the quandary of King Hussein of Jordan is becoming more acute.

title: Giants' Collins and Howard Sign for 2 Years
description: Mark Collins and Erik Howard signed contracts and practiced today, leaving Lawrence Taylor and Leonard Marshall as the only Giants missing from camp.

title: CHRONICLE
description: August has been the nicest month for MAGGIE KUHN, who founded the Gray Panthers 20 years ago: she became a Giraffe, she received 1,000 pints of Ben and Jerry's light ice cream and she turned 85.

title: British Aerospace In $900 Million Deal
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had firm orders for 25 of its BAe-146 aircraft and options for eight more, in a deal worth about $900 million. The company has sold 293 of the four-engine airliners that entered service in 1983. The aircraft can seat between 70 and 120 passengers.

title: Shuttle Fuel Leak Is Traced to Glass Beads
description: Glass beads found in hydrogen lines from the space shuttle Columbia contributed to its fuel leaks, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Vermont Journal;   New Battle Goes On As Guns Lie Quiet
description: The crews have gone home, their excavation pits refilled with clay, the buttons and cow bones and glass shards they unearthed bagged and ready for analysis. Mount Independence, the site of New England's main fortress in the early years of the American Revolution, is silent again.

title: Home Improvement
description: WOODEN windowsills are designed to shed moisture, but unless they are regularly painted or waterproofed, snow and rain can penetrate them during long periods of bad weather. The resulting decay eventually destroys the sill and can damage the window and adjoining walls, causing interior paint to peel and plaster or wallboard to crumble.

title: East Germans Agree to Unification Date
description: The East German Parliament ended weeks of bitter dispute early this morning by agreeing to Oct. 3 as the date for formal unification with West Germany.

title: Staten Island Boy, 9, Killed By Car While Chasing a Ball
description: A 9-year-old boy was struck and killed by a car yesterday when he chased a ball from a school playground into a street on Staten Island, the police said.

title: In Turnabout, Rinfret Is Victim Of an Ambush
description: As a vote-getting tactic, it probably has as much utility as eating goldfish. Still, ambush, it seems, has become the strategy of choice for some of this year's gubernatorial candidates.

title: The Shaken Financial Markets
description: The world's financial markets have been reeling as fears mount of war in the Middle East and oil prices soar.

title: Tokyo Offering By Pepsico Unit
description: Pepsico Inc. said on Tuesday that a Japanese joint venture of its Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant chain had begun selling shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: Taking Time to Consider the Lilies of the Wayside
description: AUGUST brings to the garden a sense of pause. It is a time of already over and of not yet. The vegetative rush that began in the spring has come to a halt. Except for crabgrass and poke, even my weeds have lowered their metabolism, moderated their ambitions to conquer the patch of earth I tend.The day lilies that came in on a tide of radiant colors in July have had their day, now showing only tired foliage and ugly brown stalks that I would remove if I felt more like working a few hours to tidy up.

title: Comez Struggles At Hamlet Challenge
description: With less than one week to the start of the United States Open, the reigning French Open champion, Andres Gomez, appears to be in need of a shot of adrenaline and the new giant killer of tennis, Goran Ivanisevic, looks poised to take another Grand Slam tournament by storm.

title: Latest in Breast Reconstruction: Take Wedges of the Patient's Fat
description: An increasing number of women who undergo mastectomies are having breast reconstruction using wedges of fat from their abdomens, buttocks or thighs, doctors say.

title: When Sideline Becomes Firing Line
description: To Mike Kelly, the memory of Rick Carter hangs like a banner at half-staff over a profession that has become increasingly pressurized and less forgiving in recent years.

title: Currents;   For Gardeners, Pants You Can Really Kneel In
description: AT last, pants for the working gardener. The clothing designer at Smith & Hawkens, Gibson Mann, has attempted to put an end to aching kneecaps and lost pruners, trowels or other totable paraphernalia. He has designed pants with pouches for foam pads where knees meet ground, and with seven deep pockets along the legs, back and sides.

title: Armed Raids in Pakistan Kill 27 Mohajirs
description: Masked gunmen killed 27 people and wounded 83 today in raids on members of Pakistan's powerful Mohajir national movement, hospital officials said.

title: Drug Given for Head Injury Is Ineffective in Long Term, Study Says
description: A drug given to more than 100,000 head injury patients each year is ineffective after the first week and, as a long-term treatment, is actually worse than giving nothing at all, a study has found.

title: Bernard Wex, Bridge Designer, 68
description: Bernard Wex, designer of the world's longest suspension bridge span, died on July 31, The Independent newspaper reported today. He was 68 years old.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   China Gives Its View
description: Prime Minister Li Peng said today that China opposed any military involvement in the Persian Gulf by ''big powers,'' but officials reportedly told a visitor that it would not oppose a United Nations resolution allowing the use of force to back up the embargo of Iraq.

title: Cray Research
description: Cray Research Inc. said it had sold a Cray X-MP supercomputer system to Hydro-Quebec, the principal Canadian supplier of hydroelectric power. It said Hydro-Quebec had installed the computer at its center for numerical network analysis in Montreal. It will be used to simulate Hydro-Quebec's power networks. Cray said it would work with Hydro-Quebec in developing software for the system. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

title: Merc May Trade in Rubles
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it was working with Soviet officials and economists to develop futures and options markets for the ruble.

title: George Chambers, 87; Lost Disputed Election
description: George O. Chambers, an Indiana Republican apparently elected to Congress by 12 votes in 1960 but rejected seven months later by the House of Representatives, died Friday at the Muncie-Ball Hospital in Muncie, Ind. He was 87 years old and had lived in Anderson, Ind., before moving to Muncie six years ago. His family said he died of lupus.

title: Negotiations to Settle Liberian War End in Failure
description: Negotiations for a settlement of the Liberian civil war ended in failure today after the country's main rebel group and West African leaders were unable to agree on more than postponing a discussion of their differences to the indefinite future.

title: Poland Seeks to Revive Its Stately Homes
description: Poland's old noble families, dispersed around the world or reduced to cramped walk-ups in their homeland, have little but memories of their once elegant estates.

title: Radio Link With Venus Probe Is Still Intermittent
description: For the second time in less than a week, flight controllers lost radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft orbiting Venus but after hours of unsuccessful attempts yesterday, they finally managed to restore limited communications.

title: Boeing, Insurers In Federal Court
description: The Boeing Company has sued its insurance companies to settle an $80 million dispute over who should pay to clean up toxic wastes at two Seattle-area sites. The insurance companies have refused to pay, contending Boeing knew it was polluting the areas.

title: Holtz Denies Condoning Steroids
description: Notre Dame said today that five football players had tested positive for steroid use in the past three years, but Coach Lou Holtz denied published allegations by a former player that steroid use was widespread and that he must have known about it.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Planning at the Helm For Troops in the Sand
description: Operating around the clock since the invasion of Kuwait, a small staff of Pentagon officials has served as the pivot point for the United States military deployment in the Persian Gulf, coordinating a sprawling operation involving a large-scale air and sealift, the mobilization of troops and daily revisions in battle plans.

title: 3Com President Makes A Rapid Rise to Chief
description: Just four months after being named president of the 3Com Corporation, Eric P. Benhamou has been elected chief executive. On Sept. 20, Mr. Benhamou will succeed L. William Krause, who will continue as chairman of the computer networking company based in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, the oil company, retained Goldman, Sachs & Co., to assist in the sale of assets from its petroleum additives manufacturing facility based in Clayton, Mo. The value of the assets was not disclosed.

title: Currents;   Tropical Plants Thrive In the Great Indoor Jungle
description: GARDEN shops are now stocking tropical plants suitable to the low light of indoor winter gardens. ''Now's the time to start to look at these plants and see which ones appeal to you,'' said Nancy Tim, horticulturalist at the Central Park Zoo.

title: Streets Are Closed After Masonry Falls
description: Broadway between 102d and 105th Streets was closed to traffic last night after masonry fell from the seventh floor of an 11-story building at 230 West 103d Street, the police said. There were no injuries. A spokesman for the Buildings Department, Vahe Tiryakian, said that problems with ornamental stonework on the building's facade had been detected on Monday and that nets were put up as a precaution. He said the stonework fell about 24 hours later. One side of the structure faces Broadway.

title: Review/Music;   A Conductor Who Transcends the Predictable
description: Neeme Jarvi, who takes over as music director of the Detroit Symphony this fall, made his Mostly Mozart debut on Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall with mostly auspicious results.

title: Control Data Allowed to Sell 6 Computers to Soviet Union
description: In a significant policy relaxation, the United States Government is allowing the Control Data Corporation to sell six mainframe computers to the Soviet Union. The machines, which are considered mid-size mainframes and not supercomputers, will be used for analyzing safety factors in civilian nuclear power reactors. They would be the fastest yet sold to the Soviets.

title: A Dispute Over Radio Technology
description: Setting the stage for a contentious regulatory battle over emerging radio technology, the National Association of Broadcasters has asked the Federal Communications Commission to dismiss the application of a company that wants to provide ''digital audio broadcasting,'' or D.A.B., by satellite.

title: Breaking The Cycle
description: About 15,000 buses, unregulated, unscheduled, following any route the owner chooses, rumble through this city, many unsafe, some half-empty, all spewing pollution - a noxious product of the deregulation that has brought Chile the most open-market economy in Latin America.

title: Seabrook Closes Down Again
description: Three days after beginning regular operation, the Seabrook nuclear reactor closed down today, its eighth unplanned shutdown since connecting to the regional power grid on May 29. Today's shutdown occurred automatically during scheduled maintenance on a turbine control system, said a plant spokesman, Ron Sher. All seven previous shutdowns were also turbine-related, and the plant was shut down for about a month in April for turbine modifications.

title: Reagan Set Table for Savings and Loan Orgy
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Oust Armenia Rebels in Azerbaijan
description: Soviet troops expelled hundreds of Armenian guerrilla fighters today from the Kazakh border region of neighboring Azerbaijan, where they had been attacking villages and battling soldiers sent by Moscow to intervene.

title: Beijing Journal;   As Daily Toes the Line, Readers Turn Their Backs
description: Behind the armed guards at the grand main gate of the compound, beyond the cafeteria in a pleasant park-like setting, is a building that is identified as No. 5, but which might better be labeled as a battleground for the future of China.

title: Viola Puts Mets Back on Track
description: Things were getting so shabby, Bud Harrelson said, that he began keeping a kind of diary or log on the Mets' sins, slumps and swoons. Too laid-back. Too lackadaisical. Time to get the act together before they ran out of time.

title: The Goals of War
description: The likelihood is that Americans will die in the Middle East -soldiers, pilots flying missions against Iraqi targets or hostages tethered by Saddam Hussein like sacrificial goats.

title: Judge Found Guilty in Obstruction of Justice
description: A Federal District Court judge was convicted today of illegally disclosing a wiretap to its target and lying to the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the intent to obstruct a grand jury investigation.

title: Hilton's New Campaign Promotes Brand Image
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation has begun a series of brand-image commercials created by the Los Angeles office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, its first of this type in six years. The hotel chain, which has relied on promotional spots for things like special weekend rates, has turned its $7 million budget toward print and television ads that feature scenes from hotels around the world and the theme line, ''Hilton, it's all in the name.''

title: Tokyo's Offer Welcomed
description: Egyptian officials said today that President Hosni Mubarak had gained a pledge of financial assistance from Japan and that they expected the help to go ''some way'' toward meeting losses that Mr. Mubarak said could run at a rate of $2 billion a year.

title: More Pension Benefits Awarded to Old-Timers
description: It cost fans and active players part of the 1990 spring training season, but the basic agreement hammered out before the regular season by representatives of the major league players and the owners has some special benefits for retired players, especially those who left the game before 1959.

title: Greek Warning On Olympic Bid
description: It's 1996 or never for Athens and the Olympics, the president of Greece's Olympic bid committee said today.

title: Market Place;   The Big Selloff In O-T-C Stocks
description: THE 400-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average since mid-July has captured headlines, but the real carnage is taking place in the over-the-counter market. Investors describe the activity of recent weeks as the worst since the October 1987 crash.

title: Found: A New Treasure in the Gulf
description: President Bush's main goal in the Persian Gulf is to protect moderate Arab states threatened by attack or intimidation from Iraq. His policy has already achieved a brilliant success: A broad front of Arab states are standing up to Saddam Hussein's renegade regime.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Transcript of News Session by Bush and 2 Officials on Mideast
description: Following is the transcript of the news conference by President Bush, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell yesterday in Kennebunkport, Me., as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Japan Offering Billions to Arabs To Help Offset Gulf Crisis Losses
description: Japan is offering what may amount to billions of dollars in financial aid as well as communications and transportation support to Middle East nations that would suffer by cutting off trade with Iraq and Kuwait, the Foreign Ministry has said.

title: Accounts
description: * Square D Co., Palatine, Ill., which manufactures electrical equipment, to Creswell, Munsell, Fultz & Zirbel, Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a unit of Young & Rubicam, with an estimated budget of $30 million.

title: Lawsuit Challenges Easing of Controls On Nuclear Waste
description: More than two dozen groups have filed a lawsuit challenging a decision by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to ease controls on the disposal of low-level nuclear wastes.

title: People
description: * Patricia E. Harney has been named a creative director of Leo Burnett, Chicago.

title: Germans Free Bomb Suspect
description: The police today freed a Lebanese man who was arrested a month ago as a suspect in the 1986 disco club bombing that led to United States air strikes against Libya. The suspect, Ali Mansur, was picked up on a tip from a former member of the East German security police. The police said the tip was unreliable.

title: Elderly in Apartments: Feeling Trapped
description: Esther and Leonard Farb, an elderly couple in Upper Manhattan, often feel like prisoners in their own home. Fear of crime keeps them inside at night, and they often stay inside during the day, too, because the elevators are chronically broken, they say, and they are too weak to take the stairs.

title: Bank Woes Climbing in Northeast
description: The storm at New England banks is growing more ominous.

title: Long-Term Rates Climb Sharply
description: Long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in nearly four months yesterday and Treasury bond prices fell sharply, pushed by a sharp rise in oil prices and heightened fears that war may soon break out in the Persian Gulf.

title: Second Time Around?
description: He didn't quite make it the last time around, but Andrew Gaze, the Australian star who helped Seton Hall reach the final game of the 1989 National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, may make a new run at the National Basketball Association.

title: A 14-Year Trail Leads From Harlem to a Murder Suspect's Arrest
description: Even Harvey Rosen, a veteran homicide prosecutor who does not shock easily, remembers it as a particularly gruesome case: A woman's torso found in Mount Morris Park in Harlem, her hands found by a child playing nearby, her severed head found floating in the Hudson River.

title: Editor Sues a Town That Had Sued Him
description: A newspaper editor sued the Town of West Hartford yesterday, claiming the Hartford suburb violated his First Amendment rights when it sued him for writing an editorial critical of the town's handling of an anti-abortion protest.

title: Plan to Reduce Haulers' Fees At Fresh Kills Is Withdrawn
description: Facing likely defeat, Mayor David N. Dinkins withdrew a proposal before the Board of Estimate Tuesday night that would have lowered the fee charged private garbage haulers to dump at the Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island.

title: A Scene of Sugar, Fit for a Table of Yore
description: IN the 17th and 18th centuries, landscape design was at its height in Europe, not only in vast Baroque gardens with stone terraces and fountains, but also in miniature scenes put together by porcelain makers and pastry chefs as centerpieces for banquet tables.

title: INSIDE
description: It's Official: 2 Germanys To Become One on Oct. 3

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. KEEPS KUWAIT MISSION OPEN, JOINING OTHERS IN DEFYING IRAQ; TOKYO FUNDS TO BACK EMBARGO
description: The United States announced today that it would defy Iraqi orders to close its embassy in Kuwait by Friday, and President Bush signed an order that is expected to put 40,000 reservists on active duty by the end of the month, supplementing and replacing forces involved in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: For the Children of the Working Poor
description: Affordable day care is more than a boon to working parents. It's also a way to help millions of poor children find their way into the American mainstream. Congress can make that help possible soon by enacting legislation to make it easier for low-income parents to get decent child care and advance two Administration initiatives to put more money in their pockets.

title: Topics of The Times;   The House That Roared
description: New Yorkers have learned to swallow the lump in the throat that rises each time a movie revival house is closed. Silly, they think, to feel sentimental about those rundown places, with their peeling paint, lumpy seats and threadbare curtains. Why sniffle over the shutting of the Bleecker Street Cinema, now that the Thalia, the New Yorker and the Regency are gone?

title: A Spot for Magazines You're Planning to Read
description: LEAD: NO one, it seems, ever throws old magazines out. At last, demand seems to be encouraging the marketplace: many artisans and designers are trying their hands at magazine racks in shapes that range from the geometric to the anthropomorphic. Can Philippe Starck be far behind?

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Embassy in Kuwait Keeps Up Its Aid to Stranded Americans
description: The State Department said today that despite plans to cut its diplomatic presence in Kuwait sharply, the embassy will continue to protect and assist the 2,500 Americans trapped there as best as it can.

title: Airlines Delay Fare Increase
description: Most of the big airlines said yesterday that they would delay a planned 5.3 percent fare increase until Aug. 30.

title: Board of Estimate, Headed for Demise, Approves Flurry of Projects
description: The New York City Board of Estimate approved a flurry of disputed proposals early yesterday morning, including a plan by Columbia University to build a commercial biomedical laboratory at the site of the ballroom where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965.

title: Attempt to Set OPEC Meeting Fails
description: A militant group of oil producers led by Algeria, Libya and Iran has blocked a renewed attempt by Saudi Arabia and Venezuela to convene an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to try to stablize soaring oil prices.

title: Hawaiian in Protest Drowns
description: A militant environmentalist drowned in Keauhou Bay on Tuesday shortly after leading a flotilla of boats and surfboards in an anti-geothermal protest, the police said. The man, 47-year-old Dexter Cate, failed to surface after diving from a kayak, Lieut. Errol Ishimine said. Mr. Cate, a Hilo High School teacher, was protesting state-backed plans for geothermal energy plants in Wao Kele O Puna Rainforest.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Fewer Badges of Faith
description: The Defense Department is allowing Jewish soldiers to have their religious affiliation deleted from dogtags before traveling to Saudi Arabia as part of the American military buildup in that Muslim country, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Colombia Reports the Arrest Of Cocaine Cartel Assassin
description: The Colombian security police said today that they had arrested the chief of assassins for the Medellin cocaine cartel.

title: Credit Cards Back $215 Million Issue
description: Colonial National Bank USA yesterday priced $215 million in floating-rate asset-backed certificates with a maturity date of Oct. 15, 1996, through a specially formed trust, Colonial Credit Card Trust 1990-A The certificates, which are backed by Mastercard and Visa credit card receivables, have an estimated average life of 4.3 years and are priced at par for an initial yield of 42 basis points more than the one-month London interbank offered rate - the basic short-term rate of interest in the Eurodollar market and the rate to which many Eurodollar loans and deposits are tied.

title: Review/Dance;   Ideas From the Joseph Holmes Troupe
description: The Joseph Holmes Dance Theater, a jazz dance company seen at the Studio/Theater of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Saturday night, is an engaging troupe filled with likable dancers whose stage personalities and styles blend nicely. Randy Duncan, the company's director and resident choreographer, obviously has lots of ideas and a sense of how he wants to express them. But most of the pieces needed to be edited, and several dancers pushed too hard.

title: Dispute Delays St. Louis Offering
description: A delay in settling the offering of a $24 million tax and revenue anticipation note by the City of St. Louis could have negative implications on the city's general obligation bond rating if not resolved soon, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

title: Fall Classes and Lectures on Crafts
description: Here are some classes in crafts scheduled for fall.

title: MTV Is Sued Over Phone Contest
description: A California woman has filed a lawsuit against the cable television music channel MTV, accusing it of running illegal lotteries and deceptively advertising contests that viewers can enter by calling ''900'' telephone numbers.

title: CUOMO AND DINKINS AGREE TO HOUSE 5,225 MENTALLY ILL
description: In the state's most ambitious effort to date to solve the problem of New York City's homeless mentally ill, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday signed an agreement to find, refurbish or build new housing for 5,225 mentally ill people by the middle of 1992.

title: Yanks Top Blue Jays For Sixth in a Row
description: The Yankees, waging a more spirited battle for sixth place than the Blue Jays are for first these days, completed a three-game sweep of the perplexing American League East contenders by defeating Toronto, 4-2, last night.

title: 59th St. Bridge Market Developers Have Duty to Clean Up Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television;   Beer for Slim, Elegant Sophisticates
description: Why should wine drinkers be esteemed as nobs while beer drinkers are put down as slobs? An effort to correct this injustice and get equal treatment for those who prefer the mix of the malt to the fruit of the vine appears to be the life's mission of Michael Jackson. No, not that Michael Jackson. This one is an Englishman who lives up to his title, ''The Bard of Beer,'' in the six-part series, sensibly called ''Beer,'' that begins tonight at 10:30 on the Discovery Channel.

title: Currents;   Greenhouse Group Offers To Let the Public Look In
description: THE Texas Greenhouse Company, which manufacturers window greenhouse kits, and the Turner Greenhouse Company, which sells fiberglass units for as little as $500, are two of more than three dozen suppliers described in the most recent copy of the Directory of Manufacturers of Hobby Greenhouses, Solariums, Sun Rooms and Window Greenhouses.

title: If My Marine Son Is Killed . . .
description: LEAD: Dear President Bush:

title: Q&A
description: Restoring Marble Sheen

title: For Regina Resnik, Feisty Fun In City Opera's 'Little Night Music'
description: Before she has uttered her first withering lines as Mme. Armfeldt, the acerbic grandmother in the revival of ''A Little Night Music'' at the New York State Theater, the mezzo-soprano Regina Resnik is greeted with applause.

title: A Story Of a Pair Of Eras
description: The day was gray; it was overcast, and there was a chance of squalls. And this had nothing to do with the weather. This was often the atmosphere in the Yankees' clubhouse.

title: Justin in Merger
description: Justin Industries said it had signed a definitive merger agreement with the Tony Lama Company. A Justin subsidiary will pay $9 a share in cash for Tony Lama common stock. The offer will start no later than Aug. 28 and will be for all of the approximately two million shares of Tony Lama's outstanding stock. The cost of the transaction, including the assumption of debt, is about $52 million. Tony Lama, a maker of western boots and leather accessories based in El Paso, will become a unit of Justin, a building products and leather goods company based in Fort Worth.

title: Miscellany
description: * Korey, Kay & Partners has rushed ahead its creation of an executive board because of the death of a partner, Lois Korey. Its members are Steven R. Fajen, executive vice president, director of media and marketing services; Milda Misevicius, executive vice president, director of business development; Neil R. Leinwohl, senior vice president, creative director; Joe Palladino, senior vice president, account director; Michael F. Glavin, senior vice president, account director, and David S. Harris, senior vice president, director of finance.

title: Parker Birthday Concert
description: The 70th anniversary of the birth of the jazz saxophonist Charlie (Bird) Parker will be celebrated with a free concert on Tuesday at 7 P.M. at the Great Hill in Central Park, at West 106th Street. The concert, sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy, will feature the Lou Donaldson Quintet. The drummer Max Roach will be the master of ceremonies. Parker was born on Aug. 29, 1920; he died in 1955 at the age of 35.

title: With Money and Talent, Emory Raises Its Status
description: LEAD: In the sort of coup that happens once every few years in academia, Emory University this spring hired away three senior members of the French department at Johns Hopkins University. For good measure, Emory also induced at least 10 of 18 graduate students in French to shift with the senior faculty from Baltimore to

title: Smokers' Revolt Succeeds in Moscow
description: Scores of angry smokers blocked a street next to Red Square for several hours today as public outrage over a summerlong cigarette shortage boiled over.

title: Patient Is Too Weak For a Transplant
description: A teacher with AIDS who won a court decision to make his medical insurer pay for a lifesaving bone marrow transplant has learned he is now too weak to get the transplant.

title: After Melee, 'Fragile' Calm At Rikers Jail
description: The day after dozens of correction officers quelled another inmate outburst at Rikers Island, First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said yesterday that the climate at the jail complex was calmer than a week before but still ''fragile and tense.''

title: Police Protest 2d Inquiry On Shooting in Teaneck
description: After cheering angry speeches in which Gov. Jim Florio and Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo were denounced, hundreds of police officers marched through the heart of Teaneck late this afternoon to protest a new investigation by New Jersey into the shooting of a black teen-ager by a white Teaneck policeman on April 10.

title: Topics of The Times;   Fine-Tune the Tunes
description: Why didn't somebody think of it sooner? Owners of convenience stores in the Pacific Northwest have found a fail-safe way to curb teen-age loitering: they blare out easy-listening music outside their all-night stores, and the kids flee. At the first swell of Mantovani's strings from Hoagy's Corner Deli in Tillicum, Wash., 14-year-old Felix Mendiola said ''I'm out of here, dude.''

title: In Mongolia, Taking Stock of Rare Animals
description: This vast nation of steppes, rich in animal species, is beginning to count its living wealth to improve conservation.

title: KEY RATES
Parent & Child
description: MADDY COHEN had her two children, Matthew and Benjamin, at an age when some parents are worried about paying their children's college tuition. She was just shy of 40 years old when Matthew was born two and a half years ago. She had Benjamin four months ago.

title: 3d Defendant in Bensonhurst Case Gets Maximum Sentence
description: John S. Vento, the Bensonhurst defendant who first agreed to testify for the prosecution, then was charged with murder after he changed his mind, was sentenced yesterday to a maximum prison term of two years and eight months to eight years for unlawful imprisonment.

title: Crossland's Capital Plan Is Rejected
description: Crossland Savings Bank of Brooklyn, the largest savings institution in New York, said yesterday that Federal regulators had turned down its plan for a financial revamping and had imposed limits on its lending in the future.

title: Romanians Look Anew at Wartime Dictator
description: For more than 40 years under Communist rule the 23d of August was National Day, marking the day in 1944 when Romania turned against its Nazi allies, declaring a unilateral armistice in its war with the Allies.

title: With Steinbrenner Gone, Will Stability Arrive?
description: It is too early, Gene Michael said, to know if stability, at long last, will come to the Yankees.

title: Washington at Work;   Religion and Politics Become Fused In Congressman's District, and Heart
description: Boston is one of those places where religion and politics sometimes merge to the point of being indistinguishable. Such was the case during one of Representative Joe Moakley's visits to the streets of the South Boston district that has been his base since he entered politics 37 years ago.

title: Shevack's Attraction to Big Clients
description: PARTNERS & SHEVACK, a small New York agency, recently pulled off a feat uncommon for an agency its size: It snatched an important account, Anacin, away from the giant Young & Rubicam.

title: Close to Home
description: THIS month I will have lived in my present home for 11 years. That's the longest I have ever lived in any one place in my entire adult life.

title: Cigars Made the Old-Fashioned Way
description: ALBERT CASTELLANO considers himself a tailor for cigar smokers. ''It's like a custom-made suit,'' said Mr. Castellano, the manager of Tobacco Products, a 40-year-old shop on in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. ''You get individual attention.

title: Correction
description: Because of editing errors, an article yesterday about plans for satellites to measure climatic change misstated the conclusion of a report to the White House and carried an erroneous byline. A panel said that smaller, simpler satellites could begin monitoring the climate sooner, rather than later, and that they should take budgetary priority over the elaborate Earth Observing System. The writer was William K. Stevens.

title: Younger Consumers: More to Spend, More to Want
description: AT the moment Kimberly Esteves doesn't have any money. But if she did, the 6-year-old would head for a restaurant.

title: Free Fuel for the Troops
description: Saudi Arabia is diverting hundreds of thousands of barrels of jet and diesel fuel daily from exports and supplying it free to the international force on its territory. Page A14.

title: Yields Rise In Week
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report rose for the week ended yesterday.

title: Sochia Suspended
description: Brian Sochia, the starting nose tackle for the Miami Dolphins, was suspended for five weeks yesterday by the National Football League for violating the league's policy banning the use of steroids.

title: Adding Police Won't Hold Back New York's Crime Tidal Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Oil Companies' Stocks Fall Again
description: Investors continued to unload their holdings in oil companies and oilfield service companies for the third consecutive day.

title: Books of the Times;   Seeing the Landscape At Its Best and Worst
description: The Experience of Place

title: Neeme Jarvi to Conduct Mozart Works
description: Neeme Jarvi is to conduct the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in Johann Roman's ''Drottningholm Music,'' and Mozart's Symphony No. 41 (K. 551) at 8 tonight at Avery Fisher Hall. The program also includes two other Mozart works, the Piano Concerto No. 13 in C (K. 415), with Louie Lortie as the soloist, and the Sinfonia Concertante in E flat (K. 364), with the violinist Cho-Liang Lin and the violist Jaime Laredo as the soloists. Mr. Lortie is to give a pre-concert recital at 7 P.M. at Fisher Hall. The program and the pre-concert recital are to be repeated tomorrow evening. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds increased $6.22 billion, to $408 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. At the 162 institutional funds, assets rose $1.15 billion, to $99.48 billion. The assets of the 253 general-purpose funds were up $2.40 billion, to $142.45 billion. The 105 broker-dealer funds' assets increased $2.67 billion, to $166.07 billion.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR will co-produce a television film based on the life of the Rev. Vernon Johns, who as minister of the Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery, Ala., was an early civil rights activist. He is regarded as a mentor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who succeeded Mr. Johns at the church. Mr. Johns died in 1965.

title: Transcript of Iraqi Chief's Conversation With English-Speaking Captives
description: Following is a transcript of a televised conversation between President Saddam Hussein and several English-speaking foreigners held at an undisclosed location in Iraq. Mr. Hussein's remarks, in Arabic, were translated by an Iraqi interpreter; some sections were inaudible. The broadcast was recorded by The New York Times from Cable News Network.

title: Editorial Post Filled by Times
description: Philip M. Boffey will become the deputy editorial page editor of The New York Times on Nov. 1. The appointment was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, the editorial page editor.

title: Flora Staal Hartog, 87, Jewelry Store Founder
description: Flora Staal Hartog, who founded F. Staal, the Fifth Avenue jewelry store, 50 years ago and ran it until she retired in 1983, died yesterday at her home in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 87 years old.

title: Soviet Circus Ends Bittersweet Tour
description: After being stranded for three months and abandoned by its promoters, the Great Circus Bim Bom returned to the Soviet Union today with bittersweet memories of the United States but without the equipment and animals they brought here.

title: Tourism in New York City Is Down After 80's Boom
description: After the boom years of the 1980's, New York City tourism is down slightly this summer, a dip that is being closely monitored by the local tourist industry.

title: Price of Being No. 1 Is Nothing to Cheer About;   Japan Gains on Us
description: To the Editor:

title: DEALS
description: Baseball

title: Officers Kill Robbery Suspect
description: A robbery suspect was killed last night in an exchange of gunfire with two undercover police officers in a Bronx school yard, the police said. The shootout occurred at 10:25 P.M. after the officers came upon two suspects robbing three men at gunpoint on the playground of Junior High School 145 at East 164th Street and Teller Avenue in the Morrisania section, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman. One suspect shot at the police, who returned fire, the sergeant said. The second gunman was captured after a brief chase, Sergeant Wrensen said. Neither suspect was immediately identified.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Media Business page on Aug. 6 about an investment by the Times Mirror Company in La Opinion, one of the United States' largest Spanish-language daily newspapers, referred to the action incorrectly in some editions. Times Mirror is purchasing 50 percent of the newspaper; it is not buying the whole paper.

title: For a Start, There's Gilbert vs. Wilander
description: A year after eighth-seeded Brad Gilbert was upset by Todd Witsken in the first round of the United States Open, Gilbert, again seeded eighth, got something of a shock today when he learned that his first-round opponent for the 1990 Open next week would not be a potential giant killer but a bona fide giant of the game: the 1988 champion, Mats Wilander.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Gains Some Support at U.N. for a Resolution Endorsing Force
description: American French and British representatives have agreed on the text of a Security Council resolution endorsing military action to enforce the embargo against Iraq, diplomats said today.

title: 3,000 West African Troops Leave For Liberia to Enforce Cease-Fire
description: Six ships carrying 3,000 West African soldiers sailed from here today to enforce a cease-fire in Liberia, where a 10,000-man rebel army has rejected a proposed truce.

title: Review/Film;   When the Ladies Take Off Their Wigs, Head for Home. Fast.
description: ''The Witches'' resembles a brilliantly told bedtime story, though the teller of this children's tale may well be the slightly cracked relative who can't judge when scary stories become nightmares. This tale about a witches' plot to turn every child in England into a mouse is based on the novel by Roald Dahl, who does not write cuddly sugarcoated books. It was directed by Nicolas Roeg, best known for the wonderfully terrifying ''Don't Look Now'' and the deeply strange ''The Man Who Fell to Earth,'' with David Bowie as an alien.

title: Robbery Suspect Dies and a Neighborhood Is Silent
description: A crowd in a crime-ridden Bronx neighborhood took justice into its own hands Wednesday night, surrounding a fleeing robbery suspect and stabbing him to death, the police said.

title: New York Tourism: Some Ups, Some Downs
description: Traditionally, tourists coming to New York City have braved the noise , the crime and the people. They are doing so this summer as well, but in smaller numbers than they did during the boom years of the 1980's.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Waldheim to Travel to Iraq
description: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria is to meet with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq on Saturday in Baghdad to discuss the release of Westerners held in Iraq and Kuwait, Mr. Waldheim's office said today.

title: HORSE RACING: Notebook;   Best 2-Year-Olds May Bi in Hiding
description: Talented 2-year-olds have been so slow to emerge this year that it seems possible the eventual champion juvenile has yet to make his debut. It is more comforting to think that the best are yet to run than to pronounce the crop a dull one already, and there is a theory to support that notion.

title: Big Board Seat Is Sold
description: The price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange has fallen to a six-year low with the purchase yesterday of a seat for $301,000. That price is the lowest since 1984 and a decline of $9,000 from the previous sale price of $310,000 on Monday, exchange officials said. The record price for a seat, $1.15 million, was paid in 1987, before the stock market crashed that year.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf: TV Critic's Notebook;   Iraq's Leader Entertains 'Guests,' Not 'Hostages'
description: Suddenly, yesterday at noon, viewers of CNN's ''News Hour'' were presented with President Saddam Hussein, in civilian suit and shiny tie, sitting amid some two dozen people, most of them under 21 and dressed for kicking a ball around.

title: Of all the sad words of tongue of pen, what of the clerkship that might have been?
description: On the fourth Monday in July, Marcella David was supposed to start preparing for the first Monday in October.

title: Review/Music;   Second Cast For 'Lucia' At City Opera
description: Whatever else might be said for or against Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor,'' the conflicting passions that drive the work are meant to kindle the operagoer's instant sympathy for Lucia and her secret lover, Edgardo, and antipathy for her desperate, scheming brother, Enrico.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Barbara Lea Pays Tribute

title: Another Parting for Steinbrenner
description: For all the elements of the agreement that removed him from the daily operations of the Yankees, George Steinbrenner was most concerned that the public understood he was neither ''banned,'' ''suspended'' nor put on any kind of probation.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business People column on Monday about Andre Danesh, an investor in distressed companies, referred incorrectly to one of his investments. He invested in Revco D.S.

title: F.D.A. Defends Milk-Producing Drug in Study
description: The Food and Drug Administration said in a study to be published on Friday that a genetically engineered growth hormone that increases milk production in dairy cows was harmless to human health.

title: Rangers Sign Gartner To a 2-Year Contract
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that they had signed Mike Gartner to a new contract. The deal, said a source familiar with the negotiations, is for two years and is worth roughly $1.2 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST, 24, 1990
description: Markets

title: Taylor Seeks Pot of Gold At End of Contract Talks
description: In recent months, Jose Canseco, perhaps the most dynamic player in baseball, signed a five-year contract for $23.5 million and Joe Montana, the best quarterback in pro football, signed a four-year contract for at least $13 million.

title: Siren Call of Niagara Falls and a Tragedy
description: Legend has it that the Iroquois who once populated this area believed that the Great Spirit observed the world from behind the thick curtain of Horseshoe Falls. If so, the Spirit has been a backstage witness to a summer that might have been a script by David Lynch: an eerie season of intrigue, dark comedy and tragedy that has been unusual even by Niagara Falls standards.

title: U.S. Bank Quits Bahrain
description: The Bank of America said on Wednesday that it was closing its operations in Bahrain but stressed that the Persian Gulf crisis had not been a major factor in the decision. ''We are winding down our Bahrain operations as a result of a continuing review of the bank's international strategy for business,'' said Zakir Mahmoud, a regional vice president. ''The gulf crisis has had very little impact on our decision. We will continue to serve the area in a more cost-effective manner from London.'' Bank of America, based in San Francisco, employs 20 people in Bahrain, including 14 citizens of Bahrain. Mr. Mahmoud said the closing would be completed in several weeks and the bank was trying to relocate as many of the employees as possible.

title: Steady Radio Contact With Venus Craft Regained
description: Steady radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft orbiting Venus was re-established yesterday, but the reason for the on-again, off-again communications continued to mystify project engineers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Lyons P.L.C., London, the beverage company, said Suntory Ltd., the Japanese beverage maker, had increased its Allied stake to almost 5 percent from 2.5 percent.

title: Few Tears Over Changes at CBS
description: LEAD: If CBS News staff members were anguished about the sudden turnover in the division's management yesterday, they expressed their anguish privately. Several said they were relieved that Eric W. Ober, the new president of the news division, was well known to them and widely regarded as an executive who will represent their interests in the increasingly cost-conscious network.

title: Pearl Bailey's Love Is Remembered at Her Funeral
description: Pearl Bailey was remembered at her funeral today as an extraordinary entertainer and a woman who loved life and everyone she met.

title: Mongol Journal;   Spared by Rebels? The Spirit Says That'll Be $2
description: In this war-battered country, a traditional healer - a woman who says she is possessed by the spirit of a man - has brought peace to her village, winning the return of kidnapped families from the clasp of the notoriously brutal Renamo rebels.

title: 'Parking' Spaces for Jittery Dollars
description: In the midst of the Persian Gulf oil crisis, much of the world's money is fleeing to safe harbors in Britain, Australia and Canada.

title: Ex-Drexel Executives Arrange Aid for Fruit of the Loom
description: A group of former employees and associates of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the defunct brokerage house, have arranged what amounts to a secured loan to William Farley, a former Drexel client who controls Fruit of the Loom Inc., filings made yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission show.

title: East Germany Rethinks Its Laws on Eve of Unity
description: The tumultuous combination of democracy and unrest that has swept East Germany into an October reunification with West Germany reaches beyond the nation's much-publicized crumbling economy. The toppling of Communist rule last year has also brought turmoil in the criminal justice system.

title: Insurer Clarifies Retirement Stance
description: The Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance Company is asking workers to retire, but its general counsel says a report that the company wants 80 percent of its work force to leave was exaggerated. ''In no way would there be an 80 percent reduction in our work force,'' said, Richard W. Berstein, a vice president, in regard to an article in The Providence Journal-Bulletin that the company wanted 475 of its 670 workers to leave.

title: President Of New York Post Resigns
description: Valerie B. Salembier, president of The New York Post for nearly 17 months, announced yesterday that she was resigning as of today.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Shrinking Supplies of Food Evident in Iraq, Reports Say
description: While the American-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia continues, another weapon, the withholding of food for Iraq under the United Nations trade embargo, is beginning to cause hardship, a variety of reports from officials of Western governments and food experts say.

title: Ambase Gets Bid For $68 Million
description: The Ambase Corporation of New York said it had received an acquisition proposal from an investment group led by several former top executives of the insurance industry. The group offered to acquire 50.1 percent of Ambase's common stock for $4 a share, or about $68 million. Ambase's board said it would consider the offer. The investors, led by Sequoia Associates, include Donald MacNaughton, the former chairman of the Prudential Insurance Company of America; Benjamin N. Woodson, the former chairman of the American General Corporation; H. John Bremermann Jr., the former chairman of the Maryland Casualty Company, and Guilford Dudley Jr., the former chairman of the Life and Casualty Insurance Company.

title: New Endowment Panel To Watch for Obscenity
description: The National Endowment for the Arts is creating a panel to investigate complaints from ''any reliable source'' that grant recipients are violating the law by using Federal money to produce obscene art.

title: Review/Art;   Parallels in American and Soviet Post-Modernism
description: To American eyes, contemporary Soviet art is endlessly fascinating. It comes from a culture that for most of this century has been closed to the West. It dispenses with the approved style of Socialist Realism and contradicts our preconceived ideas about the creative conditions of Communist life. Moreover, it bears a disconcerting resemblance to recent American art.

title: At Hanford, a Cleanup That May Leave a Bigger Mess
description: LEAD: The Department of Energy recently acknowledged what is probably the most urgent safety issue facing its nuclear weapons complexes: the threat of an explosion in some 50 large underground storage tanks holding radioactive waste. A few weeks ago, the department's advisory committee on nuclear facility safety, headed by John Ahearne, called the situation at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State, where the most dangerous tanks are, ''a prescription for disaster.

title: Suit By Apple Is Extended
description: The long-running copyright infringment suit brought by Apple Computer Inc. against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company will run a little longer.

title: Vintners Head Said to Resign
description: Officials in the wine industry said today that Paul M. Schlem had been forced out as chief executive of the Vintners International Company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm sure that you'd prefer to be in Britain now. Yes. I am an Iraqi and I realize that if I were in your shoes, I'd rather be in my - in Iraq, my country. But sometimes one is forced to face situations which are not of his own choice.''

title: Several Top Managers Are Named by Hasbro
description: Hasbro Inc., the toy company, has named George R. Ditomassi chief operating officer for the company's games and international operations, one of several key changes in senior management this week. The company also named Alfred J. Verrecchia chief operating officer of domestic toy operations and manufacturing services.

title: Venezuela to Increase Oil Production by 25%
description: Venezuela, the largest oil producer in Latin America, has announced it will raise production by 25 percent to offset oil lost because of the embargo on Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Auctions;   Eleanor Blau
description: Money, money everywhere, useless but oh, so, interesting, in red and blue instead of green, with George Washington in a toga. A toga? Yes, a toga. The dollars in his wallet are boring, James Lamb was saying, though he would probably welcome a stout billfold as much as the next fellow. He was comparing their look with the designs on antique notes to be auctioned at Christie's in Manhattan next month in a sale he described as unprecedented in the history of security printing.

title: Farm Bank Offers $200 Million Bonds
description: The Federal Farm Credit Bank Funding Corporation yesterday priced $200 million in 8.94 percent callable consolidated systemwide bonds due Sept. 7, 1995, at par through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Review/Film;   Balladlike Wartime Tale Of Maturing
description: Anne Wheeler's ''Bye Bye Blues'' has the tone and texture of a dreamy pop ballad from World War II spun out over nearly two hours. Reflecting the wide-open spaces of western Canada where most of it was shot, the slow-moving, beautifully photographed film takes its time in telling the story of a young woman who finds self-sufficiency as a band singer during World War II while her husband is a prisoner of the Japanese.

title: Trenary Looks to '92
description: Jill Trenary said yesterday that she would remain an amateur with a goal of winning a gold medal in the 1992 Winter Olympics, something she has failed to accomplish in previous Games.

title: David W. Peck, 87, Former Justice And Court Reformer in New York
description: David W. Peck, a retired Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court who played a leading role in court reform in the late 1940's and 1950's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: DIALOGUE: Next Step in the Gulf    Should the U.S. Attack Iraq?;   No, U.N. Pressure Will Work Best
description: The U.S. has accomplished its original military objective in the Middle East: We stepped in with a strong presence in Saudi Arabia and stopped Saddam Hussein's march south to control the Middle East oilfields. That was a bold and proper action. It was a brilliant performance.

title: Teen-Ager Sentenced to Life
description: A teen-ager was sentenced today to life in prison without hope of parole for stabbing and strangling a friend in a crime he said was influenced by repeated viewings of the movie ''A Clockwork Orange.'' On June 21, the defendant, Michale Anderson, who turned 18 years old today, was convicted of first-degree murder in the death of 17-year-old Karen Hurwitz, who died on Oct. 27, 1989. She was strangled and stabbed in the chest half a dozen times.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Be-Bop's Lou Donaldson

title: Tokyo Stocks Are Up 1.8% In a Volatile, Nervous Day
description: Share prices rose in volatile trading here today, but traders said the market remained extremely nervous.

title: Review/Art;   Long Island Art, a Refuge From the Whirl
description: August comes but once a year to Long Island, and that may be as much as anyone can take. The frantic whir of relaxation and hand-to-hand socializing fills the air, and the pesto intake skyrockets. For those who need a break from the work of not working, the area's museums are one option. They are generally cool, calm, a little underpopulated and, even better, the season's crop of summer exhibitions is unusually fine.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: First Catch of Atlantic Salmon Documented in Alaska Water
description: Biologists have documented the first catch of an Atlantic salmon in Alaska waters, raising fears that escaped fish from commercial farms will introduce diseases dangerous to the state's valuable native species.

title: DIALOGUE: Next Step in the Gulf    Should the U.S. Attack Iraq?;   Yes, Hussein Must Be Ousted
description: Imagine the Middle East with Saddam Hussein in command of a multimillion-man army, equipped with chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, and intercontinental missiles to deliver them.

title: Brewers Put Yanks In Proper Place
description: For the Yankees, their season so full of shame and empty of success had left them with that most modest of ambitions: an escape from last place. It was a sad sort of quest, but as a challenge it had at least one redeeming quality. It could conceivably be met.

title: Regan Used Advice of Donor On Investment That Declined
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who has faced criticism over awarding lucrative state contracts to campaign contributors, relied on a New York consultant firm that contributed $10,000 to his campaign in investing state pension funds in a Boston office building. The property's appraised value has since declined by slightly more than a third.

title: In Europe, Ambiance Costs $10
description: It's one thing to hand over an unfamiliar bill or a few strange coins after a pleasant hour at a Paris sidewalk cafe. It's quite a different thing to find that you've just spent $10 for a Coke and sandwich and a touch of ambiance.

title: Article 338290 -- No Title
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $100 million in senior notes due Sept. 4, 1993, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole manager. The issue carries a 9.30 percent coupon and is priced at par to yield about 88 basis points more than three-year Treasury notes.

title: Review/Film;   Kurosawa's Magical Tales of Art, Time and Death
description: A solemn little boy comes out of his house one rainy morning to find the sun shining. His mother, practical and no-nonsense, looks up at the sky and says that foxes hold their wedding processions in such weather. ''They don't like to be seen by people,'' she says, and goes about her business.

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING

title: Adding Police Won't Hold Back New York's Crime Tidal Wave;   Don't Cut Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: Who's to Pay?
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams knows he'll receive $26.5 million over the next seven years. What the 6-foot-11-inch power forward doesn't know is whether the money will come from the Miami Heat or the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Our Towns;   For a Teacher Fighting AIDS, Love and Loss
description: When Tom Bradley realized that the illness inside him was going public, he envisioned headlines: ''GAY AIDS TEACHER! PARENTS REVOLT! CLASSROOM MAYHEM!''

title: 20,000 Protest K.G.B. at a Lithuanian Border
description: About 20,000 people rallied today near the Soviet border with Poland to protest K.G.B. control of travel to and from Lithuania.

title: INSIDE
description: Guam Abortion Law Voided

title: Western Nations Back U.N. Gulf Resolution
description: American, French and British representatives agreed on the text of a Security Council resolution endorsing military action to enforce the embargo against Iraq, diplomats said.

title: Agent for Two Jets Doesn't See Deal Soon
description: With their preseason game against the Giants coming up Saturday, the Jets still have three players out of camp. They are the running back Blair Thomas and the wide receiver Reggie Rembert - the top two draft picks - and Jim Sweeney, the seventh-year center.

title: Durables Orders Up 2.9% in July
description: Factory orders for durable goods rebounded 2.9 percent in July, the Government reported today.

title: Victor Siegel, 81, Dies; Ex-Bank Street Official
description: Victor J. Siegel, former adminstrative vice president of the Bank Street College of Education, a private school for teachers, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Plan to Aid Homeless Runs Into Opposition
description: A state agency has asked its employees to collect unused soap bars and shampoo bottles from hotels and motels when they are on trips and save them for the state's homeless. The proposal has drawn the anger of the state hotel industry, which said it might lead to taking more than complimentary items.

title: Zapata Selling 90% of Fleet
description: The Zapata Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to sell 90 percent of its drilling-rig fleet to a European group for $280 million.

title: Repurchase Set At Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, will repurchase about $500 million in common stock warrants and common stock.

title: Mobil's European Plan
description: The Mobil Corporation said today that it would restructure operations of its 16 European marketing and refining affiliates to take advantage of the opportunities associated with a single European market in 1992. Europe-wide responsibility for selected business operations will be centralized in the new Mobil Europe Center of Operations in London, the company said. Joe B. Hinton will be president of the new unit. He is now president of Mobil Europe Inc., a service company based in Fairfax that coordinates the company's marketing and refining businesses in Europe.

title: Economic Scene;   Trade Obstacles Among Africans
description: On the edge of Nairobi's industrial park sits one of the most visible manufacturing ventures in Kenya. Founded after independence in 1963 by the Jumas, an Asian family who came to Kenya from Uganda, the company, Orbitsports, makes soccer balls, rugby balls - indeed, all kinds of balls - dart boards, boxing gloves, and a wide range of sports clothing and leisure wear. Its soccer balls were used in the recent World Cup matches in Rome.

title: Help the homeless Off the Street;   Making Room for the Mentally Ill
description: An agreement signed this week by Mayor David Dinkins of New York and Gov. Mario Cuomo marks a monumental advance for the unkempt mentally ill who wander the streets and parks talking to the voices in their heads.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on Aug. 7 referred incorrectly to the origins of the Old Joe advertising campaign for Camel cigarettes. The ''smooth character'' cartoon, the concept for the campaign, was created for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company by Trone Advertising in Greensboro, N.C.; the campaign was later developed by McCann-Erickson Worldwide.

title: Review/Film;   Misfits Whose Crime Does Not Pay
description: James Foley's ''After Dark, My Sweet'' is a brisk, entertaining contemporary melodrama about the kind of sleazy characters who populated California crime literature 35 years ago. That's no surprise, since the screenplay, adapted by Robert Redlin and Mr. Foley, is based on Jim Thompson's novel, published in 1955.

title: Renault Rethinks Mack Trucks Bid
description: Renault S.A., the French state-owned automobile maker, is reconsidering its $6-a-share offer for all remaining shares of Mack Trucks Inc. because of the company's revised forecast of losses for the year. The shares of Mack Trucks fell by $1.125 each today, to $5.25, in over-the-counter trading.

title: King Broadcasting Sale Will Aid Environment
description: Priscilla Bullitt Collins, a member of the family that pioneered television in the Pacific Northwest, said this week that the Seattle-based King Broadcasting Company was up for sale and that about $100 million of the proceeds would be used to finance environmental causes.

title: Reviews/Art;   In Westchester, Fantasies of Odilon Redon
description: Odilon Redon's name does not often appear near the top of lists of 19th-century artists who influenced 20th-century art, but before the Surrealists - before many of the Surrealists were born, in fact - he was exploring the dark side of the subconscious.

title: Zulus vs. Mandela's Group: Strife Sets Back Both
description: In the string of black townships east and west of Johannesburg where factional fighting has spilled blood and shaken the nation's political kaleidoscope, the victories claimed by Zulu hostel dwellers seem ambiguous.

title: Editorial Notebook;   A Very Special Graveyard
description: For the last 127 years, the remains of a man named Pierre Toussaint have been lying in a cemetery in what is now New York City's Little Italy. If the State Supreme Court agrees, they are about to be disturbed. The Catholic Church wants to unearth the grave to make sure it does indeed embrace Mr. Toussaint, and to find out whether he is, perhaps, in a miraculous state of preservation.

title: Even as Profits Fall, Home Builder Plans to Gain
description: The Ryland Group, the nation's second-largest home builder, took analysts by surprise earlier this summer when it said it would earn less in the second quarter than it had expected.

title: Righetti Gains Vote of Support
description: Stump Merrill, the manager of the Yankees, said yesterday that he had full confidence in the ability of Dave Righetti, the left-handed closer who will become a free agent at the end of the season, and that he couldn't or wouldn't imagine a bullpen without him next season.

title: On Stage
description: Born of Faith

title: Market Place;   Why the Broad Selloff in Oil Stocks?
description: Even as commodity traders extended the upward march of oil prices in the futures market, investors continued to unload their holdings in oil companies and oilfield service companies, for the third consecutive day.

title: Cone Outhurled As Mets Fall 4 Out
description: He is round and chubby, and he wears eyeglasses now, and his left arm has pitched baseballs for 2,300 innings in the last 10 years in a career that seemed finished two summers ago.

title: Planes Ordered By AMR Eagle
description: The regional airline subsidiary of the AMR Corporation will become the largest operator of ATR aircraft in the world with its order this week for $1 billion worth of aircraft.

title: At the Movies
description: With Big Bugs

title: Agreement On Maalox Is Canceled
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that they were ending an agreement to transfer Rorer's Maalox antacid franchise in the United States to Procter & Gamble.

title: SmithKline Will Produce A Generic of Its Dyazide
description: The SmithKline Beecham Company said yesterday that it would bow to the inevitable and make its own lower-priced, generic copy of Dyazide, its widely used blood-pressure drug, which lost its patent protection three years ago. Rugby Laboratories will start selling the generic version for SmithKline in October.

title: Freer Economy Resisted in Uruguay
description: The six-month-old Government of President Luis Alberto Lacalle has joined the trend in South America toward reducing the state's role in the economy, but tough labor opposition means that each step will be hard fought.

title: Judge in North's Appeal Tainted Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTBALL: The Making of a Quarterback;   U.S.C.'s Marinovich Was Raised According to a Game Plan
description: The man is sitting in his office at a fitness center, looking at the figure on the television screen. The television is on a chair, resting upon the book ''Secrets of Soviet Sports Fitness and Training.'' The figure on the screen is throwing footballs, viewed from the side and the front in normal and slow motion.

title: Treasury Bonds Decline Further
description: The selloff in the credit markets continued yesterday and interest rates rose, as dealers reacted to a further rise in oil prices by marking down the price of most Treasury securities.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Quick Changes

title: News Corp.'s Profit Fell 27% in 4th Quarter
description: Hit by a worldwide advertising slump and heavy losses at its British satellite-television service, the News Corporation reported yesterday that its profits had fallen 27 percent in the fourth quarter and 43 percent for the fiscal year.

title: The Soviets: Steady, if Slow
description: Differences between the Soviet Union and the United States on when to use force to uphold economic sanctions against Iraq are troublesome. But they scarcely threaten the remarkable international consensus that increasingly isolates Saddam Hussein.

title: Restaurants
description: An American menu that ranges from the homey to dishes for the adventuresome.

title: Price of Being No. 1 Is Nothing to Cheer About;   Tomorrow's Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev Meets Afghan
description: Presidents Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Najibullah of Afghanistan met today and discussed the problems their nations face, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. They also discussed events in Iraq, but Tass provided few details.

title: Quiet Shift in Trading Rules On Japan's Stock Exchange
description: In an effort to bolster the battered stock market here, the Tokyo stock exchange and the Ministry of Finance have quietly stepped in and changed trading rules.

title: 92 Captive Aliens Are Rescued in a Raid
description: Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies raided a house here Wednesday night and rescued 92 illegal aliens who were being held captive by nine smugglers demanding ransom from the aliens' relatives, the authorities said today.

title: Edward Pattison, 58, Former Congressman And Lawyer in Troy
description: Edward W. Pattison, a former United States Representative from Troy, N.Y., died on Wednesday at his home in West Sand Lake, N.Y. He was 58 years old.

title: Economic Pessimism
description: A New York Times/CBS News Poll found that Americans had turned decidedly sour in their perceptions about the state of the economy. Such a sentiment frequently worsens the nation's actual economic condition.

title:
Low-Cost Housing in Trenton;

Project Blends With 19th-Century Area
description: LEAD: In an effort to create a prototype that can be replicated in other older cities, construction will begin this fall in downtown Trenton on 14 duplex houses designed to be affordable and to preserve the 19th-century character of a reviving neighborhood.

title: Revco Plans to Sell Southwest Stores
