description: Revco D.S. Inc. will sell 146 retail stores in the Southwest to a Maryland company in a divestiture plan announced in January. The stores, in Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and Colorado, are being sold to the RDS Acquisition Corporation, formed by a group of longtime retail drugstore executives, Revco said. The agreement also calls for RDS to lease Revco's distribution center in Glendale, Ariz. No other terms were disclosed. Revco, based in Twinsburg, is operating under creditor protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The RDS deal, which would complete Revco's 712-store divestiture program, must be approved by a bankruptcy court judge. A hearing has been set for Sept. 11. Revco has recently closed on its sale of 223 stores to the Jack Eckerd Corporation and on the sale of stores in Alabama and inventory to Big B Inc. and Harco Drug Inc. The bankruptcy court also approved the sale of Revco's Arkansas stores to Affiliated Food Stores Inc. on Aug. 14.

title: Robertson Group Holds 18.2% Stake
description: A group of dissident shareholders of the H. H. Robertson Company has raised its stake in the Pittsburgh-based maker of building materials to 18.2 percent from 15.9 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the dissident group said it would continue to oppose Robertson's planned acquisition of Ceco Industries, despite the recent death of Anthony Pedone, a New York investor who is one of its principals.

title: Nearly 2 Years Late, Air Force Receives New Presidential Jet
description: Nearly two years after the originally scheduled delivery date, a brand-new jumbo jet that will serve as President Bush's airplane was handed over to the Air Force by the Boeing Company today, the President's spokesman said.

title: Trump Keeps Shuttle; $10 Fare Rise Planned
description: Donald J. Trump said yesterday that the Trump Shuttle was no longer for sale. In a separate announcement, the airline said it would raise its fares by $10, effective Monday.

title: Luigi Cardinal Dadaglio, 75, Dies; Envoy Aided Spain in Transition
description: Luigi Cardinal Dadaglio, a Vatican diplomat who played a major role in liberalizing the Roman Catholic Church in Spain in the waning years of Franco's rule, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Rome at the age of 75. The Vatican said he died of a heart ailment.

title: At Stewart Airport, a Whiff of Success
description: Amid the military cargo planes and private jets that have long rolled along the runways at Stewart International Airport is a new addition these days: Boeing 727's.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Pakistan Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed on Sunday from 26th to 47th Streets from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. For a related street fair, Madison Avenue will be closed from 23d to 26th Streets from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M.

title: U.S. Already in a Recession, More Than 60 Percent Say
description: Americans have turned decidedly sour about the state of the economy, with the perception that the country is in a recession now shared by 6 out of 10 of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: KEY RATES
Report of Move By the Raiders
description: Al Davis was quoted in a published report today as having told a Raider team meeting it was ''100 percent certain'' the club would return to its old home in Oakland to play the 1990 season. The Raiders, however, vehemently denied it. ''We fully expect to play our 1990 home games in Los Angeles,'' said Al LoCasale, the Raiders' executive assistant. ''This sort of reporting makes it extremely difficult for us to sell tickets in Los Angeles.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 16 about Texas' use of prisoners in training dogs to track escaped inmates misstated the position taken by Ann Richards, the Democratic candidate for governor.

title: 'Junk Bond' Prices Plunge In Reaction to Stocks' Fall
description: Heavy selling sent prices of high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' sharply lower yesterday as traders reacted to the uncertainty in the Middle East and the sharp decline in the stock market.

title: New York a Jungle? Seems So to Monkeys
description: They went that-a-way. No, that-a-way. Well, then, maybe that-a-way. Catching monkeys in Queens is no easy task. Just ask the A.S.P.C.A. Or the police officer with the peach.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: From noon to 9 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, the Roots of American Music Festival is presenting an impressive array of blues and country performers, each giving a free one-hour show.

title: Mackintosh And Equity Plan Meeting
description: Actors' Equity and Cameron Mackintosh, the producer of ''Miss Saigon,'' agreed yesterday to meet in New York City in early September ''in an effort to establish a working relationship'' that would clear the way for the hit London musical to come to Broadway.

title: Volunteer Prosecutors End Backlog of Drug Cases
description: Faced with a growing backlog of drug cases, prosecutors in Washington State have adopted a novel tactic. They are deputizing volunteer lawyers from private firms to act as pro bono prosecutors.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Cheney Steps to Center of the Lineup
description: The Persian Gulf crisis has brought Defense Secretary Dick Cheney into new prominence in the White House, strengthening his relationships with President Bush and with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BAGHDAD WARNS DIPLOMATS AGAINST 'ACT OF AGGRESSION'; HUSSEIN SHOWS OFF HOSTAGES
description: Iraq warned the United States and more than two dozen other nations Thursday that if they challenged a deadline today and tried to keep their embassies in Iraq-occupied Kuwait open, as they have vowed to do, Baghdad would take it as an ''act of aggression.''

title: Eastern Planning Vacation Flights
description: Eastern Airlines said it would begin special vacation flights during the peak winter travel season to reward frequent business fliers. The airline said that in December it would start special ''Business Break'' flights from Atlanta to Hawaii, Mexico and the Caribbean to serve business fliers fulfilling free travel rewards during peak travel periods.

title: Conservative Says Sununu Assured Him on Souter
description: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, assured a conservative writer that President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, David H. Souter, would offer a strong conservative voice on the Court if confirmed, according to a memorandum made public today.

title: Yugo America Account To Buckley/DeCerchio
description: Buckley/DeCerchio Advertising got a great gift to celebrate its second anniversary - the $8 million to $10 million account for Yugo America cars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In a ceremony yesterday in Canberra, SIR GEOFFREY HOWE, the Deputy Prime Minister of Britain, handed over Australia's birth certificate, Reuters reported. The document, with its faded writing on vellum, officially ended Australia's status as a British colony in 1901 and recognized it as a nation. The country is a member of the Commonwealth.

title: Mets Never Got Over Kid and Mex
description: While the Mets sleepwalk through the West, the Kid and the Mex are looking better and better, in retrospect.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraqi TV Shows a Smiling Leader With Grim-Faced British Captives
description: In one of his few public appearances since the invasion of Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq held a strained meeting today with British hostages that was shown on Iraqi television and broadcast abroad.

title: Persian Gulf States Use Wealth Wisely
description: To the Editor:

title: Art, Too, Finds a Summer Home Outside Manhattan
description: New York may be the archetypal cosmopolitan city, but New Yorkers are notoriously provincial when it comes to acknowledging the extent of cultural life beyond the Hudson River or across the Throgs Neck Bridge. The fact is that while much of Manhattan dozes through August, museums and galleries at nearby points north, south, east and west offer the summer's most substantive and inventive exhibitions.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the Higher Education Assistance Foundation referred incorrectly in some editions to its chairman's role in any rescue of the troubled organization. The chairman, Richard C. Hawk, will participate in rescue negotiations. The article also misstated the business of the organization in some editions. It guarantees loans to trade school and college students; it does not make the loans themselves. And the article misstated the representation of trade school students among recipients of the foundation's loan guarantees; it is about one-third of the total, not most of them.

title: Review/Art;   New Jerseyans Examine the Road to Uniqueness
description: Ordinarily showcases for artists of a particular state or region are uneven affairs, lacking a theme, stylistic consistency or both. Such is not the case with ''A Force of Repetition,'' an exhibition at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton that is subtitled ''Contemporary Arts: The New Jersey Context.'' The 19 artists in the show all live or work in New Jersey, but they have more in common than that.

title: Joy Postponed in Mudville: Rainout for Little Leaguers
description: The most active people on the baseball field during a session of the Little League World Series today were the dozen groundskeepers who battled rain and mud in a losing cause.

title: And Now, A Show From Our Sponsor
description: Bozell, the giant New York advertising agency, has created a series of commercials for Valvoline Oil, but the real news is that the campaign will be broadcast next week during a special television program the agency also created for its client.

title: Foe Studying Takeover Act
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, one of the nation's largest and most influential institutional investors, said today that it was considering stepping up its challenge to Pennsylvania's anti-takeover law.

title: Up Anchor and Cast Off! A Nautical Night on the Town
description: World Yacht is a rather grandiose name for a craft that rarely ventures beyond the Statue of Liberty. Yet for a dazzling sightseeing tour of New York Harbor combined with music, dancing and a surprisingly good meal, World Yacht can be enthusiastically recommended.

title: 3 Dead and 12 Hurt in Houston Plane Crash
description: A private airplane crashed on takeoff and burned at Houston Intercontinental Airport today, killing three men and injuring 12 others, officials said.

title: Accounts
description: * Tasco Sales Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a distributor of consumer optics, to W.B. Doner and Co., Baltimore and St. Petersburg, Fla., for a reported billing of more than $1 million. Advertsing had previously been done in house.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc., Hercules, Calif., named Tony R. Brown vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Vehicle Sales Drop By 4.7%
description: Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 4.7 percent in mid-August, a decline that analysts attributed to record high sales a year ago.

title: Weekender Guide
description: Friday

title: Despite All, German Literati Keep Jousting
description: As the unification of the two Germanys approaches, it has become clear that one group in German society will remain bitterly divided among themselves: the writers of East Germany and West Germany.

title: Nippon Steel Unit
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation of Japan has formed a new American subsidiary, Librex Computer Systems Inc., to manufacture and market computer products. The unit, based in San Jose, Calif., plans to introduce its first products, notebook computers, in the fourth quarter of the year. Many Japanese companies in basic industries like steel and chemicals have been diversifying into electronics and biotechnology.

title: Water Under A-Plant Is Found to Be Tainted
description: Workers excavating storage tanks at a plant that processes uranium found levels of radioactive uranium in underground water that were as much as 35,000 times higher than Federal safety standards allow, officials said today.

title: TV Weekend;   Sex Talk, Jurisprudence and Big-Band Echoes
description: Tonight the Lifetime cable channel offers a civics lesson in the form of a drama, and some sex talk in the form of Bill Cosby and Dr. Ruth Westheimer.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Refugees Flooding Into Iraq-Jordan No Man's Land
description: Tens of thousands of people were caught today in a vast stretch of scorching desert no man's land between Iraq and Jordan as this country struggled to cope with a tidal wave of refugees fleeing the threat of war in Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about preliminary 1990 census figures misidentified a Census Bureau official. She is Deirdre Blackwood, a spokeswoman, not the director.

title: The Hitler Analogy
description: The most excruciating choice faced by ethical people is called triage. When a field hospital is overwhelmed with casualties, someone has to decide which of the wounded can be saved before allocating scarce medicine and treatment -denying it to those with little chance of survival.

title: Crude Oil Up to $31.93 A Barrel
description: Crude oil prices climbed 71 cents yesterday, reaching $31.93 a barrel. Analysts attributed the increase to momentum from Wednesday's leap of $2.51 and anxiety over today's deadline set by Iraq for closing all embassies in Kuwait.

title: T. W. McMahon, 69, Former Bank Executive
description: Thomas W. McMahon Jr., a former executive at the Chase Manhattan Bank, died yesterday at Union (N.J.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Union.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES faces a second operation on his right arm, which was broken earlier this summer when he fell off his pony during a polo match. Since undergoing surgery at Circencester Hospital, Wiltshire, after the fall, he has continued to have pain and it has led him to cancel public engagements.

title: New Nightmare: Peril of Floods Is Fires' Legacy
description: Those who were spared the fire now face the flood as the rainy season approaches, nearly three months after brush fires that devoured more than 400 homes left the hillsides above the city bare and dangerous.

title: After 6-Month Absence, Connors back Winning
description: In his first match since February, Jimmy Connors once again graced the stadium court at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, with his charismatic presence, defeating Robert Seguso, ranked 280th in the world, 6-2, 4-6, 6-0, yesterday in the second round of the W.C.T. Tournament of Champions.

title: Cuts at Unit Of Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. announced today that its Defense and Marine Systems unit plans to cut 120 of its 8,300 employees effective Sept. 6. The staff cuts are in preparation for the planned spinoff of the Defense and Marine Systems unit.

title: Priva Gross, Art Professor, 79
description: Priva Gross, a retired chairwoman of the art department of Queensborough Community College of the City University of New York, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan. She died of cancer, a spokesman for the family said. Professor Gross, whose specialty was medieval art, taught at the college for 20 years, retiring in 1981.

title: Slavomir Stracer, Prague Minister, 55
description: Slavomir Stracer, Czechoslvakia's Minister of Foreign Trade, died of a heart attack Tuesday. He was 55 years old.

title: Guards' Chief Says Dinkins Backs Inmates
description: As the third day of a water shortage on Rikers Island threatened the fragile mood there, relations between Mayor David N. Dinkins and the head of the correction officers' union turned even more bitter yesterday, with the union chief accusing the Mayor of siding with rebellious inmates because most of them are black.

title: New Office for Warner
description: Warner Brothers Inc. has agreed to move its film, television, comic book and licensing divisions from 75 Rockefeller Center to 140,000 square feet of office space at 1325 Avenue of the Americas. The new 35-story tower, which Warner will move into next spring, was developed by Edward J. Minskoff Equities Inc. It is slightly more than 60 percent leased. The new Warner lease, which was signed on Aug. 9, will give the entertainment company the right to occupy six floors for 20 years. As part of the deal, Warner was given time to design and build the floor space to suit its needs. Detailed terms of the lease were not disclosed.

title: Review/Film;   What Is Art? What Is Real? Where's the Bicycle?
description: A woman in a black-and-white movie called ''The Icicle Thief'' leaps into a river and emerges from a washing machine in a full-colored television commercial for detergent. A family half-watching this movie on television doesn't notice anything strange. Maurizio Nichetti's ''Icicle Thief,'' the work that includes the film within a film, the commercials within a film and more, sounds too strained and clever for its own good. But it is not some surreal, convoluted treatise on life and art. It is a slow-starting mild satire of television, which becomes an energetic and congenial farce.

title: Price of Being No. 1 Is Nothing to Cheer About
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film;   A Quirky Return to Hong Kong, the Last Frontier
description: In ''Life Is Cheap . . . but Toilet Paper Is Expensive,'' Wayne Wang, the Chinese-American film maker (''Chan Is Missing''), returns to Hong Kong, where he was born and where, it's said more than once in the film, ''Life is cheap, but toilet paper is expensive.''

title: Washington Talk;   How Old Votes Become New Political Liabilities
description: Recorded votes in Congress have a habit of becoming campaign nightmares. To avoid them, lawmakers often jockey for voice votes on controversial legislation, so as not to have to risk going on the record.

title: 'Micromachine' Project in Japan
description: Japan plans a multimillion-dollar research project into ''micromachines'' that can travel through blood vessels or look for faults in tiny crevices in jet engines and nuclear power plants, officials said today.

title: Let Postbabies Alone, You Neo-Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Richard Kaufman, a managing director of the Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Reservists to Learn Today if a Call-Up Changes Their Lives
description: After more than a week of uncertainty, thousands of military reservists throughout the country will begin hearing today whether they are among the more than 40,000 ordered to leave their jobs and homes and report for active duty.

title: Kohl Hails 'Day of Joy' for Reuniting Germans
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, a champion of German unification, basked in his triumph today with East Germany's decision to accede to the West on Oct. 3.

title: Judge Rejects Keating Suit; Sees 'Looting' of Lincoln
description: In a blistering opinion, a Federal judge today dismissed the lawsuit brought by Charles H. Keating Jr. to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. The judge said that the Government seizure of Lincoln was ''fully justified'' and that the actions of Mr. Keating and his associates amounted to a ''looting'' of the institution.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SEAN CONNERY, who quickened pulses in the 60's and 70's as James Bond and set a new standard as sophisticated-hero-with-humor, will be 60 years old tomorrow. And this fall, he will receive a rare tribute from the British Academy of Film and Television. Mr. Connery, who played Agent 007 in seven films, is only the third recipient of the Tribute Award, given previously to DIRK BOGARDE and JULIE ANDREWS.

title: Cancer Rates Are Rising Steeply For Those 55 or Older, Study Says
description: Cancer deaths among people 55 and older are climbing steeply and steadily, according to a new study. The increases are occurring in all six countries analyzed in the study: the United States, Japan and four European nations.

title: New Face: Wesley Snipes;   How an Actor Turned Into a Jazzman
description: When Wesley Snipes was preparing for the role of the jazz saxophonist Shadow Henderson in Spike Lee's film ''Mo' Better Blues,'' he studied the moves of some of the greatest jazz legends of all time.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Carlos Kleiber to Lead 'Rosenkavalier'
description: Carlos Kleiber will return to the Metropolitan Opera next month to conduct seven performances of ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' the Met announced yesterday. The West German conductor, who led critically acclaimed performances of ''La Traviata'' and ''Otello'' in the house last season, will replace James Levine, the Met's artistic director, who was scheduled to lead all seven performances of the Richard Strauss opera in September and October.

title: Airline Parts Investigation
description: An airplane parts distributor is being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Federal Aviation Administration for possibly misrepresenting the condition and source of the parts it sold to airlines, aircraft operators and other aviation vendors.

title: F.B.I. Man Tried Again on Spying Charges
description: The third trial of Richard W. Miller, the only agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who has ever been charged with spying against the United States, opened here on Wednesday.

title: Judge in Guam Rejects Strict Law on Abortion
description: A Federal district judge on the Pacific island of Guam has struck down the nation's most restrictive abortion law, one that directly challenged the constitutional right to abortion established in the landmark Roe v. Wade case.

title: A Reservist Waits
description: Ed Reynolds, a linebacker for the New England Patriots who is also a captain in the United States Army Reserves, was informed Wednesday that he could be called to action after President Bush announced a call-up of 40,000 reserve units because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Israelis' Fear of a Poison Gas Attack Is Growing
description: A senior civil defense official advised Israelis today to purchase a two-week stock of food for their homes, check fire extinguishers and buy masking tape so they can seal their windows against poison gas in case of attack.

title: A Light Rain and Heavy Trucks Entangle New York City Traffic
description: The fates, mainly in the form of a light rain and tractor-trailers, conspired against drivers in New York City yesterday.

title: Under-3-Hour N.F.L. Game? New Rules Make It Possible
description: When the Chicago Bears are hosts to the Los Angeles Raiders tonight at Soldier Field in a nationally televised preseason game, the Bears' quarterback, Jim Harbaugh, expects two patterns to continue: that the game will flow quickly and that his on-field play-calling responsibilities might increase.

title: Pirates Remain Merciless To Reds
description: Bobby Bonilla hit a grand slam to cap Pittsburgh's six-run fifth inning and Barry Bonds hit a two-run homer as the Pirates won their fifth in a row over Cincinnati, beating the Reds by 9-3 tonight in a battle of National League division leaders.

title: Review/Music;   Hearing and Seeing Things
description: Listening to ''Angels: Visions and Apparitions'' at Damrosch Park on Wednesday night, one longed for childhood. Give the very young a little melodrama, a spooky sound or two, even the barest of props, and innocent imaginations will have no trouble building their own private worlds of wonder.

title: Panel Asks Test Use of Cameras For Civil Cases in Federal Courts
description: Reversing a recommendation made last year, a five-judge panel appointed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today called for allowing television, radio and photographic coverage of civil proceedings in Federal courts in an experiment.

title: Review/Film;   With Brains and Skin, Another Cloaked Avenger Fights Evil
description: Of all this summer's movies, ''Darkman'' is the one aimed most directly at the audience for ''Batman.'' From its title to the organ-swelling music by Danny Elfman (who seems to have borrowed his own score for ''Batman''), on to its dim, foggy, comic-book look, this film lives in the shadow of last year's hit. ''Darkman'' invites the comparison, an odd strategy for an ambitious and self-consciously old-fashioned film whose hero spends much of his time looking like Claude Rains in ''The Invisible Man.''

title: THE MUSEUMS
description: Here are the addresses and hours for the exhibitions listed. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Long Island ''TWO DECADES OF AMERICAN ART: THE 60's AND 70's'' (through Sept. 3), Nassau County Museum of Fine Art, Northern Boulevard and Museum Drive, Roslyn Harbor. (516) 484-9337. Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.

title: Postal Service Unions Open Contract Talks
description: The Postal Service and unions representing its workers opened contract negotiations here today against a backdrop of the service's financial distress and labor's charges of mismanagement.

title: INSIDE
description: Abortion Law Struck Down

title: Phantom Panther in Vermont Evergreens;   Hunted in the West
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Panel Kept Steady Course in July
description: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded in July that inflation remained high enough to require that current interest rates be maintained despite a ''relatively slow'' economy, records released today show.

title: Harold Masursky, 66, a Leader In Mapping of Moon and Planets
description: Harold Masursky, the former chief scientist of the United States Geological Survey's Center of Astrogeology and a leader in lunar and planetary exploration, died yesterday at his home in Flagstaff, Ariz. He was 66 years old.

title: Moscow Journal;   To Leninists, It Smells Like a Purge
description: These are not easy times for the people charged with looking after Lenin's good name. His theories are falling into disrepute, his historic role is being re-examined and now, in a half dozen cities around the Soviet Union, his statues are being dismantled, not by bands of hooligans but by local city councils.

title: Gift to Regan Revives Debate on Business Donations
description: Reports this week that the State Comptroller had invested state money on the advice of consultants who had given money to his campaign have raised questions again about the influence of campaign contributions in government decisions.

title: Patents;   Simplifying the Output Of a Class of Compounds
description: Researchers at the Celgene Corporation in Warren, N.J., obtained patent approval this week for a method of determining whether molecules are, in effect, left-handed or right-handed.

title: Arts Appeal Is Rejected
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has rejected a request for an administrative appeal of the agency's decision last June to deny grants to four performance artists whose work has strong sexual content.

title: Wrong Fix for Public Schools
description: Oregon's citizens are now considering a state constitutional amendment that would give parents more flexibility to choose schools. While choice is to be encouraged, the Oregon plan would create a kind of free market among public, private and religious schools. That's dubious public policy.

title: Jewish Prisoners Lose Appeal Over Beards
description: Arizona's ban on prisoners' wearing beards has been upheld by a Federal appeals court over the objection of two Orthodox Jewish prisoners who contended that the policy discriminated against them.

title: Review/Films;   The Invincible Hero Who Hardly Growls
description: Early in Chuck Norris's new film, ''Delta Force 2,'' the star, who portrays an Army colonel named Scott McCoy, casually beats up some skinhead bullies who have been menacing the owner of a Chinese restaurant. When congratulated on winning the fight, he remarks: ''I didn't fight. I gave a motivational seminar.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amerifirst Bank, Miami, said it would eliminate 50 staff and management positions and would decrease its asset size.

title: Band Is Held Not Liable In Suicides of Two Fans
description: A judge ruled today that the British heavy-metal band Judas Priest was not responsible for the deaths of two youths who committed suicide after listening to the group's album ''Stained Class.''

title: Patents;   Protecting Child From Electric Plug
description: An inventor in Des Moines, Mark Menninga, obtained a patent this week on a magnetically controlled device to help parents ''baby proof'' their homes by blocking a child's access to electrical plugs.

title: Mapping of Venus Is Delayed For Study of Radio Problems
description: The start of the Magellan spacecraft's mapping survey of Venus will be delayed two or three weeks as engineers struggle to figure out how to prevent further communications losses and, in the event of recurrences, how to protect the craft from catastrophic damage.

title: Christian Science Case Tests Medical Belief;   State Intervention
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Not Count on Electricity to Reduce the Greenhouse Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: World Talks on Air Fares
description: Major airlines will meet next week to discuss international fare increases in response to soaring fuel prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis, an industry association said today.

title: The Oasis Crowd
description: He had been the first to get into Baghdad. That's why they called him Koppel of Arabia. The name had weight. Before he was Koppel of Arabia he had been just another Ted.

title: Red Sox Edge Blue Jays in Ninth
description: Mike Marshall's run-scoring single in the ninth inning broke a scoreless tie and the Boston Red Sox beat Toronto, 2-0, tonight to take a two-game lead over the Blue Jays in the American League East.

title: Did I Say Average? I Meant Superior
description: My brother Ted and his wife Lynn waited, eagerly checking the mail, for the results of their 3-year-old's first I.Q. test. They had paid the requisite $90 for a ''next-day'' mailing. But after 10 days, 2 phone calls and promises that it ''went out days ago,'' Ted sent a messenger to the Resource Center for Gifted Children to pick up the scores.

title: Letter: On Energy;   A Tax Would Make Oil Shock Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Found Dead in Burning Queens House in Apparent Murder-Suicide
description: A Queens man, enraged that his wife was about to take their children and leave him, shot the woman and two of the youngsters to death with a hunting rifle, set their house on fire and then killed himself, the police said.

title: Leading Executive and 2 in Family Are Killed in Boston Plane Crash
description: A development company executive and his wife who were flying their daughter to meet a commercial flight at Logan International Airport crashed their twin-engine private airplane into a crowded residential neighborhood here today, setting two houses on fire. The three people on the plane all died in the crash.

title: John M. Karns Jr., 62, Illinois Appeals Judge
description: John Marshall Karns Jr., a retired Justice of the Illinois Appellate Court, died Wednesday at Memorial Hospital in Belleville, Ill. He was 62 years old and lived in Belleville. His wife, Joan, said he died of lung cancer.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: 500 Are Detained in Burmese Capital
description: About 500 people have been detained for questioning by the military authorities in the last two weeks in the capital of Myanmar, formerly Burma, diplomats said today.

title: About New York; It's Not Exactly Dial-a-Quote, But It's Close
description: This is about people who take down everything that Phil and Oprah and Geraldo say. And Sam and Diane (the Sam and Diane on ''PrimeTime Live,'' not the Sam and Diane on ''Cheers''). Every ''uh-huh,'' every ''well, now.'' So we will take extra-careful notes here. Wouldn't want to misquote the quoters. Quoter No. 1 is Jim Smith. He owns Journal Graphics, which transcribes television shows. He says that some viewers call his 800 number, send in their money and then have the nerve to complain that what he sends back in the mail is not a videocassette but something that has to be read the old-fashioned way, like a play without stage directions. Soliloquies in a Journal Graphics transcript are never preceded by words like ''Donahue, running up the aisle.''

title: AN IRISH HOSTAGE FREED IN LEBANON
description: An Irish hostage held for more than four years in Lebanon was released Friday night, in what could be a step by Iran's Islamic Government toward warmer relations with the West.

title: Roosevelt Watson, A Freed Defendant In 70's Slaying Case
description: Roosevelt Watson, one of five black youths who won dismissal of murder charges in a widely publicized case in rural Dawson, Ga., in the mid-1970's, died Tuesday at his home in Albany, Ga. He was 34 years old.

title: U.S. Bank Regulators Challenged By the Co-op Market in New York
description: Federal regulators, fresh from their experience taking over distressed property elsewhere in the nation, are facing new legal challenges and deep resentment as they move into the troubled market for New York area cooperative apartments.

title: Tadzhikstan Declares Sovereignty
description: The Soviet Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan declared sovereignty today, becoming the 13th of the 15 Soviet republics to make some move toward greater autonomy, a news service reported.

title: U.N. Reviews Proposal
description: The 15 members of the Security Council opened formal consultations today on a proposed resolution that would allow countries to halt ships suspected of violating the trade embargo against Iraq.

title: To Insure Toy Safety, U.S. Shifts Its Attack
description: The Federal Government shifted its strategy on toy safety this week, filing lawsuits against seven major companies in the United States that distribute or sell imported toys.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: Golden Nugget
description: Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Golden Nugget Inc., has lowered his stake in the Las Vegas, Nev., casino concern to 31.1 percent from 32 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Wynn gave no reason for the sale of the shares. Golden Nugget has 16.5 million shares outstanding. Between July 3 and July 11, Mr. Wynn sold 150,000 Golden Nugget shares on the open market for prices ranging from $34.50 to $35.625.

title: G.E. Announces Plans To Cut More Jobs
description: The General Electric Company said today that it would cut more jobs because of a shrinking military budget.

title: Christian Science Case Tests Medical Belief
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Pakistan Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 26th to 47th Streets from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. For a related street fair, Madison Avenue will be closed from 23d to 26th Streets from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Saratoga's Backyard Success
description: Business at Saratoga this month should have been rotten. The economy is receding. Tourism in the area is down. The racing is indifferent and the weather is as unpredictable as the steeplechasers.

title: Bond Yields Rise in Volatile Trading
description: Long-term Treasury bond yields continued to edge higher yesterday in a trading session marked by volatile price swings. The Treasury debt market was buoyed after the opening by weakness in oil prices and the absence of any signifcant worsening of the situation in the Middle East, as well as by the expected slowing in the growth rate of the second-quarter gross national product.

title: An Iraqi Visitor
description: My Iraqi visitor turned up again. Six years ago he came by, out of the blue, to ask why the Western press failed to tell about the horrors and brutalities of Saddam Hussein's regime, why America only paid attention to oil and strategy in the Persian Gulf and ignored the human dimension.

title: Congress Gets Bush Pay Plan
description: President Bush today sent Congress his recommendation that Federal employees receive a 3.5 percent pay rise on Jan. 1. Congress has until the end of September to approve the plan or substitute its own. The House has approved a 4.1 percent raise. The President's advisers had recommended raises of 22 percent to 40 percent to keep Civil Service pay abreast of salaries in the private sector.

title: Quiet Race Worries Connecticut Democrats
description: In two weeks Democrats will choose in a primary for governor between a challenger whose strategy for victory counts on as few voters as possible going to the polls and a convention-endorsed candidate who rarely acknowledges there is a race at all.

title: Redskin Enters Plea
description: In Houston yesterday, the Washington Redskins receiver Ricky Sanders pleaded not guilty to charges stemming from a May 1 fight with a parking-lot attendant outside a nightclub. The attendant said Sanders drove a Cadillac into him after the two argued about Sanders's hubcaps.

title: Apple Listing in Tokyo
description: The Tokyo stock exchange plans to list shares of Apple Computer Inc. on its foreign section in mid-September, the exchange said. Apple, a United States personal computer and software maker listed on the over-the-counter market, will not issue new shares after it is listed in Tokyo, the exchange said. The Nomura Securities Company will be the lead manager for the listing.

title: Telescope Construction Cleared Over Objections
description: The United States Forest Service has authorized the University of Arizona to build three telescopes on Mount Graham after determining that the project's possible harm to an endangered subspecies of squirrel had been studied sufficiently.

title: Kuwaitis Recount Gunfire and Terror
description: Iraqi soldiers are shooting at carloads of people trying to drive overland out of Kuwait, while occasional attacks on the occupied forces continue in urban areas, according to two Kuwaitis who fled to Saudi Arabia.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Pearl Bailey in some editions last Saturday and some on Sunday referred incompletely to her co-stars in the Broadway musical ''Hello, Dolly!,'' and a correction in this space on Tuesday misidentified the actor with whom she first performed the role. Cab Calloway starred with Miss Bailey in a 1967 staging of the musical, and Billy Daniels appeared with her in a 1975 revival.

title: CHEMICAL ACCIDENT IN URALS HURTS 110
description: An explosion at a chemical factory injured more than 100 people and polluted the drinking water of the city of Ufa in the Ural mountains, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News Poll on Americans' view of the economy referred incorrectly in some copies to the segment who believe the nation is now in a recession. It was slightly more than 6 in 10, not ''nearly.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: LIV ULLMANN and JEREMY IRONS won the Francois Truffaut Award at the Giffoni Film Festival recently. The jury was made up of 120 children. The festival, near Salerno, Italy, is devoted to films for children 10 14 years old. Ms. Ullmann won for her 10 years of work with children as good-will ambassador for Unicef and as vice president of the International Rescue Committee. Mr. Irons won for his film ''Danny and the Champion of the World,'' with his 11-year-old son, SAM IRONS.

title: Tamzin Anderson Is a Bride
description: Tamzin Ellen Anderson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael W. Anderson of Bozeman, Mont., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Andrew White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard D. White Jr. of New York. The Rev. Charles Willming performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church. Mrs. White, 23 years old, expects to graduate from Montana State University in June. Her father is a junior high school mathematics teacher and a high school tennis coach in Bozeman, where her mother, Ellen G. Anderson, is an elementary-school teacher. The bridegroom, 26, is the day manager at the Pickle Barrel Restaurants in Bozeman. He graduated from the University of California at Santa Barbara. His mother, Marjorie P. White, is a printmaker and his father is a sculptor.

title: Review/Film;   2 Garbage Men and 1 Corpse
description: ''Men at Work,'' which opened here yesterday, is a good-natured lowbrow farce about two southern California garbage men who dream of opening their own surf shop. It's also about toxic waste, political corruption, a dead body with its face hidden behind a Nixon mask and two dumb cops.

title: Forces Committed to Saudi Arabia and Nearby Waters
description: FROM THE UNITED STATES

title: 5 South Carolina Lawmakers Indicted in Corruption Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury here indicted five state legislators today on charges of selling their votes to undercover Government operatives who were seeking their support for a bill authorizing parimutuel horse and dog racing in South Carolina.

title: Southwest Boomed in 80's, Census Finds
description: The five states whose deserts and canyons form the vast expanse of the American Southwest have seen some of the nation's sharpest increases in population in the last decade, preliminary 1990 census figures show. A boom in the Las Vegas area raised Nevada's population by nearly 50 percent.

title: Sergei Dovlatov, 48, Soviet Emigre Who Wrote About His Homeland
description: Sergei Dovlatov, a leading Soviet emigre writer noted for the laconic irony and graceful irreverence of his stories about his homeland, died of heart failure yesterday at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 48 years old.

title: Gooden Pitches Strongly As Mets Defeat the Dodgers
description: The Mets finally found their sense of timing tonight when they edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, on the powerful pitching by Dwight Gooden and two home runs by Kevin McReynolds, and moved to within three games of the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League East.

title: Yankees Start Looking to Future
description: In the final weeks of their dry season, the Yankees seem ready to begin laying more groundwork for the future. They are talking with other clubs about trades, pondering the possibility of moving veterans and looking closely at prospects who might offer help as early as next summer. They are also still losing. For the second time in two nights, they were beaten by the team they must catch and pass to avoid finishing last in the American League East. The Milwaukee Brewers turned a fifth-inning wild pitch by Tim Leary into the deciding run and handed the Yankees a 1-0 loss last night at the Stadium.

title: Football;   After Jets Tonight, Will There Be a Tomorrow?
description: When the Giants play the Jets on Saturday night in the teams' annual preseason game at Giants Stadium, it may be the last or almost the last hurrah for one or both of the Giants' recent running-back heroes.

title: Oil? Nation's Utilities Are Not So Worried
description: Whatever damage the run-up in oil prices inflicts on the economy as a whole, the effect on electricity bills is likely to be relatively modest. Of the fuel-consuming industries, the electric utilities have been the most successful in learning the lessons of the first two oil shocks, in the 1970's, and finding other sources.

title: Patents;   Cork Has 2 Chambers To Purify Champagne
description: Ernest Gladstone, a retired teacher in Brooklyn, has patented a two-chambered cork that he says makes it possible to purify champagne without exposing it to the air.

title: Jefferey Bucholtz, Designer of Homes And Apartments, 33
description: Jefferey D. Bucholtz, an architectural designer, died Thursday at the Davies Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 33 years old. Michael Goldblum, a colleague of his, said he had died of AIDS.

title: Guilty in Money Laundering
description: A Colombian reputed to be the financial wizard for the Medellin drug ring pleaded guilty on Thursday to charges that he helped launder more than $1.2 billion in illegal drug profits. The plea was entered by Eduardo Martinez-Romero before Federal District Judge William C. O'Kelley. Mr. Martinez could be sentenced to up to 30 years in prison without parole and fined up to $4 million.

title: Griffey, Put on Waivers, Could Join Mariners
description: The Cincinnati Reds agreed yesterday to put Ken Griffey Sr. on waivers, clearing the way for him to team with his son, Ken Jr., on the Seattle Mariners.

title: KEY RATES
Nets Sign Rookie Guard
description: The Nets have signed a rookie free-agent guard, Doug Lee, who averaged 27 points a game at Purdue in the 1986-87 season.

title: At Payola Trial, Primer on Forms and Mechanics
description: Packets of cocaine hidden in audiocassette cases. Thousands of dollars handed over furtively in the men's room of Hollywood restaurants. Record album jackets stuffed with cash and shipped by Federal Express to radio station executives.

title: Phantom Panther in Vermont Evergreens
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You ask contractors to open jobs to women, and they say they'd love to but that the unions don't have any women.

title: Generals Favor 'No Holds Barred' By U.S. if Iraq Attacks the Saudis
description: Top American military commanders here are recommending that Washington respond to any Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia with a punishing, all-out attack against Iraqi military forces and installations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM PENTLAND, the former husband of ROSEANNE BARR, has filed a lawsuit seeking at least $15 million from her and $3 million from her husband, TOM ARNOLD. Mr. Pentland, whose 16-year marriage to Ms. Barr ended in divorce in January, is represented by MARVIN MITCHELSON. Ms. Barr's lawyer is ARLENE COLMAN-SCHWIMMER.

title: Man Suffocates As Intruders Hold a Party
description: Four people, three of them teen-agers, were charged yesterday with murdering a mentally retarded man who suffocated inside a closet while they caroused in his Bronx apartment for nearly six days and sold his belongings, the police said.

title: U.S. Contends Nassau Broke Pact on Sludge
description: Saying that Nassau County had broken an agreement that would have enabled it to meet a deadline to stop dumping sewage sludge in the ocean by the end of 1991, Federal prosecutors today asked a Federal judge to declare the county in contempt of court.

title: Chief of Correction Faults Rikers's Way Of Hiring Officers
description: New York City Correction Commissioner Allyn R. Sielaff yesterday painted a bleak portrait of Rikers Island as a violent institution protected by correction officers who slipped through lax hiring standards and where prisoners are rarely punished for assaulting officers and one another.

title: Air Force Calls Up Reserves in 6 States
description: In the first round of reserve call-ups, the Air Force activated units today in six states to augment flight crews shuttling cargo and equipment to the Persian Gulf region.

title: G.N.P. Rate For 2d Period A Weak 1.2%
description: In what many analysts see as a further sign of a weakened economy, the Government confirmed today that growth was listless even before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait jolted oil prices.

title: Bridge
description: A basic principle of bidding that is learned by beginners and observed quite strictly by experts is this: If your partner shows a five-card major suit and you have three-card support, you must show it, either immediately or on the next round, unless perhaps you uncover a good fit elsewhere.

title: Showing His Old Form, McEnroe Beats Gilbert
description: For at least one satisfying match, on center court here in the quarterfinals of the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup today, the 31-year-old John McEnroe looked like the McEnroe of old, serving convincingly, returning the ball effectively and volleying with authority.

title: James Wine, 71, Church Leader Active in '60 Kennedy Campaign
description: James W. Wine, a Protestant layman who played a major role in defusing anti-Catholic sentiment in the Presidential campaign of John F. Kennedy, died Thursday at his home in Linden, Va. He was 71 years old.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE SAID TO RULE OUT A RATE SHIFT NOW
description: The Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to make no changes in interest rates until the Middle East crisis quieted down and a clearer picture emerged of its effect on the economy.

title: Reserves' Quick Shift: Civvies to Olive Drab
description: He spent Thursday night in Greenwich Village, shopping for clothes - just another 19-year-old. He got the call at 11:30 P.M. By this afternoon he was in an olive drab flight suit with an American flag insignia on one arm, checking in at the Air National Guard base here, 60 miles north of New York City.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Winter, in Advance
description: The warm, dry weather that usually arrives in the Northeast around Labor Day, ending summer's fiercest heat and humidity, offers ideal conditions for sealing and preparing outdoor surfaces for fall and winter.

title: Hong Kong Outlook
description: The Government of Hong Kong today cut its estimate of economic growth for the year and said conditions could deteriorate further, adding that a slowdown seemed likely even before the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Oil Prices Fall Back $1 a Barrel
description: Prices of crude oil fell $1.02 a barrel in the futures market yesterday, and prices for gasoline and home heating oil eased slightly. Analysts and brokers said jittery commodity traders cashed in some profits before the close of a landmark week in the oil markets.

title: Oil vs. Gas: A Question of Cost Again
description: The contest between oil and natural gas for supremacy in the home heating market has been long and bitter. Now the confrontation between the United States and Iraq has made it more intense.

title: Sign Vandal Case Dismissed
description: A judge today dismissed charges against a Greenwich millionaire arrested in July in the spray painting of a real-estate sign that he contended was offensive and illegal. The 64-year-old man, Rene Anselmo, who was charged with third-degree criminal mischief, said that he thought he had made his point. ''I'm going to concentrate on working on a new ordinance that would totally ban the signs,'' he said.

title: Ambase Accepts A Takeover Bid
description: The Ambase Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent accepting an investor group's offer to acquire 50.1 percent of the company for $4 a share, or about $68 million. The group, led by Sequoia Associates and including several former top executives of the insurance industry, said that if the deal was consummated, Ambase's chairman, president and chief executive, George T. Scharffenberger, would step down. He will probably be replaced as chairman by Donald MacNaughton, a member of the investor group and a former top executive at the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: Gorbachev Sends a Signal Ending Hesitation at U.N.
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today that the Iraqi leader will face additional international sanctions if he does not withdraw his troops from Kuwait and release foreign nationals under his control.

title: Pact for Chargers' Seau
description: Junior Seau, the linebacker from Southern Cal who was the San Diego Chargers' first-round draft pick, has agreed to the club's final offer of a five-year contract worth a reported $4.525 million.

title: Disadvantage for U.S. in the Desert: Fewer Tanks
description: If the crisis in the Persian Gulf should lead to full-scale war, United States and Iraqi forces would square off in a desert four times the size of France in a battle unlike any other in American history. While most American, British and Israeli military experts say United States aircraft in the region could quickly smash an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, American counterattacks on the ground might be hindered by a relative lack of armored vehicles, without which ground troops in a desert environment can do little more than defend static positions.

title: College Football;   How the Other Half Lives
description: There are no white lines to define the shaggy practice field at Miles College. As his players scrimmaged recently in the draining Alabama heat, the Golden Bears' new coach, Jerome Barkum, determined what was out of bounds and how far to go for a first down.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Prime Minister MICHAEL MANLEY of Jamaica was released from a Manhattan hospital yesterday, nine days after doctors removed a benign growth from his prostate.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pop Life column on Wednesday about the Neville Brothers misinterpreted a reference to Angola in ''Sons and Daughters,'' a poem by Art Neville that is on the group's new album, ''Brother's Keeper.'' The reference is to the Louisiana State Penitentiary at Angola, La., not to the African country.

title: At Last, the Police Are Back on Track
description: LEAD: While New York City struggles with the many problems at its troubled and overcrowded Rikers Island jail, the Police Department is improving its capacity to reduce the prison population by the best means possible: crime prevention.

title: Data General To Cut 2,000
description: The Data General Corporation said it would lay off more than 2,000 workers, or 4.9 percent of its work force, in the next several weeks.

title: Putting Up Office Tower, Women Break Sex Barrier
description: Vickie Barnes is putting up a 27-story glass and granite office building here with 43 other women and about 600 men. An apprentice carpenter, she earns $13.62 an hour, enough to support herself and her 12-year-old daughter.

title: Syrian Gains Are Seen In the Shift Toward U.S.
description: What has led President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, long viewed in the West as an intractable adversary, to align his nation with the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis?

title: Pretoria Takes Broad Steps To End Factional Fighting
description: In a crackdown on factional bloodletting that has claimed more than 500 lives in 11 days, South African authorities today designated 27 black townships ''unrest areas'' and gave the police wide powers to arrest and search people without warrant and to seize weapons.

title: Toeing Party Line, Chinese Films Falter
description: Ideological purity in the arts always exacts a price, but in China's film industry, which was blossoming before political hard-liners took control of the Government, it is proving ruinous.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CURTIS MAYFIELD, paralyzed by an accident at a concert in Brooklyn on Aug. 13, left Kings County Hospital yesterday for the Shepherd Spinal Center in Atlanta, near his home, according to a spokesman for Kings County Hospital. The 48-year-old singer-songwriter was accompanied by his wife and son.

title: Jordan Keeps Border Open; Thousands of Refugees Near
description: Facing a relentless wave of refugees from Kuwait and Iraq, Jordan today gave up the idea of closing the desert border crossing that has become the main escape route in the gulf crisis.

title: The World v. Saddam Hussein
description: Cornered and desperate, Saddam Hussein now lashes out against diplomacy itself. His troops lawlessly threaten foreign embassies in Kuwait while his regime detains U.S. diplomats and dependents who were promised a safe exit from Baghdad. The most telling condemnation comes from Moscow, Iraq's longtime ally. An outraged Mikhail Gorbachev warns that an Iraqi failure to heed United Nations resolutions would ''inevitably compel the Security Council to adopt appropriate additional measures.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture on the Law page yesterday with an article about volunteer prosecutors was published in error.

title: S.I. Port's Fate Is Muddled by the Mideast Crisis
description: Before the Persian Gulf crisis began, the Staten Island home port was almost ready to open, or almost ready to close, depending on who was asked. Now, the prospects for the port are even more confused.

title: CHRONICLE
description: B. DON MAGNESS, chairman of the Miss Texas Scholarship Pageant for 20 years, resigned Thursday night after reports of impropriety. He told the pageant's board of directors that he was unfairly depicted in a Life magazine article as a dirty old man who made lewd comments to pageant contestants.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: LITTLE LEAGUE

title: The Golf Crisis: It's Getting Rough
description: LEAD: Nothing is more sacred to Americans than the summer vacation.

title: Jets-Giants Rivalry a Subject for the Scrapbooks
description: Has the Jets-Giants rivalry, which began at the Yale Bowl in August 1969, the weekend of Woodstock, finally gone the way of bell-bottom jeans?

title: Convicted Northwest Pilots Plead Guilty to a 2d Charge
description: Two of the three members of a Northwest Airlines crew who were convicted in a Federal court this week of flying their plane and its 73 passengers while drunk have pleaded guilty to a second charge growing out of the incident.

title: For The Iraqi Ruler, Variations on a Name
description: In reports on the crisis in the Persian Gulf, many Western news organizations and many officials have referred to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as Saddam, or President Saddam. Other organizations, including The New York Times, call him President Hussein. The inconsistency derives from the Iraqi President's official name change in 1977.

title: GORBACHEV WARNS BAGHDAD TO BACK OFF OR U.N. WILL ACT; IRAQIS RING KUWAIT MISSIONS
description: President Bush made a big gain today in his effort to isolate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union warned Baghdad that he was ready to back additional measures to toughen the United Nations embargo against Iraqi commerce.

title: Review/Theater;   Poetry and Surreal Imagery In Praise of the Mambo Beat
description: In a poem by Pedro Pietri that runs like a hallucinatory thread through the first half of the revue ''Mondo Mambo,'' the Puerto Rican-born writer compiles a series of surreal images to evoke the transcendental mysteries of mambo music. The train of associations, recited by Edwin de Asis, begins with images of an ''absent-minded alarm clock,'' rain that falls upward and ''colors that no one can name.'' As the narration continues, the imagery turns religious. The mambo beat is praised as a ''pure and supernatural rhythm that can keep you alive.''

title: Amid Crisis, West Meets Mideast in Saudi Arabia
description: The arrival of American and foreign troops in Saudi Arabia and the flood of Kuwaiti refugees here are helping to pry open Saudi society, which has been hermetically sealed.

title: Religion Notes
description: Woman to Head Alliance An American Presbyterian scholar has become the first woman to head a worldwide communion of churches. Dr. Jane Dempsey Douglass was elected president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, an association of churches rooted in the 16th-century Reformation theology of John Calvin.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.29 percent this week, up from 10.05 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest level since a similar 10.29 percent rate was posted last June 1. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.36 percent, up from 8.31 percent last week.

title: Dow Gains On Peace Sentiment
description: Stock prices advanced briskly yesterday, posting their first gain after three days of heavy losses.

title: Pennsylvania's Abortion Restrictions Are Struck Down by a Federal Judge
description: A Federal district judge in Reading, Pa., today struck down several provisions of a restrictive abortion law that was enacted in Pennsylvania last year with the intention that it become a vehicle for the Supreme Court to reconsider the issue of abortion.

title: Texas and Texas A&M Are Staying in S.W.C.
description: Texas and Texas A&M announced today that they would stay in the Southwest Conference, the league the two schools helped form 76 years ago.

title: Baxter Is Selling Stake in Genetics
description: Baxter International Inc., the Deerfield, Ill., hospital supply concern, said it intends to sell its 7.3 percent stake in Genetics Institute Inc., a biotechnology concern in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Officer Is Cut in Face by Disturbed Woman
description: An emotionally disturbed woman jabbed a broken bottle into the face of a police officer in Harlem yesterday, slashing his cheek, the police said.

title: Develop a Seaplane To Deploy Our Troops
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncovered Short Sales Decline 0.5% on Nasdaq
description: But many other analysts contend that a large short position is a bullish sign for the stock market, because short-sellers must eventually buy back the stock they have sold.

title: 3,000 West African Troops Anchor Off Liberian Capital
description: Six ships carrying 3,000 West African soldiers arrived off Monrovia today, but did not attempt to dock as gunfire erupted in the port of the Liberian capital.

title: Sematech Gains In Chip-Making
description: Officials at Sematech, the private industry and Federal Government chip-making consortium, said yesterday that they were now making semiconductor chips with half-micron-wide circuit lines on American-made equipment.

title: Guilty Plea in '88 Rampage
description: A Bronx teen-ager pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to eight robbery and burglary charges stemming from his part in murder, rape and robbery by five young men two years ago. The teen-ager, Brandon Campos, who was 15 at the time, admitted helping to loot an apartment in Brooklyn after a group of companions strangled a construction foreman in the Bronx. The youths took the dead man's keys, rode the subway to Brooklyn, entered his apartment, raped his wife and teen-age daughter, and burglarized the apartment. The teen-ager faces six years in prison.

title: Soviets Verify Big Oil Find
description: The Soviet Union confirmed today that it had found two oilfields and the world's biggest offshore gas field in the Barents Sea, the scene of costly but until now fruitless exploration efforts in recent years.

title: Activated Reservists Report for Gulf Duty
description: As the call-up of reservists began, the Pentagon yesterday discarded a policy that had prohibited journalists from publishing or broadcasting the names and hometowns of enlisted men and women stationed in the Persian Gulf region.

title: Mexican Democracy Means Brokered Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A listing of museum hours in Weekend yesterday with articles about museums near Manhattan misstated the visiting days and the admission policy for the Newark Museum. It is open from noon to 5 P.M. Wednesday to Sunday, not on Tuesdays. Admission is free, not $1.

title: Oil May Affect Price of Tires
description: Further jumps in crude oil prices could push up retail prices of American-made tires in coming months, a trade official of a rubber trade group said today.

title: Offering by Sun May Be Halted
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it might not proceed with previously announced plans for a stock offering because the price of its stock had declined as a result of the selloff on the stock market amid the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Judge Antoinette L. Dupont Marries Judge A. W. Cretella Jr. in New London
description: Chief Judge Antoinette Loiacono Dupont and Judge Albert W. Cretella Jr. of the Connecticut State Appellate Court were married yesterday in New London. The Rev. Joseph Castaldi officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. Felix H. McGuire and the Rev. Vincent E. Lyddy.

title: Challenging Nike, Rights Group Takes a Risky Stand
description: For days now, the image of Jesse Jackson has hovered over the Rev. Tyrone Crider as he sits in the Chicago offices of Operation PUSH, devising a boycott of Nike Inc., the athletic shoe giant. For Mr. Crider and the civil rights organization he heads, it is their biggest test since Mr. Jackson, the group's founder and soul, left for Washington last year.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Watching Interest Rates
description: International events are now influencing the interest rates that banks pay more than the economy is influencing them. Yields on certificates of deposit have been falling for more than three months, but the Middle East situation could mean higher yields in the near future. Bank rate analysts suggest watching rates on certificates of deposit closely for the next three weeks and holding some money in a federally insured bank money market account to be ready to shift to C.D.'s if interest rates rise. Investors might also want to split money between short-term certificates of deposit and money market accounts. Here are some current national average yields on certificates of deposit and the comparable yields in early May. $ Maturity Current Yield Yield on May 9 Money market account 6.08% 6.23% Six months 7.71% 8.01% One year 7.86% 8.08% 2 1/2 years 7.93% 8.20% 5 years 8.04% 8.24%

title: Poles Tell of Americans Held at Iraq Chemical Plant
description: Some Americans in Iraq are being held at a chemical factory near the Syrian border that also produces enriched uranium, according to Polish workers who witnessed the arrival of the hostages.

title: Review/Music;   Mozart and Beethoven, Together but Far Apart
description: Some 40 years of history separated the two halves of Thursday's Mostly Mozart concert by the Takacs String Quartet. Yet the musical space between the two introductory Mozart pieces and Beethoven's A minor Quartet at the end seemed far wider.

title: Your Money;   Aiding Charities And One's Family
description: An elderly widow who recently came to see Ilene T. Nadel, president of Creative Philantrophic Resources in New York, had needs similar to those of many of her generation: She wanted to be sure her grandchild got a good education; she wanted to provide a nice memorial for her husband, a Holocaust victim, and she wanted as little of her money as possible to go to taxes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST, 25, 1990
description: The Economy

title: 2 Court Rulings Prevent Release Of Mexican Doctor Held by U.S.
description: A pair of court rulings in the last two days seem to assure that a Mexican doctor charged in the slaying of an American drug agent will remain in Federal custody while the Government pursues its appeal of a judge's order that he be returned to Mexico.

title: 2 Soviet Athletes Out
description: Two female Soviet athletes - the former world high-jump champion Tamara Bykova and the heptathlete Larisa Nikitina - have been suspended for using banned drugs at the Goodwill Games last month in Seattle and will miss next week's European championships, the Soviet Athletics Federation said in Moscow yesterday.

title: Books of the Times;   How the U.S. Decides It's Times to Go to War
description: Constitutional Diplomacy

title: Adviser Loses $100 Million
description: A financial adviser afraid to face his clients admitted in a videotape message that he lost about $100 million of investors' money by making risky trades in stock options.

title: Going Private Is a Public Affair
description: Under the plan of the Mexican Government to privatize its huge national telephone company, the winning bidder will have to agree to increase the number of household phone lines from 5 million to 10 million over the next four years; reduce installation time from 18 months to 6, and shrink the wait for a dial tone from 30 seconds to under 10.

title: G.M. Sets Incentive Offer On Many of Its 1991 Models
description: In a move that analysts said amounted to a concession that its new cars and trucks may be priced too high in a soft market, the General Motors Corporation said today that it was offering incentives on many of its 1991 models, including several that go on sale this month for the first time.

title: Dirty Minds, or Little Minds?
description: There is a scene in Shakespeare's ''Henry the Fifth'' in which Katharine, the French princess, asks someone described as ''an old Gentlewoman'' for an English lesson. The ensuing instructions, in schoolgirl French, are funny - and as anyone knows who has seen them performed with vivid gestures in Kenneth Branagh's movie version of the play, even ribald - a dazzling exercise in double entendre, even to one who doesn't grasp all the dialogue. Obscene? Most theatergoers don't think so, but some might. And there's the rub.

title: I.B.M. to Offer New Computers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce on Sept. 5 its plans for introducing mainframe computers twice as powerful as the current systems, a market research group said.

title: Bucket Danger Warning
description: Warning that household buckets pose a serious drowning threat to small children, Government and industry are making available labels alerting the public to the hazard.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Campbell Enlists in Camden's Comeback
description: LEAD: Camden, a bustling industrial port that fell into decline decades ago and became the poorest of New Jersey's cities, is slowly rebounding. And nowhere are the traces of hope more evident than along its mile-long Delaware River waterfront.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Visualize a room with plenty of capacious, comfortable, welcoming sofas and chairs, not all of them occupied. In this room there are, too, a few straight-back chairs and someone is sitting in one of them. Someone with a bad back? Wrong guess. This person has a wonderful, healthy, much-to-be envied back. The straight-back chair is being sat on by choice.

title: Paul Moore Weds Elizabeth Brooks
description: Elizabeth Ann Brooks and Paul Philip Moore were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., by the Rev. Paul Daleo.

title: Detroit: America's Best Source of Oil
description: At least one fact has become inescapably clear during the past two weeks. The world cannot afford a continuation of the steady increase in dependence on Persian Gulf oil. Means are available to reverse this trend. We can make our cars, buildings and industry far more fuel-efficient than they are today. The question is whether there is the political will to do so.

title: When Children Shoot Children
description: The kids don't have .38's anymore. They have Uzis. - Jose Resto, resident of a crime-plagued Bronx community after neighbors stabbed a robbery suspect to death.

title: A Place for Hearing and Reading Poetry
description: The third Geraldine R. Dodge Poetry Festival is to be held Sept. 13 to 15 at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. Joyce Carol Oates and several Pulitzer Prize-winning poets are to participate in the festival's series of readings, panel discussions and workshops.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Campus Life: Case Western;   At Boot Camps for Freshmen, Lessons in Tradition and Tolerance
description: Last week, college students began converging on America's campuses for the start of the fall semester. Among them were some four million freshmen. Nowadays, more and more colleges try to make the transition from high school easier with orientation programs. Here are reports from Southern Methodist University and Case Western Reserve University on their programs.

title: Rent Control
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: FOOD-PATCH;

Supplying the Soup Kitchens, Food Pantries and Shelters
description: LEAD: THE refrigerators are filled, the vans are warming up outside and the food is ready to go.

title: Public Works, Private Cash
description: A few months after a major new building opens in New York City, the subway stations and buses serving it often overflow with additional passengers, causing congestion and delays.

title: Softball Team Aims for a National Title
description: LEAD: WHEN Bob Wilson became the coach of the women's softball team at Pitney Bowes Inc., in Stamford, his goal was to turn a mediocre team into a consistent winner. Six years later, the team has become a dominant force in the seven-team Stamford Monday Night Industrial League, as well as in the state. Now Mr.

title: In September, Warm Up For the New Season
description: ALTHOUGH October is the starting month for most orchestras and concert series as well, several organizations will be performing by the middle of September.

title: Lisa Marie Knoechel Wed
description: Lisa Marie Knoechel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Knoechel of Lake Carmel, N.Y., was married yesterday to Antony Leo Kerz, a son of Louise Kerz of Los Angeles and the late Leo Kerz. The Rev. Brian McWeeney officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. James the Apostle in Carmel, N.Y. Mrs. Kerz, a magna cum laude graduate of the State University of New York at Albany, and her husband are both senior systems programmer analysts in the Southington, Conn., plant of Pratt & Whitney. Mr. Kerz graduated from Carnegie Mellon University.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Gaetano Ferro;   Contemplating Divorce? 'Be Reasonable.'
description: CHANGES in society and in the law have brought changes in divorce, says Gaetano Ferro, a lawyer in Westport. Reasons for divorce as well as settlements and child-custody arrangements are changing, he said, yet many people are still dissatisfied with the process of of dissolving a marriage.

title: Men's Style;   A STORE IS BORN
description: You don't have to be a romantic to sell men's clothing in Manhattan. But it helps. Consider Alan Flusser, whose recently opened Wall Street-area tailor shop is a florid evocation of old England. There are trellis-patterned carpets, chintz-covered chairs and an old-fashioned sofa in which customers can wallow as they ponder the distinction between a chalk and a pin stripe.

title:
The Executive Life;

Sea, Sun and Society Meet Texas Down East
description: LEAD: It's summer, and the Basses - the family, not the fish - have returned to the coast of Maine.

title: Tracy Campbell Weds M. H. Smith
description: Tracy Ann Campbell, a daughter of Frank J. Campbell 3d and a stepdaughter of Judith W. Campbell of Gladwyne, Pa., was married there yesterday to Michael Hodgsdon Smith, a son of Peter B. Smith of New York and the late Kathleen M. Hodgsdon. The Rev. Martin O'Halloran performed the ceremony at St. John Vianney Baptist Roman Catholic Church.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: More and more manufacturers are producing cameras with red-eye reduction systems these days, and the question inevitably arises: Do they work, and is it worth trading up to a new model just to get this feature?

title: In the Trail of the Nuclear Arms Industry
description: At the University of California at Davis, the carcasses of 1,000 slightly radioactive beagles are frozen solid, ready to be buried by the Department of Energy in a project to decommission a nuclear research laboratory that could cost as much as $22 million.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Because our driveway slopes toward the garage and the drain is small, water collects during heavy rains. Also, since the garage floor is uneven, the rubber door bottom does not seal properly and water flows underneath.

title: Horse Racing;   'Jake' Winner In Cane Pace
description: After barely qualifying for the final, Jake and Elwood took an easy victory in the Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: Programmed for Life and Death
description: This spring a California man symbolically took his life by using a computer program to seek out and destroy the contributions he had made over the years to a continuing electronic conversation run by a computer group called the Well. Several weeks later, he followed this ''virtual'' suicide by killing himself in the real world.

title: Career Skills For Campers Via Fresh Air
description: On the first day of the Fresh Air Fund's Career Camp Program, Kyshia Gillespie, a 12-year-old from Far Rockaway, Queens, fired off a barrage of questions to a visiting reporter.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MEXICAN BOLERO. By Angeles Mastretta. Translated by Ann Wright. (Viking, $19.95.) The Mexican journalist Angeles Mastretta's debut novel is part of Latin America's literature of political repression: in ''Mexican Bolero,'' a young girl loses her innocence while corrupt politicians, generals, labor leaders and peasant bosses jockey for power in the years after the Mexican Revolution of 1911. This spare, seamlessly translated book, originally published in Spanish in 1986, realistically portrays how people are bent by and eventually defy the evil that surrounds them. In a tone of cynical irony, Catalina Guzman, who is just 14 when she begins her narration, tells of her deflowering by Gen. Andres Ascencio, who is twice her age. After they marry and settle in her home state of Puebla, Cati watches, horrified, as her ambitious, amoral husband rises from local army supervisor to iron-fisted governor, robbing families of their property and arranging for his critics to be killed. Helplessly, she assists him with his official duties and raises their children. But his unfaithfulness infuriates her and she eventually sabotages him, with surprising results. Like Ms. Mastretta, Cati is a reporter, and her strength as a narrator lies in her understated descriptions of Mexico's social ills, which are suffused with mockery of ruling-class hypocrisy. (After the general places her in charge of Puebla's public welfare projects, she quips, ''For a while, I hadn't time to think about the mad, the sick and the orphaned, I was so busy organizing parties. In the end I think we even forgot what they were in aid of.'') Unfortunately, Ms. Mastretta sometimes seems to forget her own obligations to her readers; too often, for example, she states rather than shows the reasons for the townspeople's ignorance and apathy. Nevertheless, ''Mexican Bolero'' offers a revealing portrait of Mexico in the 1920's and 30's, an era largely unknown to most Americans.

title: Review/Theater;   First-Person Lampoon Of a Former First Lady
description: Nancy Reagan may be out of the public eye, but one person who hasn't forgotten her is Terry Sweeney.

title: In The Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Cheshire, Conn. $155,000

title: Jacqueline Kristan Married
description: Jacqueline A. Kristan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Kristan of Austintown, Ohio, was married yesterday to Stephen J. LoPresti, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph D. LoPresti of Belmont, Mass., by the Rev. Fred Lukehart at the St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church in Austintown.
