Mrs. LoPresti, 28 years old and a graduate of Bowling Green State University in Ohio, worked until recently as an assistant treasurer at J. P. Morgan & Company in New York. The bridegroom, 29, graduated from Harvard University and is the vice president of London and Edinburgh Trust, a real-estate development company in San Francisco.

title: Of Nazism And Nonsense
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stuff Wars Are Made Of
description: In the last week the United States crossed a threshold in confronting Iraq over its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It became more than a nation responding firmly to an international crisis; in its collective consciousness and in cold fact, it began preparing for war.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Sea Theme In Disney Plan For Long Beach

title: Miss Murray Wed To G. M. Creamer
description: Mary Jane Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Murray of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Glenn Michael Creamer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Creamer of Pawtucket, R.I. The Rev. Gerald E. Murray, the bride's brother, performed the ceremony at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.

title: Hostage Families Tell Their Stories
description: A decade ago, Arleen Uerling was working in a restaurant in Yakima, Wash., when Mohammed Tayeh walked in, ''and it was love at first sight,'' her mother said. Two years later they were married and headed for Kuwait, where, until the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2, Mr. Tayeh had a catering service and Arleen Tayeh was a homemaker.

title: Japan Has Its Own Set of Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in The Times Magazine on July 29 with an article about Detroit misidentified a downtown street that appeared deserted in the early evening. It is John R Street, not Brush Street.

title: Jails Chief Is Criticized For Being Too Isolated
description: Shortly after he took over New York City's jails, Allyn R. Sielaff brought in workers to remodel his suite so that a visitor must pass through two reception areas, and two sets of security buzzers, before getting to his corner office.

title: Sentence in Plot to Kill Priest
description: A man convicted of plotting to kill a Roman Catholic priest who had sexually abused him when he was a teen-age altar boy, was placed on probation for three years on Friday. The defendant, Gregory J. Riedle, 26 years old, of St. Paul, was arrested in May, and the police found a butcher knife and a 4-foot-long wooden club in his car.

title: Spotlight on a Commissioner
description: Allyn Sielaff had a progressive reputation when he took over New York City's jails. Now critics are asking whether isolation made him blind to tension at Rikers Island. Page 40.

title: Adeline Horner Married on L.I.
description: Adeline Sue Horner, a daughter of Mrs. Albert H. J. Mueller of Tucson, Ariz., and Larry D. Horner of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Olaf Neubert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Werner J. Neubert of Hamburg, West Germany. The Rev. Charles Newberry performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, L.I.

description: Contaminated processing plants, laboratories, nuclear reactors and testing ground that were part of the nuclear weapons industry. Site; Description Location 1. Amchitka Island; Amchitka Island, nuclear test site Alaska 2. Monument Valley; Monument Valley, uranium mill tailings Ariz. 3. Tuba City; uranium mill tailings Tuba City, Ariz. 4. Energy Technology Engineering Center; reactor test lab Santa Susana, Calif. 5. General Atomics; reactor manufacturer San Diego, Calif. 6. title: College '90;   Headed in New Directions
description: Back in those carefree days when we could count on the college football season starting some time after the beginning of the fall semester, when we could make our tailgating plans based on 1:30 kickoffs that had been chiseled in stone months before, and when we didn't need an announcement to know who would be in the Southwest Conference for the foreseeable future, even back then, there was this problem.

title: The Word Spread Anew About Video
description: The beef and dairy businesses did it, and now video might try the same thing. This summer the industry is contemplating a generic advertising campaign to promote all of video as a medium of home entertainment. Recent studies indicate that people are less enthusiatic about renting videos than they once were. ''We have to regenerate some excitement,'' says Robert Klingensmith, president of Paramount Home Video and a leading proponent of the generic campaign.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;

Hotel to Rise, After 25 Years
description: LEAD: Twenty-five years after it first appeared on the drawing board, a hotel-conference center is set for ground-breaking this fall, a half-dozen blocks from one of the city's poorest neighborhoods.

title: A Taste For Tchaikovsky
description: To the Editor:

title:
RECORDINGS;

At Season's End, Evocative Sounds Of Summers Past
description: LEAD: In the summer of 1951, two extraordinary families of musicians gathered with colleagues in Marlboro, Vt., to make music, and the Marlboro School and Festival of Music was born. The wording was significant: the event was to be, first, a gathering for practice and study and, second, a forum for public performance.

title: The Big Dirty Apple
description: THE NEW YORK ENVIRONMENT BOOK

title: Grumman's F-14 May Be Revived In New Buildup
description: LEAD: THE threat of tactical warfare in the Middle East, coupled with Department of Defense delays in proposals for a new generation of military aircraft, are fueling predictions that the department may alter plans to end production of the Grumman F-14 fighter jet.

title: State Stewards Guard Adirondacks' Alpine Flora
description: Alix Cleveland did not think that climbing to the top could become so routine. But this summer, as one of New York State's first ''summit stewards,'' she climbs 5,344-foot Mount Marcy five days a week.

title: Campus Life: Catholic University;   Angry Questions Over Cancellation Of Abortion Talk
description: Amid charges and denials of interference by leaders of the Roman Catholic Church, the student-run Program Board at the Catholic University of America - a committee of one student at the time - has canceled a debate on abortion rights that would have involved Bill Baird, one of the most outspoken proponents of women's access to abortion.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: Deltiologists, collectors of postcards, the cliche goes, should look for postcards at stamp shows. Philatelists often fail to recognize the special value a postcard might have because of its picture rather than its stamp.

title: Lives on Hold: Call-Up Sends Harlem Guard Unit Scrambling and Packing
description: Her first week of law school behind her, Hillaire Wheatley walked into her apartment Friday afternoon, threw down her books and noticed her answering machine blinking.

title: Leslie Kahn Is Married
description: Leslie Gayle Kahn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Kahn of Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married last evening to Mitchell Craig Tolep, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin B. Tolep of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Robert Jacobs performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I. The bride graduated from the University of Maryland and is an international account associate in the Latin American division of the Bank of Boston in New York. Her husband, a graduate of Ryder College, is a sales representative at Keystone Paper Company in New York.

title: Sri Lankan Army Is Closing In on a Citadel of Resistance by Tamil Rebels
description: The Sri Lankan Army is closing in on Jaffna, the citadel and city that have symbolized Tamil resistance in an ethnic conflict that has torn apart South Asia's most developed nation.

title: Caution: Tomato Season Nearing End
description: WITH only a few more weeks of summer on the calendar, tomatoes top the shopping list. Is it possible to indulge in enough of them, to become sated now so they will not be missed as sorely after the season?

title: Christina Weaver Weds Don Fixler
description: Christina Weaver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Weaver of Setauket, L.I., was married last evening at Temple Beth Sholom in Smithtown, L.I., to Dr. Don Sheldon Fixler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Z. Charles Fixler of Cincinnati. Rabbi Elliot Spar officiated.

title: Tennis;   U.S. Open Shows No Favorite
description: This year the United States Open promises to be a quieter tournament than usual: along with the temporary banishment of La Guardia Airport's jet stream from the sultry skies above Flushing Meadows, there is the absence of a contender for a 1990 Grand Slam on both sides of the draw.

title: What to Call the Poorest Poor?
description: Two weeks ago, Prof. William Julius Wilson stood up before 1,500 colleagues and called into question the usefulness of a term that has become a fixture of the American political vocabulary and one that he, more than anyone, helped legitimize: ''the underclass.''

title: Dennis Shields Weds Jill Schwartzberg
description: Jill Barrie Schwartzberg was married last evening at the Plaza in New York to Dennis Alexander Shields. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated.

title: Jewels for a Worthless Lover
description: DESIRE

title: On the River, Naturalists Try to Turn Back a Tide of Development
description: LEAD: OUT in the midday sun on one recent 90-degree afternoon, Juliana Barrett and Margaret Ardwin were paddling their canoe upstream through Pratt Cove, a freshwater tidal marsh near the mouth of the Connecticut River. Oblivious to the heat, skidding into islands of wild rice, they were searching for a rare species of bidens, a member of the daisy family.

title: Voltaire vs. Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Just in Time
description: William Neal Moore was not the first murderer to find God on death row, but the sincerity of his conversion was particularly impressive. After appeals on his behalf by Mother Teresa, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and relatives of the man he admitted killing in 1974, Mr. Moore was granted clemency last week by the Georgia Board of Pardons and Paroles. The commutation came a day before he was to die. Earlier that day, the Supreme Court had granted him a stay of execution, but the board ruling took him off death row and made him eligible for parole in nine years. He had been condemned after admitting he killed a 77-year-old man during an attempted robbery that had been suggested by the victim's nephew, who was not charged. Other relatives of the victim considered the nephew more to blame than Mr. Moore. That carried some weight with the pardons board. ''The board was impressed that we had the family of the victim urging clemency,'' said the chairman.

title: Campus Life: Maryland;   Seeking Clout, Students Work To Register Voters
description: To combat what they consider anti-student legislation passed by city and county officials, the Student Government Association at the University of Maryland has registered more than 800 students this year to vote in the fall county and state elections. And the president of the association, Daniel Cones, vows that it will continue its efforts.

title: THE GUIDE
description: SINATRA PAYING A VISIT

title: Foreign Cassettes Aren't So Friendly On Home Turf
description: Travelers returning home with videocassettes bought abroad often discover with dismay that those tapes won't play on their VCR's. The reason is that tapes bought in Europe and many other parts of the world are recorded using different technical standards than those used in this country.

title: Fashion;   Ever Comfortable, Oversized Sweaters Express Whimsy
description: For women who have more than enough structured jackets in their closets, there is an alternative this fall: big, slouchy sweaters. Some have hand-crocheted detail for an old-fashioned look. Others have blown-up, large-scale patterns taken from sources as diverse as Scottish tartans, Walt Disney, African cloths and Mondrian.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Children of Divorce Still Need Parents Who Are Partners
description: LEAD: YESTERDAY a friend called to commend me on my divorce situation. ''I just want you to know you're the exception to the rule,'' she said. ''Your kids aren't torn between you and your ex-husband.'' She had just finished taking a two-week college seminar on divorce in which she had learned that many parents who try to turn their children against their former spouses.

title: Long Career With a Camera Features Changes of Perspective
description: IN a 1982 monograph on Aaron Siskind, ''Pleasures and Terrors,'' Carl Chiarenza said his subject ''resembles nothing so much as a fruit peddler from turn-of-the-century Lower East Side Manhattan,'' but a ''well-tuned, well-rehearsed'' peddler. Refining the point, Mr. Chiarenza added that the photographer's schtick is the result of ''a lifetime of cultivation.''

title: FASHION'S DESIGNING WOMEN
description: Ask a fashion designer how she selects her business wardrobe, and she will mention the same concerns as other working women. Although she may have a greater array of stylish choices, she wants her clothes to be comfortable as well as chic, as practical as they are handsome. and she doesn't want to have to think about them twice. For many designing women, that means a silhouette that frees the body and a fabric that pampers it, such as cashmere or an easy jersey knit. Layered dressing that suits the occasion as well as the temperature. Adaptable combinations that go the distance from corporate boardroom to cocktail party - or city to city. versatile colors, particularly black and white. and, of course, clothes with a sense of personal style. Here, the designer may take flair a little farther than the typical office permits, with shorts or a miniskirt, a bold accessory or a whimsical jacket. On these and the following pages, we asked some top women designers to tell us how they dress for work, and why.

title: Pitfalls for the Obliging Gofer
description: I'm in London standing in Harrods lower-level market - not the fabled Food Halls that take up maybe a quarter of the ground floor, but the much less touristy lower-level market. I'm staring in dismay at the tea display, which, to my eye, can be no less than 20 feet wide and 6 feet high.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: VACANT city lots are powerful symbols. Betrayal, despair, mistrust - name it, and for someone the weedy blocks that dot every city represent a modern age that has all but said cities are worthless.

title: The Golf Cart Crisis
description: Even on a day when he savored a hard-won diplomatic triumph at the United Nations, President Bush and his handling of the Persian Gulf crisis encountered irritating criticisms from unexpected quarters.

title:
ART;

Sculpture Dominates in Annual Show of Emerging Artists
description: LEAD: THESE days the Bronx Museum of the Arts is overflowing with new art. The museum runs a program for emerging artists called ''Artist in the Marketplace,'' which includes a large group exhibition at its conclusion. Alongside a ''Reunion Exhibition'' celebrating the program's first 10 years there is also an ''annual,'' featuring this year's participants.

title: Lots of Volunteers for the No. 1 Spot
description: The New York Times Top 20 as compiled by Michael Sisak. Coaches' records are for their careers, not just for their present teams.

title: Everybody Loves Somebody Sometime
description: A PLACE I'VE NEVER BEEN

title: Pamela Rago and Brian Hughes Marry
description: Pamela Lorraine Rago, a daughter of Sharon Lord Naeole of Princeton, N.J., and Albert J. Rago of Lambertville, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Murphy Hughes, a son of Richard J. Hughes of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late Betty Hughes. The ceremony was held in Chatham, N.J., at the home of the bridegroom's brother, W. Michael Murphy Jr., and sister-in-law, Judge Marianne Espinosa Murphy of State Superior Court. Judge Murphy officiated.

title: Eligibility Suit
description: THE school has said no. The family has cried foul. The doctors -well, they have said different things. And so it appears that for Stephen Larkin, the courts will have the final say.

title: Margaret Stone Wed to Ted Cox
description: Margaret Lucile Stone, a faculty administrative officer at the South Bank Polytechnic college in London, and Edwin Hindle Cox, the international officer at Goldsmiths' College of the University of London, were married yesterday at the Union Presbyterian Church in Union, Pa. The bride's father, the Rev. Robert J. Stone of Lowell, Mich., officiated.

title: Renting A Cotswolds Cottage
description: For years I had wanted to rent a cottage in the English countryside. I had a clear, if idealized, notion of my requirements: a thatched-roof cottage in a sleepy English village; a rustic stone fence bordering pastures and meadows; honeysuckle and roses by the front door; a pub just a short walk down the lane, and easy access to London should all the above ever become boring. In short, the sort of place Jane Marple might be seen emerging from in the course of her investigations into a delectable homicide.

title: Lifestyle;   Football Hasn't Started for Real Yet, But Real Fans Show They're Ready
description: Under an overcast sky on a recent afternoon, Jay Silver, a 24-year-old commercial real-estate broker, demonstrated his unconditional adoration for the New York Jets, whose 4-12 record last year was hardly easy to love.

title: Laurie Sappern Is a Bride
description: Laurie A. Sappern, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Sappern of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Dean H. Gaugler, a son of Chester F. Gaugler of Bloomsburg, Pa., and Mrs. Arnold Kohl of Newville, Pa. Rabbi Jacob Lantz officiated at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton, Conn. Mrs. Gaugler is a marketing representative for I.B.M. in Norwalk, Conn. She graduated from Duke University and is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at New York University. Her husband is a founding partner of Prime Finance Ltd. in Westport. He graduated from the University of Maryland and received an M.B.A. from the University of Connecticut.

title: HORSY HERITAGE
description: Designers are catching on to what the horsy set has long known: that riding clothes are comfortable, stylish and flattering. And they are adapting the look for women's everyday fashions. Epitomizing the equestrian style is one of the pillars of America's horsy society, C.Z. Guest. Known for her skill as an accomplished horsewoman (she rises most mornings at 7:30 for a one-and-a-half-hour ride), Guest has always had an eye for clothing that suits her passion. Her own gear comes from the established riding-apparel shops: jodhpurs from Manhattan's M.J. Knoud, jackets from Savile Row's H. Huntsman & Sons Ltd. and boots - some of which date back to her school days - from Henry Maxwell's & Company, also of London.

title: Carol Ann Baxter a Bride
description: Carol Ann Baxter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Baxter of North Syracuse, N.Y., was married yesterday to Loren H. Plotkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Plotkin of Miami Beach, Fla. Judge Edward Sharretts Jr. performed the ceremony at Mr. Plotkin's home in Water Mill, L.I. The bride, who is 36 years old and graduated from the State University of New York at Brockport, is an actress and dancer who has performed on Broadway and in the national touring company of ''La Cage aux Folles.'' The bridegroom, 47, graduated from Harper College in Binghamton and St. John's University School of Law in New York where he was an editor of the Law Review. He is a senior partner with Levine Thall & Plotkin, an entertainment law firm in New York. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Jennifer M. Brown Wed in Michigan
description: Jennifer Mills Brown, the educational marketing manager in the children's book department at HarperCollins Publishers in New York, and John Philip Irwin 3d, who will become an associate at the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton next month, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Muskegon, Mich. The Rev. Robert A. Shackles officiated, assisted by the Rev. R. Louis Stasker, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Food;   THE CAPER CHASE
description: Traveling to Aguilas in the Southeastern corner of Spain to learn how the caper finds its way from plant to table, I came away knowing how, but wondering why. Even as a lifelong fan who values the caper's sharp salinity in dishes of all sorts, I marveled, once again, at the trouble people go to for this tiny culinary adornment. Piquing appetites as far back as ancient Greece and Rome, the caper may indeed function as a digestive aid and an aphrodisiac, as old herbals suggest, but a dietary staple it is not - by a long shot.

title:
WALL STREET;

Bullion Coins Get a Boost From the Mideast
description: LEAD: Whatever his other shortcomings, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has sure helped the beleaguered bullion coin business. Sales of the American Eagle , marketed by the United States Mint, and the Royal Canadian Mint's Maple Leaf have skyrocketed in the last four weeks.

title: Paul Simon to Sing for Montauk Beacon
description: LEAD: WHEN the singer and songwriter Paul Simon takes the stage Thursday for his first American concert in at least two years - and his first since a monthlong tour of the Soviet Union in 1989 - the venue will not be in the Meadowlands, Madison Square Garden or even Jones Beach, but the grounds of a horse ranch in

title: Style Makers;   Elaine Hart, Quilt Dealer
description: Two and a half years ago, Elaine Hart turned a 20-year hobby into a business. She opened a quilt shop in Manhattan. But she still marvels at the serendipitous way she got involved with quilts.

title: Against Their Will: 12 Families' Stories of American Hostages
description: Some are oil workers; some are corporate managers; some are diplomats. Some were in Iraq or Kuwait to visit relatives. Some are tourists who had the wretched luck to make a fueling stop in Kuwait City only to find themselves squarely in the path of an international crisis.

title: Kuwaiti Exiles Talk of Iraqi Search for Westerners
description: Some Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait are searching for Westerners, Kuwaiti exiles in Saudi Arabia said yesterday in telephone interviews.

title: Pretoria's Forces Impose Tense Peace in Towns
description: The battles have ebbed today in these bleak townships on South Africa's gold-mining reef, where more than 500 people have died. And the lines of competing black factions have been frozen in place by a deployment of the police and soldiers in trucks intended for bush warfare and now imposing a kind of civilian peace.

title: In a Dusty Texas Town, a Bizarre Tale Takes Shape
description: Only on second glance does one realize that it's actually Vanessa Redgrave on the set and not a crew member or a male extra biding his time between camera setups. Her blond hair is short-cropped, unkempt and brushed straight back from her face, emphasizing her square jaw and her sharp, oddly masculine features. She is without makeup, dressed in overalls and work shirt, and she stands taller than most of the men nearby.

title:
THEATER: Why the Furor Over 'Miss Saigon' Won't Fade;

'The Ideal World We All Long For' Is Not the World We Live In
description: LEAD: The recent controversy swirling around the hit London musical ''Miss Saigon'' has stirred emotions in the theater world and beyond. When Actors' Equity voted earlier this month to bar the British actor Jonathan Pryce from reprising his role on Broadway because the union said it could not ''appear to condone the casting of a Caucasian in the role of a Eurasian,'' Cameron Mackintosh, the musical's producer, canceled the American production.

title:
Your Own Account;

Marking Out Your Own Path
description: LEAD: As senior vice president for planning and development at the New York Mercantile Exchange, Jan Kay spent much of her time traveling around the world to develop new markets. She particularly enjoyed the time spent in Spain.

title: TURNING HEADS
description: AT MANHATTAN's Patricia Field, a quirky Greenwich Village emporium known for its radical street-chic fashions, a small, furry revolution is under way. All manner of wigs - the neo, the retro, the bizarre, even the downright pretty - are displayed like some rogue's gallery of pop-culture idols. Want to pass for Bart Simpson, America's reigning cartoon brat? Then pull on his curly cone of synthetic madness. Joey Heatherton? Try a thick, boyish platinum mop. In this setting, a wig is never a hairdo, it's an identity.

title: Ms. Cary Is Wed To R.C. Whitlock
description: Catharine Anne Cary, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Whittier Cary of Saco, Me., was married yesterday to Robert Carlisle Whitlock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Whitlock of Trenton. The Revs. David Prince and Fredrick Schulz performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of East Hampton, L.I.

title: 50 Reported Dead in a Week Of Monsoon Floods in India
description: Flooding has killed at least 50 people this week, Indian officials and news reports said today.

title: Cindy Kanter, Lawyer, Weds
description: Cynthia Dana Kanter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip D. Kanter of Great Neck, L.I., was married there yesterday to Michael Harris Sonnabend, a son of Katherine H. Sonnabend of Livingston, N.J., and Henry Sonnabend of Dallas. Rabbi Morris Barzilai, assisted by Cantor Norman Summers, officiated at at Temple Beth-El.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 5 with an article about Vermont villages misidentified a building and its location. The building was the Peacham Store in Peacham, not a bed and breakfast in Wells River.

title: 'As You Like It;' Another View
description: Mr. Klein apparently learned from a dreary pedagogue that this play demonstrates a deep ''sense of loss.'' However, the ''romantic and comic artifice and its celebratory air,'' which Mr. Klein deprecates, is exactly the message my mentor believes is the esence of Shakespeare's comedies; happy endings with marriage and the prospect of procreation was indeed celebratory for a nation that had been severely depleted by many years of plague.

title: Turning Marinas Into the Holiday Inns of the Water.
description: LEAD: Say goodbye to the 40-slips-and-a-bait-shop days, the time when mom-and-pop marinas contributed a modicum of service to enhance, but not disturb, tranquillity at the water's edge.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. CHARLES CARLUCCIO;

Where Headache Sufferers Seek Relief
description: LEAD: EVERY year, 42 million Americans take 20,000 tons of aspirin for headache relief. Chronic sufferers made more than 11 million doctor visits and lost 5 million work days in 1987.

title: Surge of Addicts Strains Criminal Justice System
description: THE number of people addicted to drugs or alcohol entering the criminal-justice system on Long Island has increased so rapidly that the agencies treating them are overwhelmed.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Why Must An Intern Work A 110-Hour Week?
description: LEAD: I AM engaged to a surgical intern, and I say limit the number of hours New Jersey interns and residents work, as New York has done.

title: Iraqi Diplomat Vows to Release Kin of Envoys
description: Iraq promised today to release dependents of American diplomats from Kuwait who are being held in Baghdad, but not the diplomats themselves.

title: Diplomats' Position in Kuwait: Gray Area in International Law
description: The Persian Gulf crisis poses questions of international law that appear clear cut in the case of United Nations actions, but murky when it comes to the protection of foreign diplomats in Kuwait.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Handmaid's Tale

title: Cuomo's Green Period
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been campaigning vigorously across the state. He has political advertisements on the radio. He has spent $300,000 on television commercials, just in August. ''The choice is very clear,'' he says solemnly, staring into the lens.

title: THE LANGUAGE THING
description: Recovering from recent ''abominable'' surgery, I nearly split the sides of my stitches with the laughter thing when I read Maureen Dowd's article about President Bush's unique rendition of what I'm sure he thinks of as his mother's tongue (''The Language Thing,'' July 29).

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MARJORIE PHILLIPS;

Stepping In to Help Combat Child Abuse
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to dealing with child abuse, society has enacted laws, trained police officers, teachers and social workers and tried to educate children themselves. But with reported cases of child abuse on the increase - 4,600 in Westchester alone last year - the professionals are overworked and the court system is overloaded, unable to do enough to protect all children.

title: Berkeley Journal;   Enter Politics, Stage Left
description: Under the rustling oak trees at John Hinkel Park, before performances of ''Cymbeline,'' ''Othello'' or ''The Merry Wives of Windsor,'' the audience at the Berkeley Shakespeare Festival is wildly applauding the nightly announcement that the company has refused a Federal grant rather than sign an anti-obscenity pledge.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

'A Firsthand Look At What the Future Might Hold'
description: LEAD: TWO summers ago, when I was transferred from the Greenwich Hospital to a nursing home in another community for rehabilitation of an injured leg, my heart sank when I caught sight of the preponderance of gray heads, mostly widowed females, that constituted the patient population.

title: One Hat Too Many
description: Elected officials are supposed to put the public good ahead of narrow partisan interests. That is the common-sense reasoning behind a provision in New York City's new Charter that bars key officeholders from holding party jobs. But a disappointing court decision now casts doubt on whether that ban against political moonlighting can be enforced.

title: Board Sends a Message For the Budget Season
description: AMID growing evidence that the county will have to lean more heavily on its property tax in difficult economic times, the Board of Legislators last week approved its first departmental budget of the new fiscal season and considered some unusual new sources of revenue.

title: Doctor Talk to Me
description: When, in the Summer of 1989, I moved from Connecticut to Cambridge, Mass., I found that I had difficulty urinating. I was like Portnoy, in ''Portnoy's Complaint,'' who couldn't fornicate in Israel. I had always wanted to live in Cambridge, and the thought passed through my mind that I couldn't urinate because - like Israel for Portnoy - Cambridge was a transcendent place for me.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

Birding Zealots On the March for Least Tern
description: LEAD: SINCE into every beginning birder's life a little embarrassment seems to fly, Frank Moretti was trying to make Margaret Davison feel better. A participant in a bird-watching walk along the shores of Accabonac Harbor in East Hampton, Mrs. Davison had just raised the alarm to catch her discovery, a ''rare bird at 11 o'clock'' off a stand of lobster traps jutting out into Gardiner's Bay.

title: Spike Lee Riffs About an Artist, Not a Genius
description: Spike Lee has done it again with ''Mo' Better Blues,'' his new film about black musicians that he describes as an answer to Clint Eastwood's ''Bird'' and Bertrand Tavernier's '' 'Round Midnight.'' As did his earlier films, ''Mo' Better Blues'' exists not only as a movie, as an end in itself, but also as a social phenomenon. This one is also a challenge to everyone who knows the direction in which his career ought to go, especially when it doesn't.

title: OPEC LEADER URGES HIGHER OIL OUTPUT
description: The president of OPEC said today that the organization should help alleviate any oil shortages caused by the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Ready to Deal After Shuffle
description: FOR the Yankees' reshuffled front-office personnel, it is still just the beginning of the post-George Steinbrenner era. But so far, things seem to be progressing well.

title: Data Bank/August 26, 1990
At This Rate, We'll Never Get Off the Planet
description: NASA, the proud agency that once bore the nation's hopes in space, has outlived its usefulness. It is an aged and faltering institution whose shortcomings have become embarrassingly evident to all but the most self-interested.

title: Tech Notes;   Getting Photographs From Medical Imaging
description: First there was medical imaging - electronic devices that produce video pictures of structures deep within the body using X-rays, sound waves or magnetic resonance techniques. Now there is a way to directly convert these electronic images into high-quality, instant, black and white photographs printed on film. The new device (left), developed by the Polaroid Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., uses a specially designed laser printer that takes the video image, converts it into laser light and uses that light to expose sheets of photographic film. The film has a light-sensitive medium that can be handled in daylight and processed without a darkroom or wet chemicals. The film is made from two layers of transparent polyester; sandwiched between them is the laser-light sensitive medium. A few seconds after exposure, the layers are automatically separated to reveal the image.

title: Unhappy Landing
description: GROUNDED

title: On Condemnation And the Jay Property
description: Your July 29 article on rival plans for the Jay property [''Rival Proposals for Purchase of Jay Land''] contains a subhead, ''Condemnation Could Triple Price,'' which, presented as fact, is incorrect and misleading.

title: Sarah Gant Weds Michael Mandanis
description: Sarah Ross Gant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Gant of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Anthony Mandanis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Mandanis of San Rafael, Calif. The Rev. J. Calvin K. Jackson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Baseball;   Clemens Fires Shutout For Three-Game Lead

title: How to Install a Dimmer Switch
description: DIMMER switches allow adjusting lighting levels; they also save energy and extend the lives of light bulbs. Most often, dimmer switches are used for controlling incandescent ceiling lights. Installing one is easy. The job involves simply replacing the conventional wall switch with the dimmer.

title: For Vietnamese in U.S., Uneasy Ties to Home

title: Pregnant Teen-Agers Face Loss of Home

title: Looking Ahead
description: SUNDAY: Some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plan to meet in Vienna.

title: Japan's Imperial Present
description: In the 22d day of November this year, if all goes according to plan, an enigmatic and lonely 56-year-old man who has lived almost all his life in the shadow of his father will leave his modest home for the grounds of the Imperial Palace in downtown Tokyo. At 6:30 P.M., Akihito will bathe, put on white ceremonial robes and enter a shrine in a wooded glade. He will eat boiled rice and millet and then commune alone with the spirit of his mythological ancestor, the sun goddess Amaterasu Omikami. Three hours before dawn, he will emerge spiritually transformed as the 125th Emperor of Japan.

title: Humor Succeeds Simply Because People Like to Laugh
description: To the Editor:

title: Twin Spotlights on Parsons of the Dime
description: The directors of the Dime Savings Bank of New York had one final misgiving about naming Richard D. Parsons as its president two years ago: whether, as a former aide to Nelson A. Rockefeller and Gerald R. Ford, he could resist returning to politics. ''You know, we're not going to keep that guy,'' one board member told the chairman. ''How many black Republicans are there?''

title: Francis J. Sugrue, Journalist, 72

title: Ann Harrington Wed in Vermont
description: Ann Marie Harrington, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray D. Harrington of Hancock, N.H., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Blandford Shilling, a son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Gary Shilling of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Charles Fox performed the ceremony at the Old First Congregational Church in Old Bennington, Vt.

title: Writers Help Writers, Query to Cover

In two-hour work sessions,they take turns reading and critiquingtheir works. More importantly, they come to offer support through the writing process, from the disappointment of rejection to the joy of publication.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Many Lives of My Favorite Wallet
description: LEAD: IT is a fat red wallet. It looks like it has lots of money in it, but what it does have is a buckle that will not close and room for eight pages of pictures.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Plan for next spring's flower garden; mail orders for hardy bulbs. Feed 'mums to support oncoming bloom. Last call to dig and divide bearded iris. Keep after weeds. Repair weak, established lawns and seed or sod new ones. Spray rosebushes with a fungicide to protect them from black spot.

title: Change in Identity Is Coming to the East
description: The settling of new conference affiliations, ones to resolve the makeup of major-college football in the East for a long time to come, is an important adjunct of the impending season.

title: Swedish Educator Explains Sex Film
description: LEAD: THE world-renowned educator, psychologist and sex therapist R. Maj-Briht Bergstrom-Walan, whose film on human sexuality has been used in courses at nearly 200 American colleges and universities over the last two decades, confesses that she is perplexed by periodic uproars in the United States over the film.

title: Britons' Families Torn Between Hope and Fear
description: Mary Wright timed her first trip outside Britain in all her 70 years to coincide with the birth of her granddaughter.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 22 about Budapest, and an accompanying caption, misidentified the sculptor of a statue of Persephone. As a reader has recently written to point out, he was Benno Elkan, not Benno Elkan Roma.

title: Toyota Minivan Is at Head of the Class
description: CHRYSLER'S minivan was an original that gonged out a knell for suburbia's well-entrenched station wagon, and I have long thought it was the only way to go. I raced a Plymouth Voyager around the perimeter of the country in the nutty race called One Lap of America and I fell in love. I liked the feel of it. I admired Lee Iacocca for inventing it.

title: Postings: Sheepshead Bay Condos;   An Alluring Site
description: When Nicholas Cammarato, a Brooklyn developer, first saw the neighboring homes of a father and son, Eric and Richard Stockley, on East 23d Street in the Sheepshead Bay section during an exploratory drive through the neighborhood a few years ago, it was not just their Victorian-styled residences that caught his eye.

title: Postings: 91st St. Town House;   Dalton Expansion
description: The Dalton School has added another town house to its diverse holdings on the Upper East Side, expanding by one the 91st Street row in which its lower school is conducted. Its newest building, 63 East 91st Street, was bought for $2 million from Martha Rusk Sutphen, through the Leslie J. Garfield brokerage. It was a residence until about a month ago and will simply be converted to office and conference use for the time being.

title: Talking: Oil Tanks;   New York's New Rules On Storage
description: Until recently, people with free-standing fuel-oil storage tanks in their basements or beside their houses did not have to worry about rules designed to avoid environmental contamination. Spills from these above-ground tanks are not likely to seep into ground water or waterways because even a small leak is immediately visible and can be cleaned up before becoming an environmental hazard.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   A Lot of World to See With a Ranger as a Guide
description: ''We appreciate the little things,'' said Rich DeSimone, an Urban Park Ranger at Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. ''And we encourage people to come back to the parks.''

title: Another Jogger Trial, but One With Less Outcry
description: As jurors in New York City weighed the fate of three teen-agers charged with the rape and beating of a Central Park jogger, a jury 300 miles to the northwest heard the gruesome details of an attack on another jogger raped and left to die.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT: An Inside View of the Game;   Wearing the Scars of Football
description: I grew up in an Irish Catholic family of six that accepted and cherished violence as an integral part of life. But in that context, the negative connotations of the word should be forgotten. In my house we wrestled, raced, slugged, and body-slammed our way through childhood. Although never meant as a replacement for a hug and a kiss, the intimacy of violent play helped bond us. Until I was 12, my middle-aged mother could pin me in under a minute.

title: Mont-St.-Michel
description: To the Editor: R. S., from New Hyde Park, asked about the tides at Mont-St.-Michel (Q & A, April 8).

title: One Killed, 4 Wounded on Brooklyn Street
description: A bystander was slain and four men wounded when a robbery attempt erupted into a gunfight on a Brooklyn street early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Mama, Papa and Baby Tiger
description: TIGERS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 5 about Pullman, Ill., rendered the name of the writer incorrectly and misstated his hometown. It was written by Karl Zimmermann, who now lives in Norwood, N.J.

title: Thomas W. McKnew, Geographic Figure, 94
description: Thomas Willson McKnew, chairman emeritus of the National Geographic Society, died Friday at Carriage Hill, a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 94 and was a resident of McLean, Va.

title: Baseball Notebook;   When the Performance of a Pitcher Outshines His Team's
description: Any pitcher who has 21 victories and 4 defeats is obviously having an outstanding season, but Bob Welch's performance grows even more impressive when it is placed in the context of his team's outstanding season.

title: Equipment That Plays in the Key of Flexibility
description: If Beethoven could hear a CD recording of his music (assuming he returned to this world with his hearing intact) he would probably throw one of his famous fits. The performance would seem to him consistently off key.

title: French Villas Fit for a Family Reunion
description: It's 11 A.M in the South of France and the sun is climbing high and hot in a blue sky. The pool's turquoise water sparkles in a corner of a vast garden. Sitting under the shade of a huge tree by a wooden picnic table at my rented villa, I sip my coffee, munch on a fresh croissant, and wade through the third chapter of another book I never got to read during a busy year.

title: Living Ruins
description: In VISIONS OF ANCIENT AMERICA (Rizzoli, $50), the photographer Roberto Schezen turns his lens on archeological sites in Mexico and Central America. The cities he records were built by Aztecs, Toltecs, Olmecs and Mayans, but it is nearly impossible to imagine human creatures living amid these desolate twilight landscapes. The ruins seem to have been set down directly out of angry skies by brutal but dazzling gods; they could be inhabited only by the jungle demons that snarl from the facades, or by hollow-eyed and solitary stone giants like those carved at Tula, north of Mexico City. The choice of a stark and coarse-grained black-and-white format is startling and paradoxical. Many of the actual sites are half-consumed by humid, emerald jungle, but the terrain of ''Visions of Ancient America'' has the luminous and cold-shadowed texture of a lunar surface. Mr. Schezen's photographs reveal three main levels of compositional interest: on the smallest scale, the tantalizingly elusive patterns formed by masses of repeated three-dimensional shapes, often of stylized plant and animal form; the almost miraculous resolution of that intricate tangle into the large and simple geometries that form the individual monuments, and, finally, the numinous symbiosis of architecture, sky and horizon. The mode of presentation - site by site, with diagrams and thumbnail historical sketches - seems to be a sly wink at those collections of photographs of classical Roman ruins that exude a mysterious drama despite the scholarly intentions of their authors. Mr. Schezen, who lives and works in Milan, is surely familiar with that tradition, but his purpose is far from scientific. Even the names of those forlorn cities - Sayil, Tikal, Uxmal, Yaxchilan, Teotihuacan - echo the photographs' haunting esthetic, which like the architecture itself is shockingly alien to the Western classical tradition.

title:
ART;

They Were Driven to Abstraction
description: LEAD: EAST HAMPTON's Signa Gallery operated for four summers, 1957 through 1960, and was an attempt to further the area's identification with the avant-garde.

title: An Irish 'Toy House' For Two (or More)
description: For a simple, undemanding and not-too-foreign week removed from the ruts of home and disciplines of office, renting a cottage in Ireland seemed ideal. After all, Ireland is about as close as Europe gets to America, the people speak our language, and my wife and I personally share, across uncertain generations, elements of the culture. And, having rented cottages from Maine to California, we knew how to turn apparent disadvantages into advantages: cleaning up after yourself means not being disturbed by someone else's cleaning up after you; preparing the occasional meal means not always having to dress up and fit into restaurant deadlines; keeping different schedules means not having to wait for breakfast or to turn off the reading light when your partner is ready to sleep.

title: The Battle Of the Sexes
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

An Appealing Mediterranean Menu
description: LEAD: ES-TA-TI, a hyphenated version of the word that means ''summer'' in northern Italian dialect, is the curious name of a year-old offspring of the restaurant Maureen in Cape May. Stephen and Maureen Horn, who have offered contemporary French and American fare at her namesake dining room upstairs for several years, now provide a satisfying melange of Mediterranean dishes, mostly northern Italian, on the ground floor.

Clarke K. Oler, an Episcopal minister, officiated.

description: On a quiet evening this March, in the leafy Brussels suburb of Uccle, Gerald Bull walked down the hallway leading to his apartment and pulled out the key to his door. It was the last thing he ever did.

title: Judge Bars Evidence Seized by Agents in 'Gas Leak Inspector' Trick
description: A Federal judge has ruled that cocaine and cash seized in the apartment of a Brooklyn man cannot be used as evidence against him because the ploy used by the authorities to enter the home - posing as gas company workers and falsely warning of an imminent gas explosion - could not be condoned.

But another partisan battle is already brewing, this time over German abortion law.

The movie industry enlisted massively and for the first time used war as an instrument of propaganda for a national cause. title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

The Opportunities of Municipal Planning
description: LEAD: MUNICIPAL planning has turned into one long, continuing approval process bordering on sheer insanity. And you need not be an urban-planner or architect to realize it.

title: THE TRAGEDY OF DETROIT
description: I was grateful for Ze'ev Chafets's article ''The Tragedy of Detroit'' (July 29). For years I've been mystified by the fact that no one really talks about what's happened there - that this national shame is treated as if it didn't exist.

title: Q and A
description: Hiking the Appalachian Trail

title: When a Dance Delves Into Literature
description: ''Why should we do Shakespeare? Shakespeare's already done Shakespeare.'' George Balanchine once made that scornful declaration about the way some choreographers base works on literary classics, including the plays of Shakespeare. However, by choreographing his own ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Balanchine himself ''did Shakespeare.'' And he did so quite wittily. Other choreographers have also ''done Shakespeare,'' and they have based works on other literary classics as well. For instance, this summer American Ballet Theater danced Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' and the Bolshoi Ballet offered both Yuri Grigorovich's version of that Shakespearean tragedy and excerpts from Marius Petipa's 19th-century balletic adaptation of Cervantes's ''Don Quixote.''

It also maintains an art gallery - the better to warm up the atmosphere of its main building, a ''layer cake'' of concrete and glass that dominates the hill bounded by River Road and DeForest Avenue.

title: Postings: Going Up in Hartford;   Sweat-Equity Affordables
description: For $2,500 in sweat equity, $1 for a vacant lot and a $1,500 cash contribution, nine families with two or more children and household incomes of at least $22,000 may be able to own their own homes in Hartford by next year. Eighteen other families, including smaller ones, will be considered for 18 two-bedroom condominiums with no sweat equity, but requiring down payments of $3,088 and $120 monthly association fees.

Nowadays, more and more colleges try to make the transition from high school easier with orientation programs. Here are reports from Southern Methodist University and Case Western Reserve University on their programs.

title: Cuba
description: To the Editor: Cuba's achievements - the eradication of illiteracy, the low rate of infant mortality, increased longevity and free education through the university level - are rarely the focus for reports in the U.S. press. Space is allotted to Cuba, however, when problems occur in Havana or when Cuban expatriates in the United States make outrageous statements of their plans to overthrow the Government of Cuba.

title: Keep Bathos Out of Bach
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

Panorama-on-Hudson, in Cold Spring
description: LEAD: FULL of inviting charm that draws visitors, who come for the architecture, history, antiques shops and panoramic riverfront, the village of Cold Spring amazingly enough lacks its share of good restaurants. Whether one eats in plain or fancy establishments, what money buys in terms of the quality of food and its preparation varies little; in all cases judicious selecting is necessary in order to get one's money's worth.

title: LeeAnn Agnelli Wed
description: LeeAnn Agnelli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Agnelli of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to Kenneth Lee Horton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgil K. Horton Jr. of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. George C. Bland Jr. officiated at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield. Mrs. Horton, 25 years old, received a law degree from Boston College in May. She and her husband, 23, are graduates of Dartmouth College, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He will rejoin the Boston management consulting firm Corporate Decisions next month following the completion of a one-year fellowship at the University of Bonn in West Germany.

description: Arizona State University, where alcohol consumption is restricted, has been having quite a few debates about drinking lately.

description: To the Editor:

title: Conlan Ends Holdout
description: THE contract was extended, and so Shane Conlan's season no longer stands to be shortened.

Cann and Laura Cann, both of Rochester. The Rev. Christopher Brown performed the ceremony.

description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHRONICLE OF A REVOLUTION: A Western-Soviet Inquiry Into Perestroika. Edited by Abraham Brumberg. (Pantheon, $24.95.) Just how the Soviet Union will emerge from the tumultuous events that are still shaking that country is still anybody's guess. But ''Chronicle of a Revolution,'' a collection of highly readable, provocative essays edited by Abraham Brumberg, a visiting scholar at Georgetown University, suggests that most of the changes that have swept across the country over the past five years were predictable. The authors, who include Soviet and Western scholars, argue that a conscious, if cautious, search for alternative economic and political structures began shortly after Stalin's death. In the Khrushchev era, economists and other academicians conducted more adventurous dialogues and experiments, which in time attracted wider attention and eventually extended to international relations and foreign policy questions. Even during Brezhnev's counterreformation, some observers saw advances in human rights and legal reform. The pace of these changes was slow; reforms encountered widespread resistance. But the moment finally came when a critical mass of revolutionaries led by Mikhail Gorbachev challenged everything, including the sacrosanct Communist Party, to forge a new civil society where new ideas could compete for power, including privatization and inevitably some kind of self-determination for the national republics of the Soviet Union. The specialists who cover these subjects offer no single view and have different preferences, but they salute, if not unanimously celebrate, the explosion of pluralism in the Soviet Union today.

title: Going Back to School
description: IN perhaps his most remarkable reversal of field, Emmitt Smith, the most prolific running back in University of Florida history, has said he is going to spend this fall seeking enlightenment instead of running for daylight.

title: Businesses Strengthen Commitments To Schools
description: LEAD: WHETHER it is an Atlantic Electric lineman speaking on electricity and safety at a school in South Jersey, a New Jersey Bell employee tutoring students at an Elizabeth school or the Harrah's Hotel-Casino financing a Pleasantville school trip, New Jersey businesses are not only interested in the state's education system but also trying to improve it.

title: Darien's Student Actors Find Peers in Moscow
description: LEAD: VISITS with students from the Soviet Union have shown a group from Darien High School how much young people from the two nations have in common. Members of Darien's Theater 308 spent much of July performing for Soviet audiences. This month, they welcomed a group from the Center of Musical and Dramatic Arts, in Moscow, who came to perform Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Aniky Baniky,'' a rock opera based on Russian folk tales, at Darien High School last Friday and Saturday.

title: Pesticide Makers Fight Export Curb
description: A battle over proposed legislation to bar the export of pesticides banned in the United States has escalated, with top chemical industry executives warning that it could cause job losses in plants around the country and impede scientific research.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: State Offers Amnesty to Tax Cheaters
description: TRYING to wring residents for every dollar they owe, the state is offering delinquent taxpayers a chance to pay up without penalty. State officials, trying to cope with a budget deficit of at least $200 million, are starting their tax-amnesty program this week, with a warning: ''If you don't pay now, we'll make you pay later.''

title: Decision Is Praised
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Campus Life: SUNY, New Paltz;   Canvas Bags Replace Plastic At a Bookstore
description: ''You're always looking for ways to make a difference, and when they stick it right in your face, how can you say no?'' said Elisa Quinzi, a junior photography major at the State University of New York at New Paltz.

title: Know Your Allies
description: Americans have a pretty clear idea why the United States is fighting in the Arab Middle East, what rings true and what clunks like a counterfeit coin.

title: Chased Out?
description: The slings and arrows of the Dartmouth Review have apparently taken their toll on William S. Cole. For several years, Dr. Cole, a tenured music professor at Dartmouth College, faced a stream of criticism from the conservative, off-campus Review, which commented caustically on his teaching style. The Review also criticized others, but its attacks on Dr. Cole were particularly harsh. Supporters of Dr. Cole, who is black, accused the newspaper of racial bias. The professor did not mention the publication in his letter of resignation, but referred to a ''series of events that began in 1983'' - the year he first clashed with the Review. He said that his departure might lead some to conclude that his critics ''have won a major victory,'' but he was simply weary of wrestling with the problem. Editors of the Review denied any motivation but the pursuit of academic excellence. James Wright, the dean of faculty, said Dr. Cole was ''a talented and dedicated teacher, scholar and musician.''

title: Bush's Trade Offer Gets a Warm Latin Reception
description: When President Bush made his offer to open a free-trade partnership with all of Latin America, President Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay jumped to the telephone and said he would accept.

title: Fashion;   Broomstick Skirts Bring Navaho Grace Anywhere
description: Broomstick skirts, the gathered three-tiered skirts worn by Navaho women, look as graceful in Columbus Avenue cafes as they do in the Southwest, where they are enthusiastically worn as a local uniform.

title: Mr. Dinkins Clears the Air
description: Tennis fans and players alike will notice some changes at the United States Open, which begins tomorrow at the National Tennis Center in Queens. Chris Evert, now retired, won't be there. And for the first time in over a decade, neither Jimmy Connors nor John McEnroe are among the seeded players. But the biggest and most welcome change will be the absence of the incessant roar of planes.

title: Pro Football;   Falcons Defeat Packers
description: Chris Miller passed 54 yards to George Thomas for a touchdown and Steve Broussard ran 71 yards for another tonight as the Atlanta Falcons beat the Green Bay Packers, 17-14, for their best-ever preseason start.

title: Middle-Class Radical
description: BLACK IN SELMA

title: Critic's Notebook;   Junk Holds Its Own As Vacation Reading
description: Vacation time is when even serious readers ask, Is there something good and junky I can read? Good and junky are not necessarily opposites, and it is possible to guess what such readers are looking for, or at least what they are not looking for, always bearing in mind Andre Maurois's observation that ''in literature, as in love, we are astonished by what is chosen by others.''

title: More Andy
description: HOLY TERROR

title: Guard Leader May Be Asked To Step Down
description: New York City's black correction officers association yesterday scheduled a meeting for Wednesday, at which it is expected to ask Phil Seelig, president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, to resign.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Works in Progress;   Softening of the Arteries
description: Traffic in Los Angeles has by now reached legendary dimensions, spawning potential remedies left and right. One of them is an experimental project called Pathfinder, a joint effort by the United States Department of Transportation's Federal Highway Administration, the California Department of Transportation (Caltrans) and the General Motors Corporation, that is aimed at figuring out whether giving drivers enough up-to-date information will enable them to avoid trouble.

title: The City's Rough Past: Frighteningly Familar
description: Crimes of violence up 30 percent in six years. Arrests up 20 percent. Five police officers killed in a year. Court calendars clogged. Citizens arming themselves. Racial tensions at a boil. Critics bewailing a ''carnival of murder.'' So it went in the New York City of the 1860's. Today's alarming crime rate and fearful populace have clear parallels in earlier eras of city history, although historians say they have to go back to the 19th century and earlier to find them.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: WHEN we were growing up, children didn't wear protective helmets when they rode their bicycles.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Swirls of Is-ness

title: West Africa Force Repels Attack by Liberia Rebels
description: West African troops sent to Monrovia to end Liberia's eight-month-old civil war repulsed an attack today by rebels loyal to Charles Taylor, the Ghana news agency reported.

title: Orchestras Outline Coming Season
description: AS summer progresses toward the Labor Day sunset, it is not too early to look ahead to the concerts that await in the fall - remembering that season subscribers not only get tickets at a discount but also assure themselves of better seats.

title: Singing the Cancellation Blues, Again
description: Seekers after mystic signs had to be nonplused the other day when Joseph Volpe, the newly appointed general director of the Metropolitan Opera, made it his first public act to confirm the company's abandonment of a planned Werner Herzog staging of Mozart's ''Zauberflote'' next season. (It will be replaced by a David Hockney production borrowed from the San Francisco Opera.) This might be seen as an evil omen for Mr. Volpe's future as ruler of the Met. His predecessor, Hugh Southern, made only one real public pronouncement during his six-month regime. That was to announce another cancellation, of the Met's plans to present two short seasons of unusual repertory and Peter Sellars productions at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Afghan President Returns; Kabul Attacked With Rockets
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan returned to Kabul today, hours after rockets slammed into the capital, killing 9 people and wounding 15.

title: The All-Purpose Bad Guy
description: BENEDICT ARNOLD

title: Amanda Cook and Steven Spalten, Florists, Marry
description: Amanda Pope Cook, a daughter of Edith Pope Cook of Washington, and Philip Sidney Cook of Santa Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to Steven Joseph Spalten, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert George Spalten of San Antonio. The Rev. Philip Compton, an Episcopalian, officiated at Beaulieu Gardens in Rutherford, Calif.

title: After 13 Years, Y of Northern Westchester Finds a Home
description: LEAD: ''WE have been up until now a Y without walls,'' said Martin Greenberg. ''We have been a lot of things without a center. We're now going to have a hub.''

title: Outdoors;   Prices Ebb at Tackle Auction
description: ANTIQUE fishing tackle and related paraphernalia, including fish decoys, continue to capture the fancy of collectors, but record-breaking prices are apparently a thing of the past, at least for the time being.

title: For Wonder Years, Actor Recalls L.I.
description: DAN LAURIA is nothing like Jack Arnold, the grumpy character he plays on the ABC-TV series ''The Wonder Years.'' Nothing.

title: In the Polls, the Economy Declines, Bush Doesn't
description: Saddam Hussein has thrown America's election-year political forces into a strange and unpredictable alignment.

title: Tennis;   Briskly, Edberg Defeats McEnroe
description: John McEnroe is showing signs of improvement in his attempt to regain his old form, but he's not ready for the Stefan Edbergs of the world.

title: Ms. Lippe to Wed Russell Davis
description: Barbara C. Lippe of Bronxville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Patricia Stuyvesant Lippe to Russell Davis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse A. Davis of Birmingham, Ala. Ms. Lippe is also the daughter of the late Vincent S. Lippe. An October wedding is planned.

title: Taiwan Accused in Deaths of 25 Refugees at Sea
description: Late last month, Chinese fishermen spotted a small oceangoing fishing boat that was stranded and seemed to be in trouble. Upon boarding they discovered the problem: the boat contained 25 corpses and a few more gasping passengers locked in several cabins below deck.

title: Righteous Rock: Issues You Can Dance To
description: It used to be easy to spot the rockers with good intentions. They had earnest expressions and dull wardrobes, and they put across their messages with an almost puritanical disdain for embellishment, clutching acoustic guitars as talismans of sincerity. A serious song might allow itself a singalong chorus, but it couldn't be seductive or sensual - that might seem too frivolous for important subjects.

title: COURT BACKS F.C.C. IN LICENSING RULES
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld rules requiring applicants for radio or television licenses to make only the briefest assertions that their programming will serve the public interest.

title: Hong Kong Dishes With Parisian Flair
description: HONG KONG TASTE, a new Chinese restaurant in Westport (formerly the Beansprout), is a benchmark of sorts: it does not bear the word Sichuan or Hunan in its title, and it presents the dishes of Hong Kong with Parisian flair, in a stylish setting as sophisticated as the presentations. With service as polished as the decor, each platter is set before you as a work of art, before being removed to a side table and dished up in individual servings.

title: Text of Resolution by U.N. Security Council
description: Following is the text of the Security Council resolution authorizing military action to halt all maritime trade with Iraq:

title: In The Region:;   Recent Sales
description: Basking Ridge $335,000

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 5 about magazines aimed at black audiences misstated the combined circulation for three of them.

title: A Travel Nut's Library
description: Old travel books occupy so many shelves in my apartment that a visitor might take me to be some kind of antiquarian nut. I am merely a travel nut, and the books are artifacts of that hobby. Just looking at their sonorous titles (''Forbidden Sands,'' ''Monsoon Seas,'' ''Dead Cities and Forgotten Tribes,'' ''They Reigned in Mandalay''), I am taken back to places in many parts of the world that I traveled far to see. I am also reminded of how the books found their way into my life.

title: A California Pension Fund Cuts the New York Umbilical Cord
description: How many people does it take to invest $17 billion? Just one manager and two part-time traders if you are the California Public Employees' Retirement System.

title: A Drugstore Industry Leader Raises the Level of Its Game
description: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar. But during a recent crowded lunch hour in downtown Chicago, Jim McCallister's cigar became proof of just how quickly a customer can get in and out of one of Walgreen's drugstores.

title: Dr. Innes Wed to Dr. James Zonghetti
description: Dr. Cynthia Howe Innes and Dr. James Robert Zonghetti, 1989 graduates of the Tufts University School of Dental Medicine, were married yesterday at the Union Church in Enfield Center, N.H. The Rev. Thomas Warner performed the Congregational ceremony. The bride, 28 years old, will keep her name. A graduate of Wheaton College, she is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Innes of Bronxville, N.Y. Her father retired as a vice president of C. H. Kline & Company, a chemical consulting firm in Fairfield, N.J. The bride, who practices in Canton, Mass., is a granddaughter of Mrs. Phillips C. Salman of Enfield, N.H., and the late Mr. Salman, who was the controller of the Mobil Oil Company in New York.

title: Move Over, Tex-Mex, It's Tex-Czech
description: With no McDonald's, no movie theaters and only one exit off the Interstate, West could be any one of the dusty rural towns that dot central Texas. But as the Czech Point of Texas, as the town sometimes calls itself, West is the unofficial capital of a thriving Czechoslovak culture that came to Texas more than 150 years ago.

title: 2 Men Slain by Man Posing as Park Ranger
description: A man impersonating a park ranger approached five men who were target shooting in the mountains northwest of here on Friday and, after ordering them to march down a hill, started shooting them.

title: Those Who Left Wall Street Are Not Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball;   Steinbrenner Had Ex-I.R.S. Man Check Winfield
description: The chief criminal investigator for the Internal Revenue Service in New Jersey retired and went to work the same week for George Steinbrenner, who hired him to look for evidence that a charitable foundation set up by Dave Winfield was involved in fraud and misappropriation of funds.

title: Demons in Cuba
description: THE MAGIC DOG

title: She Too Disliked Poetry
description: MARIANNE MOORE

title: His Life as a Drone
description: NATURAL ORDER

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Milford
description: Milford, a city of 52,000 residents living in mostly modest homes, is a bedroom community on Long Island Sound midway between Bridgeport and New Haven.

title: Judith Allen and Paul Mulkerrin Marry
description: Judith Gibson Allen and Paul Francis Mulkerrin were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Raymond Webster performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Perry, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Photographer's Eye Captures State's Industrial Landscapes
description: LEAD: BRICK factories, built in the 19th century by waterfalls or streams, are as typical of the Connecticut landscape as the more celebrated village greens of earlier days. Most mills are silent now, a few converted to new uses, but many simply abandoned, victims of the decline in manufacturing in New England.

title: In Big Factory, Small Businesses Prosper
description: It is now 36 years since the mills of the Alexander Smith & Sons Carpet Company in Yonkers shut down. The factory, founded in 1845, was at its zenith during World War II, when with a work force of 7,000 people, it operated around the clock producing blankets and tents for the United States armed services.

title: Meg Smith Wed To G. J. Kimball
description: Marilyn Ann Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Smith of Lexington, Mass., was married yesterday to George Jones Kimball, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Kimball Jr. of New York. The Rev. Richard T. Cleary performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Stalking a Summer Favorite: 'We're Addicted to This Crab'
description: ''WHEN the crabs are running, everyone goes a little crazy around here,'' said Tucker Crawford, a commercial fisherman fishing out of Verplanck, a close-knit village on the Hudson River.
