title: Hussein Has The Market Over a Barrel
description: As stock and bond prices plunged around the world last week, it appeared that investors were losing hope that the Gulf crisis will end quickly. If it doesn't, the markets' travails could continue.

title: The Stars of Autumn
description: Legs have it. The short skirts, leggings, jodhpurs and snug boots that are everywhere prove it. So do the taut bodysuits, dark or dazzling with patterns. Fabrics laced with stretch certainly have it, as do those that smolder to the touch - velvet, cashmere, spongy tweeds, mohairs and meltons. And sequins, paillettes and false gem stones never lost it.

title:
THEATER: Why the Furor Over 'Miss Saigon' Won't Fade;

For Asians Denied Asian Roles, 'Artistic Freedom' Is No Comfort
description: LEAD: The recent controversy swirling around the hit London musical ''Miss Saigon'' has stirred emotions in the theater world and beyond. When Actors' Equity voted earlier this month to bar the British actor Jonathan Pryce from reprising his role on Broadway because the union said it could not ''appear to condone the casting of a Caucasian in the role of a Eurasian,'' Cameron Mackintosh, the musical's producer, canceled the American production.

title: Give Law a Chance
description: ON THE LAW OF NATIONS

title: The Triumph of the Vulgar
description: DEMOCRATIC ELOQUENCE

title: Managing;   Teamwork or Tug of War?
description: Add team dynamics to the lengthening list of strains to come out of the tumultuous 1980's.

title: Latino Literature
description: To the Editor:

title:
MANVILLE JOURNAL;

Borough Refuses to Lose Its Expectation of a Renaissance
description: LEAD: ONCE a haven for Pennsylvania coal miners looking to tap into the American dream and escape the imminent threat of black lung, this Somerset County community of 11,670 could boast of self-sufficiency and industrial prowess.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Nassau Museum Defended and Praised
description: The Rip Van Winkle Award for 1990 surely must go to Harold Jaffe (''Fine Art Museum Is Not Needed in Roslyn,'' Aug. 5) for his notion that Nassau County's Museum of Fine Art should be abandoned because ''we simply do not need another fine-art museum located at its present location.''

title: Review/Pop;   Dialogue and Harmony By Blaze, a Vocal Trio
description: Most dance music seeks ecstasy in the moment it's heard, but Blaze, which performed Thursday night at S.O.B.'s, sets its mind to the future. Over the thumping beat of house music, which currently reigns in urban clubs, Blaze's songs proclaim hope and self-affirmation, insisting ''Problems always work themselves out'' and ''Keep on reaching and keep on striving.'' Blaze aims to do for house music what Earth, Wind and Fire did for disco, mixing faith and cultural pride with the latest dance beat. The group, dressed in African robes, was unceasingly positive; in Thursday's first set, the members brought their parents onstage for hugs. The three-man vocal group from Newark takes some pointers from 1970's soul. On its album, ''25 Years Later'' (Motown), it ties together songs with dramatic dialogue (a story about a black activist that doesn't have much to do with the songs), as Stevie Wonder has done. The music includes well-crafted ballads and a bossa nova along with dance tunes, and the group revels in harmonies and extravagant vocal display.

title: Black Producers Add a Fresh Nuance
description: Benny Medina, a 31-year-old record industry executive, had an idea for a sitcom about a teenager from the streets who goes to live with a family in Beverly Hills. He also had a promising star to play the role, a young rap singer named Will Smith, who is known professionally as the Fresh Prince. What Mr. Medina needed was a way to get his idea in front of the right people at the networks.

title: Riddoch Stays Put
description: HE took over the hot seat when Jack McKeon opted for his old office chair, and on Friday, Greg Riddoch found out that he could now sit back and relax a bit. The Padres announced that Riddoch, the coach who replaced McKeon as manager July 11 after McKeon left the dugout to concentrate full time on his job as vice president of baseball operations, would remain as the team's manager through next season.

title: Marcia L. Worth Marries
description: Marcia Lynn Worth, the daughter of Catherine T. Worth of Paterson, N.J., and Larry D. Worth of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to David Weil Baker, the son of Mrs. Leonard F. Baker of Washington and the late Mr. Baker. Judge Joseph J. Riva of the New Jersey Supreme Court officiated at the Hermitage in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. The bride, who is 23 years old and is keeping her name, graduated from Mount Holyoke College and will begins studies for a master's degree at the Teachers College of Columbia University next month. The bridegroom, 27, graduated from Bennington College. He is a candidate for a Ph.D. in English and comparative literature at Columbia.

title:
MUSIC;

Symphony Ends Season With Midori in a Debut
description: LEAD: A PROGRAM of works by Dvorak and Brahms is a natural combination, said the conductor Zdenek Macal, who will conduct music by both composers for the final concert in the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's summer season.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Like most other aspects of life in the Soviet Union, bridge has been affected by perestroika. The number of tournament players in Moscow has more than doubled in the past year from 400 to 1,000. The progression is expected to continue.

title: Thomas Hyde Jr. Weds Carri Payne
description: Carri April Payne, the daughter of Mrs. Linton M. Rigg of Villanova, Pa., and Lloyd E. Payne of Dallas, was married yesterday in Rosemont, Pa., to Thomas Allen Hyde Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Hyde of Midland, Tex. The Rev. John M. Holt performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Because our driveway slopes toward the garage and the drain is small, water collects during heavy rains. Also, since the garage floor is uneven, the rubber door bottom does not seal properly and water flows underneath.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing on Aug. 12 misstated telephone numbers for eating places and hotels in San Sebastian, Spain, and the immediate area. The correct numbers follow: Arzak, 27-8465; Akelarre, 21-2052; Nicolasa, 42-1762; Panier Fleuri, 42-4205; Chomin, 21-0705; Bodegon Alejandro, 42-7158; Kako, 55-1741; the Maria Cristina, 42-4900; the Hotel de Londres y de Inglaterra, 42-6989; Niza, 42-6663; Hostal Bahia, 46-1083, and Pension Lorea, 42-7258.

title: Hunter Stalks Records So Melody Can Linger
description: LEAD: GREGORY ADAMS'S name is music to the ears of frustrated record enthusiasts. The tedious search for an unusual, out-of-print or old recording can end with Mr. Adams, who runs The Record Player, a shopping service, from his apartment in West Hartford.

title: She's Tired Of McEnroe
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Cool, and as Colorful as You Like
description: The oversized shirt, loose and easy, seems perfect for the winding-down days of summer. It is cool and airy on hot and humid days, and can work up a good billow on windier ones.

title: THE LANGUAGE THING
description: President Bush's choppy locutions may remind some readers of the similar speech patterns of Alfred Jingle, a memorable if minor character found in Charles Dickens's ''Pickwick Papers.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Because our driveway slopes toward the garage and the drain is small, water collects during heavy rains. Also, since the garage floor is uneven, the rubber door bottom does not seal properly and water flows underneath.

title: For South African Businessmen, Mozambique Is a Place for Profit
description: As Michael Furze sat in the bar of the elegant Polana Hotel overlooking the Indian Ocean, he could have been forgiven for thinking he was back home in South Africa. His can of beer came from Johannesburg, he was expected to pay in South African rands and the voices of Afrikaans speakers could be heard in the room.

title: Streetscapes: 316 East 59th Street;   New Role for 'Gnomes' Home'
description: Storefront design bubbled with vitality in the 1920's and early 30's as small shops sought an identity amid a rising group of chain operations and department stores.

title: In Saddam Hussein's Iraq, All Real Power Settles at the Top
description: In the 11 years of Saddam Hussein's presidency, Iraq has produced no heir apparent, no viable domestic opposition, no democratic tradition and no popular leader in exile waiting to return in triumph.

title: For an Egyptian Father, The Joy of Sons' Escape
description: Outside the Mourci cafe on a dusty Cairo back street on Friday, Mohammed Gamal was all smiles. In a telephone call from Nuweiba, a port on the Sinai peninsula, he had learned that his five sons had returned safely to Egypt on a ferry from Jordan, after a grueling 1,200-mile bus journey from Kuwait.

title: Pro Football;   Simms Paces Giants
description: The magic was back for the Giants tonight, at least for one period. Phil Simms's 11-for-11 passing in the second quarter provided two touchdowns and a 17-7 preseason victory over the Jets.

title: Baptist Group Challenges Conservative Leadership
description: The steps taken at a Southern Baptist meeting here this week were still a long way from breaking America's largest Protestant denomination in two, but many here said that this outcome might be unavoidable.

title: Rebecca Clement Marries in Akron
description: Rebecca Diane Clement, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Clement of Akron, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Patrick Joseph Corless 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. P. Joseph Corless Jr. of Pomona, N.Y. The Rev. David Pumphrey officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The bride, who will keep her name, and Mr. Corless are graduates of Princeton University. She is to enter the Columbia University Business School in September. He is a manager at Andersen Consulting, a business unit of Arthur Andersen & Company in New York.

title: Ballet, Boogie, Rap, Tap and Roll
description: A wedge of hard-driving bodies moves like a robot battalion in precision drill through ''Rhythm Nation,'' the title song of Janet Jackson's current national tour. Legs chop wide open, then close again. They shoot out abruptly to the sides, then kick into jazz spins and bouncing splits to the floor. There are sedate pelvic jerks and a swiveling turn on a toe, trotting runs and purposeful syncopated walks. But essentially these are bodies rooted into the floor, taut yet alive in the way of a boxer edgily biding his time in the ring.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/August 19-24
description: COMPANIES

title: Oops! There Goes The Wine
description: In Anne Semmes's restaurant review of Beaugard's on July 29, she cites an incident of a busboy's knocking over a half bottle of wine as evidence of tentative and inexperienced service. Has she never knocked over something? I have, and so have busboys in the finest restaurants that we've frequented here and in Europe.

title: At a Rustic Resort, Style Doesn't Change
description: THE main office at the Solair Recreation League is the place to check on upcoming activities at the lakeside resort. Fliers announce a Saturday-night buffet and a children's sleep-out; the Labor Day craft sale will be followed by a wine-and-cheese party. Standing behind the counter, ready to offer more information on any of these events, is Marlene Gorman, a cheery woman clad in purple beach thongs and dangling earrings.

title: Are College Athletes' Rights Ignored?
description: Braxston Banks went for a job interview with the National Football League and was not hired. He was ''overqualified,'' or the N.F.L. ''just isn't hiring now,'' or the employer was simply not impressed.

title: Liberia Will Topple, But Which Way?
description: The question being asked in the eight-month-old Liberian civil war is no longer whether President Samuel K. Doe will be removed from office, but when and by whom.

title: INTERNATIONAL/3-24
description: Chicago's response to the gulf crisis has been muted. People agree with the decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia, but perhaps because they doubt war will come of it, there has been little flag-waving. 26

title:
The View From: Weston;

Advocates for Open Space Try to Shape Town's Priorities
description: LEAD: IN the early 1900's, the story goes, one could stand on any good-sized hill in Weston and get a clear view of Long Island Sound. Local historians describe an expanse of corn and onion fields, grassy hillsides and meadows of grazing livestock. Only low-lying stone walls cordoned off the large tracts of farmland.

title: Climbing Mount Fuji By Night
description: It's 3 A.M. on Mount Fuji as we grope our way up a massive scree slope in the dark. In this hour of reckoning, thin air and night silence fuse with exertion, exhilaration and lack of sleep. We're high. The objective is to be on top of the sacred peak at sunrise. The trail is indistinct but there's enough light to be aware of the elevation and the infinite black space that is not rock. Stars fill the sky and city lights map out the abode of mortals down below. The flashlights of fellow climbers ascend in a bizarre procession. No matter how you try to outwit the crowds, you never walk alone in Japan. Unbelievably, climbing Mount Fuji at night is not some deviation only gaijin (foreigners) are crazy enough to perform. It's a Japanese tradition to watch sunrise from the volcano, and in summer inspired pilgrims hike the mountain at all hours. As many as 400,000 people will climb Fuji-san, ''the honorable'' Fuji, this year. A night ascent, particularly with ample moonlight, has many advantages.

title: Buildup of U.S. Troops Alarms the Arab World;   Invasion of Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Earthly Risks of Business in Space
description: When the founders of Space Services Inc. built a rocket and named it the Conestoga, they had in mind an image of dogged determination in the face of daunting risk. They never intended their pioneering enterprise to be facing that risk in the financial desert just short of the next watering hole.

title: D.L. McCullough Weds Miss Mead
description: Kristen Key Mead, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Key Mead of Barrington, R.I., was married yesterday to Darrin Lee McCullough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lee McCullough of Athens, Ga. The Rev. Daryl Wayne Stahl performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Barrington.

title: Little League;   Shippensburg in Final
description: Bobby Shannon's two-run homer in the fifth inning lifted Shippensburg to a 5-4 victory today over Cypress, Calif., sending the Pennsylvania team into the championship game of the Little League World Series against powerful Taiwan.

title: A Newcomer to Politics Challenges Zaleski
description: LEAD: REPUBLICANS seeking to oust the incumbent Democratic State Assemblyman Terence M. Zaleski of Yonkers have adopted a tactic reminiscent of President Bush's 1988 campaign.

title: Tyros, Tyrants and Great Talents
description: LEAD:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PUTTING OUT. By Neil Ferguson. (Penguin, Paper, $8.95.) New York - arguably the style capital of the world - is the setting for the English writer Neil Ferguson's ambitious first novel, which turns out to be sometimes promising and brilliant yet often exasperating. In ''Putting Out,'' Mr. Ferguson has taken on a formidable and intriguing topic, the rough and tumble of a New York mayoral campaign complicated by terrorism and murder in the garment district. A bonfire couldn't contain the vanity of these characters: Max Faraday, a style-conscious police detective who dabbles in semiotics; Delia Summers, a calculating scientist with a passion for insects; and Tina Rauch and Rocco Da Silva, the clotheshorse candidates. ''Putting Out'' aspires to be a satire on New York life, an excoriation of modern mores in the tradition of Evelyn Waugh and Tom Wolfe. Mr. Ferguson occasionally reveals a sharp, savage eye for the habits and proclivities of New Yorkers, but it's hard to hear the real voices of the city in his pages. His New Yorkers talk like Oxbridge dons and his characters' vocabulary owes more to Fleet Street than Flatbush. There's the suspicion that Mr. Ferguson did his research from afar: he's got the physical landmarks nailed down, but the ambiance, the feel of the city just isn't here. Like the wardrobe fixtures it often describes, ''Putting Out'' has the problems of many a failed fashion: the design is provocative, but the execution leaves much to be desired.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Shops and Housing May Soon Join Yachts
description: Since the early 1900's a 14-acre peninsula in the west branch of Stamford Harbor has been a boat yard, a boat-building site and a marina, where forests of sailboat masts tower over yachts, speed boats and catamarans.

title: Stewards of a Most Delicate Resource
description: LEAD: THERE are times when it is difficult to explain why a grown man, after 40 summers of doing the same thing, still smears on the sun screen, slings a whistle around his neck and spends the days of June, July and August perched on a wooden platform staring out over the waves as they march relentlessly toward their final foamy collision with the bathers.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Crayola Gold, Buster Brown Blues
description: LEAD: I WAS probably the only child who looked forward to going back to school. But only for the school supplies: the crisp pink oblong erasers that looked like bubble gum, the sophistication of being allowed to use a pencil sharpener, the crackle of new black-and-white notebooks when you opened them, the fresh-start promise of the empty pages (which later held the 45's and 68's in arithmetic tests with the teacher's ominous inscription, ''Parent must sign'').

title: Rediscovering The Pioneers Of the Blues
description: To get a sketchy idea of what musical, and therefore cultural, life was like in the first half of the 20th century, a collector has had to become single-minded, slogging through used-record bins or buying expensive imported albums and CD's from specialty stores. It is impossible, using albums released by domestic record companies, to construct a decent chronology of American music that reflects the variety of the last 75 years or so.

title: Drawing Developers Into Day Care
description: On weekday mornings, 3-year-old Carolyn Keen, sometimes with a cherished toy in tow, heads with her father, Robert, for the Heller Industrial Park in Edison, N.J., where he is a forklift operator at Linden Motor Freight Company.

title: Teaching the Bartender How to Say No, Firmly
description: LEAD: THE man at the bar had obviously had a few too many.

title: Discovered Along the Flowered-Silk Route
description: When it comes to antiques, whether they be furniture or textiles, their history bespeaks a world of fashion and a way of life that affected the owners as well as the makers. But rare is the exhibition of antiques that takes this factor into account; if an exhibition does, objects appreciated for their beauty alone can also tell a story of commerce.

title: Drug Suspects Arrested Holding Bag, Literally
description: Two patrol officers responding to a routine complaint surprised three suspected drug dealers in upper Manhattan early yesterday morning as they walked out of an apartment carrying shopping bags full of cocaine and cash, the police said.

title: Boon to Paper in El Salvador: Free Speech
description: In an act of journalistic courage here, the small afternoon newspaper Diario Latino, in May published a scathing report by investigators for the United States Congress asserting that 14 of El Salvador's 15 highest-ranking officers had commanded troops responsible for killing and torturing hundreds of civilians.

title: Alison Boardman Is Wed in Jersey
description: Alison Boardman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Boardman of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew James Goessling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Goessling of Evanston, Ill. Royce R. Anderson, a recent graduate of the Drew University divinity school, performed the ceremony at the Morristown (N.J.) Unitarian Fellowship, with the sanction of Mayor William Layton of Far Hills, N.J.

description: Nancy Seligson and Peter R. Green were married yesterday at the Locust Valley, L.I., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan Seligson. Rabbi Nancy Weiner officiated. The bride, 29 years old, graduated from Northwestern University. She is an independent television associate producer. The bridegroom, 30, is a son of Mrs. Richard Seidman of Ancramdale, N.Y., and Paul Green of Westport, Conn. A cum laude graduate of Seattle University, he is a manager at International Investor magazine in New York.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Soothing Soups, Glorious Noodles and Bargains
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Look, Ma, No Hands, or Tim Burton's Latest Feat
description: ''This is the most uncomfortable I've ever been in a movie,'' said the actor Johnny Depp between puffs on a cigarette proferred by an assistant on a makeshift roach clip. Mr. Depp was clad in skintight black leather from Adam's apple to toes. His hair was a mass of black tangles, and his face was made up like a mime's, except that it was covered with prosthetic scars. Most startling of all were the sets of lethal-looking blades where his hands should have been.

title: Mutual Funds;   Hunting the Closed-End Conversion
description: Many closed-end funds are selling at steep discounts these days, offering investors the tantalizing possibility of handsome profits. After all, a discount is a bargain, whether you buy a cartful of groceries or a basket of stocks. But in the arcane world of closed-end funds, some investors are finding that bargains can prove illusory and discounts don't necessarily turn into dollars.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: 33 Are Hurt at a Rap Concert
description: About 40 youths scaled gates at an amphitheater during a concert by the rap group Public Enemy on Friday night and randomly assaulted concert-goers and security guards, the police said. Thirty people were treated for minor injuries at first aid stations and three others were treated at a hospital, the police said. The assaults in the outer plaza of the Shoreline Amphitheater apparently did not disrupt the concert, which was attended by about 8,000 people.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about George Balanchine's troupe Les Ballets 1933 characterized the company incorrectly. It was the choreographyer's first company in the West, not his first American one.

title: Campus Life: Texas;   Parents Sue A Fraternity Over a Fatal Fall
description: The mother and stepfather of a University of Texas fraternity member who died here in September 1988 after falling 150 feet from a cliff have filed a $30 million negligence suit against the fraternity.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Aug. 11

title: David Rose, Composer, Dies at 80; Wrote for Television and Movies
description: David Rose, a composer and conductor whose work in television, films and recordings won four Emmy awards, 22 Grammys and an Oscar nomination, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 80 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: At Jacob's Pillow, Endless Summer
description: The gardens at Jacob's Pillow are slug-eaten, and the mosquitoes have grown sharks' jaws. Samba drumbeats are heard from studio windows as classes in Afro-Brazilian dance finish out the summer school calendar. And the final entry of the 1990 concert schedule is performances by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane & Company in the barnlike Ted Shawn Theater through this Saturday.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Waterbury, Vt.;

Esthetics Issue Stirring Debate
description: LEAD: Concerned that development threatens Vermont's vistas, and thus its tourism, the state has begun trying to define the esthetics of rural landscape and architectural design.

title: New County Sludge Plan Ready for Vote
description: LEAD: FACED with mounting fines of $40,000 a day that now total more than $1.3 million, Nassau County will make a new attempt tomorrow to solve the gnawing problem of what to do with its sewer sludge.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

White-Haired, Energetic and Shunted Aside
description: LEAD: WHEN I stopped in to visit her, she was hunched over a portable typewriter at the dining room table, pecking away with two fingers. An instruction book lay open at her side.

description: Karla Mary Buchinskas, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edmund Buchinskas of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday to Kenneth Kinam Coe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Yun Myung Coe of Seoul, South Korea. The Rev. Carmel F. Miotke, a Roman Catholic priest, officated at St. Thomas Chapel in Falmouth, Mass. Mrs. Coe, 31 years old, is a magna cum laude graduate of Clark University with a master's degree in fine arts from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. She is the studio manager of Vignelli Associates, a design firm in New York. Her husband, 26, is an associate at Houlihan, Lokey, Howard & Zukin, a financial services company in New York. He graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles and has an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania.

description: Neither rain nor wind nor an abbreviated program kept thousands of picnickers from the giant, informal party on the Great Lawn of Central Park for a free outdoor concert.

title: Builders Facing Rough Seas
description: The annual round of fall boat shows, which begins with a major trade exhibit in Boston this weekend, brings with it grim forecasts for the marine industry. But in the midst of the manufacturers' quagmire exists an area where optimism rules the waves: in the marine export business.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Because our driveway slopes toward the garage and the drain is small, water collects during heavy rains. Also, since the garage floor is uneven, the rubber door bottom does not seal properly and water flows underneath.

description: S.& L.'s: Placing the Blame

title: Affordability in the Dearest U.S. Market
description: LEAD: When Casa Guadalupe, with its 22 apartments, opened recently in a rough East Los Angeles neighborhood, nearly 300 families applied. Small wonder; the two- and three-bedroom units had dishwashers, air-conditioning, balconies and enclosed patios - unusual upscale amenities in a low-income housing project bordering a major freeway.

title:
Focus: Southeast Florida;

Developers Dangle Housing Incentives
description: LEAD: Levitt homes, a builder based here, ran a two-page ad in The Miami Herald in July announcing a 48-hour sale-a-thon in which it would reduce the prices of its houses by $10,000 or $11,000. Single-family detached homes normally priced at $95,000 would sell for $85,000 and $80,000 homes would go for $69,000.

title: Annual Air Force Show Goes On, But Thoughts of the Mideast Prevail
description: THEY came armed with picnic baskets and lawn chairs and rations of summer sandwiches and fruit juices. But their minds, like those of the people in the planes they had come to see, were on events unwinding in the Saudi Arabian desert.

title: At 98, an Ex-Olympian Has a New Spurt of Fame
description: LEAD: AT the age of 98, he has received enough medals and trophies to open a museum, and he says he sometimes signs so many autographs that his hand aches.

title: In Nice, a Sumptuous New See-Through Museum
description: Nice, the largest city on the Cote d'Azur, has long had a double personality. It attracts tourists because of its beaches, but it also functions as a cultural center: the Chagall Museum, the Matisse Museum, the Museum of Fine Arts are all proof of this. These institutions, however, are not involved with living art. That lack was corrected with the opening of the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art two months ago.

description: With lots of American flags and a homemade sign that read ''Send a message to our troops in the Persian Gulf,'' Lydia Munger and her friends set out on a mission this week, a campaign to flood soldiers and sailors in the Middle East with cheerful postcards from back home.

News analysts called the presence of American troops in the path of Saddam Hussein's ''megalomaniacal and hegemonic'' ambitions a tripwire. Lexicographers donned their battle gear.

title: Protecting Creativity in a Global Market
description: As this nation ponders its place in world markets, it is increasingly clear that the protection of intellectual property and the upholding of American patent laws are inexorably intertwined with competitiveness.

title: Women's Shelter Wants Women Only on Its Board
description: Every day more than 100 women drop in at Rosie's Place because they are homeless and hungry, and in most cases because they have been abused at the hands of men. At Rosie's, the first homeless shelter in the country for females only, women are always welcome.

Hirshorn of Schenectady, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick H. Koch and Rabbi Ben J. Leinow officiated at St. Rita's Roman Catholic Church in Dallas.

title: CRIME
description: You hang around Shifty Lou Anderson long enough, you pick up all sorts of useful race track tips. Can't hurt to know a new name for The Daily Racing Form (''the horseplayers' Koran'') or what a ''hospital handicap'' is (a race with most of the horses ''bandaged to their eyeballs like Egyptian mummies'' because of ''various crippling infirmities''). Things like that.

title: Visual Era or No, Voices Are Back In the Picture
description: Kathleen Turner in the movies - a vocal oasis in a desert of sound. The Voice may be making a comeback. There is some evidence in movies and on television that we are headed toward an aural reawakening. Until Ms. Turner, there had been no distinctive voices in film for decades. In the old days, Katharine Hepburn and Bette Davis and Jimmy Stewart and Cary Grant pleased the ear as well as the eye. Their singular voices filled movie theaters just as their images filled the screens. Idiosyncratic, unmistakable, the sounds they made took up residence in our synapses. Just as Fred Astaire never really possessed Ginger Rogers until he danced with her, so Spencer Tracy never became Spencer Tracy until he opened that puckish mouth and spoke. Then the picture was complete. The voice made the image whole.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CASTLES IN THE SAND

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a chart last Sunday with an article on the petroleum industry's outlook given the Middle East crisis omitted the names of several major oil producers. The complete chart appears today on page 19.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: TORNADO ALLEY, by Craig Nova. (Delta, $10.95.) Carrying a gun and a cylinder of her father's ashes, Marie Boule escapes from her dreary Pennsylvania hometown and heads for a complicated existence in San Francisco. '' 'Tornado Alley' is the kind of book one takes to the beach or to the mountains for the purpose of total immersion,'' Andrei Codrescu said here last year. ''There are brilliant stretches of writing as well as truly touching glimpses of deeply hurt but paradoxically alive people.''

title: Irene Mahoney Married on L.I.
description: The Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church in Southampton, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Irene Marie Mahoney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Mahoney of Southampton, to Carl Eric Trautmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Trautmann of Westport, Conn. Msgr. Edmond J. Trench and the Rev. Peter Colapietro performed the ceremony.

title: THE TRAGEDY OF DETROIT
description: Your article on Detroit implied that the 1967 riot caused whites to abandon Detroit and that Detroit and suburbs were more segregated than other cities. The riot may have accelerated a trend, but the pattern of population shift was quite clear. Blacks were already buying in the northwest, the city's most attractive area, and the housing available to Detroit's black citizens was probably the best of any major American city.

title: Cool Eating During Kyoto's Dog Days
description: In the deep green pockets of Kyoto, in temple gardens and the groves surrounding Shinto shrines and the lush park enclosing the Imperial Palace, short-lived cicadas raise their shrill, mournful voices. The overcast and intermittently cool rainy season ends (almost always) by the middle of July, and from then well into August are the dog days of Japan's summer.

title: Ms. Stringer Wed To David Usdan
description: Elizabeth Doble Stringer, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur C. Stringer of Brewster, Mass., was married there yesterday to David Edward Usdan, the son of Betsy See Dean of New York and Myron S. Usdan of Ardmore, Pa. The Rev. James A. Robinson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Parish Church.

title: World Markets;   Even Norway Takes a Nose Dive
description: With its North Sea oil production, Norway's stock market should have been reasonably immune to the swirling downdraft from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait that has dragged most of the world's stock markets to new lows for the year.

description: The shadow cast by Black Monday is growing longer and longer through the canyons of lower Manhattan, where commercial vacancy rates continue to climb higher than they have in years.

title: Ground Covers Go Beyond Pachysandra
description: SOMETIMES ground covers other than grass are the best solution to protect bare earth. If soil is not covered with something, weeds move in rapidly. The goal is to plant cover that will establish itself quickly. This is especially true for areas like slopes or heavily shaded patches under mature trees.

title: China Finds a Han Tomb and 'Men of Mud'
description: Workers building a road in central China appear to have stumbled on an archeological treasure: a 2,100-year-old network of underground vaults said to contain tens of thousands of terra-cotta sculptures buried with a Han Dynasty emperor, during one of the greatest civilizations of ancient times.

Gratsias performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I.

Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: Common Market Prepares for German Unity
description: With German unification now only weeks away, the 12-nation European Community has hurriedly drafted a set of provisional measures aimed at smoothing the integration of East Germany's backward economy into this prosperous region.

title: 1,500 Riot Over Siberian Shortages and March on Party Office
description: Rioters in the Soviet city of Chelyabinsk smashed cars and shop windows and tried to storm a Government office in a third successive night of protests over food, tobacco and other shortages, the official press agency Tass said today.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Plants at the Seashore: A Pleasant Diversion
description: LEAD: From Nantucket to Far Rockaway, people are enjoying the last of the summer sun. Like single-minded soldiers, they trudge across the sand with beach chairs, coolers and umbrellas and stare for the rest of the day at the massive monochrome of ocean, perhaps occasionally noting a squawking gull.

title: Fear Cracks Smooth Facade of the Saudi Capital
description: The other day a mysterious message was faxed to offices in the Saudi capital here ostensibly offering advice on how to deal with the deadly effects of chemical weapons. The fax soon became the talk of the town, fueling the already deep-seated worries over Iraq's poison gas capability.

title: Minh-Chau Luong, Translator, Wed
description: Minh-Chau Luong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luong-Si Chuong of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to William Maxwell Crouch Jr., a son of Mrs. William M. Crouch of Bridgeport, Conn., and the late Mr. Crouch. The Rev. Jacques Bossiere, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church Center in New York.

title: After a Stray Shot: A Girl's Family Seeks Meaning in a Random Loss
description: Daisy L. Rasberry lives as if suspended in time. She has not been to work for two months. Nor has she slept a full night since the evening of June 23, when a Saturday shopping trip with two of her daughters ended with her 10-year-old ''baby,'' Shaniqua, bleeding in her arms from a fatal gunshot wound to the chest.

title: Data Update
Tasty Thai Cuisine for the Uninitiated
description: THAI food has become commonplace on Long Island, but when the Bangkok Palace opened in Woodmere over five years ago, the restaurant was an exotic trailblazer. This Five Towns pioneer has recently changed ownership and renamed itself New Bangkok Palace.

But for those familiar with the tales of pious ascetics and misty mountain redoubts, where many of Japan's religious sects originated, the nearby Kii Peninsula can bring one closer to the country's religious roots, not to mention its striking natural landscape.

title: Facts and Feelings About Dresden

On Feb. 13, 1945, English and American bombers engineered an air attack on the city that created a fire storm that merged human flesh and Baroque masterworks into a heap of ashes. According to some accounts, 300,000 inhabitants were killed.

description: Eliot Weinberger's letter (''Farm Stand Story Is About One Person,''Aug. 19), about a retail farm stand in the residential zone of East Hampton, requires correcting.

title: In China, Too, Centrifugal Forces Are Growing Stronger
description: One of the Chinese Communist Party's proudest accomplishments is that it reunited a nation torn apart by warlords and recreated a central government that could lead the country. That achievement stands, but in these days of economic slowdown, it is somewhat undermined by provinces that are quietly carving up the vast national market into protectionist fiefs.

title: County and Business: A Growing Partnership
description: LEAD: FOR the last few years, the county and the local business community have shown a growing willingness to join forces on some of the major issues facing Westchester, like housing, transportation and education.

title: St. Luke's Status as a Trauma Center Is Dropped
description: The Emergency Medical Service notified St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center on Friday that it would no longer bring trauma patients to St. Luke's because the hospital's trauma center does not meet the service's standards.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Collector's Auctions, Ltd. will hold a two-day sale on Sept. 6 and 7. It is one of the largest collections of medals ever offered.

title: Eleanor B. FitzSimons, Public Relations Executive
description: Eleanor B. FitzSimons, a trustee of the Citizens Budget Commission and a public relations executive, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 65 years old. Her longtime associate, Louis Weintraub, said she died of cancer.

title: What's Star Style?
description: The season's brightest looks, plus a few that are fading fast.

title: Karen Page Wed in Boston
description: Karen Ann Page, a daughter of Joan A. Page of St. Charles, Ill., and George L. Page of Mount Prospect, Ill., was married yesterday to Andrew Noel Dornenburg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Dornenburg of Concord, Calif. The Rev. Judith Bowman Howie, an African Methodist Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Biba Restaurant in Boston. The bride, who is 28 years old, is keeping her name. She is a management consultant at Braxton Associates, the strategy consulting division of Deloitte & Touche in Boston. The bridegroom, 31 and a chef at Biba, operates his own specialty catering company in Boston.

title: The Education of a Phony
description: LEAD:

title: Alicia Drummey Weds John Doner
description: Alicia Louise Drummey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Drummey of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. John William Doner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Royal DeVere Doner of Chalfont, Pa. The Rev. Canon Robert Broesler performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City.

title: Longtime Official Dropped From Michigan Ticket
description: Lieut. Gov. Martha Griffiths, who served in Congress for 20 years and was a force behind its passage of the equal rights amendment, has been dropped from the 1990 Democratic gubernatorial ticket by Gov. James J. Blanchard.

title: Job for Bob Wade
description: HE resigned under extreme pressure as Maryland's basketball coach last year during an investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association that uncovered recruiting and other violations by members of his staff. Now Bob Wade is going to work for the Baltimore parks department. Next week, Wade will begin a job created for him by Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke. His salary will be $46,000, about half what he made as coach. Wade will review parks department athletic programs and ''look at ways that we can enhance those programs,'' said Alama T. Bell, parks department a spokeswoman. (AP)

title: Amy Fukae Wed To Bryan Massey
description: Amy Christine Fukae, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kensuke Fukae of Monsey, N.Y., and Tokyo, was married yesterday to Bryan P. R. Massey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Massey of Orpington, Kent, England. The Rev. Roslyn V. Parrett performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Sheldwich, Kent.

title: U.S. Takes Back Seat in Third World
description: The United States and Japan have already traded places in the global financial hierarchy. Long the world's greatest exporter of capital, the United States over the past decade has become a capital importer on a gigantic scale to finance its chronic deficits. Japan's economic surge has made it the world's pre-eminent international creditor.

title: Reform Can't Be Left to the Education Establishment
description: LEAD: Since the mid-1980's, the educational establishment has been intent on reform. School systems have received more money; students have faced higher graduation requirements; and teachers and administrators have been enlisted to restructure school management. These efforts have largely failed. Average S.A.T.

title: DEALS
description: Baseball

title: Postings: Italian-Designed, Korean-Made;   Furniture Showrooms for 5th Avenue
description: At a time when entrepreneurs from Korea have become New York City's leading food retailers and moved aggressively into other businesses, that country's largest furniture exporter is about to make a foray into the city from an 11-story building it has bought at 315 Fifth Avenue.

title: 'Sexual Personae'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lead Paint Poisons Children Despite 1971 Law on Removal
description: Nearly 20 years after Congress declared lead-based paint a health hazard and ordered it stripped from the nation's stock of federally subsidized housing, it remains on the walls and woodwork of dwellings across the nation, posing a lasting toxic threat that medical experts say afflicts as many as one in every six children.

title: Anne Dresselhuys Weds
description: At the Fox Point (Wis.) Lutheran Church, Anne Catherine Dresselhuys, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donn R. Dresselhuys of Milwaukee, was married yesterday to Michael John Alix, a son of John A. Alix of Frederick, Md., and Tincy Crouse of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. David Schoob officiated. Mrs. Alix, 27 years old, graduated from Mount Holyoke College. She will begin studying for an M.B.A. degree next month at Columbia University. Mr. Alix, 29, graduated from Duke University and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. He is a vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ''YOU GOTTA HAVE HEART.'' By Richard Adler with Lee Davis. (Donald I. Fine, $21.95.) ''Hernando's Hideaway,'' ''Hey There,'' ''Steam Heat,'' ''Heart,'' ''Whatever Lola Wants'' - for such songs from his first two shows, ''The Pajama Game'' and ''Damn Yankees,'' which opened on Broadway within a year of each other in the mid-1950's, Richard Adler remains one of the more beloved names in American musical comedy. In his autobiography, '' 'You Gotta Have Heart','' written with the music historian Lee David, Mr. Adler says that he never recovered from the death of his songwriting collaborator, Jerry Ross, only months after ''Damn Yankees'' opened in 1955. ''Eighteen short months, and the memory of them would have to do me for a lifetime,'' writes Mr. Adler. With only intermittent success writing commercial jingles and Government-sponsored symphonies, his career has languished ever since, and the peripatetic account it receives here tends to hover on one ''doomed musical venture'' after the other. With occasional comments on the various theatrical personalities involved, '' 'You Gotta Have Heart' '' tells of a Broadway that is no more. Mr. Adler's details of what went right with his two hits - and what went wrong with just about everything else - can be both enlightening and amusing. Some of the best stories entail his coordinating Presidential galas at John F. Kennedy's request, including the memorable birthday celebration for Kennedy at Madison Square Garden that featured Marilyn Monroe. However, Mr. Adler's memoir is perhaps sincere to a fault, as his cosmic advice proves heady going for anyone who has not become, as he has, a proselytizing convert of the karmic philosophy of Shirley MacLaine. Though metaphysics may have provided Mr. Adler with the relief he sought for a bumpy career and for the death of his son Christopher, the relevant issues of his book are obfuscated rather than clarified by his philosophy. It makes for sappy reading.

title: A Fall Wedding For Barbara Burg
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman Burg of Woodstock, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Barbara Burg and Steven Schieffelin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Schieffelin of Albany.

title: Miss Miller Wed To B. C. Barstow
description: Cynthia Ellen Miller and Beverly Chew Barstow were married yesterday at St. Martin's in the Field Episcopal Church in Biddeford Pool, Me. The Rev. Mark S. Delcuze performed the ceremony.

title: Pro Football;   Thomas and Jets Agree on a Deal
description: The Jets reached agreement today with Blair Thomas, their No. 1 draft choice, and the running back from Penn State held a brief news conference, then suited up for did not play in the exhibition game against the Giants at Giants Stadium.

title: In Poland, Reveries of 1980 Give Way to Reality
description: Poland is awash in nostalgia this month as the nation revisits those simpler times of a decade ago, when an August strike at the Gdansk shipyard gave birth to the Solidarity union. To Solidarity's leaders, this anniversary has been an occasion for pleasant reminiscenses about the years when their lives were a straightforward morality play: dissidence against Communist oppressors.

title: A Fond Look at 'a Sport for Everyone'
description: MOST people who know me are aware of my fondness for the sport of tennis. I was first introduced to the game more than 40 years ago in Trenton by my good friend Dr. Bill Hayling.

title: Thrown Out
description: The lawsuit brought by Charles H. Keating Jr. to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Associaton bounced like a bad check last week. In what Federal officials called ''an extremely important victory,'' a Federal judge dismissed Mr. Keating's suit, accused him and other Lincoln executives of pillaging the Arizona institution and said the Government was ''fully justified'' in taking over Lincoln last year. Mr. Keating had claimed in his suit that Lincoln's failure was the result of a vendetta against him by Federal regulators. Judge Stanley Sporkin ridiculed that contention. He said Lincoln's failure, which is expected to cost taxpayers more than $2 billion, was caused by the people who ran it. ''Bluntly speaking, their actions amounted to a looting of Lincoln,'' he said. Mr. Keating's lawyers had no comment and did not say whether they would appeal.

title: Are College Athletes' Rights Ignored?
description: As long as college athletic programs embrace commercialism and are little more than proving grounds for the pros, student athletes will suffer.

title: Currency;   Pressure on the Dollar
description: Another week and another milestone for the dollar. First, the dollar set a new low against the German mark on Aug. 14. Then, last Thursday, it fell to a low against the Swiss franc, 1.2560, and set another low aganst the mark, 1.5444. At the same time, the weary dollar fell further against the three popular high-yield currencies that are backed by high interest rates and are also net energy exporters, making them less vulnerable to the Persian Gulf crisis. On Thursday, the pound jumped three cents to $1.9555; the Australian dollar rose to 83.52 cents. And the dollar fell to a 12-year low against the Canadian dollar of 1.1293. The dollar got a little lift from tension in the Middle East on Friday, as the Iraqis surrounded foreign embassies in Kuwait City.

title: Men, Women and Understanding
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HARD CITY. By Clark Howard. (Dutton, $21.95.) Clark Howard's autobiographical novel is set in the slums of Chicago's West Side in the 1950's. Its hero, Richie, is a 12-year-old who escapes from a succession of malignant foster homes, as well as his heroin-ridden mother, to strike out on his own. While polishing his talents as a petty thief, he manages to eke out an existence by working in a bowling alley, where he secretly holes up at night. When his mother dies, Richie is sent to a sadistic correctional institution for juveniles, then later is released to his maternal grandmother, who lives in a small town in Tennessee, where he is ostracized not only for being the son of a convict but also because he's a Yankee. Two factors sustain Richie: the hope of finding his father, who disappeared after his release from prison, and a passion for books. Although there are no surprises in Mr. Howard's 19th novel, it sustains a sense of tension, moving smoothly between flashbacks of the events of Richie's early years and the traumatic experiences of his adolescence, then on to his return to Chicago and his emergence as a young man in control of his life.

title: The Essential Chatham
description: Like other towns much visited by tourists, Chatham, Mass., reveals its many faces only to those who take time to look below the surface. To casual travelers who leave their cars in the public parking lot after surviving the summer traffic jam, a stroll along its gently curving Main Street with elegant low-key shops, restaurants and inns unobtrusively tucked into sea captains' houses, conjures up the picture of Olde New England charm, even when T-shirts are being sold. To several thousand weekenders and weekly renters, a good part of Chatham's attraction probably results from its great variety of fine sandy public beaches on ocean, bay, sound or glacial pond. The same sparkling waters provide recreation and challenge to the summer sailor and sports fisherman.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: COWBOY DREAMS

title: Squeeze - and Contain - Iraq
description: The United States has forged two potent weapons against Iraq, a worldwide diplomatic alliance and a swelling army in the Saudi sands. Some analysts fear the alliance cannot long hold, however, and impatiently urge that force be used immediately to quell Iraq's grandiose ambitions once and for all. But there's a solid chance that the alliance and its trade embargo will force Saddam Hussein to negotiate.

title: Mary O'Connor and C. S. Morgan Wed
description: Mary Gallagher O'Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas David O'Connor of Loudonville, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Smith Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Phillip Morgan of Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Robert McNulty performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: The Executive Computer;   Being Ready for the Day When the Lights Go Out
description: Wall Street learned its lesson at 1:13 P.M. on Aug. 13 when traders' computer screens went dead. A fire in a Consolidated Edison substation in lower Manhattan knocked out power to much of the financial district. The blackout served to demonstrate how important it is for companies to have a reliable backup power supply for their computers.

title: Tom Jones Looks Forward and Back
description: TOM JONES was sitting at his desk in his West Cornwallhome ''trying to remember.'' That's the apt title of a 27-page ''selective personal reminiscence'' he came up with last February. Subtitled ''One Man's Recollections of the Origins of 'The Fantasticks,' '' it appears as the forward for the newly published (Applause Books) 30th-anniversary edition of the evergreen musical whose best-known song is ''Try to Remember.'' The book also contains a scrapbook including the lyrics of a new song, illustrations by Harvey Schmidt, Mr. Jones's collaborator, and assorted memorabilia.

title: Iraq Yearns for Greatness - and an Identity
description: Behind a pale brick fence on the outskirts of the Iraqi village of Qurna sits a small, gnarled apple tree with a double trunk. A bronze plaque tells visitors they have reached the Garden of Eden. But this unassuming shrine is little more than a tourist trap for weekend picnickers. There is, after all, another Garden of Eden in Syria, and nobody can be sure where the real site is. The existence of this tree and the claims made for it illustrate a force that drives President Saddam Hussein's Iraq: a yearning for greatness amid uncertainty about its very identity.

title: Janacek's 'House' Is Not a Home
description: The novels of Fyodor Dostoyevsky pack enough violence, sex and intrigue to make even Tosca blush, but they have inspired surprisingly few operas. Perhaps composers balk at their sheer mass. Or perhaps it's at all those feverish philosophical dialogues on the Essence of Being.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Elderly Have a Lot to Offer The Baby Boomers
description: LEAD: RECENTLY, I listened to several friends - all in their 70's or 80's - reminisce about nickel subway rides, swing bands and gasoline at 11 cents a gallon. One of them said to me, age 38, ''You must think we're a bunch of old fogies.'' ''Absolutely not,'' I assured him. ''Keep talking.'' I'm grateful for my elderly friends.

title: Lanford Wilson Tries a New Role
description: LEAD: LANFORD WILSON, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, says he has been writing about outsiders ''all my life.''

title: Maria-Flora Miller, College Student, Weds Anthony Smoller, Film Producer
description: Maria-Flora Miller, the daughter of Ava Mohas of Mill Neck, L.I., and Leverett Saltonstall Miller of Fairfield, Fla., was married yesterday to Anthony Michael Smoller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Smoller of Larchmont, N.Y. James H. McIntyre, the town justice of Long Lake, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Camp Togus, the summer home of the bride's family in Whitney Park in the Adirondacks.

title: Sorry, the President's English Won't Do
description: To the Editor:

title: When Raccoons Drop In
description: At the suggestion of the A.S.P.C.A., we called Tender Trappers of Wild Life and were told there was nothing unusual about raccoons this far from the cabin at Rangely Lake in Maine, where my family first experienced them. ''We get calls about raccoons every day,'' said our correspondent, ''from all over the Bronx and Manhattan, too.''

title: Are College Athletes' Rights Ignored?
description: Are college athletes' rights ignored?

title: Security, Passenger Delays and the Gulf Crisis
description: The homebound crush through European airports in late August and early September will be made more difficult this year by security measures augmented because of the Persian Gulf crisis. In mid-August, cities that were checked - Athens, Frankfurt, London, Madrid, Paris and Rome - reported that security requirements so far had delayed no departures, but spokesmen for United States airlines said the carriers were braced for a later impact.

title: For Now, It's Just First Aid for U.S. Field Hospital
description: At the field hospital here the nurses are engaged in a nervous waiting game.

title: Baseball;   Stunner in the 14th Defeats the Mets
description: The Mets remembered that Gonzalez's only other home run had been hit against them on May 21 off the rookie Wally Whitehurst. They also remembered that he was a fastball hitter. But after Darling just missed getting strike 3 on a curveball, he fired a fastball on the full count and the supersub of the Dodgers hammered it.

title: Number of Cows Drops to Lowest Since 1930
description: The number of cows on New York State farms dropped last year to 776,000, the lowest level since the state began to record dairy statistics in 1930, the state Agricultural Statistics Service reported this week.

title: Comments of Writer From Japan Disrupt Reunion of Veterans
description: Veterans from the unit that dropped the atomic bombs on two cities in Japan in World War II today dedicated a peace memorial, but they caused a furor when they scratched a Japanese writer off the speaker list for saying the bombings were not necessary.

title: Stephanie Kelly Is Married
description: Stephanie Danielle Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde P. Kelly of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Lucien Newhouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Newhouse of Scarsdale. Donald Sullivan, a retired justice of State Supreme Court, officiated at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Mrs. Kelly-Newhouse, 26, was until recently the purchasing specialist in Thornwood, N.Y., for the United States division of Carl Zeiss Inc. of West Germany. She is a biology student at the State University of New York at Purchase. The bridegroom, 28, is a consultant at the National Pension Service in White Plains. He graduated from Washington and Jefferson College.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

In One Year, a Doubling in Foreclosures
description: LEAD: Foreclosure actions on houses are increasing, and the rising number of properties seized by lenders is creating new opportunities for buyers to acquire a home at a knock-down price.

title: Hers;   Fraud by Friendship
description: You're involved too many ways - better not go,'' warned my husband. His forebodings have a way of coming true, but I was determined to attend the hearing downtown at the criminal court at Foley Square.

title: Come Back, Oscar Wilde! All Is Forgiven!
description: LEAD:

title: The Bard and the Multitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Berlin Seeks Its Cultural Soul
description: ''And what will Berlin be like when it's truly one city?'' someone said to me the other day. ''Will it be the new Paris? Will people flock there from all over? Will they discover their true selves in Berlin and be forever at home there, just as they used to be in Paris?''

title: Janet Laub Wed To David Barcus
description: Janet Lynn Laub, the daughter of Barbara Ann Laub of Plainview, L.I., and the late Mitchell Laub, was married last evening to David Ashley Barcus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert M. Barcus of North Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein officated at Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, L.I. Mrs. Barcus, 24 years old, is a graduate of American University and attended the University of Grenoble in France. Her father was a co-founder of Saxe Mitchell Inc., an advertising agency in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Buildup of U.S. Troops Alarms the Arab World
description: To the Editor:

title: Truth Outs
description: Uncle Miltie is also a father, and not just to the children mentioned in his ''Who's Who'' biography. In an interview with the National Enquirer last week, Milton Berle said he has an illegitimate son, now 51 years old, whom he sometimes sees at social gatherings but who is unaware of their connection. ''My son comes up to me and says, 'Hello, Milton. How are you?' Little does he know he's talking to his father,'' Mr. Berle said. He said that his son's mother is an actress whom he offered to marry when he learned she was carrying his child. She married a Hollywood executive instead, Mr. Berle said, and the boy grew up believing that was his father. ''Only his mother and I knew the truth,'' he said. But at 82 years old, he wants someone else to know. ''I dream of him, and in those dreams I tell him,'' he said. ''In case I die without ever telling him, he's taken care of in my will.''

title: George Vecsey;   Stump Merrill: Yanks' Maine Man
description: THERE were times, Carl Harrison Merrill said, when he slept right over there.

title: Sharon Bowden Wed to Sean Abbott
description: Sharon Scott Bowden, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Bowden of San Antonio was married yesterday to Sean Lawrence Abbott, a son of Prof. and Mrs. John L. Abbott of Mansfield Center, Conn., and New York. The Rev. Vester Vanstrom, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Southwest Craft Center Chapel in San Antonio.

title: India
description: To the Editor: ''The Vegetarian Snacks of South India'' by Sharon Voros (Travel, July 15) should be welcomed by all admirers of Madrasi cooking. But the assertion that dosas and idlis ''are widely available throughout South India - and difficult to find anywhere else'' is thankfully inaccurate. Even on my first trip to India over 25 years ago, the pleasures of dosa, idli, uppama, coffee and South India sweets like badam halwa and Mysore pak were a traveler's mainstay in any large Indian city north or south, east or west.

title: Highway Choice: Roll Together or Crawl Alone
description: LEAD: A YEARLONG experiment with special highway lanes for buses and car pools on Interstate 84 east of Hartford has been pronounced a success, state transportation officials said. Similar lanes will be opened in a couple of years on Interstate 91 north of Hartford, they said, and in the distant future, such lanes could be added to highways through Fairfield County.

title: A Week of Tension in the Gulf
description: Sunday, Aug. 19 - President Saddam Hussein of Iraq says foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait must remain until the United States withdraws from the gulf. Many are transferred to potential targets. American warships decline to use force to stop Iraqi tankers pending United Nations approval of such action.

title: Lyons
description: The Lyonnais are not at all embarrassed to call their hometown France's second city. They view Paris less as a rival than as the other great French city.

title: The Census Is Coming Up Short
description: So much in commerce and politics hinges on the once-a-decade census that experts by the swarm leap to dissect and interpret even the most incomplete and preliminary data. As a result, the Census Bureau has grown a bit testy on the subject of its accuracy.

title: Sarah Humphreys Is Wed
description: Sarah Jane Humphreys, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Humphreys of Joplin, Mo., was married yesterday to Paul Stewart Atkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neill S. Atkins Jr., of Anna Maria, Fla. The Rev. Keith B. Whitmore officiated at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Joplin.

title: England
description: To the Editor: The article ''Memorable Gardens in England's Oxbridge'' by A. L. Rowse (Travel, May 29) described the very attractive botanic garden in Oxford, which goes back to about 1630. The garden was built over what had been a Jewish cemetery, a fact that is commemorated on a plaque at the stone entryway.

title: In the Salt Marshes, Beware
description: Re: ''In the Natural State,'' July 15, about the salt marshes of South Jersey:

title: Deposit Ticket Cashes In Big
description: Deposit Ticket assumed the leadership of the nation's 2-year-olds by scoring a front-running 4 1/2-length victory over Hansel today in the $232,800 Hopeful Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Tourism At Shore: Changing Patterns
description: ALTHOUGH state and local tourism officials say that the crowds have begun returning to the Jersey Shore after three years of being repelled by reports of coastal pollution, business somehow is just not the same, they say. The officials add that Shore tourism may never be what it once was.

title: Students Find Ancient Indian Site in Colorado
description: Two University of Colorado students who were tracking bighorn sheep in southwest Colorado have stumbled upon the virtually untouched ruins of a lost Indian village more than 1,100 years old.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Northampton, Mass.;

City Preserving Its S.R.O.'s
description: LEAD: This western Massachusetts city is using Federal grants to help provide 29 one-room rentals for single people earning less than $20,640a year, or 80 percent of the area's median income.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Fresh Tuna Grilled On Stove
description: If you are fortunate enough to be able to grill a piece of tuna over charcoal, you know that it requires no seasonings at all for spectacular flavor.

title:
WINE;

Touring the Wineries of the Hudson Valley
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH not ready to rival the Napa Valley or even the Finger Lakes Region in sophistication, nearby Hudson Valley wineries give visitors an insight into grape-growing practices and the vinification process. And sampling the currently available vintage often uncovers a number of well-made, reasonably priced bottles.

title: Volcanoes
description: To the Editor: In Q & A (Travel, June 17) a reader asked about the danger of visiting Kilauea volcano on the island of Hawaii during an eruption. The geologist Christina Heliko of the Hawaiian volcano observatory stated that ''there is nothing to be worried about.''

title: Some Questions About Demolition
description: While some peole are donating their time, money, labor and expertise to putting a dent in the much-talked-about homelessness and affordable-housing problems, others are planning and paying for the demolition of perfectly sound existing homes so they can put up more new commercial space. This seems a bit questionable at a time when there already is a sizable vacancy rate for existing commercial space, not only downtown but also uptown and in the malls.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Why Are Baseball Brawls So Common?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: MILITARY ROOTS
description: A FADED FAMILY photograph from 1944 shows my 6-foot-5 cousin Mel, on Army leave, stooping to hold me, a shy little girl, in my backyard. We are both in uniform: his a handsome olive drab with brass buttons; mine a spiffy ''junior'' WAC uniform in khaki twill with gold bars and braid. The skirt had already been lengthened twice. Inspired by his courtly visits and my scrapbook filled with snappy WAC recruiting posters, I began, then, my love affair with uniforms and their glamorous sense of mission.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Pakistan Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed today from 26th to 47th Streets from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. For a related street fair, Madison Avenue will be closed from 23d to 26th Streets from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M.

title: When a Talent Remains Hidden
description: EVERY family has its share of characters ranging from the stoics to the Pollyannas, the troubled to the troublesome, the heroes to the villains. In my family, I was cast in the role of comedienne.

title: Coming To America...And Staying
description: I ARRIVED in the United States on Sept. 5, 1965. I had come as a foreign student in a Ph.D. program at a major American university and intended to return to India, my native land, after obtaining a doctorate. I stayed on to enjoy the freedom, an organized way of life and the creature comforts that were not available to me in my old country. But adapting to America has been a slow and difficult process for me.

title: All About/Coal;   Will Coal, the Plentiful Old Standby, Pick Up Speed?
description: All it takes to give coal more luster is a crisis in the Middle East. With the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait cutting off about a fifth of the world's oil supplies, coal demand can only increase. But even before the recent jump in oil prices, the United States coal industry was growing enough in both size and efficiency to make healthy profits. And coal reserves are vast: if the nation derived all of its energy from one domestic source, crude oil would last eight years, coal 100 years. The United States now imports as much oil as it produces, but exports about 10 percent of its coal.

title: U.N. CALLS ON NAVIES TO BLOCK IRAQ'S TRADE; RESOLUTION PERMITS USE OF FORCE, U.S. SAYS
description: The Security Council overwhelmingly adopted a resolution early today giving the United States and other nations the right to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq by halting shipping to and from that country.

title: Miss Martin Wed To David Brown
description: Cynthia Morris Martin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Newkirk Martin of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to David Noah Brown, the son of Carol Z. Brown of Boston, and Murton L. Brown of New York. The Rev. George Anastos, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Old Meeting House in Granville, Mass.

title: Marc Neuhof, Photographer, 75
description: Marc Neuhof, an architectural photographer whose work appeared in publications in the United States and abroad, died on Thursday at White Plains Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y. His family said his death followed a stroke.

title: Lisa Radley Weds Roger Mullarkey
description: Lisa Louise Radley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Radley of Pueblo, Colo., was married yesterday to Roger Tighe Mullarkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. X. Mullarkey of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Richard Hendry, a Methodist minister, was assisted by the Rev. Eugene O'Brien, the executive vice president of Fordham University and a Roman Catholic priest, in performing the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Pueblo.

title: Wall Street;   Shareholders Get a Say on Salary
description: How much is good corporate management worth? A great deal, no doubt, when markets are in upheaval and economic prospects grow cloudier every day; even in sunny times, nobody expects corporate executives to toil for free.

title: Ethyl Eichelberger and His Interior Spotlight
description: With equal zest, Ethyl Eichelberger played men and women. Sometimes portraying a dozen characters in a single show, he leaped from fright-wigged mad doctors to pompadourable courtesans. In ''The Tempest of Chim-Lee,'' he represented an entire gallery of Oriental characters (with no protest from Actors' Equity). There was something about his female roles - his towering height, the absurd wigs atop his bald head, his toes teetering on point - that made these impersonations unique, especially when he did cartwheels and splits in full drag.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption on Aug. 5 about Guadeloupe misidentified the lead singer of the Caribbean group Kassav'. He is Jacob Desvarieux, not Pascal Vallot.

title: Players to Watch
description: Eric Bieniemy, TB, Colorado, Sr., 5-7, 195

title: Myanmar Is Different From Other Lands
description: LEAD: As Rudyard Kipling looked out from the deck of his ship to the distant shore, a fellow passenger said to him, ''And this is Burma, and it will be quite unlike any land that you know about. . . .'' Even the elections are different. All over the world, from South Korea to Argentina to, most recently, Nicaragua, ''free and fair elections'' have been an important part of the transition from dictatorship to democracy.

title: Michigan Charging Murder After a 2d Assisted Suicide
description: Saying he is determined to keep Michigan from becoming a haven for assisted suicides, the county prosecutor here has brought murder charges against a California man who the prosecutor says helped his wife take her own life at a suburban motel last Sunday.

title: A Correction: Oil Earnings
description: Because of a mechanical error, a chart last Sunday about the effect of crude oil prices on company earnings omitted the names of several oil producers. Here is the complete list of estimated additional earnings per share for each $1 increase in the price of a barrel of oil. Atlantic Richfield $0.83 British Petroleum 0.54 Texaco 0.52 Amerada Hess 0.45 Chevron 0.40 Royal Dutch/Shell 0.39 Mobil 0.27 Exxon 0.22 Uniocal 0.22 Amoco 0.21 Phillips Petroleum 0.20 Kerr McGee 0.18 Penzoil 0.18

title: Merrilec Forgy Is Married
description: Merrilec Forgy, a daughter of Molly M. Forgy of Santa Ana, Calif., and Fred W. Forgy Jr. of Tustin, Calif., was married yesterday to William H. Harris Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Boston. The Rev. Ian Douglas, the bridegroom's brother-in-law, officiated at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Laguna Beach, Calif. Mrs. Harris graduated from the University of Southern California and is an account manager for Architectural Digest in New York. Her husband, a Middlebury College graduate who received an M.B.A. from Harvard University, is the executive vice president of U.S. News and World Report in Washington and New York.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

At Ease With Being at Odds
description: LEAD:

title: Technology;   As Oil Prices Rise, the Hydrogen Car Is Looking Better
description: On the surface, the hydrogen-powered car looks as if it were made by a malevolent Rube Goldberg.

title: Wine;   OPEN COUNTRY
description: Country wine. what a beautiful concept. Like a Norman Rockwell painting. Innocence, naivete, freshness; what old-time virtues does it not evoke?

title: Popular Durham Bulls Are Seeking a New Home
description: THE Durham Bulls, undaunted by cinematic fame and unprecedented attendance levels, are continuing their efforts to lead the renaissance of minor league baseball in the United States.

title: Saudis Provide Wherewithal For a Growing U.S. Force
description: A top United States military official said today that the Saudi Arabian Government is providing the bulk of the fuel, transportation, food and installations for the thousands of American soldiers sent here.

title: Higher Long-Term Rates Predicted
description: The week before Labor Day is normally one of Wall Street's slowest periods. But with the Persian Gulf crisis becoming increasingly volatile, the atmosphere in the financial markets will hardly be holiday-like in the coming days.

title: U.N. Leader to Meet With Iraqi Minister
description: The United Nations Secretary General, who said this weekend that he would personally intervene in the Persian Gulf crisis, is to meet with the Iraqi Foreign Minister on Thursday in Amman, the Jordanian capital, a spokeswoman said today.

title: Outdoors: Tautog A Northeast Treat
description: IF you live in the Northeast and have a yen to try saltwater spearfishing, the chunky tautog is your logical quarry. It is fairly abundant, is a relatively slow swimmer that is not overly chary of intruders, and is an excellent chowder fish.

title: Refugees' Picture of Kuwait: A Plundered, Fearful Nation
description: Refugees pouring into Jordan from Kuwait talked today of rising fears of chemical warfare and occasional skirmishing between Iraqi troops and Kuwaiti guerrilla groups.

title: INSIDE
description: Nudging a Bureaucracy

title: Working Out for 2 in Comfort
description: The tendency for women to continue working out while they are pregnant has prompted Avia, the athletic footwear company, to design a special line of fitness clothing for mothers-to-be.

title: Jennifer Hisrich, Librarian, Weds
description: Jennifer Dell Hisrich, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Glenn D. Hisrich of Washington, Pa., was married yesterday to Jason Drew Zions, a son of Leona Rund Zions of New York and Herbert G. Zions of Island Park, L.I. Rabbi Albert Goldman performed the ceremony at Chestnut Farm, the home of the bride's parents.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Kellogg Files Lawsuit To Protect Ad Claims
description: The Kellogg Company has filed suit in Federal District Court in Iowa to protect the company's right to make what it says are truthful claims in advertising for its Frosted Flakes, Special K and Bran Flakes cereals.

title: R. Caird Watson, 61, Radiology Researcher
description: Dr. R. Caird Watson, a radiologist and chairman of the medical-imaging department at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, died there on Thursday. He was 61 years old.

title: Osel Tendzin, 47, First Westerner to Lead Tibetan Buddhist Sect
description: Osel Tendzin, the first Westerner to lead an international Tibetan Buddhist sect, died Saturday, members of the religious group said today. He was 47 years old.

title: Miriam Berken and R. E. Vidal Wed
description: Miriam L. Berken, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Berken of Huntington, L.I., and Roberto E. Vidal, the son of Gloria A. Vidal of Ventnor, N.J., were married yesterday on the yacht Princess in the Hudson River. Rabbi Barton A. Shallat officiated.

title: United Airlines' Rates
description: United Airlines will increase its air freight rates 5.3 percent on all domestic flights effective Oct. 1 to cover rising jet fuel costs, the airline announced Friday. United will also impose a 5.3 percent fuel surcharge on passenger flights, beginning at the end of August.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Analysis & Technology Inc., North Stonington, Conn., an engineering service, named John P. Cretella a senior vice president.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Masses, Fashion and J. C. Penney
description: THE name is J. C. Penney, but the advertising portrays a style-conscious retailer that is sort of a Saks Fifth Avenue for the masses.

title: Welfare Chief Battles Crises and Critics
description: The job is daunting and she knows it. Barbara J. Sabol, New York City's new Human Resources Administrator, is struggling -some say without success - to nudge a mammoth bureaucracy not known for compassion into being more responsive to the city's most vulnerable citizens.

title: In Reversal, Alabama Club Allows a Japanese Member
description: The all-white Selma Country Club has reversed itself and extended membership to a Japanese businessman barred last month amid lingering ill feelings about World War II.

title: The Media Business;   As S.& L.'s Sink, a Trade Weekly is Soaring
description: Not too long ago, The National Mortgage News could not give away its reports about the savings and loan crisis.

title: International Report;   Brazil Data Show Recession
