description: President Fernando Collor de Mello's anti-inflation plan, begun on March 16, has produced Brazil's worst recession in 10 years, data from the Government Statistics Institute show.

title: Lillian Lampkin, 75, Retired Social Worker
description: Lillian C. Lampkin, a retired social worker and professor of social work, died on Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. She was 75 years old.

title: Lyons To Miss 12 to 16 Weeks
description: In their 17-7 exhibition loss to the Giants on Saturday night, the Jets lost their most experienced player on defense when Marty Lyons suffered a torn right bicep muscle.

title: Key Talks On Output For OPEC
description: As members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gathered informally here today to confront some of the most crucial issues in the group's 30-year history, some predicted that a formal meeting would be announced on Monday to address questions of oil production and prices.

title: Exciting Positions Available At Connecticut Enterprise
description: STARTING a varsity football program can be difficult, especially at a small commuter school like Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., which doesn't even have a football field.

title: U.S. Says Iraqis Briefly Entered Chinese Embassy in Kuwait
description: Iraqi authorities reportedly entered the Chinese Embassy in Kuwait and tightened their grip on other foreign embassies there today by shutting off their water supply, Administration officials said.

title: Metro Matters;   After the Conflict At Rikers Island, A War of Words
description: In his eighth month on the job, Mayor David N. Dinkins finally seems to have met a man he doesn't like.

title: Francine Kravetz Marries
description: Francine Amy Kravetz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Kravetz of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Pepe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene N. Pepe of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. Mrs. Pepe, 25 years old and a graduate of Boston University, is a registered sales assistant at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Consumer Markets in White Plains. Her father is the director of the ''MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour.'' Mr. Pepe, 30, is a graduate of Iona College. He is the treasurer of the Pepe Motors Corporation in White Plains. His father is the company's president.

title: Jesse Fried Wed To Naomi Super
description: Naomi Anne Super, a doctoral candidate in materials science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Jesse Mackenzie Fried, a Harvard University law student, were married yesterday at Congregation Shaarei Tefilla in Las Vegas, Nev. Rabbi Abner Weiss officiated.

title: Take a Hike, on Cross-Country Trails
description: A SCOUTING party has taken to the woods and backroads to mark a trail that will offer, if you are fit and eager, the opportunity to take an eight-month nature walk across the United States. But the purpose for staking out the new path has to do as much with image as reality.

title: A Market Slumps and Real-Estate Lawyers Scramble
description: When houses and apartments were selling in days or weeks during the mid-1980's, real-estate closings were the bread and butter of many law practices in the New York metropolitan region. Some lawyers conducted hundreds of closings a year, collecting from $750 to $1,000 for each one.

title: Tough Casino-Control Rules Kept Out Mob but Not Debt
description: When the Casino Control Commission gave grudging approval this week to a bank loan package for Donald J. Trump's tottering casino empire, it tacitly acknowledged that its extraordinary regulatory powers had failed to shield New Jersey's casinos from the high-rolling borrowing practices of the 1980's.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   People
description: * Robin Davenport has been appointed senior vice president of Sudler & Hennessey, a New York agency.

title: The Media Business: Ad Scene;   Sponsors' New Message: Buy It, but Have Patience
description: ADVERTISING, with its brassy promise of immediate, when-it-absolutely-positively-has-to-be-there-overnight results, has begun to croon a softer, sweeter tune: Buy now, be satisfied later.

title: Will America Stand A Stalemate in Iraq?
description: As the U.S. moves closer to military confrontation in the Middle East, people are beginning to wonder how long the American public will support the enterprise. Historical experience suggests a few answers.

title: Market Place;   Reviewing Deals After the Invasion
description: THE best of Wall Street's merger experts in the 1980's specialized in determining how much debt their target companies could take on in a leveraged buyout. To do so, they made assumptions about the future, including the direction of interest rates, economic growth, inflation, even oil prices. But none of them figured on Saddam Hussein. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has sent Wall Street and corporate America back to the calculators, and a number of the assumptions that determined the prices of takeover deals have been discarded. Since the invasion, oil prices have soared more than 70 percent, increasing inflationary pressure. And the economy, already slowing, appears to many economists to have been pushed to the edge of recession.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Airlines Plan Gulf Risk Fee
description: The leading international airlines are planning fare increases for the Persian Gulf region to absorb war-risk charges, airline and travel industry officials say.

title: Belinda Ward, Writer, Wed
description: Belinda Ward, a writer for the television program ''Sesame Street,'' was married yesterday to Frank Kirby, the vice president of finance for the E & B Giftware Corporation in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel and the Rev. James Gardner, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Stamford, Conn., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Russell Ward. The bride, 34 years old, will keep her name. She graduated from Cornell University and received a master's degree in fiction writing from New York University. Mr. Kirby, 36, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kirby of Sag Harbor, L.I. He graduated from the State University of New York at Purchase and received an M.B.A. from Baruch College.

title: Flags Fly Over South For Troops
description: As the news swept through this area last week that military convoys were moving along the Interstates carrying soldiers bound for the Middle East, clutches of people waving flags seemed to appear magically along the highway overpasses to salute them.

title: Mauritius' Political Quarrel Saves the Queen
description: The Mauritians, a mixture of Indians, creoles, and Chinese who inhabit this small Indian Ocean island, want to be rid of the Queen of England. That at least is how the political argument in one of Africa's few working democracies looked on the surface.

title: Weicker Honeymoon Over as Governor's Race Heats Up
description: Former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an independent running for governor, has enjoyed nothing less than a political honeymoon for the last six months. He has held wide leads in all public opinion polls. His campaign has been gentlemanly and issue-oriented. He also has been successful at raising funds, frequently attracting the news media and collecting endorsements from Democrats and Republicans.

title: Ilene Chugerman Is Wed
description: Ilene Paula Chugerman, a daughter of Evelyn Chugerman of Brooklyn was married yesterday to Steven Jay Amiel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Amiel of New York. Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach performed the ceremony at the James House in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Mrs. Amiel, 29 years old, graduated from Boston University and is an account supervisor at DCA Advertising in New York. The bridegroom, 35, a graduate of New York University, is the president of National Hanover Press Ltd., a New York printing company owned by his father. The bridegroom's first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills and Notes
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to bill and note auctions, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. Tomorrow there will be an auction of new two-year notes and on Wednesday an auction of new five-year notes.

title: Not a Fun Sunday For Giant Linemen
description: On this hot, sticky Sunday, most of the Giants, like most civilized people, had the day off. But not the Giants' offensive line.

title: For Ill Children, a Chance at Camping
description: Oxygen tanks, respirators and intravenous tubes share cabin space with sleeping bags and backpacks at a camp for children whose medical needs make them dependent on technology.

title: Political Influence Corrodes the Civil Service;   Foxes in Chicken Coop
description: To the Editor:

title: Czech Brings Enthusiasm To Fed Event
description: The star of the proceedings at the Federal Reserve's annual summer retreat, dedicated this year to a discussion of central banking in Eastern Europe, turned out to be the Finance Minister of Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Klaus.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My parents say, 'Amy's going to be a teacher and that's nice.'

title: Chrysler's Japan Ties Stir a Fuss
description: With a flourish of patriotism, the Chrysler Corporation's latest advertising campaign, ''Advantage: Chrysler,'' takes aim at the company's Japanese competitors, but the company is being accused of hypocrisy.

title: A Nose Decides Forego
description: It is only fitting that the tightest and most competitive race of the Saratoga meeting will probably turn out to be the one that decides the riding title.

title: Tennessee Rallies to 31-31 Tie
description: LEAD: The game had all the trappings of a major college football bowl game.

title: U.N'S DIPLOMACY WELCOMED;   A Little Oil Means a Lot
description: The price of crude oil jumped more than 70 percent since the beginning of July, the financial markets have plunged, and the economic future of the industrial world has been thrown into question, all because of an interruption in supplies that may turn out to be quite modest. A host who bought two cases of beer for a party and broke one bottle would face about the same degree of shortage.

title: Max Gordon, an Architect, 59; Known for His Exhibition Spaces
description: Max Gordon, an architect internationally known for his mastery of exhibition spaces, both public and private, died on Friday in London, where he lived. He was 59 years old.

title: A Festival Embraces The Pacific Cultures
description: Back in 1988, when the innovative opera and theater director Peter Sellars became director of the 1990 Los Angeles Festival, no one would have been shocked to hear that the festival would include Mr. Sellars directing the West Coast premiere of John Adams's opera ''Nixon in China.'' Few would also have been particularly amazed to find that the festival, which is to take place Sept. 1 through 16, would feature a reunion of Ornette Coleman's original jazz quartet or, in theater, the Wooster Group of New York performing ''Frank Dell's 'The Temptation of St. Antony.' ''

title: Books of The Times;   High Price of Putting a Song in the Heart
description: Hit Men

title: The Media Business;   For Authors, the Key Words Are in the Book Contracts
description: Publishing used to be about trust. But today, the old relationships between authors and publishers have given way to growing differences over the contracts that define the business ties between them.

title: Already Weak, New York Area Is Spending Less
description: Confronted with a fragile economy and haunted perhaps by the slide of the 1970's, consumers in the New York region are cutting spending and delaying purchases in a display of frugality that seems likely to make the slump worse.

title: Bulgarian Socialist Offices Are Stormed by Protesters
description: Several hundred rioters tonight stormed the headquarters of Bulgaria's Socialist Party, the country's former Communist Party, to protest the continued presence of Communist symbols in public places throughout the country.

title: At Gulag Cemetery, a Struggle Against Forgetting
description: These morn-ings, as the all-night twilight of an Arctic summer brightens into real day, Stanislavas Grintsyavicius can be found tending anonymous graves in a gnat-infested field near the Yurshor Coal Mine.

title: Republican Fund Raising Is Attacked in Federal Suit
description: The Federal Election Commission has sued a Republican Party fund-raising organization, charging that in 1986 the group illegally gave Republican senatorial candidates more than $2 million raised through solicitation letters signed by Vice President George Bush.

title: SANCTIONS STARTING TO PINCH IRAQ ECONOMY, U.S. AIDES SAY; U.N.'S DIPLOMACY WELCOMED
description: Amid tentative new stirrings of diplomatic activity in the Middle East crisis, American officials said today that economic sanctions against Iraq, while already starting to have some effect, will probably not have a decisive impact for months.

title: Carol H. Amsterdam Wed To Arthur D. Fornari
description: Carol Helena Amsterdam, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Amsterdam of Alexandria Bay, N.Y., was married yesterday to Arthur David Fornari, a son of Dr. Ermanno D. Fornari of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Alice N. Fornari. Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein and Cantor A. Lopez Cardozo officiated at Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, in New York.

title: Catch-22 For Menem
description: Carlos Menem, the Peronist who as President has startled Argentines with frugal government and plans for an open-market economy, has encountered a sort of Catch-22 in his attack on inflation.

title: Edberg Comfortable at the Top
description: STEFAN EDBERG, the world's new No. 1 tennis player and for the longest time the most prolific shrinking violet on the men's tour, swiveled and swayed on the first tee of the Fresh Meadows Country Club last week as he got set to play host to a celebrity golf tournament.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SIR PETER HALL is not looking back, his untimely resignation on Aug. 7 as artistic director of the Glyndebourne Festival Opera notwithstanding. He will direct ''The Homecoming'' in London in October to celebrate the 60th birthday of his pal, HAROLD PINTER. Sir Peter first directed the play 25 years ago, which won a Tony award on Broadway. He'll be 60 himself on Nov. 22. He is also writing a movie on Enrico Caruso with NICKI FREI, whom he plans to marry. A date has not been set, because Mr. Hall is not yet divorced from MARIA EWING, his third wife.

title: Mario de Andrade, 62, a Founder of Angola's Governing Movement
description: Mario Pinto de Andrade, the father of Angolan nationalism and first president of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, which has governed Angola since independence in 1975, died in London today. He was 62 years old.

title: Utah Is Divided Over Prayer at Graduations
description: An impending legal battle over prayers at public school graduations has divided Utah residents on religious lines perhaps more sharply than any other issue since efforts to permit liquor served by the drink failed in 1968.

title: U.S. Put Germans In Detention Camps
description: To the Editor:

title: What Makes Some Crimes More Unacceptable Than Others?;   Anti-Gay Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: A Decisive Victory For Edberg in Hamlet
description: Stefan Edberg, his volleys precise and his attention unwavering despite the shimmer of heat that wrapped the stadium court in a cloudy blanket, defeated Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia, 7-6, 6-3, in the final of the Norstar Hamlet Challenge Cup this afternoon.

title: Proudly Sinking, Hudson's One-Day Fleet
description: A small red-and-green Viking boat, a kayak in the shape of a beer bottle and a lobster boat that looked a lot like a small brown bathtub were part of an unseaworthy armada that sloshed about on the Hudson River yesterday afternoon during New York City's strangest annual regatta.

title: OPEC Braces for a Showdown
description: Some oil producing nations expect the deeply split group to call a formal meeting. A majority believes some members will raise output. Page D1.

title: M-1 Tanks Arrive
description: In a sign of increasing American military punch in Saudi Arabia, the first of more than 200 M-1 Abrams tanks are expected to arrive by fast transport ship in northeastern Saudi Arabia on Monday.

title: In New-Day Romania, The Deprivation Lingers
description: A man was dancing on the steps of the House of Culture here at noon today, waving his arms as he circled his bottle of plum brandy and mumbling the words of a song.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Theater in Britain Is No Longer a Bargain
description: Even when the plays have been less than perfect here, the price of a ticket has always been exactly right for American visitors. Not this year.

title: Attacks by Sikhs Reported
description: Sikh gunmen raided the home of a police interrogator in Punjab on Saturday and killed four members of his family, the police said today. Elsewhere in the state, eight deaths on Saturday were attributed to Sikh militants who are leading a violent campaign for an independent homeland, news reports said. The Sikhs say they are discriminated against by India's Hindu majority.

title: Laura M. Stein Is Married
description: Laura Michele Stein, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allan Stein of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Robert Winkler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul B. Winkler of Philadelphia. Rabbi Daniel Fogel officiated at the ceremony in the South Huntington Jewish Center in Melville, L.I.

title: Melanie Cohen, a Lawyer, Is Married
description: Melanie Cohen and Lawrence Greenberg, 1986 magna cum laude graduates of Harvard University, were married yesterday at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony.

title: Abortion Pill Might Well Fix Roe v. Wade;   A Necessary Option
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Accounts
description: * BellSouth Mobility, a unit of BellSouth Corp., Atlanta, a cellular phone service, to Tucker Wayne/Luckie & Co., Atlanta, with billings of $7.5 million. The company will continue to use Hutcheson Shutze, Atlanta, through 1990 for media placement.

title: Ford Plant Stays Closed
description: The Ford Motor Company said Friday that an engine parts shortage would force it to extend a two-week shutdown of its Dearborn assembly plant for another two weeks, until Sept. 10. Initially, the factory, which makes Mustang automobiles, was closed because of a shortage of dealer orders. The shutdown this week was attributed to the parts shortage. The plant employs about 2,100 hourly workers.

title: Liberia Peacekeepers Ask Rebel to Quit Port
description: West African peacekeeping forces called today on the rebel group led by Prince Johnson to pull out from the port area of Monrovia, the Liberian capital.

title: A Grand (Slam?) Team in the Doubles
description: LEAD: A PERFECT season in doubles for Jana Novotna and Helena Sukova almost came to an end at the French Open in early June. The two Czechoslovaks were down at match point against Regina Rajchrtova and Andrea Temesvari in the quarterfinals.

title: International Report;   Huge Withdrawals Hurt Gulf Banks
description: A huge withdrawal of deposits and the cutting of vital Western and Japanese credit lines have dealt severe blows to the banking systems and economies of the Persian Gulf region.

title: Gulf Crisis Has Brazil in a Tailspin
description: Shock waves from the crisis in the Persian Gulf are rippling through Brazil's economy, swelling the bill on oil imports, threatening an anti-inflation program, deepening a recession and freezing a close trade relationship with Iraq.

title: North Dakota Town Enlists Bats In War on Mosquitoes
description: This summer, residents of this town at the confluence of the Missouri and Yellowstone rivers may have finally hit on a way to combat its oldest problem, mosquitoes, by using natural forms of control: bats and birds.

title: NBC Previews 5 of Its New Shows
description: The television season doesn't start until Sept. 17, but last week was a kind of phony war anticipating the competition to come.

title: A Robbery Suspect Is Shot in Times Square
description: An armed-robbery suspect was shot and critically wounded and three other supects arrested by police officers in a Times Square grocery last night, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As the closing tribute to Charles Mingus on the 10th anniversary of his death, several pop musicians have recorded his works. ELVIS COSTELLO sings the lead song, ''Weird Nightmare,'' on the album of the same name to be released at the end of the year on A & M Records. Other performers include SONNY ROLLINS, KEITH RICHARDS and CHARLIE WATTS.

title: Political Influence Corrodes the Civil Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday headed Washington at Work, about Representative Joe Moakley, referred incorrectly in some copies to the late Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador. The Archbishop was not a leader of the Arena Party; the party was organized after he was assassinated in 1980 by a gunman who was later linked to a current party leader.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Cox Landley Awarded Acura Dealers Account
description: Cox Landey & Partners has won the $8 million to $10 million account for the Tri-State Acura Dealers. The campaign created by the New York agency will begin in October.

title: Jordanian King Begins Effort in North Africa
description: King Hussein left today for a tour of North Africa, and diplomats said he would also travel to Britain and West Germany in an effort to defuse the crisis in the Persian Gulf.

title: Military Drops Gulf Press Pool
description: The Pentagon disbanded its Persian Gulf news media pool today, saying it was no longer needed because open coverage was now being permitted.

title: Tokyo Stocks Set a Record
description: Share prices in Tokyo today rose to its ninth-largest one-day gain on techincal factors and investor relief after a weekend without news of military conflict in the Middle East.

title: Business Digest
description: The Oil Jolt

title: Sax and Barfield Show Youth Can't Do It All
description: The second-half surge of the Yankees has been one built for the most part on the youthful strength of players like Kevin Maas, Oscar Azocar and Jim Leyritz.

title: Vienna Journal;   Forging a New Gypsy Spirit: Will Sanskrit Help?
description: The group of gypsies had gathered for an evening of poetry and song, and their language and music bounced out over the audience, round and strong, full of dark tones and hissing sounds.

title: Mets Lose Game And Chance to Gain
description: Ten days after they flew West only half a game out of first place, the Mets flew home tonight three games out. It was, they admitted, a lost trip: they lost three of four games in Los Angeles. They lost 6 of 10 in California. They lost their bats and their smarts and even their confidence.

title: Business Scene;   Mexico's Vibrant Untaxed Sector
description: EIGHT blocks from Mexico City's ancient central plaza and historic cathedral is a major shopping district. The streets are as packed with shoppers as Fifth Avenue in New York before Christmas. The shops are mostly makeshift sidewalk stalls, but they display a huge variety of clothing, shoes, household wares, toys and electronic products. Buyers come from all walks of life, and rare is the upper-middle-class home that does not have a videocassette recorder, a refrigerator or a stereo system purchased from vendors like those here, who are prominent participants in Mexico's ''informal economy.''

title: The Media Business;   Magazines Follow Readers to the Beach
description: Summer is ending soon, but the lure of the beach remains strong -especially for magazine readers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - Addenda;   Miscellany
description: * Young & Rubicam bought a minority share of Javelin, a Dublin advertising agency, which will be renamed Javelin/Young & Rubicam. The agency's billings are about $3 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When ROSE BOYT wrote her first novel, published in London last year to considerable praise, interviewers were fascinated by her background. When the 31-year-old great-granddaughter of Sigmund Freud writes about Oedipal love and calls the book ''Sexual Intercourse,'' all sorts of skeletons might tumble from the closet. Plus, she's the illegitimate daughter of LUCIEN FREUD, one of Britain's preeminent painters.

title: Return of the Doves
description: Longtime doves of the left, joined by anti-Israelites of the far right - plus sober second thinkers who want to give pacifism a chance -have combined forces to try to stop the worldwide momentum aimed at driving Saddam Hussein from power.

title: Red Sox Capture 3d Straight Shutout
description: The Boston Red Sox swept to a third straight shutout for the first time in 28 years and increased their largest lead of the season in the American League East to four games today, beating Toronto, 1-0, on a combined two-hitter by Greg Harris and Jeff Gray.

title: In the Drive to Revive Schools, Better Teachers but Too Few
description: In the struggle to revive America's schools, the news is bittersweet. Despite growing evidence that more and better qualified people are choosing teaching, educators say there are nowhere near enough of them.

title: Calmen Fleisig Dead; Viola Player Was 81
description: Calmen Fleisig, a viola player who led fellow musicians in a bitter labor dispute with the New York Philharmonic in the 1940's, died Friday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 81 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens. He died of a cerebral hemorrhage, his son Paul said. Mr. Fleisig was a member of the Philharmonic from 1938 to 1943 and was its union chairman when the Philharmonic's board announced that it would not renew the contracts of 14 musicians, including Mr. Fleisig. He filed charges against the orchestra's incoming conductor, Artur Rodzinski, and threatened to delay contract negotiations and postpone the 1944 season. The charges were dropped after the American Federation of Musicians upheld the Philharmonic's decision.

title: DEALS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Lauren Ruth Weinstock Is Married
description: Lauren Ruth Weinstock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Weinstock of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to David Edward Freedman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Freedman of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbis Michael Katz and Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck.

title: Randi Justus Wed To Howard Simon
description: Randi Michele Justus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Justus of East Northport, L.I., was married yesterday to Howard Keith Simon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Simon of Jericho, L.I. Cantor Marvin Antosofsky performed the ceremony at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Passenger Shoots at Driver Of a Livery Cab in the Bronx
description: A 43-year-old livery-cab driver was injured early yesterday during an apparent robbery attempt when a passenger shot at him through the cab's plastic security divider, the police said.

title: With Embargo, U.S. Farmers Lose One of Their Best Clients
description: The Middle East crisis is confronting farmers, the United States Treasury and taxpayers with costs that go far beyond the rising price of oil.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: From Lithuania to Seton Hall
description: Less than two years ago, Arturas Karnishovas did not speak English. He had never heard of Seton Hall University. And he lived in Vilnius, Lithuania, which is a long way from New Jersey both geographically and culturally.

title: The Board of Estimate's Upbeat End
description: New York City's Board of Estimate, due to die on Sept. 1 under the new City Charter, in its protracted final session last week reached acceptable compromises on four disputed matters. A last issue remains for today.

title: Molly M. Fowler Is Married
description: Molly Macklin Fowler, an associate producer for ''The Phil Donohue Show,'' and Jack Levine, a photographer and film maker, were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Rosen, the bridegroom's sister and brother-in-law, in Patterson, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated. The bride, 33 years old and a graduate of the University of Utah, is keeping her name. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. Thomas Fowler Jr. of King, N.C. The bridegroom, 48, is the son of Mrs. Herman Levine of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Levine. He graduated from Amherst College and received a law degree at Columbia University.

title: To Cut the S.& L. Losses . . .
description: Washington budget summit negotiators have been engaged in a political tug of war over which taxes to raise to pay for the savings and loan bailout. What they should be addressing is the more important question of how to keep the tab from rising. Policy-makers have ignored one of the most effective steps we can take to stem further S.& L. losses: A cut in the capital gains tax.

title: Machine Tool Orders Fell 11.9% Last Month
description: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped by 11.9 percent in July, according to a monthly report by the Association for Manufacturing Technology. Economists said the figures showed that the nation's economy had begun slowing before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

title: Political Influence Corrodes the Civil Service;   Mired in Bureaucracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Crippled Yacht Found With Its Crew Safe
description: The Coast Guard found a yacht that had been crippled in rough seas southwest of Guam and sent a patrol boat today to tow the boat and its crew to safety, officials said.

title: Sri Lankan Troops Report Seizing Island From Rebels
description: The Sri Lankan Army said today that it had captured the strategic island closest to the 300-year-old Jaffna Fort, killing dozens of Tamil guerrillas now engaged in a bitter battle for the heart of their traditional homeland.

title: 9-0 Rout Returns Title to Taiwan
description: Taiwan returned to business as usual today, topping Shippensburg (Pa.), 9-0, to earn the 14th championship since Taiwan teams began playing in the Little League World Series in 1969.

title: The Game on the Beach
description: THE sportswriter sat on the beach recently under the shade of his red-and-white umbrella and was reading a book when he suddenly heard shouts. He looked up and, as if in a bad dream, saw a football game breaking out a short distance away.

title: Distant but Happy Second
description: TO those who follow professional bowling, Earl Anthony is a household name - the name, of course, of bowling's first $1 million man, the winner of 41 tournaments in a 14-year-career that ended, for the first time, in 1983.

title: Church Poses No Threat To Park, Lujan Asserts
description: For nearly a decade, followers of Elizabeth Clare Prophet have come to the spectacular Upper Yellowstone Valley, drawn by the woman they call Guru Ma. Hundreds of members of her Church Universal and Triumphant settled here, near huge bomb shelters they have cut into the mountainside and stocked with radiation suits, food and automatic weapons.

title: Slovak Rally Demands An Independent State
description: Tens of thousands of Slovaks demanding an independent state demonstrated today at a rally that was part of a separatist upsurge since the end of Communist rule in Czechoslovakia.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MEL TORME has finished ''Traps, the Drum Wonder,'' his biography of Buddy Rich. The singer started it in 1975, put it aside for his own autobiography and completed the manuscript last month. It has been submitted to publishers by STERLING LORD, who says that one will be chosen by mid-September.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about the Crossland Savings Bank of Brooklyn misidentified the operator of the deposit insurance fund for credit unions. It is the National Credit Union Administration, not the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title:
Business People;

Deal in Alaska Is First At Buyout Expert's Firm
description: LEAD: Leonard I. Green has 20 years of experience executing leveraged buyouts, and he knows the supermarket business. So it was logical for his new investment firm to strike as its first deal the acquisition of a food industry company. On Aug. 16, Leonard Green & Partners announced in Los Angeles that it had agreed to buy Carr-Gottstein Inc.,

title: Dale C. Reyer Married to Jonathan Mondschein
description: Dale Caryn Reyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Reyer of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Jonathan Mondschein, a son of the late Saul Mondschein and the late Gloria Mondschein Warshaw and the adoptive son of Milton Warshaw of New York. Rabbi Robert S. Widom and Cantor Henry Weintraub officiated at the DeSeversky Conference Center in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Researchers Study Giant Sequoias To Determine Effects of Pollution
description: Looking a little like a high-rise construction project, three tall trees stand surrounded by scaffolding here in an experiment to gauge damage to them from the pollutant ozone.

title: Israel Says It Will Block Exports Bound for Iraq at Jordan's Border
description: The Israeli military announced its first tangible involvement in the gulf crisis today by saying it will begin blocking exports of Palestinian-produced fruits, vegetables and other items shipped through Jordan to Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about the performance of the stock market misstated the ranking of the New York Stock Exchange volume on Thursday.

title: Parades, Contests and Races in Honor of the Crab
description: AN event that may provide some excitement along with a lot of fun and good eating will take place in Crisfield, Md., Labor Day weekend.

title: Officer Accidentally Shoots His Partner Instead of Dog
description: A police officer accidentally shot his partner in the leg last night when they attempted to halt a dispute between two tenants at an apartment building in Jamaica, Queens, and were attacked by a pit bull, the police said.

title: Review/Television;   The Irreverence of a Lifelong Radical
description: Jessica Mitford is best known for her 1963 book, ''The American Way of Death,'' a funny-serious assault on the funeral industry that goaded the Federal Trade Commission to act against price fixing by funeral directors. ''Jessica Mitford: Portrait of a Muckraker,'' the subject-friendly documentary at 10 on Channel 13, presents her as that most unusual phenomenon, a dedicated radical with a sense of humor.

title: Treaty Oak Pruning Planned
description: The historic Treaty Oak, a centuries-old tree that was poisoned with a powerful herbicide early last year, will be severely pruned later this year in an effort to save it, the city forester says. The pruning will leave only one living section, he said. The tree is supposedly where Stephen F. Austin, founder of the American colony in the Mexican territory of Texas, signed a treaty with the Indians. Earlier this year, Paul Stedman Cullen was sentenced to nine years in prison for poisoning the tree.

title: In a New Germany, Will Bertolt Brecht Still Play?
description: LEAD:

title: Mulroney Hints at Force Against Mohawks
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that unreasonable demands by militant Mohawk Indians may force the Canadian Government to send in the army to end six-week-old standoffs at two places in Quebec.

title: Peru Activist and Son Killed
description: Rebels killed a prominent political activist and his 8-year-old son today as the family took a drive outside the capital, the police said. Arturo Pacheco, a member of the Aprista party of former President Alan Garcia Perez, was killed by a dynamite charge that was placed on his chest after the assailants stopped the car, officers said. The boy died later of bullet wounds. The authorities said they believed that members of the Shining Path were responsible.

title: Official Urges Lower Rates
description: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today in a television interview that interest rates should be cut to help avoid recession.

title: Abortion Pill Might Well Fix Roe v. Wade
description: To the Editor:

title: Epileptic Driver Is Charged In Car Crash That Killed Boy
description: A man whose driver's license was taken away because he has epilepsy was charged with homicide after he suffered a seizure while driving and struck and killed a 7-year-old boy, the authorities said.

title: Give Me, Also, Your Skilled
description: America is about to enhance its reputation as a nation of immigrants, and not just for tired, huddled masses. Legislation moving through Congress would increase the number of immigrants, making it easier for families to unite and for businesses to recruit skilled workers. This first major overhaul of legal immigration in 25 years would be as welcome as it is overdue.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Review/Dance;   Cunningham Alumnus Offers His Own Program
description: Is there life after the Merce Cunningham Dance Company? The answer would seem to be yes, to judge by a first independent program of choreography presented by Dennis O'Connor, a former Cunningham dancer, on Saturday night at the funky Gas Station theater on Avenue B at Second Street in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section on Aug. 2 about the Design Review of ID Magazine misidentified a photograph. It showed the Rhode Gear CS1001 bicycle seat, which was given special recognition by the magazine, not the Baby Bob Car Seat by Dremefa, which won a design award from the magazine.

title: Mayor Barry's Verdict Outraging Colombians
description: Anger among Colombians over the verdicts in the drug trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington appears to be threatening a keystone of American anti-cocaine policy here: extradition of Colombian drug suspects to the United States for trial.

title: Protecting Democracy in Pakistan
description: Pakistan's President, Ghulam Ishaq Khan, carefully observed constitutional formalities when he ousted the elected Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto earlier this month. Ms. Bhutto was nevertheless the victim of a coup in constitutional clothing, sponsored from behind the scenes by military leaders.

title: Trump Shuttle Looking to Expand Service
description: The Trump Shuttle plans to become more than a shuttle by expanding its charter flights to the Caribbean and Mexico and by expanding service to Atlantic City in a move to make better use of its fleet and broaden its customer base.

title: 2d-Largest Philanthropy Widens Role
description: Even here in Philadelphia, where the Pew family amassed a fortune from Sun Oil Company profits, the Pew Charitable Trusts are hardly a household name. But they are the country's second-most generous philanthropy, behind only the Ford Foundation and comfortably ahead of better-known giants like the Rockefeller, Carnegie and Mellon foundations.

title: Suzanne E. Mumma Wed To William E. Hegarty Jr.
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Mumma, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Mumma of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Edward Hegarty Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hegarty of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Joseph deSantos performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bridge
description: It is not often that two teams with national credentials meet in the semifinal of a regional tournament but it happened in February in a Knockout Championship in Cromwell, Conn.

title: Morley Callaghan Is Dead at 87; Canadian Writer for Six Decades
description: Morley Callaghan, a Canadian writer who lived in Paris in the 1920's and mixed with Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald, died Saturday, his son Barry said today. He was 87 years oldandlived in Toronto. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Dr. Renee Frankel Marries
description: Dr. Renee Ellen Frankel, a resident at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, and Dr. Keith Fred Silverman, a dentist in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club in Bedminister, N.J., by Rabbi Louis Sigel. The bride, who is keeping her name, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Frankel of Watchung, N.J. She graduated from Duke University and the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in Piscataway, N.J. Dr. Silverman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Silverman of Massapequa, L.I., is a graduate of Brandeis University with a dentistry degree from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Iraqi Tanker, Its Cargo of Oil Refused, Will Sail Elsewhere
description: A fully laden Iraqi tanker returned to the Mediterranean Sea today after its oil cargo was rejected by Sweden and agents said it would head for a friendly country, shipping officials said.

title: Benicia Journal;   Bible and Constitution Clash in a Liberal Land
description: The greater Bay Area, with San Francisco to the west and Berkeley to the east, is generally considered so philosophically far from the Bible Belt that some might argue it constitutes an emotionally different country.

title: Question Box
description: Runners Left Stranded

title: Caribbeans Preparing For Hurricane Gustav
description: Hurricane Gustav spun toward the northeastern Caribbean today with winds of 80 miles per hour.

title: Fitness Taking a Leap Into the Pool
description: EARLY morning. A businessman recovering from back surgery works through his water-therapy routine in his backyard pool. Across town at the Y.M.C.A., a marathoner runs in the shallow end of the pool to vary his road-running routine. In an apartment nearby, a ballerina reads the morning paper as she moves her sprained ankle up and down, then in circles, in a large bucket of ice water. At an upstate lake, two vacationing basketball pros practice jumping for rebounds on a backboard set in chest-deep water.

title: What Makes Some Crimes More Unacceptable Than Others?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 26, 1990:

title: RIOT POLICE BATTLE BUCHAREST YOUTHS
description: The riot police clashed tonight with anti-Government demonstrators in the fifth night of protests in central Bucharest.

title: 178 Miners Feared Dead In Yugoslav Explosion
description: A total of 178 miners were believed dead today after a gas explosion ripped through a coal mine in central Yugoslavia.

title: Allison Greenhut Is Married on L.I.
description: Allison B. Greenhut, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald N. Greenhut of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to James P. Godman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Godman of New York. Rabbi Dov Lerner performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.

title: Estimate Panel Faces a Delay In Last Session
description: The last meeting of the 92-year-old New York City Board of Estimate should finally come to an end today - nearly two weeks after it began.

title: Microchip Technology Names New President
description: Microchip Technology Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer based in Chandler, Ariz., has named Steve Sanghi president and chief operating officer. He has been vice president for operations of Microchip, a privately held company that was spun off by the General Instrument Corporation in September 1987.

title: White Plains Plan by Saks
description: Saks Fifth Avenue will build a new 120,000-square-foot store in White Plains, which will replace the chain's existing store there, the company said last week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10

title: Ghanaians Celebrate New Babies and One Another
description: The Ashanti chief, adorned with gold bracelets, rings and chains, closed his eyes, bent his head down and chanted a prayer to the health and fortune of the squirming 3-month-old boy before him.

title: Runaway Train Goes 15 Miles
description: A freight train with no one aboard started up and traveled more than 15 miles and as fast as 35 miles an hour on Saturday before an engineer hopped aboard and halted it, the police said. Railroad crossing lights, which are normally activated by train engineers, were not working so the police blocked crossings with patrol cars. No injuries were reported. The authorities were unsure how the Union Pacific freight train of about 20 cars started.

title: Iraqis Who Face Expulsion Show Defiance and Sadness
description: Iraqi diplomats stationed in Washington responded with defiance and a touch of sadness today to the State Department's announcement that it would expel most of their colleagues from the Iraqi Embassy here.

title: Treasuries Make Strong Advance
description: A steep $4-a-barrel drop in oil prices and what traders saw as a slight easing of tension in the Persian Gulf served as a tonic to the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose sharply and interest rates fell.

title: Efforts to Reshape Teaching Focus on Finding New Talent
description: To become a teacher, John Davis gave up his job as a treasurer for the teamsters' union and took a pay cut of $10,000 a year.

title: Merrill Lynch Settles Claims From $250 Million '87 Loss
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and its insurers have quietly settled a set of claims filed after the brokerage firm stunned Wall Street by announcing in April 1987 that it had lost more than $250 million trading mortgage-backed securities, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Deals
description: Football

title: Moscow Can Help
description: The Security Council vote endorsing military enforcement of the U.N. blockade on Iraq was an impressive feat of diplomacy. It not only strengthened the international coalition against President Saddam Hussein; it blocked the temptation of American hawks to plunge into war.

title: Jackson Aide Seeks Presidency in Third-Party Bid
description: One of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's deputy campaign managers in 1988 announced today that he was organizing a third-party campaign to run for President himself in 1992.

title: KEY RATES
Stake in Measurex Increased to 14%
description: Harnischfeger Industries Inc., a machine manufacturer based in Milwaukee, has raised its stake in the Measurex Corporation, a Cupertino, Calif., computer company, to 14 percent from 12.64 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harnischfeger said it might acquire additional shares of Measurex.

title: Corrections
description: A table with an article on Saturday about preliminary figures from the new census misstated the 1980 population and preliminary 1990 count for Oklahoma, and in some copies misstated the Census Bureau's 1990 estimate for the District of Columbia.

title: Fed Reports Bank Loan Tightening
description: Reflecting a further tightening of credit conditions for commercial borrowers, the Federal Reserve Board said today that the nation's banks had increased restrictions on lending since May.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, promoted Jose M. de Lasa to vice president.

title: Letter: On Georgia;   Primary Law Hasn't Hurt Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Skunk Musk's Secret
description: A scientist has identified the components of skunk musk that cause its unpleasant smell to linger on the victims of a spraying.

title: Chess
description: ''Usually I have one good tournament a year. A lot depends on the opponents' play.'' That was how Lev Alburt explained his winning the 1990 United States Championship, which ran from Aug. 5 to 16 at the Jacksonville Hotel in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Satisfying Evening for Hawkins
description: With a crowd gathered around him tonight in the Yankee clubhouse, Andy Hawkins said he would not attempt to dissect what has been a season of inconsistency and frustration. If he did, he might never find an answer.

title: S.E.C. Acts in Fraud Case
description: Federal securities regulators began an administrative action today against a Florida man accused of selling more than $4 million in unregistered or risky securities.

title: Keeping Track of Time
description: THE computer in our one-person office used to share the desk with an alarm clock, a desk calendar and a to-do list. We added the alarm clock because we often forget to look at the desk calendar and to-do list in time to remember the scheduled events we so diligently write down. It was not an elegant solution, but it was less expensive and intrusive than an office assistant.

title: End Comes With Hisses For Board Of Estimate
description: The Board of Estimate died yesterday in much the manner that it lived for more than nine decades: with a series of protracted behind-the-scenes maneuverings, an emotional head-butting with the public and a quick vote. In the end, a 7-to-4 vote approved a United Parcel Service proposal to expand a sorting plant in lower Manhattan by up to a million square feet.

title: Review/Theater;   Indecency in the Eye of the Beholder
description: The borderline between politics and political theater is crossed with polemical results in ''Indecent Materials,'' two one-act plays that opened last night at the Public Theater. The plays, one dealing with AIDS, the other with Senator Jesse Helms's attack on the National Endowment for the Arts, come to New York from the Manbites Dog Theater Company of Durham, N.C. Evidently there is a rumbling of protest in Senator Helms's home territory.

title: 2 Cardinals Acquitted
description: A jury in Covington, Ky., cleared two St. Louis Cardinal players yesterday of disorderly-conduct charges stemming from a brawl May 19 at a service station.

title: Mathematical Brush-Up
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: An AIDS Mystery Unravels

title: Dangers of Alcohol Get Hearing Among Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: An entrepreneur from Ghana and a statesman from Nigeria will share the $100,000 Africa Prize for Leadership, to be awarded next month by the Hunger Project of San Francisco.

title: Human Rights Group Accuses Zaire of Abuse
description: A report released by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights asserts that the Government of Zaire has engaged in a ''systematic pattern of abuses'' that includes arbitrary arrests and beatings, banishment of political opponents and severe restrictions on freedoms of speech and the press.

title: 3 Bicyclists Hit by Lightning
description: A surprising, fast-moving line of thunderstorms swept across the New York metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, disrupting traffic, causing a number of injuries and bringing the area within a fraction of its normal quota of rain for the year. More thunderstorms were forecast for today.

title: Better Prenatal Care Will Lower Baby Deaths;   High Federal Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Jitters, Luminaries Hunt for Dialogue
description: If you don't think it's tough holding a peace conference on ''resolving conflict through dialogue and democracy'' in the middle of war jitters, then just listen to this.

title: Marriott Notes
description: A $150 million financing by the Marriott Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 9.125 percent senior notes due in 1993 were priced at par to yield 77 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the issue was noncallable and rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Berra Will Still Watch The Yanks From Afar
description: George Steinbrenner signed his resignation a week ago yesterday and tendered it the next day, leaving Yankee Stadium in other hands for the first time since 1972.

title: BILL ON INTERNEES RAISES NEW ALARM
description: A state legislator has raised concerns among Japanese-Americans in California by proposing a resolution to revise what schoolchildren are taught about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.

title: Reviews/Music;   The Madness of Berlioz's Requiem
description: Meticulous, clear, lovers of light, the French hide somewhere a lust for exaggeration. It is less advertised today, in a time when conservation at the gas tank and light socket is a virtue and grandeur for its own sake a sin of taste.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's hot, but not any hotter than army gear and a helmet.

title: Soviets Open Prisons and Records To Inquiry on Wallenberg's Fate
description: The Soviet Union has agreed for the first time to open prisons and archives to an international commission investigating the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who disappeared into the Soviet prison system after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, members of the commission said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about new teachers graduating from the Teach for America program misidentified the university at which it was held. It was the University of Southern California, in Los Angeles, not the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: G.M. Is Selling Cars in Poland
description: A Polish entrepreneur said today that he had opened the General Motors Corporation's first sales outlet here since World War II, selling Chevrolets, Pontiacs and Cadillacs on request.

title: Investor Acquires Stake in Watsco
description: Watsco Inc. said H. Wayne Huizenga had bought 50,000 shares from the company, or about 4.8 percent of Watsco's class A common stock, for $10 a share and a five-year warrant allowing him to buy 45,000 class B shares at $11.25 each. Watsco is in the climate-control business through Gemaire Distributors Inc. and various manufacturing subsidiaries.

title: Results Plus
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: FOOTBALL: Jets Make Big Changes; Giants Simply Trim;   Morris and Anderson Survive Roster Cuts
description: For the moment Joe Morris is still a Giant, and Ottis Anderson is one, too. ''Yes, I survived,'' Morris said today at his locker-room stall in Giants Stadium.

title: L.I. Backs Sludge Plan Despite Foes' Concerns
description: Facing a Federal deadline to stop dumping sewage sludge into the ocean by the end of 1991, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today authorized a $3.5 million plan to study building a plant to process sludge for burial in landfills.

title: G.M. Says It Will Put Air Bags In All of Its U.S. Autos by 1995
description: In a move destined to make air bags as common in cars as seat belts are now, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would install the bags on the driver's side in all its cars built in the United States starting in the fall of 1995.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Tactics By Magazine Publishers
description: WITH circulation down, publishers of many of the nation's best-known magazines are grappling with ways to keep the bad news from further scaring off skittish advertisers.

title: Bridge
description: In two weeks, a handful of American pairs will go into action in the semifinal stage of the World Women's Pairs in Geneva. Among them is likely to be the New York partnership of Jacqui Mitchell and Amalya Kearse, who won the title four years ago in Miami Beach.

title: Leonard Drops Title
description: Sugar Ray Leonard renounced his World Boxing Council supermiddleweight title yesterday but left open whether he would continue his boxing career, the W.B.C. said. A statement by the agency said that in a telephone call to the W.B.C.'s president, Jose Sulaiman, in Mexico City, Leonard said he had no plans to defend his title and offered his resignation on the ground that he was far below fight weight.(AP)

title: Horse Racing;   Meadow Star Wins Spinaway
description: Meadow Star won the Spinaway Stakes and Chris Antley won the riding title as the 122d season of racing reached the finish line today at Saratoga.

title: FOOTBALL: Jets Make Big Changes; Giants Simply Trim;   Rembert Is Traded And Sweeney Signs
description: Reggie Rembert, who became expendable before the opening of training camp, was traded today to the Cincinnati Bengals as the Jets cleared up their contract squabbles.

title: Chronicle
description: On a different level of rock, DR. MASANOBU SHINOZUKA of Princeton University will become the director of the National Center for Earthquake Engineering Research in Buffalo next month. Dr. Shinozuka, 59, will take a leave of absence from his position as Sollenberger Professor of civil engineering.

title: Head of Otis Elevator To Become Carrier Chief
description: The decision of William A. Wilson, the head of the United Technologies Corporation's Carrier Corporation unit, to take early retirement next spring has cleared the way for 41-year-old Karl J. Krapek to add another famous industrial name to his resume.

title: Gas Up 5.2/ in 2 Weeks
description: Gasoline prices rose more than a nickel a gallon at the pump in the last two weeks in a jump attributed to the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis, the Lundberg survey has found. The average price for all grades of gasoline rose 5.2 cents, to $1.3316 a gallon, the survey of 13,500 gas stations reported on Sunday.

title: Spot Gold Plummets $26.70, Its Biggest Drop Since 1983
description: Precious metals prices plunged yesterday, with gold bullion posting its biggest one-day drop since early 1983. Platinum and silver prices also dropped, as investors and traders who bought bullion in reaction to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2 sought to unload their holdings.

title: Greenpeace Faults U.N. Panel
description: The environmental group Greenpeace sharply criticized a key United Nations conference on global warming today, saying plans to prevent climate change were inadequate.

title: Quebec Premier Asks Army To Remove Indian Barricades
description: Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec asked the Canadian Army today to tear down fortified Mohawk barricades in the province after talks with the Indians broke down.

title: Distributor Withdraws Rap Album Over Lyrics
description: The first major-label album by the Geto Boys, a rap group from Houston, was withdrawn last week on the eve of its release because its distributor, Geffen Records, would not endorse its explicitly violent and sexual lyrics.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Northrop-McDonnell Fighter Plane Is Tested
description: A team from Northrop and McDonnell Douglas made the first flight today of a version of the Air Force's advanced tactical fighter.

title: IRAQ IS SAID TO ORDER SHIPS NOT TO OPPOSE INSPECTIONS; U.S. EXPELS BAGHDAD ENVOYS
description: Iraq has reversed orders to its merchant ships, instructing them not to resist if American or other naval forces try to board the vessels for inspections as part of the international blockade, United States officials said today.

title: H. Thorkilsen, 64, Ocean Spray Chief In Its Growth Years
description: Harold Thorkilsen, a leader in the agricultural cooperative movement who built Ocean Spray Cranberries from a small New England producer into a Fortune 500 concern, died Thursday at his home in Osterville, Mass. He was 64 years old.

title: Thousands in South Africa Protest Ethnic Violence
description: Tens of thousands of South African blacks stayed away from work today to commemorate the deaths of 515 people in factional clashes over the last two weeks that have drawn widespread accusations of police bias against the African National Congress.

title: SATELLITES KEEP WATCH ON THE DESERT
description: IN the Middle Eastern war of nerves, the United States has one great weapon the Iraqis cannot match: a small fleet of spy satellites that can monitor Iraqi troop movements night and day, see through camouflage and hear the most sensitive battlefield communications.

title: Nissan and Hitachi
description: The Nissan Motor Company and the electronics giant Hitachi Ltd. are studying the possibility of creating a company to develop and manufacture information systems for automobiles. Potential projects include facsimile machines, navigation systems, digital telephones and other devices to be built into Nissan automobiles, the companies said.

title: People
description: * Wayne Buder has been promoted to director of operations and Anne Spoon to director of business affairs at Young & Rubicam/San Francisco.

title: Hussein's Support: Deeper Than We Think?
description: LEAD: In the prevailing Western view, Saddam Hussein is a hero to the downtrodden Arab masses but a loathesome dictator in the eyes of educated, westernized Arabs. This misreading not only severely understates the Iraqi leader's appeal but misleads the West into minimizing the risks of a prolonged confrontation with Mr.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions on Sunday about the United Nations vote on the embargo of Iraq misidentified the Chinese chief delegate. He is Li Daoyu; Li Luye was his predecessor.

title: Metro Datelines;   Exxon to Improve Refinery Safeguards
description: Exxon will spend $2.8 million to upgrade environmental safeguards at its Bayonne refinery to settle a 1989 lawsuit brought against the company for fouling the Kill Van Kull, officials said yesterday.

title: Chargers' No. 1 Pick Is Reluctant, but Signs
description: Junior Seau, the San Diego Chargers' top draft choice, became a reluctant millionaire yesterday, signing a five-year, $4.5 million contract that left him feeling underpaid.

title: Corrections
description: The Guide column of the Westchester Weekly on Sunday misstated dates for the International Auto Show at the County Center in White Plains.

title: Mary Papajohn Haris; Ad Executive, 51
description: Mary Papajohn Haris, vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. She was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hall Still Eager for Trade
description: Mel Hall, the Yankees' angry outfielder, renewed his demand for a trade today and made his feelings emphatic, meeting behind closed doors with Manager Stump Merrill in what appeared afterward to be a heated exchange. When he left, Hall slammed the door to the manager's office, breaking the doorknob.

title: New Advances Offer Cystic Fibrosis Victims Heartening Prospects
description: INSPIRED by a string of recent advances in basic and clinical research, scientists say the prospects for cystic fibrosis patients have never been more heartening.

title: Review/Fashion;   The Galanos Style: In a Word, Glamorous
description: James Galanos designs for wealthy women who go to luncheons and cocktail parties, dine at the finest restaurants and are invited to the best parties. His clothes are rarely seen in business offices. It isn't only because of the five-figure price tags, although they are daunting to all but the highest-paid executives. It's also the glamour quotient of the clothes.

title: Population Tops 29 Million As California Widens Gap
description: A decade of explosive growth in the suburbs stretching east and south from Los Angeles pushed California's population above 29 million for a 10-year growth rate of 23.7 percent, according to preliminary 1990 census figures released today.

title: Stars Outshine the Weather as Open Begins
description: Even before an unpredicted tempest touched down and saturated the United States Open yesterday afternoon, forcing the defending women's champion, Steffi Graf, to make an inelegant scurry from her first-round match on the stadium court, opening day had offered up a controversy, an upset, and the first assault by heat prostration, the event's perennial plague.

title: Uncertainty Is in Stock In the Damascus Bazaar
description: Deep in the Suk al Hamidiye, the magnificent labyrinthine bazaar that is the heart of the old city, a merchant paused in a shop crammed with Oriental artifacts but empty of customers to consider the dizzying events of the last three weeks that have thrown the Arab world into turmoil.

title: U.N. Plan on Cambodia Reported
description: After eight months of negotiations, the five permanent members of the Security Council agreed today on a proposal for a comprehensive political settlement to end the Cambodian civil war, diplomats said.

title: On Horse Racing;   Winners and Losers at Saratoga
description: The highest and lowest moments amid the 24 days of Saratoga racing that ended here yesterday:

title: A Safe Emergency Landing
description: A United Airlines jumbo jet with 323 people aboard skidded to a safe emergency landing today at Los Angeles International Airport when it was unable to get its front landing gear down, the authorities said. The passengers and crew safely evacuated the Boeing 747 by the emergency chutes. The aircraft was on approach when the crew notified the tower it was unable to get the landing gear down, said Fred O'Donnell, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The origin of the flight was not immediately known, he said.

title: Critic's Notebook;   The Future of the Philadelphia And Germanism on the Rise
description: Although the management of the Philadelphia Orchestra, still enmeshed in its labor negotiations, will neither comment nor confirm, it seems likely that shortly after Labor Day, Wolfgang Sawallisch will be named to succeed Riccardo Muti as the orchestra's music director.

title: St. John's Suspensions Continue
description: A St. John's University dean said yesterday that she would not reinstate six suspended students until charges that they sexually assaulted another student are resolved.

title: BellSouth Plans Paging Venture
description: BellSouth Enterprises and the Celltelco Nationwide Paging Partnership announced plans today to begin a joint nationwide paging service.

title: Westair Merger
description: Westair Holding Inc. said it would merge its two regional airline subsidiaries to cut costs. The company said that after merging its NPA Inc. and Westair Airlines subsidiaires, it would lay off up to 75 people from its administrative staff. NPA and Westair Airlines will function as two operating divisions of the same company. The merger is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

title: Metro Datelines;   Woman Is Charged In Beating of 2d Child
description: A Yonkers woman who served two years in prison for beating her infant son so severely he was left partially blind and permanently disabled was charged yesterday with breaking the leg of another infant son, the Westchester District Attorney's office said.

title: This Embargo Can Work
description: Trade embargoes have often proved feeble instruments of coercion. Those who favor quick military action against Iraq argue that the present blockade won't work, or will take many months to bite. They may prove right.

title: The Spread Of AIDS: A Mystery Unravels
description: RESEARCHERS are finally finding answers to one of the biggest mysteries surrounding the heterosexual spread of AIDS: why some people contract the virus after a single act of intercourse while others have sex with an infected partner for years without using condoms and are not infected.

title: Business and Health;   Method of Pricing Drug Is Assailed
description: IN the latest battle over drug pricing tactics, state and Federal officials, doctors and advocates for patients say one company is opening the door to a novel and inflationary marketing method. The company, the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corporation, requires patients who purchase clozapine, a promising treatment for schizophrenia, to buy a Sandoz-licensed program of weekly blood tests. With the tests, a year's supply of clozapine, which Sandoz markets as Clozaril, costs $8,944.

title: Keating Quits Chairman's Job
description: Charles H. Keating Jr., the chairman of the American Continental Corporation, former operator of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, resigned on Friday, a lawyer for Mr. Keating has said.

title: Increase City's Revenue Without Raising Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: Bergdorf Men

title: Personal Income Rose 0.6% in July
description: Personal incomes grew six-tenths of a percent in July and consumer spending rose five-tenths of a percent, the Government said today in a report that some analysts said pointed to a stronger economy than expected.

title: Taylor Talks Continue
description: Negotiations continued today between the Giants and Lawrence Taylor's agent. But agreement on a contract extension for the holdout All-Pro outside linebacker did not seem imminent, although both sides indicated that could change quickly.

title: Conservatives Try for G.O.P. Inroads
description: For the first time in 20 years, the Conservative Party and its candidate for governor are waging a serious statewide campaign with the goal of making deep inroads into the Republican vote.

title: Auto Racing;   CART Eliminates Detroit Race From 1991 Indy-Car Schedule
description: The city of Detroit, which lost the Formula One auto race through its downtown streets in 1988, lost the race that replaced it for the last two years when Championship Auto Racing Teams voted this past weekend to drop the event from its 1991 Indy-car schedule.

title: Glass Deal in Europe
description: A Belgian glass maker, Glaverbel S.A., said today that it had bought a 30 percent stake in Termofrost, a Swedish company specializing in coated glass, glass doors used for freezer cabinets and heated windows. Glaverbel, a subsidiary of the Asahi Glass Company of Japan, said the acquisition should lead the two companies to develop jointly speciality glass, particularly coated glass and heated glazings. Glaverbel did not say how much it paid for the stake.

title: By Design;   Caring for Your Cat Suit
description: While the cat suit, or stretch bodysuit, is heralded as the base for the ''easy'' modern wardrobe, many women are discovering drawbacks to one-piece dressing.

title: New York Recommends a Broader Policy on AIDS Testing
description: New York State residents who have been sexually active or have used any illicit drug in the last 10 years will be urged to be tested for the AIDS virus under a broad new policy that state health officials will announce this week.

title: Nigerians Capture Liberian Rebel Gunboat
description: Nigerian warships have captured a gunboat carrying weapons for a Liberian rebel group, a spokesman for the West African forces trying to impose a cease-fire said today.

title: Dow Gains 78.71 Points, To 2,611.63
description: Stocks demonstrated surprising bounce yesterday, gaining back much of last week's loss in the wake of a big drop in crude oil prices and tentative signs of a relaxation of tensions in the Persian Gulf.

title: Oil Falls, Stocks Soar
description: Oil prices fell steeply on the news of diplomatic efforts to avoid war, and OPEC is close to authorizing higher output.

title: Triton Is Asked To Sell Three Units
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., the Hong Kong investment arm of the New Zealand businessman Ronald Brierley, has urged the board of the Triton Energy Corporation to expand its restructuring plan to include the sale of three subsidiaries. In a letter dated Friday, Robert G. Sutherland, Industrial Equity's president, said three oil and gas subsidiaries - Triton Europe, Crusader and Triton Canada Resources - ''are mature assets and not strategic.''

title: Israelis Devise Plastic Suit as Shield Against Iraqi Gas
description: Hadar Polak was ambling past a bicycle rack, looking like a primitive astronaut in the plastic chemical warfare protection suit he was demonstrating, when a friend drove past and shouted at him, ''Don't publicize our factory too much, or we'll be Saddam Hussein's No. 1 target!''

title: Bush Facing Scrutiny by Congress On His Policy in the Persian Gulf
description: After 25 days of remarkably clear sailing, perhaps unparalleled in a foreign policy crisis in the last quarter-century, President Bush is about to face closer scrutiny from Congress for his policy in the Middle East.

title: Interesting Way to See Interest On Money
description: FOR anyone who often deals with matters of interest - interest on money, that is - PercentEdge can be a great timesaver.

title: Stevie Ray Vaughan Killed; Blues Guitar Player Was 35
description: Stevie Ray Vaughan, one of the nation's top blues guitarists, and four other people were killed in a helicopter crash here early today after a performance with Eric Clapton at an outdoor theater. Mr. Vaughan was 35 years old.

title: Loews Acquires Stake in Champion
description: The Loews Corporation, the New York company headed by Laurence A. Tisch, who is also the president of CBS Inc., has acquired a 7.92 percent stake in Champion International Corp. for $204 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Loews said it had acquired the shares of the paper products company based in Stamford, Conn., as an investment.

title: Contra-Supply Pilot Wins No Jury Award
description: A jury decided against awarding money today to Eugene Hasenfus, whose plane was shot down in Nicaragua while he was flying supplies to the contras.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Mexico Sells Copper Mine
description: Mexico sold the state-run Cananea copper mine today to a private Mexican and Belgian mining group, ending a two-year struggle to pass the giant operation into private hands.

title: Swiss Know How to Conserve Gasoline
description: To the Editor:

title: Osel Tendzin, 47, Head of Tibetan Buddhists, Dies
description: Osel Tendzin, the first Westerner to lead an international Tibetan Buddhist sect, died Saturday at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center here. He was 47 years old.

title: Clues in DNA And Isotopes Help Identify Ivory Origin
description: In an effort to help regulate the trade in elephant ivory, scientists have devised two ways of identifying the origin of a tusk. One method analyzes DNA; the other analyzes ratios of certain isotopes.

title: The Press Corps in the Desert: Lots of Sweat but Little News
description: At the combined Joint Information Bureau the sign-up sheets for today's press activities have long been filled.

title: Union Leader Fights to Control Rikers Ranks
description: Struggling to maintain control over his 11,000-member union, Phil Seelig, the head of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, escalated his war of words with Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday, accusing him of trying to divide the union along racial lines.

title: Anchor Savings Bank Fills President's Post
description: The Anchor Savings Bank named Richard W. Dalrymple president and chief operating officer yesterday, almost 10 months after his successor, William G. Schneider Jr., resigned because his duties had been reduced after a management reorganization.

title: Steel Imports Decline by 9%
description: Imports of steel into the United States fell by 9 percent in the first half of 1990, chiefly because of lower shipments from Japan, Western Europe and Brazil, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.

title: Lost Opportunities Weigh Heavily on Road-Weary Mets
description: The Mets were back home yesterday beating the bushes for a hitter to energize a comatose offense. But they were physically hurt and artistically scarred, and admitted they were worried about their chances of catching the Pittsburgh Pirates in the last 37 games of the season.

title: Better Prenatal Care Will Lower Baby Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Playboy in Deal To Buy Back Stock
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said it had negotiated the purchase of 200,000 non-voting class B Playboy shares from Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd. for $825,000. Industrial Equity, a Hong Kong investment company, remains the second largest owner of Playboy stock, holding a 7.6 percent interest. Playboy's founder, Hugh M. Hefner, owns nearly 71 percent of the stock.

title: A Louder Voice for the Largest State
description: In Presidential elections, California is regarded as a showdown state. But in Presidential primaries, Calfornia hardly shows up. The reason the most populous state has so little to say about who runs is simple: California's primary is held in June, after nearly all other states have voted and the race in both parties has largely been decided.

title: E-Systems Pleads Guilty In Army Radio Fraud
description: The manufacturer of the Army's main combat radio, E-Systems Inc., pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the Government by falsifying test results on the radios. It agreed to pay $4.65 million in fines and restitution to settle the civil and criminal charges.

title: Qatar Offering Installations To Foreign Forces in the Gulf
description: Qatar joined other Arab countries in the Persian Gulf today in agreeing to make military sites available to the growing international force intended to deter an Iraqi attack.

title: TV Deal for Expos
description: In a bid to lure local investors, the Montreal Expos reached a $23 million agreement with Labatt's Brewery for television rights over the next five years.

title: Auto Workers Expected to Make G.M. a 'Negotiation Target'
description: The United Automobile Workers is expected to name the General Motors Corporation on Tuesday as its ''negotiation target'' in talks covering half a million industry workers in the United States, just two weeks after the No. 1 auto maker granted concessions to strikers in Flint, Mich.

title: 'Give and Get' in the Comptroller's Race
description: This year's race for New York State Comptroller has evolved into a discouraging test of campaign fund-raising practices. Both the Republican incumbent, Edward Regan, and his leading Democratic opponent, Carol Bellamy, give reason to question their sensitivity to government ethics.

title: British Hostages Seen On an Iraqi Broadcast
description: Britons held hostage by Iraq appeared on Iraqi television today, addressing the camera with assurances to their families.

title: Tiny Tonga Seeks Satellite Empire in Space
description: Spurred by an ambitious American entrepreneur, a tiny South Pacific kingdom has started what amounts to a turf battle in space that could affect the future control of satellite communications between Asia and the United States.

title: Yellowstone Journal;   Cookout Crasher Rekindles Park Issue
description: Every visitor to this mountainous park is warned not to approach or feed the grizzly bears. But the other night 180 paying customers at the daily Western cookout at Yancey's Hole got a rare close-up glimpse of a grizzly, and promptly abandoned their meals to him.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
