description: The number of rigs exploring for oil in the United States rose by 15 last week, to 1,002, according to the weekly report of drilling activity released today by Baker Hughes Inc. A year ago the count was 909, the Houston-based oil toolmaker said. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. It plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986.

title: Harmful Effects Dioxin Can Have on Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: Risk in 'Boot Camp' Handling of Inmates
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK TAKING AGGRESSIVE STEPS TO PROTECT WATER
description: Facing billions of dollars in cleanup costs it can hardly afford, New York City has undertaken an aggressive legal and regulatory effort to preserve its high-quality drinking water, which is increasingly threatened by pollution.

title: Police Dog Sniffs Out Suspect in Crime Spree
description: A teen-ager was charged today in a robbery spree that began when he reportedly stole a car and ended after he was tracked down by a police dog, Suffolk County authorities said.

title: OPEC Close To Raising Output Level
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is close to authorizing its members that can produce more oil to do so immediately, up to a total OPEC production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day.

title: Air Controller Fights Removal Over AIDS Drug
description: When Ronald Wilkinson, an air-traffic controller at Dulles Airport in Washington, tested positive for the AIDS virus last year, he began taking AZT, a drug that helps delay the onset of AIDS in people, like Mr. Wilkinson, who are infected with the virus but do not show symptoms of the disease.

title: Arabs to Discuss the Crisis
description: Arab diplomats here said a quorum had been reached today to call a disputed meeting of Arab League foreign ministers in Cairo on Wednesday to discuss the crisis in the Persian Gulf region.

title: Jordan Hopes U.N. Leader Cuts Tension
description: Jordanian officials and others expressed hope today that Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations could create a breathing space in the Persian Gulf crisis where diplomacy might, at least for now, take center stage.

title: Bush's Boat Is Unfaithful
description: The White House said that it had been nothing like a rescue at sea and that there had been no real danger to the leaders of the United States and Canada.

title: Airlines in Dispute
description: American Airlines Inc. today accused United Airlines Inc. of misleading passengers in the Chicago market by filing false schedule information. In a lawsuit filed in Federal court in Fort Worth, American said United schedules that take effect Oct. 1 reflect an as yet unapproved deviation from Federal guidelines governing takeoffs and landings at O'Hare International Airport. The lawsuit asked a Federal judge to stop United from filing the schedules.

title: Chronicle
description: SINEAD O'CONNOR, the 23-year-old Irish rock star who has a history of throwing tantrums and getting her way, was singing a different tune yesterday about her concert in New Jersey on Friday.

title: Bush Gives Approval To TV Aimed at Cuba
description: President Bush said today the Voice of America television station aimed at Cuban viewers has passed a five-month preliminary test and will become a permanent operation.

title: Thai Prime Minister Shakes Up His Cabinet
description: After persistent accusations of corruption within his ruling coalition, the Thai Prime Minister shuffled his Cabinet today, replacing the country's longtime Foreign Minister and bringing in some well-known technocrats.

title: Better Prenatal Care Will Lower Baby Deaths;   Ratify Convention
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsico Unit Plans 5,000 More Stores
description: Kentucky Fried Chicken said it planned to double its fast-food restaurant chain in the United States in the next decade by opening another 5,000 outlets. The company, which has been owned by Pepsico Inc. the food and beverage giant since 1986, opened its 5,000th outlet in United States in the San Francisco Bay area town of Daly City.

title: The Man Who Told Hitler, 'No'
description: ''Wer Ist Rodenkirchen?''

title: Q&A
description: Jet Trails and Weather

title: Dust Mites In Houses And Risk Of Asthma
description: Solidly built houses that hold in heat may raise the risk of childhood asthma by increasing exposure to dust mites, a new study concludes.

title: Jury's Award To Liggett Overturned
description: A Federal judge yesterday overturned a $148.8 million judgment awarded to the Liggett Group, the cigarette maker, against the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation. Liggett had accused its larger rival of predatory pricing intended to kill its business.

title: Six Eastern Teams Set Out to Lose Their Independence
description: The possibilities seem infinite, the waiting interminable, and the worst scenario frightening: to be left out, alone.

title: Our Towns;   Odd Beach Balls Are as Much Fun As Hungry Shark
description: Dr. Andrew D. McBride is a sewage-ball expert. He is the director of health here. He is also responsible for the ''No Swimming'' signs that have been posted frequently along Stamford's beaches the last three summers.

title: Scientists Find Chemical Clue To Body Odor
description: Scientists have identified the chemicals that produce underarm odor, they reported at a meeting here today. The culprits are two forms of a chemical that produces odors when exposed to certain bacteria.

title: Hong Kong Journal;   Underpaid, Overworked and From the Philippines
description: Every Sunday, tens of thousands of Filipino women stream into the heart of Hong Kong, filling the park in front of City Hall and spilling out along the sidewalks beneath the stylish skyscrapers and luxury hotels.

title: Accused Dodgers Settle
description: Charges of simple assault filed against two Los Angeles Dodger players after a scuffle with a bartender at a nightclub in Pittsburgh were withdrawn yesterday after an out-of-court settlement was reached.

title: Virtuoso of the Rock Guitar, He Helped Define the Blues
description: Stevie Ray Vaughan, one of the leading blues and rock guitarists of his generation, came from obscurity to enjoy a meteoric success in the early 1980's. Mr. Vaughan was a technical virtuoso who played with lightning speed and was a master of the explosive sound effects that had been pioneered by Jimi Hendrix, one of the most significant of many influences on his playing. Essentially a blues traditionalist, he played solos in a style that was characterized by the New York Times critic Jon Pareles as ''a smooth, long-lined summation of Texas blues, ornately filigreed phrase after phrase.''

title: 2-HomerS In the 4th For Burks
description: Ellis Burks became the second player in Red Sox history to hit two home runs in one inning and Mike Boddicker extended Boston's shutout streak to 33Z innings in a 12-4 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians.

title: A Friendly, Competitive Symbiosis In a Play Looking for a New Home
description: On his last night in the small village of Ballybeg, Ireland, 25-year-old Gareth O'Donnell sits at tea with his father, a sad, uncommunicative man with whom Gar has been trying unsuccessfully to connect all his life. On the morrow, Gar is leaving Ireland, escaping the failure of his old world for the hope of a new life with his aunt in Philadelphia. This evening, what he would most like is for his father to say something - anything - deeper than the nightly litany of ''another day over; I suppose we can't complain.''

title: Market Place;   Goals of T.C.I. In Cable Spinoff
description: FEW company officials try to placate both Wall Street and Washington with the same maneuver. But John C. Malone, president of Denver-based Tele-Communications Inc., is ready to try.

title: Thomas Gillhooly, 79, Priest and Former Dean
description: Msgr. Thomas J. Gillhooly, a former dean at Seton Hall University and a retired priest, died on Saturday at Newton (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and had lived in Sparta, N.J., since retiring in 1987.

title: Dinkins Responds to 2d Boycott of a Korean Store
description: The Dinkins administration scrambled yesterday to prevent a new boycott of a Korean-owned grocery in Brooklyn from resembling the bitter protests against another Korean-owned store in the borough, the Family Red Apple.

title: Bulgarian Socialists Rally After Attack
description: After a night of violence that left much of their party headquarters in ashes, about 15,000 undaunted backers of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, this country's renamed Communist Party, rallied in Sofia's main square this evening against what their party leaders called ''newborn neo-fascism.''

title: Choral Society Season To Present a Premiere
description: The premiere of a work by Robert DeCormier, a festival of antiphonal and liturgical music and a performance of the Bach B-minor Mass are among the highlights of the New York Choral Society's 1990-91 season. The group will sing three concerts, each to be conducted by its music director, John Daly Goodwin.

title: In Egypt, Some Skepticism
description: Egypt is eager for a breakthrough but skeptical that King Hussein will find a formula that will persuade Iraq to move toward an early withdrawal of its troops from Kuwait, diplomats here said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apple Bancorp shareholders have until Sept. 4 to tender their common shares for $38 a share under the offer whose deadline was extended yesterday by the investor Stanley Stahl.

title: Strong Mark Forcing Dollar to Move Over
description: The German mark, the currency of the soon-to-be-united Germanys, is rivaling the dollar in its pre-eminent role in the world economy.

title: Bills, Thomas in Accord
description: Thurman Thomas, who led the National Football League in total yards from scrimmage last season, agreed to a contract extension yesterday evening with the Buffalo Bills and ended his holdout.

title: Metro Datelines;   Robbery Intervention Leads to Man's Death
description: A good samaritan was shot and killed early yesterday when he tried to intervene after a robbery, the police said.

title: Scholastic Tests Show Decline in Verbal Skills
description: The average verbal skills of college-bound high school seniors declined to their lowest level in a decade and the average mathematics skills showed no improvement, according to college admissions test data to be released today by the College Board, which administers the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15

title: Robber Shoots Robber as a Victim Ducks
description: A man who the police believe is a member of the Vietnamese gang Born to Kill was accidentally shot and critically injured by another gang member during a robbery of a Chinatown produce store yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Alternatives to Oil Move From the Lab to the Road
description: IN the last 10 years, scientists and engineers have taken long strides toward the day when alternative energy sources can compete with oil from the Middle East, and some of the more promising alternatives are on the verge of practicality.

title: Oil Price Tumbles $4 a Barrel l
description: The price of oil for October delivery tumbled $4 yesterday, to $26.91 a barrel, as commodity traders reacted to an apparent easing of tensions in the Persian Gulf and the possibility that some OPEC members would increase production. The decline of 12.9 percent was the largest daily selloff in the crude oil futures markets in four years.

title: Romanians Hold Sixth Day of Protest
description: For the sixth day running, several hundred anti-Government demonstrators assembled at the main crossroads of the capital today, but there was no repetition of the confrontations with security forces that took place the previous five days.

title: Over $2 Billion in Remics In 3 Fannie Mae Offerings
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday announced three real estate mortgage investment conduit security offerings totaling more than $2 billion. Since the beginning of the year, the Congressionally chartered, privately owned company has sold more than $100 billion of these securities, known as Remics.

title: Wax, Not Flame, May Lure Moths
description: IT is the warm wax rather than the flame that attracts male moths to lighted candles, a Florida biophysicist says.

title: New Isolationism, Same Old Mistake
description: So far, the chief critics of President Bush's bold military action in the Middle East are not liberals but conservatives such as Patrick Buchanan, Robert Novak and Edward Luttwak - yesterday's most redoubtable hawks and interventionists. Strange new world! The sudden disappearance of the cold war has pulled the rationale out from under the internationalist foreign policy that America has pursued for 40 years. With a victory over Communism behind us, why care what happens to the Emirate of Kuwait?

title: Books of the Times;   The Shapes and Textures of 3 Lives
description: The Woman Lit by Fireflies

title: Fight to House Homeless at Old Missile Base Turns Nasty
description: Someone poured gasoline outside Sgt. Johnnie Peters's home at a defunct Nike missile site here last week in another expression of vandalism and hostility surrounding a plan to turn the old military base and its 36 bungalow-style homes into a project for the homeless.

title: Willard Beaulac, 91, Ambassador To Five Latin American Nations
description: Willard L. Beaulac, a Foreign Service career officer who served as United States ambassador to five Latin American countries in the 1940's and 1950's, died Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 91 years old.

title: U.N. CHIEF TO SEEK RETREAT OF IRAQIS
description: The United Nations Secretary General said today that when he meets in Jordan this week with the Iraqi Foreign Minister he will seek ''full implementation'' of Security Council resolutions calling for the full withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Oil Jolt

title: Ex-Guinness Head Guilty in Fraud
description: After a trial that lasted more than 100 days and raised serious questions about business ethics in the wave of takeovers that swept Britain in the 1980's, the former chairman of Guinness P.L.C. and three other prominent British business executives were found guilty today of charges stemming from the brewery giant's acquisition of the Distillers Company in 1986.

title: Careers;   New Focus On Quality Control
description: MANY corporate managers in charge of quality control may be talking to the wrong people, says Dale Winston, president of Battalia and Associates Inc., a management recruiting firm.

title: 'Air America' Doesn't Fly Right
description: LEAD: ''Air America'' - the movie -is a lightweight, comic caper loaded with a serious political message. As one reviewer in Daily Variety put it: ''It probably will come as news to most of the audience even at this late date that the C.I.A., through its proprietary Air America, was using drug money to finance the war in Southeast Asia and condoning the refining and exportation of heroin both to G.I.

title: Agreement to Preserve Environment Provides Help for Madagascar
description: IN the first debt-for-nature swap that cancels both trade debt and bank debt, the Central Bank of Madagascar has agreed to allow a private conservation group to pay $5 million of the Government's international debt in exchange for a commitment to try to save Madagascar's unique and endangered plants and animals.

title: July Home Resales Up 3.3%
description: Sales of existing homes rose 3.3 percent in July, the second straight monthly increase, as mortgage rates dropped into the single digits, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Metro Datelines;   2 Morning Mishaps Snarl Newark Flights
description: A jetliner's engine caught fire and a commuter plane skidded across a runway when its nosewheel failed to engage in separate incidents at Newark International Airport this morning.

title: Reviews/Music;   Final Weekend of Brahams at Bard College Festival
description: Leon Botstein, a historian, the president of Bard College and the music director of the new Bard Music Festival, is a versatile man. He may even be privy to some arcane science, or simply favored by the gods.

title: Oil Company Profits Drop
description: Despite a rise in revenues, the profitability of the 20 largest United States oil companies fell in the first half of the year, the American Petroleum Institute said on Sunday.

title: Ireland Seeks Beef Pact
description: The Irish Agriculture Minister, Michael O'Kennedy, will fly to Iran to try to receive a beef contract worth $150 million, the Prime Minister, Charles Haughey, said on Sunday. The trip was approved by the European Community, which had banned such visits to Teheran last year because of Iranian death threats against the British author Salman Rushdie for his novel ''Satanic Verses.'' Ireland's beef business has been hit hard by the Persian Gulf crisis and the embargo on trade with Iraq, an important customer.

title: Peacekeeping in a New Era: The Superpowers Act in Harmony
description: The new spirit of unanimity at the United Nations reflects an emerging partnership between the two superpowers at the end of the cold war era. But it also affirms a basic principle of international relations: collective action works when national interests coincide.

title: Notre Dame in Europe TV Deal
description: A changing European television market has given Notre Dame a ''window of opportunity'' to sell its football broadcast rights to a London-based sports channel, Athletic Director Dick Rosenthal said today.

title: Pretoria Raids Union and Seizes Leaders
description: The South African police raided the Johannesburg headquarters of the country's biggest black labor federation and arrested several of its senior leaders today after union members reportedly abducted a black undercover agent, assaulted him and then forced him to address a news conference.

title: Study Finds 'Uncounted' TV Viewers
description: Hoping to attract more advertising to summer programs, ABC released a study yesterday that it said showed that millions of viewers watching television during summer vacations are not being counted in the regular Nielsen ratings.

title: Army's Young Retiring After This Season
description: Jim Young, who is largely credited with resurrecting the Army football program during his seven years as head coach, announced yesterday that he would retire after this season for personal reasons. Bob Sutton, the defensive coordinator and an assistant to Young at Army since 1983, will take over as head coach in 1991.

title: James E. Snyder, 61, Art History Professor
description: James E. Snyder, a professor and art historian, died Thursday at Mercy Hospital in Port Jervis, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in Sunrise Lake, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the criminal case arising from Guinness P.L.C.'s takeover of the Distillers Company in 1986 misstated a business affiliation of Roger Seelig, a defendant. He is a former corporate finance director at the investment banking firm of Morgan Grenfell in London. He was never affiliated with any asset management unit of Morgan Grenfell.

title: In Uruguay, Two Leaders and Two Ideologies
description: While Uruguay's national Government tries to push the country down the capitalist path, the popular Mayor of Montevideo is governing on a platform typical of the socialist world - before that world was turned upside down.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Bush Briefs Legislators on Crisis And They Back His Gulf Strategy
description: President Bush won overwhelming support today from more than 170 members of Congress whom he briefed on the crisis in the Middle East, but several senior lawmakers expressed worry about the patience of the American people in supporting a strategy that may take months to work.

title: People
description: * Bill Dunlap, chief executive officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising, has been named chairman of the central region of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Chinese Execute an Official Convicted of Taking Bribes
description: A Government official convicted of taking bribes was one of four people put to death recently, official reports said today.

title: Guilty Plea in Futures Case
description: A soybean broker has changed his plea to guilty just two weeks before he was to have gone on trial in the Government's investigation of fraud at the nation's largest futures exchanges.

title: Oracle Stock Drops After Profits Restated
description: Shares of the Oracle Corporation, a leading producer of data base management software, fell today in heavy trading after the company restated its earnings for three quarters in its fiscal year ended May 31.

title: Investment Group Raises USAir Stake
description: An investment group led by the New York money manager Michael H. Steinhardt has raised its stake in the USAir Group to 9.46 percent from 8.38 percent, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: FIVE U.N. POWERS ANNOUNCE ACCORD ON CAMBODIA WAR
description: The five permanent members of the Security Council announced an agreement today on the main elements of a wide-ranging political settlement that could end almost 20 years of civil war in Cambodia by transferring temporary control of the country to the United Nations.

title: G.E. Engine Order
description: The All Nippon Airways Company of Japan has ordered $580 million worth of aircraft engines from the General Electric Company, G.E. said. The airline ordered G.E.'s CF6-80C2 engines for 17 Boeing 747's. With the new order, G.E. will supply the engine to 43 All Nippon 747's. All Nippon will take delivery of its first 747 later this month, with deliveries for the new order scheduled to begin in 1995, G.E. said.

title: Deadly Error Halts Sales of Larousse
description: In a country that takes its champignons seriously, Larousse, the venerable French publishing house, has suspended sales of the new edition of its famous dictionary because the book errs in saying that some highly poisonous wild mushrooms are harmless.

title: Corrections
description: An article and an illustration in Science Times yesterday about alternative energy sources misidentified the maker of an electric-powered van that is to go into limited production next month. It is Vehma International Inc. of Markham, Ontario, a subsidiary of Magna International Inc. of Canada. The General Motors Corporation supplies the van bodies.

title: Cops on Bikes Can Fight Traffic Mayhem
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Trump Official Hired by Resorts
description: Jack O'Donnell, who recently quit as president of the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, was named to run Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel.

title: Perfect Attendance
description: One runner who plans on being in the Mercedes Mile is John Walker, who has competed in every one of the nine other one-mile races down Fifth Avenue and won it in 1984. Walker announced his entry yesterday. In 1975, Walker was the first person to run the mile in less than 3 minutes 50 seconds.

title: Ferranti Case Charges Filed
description: A holding company headed by the former vice chairman of Ferranti International P.L.C., James Guerin, has been formally charged with participating in a scheme to defraud the British military contractor, the United States Attorney's office said today.

title: American Acquisitions In Europe Up Sharply
description: American acquisitions of European companies, led by the purchase by Philip Morris of the Swiss chocolate maker Jacobs Suchard, rose sharply in the second quarter after a sluggish performance in the first three months of the year.

title: Ware Reports to Camp
description: Andre Ware, the Heisman Trophy winner from the University of Houston, joined the Detroit camp Monday night after he signed a four-year contract with the Lions. The contract will pay Ware $1.15 million a year, plus a $2 million signing bonus. (AP)

title: A Spirited Capriati Survives Challenging Open Debut
description: Jennifer Capriati's debuts are always auspicious, and the one she made last night at the United States Open, the event she describes as her ''hometown Grand Slam,'' proved no exception.

title: Catching The Bus To Victory
description: He had not yet called Lufthansa to reserve a flight to Berlin. There would be plenty of time for that later. Aleksandr Volkov wasn't saying he was going to lose to Stefan Edberg in the opening round of the United States Open, and he wasn't saying he was going to beat the top-seeded player, either.

title: Papal Statement Could Shake the Church
description: Pope John Paul II is completing a major statement on Roman Catholic moral teaching that is already generating rumors and anxiety among Catholic theologians. Some suggest - and a leading Vatican official denies - that it will declare the church's condemnation of contraception to be infallible teaching.

title: U.S. TO SELL SAUDIS ADVANCED ARSENAL
description: The Bush Administration has agreed to sell Saudi Arabia a $6 billion emergency package of advanced weaponry, including F-15 fighter planes, M-60 tanks and Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Why Holocaust Art Deserves Public Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Prices Increase by 97/ a Barrel
description: Oil prices turned up yesterday, with the contract for October delivery rising 97 cents, to $27.88 a barrel, as traders searched for a new balance in the market after Monday's $4 plunge, to $26.91.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Old Republic Appoints New Chief Executive
description: The Old Republic International Corporation announced yesterday that A. C. Zucaro had been appointed chief executive of the insurance holding company based in Chicago. Mr. Zucaro, 51, succeeds William R. Stover, 67, who had served as chief executive for the last 14 years.

title: First-Time Cooks, Don't Fret: Failure Is Just a Part of Fudge
description: FUDGE may be what you do intentionally on your tax return, but fudge, the candy, began as a mistake: ruined caramel. It happened in someone's kitchen in Maryland, or maybe in Michigan, around 100 years ago. The confection was too good to throw away and good enough, in fact, to reproduce.

title: Bias by Age and Credit Is Found in Car Rentals
description: Eleven car rental companies in New York City were charged yesterday with discriminating against drivers who are younger than 21 or who do not have major credit cards.

title: Rates Move Up as Oil Prices Rise
description: Prices of Treasury securities yesterday continued to move in tandem with world petroleum markets, as a small rise in oil prices prompted credit market participants to sell notes and bonds, lifting interest rates.

title: Bridge
description: Strong unbalanced hands often present major bidding problems when the response is one no-trump. Even when, as in South's situation in the diagram, the suit to be played is obvious, the right level can be very difficult to determine.

title: At a Beer Tasting, Swirls and Sniffs Amid the Drinking
description: LEAD: ''ARE we ready for the first contestant?'' Tony Ruffino asked the judges. With their nods, he brought a pitcher of golden amber liquid to the table. ''Ladies and gentleman, this is contestant No. 1.''

title: California Prices $700 Million Issue
description: The State of California priced a $700 million general obligation bond issue through Bank of America, which made the best offer in competitive bidding yesterday.

title: Long Island Flounders in Closing Landfills
description: Almost seven years after a New York law ordered Long Island to close most landfills by the end of 1990, a third of the Island's towns and cities do not know how they will meet the approaching deadline.

title: Canada's Military Prepares Move Against Mohawks at Barricades
description: The Canadian military stepped up pressure on Mohawk protesters today, sending fighter planes over fortified Indian barricades that it has been ordered to destroy.

title: Falcon's Season Ends
description: Joe Falcon, the world's fastest miler this year, will miss the rest of the track season because of a tear in the sheath of his left Achilles' tendon.

title: New York Post to Discuss Cuts With Unions
description: Peter S. Kalikow, owner of the financially beleaguered New York Post, has called a meeting next week with leaders of the paper's unions to request significant cost cuts that he says are needed to avoid the possibility of closing the paper.

title: Advise And Lament
description: Question: Having been stung by a bee moments before it was time to compose one of his twice-a-week effusions, what did the columnist contemplate?

title: Suspect Taken off Respirator
description: A suspected gang member, believed to have been shot accidentally by another gang member, died yesterday after being disconnected from a respirator at the family's request, hospital officials and the police said.

title: Bailout Aide's $130 Billion Burden
description: Elisabeth Spector is sitting on some $130 billion in financial securities, including one of the nation's largest portfolios of high-yield ''junk bonds.'' It is all for sale, too, and that makes Ms. Spector, director of finance for the Resolution Trust Corporation, one of the most popular people on Wall Street, which is eager to do business with her.

title: Douglas Manager in Low Profile
description: John Johnson, the manager of the heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, was out of character last week in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Berio Opera Canceled
description: Luciano Berio's opera ''La Vera Storia,'' which was to have had its American premiere in concert form at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 4, has been canceled. Judith Arron, the executive director of the hall, attributed the cancellation to insufficient financial support in Italy. All ticket buyers will automatically receive refunds. Information: 247-7800.

title: Berkeley Feels Mideast Storm as a Ripple of Fear
description: At the University of California campus that was once the national stage for student unrest, young men and women with bright eyes and promising futures warily started a new semester this week in a world poised for war.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If it's drug-related, I can count myself out. If it's a domestic situation, I'm safe. But with this, you wonder who's next.''

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SUMMER'S finale coincides with a finish-line rush from my garden, yielding a plethora of zucchini, squash, tomatoes, peppers and more. Many home gardeners become diligent canners when Labor Day approaches. I do not have the time or patience to do that. Most of my excess produce becomes my neighbors' windfall, and I try to deplete the surplus by cooking with as many vegetables as possible during these weeks.

title: Shuler and Vick Won't Be Starting Against Bucs
description: In this preseason of surprises for a Jets team in ferment, Coach Bruce Coslet has waited until virtually the last moment to make changes that could drastically revamp the club.

title: Rinfret Attacks Cuomo's Flights As Free Junkets
description: Attacking one of the more cherished spoils of incumbency, Pierre A. Rinfret today demanded that the State Board of Elections investigate Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's use of state aircraft for what Mr. Rinfret described as ''political campaign activities.''

title: Fielder on List For Japan Visit
description: Cecil Fielder, who hit 38 home runs for the Hanshin Tigers of the Japanese league last season and has 41 for the Detroit Tigers of the American League this season, will be heading back to Japan as part of a major league team that will play an eight-game series against Japanese all-stars beginning Nov. 2.

title: Paul Fitchen, 88, Dies; Ex-Banking Executive
description: Paul Russell Fitchen, a former banking executive, died on Saturday at his home in Brewster, N.Y. He was 88 years old.

title: Salute to New York Schools Begins
description: New York City's First Lady, Joyce B. Dinkins, sporting a button that said ''Make The First Day Second to None,'' began a campaign yesterday to encourage parents to accompany their children to school on the first day and to get businesses to give employees time off to do so.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about attracting and training teachers misstated the name of a recruiting organization.

title: Blacks and Whites Share Control in Selma
description: Blacks and whites have agreed to rotate control of the troubled Selma school system in an effort to end months of racial tension, protests, arrests and lawsuits.

title: New York City In Violation On Diesel Soot
description: New York City, already plagued with one of the nation's worst smog and carbon-monoxide problems, is also violating the Federal health standard for the soot and dirt emitted by the diesel engines of buses and trucks, new government data show.

title: Accounts
description: * United Parcel Service in Korea to McCann-Erickson Worldwide with a budget of $500,000.

title: Battles So Real They Almost Hurt
description: THE quest for another reality, more fabulous, more heroic - at the least, slightly more entertaining - has been an unending pursuit of humankind. In a sense, this search has been epitomized by the movies, which often set forth a Technicolor world that seems more vivid than real life itself. But always there were cracks in the reality, the screen ended somewhere and the auditorium - and you - began.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Japan Putting Limits on Aid To Nations Hurt by Embargo
description: Japanese officials attached new conditions today to the financial aid pledge Japan made last week to help Middle Eastern countries hurt by the trade embargo on Iraq.

title: Saudi Force's Chief Vows Iraq's Leader 'Will Be Destroyed'
description: The newly appointed top commander of the joint Arab force here said today that the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, would be swept aside unless Iraqi troops left Kuwait.

title: Food Notes
description: An Annual Delectation

title: Option for Ex-Coach
description: Kevin Mackey, Cleveland State's recently dismissed coach, will be considered for a possible treatment option instead of a conviction on state charges of using cocaine and driving under the influence.

title: Suppliers' Employees Sent to the Mideast
description: Thousands of civilians employed by military contractors are being sent to the Middle East as part of the military buildup in and around Saudi Arabia, industry and military officials say.

title: Former Head of Guinness Is Given 5-Year Jail Term
description: The former chairman and chief executive of Guinness P.L.C. was sentenced today to five years in prison for his role in one of Britain's biggest financial scandals in decades.

title: Family Gets $1.7 Million for Stewart's Death
description: Seven years after Michael Stewart died following his arrest by the transit police, his family has won a $1.7 million settlement of a damage suit.

title: Mozambique Moving to Democracy
description: Mozambique, once a loyal follower of the Marxist-Leninist line, has gone as far and perhaps further than any sub-Saharan African country on the path toward multi-party democracy.

title: Three 'Mmmmm's and One 'Yuck'
description: CHILDREN are thought to be the taste makers when it comes to peanut butter, so last week at the House of Little People, a child-care center in the Yorkville section of Manhattan, 14 children were asked their impressions of four peanut butters - the three top-selling national brands and Krema, a smooth natural peanut butter sold in the Midwest.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE scene is the garden of a Greenwich Village cafe. A profusion of large planters overflow with a lavish display of riotously shaded flowers. At a corner table, two petite women survey the scene. Finally, one of the women releases a deep sigh and confides:

title: Barfield Sparks Yanks In Rout of the Orioles
description: Jesse Barfield made his feelings known in late July, but things have changed.

title: 4 Shot in a Brooklyn Grocery
description: An 8-year-old girl, two women and a man were struck by shotgun pellets fired yesterday by men trying to rob a Brooklyn grocery, the police said. Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman, said two or three men entered the store at 39 Mott Avenue in the Brownsville section about 5:30 P.M. One man man fired a shotgun, striking a 46-year-old man in the groin, a 33-year-old woman in the stomach and a 27-year-old woman in the leg. The girl was hit when a gunman fled and fired at a store employee who was chasing him.

title: RAGING UTAH FIRE SLOWED BY CREWS
description: A brush fire that killed two firefighters, razed 19 houses and blackened more than 2,600 acres of timber and brush defied control today, although its progress slowed, officials said.

title: Editorial Notebook;   The Estimate Board's 'Ritual Populism'
description: As New York City's doomed Board of Estimate gathered this month for its last marathon series of hearings and meetings, Mayor David Dinkins, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and some others on the eight-member board actually showed up. That was notable: in recent years, elected officials took to sending surrogates to listen to the speakers at public hearings and to cast votes according to their masters' wishes.

title: Michigan Plan on Gasoline
description: Michigan's Governor, James J. Blanchard, today proposed legislation that would bar the leading oil companies from running service stations.

title: Dr. Hugh Banks, 61, N.Y.U. Assistant Chancellor
description: Dr. Hugh C. Banks, assistant chancellor at New York University, died on Saturday at New York University Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Contra Helper Who Was Seized Loses Suit for Pay and Damages
description: Eugene V. Hasenfus, who helped ferry supplies to the Nicaraguan rebels until his plane was shot down, is due no damages because he knew the risks when he took the job, a jury decided Monday.

title: Rates Mixed At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday were mixed, but the average rate on 91-day paper was the highest in more than a month.

title: More Soviet Oil Urged
description: Eastern European countries today asked Moscow to catch up on its contracted deliveries of oil in the face of rising world oil prices and falling supplies from the Soviet Union. The request came at a quarterly meeting of senior oil officials from the Soviet Union, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland. Cuts in the Soviet supply of oil to the Eastern European countries started before the Persian Gulf crisis began.

title: Sylvia Deutscher Kushner, Bassoonist, 65
description: Sylvia Deutscher Kushner, a bassoonist who played with the New York City Opera and other orchestras, died on Monday at St. Patrick's Hospital in Lake Charles, La. She was 65 years old and lived in Lake Charles. She died of lung cancer, her sister, Martha Deutscher, said. A graduate of the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, Mrs. Kushner joined the New Orleans Symphony in 1947, and later played with the Sadler's Wells Ballet orchestra.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From Bush's Speech on Iraq Policy
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's statement this afternoon on the Persian Gulf crisis, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Civil War in Liberia Threatening To Divide West African Neighbors
description: The eight-month-old civil war in nearby Liberia is threatening to become a wider conflict as neighboring West African countries begin to take opposing sides, African and Western diplomats said today.

title: Clothes Make the Cocktail Party, Too
description: Bergdorf Goodman held a cocktail party last night to celebrate the opening of its swank new men's store. A lot of suits showed up.

title: Economic Scene;   The Oil Reserve: Big Is Beautiful
description: HOW much energy insurance is really enough?

title: Seeing Meat as Wasteful
description: To The Living Section:

title: Regard for Own Species
description: To The Living Section:

title: Devils Sign Ysebaert
description: Paul Ysebaert, the American Hockey League's most valuable player last year, has signed with the Devils, the team announced yesterday.

title: Pop Life
description: Rocking Rabble-Rouser

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title:
Real Estate;

Experts Differ On Malls for Downtowns
description: LEAD: THE conventional wisdom on retailing space is that interior malls in downtown skyscrapers are weak locations. Yet Ann Taylor Inc., the women's fashion company, has announced plans to more than triple the size of its store in the 55,000-square-foot, four-level shopping atrium at the base of 575 Fifth Avenue, a 40-story office building at 47th Street.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN LEE HOOKER, the legendary blues singer and guitarist who has recorded more than 100 albums in his 60 years in music, will be honored at an all-star concert in Madison Square Garden on Oct. 16. The benefit performance is intended to raise funds for the Delta Blues Museum in his native Clarksdale, Miss.

title: Rebels Open New Front in Eastern Sri Lanka
description: As Sri Lankan troops inch toward Jaffna Fort along a causeway carpeted with mines, Tamil guerrillas have opened another front on Sri Lanka's east coast, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Arab-Americans Face Wave of Threats in U.S.
description: Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait nearly a month ago, several dozen Arab-Americans have reported being threatened with death or receiving harassing telephone calls in what leading Arab-Americans describe as a nationwide wave of anti-Arab sentiment.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Baron EDMOND DE ROTHSCHILD, who heads an international banking and business empire, has chosen a rarely used means of satisfying an inheritance tax problem with the French Government: he is donating to the Louvre an art collection worth millions of dollars that will occupy a special wing to bear his name.

title: Sabres' Top Pick To Miss 12 Weeks
description: Brad May, the Buffalo Sabres' first-round selection in the 1990 National Hockey League draft, will be out for about 12 weeks after injuring a knee while trying out for the Canadian national junior team in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, the Sabres said today.

title: Dinkins to Ask State Inquiry On 2d Boycott
description: Moving against the latest boycott of a Korean-owned grocery store in Brooklyn, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would ask state officials to investigate whether the boycott violated state civil rights statutes.

title: Americans Can't Afford to Alienate the Saudis;   Emirs No Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Henry Duncombe, 76, Former G.M. Executive
description: Henry L. Duncombe Jr., a retired vice president of General Motors, died on Aug. 18 at Baptist Memorial Hospital in Miami. He was 76 years old and had homes in Key Biscayne, Fla., and Southampton, L.I.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A third century mosaic panel depicting the head of Medusa will be returned to the Sparta Museum in Greece, from which it was stolen four years ago. TORKOM DEMIRJIAN, president of New York's Ariadne Galleries, will present the panel during a ceremony Sept. 18 at the Greek Consulate General in New York. GEORGE ASSIMACOPOULOS, the Consul General, called the gesture ''magnanimous and a tribute to Mr. Demirjian's scholarly devotion.''

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Strains of Embargo on Iraqis Reported
description: As a result of the trade embargo against Iraq, food lines are growing in Baghdad, hoarding is common, rationing has begun and the Government is urging Iraqis to make dates a larger part of their diet, a French newspaper reported today.

title: Books of The Times;   Italian Fiction Over Four Decades
description: Name and Tears and Other Stories

title: Virginia Beach Journal;   City and Black Students Plan Holiday Together
description: A year after racially charged rioting on the waterfront here left a hundred stores looted, dozens of people injured and scores more arrested, this resort city says it is trying to do the right thing.

title: Cable in Manhattan May Lose Channels With Sex Programs
description: Two little-noticed provisions of the cable television franchise contract passed by New York City in June will likely banish nearly all sexually explicit programming, a much-debated broadcast feature in the city for 14 years, from television sets in Manhattan.

title: C.D. and Bank Funds Mixed
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mixed for the week ended yesterday. It was the second consecutive week in which yields ended mixed.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Week in Connecticut'' column of the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday misstated the admission policy for the Eli Whitney Folk Festival at Edgerton Park in New Haven on Saturday. It is not free; tickets are $9 in advance and $12.50 at the gate.

title: Americans Can't Afford to Alienate the Saudis;   'Crimes of the Tongue'
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bechtel Group, San Francisco, an engineering concern, said its Bechtel Houston unit had been awarded a contract to design and build a $140 million petroleum coke-sulfur recovery plant in Billings, Mont., for Conoco Inc., Houston, an oil and gas company.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   For Freed U.S. Families, a Tearful Homecoming
description: Relieved to be home but visibly anxious over the fate of husbands and fathers left in the Middle East, 47 women and children, the dependents of American diplomats who remain in Iraq and Kuwait, returned to a tearful welcome in the United States this evening.

title: Keating Is Replaced
description: A Federal judge today named Thomas Arnold, a Phoenix real estate developer, as the ''temporary responsible party'' for the American Continental Corporation, the parent of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Mr. Arnold will replace Charles H. Keating Jr., the chairman of American Continental who resigned.

title: Matterhorn Victims Identified
description: The police have identified an American mountain climber killed last week on the Matterhorn as Marc A. Swanson of San Francisco. Mr. Swanson, 37 years old, a mathematician working for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, died Aug. 20 when a roped three-member party fell 240 feet while climbing down from the most famous peak of the Swiss Alps, the authorities said. Hans Perren, 39, a guide, was also killed and Chuck J. Ellis, 31, of San Francisco, broke a leg.

title: Giants Keep Morris (for Now), but Waive Thorson
description: Joe Morris is still here with the Giants. Lawrence Taylor is not here yet, but may be soon. That is the latest report on the ins and outs of a team preparing for the start of the National Football League season in 12 days.

title: Volkov Gives No. 1 Edberg a First-Round Exit
description: Floundering like a fish out of water on a hot, dry day, Stefan Edberg found himself quickly ambushed and ultimately hogtied on the Stadium Court at the United States Open yesterday as he was defeated, 6-3, 7-6, 6-2, by Aleksandr Volkov, an unheralded baseliner who wears the No. 3 ranking back home in the Soviet Union.

title: William Leslie Jr., 71, Insurance Executive
description: William Leslie Jr., an insurance executive who was general manager of the National Bureau of Casualty Underwriters and the National Council on Compensation Insurance, died Aug. 22 at the Villa Pomerado nursing home in San Diego at the age of 71. He lived in San Diego and was a former resident of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Offering a Compromise
description: To The Living Section:

title: Draft Revival Ruled Out
description: Despite the largest American military buildup since the Vietnam War, the Government says it has no plans to revive the draft, which was abandoned 17 years ago.

title: Rev. Paul J. Murphy, Pornography Opponent, 82
description: The Rev. Paul J. Murphy, a Jesuit priest who was a former president of Morality in Media, the national anti-pornography organization, died Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 82 years old and lived in Weston, Mass. A spokeswoman for Morality in Media said he died of pneumonia.

title: Apple to Offer Cheaper Macintosh
description: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce a lower-priced line of Macintosh personal computers in October.

title: Alternative to Caesarean Grows More Popular
description: An increasing number of pregnant women are giving birth through vaginal delivery after a previous Caesarean section, partly because more doctors say they are discussing this option with patients, according to a national survey released today.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Reserves Face the First Major Test of Their New, Broader Role
description: In calling up the reserves, President Bush is offering the first test of a military structure reorganized over the last two decades to give the part-time soldier a more central role in the application of American military force.

title: Helping Prague: Act Two
description: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia has what the playwright Vaclav Havel would recognize as a second-act problem. In February, the United States Congress applauded his personal account of Prague's democratic revolution. The applause continued as Czechoslovakia and the U.S. signed an agreement to normalize trade and to make permanent most-favored-nation tariff cuts.

title: Late Night With the Gulf Crisis
description: LEAD: With each change, the once-legendary CBS News is looking more like the last-place New York Yankees. And Laurence Tisch, the president of CBS, is acting more like George Steinbrenner, who used to fire managers once a year, on average.

title: Syracuse Is Facing Puzzle at Quarterback
description: Two days before Syracuse opens its 101st football season with the challenge of facing Southern Cal in the eighth Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium, two quarterbacks wonder which one will start.

title: Teacher Education: Realities of Present And Dreams of Future
description: Tomorrow's teachers sit at their desks at Illinois State University, listening as a classmate explains how he would teach penmanship.

title: Cummins Engine Slows Production
description: The Cummins Engine Company said it would reduce engine assembly to one shift at its headquarters operation here. Cummins said North American demand for heavy-truck engines had significantly declined because of the prevailing economic uncertainty and the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: 2 Merchant Bankers Leaving Merrill Lynch
description: The two Merrill Lynch executives who guided the firm into merchant banking and ''junk bonds'' in the 1980's have resigned and will leave the firm on Friday.

title: Angola Foes Continue Talks on Ending War
description: Angola's leftist Government and the United States-backed rebels met again today to seek an end to the 15-year civil war.

title: To a Child, Staff of Life Is Surely Peanut Butter
description: LIKE many primordial preferences, personal taste in peanut butter is idiosyncratic.

title: Mobilizing for Desert Warfare
description: As American soldiers mobilize in the Saudi Arabian desert, hundreds of American companies are mobilizing in their own way to deliver to the armed forces everything from bullets to bug spray. While no one is hoping for a war, many companies have a chance to reap unexpected profit from the military buildup.

title: Now That Country Clubs Are Admitting Blacks . . .
description: LEAD: When the host of the U.S. Open golf championship, Shoal Creek Country Club, in Birmingham, Ala., bowed to a threatened sponsor boycott and admitted its first black member, headlines exploded. It made me very happy. Maybe, just maybe, I hoped, before the news media lose interest, someone will notice that black golfers are not alone in experiencing discrimination at most clubs.

title: Arthur Rich, 52, Dies; Researcher in Physics
description: Arthur Rich, a professor of physics at the University of Michigan, died Saturday at his home in Ann Arbor at the age of 52. His family said he died of a brain tumor.

title: Market Place;   A New Way to Bet on 1995 Price of Oil
description: Wall Street, it is said, is an odd sort of market, a place where demand regularly rises as the price goes up.

title: California Sees Housing Boom Become Slump
description: On front lawns in many cities along the California coast, the for-sale sign has become almost as common as the palm tree, and to some sellers seemingly as permanent. After several years of breathtaking price increases and demand so strong that houses were snapped up within hours of being listed, California's giant real estate market has slowed drastically.

title: Panic on a Florida Campus After 5 Are Slain
description: Five college students have been slain in the past few days near the campus of the University of Florida, creating widespread panic that a serial killer is loose here.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   IRAQI LEADER SAYS HE WILL FREE FOREIGN WOMEN AND CHILDREN
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq announced tonight that he would allow the departure of all foreign women and children, whom he had previously barred from leaving his country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: OIL AND THE MIDEAST

title: Philadelphia Is Delaying $400 Million Note Offering
description: A $400 million short-term note sale by the City of Philadelphia has been delayed for at least two weeks, and because of numerous problems, the issue may not come to market until the end of September.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV has a new spokesman, according to a Reuters dispatch from Moscow. He is VITALY IGNATENKO, editor in chief of New Times magazine, who was named assistant to the president and head of Mr. Gorbachev's own personal press service.

title: Review/Television;   New Breed Of Blacks On Politics And Power
description: With images of racial polarization dominating the tube, a documentary about black politicians who have won support from sizable numbers of white voters comes as a relief and a corrective. ''Politics: The New Black Power,'' tonight at 8 on Channel 13, focuses on three men who are making it in the mainstream: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia; Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore, and Ron Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: MGM Grand Seeks A Buyer for Hotel
description: MGM Grand Inc. said it had retained Bear, Stearns & Company to help it sell the Desert Inn Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev. The 185-acre property, which includes a casino, 821-room hotel, golf course and 34 vacant acres on the Las Vegas Strip, could be worth more than $200 million, Bear, Stearns said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-17

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Local Units Called or Alerted
description: The Pentagon has called up or put on alert the following units of the Army Reserve, the Naval Reserve, the Air Force Reserve, the Air National Guard and the Army National Guard in New York and New Jersey. The Pentagon has said no units from Connecticut have been ordered to duty or put on alert. The units and their duties:

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From Iraqi Chief's Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq during a visit with Western hostages, as broadcast by CNN and recorded by Federal News Service, a transcription company. Mr. Hussein's remarks were translated by an Iraqi interpreter.

title: Budapest Journal;   Comes the Evolution, a Nation of Shopkeepers
description: For as long as anyone can remember, there has been a grocery store at 13 Szilagyi Erzsebet Avenue. Until December 1988, it was run by the state, which ran it in the red.

title: Boren Is Renominated In Oklahoma Primary
description: Senator David L. Boren easily defeated two challengers in Oklahoma's Democratic primary on Tuesday.

title: What's the Best Answer? It's Survival of the Fittest
description: A Seattle company has developed a personal computer program that ''evolves'' the best solution among various models run on spreadsheets by financial planners for businesses. The new program, called Evolver, was developed by Axcelis Inc.. It works as an addition to a computer spreadsheet and finds the best answer by using principles taken from theories of natural selection and evolution.

title: Kodak Is Sued Over Test Dye
description: Victims of a spinal nerve disease sued the Eastman Kodak Company and four other companies over a dye used for diagnostic purposes. The 25 plaintiffs, who live in 18 states, contend they were not adequately informed of the dangers of Pantopaque, a dye that is injected into the spinal membrane.

title: Corrections
description: A graph on July 28, in the Business Day chart grouping headed ''Tracking the Markets,'' plotted the 150-day moving average incorrectly for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and the panel has since been incorrect each Saturday. Two readers' letters this week alerted The Times to the error. A corrected graph appears today on page D8.

title: Washington Talk;   2 Roads Diverge in Task Of Measuring Poverty
description: Poverty, like beauty, resides in the eye of the beholder. Many Americans think they know it when they see it, but definition has proved difficult.

title: In a Maine Kitchen, The Style Is Italian
description: THE narrow, twisting road down to Peter Cox's house at the end of Indian Point in this little community is like a path back to another era. It dips and winds between salt marshes on one side and the long reach of Sagadahoc Bay on the other. The tang of the ocean is all around, and when the car stops to let an ancient truck cross an even more ancient bridge, the clean smell of the tide drifts through the window, mingling with the fragrance of balsam fir from the woods and rock roses along the shore.

title: As Others Fold, One Show Just Keeps Tapping Along
description: Why is this weekend on Broadway different from all other weekends? Because three Tony Award winners are closing, two of them prematurely by industry standards.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Five years ago, a group of teachers met on this idyllic site in the Green Mountains to recall how six weeks of intensive study here at Bread Loaf's School of English, a graduate division of Middlebury College, had changed their way of teaching. But while praising the Program in Writing for what it taught, they also celebrated the liberation it offered from their isolated lives in rural communities or small towns.

title: Bodily Intrusions
description: Allison and Jimmy Curran are 3-year-olds, too young to make any but the simplest decisions. Any problem knottier than, say, choosing a television channel must be solved by their mother, Nancy Curran. Their father, Tamas Bosze, has had little say in their lives. Indeed, he was the object of a successful paternity suit brought by Ms. Curran, and made his first child support payment more than two years after the twins' birth.

title: Alzado Goal Thwarted
description: Lyle Alzado's dream of returning to the National Football League at the age of 41 ended yesterday when the Los Angeles Raiders announced his retirement.

title: Critic's Notebook;   British Playwrights Look Toward an Era After Thatcherism
description: What will the left-wing playwrights of England do when they don't have Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to kick around anymore? While Mrs. Thatcher is still very much on the scene, the possibility of her political exit in a year or two, as predicted by public opinion polls, may already be sapping the energy from a theater whose most inventive recent writing has often been in red-hot opposition to her policies and values. In postwar Britain, at least, Conservative Governments seem to raise the creative fevers of British playwrights, while Labor leadership tends to still the waters. Should the blandly liberal Laborite Neil Kinnock come to power, one could more easily imagine his ascendancy inspiring a nostalgic Terence Rattigan revival than inciting a new generation's anti-establishment ''Look Back in Anger'' or ''Top Girls.''

title: Eating Well
description: A STUDY published Aug. 16 in The New England Journal of Medicine created quite a stir when it suggested that margarine, the spread that has been considered more healthful than butter, may actually raise cholesterol levels and increase the risk of heart disease. Some headlines mistakenly simplified the message to, ''Is butter better?'' In a word, the answer is no.

title: Americans Can't Afford to Alienate the Saudis;   Sophisticated Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, an End to Supreme Court Activism
description: It is a measure of just how political the subject of the Supreme Court and the Constitution have become that it took Saddam Hussein to get Judge David Souter off the front pages. Perhaps the only benefit we have reaped from Iraq's aggression is the sudden disappearance of opinion pieces by law professors who think that a man who is a bachelor and lives in a small town cannot have the proper ''sensitivities'' (read ''politically correct positions'') on women, minorities and the poor.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf: Neutralizing Iraq's Threat;   For Bush, Toppling Hussein Isn't Required
description: While President Bush has made it clear that he would like to see Saddam Hussein removed from power, the Administration's diplomatic plan in the Persian Gulf rests on the more modest goal of forcing the Iraqi leader to withdraw his troops from Kuwait.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Jesse Jackson Visits Jordan On Way to Meet Iraqi Chief
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived in Jordan today on his way to Iraq to meet President Saddam Hussein.

title: Warning Strikes Hit 10 Cities in East Germany
description: About 45,000 municipal workers in several East German cities walked off their jobs for a few hours today in warning strikes for better wages and job security in a united Germany.

title: Fiat Planning 35,000 Layoffs
description: Fiat S.p.A. announced today that it would temporarily lay off 35,000 of its 116,000 factory workers.

title: Defense Considered By Kansas Utility
description: The Kansas Gas and Electric Company said it might explore a merger or recapitalization to thwart a hostile $857 million offer from the Kansas City Power and Light Company. The disclosure in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission was the first in which the Wichita, Kan., utility said it might talk to third parties to fight the Kansas City Power bid.

title: SLOVAKS ARE HURT BY ARMS-SALES BAN
description: A hand-scrawled, blue-and-white banner hangs limply over the arms factory entrance, proclaiming, ''Democracy. Full Employment. Economic Welfare.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chesapeake Packaging Co., a division of the Chesapeake Corp., Richmond, appointed George F. Barnes president of the Display and Packaging Co., a unit in Sandusky, Ohio.

title: KEY RATES
Minimum Terms for Gulf Peace
description: President Bush is right to be skeptical that Saddam Hussein will withdraw from Kuwait soon. But he is also right not to block talks with Baghdad. Washington cannot appear to oppose efforts to promote a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf conflict. What it can do is stress the minimum conditions for a settlement - that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally, and stop threatening the region. And Mr. Bush needs to work toward a broad consensus on both these objectives.

title: Martha Dodd Stern Is Dead at 82; Author and an Accused Soviet Spy
description: Martha Dodd Stern, an American author who in the 1930's and 1940's wrote popular books about Nazi Germany and later fled behind the Iron Curtain when she and her wealthy husband, Alfred K. Stern, were accused of being Soviet spies, died on Aug. 10 in Prague, friends reported. She was 82 years old and had lived in the Czechoslovak capital for more than three decades.

title: Ceausescu's Snipers Still at Large, Ex-Officials Say
description: Some members of elite sharpshooting units of the secret police force of the Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu are still at large in Romania, two recently retired Government officials say.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Oil Prices Moves Up
description: The price of oil turned back up, rising nearly $1, to $27.88 a barrel, after falling $4 Monday. Business Day, page D1. OPEC delayed a final decision to increase production. Page D19. Many companies are gaining from the military buildup as they receive orders to supply bullets, bug spray and more. Page D1.

title: Fluor Contracts
description: The Fluor Corporation said it had won a contract worth more than $200 million to upgrade a Valero Refining and Marketing Company oil refinery in Corpus Christi, Tex. The construction giant, based in Irvine, Calif., also announced a $50 million contract to engineer, build and manage a copper ore and molybdenum processing plant 200 miles north of Santiago, Chile. The contract is with Los Pelambres Copper, a Chilean company. Fluor Daniel Inc., Fluor's chief subsidiary, is handling both projects.

title: Red Sox Rally in 9th To Win 5th Straight
description: Mike Greenwell had three hits, including a two-run triple that drove in the tying and lead runs in the ninth inning, as the Boston Red Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 6-5, tonight and continued to pull away in the American League East. It was the Red Sox's fifth straight victory and gave them a six-game lead over Toronto.

title: Police Criticized for Idleness in Bulgaria Fire
description: Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov today criticized police idleness at a fire that destroyed the headquarters of the governing Communist Party but said it might be ''the price we have to pay'' for avoiding clashes with protesters.

title: INSIDE
description: Illinois Tornadoes Kill 23

title: Church Allowed to Exhume Body of Candidate for Saint
description: Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday gave the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York permission to exhume the remains of Pierre Toussaint, a former slave, as one of the first steps toward canonizing him as the first black American saint.

title: New Futures Rules Weighed
description: Federal futures regulators announced plans today to explore changes for handling the liquidation of customer accounts, in the wake of the collapse of Stotler Group Inc.

title: In Moscow, More Fanfare Than Action
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM and Ogilvy & Mather opened offices with great fanfare in Moscow 18 months ago, and while both have been busy learning the ins and outs of doing business in the Soviet Union, the one thing they have not been doing much of is creating advertising.

title: Children Who Fear Guns Suffer Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Teufel's Shot Leads Mets Past Padres
description: The shot to left was gone. Tim Teufel, watching as the ball smashed off the first deck of seats, nearly crashed across first base, then downshifted deliberately, did not trip, and safely touched each bag. At last, his cleats hit the plate as he completed probably the most exquisite 360 feet he has traveled in a disorienting season.

title: Dow Edges Up 3.22 Points on Slow Volume
description: Stock prices moved ahead slightly yesterday on slow volume as some investors and traders took to the sidelines. Many said they were waiting for further signs as to where oil prices and the Middle East crisis might be heading.

title: I.B.M. Expands Sale of New PC
description: Saying that the three-city introduction of its new PS/1 home computer in June had been well received by customers, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had begun selling the computer nationwide.

title: In Moscow, Cigarette Addicts Will Get Just Half Pack a Day
description: Facing a tobacco shortage that has produced street protests and riots in some cities, Moscow's City Council decided today to ration cigarettes starting this Saturday.

title: Resolution Trust Backed
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Resolution Trust Corporation can override Arkansas bank branching laws in approving the sale of a failed savings and loan association.

title: U.S. Foreign Trade Deficit Declined by 14% in Quarter
description: The gap between United States imports and exports shrank to its lowest level in six and a half years between April and June, the Commerce Department said today, but the improvement was largely caused by cheaper oil imports that have since shot up in price.

title: Wine Talk
description: THANKS in part to a weaker dollar, imports of French wines fell by 14 percent in the first half of 1990, which, in the simplest terms, meant that prices were too high. If the usual round of autumn price increases arrives within the next two or three weeks, it will be tougher than ever to find good French wines at reasonable prices.

title: About New York;   A Crescendo In the Concerto Of Competition
description: ''This is the Grand Central station of the New York music world,'' Michael Meltzer said. He said this in the Steinway & Sons showroom on West 57th Street, between playing a Scarlatti sonata and telling how the man who invented the windshield wiper and the shock absorber also dreamed up something that made the moving parts inside a grand piano move faster.

title: Building a More Fuel-Efficient Jet
description: Concerned about sharply higher oil prices, aircraft manufacturers are taking a fresh look at technology that can help planes squeeze more miles out of a tank of jet fuel.

title: Delay Sought In Meeting Of OPEC
description: Iran's oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, whose country said it would not support an accord proposed by a majority of the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise output, asked today that the OPEC meeting be postponed a week to consider alternative courses.

title: Frederick Schang, 96, Manager of Musicians
description: Frederick Schang, a founder and former president of Columbia Artists Management Inc., the world's largest classical-music management firm, died Sunday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 96 years old, said his granddaughter, Gabrielle Schang of Manhattan.

title: Dr. Selvan Davison, 78, Professor at Mt. Sinai
description: Dr. Selvan Davison, a rheumatologist who was chief of the arthritis clinic at Mount Sinai Hospital and clinical professor of medicine emeritus at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died on Sunday at the hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens. He died of leukemia, his family said. Dr. Davison, who practiced for 45 years in Manhattan until shortly before his death, was a founder of the first major group health insurance plan in the East in 1946. He was a Bronx native, and began his medical career as an intern at Mt. Sinai in 1938 after graduating from the medical school of the University of Edinburgh. In World War II he was a major in the Army Medical Corps.

title: Jury Orders Ernst to Pay $18.9 Million
description: A Honolulu jury has decided that the accounting firm of Ernst & Young should pay $8.9 million in actual damages and $10 million in punitive damages to a group of tax-shelter investors. The jury has found that the investors relied upon fraudulent financial forecasts, reviewed by Ernst & Young, before they put $8.9 million into various partnerships that turned out to be worthless.

title: Drug Chief Defends Abduction of Mexican Doctor
description: The new head of the Drug Enforcement Administration today defended the agency's role in the abduction of a Mexican doctor charged in the 1985 torture and killing of an American drug agent in Guadalajara.

title: Stake Is Acquired In Georgia Gulf
description: The New York investor Julian H. Robertson Jr. has acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Georgia Gulf Corporation, an Atlanta-based chemical company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Robertson said he had bought the shares as an investment.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Review/Art;   San Francisco Revolution in Style Recalled in a Traveling Exhibition
description: In the early 1950's, when Abstract Expressionism was first gaining widespread attention and the New York art scene was heating up, a quieter revolution was taking place in San Francisco. The Abstract Expressionist style, already embraced by many of the city's forward-looking painters, was being abandoned for a return to figuration that was heavy on the use of raw color and muscular paint handling, and light on traditional drawing.

title: Americans Can't Afford to Alienate the Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: TORNADOES KILL 23 IN CHICAGO REGION
description: Tornadoes ripped through several northern Illinois towns today, tossing automobiles into the air and flattening an apartment complex, a high school and at least 90 homes. At least 23 people were killed, and hospitals said 280 or more were injured.

title: Earl Veron, 68, Judge On U.S. District Court
description: Earl E. Veron, a judge of the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, died Tuesday at Tulane Medical Center in New Orleans. He was 68 years old. He collapsed at the Federal courthouse in New Orleans and was pronounced dead of heart failure at the medical center.

title: NO U.S. HOSTAGES RELEASED;   No Americans Permitted to Go After Iraqi Vow
description: None of the roughly 1,000 American women and children trapped in Kuwait and Iraq left today, despite President Saddam Hussein's promise on Tuesday to permit them and other Westerners to depart. Baghdad said that it would require each one to procure an exit visa first.

title: Donnelley's Meredith Bid
description: A Federal court has cleared the way for the Meredith Corporation to sell its printing business to the R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company for $568 million, but the Government has appealed the ruling on antitrust grounds.

title: Review/Art;   U.S. Artist Has Whole French City as His Gallery
description: Mark di Suvero's career has had its share of spectacular moments, but the American sculptor has never had an opportunity like the one he has been presented with this summer. He has essentially been given a city in which to showcase all the facets of his art.

title: Julian B. Abbott; Decorator, 64
description: Julian Bingham Abbott, an interior designer based, died on Aug. 20 at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Homeless Man Asleep on a Grate Dies as It Falls 30 Feet Into a Pit
description: One of three homeless people sleeping on a sidewalk grate near Penn Station was killed last night when the grate gave way and plunged 30 feet into an empty vault, the police said.

title: A Grand House Sticks Out Its Tongue
description: RICHARD EKSTRACT has long had a passion for Italian food and wine, siestas, Palladian architecture and the Tuscan countryside. He has studied Italian and thinks he was Italian in another life.

title: It Takes More Than Medication to Heal Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Travellers Corp., Warrington, Pa., an insurance company, appointed John Riordan president and chief operating officer. Thomas Parry was named vice president of product development and compliance.

title: Market Place;   A Short, Sad Tale Of In-Store Inc.
description: THE story of In-Store Advertising Inc. as a publicly held company is now six weeks old, but to many buyers it probably seems much longer.

title: Egypt: Now a Strategic Asset
description: LEAD: Early last year, a respected Congressman vented his frustration with Egypt's faltering economic program, claiming the U.S. got ''nothing in return'' for its billions of dollars of economic aid. Even then, it should have been apparent what we were getting for the money: Egyptian-Israeli peace. Now the Persian Gulf crisis has provided graphic evidence of how important Egypt's diplomatic and military weight can be in protecting vital oil interests.

title: Puerto Rico Prices Tax-Free Bonds
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico yesterday tentatively priced $274 million in tax-exempt public-improvement bonds with a maximum yield of 7.80 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Try to Tell a Widow That Life Goes On
description: HOME is the two top floors of a condominium apartment building in Manhattan, near Central Park, which were demolished and rebuilt over the past year as a French palace. It is a work in progress: a butler in a white jacket serves soft drinks in crystal goblets as workers on tall ladders adjust the wiring for a chandelier in the rotunda.

title: Fujitsu Introduces Two Supercomputers
description: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's biggest computer maker, today introduced two powerful supercomputers and an operating system that can run all the company's computers.

title: CBS Specials May Take On 'Nightline'
description: CBS News plans to use Dan Rather's exclusive interview with the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, which was broadcast last night, to begin a continuing series of late-night news specials focusing on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The specials may evolve into a regular news program to compete with ABC's ''Nightline.''

title: ESPN Chief Leaving To Head New Venture
description: Roger L. Werner Jr., the president and chief executive of ESPN, is leaving the cable sports service to become the president and chief executive of Prime Ventures Inc., a new company being formed by Bill Daniels, a leading cable entrepreneur.

title: Metro Matters;   2 Unlikely Allies Strike Deal On Office Tower
description: Lost amid the billion-dollar development deals approved by the Board of Estimate in its final meeting, which ended on Monday, was a modest proposal for a 28-story office building on West 34th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

title: Red Sox Stay Six Ahead With Sixth Victory in Row
description: Dana Kiecker (6-6) shut out Cleveland on three hits for seven innings as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Indians, 7-1, tonight for their sixth consecutive victory on the road.

title: Panel Affirms Claims of Beatings at Rikers Island
description: An investigation by the State Commission of Correction has concluded that correction officers on Rikers Island used excessive force during the Aug. 14 melee that left more than a hundred inmates and guards injured.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apache Corp., Denver, an oil and gas company, said it would buy certain oil properties of CNG Producing Corp., a unit of Consolidated Natural Gas Co., Pittsburgh, for $23.5 million.

title: U.S. Judge Approves Order On the Use of Force in Jails
