description: After weeks of negotiations between the Department of Correction and lawyers for inmates, a Federal judge yesterday approved a revision of the rules on the use of force by jail guards that have been at the heart of the recent turmoil at Rikers Island.

title: The Long Road Back
description: Carlos Grosso, the Peronist Mayor of this sprawling and beautiful city, is embarking on the ''privatization'' of parking-law enforcement and the maintenance of a street system that includes some of the most impressive boulevards in the world.

title: In Pakistan, Martial Law Waits to Return;   Elections Are Pledged
description: To the Editor:

title: Tin Prices Drop Sharply
description: Tin prices plunged today to their lowest level in 44 months, and market analysts said chances for a sharp recovery in the near future appeared slim.

title: Census Data Show Sharp Rural Losses
description: From the Mississippi River delta to the Appalachian mountains of Kentucky to the high plains of North Dakota, rural America suffered far greater losses in population during the 1980's than had been expected, according to preliminary figures from the 1990 census.

title: Bank of New York Ratings Are Lowered
description: The rating on $1.2 billion in long-term debt and commercial paper issued by the Bank of New York Company has been lowered, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: Chairman Quits At Ameritrust
description: The chairman of the Ameritrust Corporation, which reported big losses in the first half of this year, has resigned, the bank holding company said on Tuesday.

title: Allegre Could Lose Job to a Rookie
description: Every year, pro football teams generally bring two or more place-kickers to training camp. And almost every year, the incumbent makes the team and the bright-eyed newcomers are cut loose and float in the huge pool of midseason emergency replacements.

title: Mattar, No. 66, Knocks Gomez Out of Open
description: When 30-year-old Andres Gomez accepted his French Open trophy, his first memorable booty in more than a decade of Grand Slam endeavors, he likened the experience to watching his career ascend and explode like a sunrise.

title: Miscellany
description: * Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago, bought a share of Allied Communications, a new agency in Seoul, South Korea. The venture was created after the agency ended their three-year association with Dong Bang Advertising Co. because of a client conflict. Allied will serve local and multinational clients, including Procter & Gamble, Philip Morris and Cathay Pacific. Allied is headed by Senyon Kim.

title: Trebelhorn Keeps Job
description: Tom Trebelhorn, whose job was rumored to be in jeopardy, will continue as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers. In an interview with The Milwaukee Journal on Tuesday night, Harry Dalton, Milwaukee's general manager, said the Brewers would honor Trebelhorn's contract, which runs through the 1991 season. (AP)

title: Review/Music;   More From The Mozart Catalogue
description: There are certain pieces in the Mozart canon that make us wonder whether Mr. Kochel's chronological catalogue may not have taken a wrong turn or two. How, for instance, could so vast and operatic a piano concerto as the E-flat (K. 271) have appeared as early as Mozart's 22d year and how possibly could the great Sinfonia Concertante for Violin and Viola have emanated from his 24th?

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: WHEN I go home at night, the light is different from what it was only a few weeks ago. Inside the bus it is cold, but outside heat is rising up from the sidewalks and pushing down from the sky. The people streaming into Penn Station are jacketless if they are men and bare-armed if they are women, and the boys on bikes are stripped to singlets and shorts. Everything is what it's been for months. Except the light. The light is steely.

title: Consumer Confidence In Worrisome Drop
description: Two major indexes of consumer confidence, which for many economists is the most sensitive measure of a nation's vulnerability to recession, plunged sharply in August, indicating that frightened Americans might finally be pushing the United States into a recession, after months of weak economic growth.

title: Trump Crisis Approaching 2d Phase
description: Donald J. Trump is about to enter Round 2 of his financial crisis, and the sale of the Plaza Hotel is likely to be part of it.

title: 2 Surprises: Diane Suzanne Wins, and Charon Doesn't
description: If the rest of the races at Belmont Park this fall are anything like those on yesterday's opening card, the meeting is going to seem a lot longer than 54 days.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section last Thursday about the Collapsible Classics furniture line gave an incorrect number for the designer, Bower Studios. Its number is (802) 877-6868.

title: Alternative Screening On Fetal Neural Defects
description: Research at Harvard Medical School suggests that women at high risk of having a baby with a neural tube defect can be screened just as well with ultrasound as with the standard method, amniocentesis, which is more expensive and can itself cause miscarriage.

title: Reporter Finally Flees Kuwait After Weeks of Eluding Iraqis
description: Caryle Murphy, a reporter for The Washington Post who escaped from Kuwait on Monday after almost a month of eluding Iraqi troops, said today that she finally fled to Saudi Arabia because remaining seemed largely fruitless and increasingly dangerous.

title: Chairs Just for Little Folks
description: PARENTS, rejoice. Manufacturers are making children's furniture fashionable again. Just as in the 19th century, when miniature chairs were common, furniture makers are offering scaled-down versions of their designs.

title: Jets' Picture Not Clear
description: The winner of the Jets' quarterback showdown Thursday night may not win the starting job after all.

title: Development Proposal Roils Oyster Bay
description: As the other great harbors of Nassau County have succumbed to mistreatment and pollution, Oyster Bay Harbor has remained relatively untroubled: a home or rest stop for dozens of species of waterfowl and fish, a place where people can still swim, sail and harvest the oysters that flourish in its waters.

title: Talking Deals;   'Paralyzed' Contel In GTE's Grasp
description: THE Contel Corporation, which earlier this month signed a definitive agreement to be purchased by the GTE Corporation, provides another example of a company forced into a deal at least in part because of debt it took on to make acquisitions.

title: Dallas Police Chief Charged With Perjury in Investigation
description: The Chief of the Dallas police was charged with seven counts of perjury today over statements he made this month to a panel investigating the fatal shooting of a civilian by a police officer.

title: Trees Need Work? Beware Low Bids
description: Sometimes homeowners go through the prudent steps of obtaining three or four bids for pruning or cutting large trees and find that one estimate is significantly lower than the others. It would seem sensible to accept the low bid, the National Arborist Association says, but only if the tree contractor can show proof of liability insurance.

title: Loose Ends in Gulf Policy
description: Despite President Bush's nearly flawless handling of the Persian Gulf crisis, several key issues still dangle dangerously, unresolved or unclarified.

title: Cuomo Says State Will Buy 268 Alternative-Fuel Vehicles
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo drove to a news conference here today in a light blue, methanol-powered Ford and announced that the state would buy 268 cars and buses powered by alternative fuels in the next five years.

title: The Five vs. the Four in Cambodia
description: From the Persian Gulf to Phnom Penh, the end of the cold war has brought no respite from deadly regional conflicts. But the superpower role in these confrontations has been dramatically transformed. The agreement on Cambodia announced Tuesday by the Security Council's five permanent members converts major sponsors and suppliers of the rival factions into peacemakers.

title: Bridge
description: Among the hundreds of Americans who will be competing in the world championships beginning on Sunday in Geneva will be two who have a very short journey. Bill Russ and Irene Rothenberg are New Yorkers who have lived in Switzerland for many years and now represent that country.

title: It's Old, It's Ugly, and It Kills Tanks: It's Warthog
description: In an age of Stealth fighters, the A-10 is among the least glamorous in the Pentagon's panoply of weapons.

title: First Hubble Findings Bring Delight
description: In the first scientific results from the crippled Hubble Space Telescope, an unexpected concentration of stars, attracted by some mysterious force, has been discovered around what once appeared to be an ordinary galaxy, and a glowing ring of gaseous matter, equally surprising and puzzling, has been detected around the remnant of a star seen to explode three years ago.

title: Israel Jittery Over Shekel
description: Uneasy about the possibility of a new economic plan that could include a significant currency devaluation, Israelis rushed today to buy foreign currency.

title: Revenge Of the Dog Biscuits
description: MARK SIMON and Michael McDonough have discovered that it takes more than ingenuity to build a structure sound enough to lead a dog's life. Both architects designed doghouses made of dog biscuits for the Cooper-Hewitt Museum's ''Doghouse,'' exhibition, which runs through Oct. 14. But their doghouses disintegrated, or almost.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Sylvia Deutscher Kushner, a bassoonist with the New York City Opera, omitted a survivor. He is her husband, William Kushner.

title: Art Wedded to Architecture: A View Through Stained Glass
description: WHEN Brian Clarke was an art student, he was shown some photographic slides that a teacher had made on a vacation in Italy. A few tourists had wandered into the frames and were dwarfed by the great frescoes.

title: Chrysler Is Silent On Polish Reports
description: The Chrysler Corporation would neither confirm nor deny a report that a Polish concern was negotiating to buy assembly equipment from the United States auto maker to build a Chrysler-based car in Poland. But a company spokeswoman, Karen Stewart, said Chrysler definitely had no plans to build vehicles itself in the Eastern European country.

title: Robert Phillips Dead; Photographer Was 64
description: Robert H. Phillips, a photographer whose work has appeared in the nation's leading magazines and is in the photography collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art, died on Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 64 years old.

title: Federal Farm Credit Financing
description: A four-part financing totaling more than $4.2 billion was priced yesterday by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation.

title: Emergency Rule Is Declared in Armenia
description: Armenia's Parliament declared a state of emergency throughout the republic today after a member of the Parliament was shot dead by a rogue paramilitary group, Soviet press accounts and Armenian officials said.

title: John J. O'Hara, 71, Retired Federal Agent
description: John J. O'Hara, a former Internal Revenue Service intelligence agent and a member of the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force, died on Tuesday at the Community Medical Center in Toms River, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Berkeley Township, N.J.

title: Official Will Be Named To Police S.& L. Assets
description: Concerned about the huge potential for fraud and abuse in the savings and loan bailout, the Government agency managing the rescue effort will name an overseer within the agency to ferret out corruption among Federal officials and private firms managing the assets of failed institutions.

title: Shoji Screens at Home in the West
description: IN Japan, shoji screens are found in nearly every home, used instead of curtains to create privacy while letting in light. But Westerners have devised less traditional uses for these elegant screens, originally formed from wood and rice paper, says Hisao Hanafusa, a partner in Miya Shoji, a Manhattan company that has made customized Japanese screens for more than 40 years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Barriers Are Down in Mohawk Dispute in Quebec
description: Masked Mohawks helped soldiers today to tear down barricades set up seven weeks ago near the Mercier Bridge, avoiding a bloody confrontation.

title: 25 Dogs Seized in Brooklyn in Cruelty Case
description: A Brooklyn woman who neighbors said walked the streets of Red Hook in search of the stray dogs and cats she kept in a nearby warehouse that was her home was charged yesterday with cruelty to animals.

title: The Soot Is Gone, But What Is Lost?
description: SOOT can be sublime. Those who doubt it need travel no farther than Trinity Church, which looms at the foot of Wall Street in lower Manhattan. For most of this century, the moody, pinnacled facade of the church, Richard Upjohn's 1846 Gothic Revival masterpiece, has been distinguished by a jet-black layer of grime.

title: He Lives in a Lighthouse and Builds Ships
description: LEAD: AS the early morning fog lifts from a secluded cove here, Gilbert Charbonneau selects a choice timber and begins work on his latest shipbuilding project. This marine architect, however, builds his ships in bottles.

title: Put Periwinkle Everywhere, Please!
description: FOR those fanatics who like everything to match, a 20-month-old company in St. Louis called Dyeing to Please might be a dream come true.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is unadulterated nonsense. The Census Bureau itself admitted that its 1980 count missed some 450,000 New Yorkers.''

title: N.F.L. May Slow Down
description: Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, said yesterday that the league was considering revising its new speed-up rules to get three or four plays back into the game.

title: Harris Levin; Lawyer, 83
description: Harris Levin, a lawyer who specialized in bankruptcy law, died yesterday at Franklin Medical Center in Valley Stream, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: Autopsy Tests For AIDS Find 1 in 7 Infected
description: Six months after it began conducting AIDS tests in all autopsies, the New York City Medical Examiner's office has found infection rates as high as 38 percent in some groups.

title: Chronicle
description: NANCY REAGAN had a cancerous tumor removed from her face yesterday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., a family spokesman said. She and former President RONALD REAGAN left for their home in Los Angeles later in the day.

title: Sununu Tutors the Kremlin's Staff
description: The Kremlin moved ever closer in spirit to the White House today as President Bush's chief of staff worked within on the Soviet ''paper flow,'' and a tent city of disgruntled citizens maintained its encampment in a park just across the way.

title: A Bigger Rise In Food Prices
description: Food prices are likely to rise as much as 7 percent this year because of a citrus freeze in Florida last winter and disruptions in milk and red meat production, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Miles to End Health Claims On Vitamins
description: MILES INC., a maker of health and household products in Elkhart, Ind., agreed yesterday to stop making health claims in advertising for its One-A-Day vitamins that Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York said were ''false'' and ''unfounded.''

title: Jet Fighter By Lockheed
description: The Lockheed Corporation today presented its version of a futuristic fighter proposed for the 21st century.

title: Litton Profits Decline by 2%
description: Litton Industries' fourth-quarter earnings fell 2 percent despite higher sales, the company said today.

title: Oil-Freeze Plan in Italy
description: Italian finance officials proposed today that prices of petroleum products be frozen for three months to combat rising inflation resulting from the Gulf crisis. The Treasury Minister, Guido Carli; the Finance Minister, Rino Fomica, and the Budget Minister, Paolo Cirino Pomicino, will ask the Cabinet on Friday to approve a freeze that would be in effect from September through November. The freeze is aimed at protecting the Italian economy, which is highly dependent on oil.

title: Metro Datelines;   Judge Dismisses Suit Against Helmsley
description: A Federal judge yesterday threw out a civil racketeering lawsuit that claimed that Leona Helmsley illegally took millions of dollars from her husband.

title: New Starters Give Red Sox a Lift
description: All winter and all spring, and part of the summer too, Lou Gorman looked for a starting pitcher.

title: Deals
description: Football

title: A Timely Hit by Boston Lets Mets Edge Padres
description: Late in a game late in August. The score deadlocked. The nightly stakes readily apparent to anyone who cares to look at the scoreboard.

title: Blazing a 27,000-Mile Trail at Sea
description: A disarming quiet pervades the docks here each morning, but the stillness is misleading. Anxious yachtsmen are up at dawn preparing to race round the world in the BOC Challenge. They are moving with purpose through the innards of their boats. In two weeks, these sailors - for the first time, both men and women - will be setting sail in a competition that has no mercy for the unprepared.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Japan Lifts Discount Rate to 6%
description: Despite denials just a day earlier, the Bank of Japan said this morning that it was raising its discount rate for the fifth time in a little more than a year. The new rate is 6 percent, from 5.25 percent, effective today.

title: Keeping Your Rocker on a Steady Course
description: LEAD: Although the rocking chair is accepted as an American creation, no one seems to have determined the origin of the idea of adding curved runners to chairs. The rocking chair was born sometime in the mid-1700's, rocking became a Colonial pastime and the idea spread quickly around the world.

title: Why the Tube Can Be Hussein's Worst Enemy
description: Something there is that doesn't love a dictator - and that something may be television.

title: Retrain New York Transit Officers to Use the Guns They Have;   Risk Is Far Too Great
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Threatens to Void Payola Case
description: The Federal judge presiding over the biggest music payola trial in 30 years threatened today to dismiss all charges against the record promoter Joseph Isgro and two other defendants after defense lawyers told him the prosecution had apparently withheld a key document in the case.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Comedy, Heartbreak And Offbeat Casting On London Stages
description: Two summers ago the Gate Theater, Dublin, jolted New York audiences with the festering, dark-brewed, tragic reality of its ''Juno and the Paycock,'' a brief Broadway tenant courtesy of the New York International Festival of the Arts. Now the Gate is offering Londoners an equivalent thrill with its visiting production of ''The Three Sisters'': a stunning collaboration between Ireland's acting dynasty -Cyril Cusack and a trio of his daughters - and the English director Adrian Noble, the newly named artistic leader of the Royal Shakespeare Company. This is Chekhov in the true Russian manner - soulful, gloomy, neurotic, inward - as it could be performed only by a cast schooled in the poetic delicacy of the Irish.

title: NO U.S. HOSTAGES RELEASED
description: After weeks of deliberations, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries authorized its key oil producers today to begin pumping all the oil they can immediately, averting a feared shortage that has sent prices surging on world markets.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A TODDLER is sitting alone in a psychology laboratory with a hidden game, and she has a problem. Should she peek at the game even though the adult told her not to? And if she does peek, and if the adult asks, should she admit her transgression or tell a lie?

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline in some editions on Tuesday about Ozel Tendzin misstated his affiliation with Tibetan Buddhists. Mr. Tendzin was the leader of the Vajradhatu International Buddhist Church, a Tibetan Buddhist sect in Boulder, Colo.; the Dalai Lama is the head of Tibetan Buddhists.

title: Albanian Protest Broken Up in Yugoslavia
description: Riot policemen used clubs and tear gas today to disperse thousands of ethnic Albanians awaiting a United States Congressional delegation to complain about human rights abuses.

title: Accounts
description: * Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., to J. Walter Thompson, New York, for their new Medi-Flu flu reliever. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Metro Datelines;   Suspension Is Lifted For a Trauma Ward
description: The Emergency Medical Service began taking trauma patients to the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center again yesterday, ending a five-day suspension.

title: Phillies Sign Dykstra
description: The Philadelphia Phillies and the center fielder Len Dykstra agreed yesterday to a three-year contract. Financial terms were undisclosed and the deal includes a fourth year at the club's option. Dykstra, the National League's leading hitter at .340, could have become a free agent at the end of the season. (AP)

title: Washington at Work;   Political Lifeguard at the Justice Dept.
description: Being second in command at the Justice Department under Dick Thornburgh has proved a high-risk career choice. But William P. Barr, the Attorney General's third appointee to the post, seems to be settling in. His daunting task: to turn around one of the Bush Administration's more troubled departments.

title: People
description: * Jeffrey Soinski has joined Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., New York, as vice president and management supervisor. Margot Pitlor has joined as an account executive.

title: West German Inflation
description: Soaring oil prices pushed West Germany's inflation higher in August, but economists said the rate for the year could still be kept near the 3 percent level. The Federal Statistics Office said today that West Germany's cost of living rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, for a rise of 2.9 percent over the last 12 months. It was the highest year-on-year rise since December 1989, when prices rose 3 percent.

title: Merged Bank Sets Officers
description: The Citizens and Southern Corporation of Atlanta and the Sovran Financial Corporation of Norfolk, Va., which plan a merger on Saturday that will create the nation's 13th-largest bank, have named a management team for the new company.

title: Refco Settles Federal Charge
description: Refco Inc., a Chicago-based commodities broker, today settled Federal disciplinary charges that one of its floor brokers had aided a customer's violation of the speculative limits in pork belly futures for more than a year beginning in June 1988.

title: A Long, Hot Day at the Hilton as Fire Cuts Power
description: A smoky electrical fire in the basement of the New York Hilton, the city's largest hotel, forced a power shutdown at the 45-story building for much of yesterday.

title: Phil Seelig's Wounded Pride
description: Now more than ever, New York City's jails need well-motivated guards; as recent events demonstrate, a collapse of their morale could prove as dangerous to the public as a collapse of a jail's walls. That's a point city officials easily overlook. And it doesn't help when the head of the guards' union ignores it as well.

title: Yankees Capture Fourth Straight
description: Their winning streaks have been so rare and so sporadic this summer that in times like these, when the Yankees are finally playing well in their tiresome season, they are enjoying the luxury of looking forward.

title: Oil Drilling Tests in Alaska Refuge Are Urged
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said on Tuesday that the drilling of test wells in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge should be considered in response to the situation in the Middle East.

title: INSIDE
description: Consumer Confidence Down

title: Retrain New York Transit Officers to Use the Guns They Have
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: A ceremony at Euston train station in London yesterday marked the official departure of the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet Company from London and its reincarnation as the Birmingham Royal Ballet.

title: 5,000 Positions To Be Cut at Volvo
description: The Swedish car maker Volvo said it would cut 5,000 jobs this year and next because profits in the first six months of 1990 have declined by half. The company has already dropped 1,000 employees in the car and truck sector this year and plans to reduce the work force by another 4,000 through 1991. Most of the cuts will be made in Sweden.

title: A's Acquire McGee
description: The Oakland Athletics, in their second big deal of the day yesterday, acquired the outfielder Willie McGee - the National League's second-leading hitter - from the St. Louis Cardinals for the outfielder Felix Jose and two minor leaguers. McGee, 31, was batting .335 for the Cardinals. He was eligible for free agency at the end of the season and indicated he would not stay in St. Louis. Earlier in the day, the Athletics obtained Harold Baines from Texas. (AP)

title: Q&A
description: Wax Buildup on Tile

title: A Challenge In Cambodia
description: The agreement of the five permanent members of the United Nations on the essentials of a political settlement of the Cambodian conflict may finally force the warring Cambodian factions to negotiate seriously and confront the real risks of peace.

title: Review/Opera;   American Premiere of Janacek's 'House of the Dead'
description: The new production of Leos Janacek's ''From the House of the Dead,'' unveiled on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, amounts to Christopher Keene's calling card as the new general director of the New York City Opera. It is the first new production - indeed, the first opera - he has conducted since he took over the company in March 1989.

title: Dow Rises 17.58 Points on Low Volume
description: The stock market continued to gain yesterday as crude oil prices slid further, bond prices advanced and the danger of war with Iraq seemed increasingly distant.

title: Personal Health
description: If you frequent a health club, you probably don't expect to see an 80-year-old person pumping iron or working out on a nearby machine. But based on the results of recent studies involving people up to the age of 96, strength training is likely to become increasingly popular among old and very old Americans.

title: Jesse Jackson Arrives in Iraq
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived in Baghdad today to interview the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, for a syndicated American television program. The Iraqi press agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Mr. Jackson was met at Baghdad airport by Foreign Ministry officials. Mr. Jackson has said that he is making the trip as a journalist and that he will not be involved in any diplomatic negotiations.

title: Sales of New Homes Fell 2.3% in July
description: New-home sales fell 2.3 percent in July, the fifth drop in seven months, the Government said today, and industry observers predicted rising mortgage rates linked to the Middle East crisis would compound the decline in the months ahead.

title: U.S. Forming a Central Data Bank to Identify Incompetent Doctors
description: Beginning Saturday, for the first time the United States will have a single data base to identify incompetent doctors, dentists and other licensed health practitioners.

title: ISRAELIS WORRIED BY U.S. RESTRAINT
description: As the Persian Gulf crisis drags on, Israelis are coming to the conclusion that the United States wants a political solution and is not looking for a military confrontation with Saddam Hussein. That has caused many Israeli politicians, academic experts and ordinary citizens to grow restive, nervous and in some cases angry.

title: CLUES FOLLOWED ON FLORIDA KILLER
description: The police said today that they believed a ''shrewd, methodical'' killer was behind a string of five slayings that has traumatized this university town.

title: California Closer to Its First Execution Since 1967
description: California moved closer to its first execution in nearly a quarter of a century today when a divided Federal appeals court upheld the death sentence of Robert Alton Harris, who was hours away from execution at San Quentin prison last April when his sentence was stayed.

title: Enshrined: a Common Man of the Century
description: LEAD: While some men of note anticipate having museums, other men who are footnotes have museums. Like Presidents who collect personal memorabilia for their honorary libraries, Christian C. Sanderson saved the meaningful bits and scraps of his life for his museum, two rooms at the front of his old gray house on a winding country road in the bucolic Brandywine

title: Robert H. Brooks; Theatrical Agent, 34
description: Robert H. Brooks, a theatrical booking agent, died on Monday in a helicopter crash in East Troy, Wis., which killed the blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughn and three others. He was 34 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Dispute Over Fights
description: Bill White, the National League president, yesterday disputed Joe West's interpretation of what White said about breaking up player fights and the umpire's handling of an ejection.

title: Funds Show Mixed Yields
description: Yields of tax-exempts and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: It Takes More Than Medication to Heal Minds;   Electroshock's Damage
description: To the Editor:

title: LeRoy Makepeace; Diplomat, 75
description: LeRoy Makepeace, a career Foreign Service officer, died Friday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 75 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Foreign Genes Are Inserted In Humans, a Study Reports
description: The first effort to insert foreign genes into human patients has succeeded on every possible front, researchers say in a new report.

title: Talbert Abrams Dies; Aerial Pioneer Was 95
description: Talbert Abrams, an aviation pioneer and the developer of aerial mapping, died Saturday at a nursing home in Lansing, Mich. He was 95 years old and lived in Lansing.

title: Pentagon Orders Big Cuts To Free Money for the Crisis
description: The Pentagon has ordered worldwide spending cuts in supplies, maintenance, travel and training to free money to help pay for the Persian Gulf military operation, Defense Department officials said today.

title: No Planes, No Edberg, But About the Blimp . . .
description: It's so quiet out there on the courts that Martina Navratilova hears every syllable the umpire utters, Monica Seles has felt it incumbent upon her to smother her grunts, and Goran Ivanisevic has discovered that it's the odor of the hamburgers and hot dogs sizzling atop the vendors' grills that really distracts him from playing his best tennis.

title: Insider Charges Are Settled
description: Three former employees of MAI Basic Four Inc. today settled Federal insider trading charges accusing them of buying Prime Computer Inc. securities after they learned that MAI Basic was planning to make a hostile bid for Prime in the fall of 1988.

title: John J. Snodgrass, 70; Began Radiology Unit
description: John J. Snodgrass, founding director of the Division of Radiology at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., died at the hospital on Monday. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: In Pakistan, Martial Law Waits to Return
description: To the Editor:

title: 3,000 Are Called to Jury Duty
description: Three thousand people have been called as prospective jurors for the September trial of a man charged in the slayings of 11 women. The man, Arthur J. Shawcross, 45 years old, will be tried in Monroe County in the murders of 10 of the women. He faces a second trial in neighboring Wayne County in the 11th slaying.

title: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Splits Account Team
description: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Detroit has split its account management team into two parts. One group will serve the agency's primary client, Chrysler Jeep Eagle. The other will try to find new accounts.

title: F.D.I.C. Should Name Bank Board Trustees
description: To the Editor:

title: For Democrats, California Dreamin'
description: LEAD: The candidate stood, wind-battered, outside Gate No. 1 of the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in January 1988. 6:30 A.M. Still dark. Wind-chill factor: minus 25. ''Here's a new idea,'' Gary Hart said, shivering in a borrowed parka. ''The New Hampshire primary in July.''

title: Britain to Allow Appeal for 6 Convicted of 1974 Pub Murders
description: The British Government said today that it would send to the Court of Appeal the case of six men who were convicted of murdering 21 people in the bombings of two pubs in Birmingham, England, in 1974.

title: Dickerson Suspended And Fined by Colts
description: Eric Dickerson will miss the first six games of the National Football League season after the Indianapolis Colts placed him on one of the league's reserve lists yesterday.

title: Karen Finley Quits as Host Of Awards Show
description: Karen Finley, a performance artist who was recently denied a grant by the National Endowment for the Arts, has withdrawn as a host of this year's Bessie Awards ceremony because one of the event's sponsors is a supporter of Senator Jesse Helms.

title: Oil Drops Nearly $2 A Barrel
description: Oil prices fell sharply yesterday as traders responded to the decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to allow an immediate increase in oil production, as well as to reduced fears of war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Arab-Americans Faulting Bush on Hostility
description: Leaders of the largest Arab-American civil rights group said today that President Bush and other members of the Administration had inadvertently fostered an atmosphere of animosity toward Americans of Arab descent by using heated oratory directed at President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Japan Promises Grants and Food, But Lack of Arms Aid Nettles U.S.
description: Japan unveiled a long-awaited program on Wednesday night to help finance the international effort against Iraq, but the package drew unusual criticism from American officials for the absence of direct tangible aid to the military buildup in the Persian Gulf.

title: Canada Bank Cuts Rate
description: The Bank of Montreal said today that it would cut its prime rate to 14 percent from 14.25 percent, effective on Thursday. The bank is the first leading Canadian bank to cut its prime from the 14.25 percent level.

title: Japanese Wary Of Toys 'R' Us
description: Eleven Japanese toy retailers have formed an association to try to protect domestic toy stores from competition by Toys ''R'' Us.

title: The Hero of Saratoga? Benedict Arnold
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hate Conference
description: Somewhere in the world may be another person who could have conceived and organized this extraordinary Oslo conference, but the name does not come to mind.

title: Gilbert Lesser, 55, Poster Designer For Plays and Promotion Director
description: Gilbert Lesser, a designer of theater posters and a former promotion director for Life magazine, died on Tuesday at the Milstein Hospital of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Shearson Unit Seeks Agency
description: Lehman Brothers, a unit of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., is searching for an agency to handle its print advertising account, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Metro Datelines;   Bail Is Set for Man In Slaying of Girl, 9
description: A judge yesterday set bail for a former professional baseball player, prompting an emotional outburst from the family of the 9-year-old girl he is accused of killing with a stray bullet.

title: A Chip Patent Is Granted That May Rewrite History
description: In a shock to the computer industry, a virtually unknown California inventor has been issued a patent that he says covers a fundamental development of the computer revolution - the microprocessor.

title: Marilyn Quayle Is Rescued From River in Grand Canyon
description: Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, fell into the Colorado River during a rafting expedition through the Grand Canyon last weekend, a park spokesman said today. Mrs. Quayle was thrown from the raft when it was in Lava Falls rapids, said Chuck Lundy, a spokesman for Grand Canyon National Park.

title: Matsushita-Tandy Venture Reported
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan and the Tandy Corporation of Fort Worth will produce personal computers at a Texas plant under a joint venture, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday. The size of the planned investment was not known, the newspaper said.

title: Grace Eddy Peabody; Artist, 66
description: Grace Eddy Peabody, an abstract artist, died on Aug. 19 at her home in San Francisco, where she had lived for the last 14 years. She was 66 years old. Mrs. Peabody died of cancer, her son, Reese, said. She was a native of West Hartford, Conn. She graduated from Mount Vernon Seminary in Washington and studied at the Museum of Modern Art. She was known for her large abstract oils, one of which is in the permanent collection of the National Museum for Women in the Arts in Washington.

title: Venezuela's New Oil Prominence
description: The lines of oil wells that stretch across Lake Maracaibo here are pumping higher volumes of crude to help offset the shortage caused by the embargo of oil from Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Mariners Sign Griffey
description: Ken Griffey was signed by the Seattle Mariners yesterday, joining Ken Jr. to become the first father and son to play on the same major league team. Last year, the Griffeys became the first father and son to play in the major leagues at the same time.

title: Kansas Utility Bid May Be Sweetened
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said in a letter to the chairman of the Kansas Gas and Electric Company that it would like to discuss its merger proposal and that it would be willing to consider adjustments to its offer. On July 23, Kansas City Power began a tender offer worth $857 million in cash for all Kansas Gas shares at $27 a share.

title: CBS Names Head for TV Stations
description: CBS yesterday named Johnathan Rodgers president of its television stations division, replacing Eric W. Ober, who was named president of CBS News last week.

title: Colorado Pianist, 20, Is Competition Winner
description: Christopher Taylor, a 20-year-old pianist from Boulder, Colo., has won first prize in the 1990 University of Maryland International William Kapell Piano Competition, which ended in July. His award includes $20,000 in cash and a recital in November at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Adultery Arrests Rise To 4 in Connecticut
description: Three more arrests have been made in southeastern Connecticut under the state's rarely enforced adultery law, bringing the total since June to four.

title: Cleanup Begins At Tornado Site Where 25 Died
description: When the black wind stopped howling and the terrible roar faded, the first thing Bernice Lea noticed, as she huddled inside her bedroom, was the rain, cold and hard on her back. She looked up and saw that the roof and most of the walls of her house were gone.

title: Guerrilla Bands in Kuwait Killed Hundreds, a U.S. Official Asserts
description: Small guerrilla bands in Kuwait have killed or wounded ''a couple hundred'' Iraqi troops and have destroyed a handful of tanks and more than 20 trucks and small military vehicles, a United States Government official says.

title: Peace Dividend: Casualty in the Gulf?
description: The Persian Gulf crisis is giving members of Congress second thoughts about making major cuts in military spending for the next fiscal year and has muted but not silenced the hopeful talk of a peace dividend from the end of the cold war.

title: Workers, Hail!
description: WEATHEREND, a company in Rockland, Me., that makes outdoor furniture, is holding an art exhibition called ''Construction - Works.''

title: Slow Back-to-School Sales Hurting U.S. Retailers
description: Mired in a slow back-to-school season, America's biggest retailers have expressed deep concern that the Middle East crisis will hurt their business even further in the weeks heading into the all-important Christmas season.

title: Elster Sidelined For Rest Of Season
description: Kevin Elster, one of the National League's premier defensive shortstops, whose absence because of injury has provoked the Mets into an array of dramatic lineup shuffles, will undergo surgery to repair his right shoulder next week and be lost for the season.

title: Not All Country Houses Are in Britain, You Know
description: SO much attention has been paid to the English country house that the American country house heritage may seem insignificant by comparison. But according to two new books published by Yale University Press - ''The American Country House'' ($55) by Clive Aslet and ''The Architect and the American Country House'' ($55) by Mark Alan Hewitt - the American country house has a glamorous and important history all its own.

title: In New York, Low Count Draws Chorus of Criticism
description: Preliminary 1990 census figures show New York City with a population of 7,033,179, significantly smaller than the Census Bureau estimated in 1988 and at least 600,000 people short of estimates by city planners and at least one outside expert.

title: Kickoff Classic May Hold Answers
description: After a cross-country journey that has little to do with their traditional goal of a Pacific-10 Conference championship, will the Southern California Trojans show that they want to be here?

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: VIRTUALLY all building codes now require that the outlets in new and remodeled kitchens, bathrooms and garages be protected by a ground-fault circuit interrupter, usually called a G.F.C.I. or G.F.I. This protection is recommended for all outlets in damp locations. A G.F.C.I. protects you from shock by shutting off the power to an outlet when it detects a leak in the flow of electricity, as when a faulty appliance or cord touches a wet floor.

title: Correction Group Asks Ouster of Union Chief
description: An organization of black New York City correction officers announced yesterday that it would begin a petition and picketing drive aimed at forcing Phil Seelig, the president of the officers' union, out of office.

title: Raymond St. Jacques, an Actor Of TV and Films, Is Dead at 60
description: Raymond St. Jacques, an actor who helped lower racial barriers for blacks in television and films, died Monday in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 60 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: F. Sanford Cutler; Episcopal Priest, 68
description: The Rev. F. Sanford Cutler, an Episcopal priest who was active in the peace and women's rights movements died on Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Leading Indicators Unchanged
description: The Government's main guide for forecasting the direction of the economy was unchanged in July from June, the Commerce Department said today, and economists predicted it would soon point downward because of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Calendar: Folk Art and Wearable Art
description: Long Island Show House, Lot 1, Redcoats Lane, North Haven Point off Sunset Beach Road, Sag Harbor; (212) 551-7028.

title: PROTESTS IN SYRIA REPORTED HALTED
description: Syrian Army units may have killed dozens of people in several Syrian towns who were demonstrating in support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and against Syrian involvement in the allied military force based in Saudi Arabia, the British Broadcasting Corporation and The Associated Press reported today.

title: Transit Agency Seeking To Buy Grand Central
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is trying to smooth the way for development of a huge office tower on Madison Avenue as a necessary first step in its efforts to buy Grand Central Terminal and begin a $400 million renovation of the mid-Manhattan landmark.

title: Treasury Bonds Post Solid Gains
description: Interest rates fell and the price of Treasury securities rose yesterday, with the benchmark long bond jumping more than a point. The gains were fueled by a drop in oil prices and rising hopes among market participants that the Federal Reserve Board may move to ease short-term interest rates soon, perhaps by the end of the week.

title: THE U.N.'S WATERSHED: A SPECIAL REPORT:   CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Putting Teeth in an Embargo: How U.S. Convinced the U.N.
description: The phone call to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Aug. 22 at his Wyoming ranch was not the first to interrupt his vacation, but it was one of the most important. The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, called Mr. Baker's remote mountain retreat to say Moscow was leaning toward supporting a United Nations resolution giving the world's navies the right to enforce the international trade embargo against Iraq.

title: Metro Datelines;   Boy Shot in Stomach Playing With Pistol
description: A 10-year-old boy from Utica, N.Y., was shot in the stomach yesterday in Brooklyn while he and an older boy were playing with a pistol, the police said.

title: Aquino Says She Will Negotiate Cease-Fires
description: President Corazon C. Aquino reversed a long-held policy today and said she was willing to negotiate cease-fires with Communist guerrillas and with rebel soldiers who have staged coup attempts against her.

title: KEY RATES
Mural of Christ Must Be Removed
description: A painting of a crucifixion scene that has hung on the wall of a school auditorium in upstate New York for 25 years must be taken down, a Federal judge in Syracuse ruled today.

title: Capriati's Dashing
description: Jennifer Capriati came out to play tennis Tuesday evening wearing a white shirt with polka dots as orange as pumpkins. Her short tennis skirt was also white, and with three polka dots, all on the right side. Her brown ponytail was caught up in a band, which was orange. When she prepared to serve, in the course of her first-round match against Anke Huber of West Germany in the United States Open at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Capriati slid a second ball under her skirt at the left hip. It bulged there like a polka dot pumped up, or a little pumpkin.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Oil Jolt

title: Sandy, Mutt Who Made It On Broadway, Dies at 16
description: Sandy, who overcame abuse as a puppy and was nearly put to death at a pound before achieving Broadway fame as the best friend of Little Orphan Annie and a member of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's inner circle, died in his sleep yesterday at the age of 16. The dog, a beige terrier mix, lived in Haddam, Conn., with his owner and trainer, William Berloni.

title: Energy Plan in California
description: California utility commissioners approved an incentive plan today for four state utilities to promote energy conservation.

title: Australian Bid For Newmont Unit
description: The Poseidon mining company of Australia spent $132 million this week to buy almost 20 percent of the Australian unit of the Newmont Mining Corporation of Denver, and on Tuesday it began a surprise 1-for-2 share offer for the rest of the unit.

title: Campbell Kids to Utter First Words Since 1958
description: The Campbell Soup Company is giving the Campbell Kids speaking roles in a commercial for the first time since 1958.

title: Japanese to Buy Laura Ashley Stake
description: Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. will sell a 15 percent stake in itself to a Japanese retailing group for $58.3 million. The British retailer said it would sell 35.2 million newly issued shares of its stock to the Aeon Group of Japan for $:29.9 million. The price represented a 73 percent premium over the closing price of the company's shares on Tuesday.

title: Revamping Approved, Resorts Names Officer
description: Resorts International Inc. announced yesterday that a Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Jersey had approved its plan to emerge from bankruptcy law protection. In a separate move, the company said it had named Jack O'Donnell, the former president and chief operating officer of the Trump Plaza hotel and casino in Atlantic City, as executive vice president and chief operating officer of Resorts' Atlantic City casino.

title: Moscow Journal;   More Than a Movie, It's a Whisper of Civil War
description: For months the Soviet press studiously ignored Pavel Lungin's new film, ''Taxi Blues,'' about the relationship between an alcoholic Jewish saxophone player and a bigoted Russian taxi driver.

title: $5 Million FNN Effort To Begin Next Month
description: The Financial News Network is beginning its largest advertising campaign in its nine years as a cable network.

title: Books of The Times;   Breathing Under Water in Poland
description: Breathing Under Water and Other East European Essays

title: Judge Orders Tuna Import Ban Over Dolphin Kill
description: A Federal district judge has ordered a ban on imports of tuna fish caught by five nations until they can show that they are not killing more dolphins than United States law allows.

title: Farm Exports Steady
description: The projected value of United States farm exports this year is holding steady at $40 billion despite a decline in the volume of wheat shipments, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday.

title: Allergies in Infants Are Linked to Mothers' Diets
description: Researchers exploring how and when allergies begin are finding that allergic reactions and asthma in infants are often caused by exposure to foods and tobacco smoke introduced by parents, sometimes before the babies are born.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about financial disclosures by Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the independent candidate for governor in Connecticut, misidentified his grandfather. The grandfather was not E. R. Squibb but Theodore Weicker, one of three partners who founded the Squibb Corporation.

title: Ketchum Journal;   Real Life Intrudes On Reverie Of the Past
description: Despite a preponderance of $4 million homes, espresso cafes and galleries run by people with European accents, this golden mountain community still prefers to think of itself as somewhat of an Old West geezer in need of a bath and a shot of bourbon.

title: Williams Is Bitter
description: Doug Williams, the only black quarterback to start in the Super Bowl, says that racism is still common in the National Football League.

title: Simmons Near Limit On Stake in Lockheed
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons disclosed today that he had raised his stake in Lockheed Corporation to 19.8 percent, as high as he can without triggering the company's ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Donald J. Trump misstated the portion of a $65 million bank loan package that was for interest payments on one of his casino bonds.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a biotechnology company, said Pierre Cardin, the French designer, would reacquire the worldwide rights to his fragrance trademark and brands from the company. No terms were disclosed.

title: A Gubernatorial Candidate Who Relies on Just the Facts
description: William J. Cibes Jr., the challenger in the Democratic primary for governor, was about an hour into his interview with a group of local newspaper editors when the question came. It was a long slow looper of a pitch that many politicians would have smacked clean over the fence: What was your childhood like, growing up in rural Kansas?

title: TV Weekend;   '20/20' Plumbs Depression's Depths
description: Tonight's edition of ''20/20'' at 10 on ABC is given entirely to ''Depression: Beyond the Darkness,'' a report on a still mysterious illness that takes different forms and may affect 20 million Americans a year. It's an informative hour. Through interviews with sufferers and their doctors, the program describes the main forms of therapy now being used to control an often incapacitating affliction that sometimes ends in suicide.

title: Comprehensive Care Appoints a President
description: The newly elected board of the Comprehensive Care Corporation yesterday appointed James Carmany as president and chief executive of the St. Louis-based provider of programs to treat chemical dependency.

title: Sega Commercials Take On Nintendo
description: Sega of America, a maker of video games, will begin a campaign next week that takes a hit at rival Nintendo of America.

title: Shouting Threatens to Drown Racial Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Becker Dispatches Noah With Straight-Set Victory
description: Yannick Noah left the stadium court at the United States Open yesterday with his head bowed, a meek position he has been assuming on a weekly basis this year not because he has become a devout churchgoer, but because he has become a dependable loser.

title: Behind Rikers Riots, a Message of Weakness
description: LEAD: With his comments about a ''minority Mayor'' and other ill-timed remarks, Phil Seelig, the president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, makes an attractive scapegoat in the Rikers Island mess.

title: Wayne Newton's Libel Award Against NBC Is Overturned
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a $5.2 million libel award to the singer Wayne Newton against the National Broadcasting Company, ruling that the network's news reports suggesting links between Mr. Newton and organized crime had not been shown to be deliberately or recklessly false.

title: Lag Found in Chemical Weapons Disposal
description: The Army is behind schedule and over budget in its destruction of old chemical weapons, but Congress shares blame for some of the problems, the General Accounting Office says.

title: Chile Is Planning Ceremony to Bury Allende
description: Chile will formally bury former President Salvador Allende Gossens next week in a ceremony that has revived the controversies surrounding his Government and his death in a military coup nearly 17 years ago.

title: Kodak Photo Plan
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has scheduled news conferences for Sept. 18 in New York, Tokyo and London to introduce ''a new photographic system designed to increase the use and enjoyment of pictures.'' Kodak declined to provide details. Analysts speculate Kodak may be introducing devices or methods to electronically manipulate conventional photographs. ''Kodak has been working for many years on combining conventional photos with electronic imaging,'' said Eugene Glazer of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's use of state aircraft referred incorrectly to payment for trips that are partly political or unofficial. During campaigns, his campaign committee or the State Democratic Party will pay at least half the cost on any day that involves such activity.

title: Gorbachev Dismisses One of His Top Aides In Cigarette Shortage
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union dismissed one of his top officials today, blaming him for an acute shortage of cigarettes that has caused demonstrations in Moscow and other cities.

title: Rather Was Awakened For Midnight Interview
description: Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, said yesterday that several weeks of dogged contact with Iraqi officials paid off on Wednesday night in Baghdad when an armed Iraqi soldier awakened him in his hotel room and escorted him to the presidential palace, where he interviewed President Saddam Hussein. It was the President's first interview by an American jounralist since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. [Excerpts from the interview appear on page A10.] Iraqi officials put no conditions on the interview, Mr. Rather said, other than requesting a commitment from CBS to run the nearly 90-minute interview at approximately its full length. Mr. Rather said CBS felt the entire interview would be newsworthy as long as there were no restrictions on the questions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're more than willing to bear our fair share of the burden, but we also expect others to bear their fair share.''

title: Paul P. Casamassimo, Dentist, 77
description: Dr. Paul P. Casamassimo, a retired dentist who was on the staff of the North Central Bronx Hospital for almost 50 years, died on Monday at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: Some Possibilities for Playing on Labor Day Weekend
description: Opportunities for creative non-labor in the three-state region this holiday weekend include gazing, giggling, browsing, buying, hurling, and making ice cream.

title: California Firm on Internments
description: An effort to revise what California schoolchildren are taught about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was soundly defeated Tuesday by the State Legislature.

title: As Part of a Liquidation, Morgan Sells 'Junk Bonds'
description: Morgan Stanley & Company has been selling a large number of ''junk bonds'' as part of a liquidation of a portfolio of these high-yield, high-risk securities. The selling has some traders worried that similar funds might also have to sell bonds.

title: Restaurants
description: On a tropical Monday evening in late August, when many restaurants in town are so quiet they could double as library annexes, Lola on West 22d Street resembles a Club Med social. To the background of a blues pianist, the buoyant, well-dressed crowd gets louder in direct proportion to the wine and tropical cocktails consumed.

title: Tokyo's Share of World Leadership
description: Faced with Washington's wrath, Japan stopped some of its hemming and hawing yesterday and pledged at least $1 billion for the multilateral effort in the Persian Gulf. But regrettably, Tokyo remains vague about its promises to help beleaguered front-line gulf states.

title: 2 Films Share Prize At the Festival Latino
description: ''No Futuro - Rodrigo D'' (''No Future - Rodrigo D''), a 1990 film by the Colombian director Victor Gaviria, and ''Papeles Secondarios'' (''Bit Parts''), a 1989 Cuban film directed by Orlando Rojas, shared the award for best feature film at the Festival Latino Film Awards, presented last night at the World Wide Plaza Cineplex Odeon Theater.

title: Wholesale Gasoline Price Soars
description: Wholesale gasoline prices surged yesterday, reflecting traders' concerns about low supplies and strong demand. Crude oil prices also rose, with the contract for October delivery up 85 cents a barrel, or 3.3 percent, to $26.77 on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Mullen Wins One, But Loses Another
description: Mullen Advertising Inc., Wenham, Mass., scored a victory and a loss yesterday.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Monday is Labor Day. Here are holiday schedules:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Publishing Corp., a subsidiary of American Express Co., appointed Tracey Crane-Hennessy manager of its Midwest office in Chicago.

title: Moscow's Mutt & Jeff
description: After a five-hour session this week to paper over differences, Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin appeared for 15 minutes together on Soviet television.

title: Larry Jackson, Pitcher, 59
description: Larry Jackson, who pitched for three National League teams and was named to three All-Star teams, died of cancer Tuesday. He was 59 years old.

title: U.S. Inquiry of Dumping
description: The Government decided on Wednesday to investigate whether some equipment made by Japanese electronics companies is imported at less than fair value into the United States, threatening the domestic industry. The International Trade Commission ruled that there was reasonable indication that imports of some electronic display screens used in computers and their sub-assemblies materially injure the American industry.

title: Topics of The Times;   T-Shirt Readings
description: A New Yorker who begins her day with the astrology column and spends much of it knocking on wood went out looking for omens recently. The weather was fine, too fine for anyone to be stuck in an office, and she was in search of something that would tell her to go home. She found that something. Thrice. The first omen was sighted on West 42d Street. It was a T-shirt worn by a young woman that read ''Be Happy. Don't Work.'' The second omen was also a T-shirt, also worn by a young woman and also sighted on 42d Street. This one read, ''Always put off till tomorrow what you could do today.''

title: Sutton Still Seeks Deal With DeSoto
description: The Sutton Holding Corporation, a New York investment firm, said it was still interested in acquiring DeSoto Inc., even though the company was liquidating most of its assets and distributing the proceeds to shareholders. Since July, DeSoto has sold its industrial coating and solvent business to a unit of the Union Carbide Corporation for $200 million and its consumer-paint business to the Sherwin-Williams Company for $80 million. The liquidations will leave DeSoto with only its household detergent business.

title: Shouting Threatens to Drown Racial Dialogue;   Spike Lee's Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Markets Rally After Central Bank Raises Rate
description: The financial markets here reacted positively to Thursday's increase in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, but a number of economists warned that it was unlikely to be the last such jump in Japanese interest rates because of growing inflationary pressures.

title: Pro Bono
description: * J. Walter Thompson's New York office has created a new campaign for the Council of Independent Colleges that promotes small colleges and focuses on minority students.

title: Lisa Lieb Weds David Malamed
description: Lisa Ellen Lieb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morrie Lieb of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married yesterday to David Neal Malamed, the son of Bernice Malamed of Lynbrook, L.I., and Paul Malamed of Brooklyn. Rabbi Philmore Berger performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck in Kings Point, L.I.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   More on the Gulf
description: HOSTAGES LOSE JOBS: A Texas oil company has cut off pay to the families of six of its workers who are being held hostage in the Persian Gulf. National news, page A18.

title: Latin Debt Grew in '89
description: Latin America's foreign debt climbed last year despite efforts to curb it, according to a study that says the debtor nations failed to honor $18 billion in financial obligations.

title: South African Violence: The Limits of Leadership
description: As the dead are buried after South Africa's newest convulsion of violence, the tallies of destruction have been complemented by another consideration: the fighting showed more the limits than the strengths of those contending for leadership in this country.

title: ARMENIA DISARMS A VIGILANTE GROUP
description: The new Government of Soviet Armenia said today that it had faced down and disarmed the leaders and scores of guerrillas of a vigilante group that has alarmed the republic with factional violence.

title: Factory Orders Up 1.6% in July
description: Orders to factories for manufactured goods grew 1.6 percent in July, the Government reported today. But analysts said the fluctuating performance so far this year suggested an anemic industrial economy even before the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: People
description: * Leslie Beal has been promoted to assistant media planner at Martin Williams Advertising Inc., Minneapolis.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Lillian Pickard, Press Agent, 66
description: Lillian Pickard, a theater and television press agent, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. She was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SHUTTLE COLUMBIA IS DELAYED AGAIN
description: The space agency late tonight delayed the launching of the space shuttle Columbia for at least four days to repair a broken part on its astronomical payload.

title: It's Carnival Time As New York Turns Caribbean to Dance The Weekend Away
description: EVERY Labor Day weekend, geography warps to place New York City unmistakably in the Caribbean. This weekend brings a West Indian carnival tonight through Monday in Brooklyn, featuring calypso, steel-band and reggae music; a major salsa concert on Sunday at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., and a marathon of Dominican merengue tonight at Roseland in Manhattan. All of the music shares West African roots, in songs where exhortations to party, wry sexual come-ons and sly political satire - sometimes all at once - ring out above rhythms and cross-rhythms that demand dancing.

title: Susan B. Rauch, Executive, Weds
description: Susan Buchner Rauch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Rauch of Hewlett, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Howard Epstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Epstein of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Mark Wittstein and Cantor Howard Stahl officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Stocks Fall As Trading Dries Up
description: Stocks fell yesterday in the slowest trading in three months as many investors lightened their holdings before the Labor Day weekend.

title: Umpire Case Reviewed
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent is reviewing a complaint about the National League president Bill White's criticism of the umpire Joe West.

title: 'Georgy Girl' Then and Now In Weight Watchers Spots
description: WEIGHT WATCHERS INTERNATIONAL will start a yearlong national television campaign next week for its weight-loss programs, again using its pursuasive selling tool - Lynn Redgrave.

title: Year-End Oil Shortage Predicted
description: Officials at the International Energy Agency, which represents 21 oil-consuming nations, predict that a substantial oil shortage will develop late this year. At present, however, daily worldwide demand for oil is only slightly greater than supply, despite the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude.

title: Afghan Leader Insists on Retaining Power in a Pact
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan made it clear here today that he did not see himself as a barrier to a political solution in Afghanistan and was not prepared to give up effective powers to a transitional government in Kabul.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-14

title: Father Watches Capriati Ascend
description: For all the coaches, trainers, physiotherapists, psychotherapists and other experts who travel the world in care of this tennis player or that one, few members of the entourage ever attain the profile of the dad whose offspring has suddenly exploded into the public consciousness.

title: Beijing Journal;   The Tears of the Helmsman and Other Scuttlebutt
description: Mao Zedong's image was one of half-emperor and half-god in the days when he presided as Great Helmsman of nearly one-quarter of humanity. But now it turns out that his wife could reduce him to tears.

title: Norman DeHaan, 63, Architect and Designer
description: Norman Richard DeHaan, a Chicago architect and interior designer, died at Passavant Hospital in Chicago on Aug. 24. He was 63 years old.

title: Who Stands to Lose? Political Figuring Starts
description: Because political power drains from places where population has been lost, New York City and western New York may bear the worst political consequences of the 1990 census of New York State.

title: Chronicle
description: DIANA RIGG, the British actress who rose to stardom as the karate-chopping Emma Peal in the television series ''The Avengers,'' is seeking a divorce from Archie Stirling. An Associated Press dispatch from London said her agent, Jean Diamond, declined to comment on the reasons for the decision.

title: Chronicle
description: The New York Urban League's board has appointed DENNIS M. WALCOTT as its president and chief executive. Mr. Walcott had been executive director of Harlem Dowling-Westside Center for Children and Family Services, a voluntary welfare agency. Before that he was associate director at the Greater New York Fund/United Way. He replaces Donald L. Polk, who has joined the faculty of the Suffolk Law School in Boston.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraq Moves Some Captives to Hotel In Possible Step Toward Departure
description: Iraq moved some of its hostage women and children from outlying areas where they had been placed at potential military targets into Baghdad today, apparently in preparation for their being allowed to leave the country.

title: Emmet V. Murray, Lawyer, 64
description: Emmet V. Murray, a lawyer who had retired from the Caltex Petroleum Company, died yesterday at his home in Quogue, L.I. He was 64 years old and also lived in Gulf Stream, Fla.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   In Tallying Its Gulf Costs, U.S. Counts Impatience
description: In drawing up the burden-sharing plan announced today by President Bush to help sustain United States forces in the Persian Gulf, the Administration was mindful that the American people and Congress might become impatient with a drawn-out crisis, State Department officials said.

title: Lawyers On Call For Duty In the Gulf
description: Lieut. Col. Kevin Murphy of Hanover, Mass., does not know whether his Army Reserve unit will be dispatched to the Middle East. But if it is, he will pack two items: his chemical weapons gear and a stack of international law reference texts.

title: Healthiest S.& L.'s Show Sharp Decline In Latest U.S. Data
description: Providing troubling evidence that the savings and loan deterioration is worsening, the Government reported today that even the healthiest segment of the industry has sharply declined in the last three months.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Opening With the Blues

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   13 of 21 in Arab League Meet on Avoiding a War
description: Representatives of 13 of the 21 Arab League members met here tonight to seek a way to avoid war with Iraq.

title: Giants Expect Bavaro To Be Set for Eagles
description: When Mark Bavaro underwent reconstructive surgery on his left knee in January, the Giants hoped he would be ready for the season opener 10 nights from now against the Philadelphia Eagles. At this stage, it appears the former All-Pro tight end will be ready, but perhaps not for a full game.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Barbara Lea, in the Lee Wiley Mode
description: Among New York's veteran cabaret performers, Barbara Lea is the only one of note who continues to carry on a sultry Southern-flavored pop-jazz tradition popularized by Ethel Waters and embellished by Mildred Bailey, Connee Boswell and Lee Wiley. Like her forerunners, Miss Lea is understated when it comes to dramatizing song lyrics. Although by no means inattentive to the subtleties of lyrics, she subsumes drama to an ideal of musical fluency and balance that gives much of what she sings the quality of a wistful, sexy lullaby infused with a steady current of swing.

title: Miss Muhlstock, Executive, Weds
description: Sharon Bonnie Muhlstock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Muhlstock of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Neil Sheinker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Sheinker of Montville, N.J. Rabbi Philmore Berger performed the ceremony at Temple Avodah in Oceanside, L.I.

title: Accounts
description: * Canadian Airlines to Chiat/Day/ Mojo, Toronto, with a budget of $25 million.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Jesse Jackson Meets Hussein On Gulf Crisis, Iraq Reports
description: Jesse Jackson met with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the official Iraqi News Agency reported.

title: Luigi Beccali, 83, Olympic Champion
description: Luigi Beccali, a prominent and popular long-distance runner in the 1930's and the gold medalist in the 1,500-meter run at the 1932 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, died of natural causes Tuesday in Rafaello, Italy. He was 83 years old.

title: The Talk of Flushing Meadows;   A Genteel U.S. Open? Here? Fuhgedaboudit!
description: Ever since the U.S. Open tennis tournament moved from the staid West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills to the bigger, brasher complex in Flushing Meadows 13 years ago, it has been difficult to balance the populism of the New York crowd with the gentle traditions of tennis.

title: A Stray Bullet Kills a Bronx Prosecutor
description: A 30-year-old Bronx prosecutor was shot to death yesterday as he bent over to pick up a dozen doughnuts in a bodega near the county courthouse.

title: Iraq and Jordan
description: To the Editor:

title: Florio Chooses Close Adviser as New Chief of Staff
description: Gov. Jim Florio has chosen a longtime friend and his closest political adviser for 16 years, Joseph C. Salema, as his new chief of staff, according to members of the Legislature who have been informed of the Governor's decision.

title: Brazil to Buy 2 Satellites
description: Brazil's state telecommunications company Embratel said today that it had signed a contract to purchase two satellites made by the Hughes Aircraft Company, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, for a total of $175 million. Embratel purchased the satellites from a consortium consisting of Hughes and the Brazilian company Promon Engenharia. The telecommunications satellites will be launched in 1994 on a rocket made by Arianespace of France, Embratel said. The satellites will replace two now in orbit.

title: With Figures and Lawsuits, New York Attacks Census
description: New York City began a statistical, legal and political counterattack yesterday in an effort to prove that it is much bigger than preliminary figures from the Census Bureau show.

title: KEY RATES
Bulk of $94 Million in Special Interest Gifts Goes to Incumbents
description: Always more inclined to spend money on the campaigns of proven winners than on risky newcomers, political action committees have donated 12 times as much to incumbents as to challengers in this year's Congressional elections, said a study made public today.

title: Dan Rooney Honored
description: Dan Rooney, president of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was given the Pete Rozelle Award yesterday, the second annual presentation of an award in recognition of service to the N.F.L. (AP)

title: Critic's Choice
description: Dennis O'Connor stood out in a company of fine dancers when he performed with the Merce Cunningham troupe in the late 1980's. And gifts as a dancer are among the foremost delights of Mr. O'Connor's ''Renaissance Solos,'' at the atmospheric little Gas Station theater tonight. But in this promising first independent program as a choreographer, Mr. O'Connor proves he also knows how to create dances for himself. The six solos show off his easy, lyrical line and special mix of delicacy and physical strength and control. The dances draw on Renaissance imagery, but are unmistakably contemporary, though Mr. O'Connor shows less Cunningham influence than one might expect. He also has a finely developed sense of theater, as do his four collaborators.

title: Lack of Tornado Warning Prompts Assessment of Weather Service
description: Tornadoes that killed dozens of people had already touched down in the Chicago area this week before the National Weather Service issued a warning. Now, throughout the Middle West, where spring and summer mean the season of tornadoes, people are questioning the warning system's performance.

title: Murder or an Act of War: Soldier on Trial
description: An Army soldier who served in the United States invasion of Panama went on trial this week, charged with murdering a Panamanian, in a case that raises the question of what justifies the use of deadly force in combat. It is the first such court-martial since the Vietnam War.

title: 2 Can Sue Over Something Horrible They Saw
description: The California Supreme Court will allow two passengers who witnessed a fatal accident aboard a park tramway ride to bring a civil lawsuit because they say they suffered emotional trauma from what they saw.

title: Economic Scene;   Thai Stock Boom Grinds to a Halt
description: BRASH and booming Thailand, which has been enjoying some of the world's highest growth rates in the last few years, has suffered something of a nervous breakdown this month, as the shock waves set off by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq have ricocheted around the world.

title: Shouting Threatens to Drown Racial Dialogue;   'We Were Humiliated'
description: To the Editor:

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: At the Movies
description: Spies and Presidents From the Kremlin to the White House.

title: Paper Exceeds Goal
description: The European, a weekly newspaper begun in May, exceeded the circulation guaranteed to advertisers in June and July, its publisher, Robert Maxwell, said this week. Mr. Maxwell said weekly sales were estimated to be 360,000 in June and 340,000 in July. Advertisers had been guaranteed circulation of 225,000, Mr. Maxwell said. The paper, published in London every Friday, had average sales of 153,000 on the European continent in June, Mr. Maxwell said.

title: Irwin A. Lewis, 68, A Pioneer in Polling At the Voting Booth
description: I. A. Lewis, who in the late 1960's was one of the first poll takers to predict election results by surveying voters leaving polling places, died Aug. 18 at the Glendale Adventist Medical Center in California. He was 68 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Ex-State Senator Beatty Slain in Storefront Office in Brooklyn
description: Vander L. Beatty, a flamboyant former State Senator who was convicted of vote fraud after he ran for Congress in 1982, was shot and killed yesterday in his storefront campaign headquarters in Brooklyn.

title: Thomas Scores a Touchdown But Jets Lose to Buccaneers
description: Bruce Coslet, the Jets' rookie head coach, went into tonight's final preseason game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers with some answers that needed to be questioned before putting his new team in the jeopardy of the regular season.

title: Recovery Is Seen for Texas
description: Economists are starting to see proof that the Texas economy is recovering from the deep slump caused by the collapse of oil prices in 1985, a Federal Reserve Bank official said today.

title: Perrier to Revise Its Label
description: Perrier mineral water, having weathered a storm early this year about contamination of its water, now faces another blow: bowing to government pressure, it can no longer call its water ''naturally carbonated.''

title: Corrections
description: An article and a map yesterday about the 1990 census referred incorrectly in some copies to the percentage increase in Texas' population.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraqis Playing Waiting Game, U.S. Officers in Region Say
