description: Iraq has been avoiding military actions that could provide the United States with the justification for a strike at Iraqi forces, senior American military officials say. They say that Baghdad instead appears to be trying to turn the crisis here into an endurance contest.

title: U.S. ENERGY POLICY TO STRESS OUTPUT AND CONSERVATION
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that the Bush Administration was responding to the Persian Gulf crisis with a ''short-term strategy'' for stabilizing oil markets by raising domestic production and encouraging conservation. It will not speed up a new national energy policy now being developed, he said.

title: Gerald L. Norman, 78, Administrative Judge
description: Gerald L. Norman, a retired administrative judge for the Workmen's Compensation Board, died on Sunday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 78 years old and lived in Brooklyn. He died of lung cancer, his sister, Winifred L. Norman, said. Mr. Norman served as a judge for the Workmen's Compensation Board for several years before he retired in 1980. In the 1970's, he was assistant deputy comptroller for New York City under Mayor Abraham D. Beame. He also maintained a private law practice in Brooklyn.

title: Police Cut Back Zodiac Search As Trail Cools
description: After following more than 2,000 leads, interviewing dozens of suspects and consulting astrologers, the police are tempering their approach to tracking the so-called Zodiac gunman.

title: Chronicle
description: SERGEI N. KHRUSHCHEV, son of the deposed Soviet leader, is to spend a month this fall at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University in Boston. Theresa Donovan, a spokeswoman for the school, said Mr. Khrushchev, a 55-year-old engineer, would use the libraries and talk to the faculty while conducting research for his second book, the theme of which has not been disclosed. His first, ''Khrushchev on Khrushchev'' (Little, Brown & Company), dealt with his father being forced out of power in 1964 and his last years.

title: Sri Lankans Airlift 40 Troops From Rebel-Besieged Camp
description: Government troops evacuated more than 40 wounded soldiers from a camp beseiged by Tamil rebel forces, a top military official said today.

title: One Wrong Dance Step, and It's Curtains
description: To the Editor:

title: Infant Mortality Rates in U.S. Fall to a Record Low in 1989
description: The infant mortality rate in the United States reached the lowest level ever last year, but it remains higher than those in many industrialized nations, Federal health officials reported yesterday.

title: Shackleford Waived; He'll Play in Italy
description: Charles Shackleford, who spent two troubled seasons with the Nets, was waived at his request yesterday and will play in the Italian League this season.

title: Explosions at Lebanese Barracks Kill 10 Soldiers
description: Two powerful explosions ripped through an army barracks belonging to Gen. Michel Aoun east of here overnight, killing 10 soldiers and wounding 30 others, as warring Christian factions battled with mortar guns and tanks, shattering a three-month cease-fire, security officials said.

title: The Soviet Union Has Ceased To Exist . . .
description: LEAD: A minor mystery began on this page in January with an excerpt from the journal Daedalus, signed ''Z.''

title: Don't Send a Great American Art Collection Into Austrian Exile
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Group Assails Long Customs Delays
description: International passengers at 15 airports in the United States routinely waited two hours or more to clear customs this summer, the president of an airline trade association says, calling for action by the Government to correct the problem.

title: Our Towns;   Lobster Bargain Is No Bargain For Lobstermen
description: Here on the fishing docks in this seaside village near the Rhode Island border, stacks of empty lobster traps bake like driftwood in the noonday sun. ''Must mean people are buying lobster, else they wouldn't be empty,'' said Arthur Medeiros, the captain of the Rosemary R., a 40-foot dragger that combs Fishers Island Sound and Little Narragansett Bay.

title: Centel Plans to Sell Electricity Unit
description: The Centel Corporation said it intended to sell its electricity operation, which provides service to more than 136,000 customers in Colorado and Kansas. Centel said it expected to reach an agreement to sell the business before the end of the year. The operations generated revenues of $165 million and earnings of $29 million last year.

title: Hewlett to Drop Design Operation DTL
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said its engineering applications group would phase out of the business of developing electronic design automation software, which allows the computerized design of chips and circuit boards. The group will now concentrate on developing mechanical engineering and data-management software.

title: 2 Advances Are Cited in Tracing Mystery Disorder
description: Two advances in tracing the cause of a mysterious blood and muscle disorder linked to consumption of the food supplement L-tryptophan were reported yesterday by Federal health officials.

title: The Fast Lane to Fringe-Group Status
description: LEAD: This month, with Congress out of town, the Vice President in Arizona and the Secretary of State in Wyoming, the U.S. launched its largest military operation since Vietnam. Something close to war fever descended on the capital. It ought to be possible to raise questions about these developments without intimidation and name-calling.

title: McDonald's Opens a Diner
description: The McDonald's Corporation opened a diner-style restaurant here last week that is in sharp contrast to its fast-food outlets.

title: Alleghany Raises Stake in Cyclops
description: The Alleghany Corporation, the New York-based financial services concern, has raised its stake in Cyclops Industries, the Pittsburgh-based steel company, to 10.7 percent, from 8.4 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Alleghany said it might acquire more Cyclops shares, depending upon market conditions, or it might seek to dispose of its stock.

title: Short-Term Treasuries Advance
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday. An 85-cent rise in oil prices, to $26.77 a barrel, helped persuade bond traders to sell securities, but anticipation that the Federal Reserve Board might be on the verge of easing monetary policy helped push up prices of shorter-term notes and bills.

title: Complaints About Census Mount As Many Areas See Low Counts
description: The complaints of New York City about undercounting in the 1990 census figures grew to a chorus today as officials from cities and states across the country argued that they, too, were underrepresented in the preliminary data.

title: The Great Late Show
description: It began like a paparazzi of angels popping flashbulbs in the sky: the electric storm that swept into New York City just after midnight Tuesday, one of the season's grandest shows.

title: Scientists Question Methods Used in Animal Cancer Tests
description: A growing number of experts are questioning the usefulness of the animal tests used to decide whether chemicals cause cancer. These animal tests, they say, can themselves cause conditions that give rise to malignancy.

title: Judge Says Payola Prosecutors Broke Rules
description: The Federal judge presiding over the payola and racketeering trial of the record promoter Joseph Isgro and two other defendants ruled today that the Federal prosecutors had violated rules of evidence in the case by withholding a key document from a grand jury and defense lawyers.

title: Deloitte Said to Thin Ranks
description: Deloitte & Touche, the large accounting firm, has decided to thin its partnership ranks by as many as 100 people in the next few months, executive recruiters and others who specialize in the industry said yesterday.

title: The Quarterback of the Future Is in Syracuse's Present
description: The question was never whether Marvin Graves was going to be the starting quarterback at Syracuse University, not after his displays of arm strength on the practice field and his willingness to spend hours as a student of the game. The only question was when. And the bold answer is now. Dick MacPherson, the coach of the Orangemen, selected Graves, a freshman in his second year with the Syracuse program, over Mark McDonald, a junior, as the starter against Southern California on Friday night.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Lunch Afloat

title: Fernandez Powers Mets Over Giants
description: An instant after it's unleashed, the curveball looks like it's headed for the dugout instead of the plate. An instant after that, it's over the plate and the batter is ducking for the dugout. Sid Fernandez, the pitcher for the Mets who is equipped with one of the game's most deceptive and disabling fastballs, last night had that curveball magic. He employed it with a mischievousness that approached maliciousness and carved his way through the Giants en route to a 12-2 triumph at Shea Stadium.

title: Tearful Ex-Irish Hostage Tells of Ordeal
description: Brian Keenan, the Irish teacher who was released after four and a half years as a hostage in Lebanon, urged negotiations today for the release of remaining captives in Lebanon, with whom he formed an ''enduring and unbreakable bond'' during years in tiny basement cells.

title: Edmund H. North, 79, a Writer; He Shared an Oscar for 'Patton'
description: Edmund H. North, a screenwriter who shared an Academy Award with Francis Ford Coppola in 1970 for their script for ''Patton,'' died Tuesday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Brentwood, Calif.

title: HORSE RACING: Notebook;   2 Out-of-Town Features at Belmont
description: There are two major stakes races at Belmont Park this holiday weekend, and for the first time Belmont bettors will also be able to watch and play two other important out-of-town races.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BUSH URGES ALLIES TO BEAR 'THEIR FAIR SHARE' OF COSTS OF MILITARY EFFORT IN GULF
description: Asserting that the ''shape of the post-cold-war world'' was at issue in the Persian Gulf crisis, President Bush said today that he was asking other countries to help pay the multibillion-dollar cost of military operations and economic sanctions in the region.

title: Alice Pentlarge Loeb Radio Producer, 95
description: Alice Pentlarge Loeb, a writer and producer, died Friday at her home in Baltimore. She was 95 years old.

title: Premiers of the Koreas Plan to Meet Tuesday
description: North and South Korea agreed today on details for talks between their Prime Ministers next week, clearing the way for the highest-level contact between the two Governments since 1945, a South Korean spokesman said.

title: A Critic's Eye: Choosing Favorites In Museum Collections
description: FOR quite some weeks now, visitors to New York have been asking, ''What's new in the museums?'' And what have they heard, all too often, from host and hostess alike? ''Oh, nothing much. Just the permanent collection.'' So they decide that it's quite all right to give the museums a miss.

title: 600 Resign at Saudi Aramco
description: Amid fear that war could break out in the Persian Gulf, about 600 foreign workers have resigned from Saudi Aramco, and many more are expected to leave, a Saudi executive of the company said today.

title: Jazzmobile Season Ends Tonight
description: Two exponents of hard bop, the tenor saxophonist Jimmy Heath and the trumpeter Donald Byrd, will perform in a free concert tonight closing Jazzmobile's 26th summer season of performances by outstanding jazz musicians in New York City streets.

title: New Twist In Taylor Talks
description: Negotiations over a contract extension for Lawrence Taylor stalled today, and Joe Courrege, Taylor's agent, said the Giants had given him permission to shop Taylor to other teams.

title: Why Open Can't Leave New York
description: From the top row of the tennis stadium, you absolutely cannot tell how much topspin is on the ball. But once the weather clears, you can surely see the New York skyline, shimmering a few miles to the west.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE OIL JOLT

title: Books of The Times;   The Many Similarities At the Ends of Centuries
description: Sexual Anarchy

title: Confrontation in the Gulf: Man in the News;   Iraq's Best Face: Tariq Aziz
description: If Iraq has a good face that it wants to show to the world, then Tariq Aziz is the man to do it.

title: Robert Phillips Dead; Photographer Was 64
description: Robert H. Phillips, a photographer whose work has appeared in the nation's leading magazines and is in the photography collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art, died last Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 64 years old.

title: New York Fights Back With Computer's Help
description: New York City bgan a statistical, legal and political counterattack to prove that there are more New Yorkers than the Census Bureau's figures indicates.

title: Herbert Johnson, 81; Headed Gas Company
description: Herbert C. Johnson, retired chairman and president of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island. He was 81 years old and lived in Dongan Hills, S.I.

title: B.P.'s Outlook on Oil Prices
description: The deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company said today that he expected the new OPEC production agreement to keep oil prices in the mid-$20's.

title: GERMAN VOWS LIMIT ON THE NEW FORCE
description: In a ''binding declaration'' that will be recorded in the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher of West Germany said today that a united Germany would limit its ground and air forces to 345,000.

title: Toyota to Increase Non-Auto Output
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest automobile manufacturer, plans to triple the sales of its non-automotive divisions by 1994, Masami Iwasaki, an executive vice president, said. He also said Toyota's consolidated profit had risen 27.4 percent in its latest fiscal year.

title: In the Nightlife Of Houston Street, Some New Kids On the Block
description: WITH the East Village to the north and SoHo to the south, Houston Street is downtown's great divide. As wide as a river, it has sprawling four-way intersections that dwarf the twinkling traffic lights above. The most interesting storefront is actually a lot stocked with funky secondhand furniture. At night the street has the feeling of a no man's land.

title: Suburbs Lead in New Jersey Census
description: Preliminary census figures show Essex County, where the population of Newark and East Orange dropped sharply, being surpassed as the state's most populous county by suburban Bergen County.

title: NATO Can Get Back on the Right Track
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest in Barfield, but Price Isn't Right
description: The Yankees may have been at the center of trade rumors in recent weeks, but when August turns to September at midnight Friday, they will probably still not have made a deal.

title:
Neighborhood Development;

High-Rise Condominiums for Bayside
description: LEAD: A nine-story 47-unit residential condominium called Bayside Plaza in Bayside, Queens, has set off a zoning controversy that could affect other neighborhoods in the borough.

title: On Stage
description: In the Footsteps of 'Sarafina!'

title: Japan's Price Tag on Gulf Aid Bears U.S. Imprint
description: A decision by Japan to pledge $1 billion in aid for the military buildup against Iraq came after United States officials expressed unhappiness over the original package announced by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, American and Japanese officials said today.

title: Police Kill Suspect in a West Side Subway
description: One of three armed men who led the police on a car chase through the Upper West Side of Manhattan was shot and killed last night by officers while trying to flee into a subway tunnel, the police said.

title: All-Stravinsky Concert
description: Paul Zukofsky will conduct musicians from the Juilliard School in Stravinsky's ''Fanfare for a New Theater'' (1964), ''Epitaphium'' (1959), ''Orpheus'' (1948) and Symphony in C (1940) at the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West 54th Street, tonight at 7:30. The program will be repeated tomorrow evening at 7:30. Admission is free. Information: 708-9850.

title: These Boycotts Are Racist, and Wrong
description: When Mayor David Dinkins of New York appointed a commission in April to investigate a black boycott of two Korean grocery stores in Brooklyn's Flatbush section, cynics suggested the move was merely a device to diffuse responsibility for an intolerable display of racism. The commission's report, issued yesterday, makes even the cynics look starry-eyed.

title: Iraq's Best Face: Tariq Aziz
description: If Iraq has a good face that it wants to show to the world, then Tariq Aziz is the man to do it.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Mets Scramble to Assemble Contender
description: Mel Stottlemyre, uncomfortable in trying to be both diplomatic and enthusiastic, stood on the steps of the dugout at Shea Stadium yesterday and answered one awkward question after another.

title: Dr. John K. Frost, 68, Researcher in Lung Cancer
description: Dr. John K. Frost, a physician and researcher who specialized in early detection and diagnosis of lung cancer, died on Wednesday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 68 years old and lived in Brooklandville, Md.

title: Newmont to Offer Stock; Hanson Seeks to Cut Stake
description: In a move to take advantage of the current boom in the gold industry, the Newmont Mining Corporation, the large gold mining concern that is 49 percent owned by Hanson P.L.C. of Britain, said yesterday that it plans to sell 3.6 million new common shares in a public offering.

title: Reduction In Gains Tax Is Questioned
description: A reduction in the Federal capital gains tax ''could not be counted on'' to increase American economic growth significantly, the Congressional Budget Office said today.

title: Drug Is Found to Delay Progression of AIDS
description: New results from tests of an AIDS drug, DDI, show that it continues to protect some patients from progression to AIDS for 15 months or more, and that most of its toxic effects can be avoided, said a study released today.

title: LAW: At the Bar;   The short life and long legacy of an unsung, underpaid defender of New York's have-nots.
description: To some, the measure of a man's life is the length of his obituary. By that standard, Jack Lipson's legacy, like his life, was short. When he died of a heart attack last November at 45 years old, he rated only a few column inches of print.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: TOMORROW

title: Allison K. Sands Weds J. E. Tamis
description: Allison Kendall Sands, a daughter of Adrienne Sands of New York and Bruce A. Sands of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Evan Tamis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford H. Tamis of Bedford, N.Y. Rabbi Alvin Wainhouse performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   THATCHER WARNS EUROPE OVER GULF
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that Europeans were in danger of losing the global military protection of the United States unless they took a broader view of their security interests than they have in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: DeWitt Stetten Is Dead at 81; Top Biochemist
description: DeWitt Stetten Jr., a biochemist and former deputy director of the National Institutes of Health who in the 1970's headed a committee that drafted guidelines on genetic engineering, died Tuesday at the Fernwood Nursing Center in Bethesda, Md. He was 81 years old.

title: Service Unit For Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation today formed a new consulting services business aimed at helping large corporate customers build complex computing systems using its products.

title: Results Plus
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Hynes Criticized in Report on Boycott
description: A committee appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins to investigate the bitter black-led boycott of two Korean-owned grocery stores in Brooklyn released its final report yesterday and criticized the Brooklyn District Attorney for moving too slowly in the emotionally charged case.

title: Washington Talk;   Fiscal Indecision Makes Retirement Look Better
description: The Federal Government is an adroit procrastinator, ever ready to postpone such routine chores as balancing the budget. If Uncle Sam saw a therapist, he would surely be told that the habit is self-destructive.

title: The Rich A's Get Even Richer
description: It doesn't seem fair.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Soviets Issue Their First Criticism Of American Presence in the Gulf
description: After three weeks of quietly tolerating the buildup of United States military forces in the Persian Gulf, Soviet officials sharply challenged the American presence today and questioned whether it might be intended as a permanent foothold in the region.

title: California Measure For Earlier Primary Is Raising Questions
description: A hitch has emerged that might derail plans for an early Presidential primary in California, despite the support of both national political parties and the agreement of California's legislative leadership and Gov. George Deukmejian.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Hussein on Crisis in Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, conducted Wednesday in Baghdad by Dan Rather of CBS News, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Plaza Report Is Denied
description: The Trump Organization denied yesterday that the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan was being looked at by prospective buyers and might be sold within several months. But a person close to the organization repeated earlier statements that potential buyers had been shown the property.

title: Gannett Names Head Of Merged Divisions
description: Gary Watson was named yesterday as president of a newly consolidated newspaper group at the Gannett Company, effective Oct. 1.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds decreased $542.2 million, to $407.45 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 162 institutional funds decreased by $772.5 million, to $98.7 billion. The assets of the 253 general-purpose funds were up by $931.9 million, to $143.38 billion. The 105 broker-dealer funds decreased by $701.6 million, to $165.37 billion.

title: Bargemusic: Brooklyn's Floating Concert Site
description: ''Actually, we're practicing great economy of motion here,'' said Olga Bloom, the founder of Bargemusic Ltd. Since 1977, Mrs. Bloom has been presenting weekly concerts in the refurbished coffee barge that she transformed into a floating concert hall on the Brooklyn side of the East River, near the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: LaPoint Throws Away Streak
description: Things had gone so well for the Yankees that they almost could not have expected this: a rough night, an end to their winning streak, two errant throws by Dave LaPoint and a sudden lack of offense.

title: Mohawk-Canada Accord Collapses
description: An agreement between Mohawk Indians and the national and Quebec Governments to dismantle barricades across a main bridge in Montreal fell apart today as Indian leaders complained of continued harassment by the police.

title: Loss of Paychecks From Kuwait Makes Families Hostages of Crisis
description: Saying the Persian Gulf conflict has eliminated its only source of income, a Texas company has cut off paychecks to the families of six oil workers who are hostages of the Iraqi Government.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Clemens Captures 20th As Sox Score 7 in 9th
description: Roger Clemens became a 20-game winner tonight for the third time as the Boston Red Sox scored seven runs in the ninth inning and beat the Cleveland Indians, 9-2, for their seventh consecutive victory.

title: Goodyear Layoffs
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it was cutting production and laying off a total of about 800 workers at three North American plants. The company attributed the moves to a sluggish market for cars and a desire for balanced inventory levels. Goodyear said that its plants in Union City, Tenn., and Valleyfield, Quebec, would lay off 270 and 530 employees, respectively, and that production at its operation in Danville, Va., would be reduced for a week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr.'s comments on the Church Universal and Triumphant referred incorrectly to its bomb shelters in a mountainside in Montana. The shelters are not known to be stocked with automatic weapons.

title: Romanian Leader Is Seeking Fall Visit With Bush
description: Prime Minister Petre Roman wants very much to come to Washington this autumn and has let the Bush Administration know of this desire. But so far, the Romanian official has received no positive response.

title: Market Place;   Fund Investors Remain Steadfast
description: THE Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and the subsequent plunge in stock market prices, drew a surprisingly muted reaction from mutual fund investors, several mutual fund companies said yesterday. Some managers said investors even stepped up their purchases of stock funds.

title: Topics of The Times;   A Shield Against Thieves
description: Last year Americans reported 1.5 million cars stolen, a startling 42 percent increase since 1985. An expanding anti-theft program, pioneered in New York City, now offers car owners inexpensive protection against this epidemic.

title: Review/Art;   Was It a Love for TV? Or the TV Repairman?
description: Since its infancy in the late 1960's, video art has had to contend with a contradiction. As art, it aspires to be taken seriously, but as a relative of television it needs to entertain. This may explain why some of the most memorable examples of early video art - William Wegman's tapes of his dog's deadpan performances, Vito Acconci's risque monologues - use humor as an esthetic device.

title: Rev. Allan J. Burry, Methodist Official, 56
description: The Rev. Allan J. Burry, a Methodist minister and an official with the campus ministry section of the United Methodist Church, died Tuesday at his home in Nashville, Tenn. He was 56 years old.

title: Bessie Awards to Proceed Despite Loss of a Co-Host
description: Dance Theater Workshop announced yesterday that it would hold its seventh annual Bessie Awards ceremony as planned, despite the withdrawal of Karen Finley as a host.

title: Auctions
description: When office workers dunk a lonely tea bag in a paper cup or a ceramic mug of hot water, they are participating in a tradition that modern life has reduced to the barest essentials. In the good old days, especially in 18th- and 19th-century England at the high end of the social scale, afternoon tea was a ritual of considerable substance and extensive accessories. This should be confirmed at Christie's in New York on Sept. 14, when the Terence J. Fox Collection of tea equipage goes on view before its auction on Sept. 17 at 2 P.M.

title: Rimington Waived
description: The Philadelphia Eagles yesterday waived Dave Rimington, an eight-year center who was a two-time Outland Trophy winner at Nebraska and a first-round draft pick by the Bengals in 1983. Cincinnati waived him during the 1988 preseason, after which he was signed by the Eagles. He started every game in 1988, but he started just one regular-season game last season. (AP)

title: A Brash Deal Maker And Its Uncertain Bets
description: Picture a company with a patchwork of ownership interests in assets collectively worth $20 billion, assets that range from unglamorous textile and paper mills to trophy holdings like the Seattle Mariners major league baseball team. Just when some of those investments are due to be turned into cash, unrest in the Middle East sends oil prices soaring and threatens to usher in a recession. As a result, the businesses, many of which are cyclical, face tremendous uncertainty, especially in light of their heavy debt loads.

title: Timing Adjusted
description: The National Football League, upon determining that the changes made to shorten the length of games had gone too far, yesterday announced a modification of the timing procedure after kickoffs.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Excerpts From President's News Conference on Gulf Crisis
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington today, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Brazil Stops Debt Interest
description: The president of Brazil's central bank announced today that the country would not make any payment this year on overdue interest owed on its $114 billion foreign debt, the largest in the developing world.

title: Loss on Campeau Loan
description: The National Bank of Canada said today that it had written off an $80 million loan to Robert Campeau's private company, with the provision for the loss split equally between the bank's third and fourth quarters.

title: Shouting Threatens to Drown Racial Dialogue;   Fear Doesn't Go Away
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Shuttle Delayed Again

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Dizzy Gillespie's Be-Bop

title: GIFTS FROM S.& L. NOW SEEN AS CURSE
description: In the heyday of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, its officials and major borrowers contributed more than $1 million to politicians in both parties. Now officeholders and national Republican and Democratic officials are looking for a way to get rid of the money, which they regard as a curse.

title: Patz Suspect Arraigned In Pennsylvania Case
description: A man considered by officials in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan to be a prime suspect in the disappearance of Etan Patz, pleaded not guilty yesterday to two charges of child molestation in Pennsylvania.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the National Endowment for the Arts misstated the origin of an anti-obscenity pledge required by the agency from grant recipients. John E. Frohnmayer, the endowment chairman, instituted it last year after Congress amended the endowment's appropriation to prohibit Federal support for art considered obscene.
